0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19248/homepage_large.2d1608a8.jpg|Mind Control|31307.0|Uncle Acid and the Deadbeats|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rise Above']|2013-05-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:00.518138|"

Do we really have the space for another retro-metal act from the opposite side of the Atlantic? Witchcraft kicked things off with their worship of 70s Pentagram and Black Sabbath's self-titled. Graveyard became the Swedish representatives when Witchcraft wasn't all that hip anymore. Kadavar are leading the German front. The Devil's Blood made “occult rock” the new thing for overly discerning metal listeners to hate. British unit Uncle Acid and the Deadbeats think there's room for one more. Mind Control
column2: their latest
column3: almost makes the case.

column1: Uncle Acid and the Deadbeats have clear influences from the heavier side of 1970s rock
column2: but they don't feel like a band from that time. Take 70s Pentagram's core guitar sound
column3: meld it with the foreboding gloom of their 80s work
column4: and you've got an idea of what the Deadbeats are going for. The guitars have a smokey
column5: hypnotic murk to them
column6: slathered over Uncle Acid's snaky vocals. Not that it stops “Evil Love” from being a bouncy romp
column7: or opener “Mt. Abraxis” from dooming out gloriously. They also play up their psych edge more than their contemporaries-- not by being a garage rock band that cranks up the reverb
column8: but through their disorienting production and arrangements. Mind Control take a turn for the mellow on its second half
column9: bringing their psych influences into prominence. “Follow the Leader” is the most subdued number here
column10: with marimbas accentuating soft feedback
column11: while “Devil's Work”'s heavy
column12: plodding intro builds up into a dark dirge. If modern sludge bands have ruined that idea for you
column13: take comfort in that Uncle Acid vocals really add to the slow banging.

column1: Most of the songs on Mind Control are worth a few spins
column2: but nothing on here quite matches “I'll Cut You Down” from Uncle Acid's 2011 album Bloodlust. Ghost mostly succeeds at sex appeal through menace
column3: but with “Cut”
column4: Uncle Acid beat the ghouls at their own game. The venomous declaration
column5: “I was born a wicked man
column6: no hopes or dreams/ I get my kicks from torturing and screams/ I lust for women's blood
column7: and their evil ways/ I twist my words to what the good book says” becomes even more sinister with the song's foot-stomping
column8: head-bobbing power. “Poison Apple”
column9: released as a single in March
column10: comes the closest to besting “Cut”. Bloodlust was about murder
column11: frenzy
column12: and ids running wild
column13: while Control is about seductive coercion. Not exactly subtle
column14: but most heavy music isn't and probably shouldn't be. It makes sense not from just a lyrical standpoint but also musically
column15: as Bloodlust had a harder sound to compliment those lyrics.

column1: “Valley of the Dolls” is where Control loses its ability to truly stand above
column2: dragging on with no real purpose. It's the only bad song on the whole record
column3: but even just one lapse can throw off the vibe. Control almost shows real signs of vitality in a necrophillic genre. Still
column4: Black Sabbath tickets start at 70 bucks and Bobby Liebling
column5: though doing better
column6: is still pushing it in years. If Control gets Uncle Acid on tour and into the psyches of more listeners
column7:
we can put those “Dolls” in the closet.

The recording career of little-known French musician Patrick Vian
column2: son of novelist and jazz trumpeter Boris Vian
column3: began with the sound of someone using and then flushing a toilet. Fortunately
column4: from such inauspicious beginnings came great wonder. That recording
column5: as part of the prog-leaning group Red Noise
column6: came from their sole album from 1970
column7: Sarcelles - Lochères. The band subsequently split in two
column8: mirroring the actions of German krautrock collective Amon Düül. While one half of the group soldiered on under the name Komintern
column9: Vian was preparing his masterwork. Released six years after Sarcelles - Lochères
column10: the playful spirit of that album remained on Bruits et Temps Analogues
column11: even if the tools for getting the job done were remarkably different. Here
column12: Vian cooks up a form of cosmic jazz
column13: made with the aid of various Moog and ARP synths
column14: plus a backing band that includes drummer Mino Cinelu (Weather Report
column15: Miles Davis
column16: Gong).

column1: It's the type of recording that's circulated in small underground circles for years
column2: partly abetted by Vian's inclusion (along with Red Noise) on Nurse With Wound's notorious list of artists that inspired them. There's a sense of a beginning rather than an end
column3: a feeling that Vian was onto something that he could have developed further. Instead
column4: he fell silent in subsequent decades
column5: just leaving this singular recording hanging. Vian leans heavily on his analog arsenal
column6: but there's plenty of room for bursts of guitar noodling (courtesy of Bernard Lavialle) and Cinelu's impeccably fussy rolls. The circular
column7: clean-cut guitar riff that drives ""Sphere"" even sounds like a precursor to the Sea and Cake's central sound. But this is an album that doesn't stay in place for long. Sometimes it's purely made up of intricately overlapping keyboard parts
column8: similar in tone to Harald Grosskopf's analog wanderings; elsewhere there's an airy
column9: new age feel; on ""Old Vienna"" a form of mania sets in
column10: as rhythms escalate wildly in tempo.

column1: The way the album lurches in mood adds to the mystery
column2: with the quirky parts bolted on to more somber fare
column3: occasionally making it sound like a Moog demonstration record that was intended to be taken utterly seriously. Vian's motivations for making this are anyone's guess
column4: but somehow he managed to sequence it so a crazy burst of machine noise could effortlessly slide into a piece of elegant Moog-driven funk and then back out into utter chaos again (""R & B Degenerit !""). Of course there were many other artists testing out the boundaries of old ARP synths and similar instruments during the 70s
column5: but here Vian demonstrates both a mastery of the tools at his disposal and a wide-open mind as to where they could take him. His work with Red Noise awkwardly hopped through an array of genres
column6: but here there's a more seamless blend
column7: with his keyboard work tying together all the maniacal shifts charging through his mind.

column1: This reissue of Bruits et Temps Analogues by the Staubgold label doesn't add anything to what came before; no outtakes
column2: no demos
column3: no lost material excavated from the vaults. It's better that way
column4: leaving something of the original spirit of the LP intact. What's most perplexing about Vian's short career is the breadcrumb trail he left behind here
column5: offering hints of further experimentation to come. ""Tricentennial Drag"" appears to be leading us somewhere else altogether via a series of primitive cut-ups
column6: bursts of sheer aggression
column7: and blaring police sirens. It was nothing particularly new for the time
column8: perhaps even a little dated when you consider the White Noise were working in a similar zone some eight years prior. But it sounds like the germ of an idea he was about to exploit. Instead
column9: all that’s left is this
column10: sealed by a back cover image of Vian that's easy to romanticize
column11:
depicting him rowing away on an old wooden canoe to some unspecified destination.

“It’s really hard to even talk about the internet without seeming instantly corny
column2: Ezra Koenig told Pitchfork recently
column3: ""even the word 'blog' sounds a little grandma-y."" He should know. The Vampire Weekend singer and lyricist gave up on his own Blogspot site
column4: Internet Vibes
column5: seven years ago
column6: as he finished up his English studies at Columbia University (the final post's title: ""I HATE BLOGGING""). But before he graduated from the ye olde blogosphere
column7: Koenig held forth on a vast array of topics-- from geography
column8: to Wellington boots
column9: to music writer Robert Christgau's allegedly unfair critique of Billy Joel's oeuvre-- looking at everything from a incisively self-aware
column10: curious
column11: and optimistic angle. What's most impressive is the way he's able to connect art and ideas from different eras and continents into a kind of ecstatic worldview. One particularly inspired ramble spins an analytic web from a friend's visit to Morocco
column12: the history of the Strait of Gibraltar
column13: a 1984 interview between Bob Dylan and Bono
column14: the film <i>The Secret of Roan Inish
column15: and National Geographic's famed Afghan refugee cover-- and not only does it make sense
column16: it's written in a way that's funny and smart and completely inclusive. Pretty good for a 22-year-old kid from middle-class New Jersey. Now 28
column17: Koenig's creative medium has changed
column18: but his omnivorous cultural appetite has not.

column1: Take ""Step""
column2: the third song on Vampire Weekend's third album
column3: Modern Vampires of the City-- the record that is already forcing one-time haters of this band to rethink their entire lives. At its core
column4: the song reads like an ode to obsessive music fandom in which the object of Koenig's affection is ""entombed within boombox and walkman."" Modest Mouse are name-checked. But the sense of infatuation extends beyond a list of influences and is embedded into the music itself. The chorus and parts of the melody are borrowed from wordy Oakland rap act Souls of Mischief's ""Step to My Girl""-- which itself samples Grover Washington
column5: Jr.'s version of a Bread song called ""Aubrey"". But ""Step"" avoids back-patting nostalgia and debunks bogus generational hierarchies while using the past to inspire the present. It's also melancholy
column6: with Vampire Weekend musical mastermind Rostam Batmanglij surrounding Koenig's musings with lilting harpsichord ambience. Because
column7: as we know
column8: music is a young man's pursuit. ""Wisdom's a gift but you'd trade it for youth
column9: Koenig sings.

column1: Still
column2: Vampire Weekend make a damn good case for wisdom all across Modern Vampires. Yes
column3: this is a more grown-up album. It largely trades in the Africa-inspired giddiness of their first two records for a sound that's distinctly innate and closer to the ear. There's more air in these songs
column4: more spontaneity
column5: more dynamics. The overarching themes-- death and a dubious sense of faith-- are certainly Serious. But you never feel like you're being preached at while listening to this album. Koenig and company are probably more clever and gifted than you
column6: sure-- but they're not rubbing your face in it or anything. Their message is one of collective understanding and betterment
column7: and Modern Vampires is the kind of album that'll have you Googling for Buddhist temples and Old Testament allusions at 3 a.m. while listening to reggae great Ras Michael (who's sampled on opener ""Obvious Bicycle""). Now
column8: you don't have to get obsessed to enjoy this music
column9: but it's presented with such care that you can't help but want to learn about its deeper meanings. So while Koenig gave up a potential teaching career to take his chances as a rock singer
column10: he's still doling out knowledge in his own way.

column1: Though the record often traverses in darkness-- the zipped-tight ""Finger Back"" alludes to historic atrocities and brutality while ""Hudson""
column2: easily the band's bleakest track to date
column3: imagines an apocalyptic Manhattan-- there's also hope here. Partly because Vampire Weekend seem to have internalized all of the positive traits of their internet-soaked generation while resisting the ugly ones: they'll offer jokes and humanity on Twitter without navel-gazing; they'll play a concert for a credit-card company while roping in Steve Buscemi for promo videos that are no-shit funny; they'll use the tools of modernity to expand their universe rather than contract it. And then they'll go ahead and crack your heart in two.

column1: Along with the more lived-in sonics
column2: Modern Vampires has the band taking a leap forward into emotional directness. Koenig and Batmanglij truly seem of one mind here
column3: as the vocals and music interact with each other in an effortless flow. While skronks and snares pop on ""Diane Young""
column4: the singer matches the live-fast intensity hit-for-hit. The song is a dissection of the 27 Club rock'n'roll myth
column5: where Koenig's voice on the sly ""baby
column6: baby
column7: baby"" bridge is manipulated to intoxicating effect.

column1: Then there's ""Hannah Hunt"". In some sense
column2: it seems like Vampire Weekend's entire career thus far has led to this one song. It begins with the hiss of wind and some vague background chatter-- the sounds of the everyday-- before it's all quickly tuned out in favor of Batmanglij's piano and bassist Chris Baio's upright plucks. Koenig comes in soft
column3: telling of a couple on a cross-country road trip. His details-- crawling vines
column4: mysterious men of faith
column5: newspaper kindling-- are sparse
column6: delicate
column7: perfect. And then
column8: after two minutes and 40 seconds of quiet beauty
column9: the song blooms
column10: and Koenig lets it absolutely rip: ""If I can't trust you then damn it
column11: Hannah/ There's no future/ There's no answer/ Though we live on the U.S. dollar/ You and me
column12: we got our own sense of time."" On an album preoccupied with the ominous ticking of clocks
column13: this is the moment that stops them cold.

column1: Koenig has said in recent interviews that the band's three albums make up a trilogy. ""Hannah Hunt"" could be a sobering continuation of Contra's Springsteen-ian ""Run""
column2: where two people decide to up and leave their known lives in search of some sort of American transcendence. There's also a perilous chandelier at the center of new track ""Everlasting Arms""
column3: perhaps a callback to the hanging lights that cover the band's debut LP. And the Modern Vampires font is the same exact one used in a trailer for Koenig's absurd-looking college-era werewolf movie
column4: from which Vampire Weekend got its name. These little links are not only satisfying
column5: but inevitable. After years of engaging with anything and everything in reach
column6:
Vampire Weekend are now a primary source in their own right.

For Sam Amidon
column2: there is no difference between an old rural folk ballad and a new urban radio jam. On his new album
column3: <i>Bright Sunny South
column4: he covers both Mariah Carey and Tim McGraw
column5: who join the illustrious ranks of Dock Boggs
column6: children's folk singer Ella Jenkins
column7: R. Kelly
column8: Tears for Fears
column9: and Katrina and the Waves in his catalogue of covers. He brings the sentiments from each song into his own weird world-- some Appalachian mountain holler
column10: essentially removed from time. These covers could have come across as cheap stunts
column11: not unlike those acoustic approximations of rap hits
column12: but instead they’ve become essential to Amidon’s catalog. Born into a musical family and trained since infancy on fiddle and banjo
column13: he does not view old-time music as an easy path to authenticity
column14: just as he has no use for suspenders and tweed. On the other hand
column15: he understands that the folk tradition extends to pop music. Amidon is not awestruck by the songs he sings
column16: whether they’re several decades or several months old
column17: and that gives his music-- especially on his new album-- a breeziness that underscores rather than undercuts the songs’ sense of persistent loneliness.

column1: Not quite as stylized as 2010’s I See the Sign
column2: but certainly no less ambitious
column3: Bright Sunny South is a quiet
column4: austere album that emphasizes Amidon’s banjo playing and singing. Again he’s working with longtime friend and collaborator Thomas Bartlett (a.k.a. Doveman). But the new presence here is Jerry Boys
column5: the legendary studio engineer best known for his work with Steeleye Span
column6: Sandy Denny
column7: and Vashti Bunyan. He creates in these songs a naturalistic space
column8: suggesting the shape of a room or a copse of trees around the performer
column9: while still maintaining a throughline with Amidon’s previous albums. Songs like “I Wish I Wish” and the title track
column10: a lament by a soldier leaving home
column11: sound emotionally and musically austere: less folk hymns than interior monologues full of barely repressed angers and resignations.

column1: From the ground up Amidon reimagines these old tunes
column2: some of which have been sung both in and out of the indie-folk realm innumerable times (“I Wish I Wish”
column3: for example
column4: comes from the same source material as Uncle Tupelo’s “I Wish My Baby Was Born”
column5: off <i>March 16-20
column7: although the two versions sound remarkably different). His voice goes eloquently flat at particularly dramatic moments
column8: usually to evoke some desperation at parting ways with a loved one
column9: and his strange phrasing molds these melodies into new and unexpected shapes. On the shape-note hymn “Weeping Mary”-- famously recorded in the 1970s by the Word of Mouth Chorus
column10: whose membership included Amidon’s parents-- he lets his voice trail off into an arrhythmic murmur
column11: chewing over the syllables as well as the concept of “glory glory glory.”

column1: Yet the best moments on Bright Sunny South may actually be the least lonely passages
column2: the ones that emphasize a group dynamic. Working with a skeleton crew of a band-- mostly strings and percussion
column3: with brief interjections of horns-- Amidon interrupts the delicate reveries of “He’s Taken My Feet” for a noisy bridge
column4: as though he’s stolen a glimpse of Hell to reinforce his salvation. As he ponders that very concept on “Weeping Mary”
column5: the song goes in and out of focus
column6: as Bartlett creates a prismatic shift of woodwinds. “As I Roved Out” may be the loosest
column7: the loudest
column8: and the most unhinged Amidon has ever sounded on record. As he scribbles out a rackety riff on his banjo
column9: he turns to the instrument for moral support. “What is it
column10: banjo?” he beseeches
column11: just as drummer Chris Vatalaro runs away with the song. “Did you ever feel such pain?” Even at its most baroque
column12: the music remains essential to the tangled stories these songs recount and the troubled characters Amidon inhabits.

column1: About that Mariah Carey cover. “Shake It Off” was the third single on 2005 album
column2: The Emancipation of Mimi
column3: but it remains minor on Bright Sunny South as well. Played on piano at a molasses pace
column4: the songs sounds stiff on its own and shoehorned into the tracklist
column5: as Amidon cannot sell the commercial references to Calgon (tellingly
column6: he omits the verse about Louis Vuitton). He fares better with Tim McGraw’s ruminative “My Old Friend”
column7: from 2004’s Live Like You Were Dying. As though a refute to anyone who would mindlessly dismiss commercial country music
column8: Amidon retains the song’s melodic skeleton
column9: slows it down a notch
column10: transposes it to a minor key
column11: and creates something that sounds like the long-lost sequel to “I See A Darkness”
column12: another song about old friends with a long history. And that’s what distinguishes Amidon from the pack of folk revivalists currently enamored with pre-rock Americana: He not only has an impressively deep knowledge of traditional song forms
column13:
but takes liberties with the country's past in order to document his own personal present.

Sacramento trio Tera Melos traffic in genres that are often viewed as the opposite of punk
column2: i.e.
column3: prog
column4: math-rock
column5: post-hardcore. But when done properly
column6: these styles generate all of the enthusiasm of punk while turning its traditional logic about formal training on its head: What if your love of music inspires you to train to the point where you can accomplish anything you want? That’s what Tera Melos get at on their fourth album
column7: <i>X’ed Out
column8: a super-collider of genres
column9: riffs and mad rhythms that is often thrilling
column10: occasionally exhausting
column11: and
column12: unlike most chops-based music
column13: never dull.

column1: It wasn’t always this way. Their previous work was often chops for chops'-sake
column2: impressive on a theoretical level
column3: manifesting in songs as spazzed-out and inscrutable as their titles-- “Guy vs D.C. Sniper
column4: ” “A Spoonful Of Slurry (is Good for What Ails You)
column5: ” to name a few. While their instrumental capacities are still plenty baffling
column6: Tera Melos appear to be relishing the opportunity to encounter new difficulties; whereas jamming a 7/4 riff against a 12/8 backbeat is a puzzle that can be solved with enough effort
column7: the stuff X'ed Out goes for is sparked by the metaphysical-- ingenuity and serendipity.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Tera Melos sound exhilarated by the potential of not having an idea of where these songs might end up. X’ed Out begins on a monotone
column3: palm-muted riff that could’ve found itself on a Phoenix or Strokes record; in fact
column4: when Nick Reinhart’s vaporous falsetto first enters
column5: it sounds a great deal like “Tap Out” from Comedown Machine. A couple of clean guitar runs nestle their way into the mix
column6: and all of a sudden
column7: it’s more in the style of looping enthusiasts like Dustin Wong. And then... a circle-pit ready chorus in Sufjan Stevens’ favorite time signature?

column1: The name of that song is “Weird Circles”
column2: which becomes a prophetic statement. X’ed Out is full of loops that don’t quite close
column3: song structures that aren’t verses and choruses so much as geometric patterns jutting against each other at strange angles
column4: genres ricocheting in a game of pinball. Siphon out the hooks of “Weird Circles”
column5: “Sunburn”
column6: and “Tropic Lame”
column7: and you have the basis for 2013’s most excellent skate punk EP. Isolate the beatless and beatific drift of “Snake Lake” and “No Phase”
column8: and Tera Melos make a case for themselves as a covert dream pop act. Come across “New Chlorine” or “Until Lufthansa” in the wild and Tera Melos is a fine reminder of a time when Jawbox and Jawbreaker were getting major-label deals.

column1: Which is to say that while X’ed Out is Tera Melos’ most accessible work by a large margin
column2: it’s still all relative. There are hooks all over the place and just as many ways to deliver them-- guitars that sound more like steel drums
column3: phonetic cooing
column4: ridiculous drum fills. But Tera Melos aren’t pop craftsmen working in ornate arrangements; they’re playing with such frantic speed and precision
column5: it’s more like they’re trying to defuse live bombs. This makes Tera Melos a cozy fit on Sargent House
column6: a label which has cornered the market on carnival rock with the likes of Fang Island
column7: And So I Watch You From Afar and Bosnian Rainbows. It’s not divisive so much as deep niche-- this stuff isn’t for everyone
column8: largely because the accompanying up-with-people delivery that can be somewhat grating. But X’ed Out offers the same thrill rides without the sugary stodge. Granted
column9: Reinhart’s vocals are so airy that they often sound indecipherable in isolation
column10: to say nothing of when they’re placed amidst Tera Melos’ whirligig arrangements. That said
column11: there’s substance and protein here-- the music is always given muscle to counteract the finger-tapping treble and you can suss out lyrics about punk rock bills
column12: street names
column13: and other clues to the emotional and physical geography of X’ed Out.

column1: They're still subject to incomprehensibility; besides being the longest track on X’ed Out
column2: “Slimed” relies too much on overeager skronk to fill the time
column3: as if to give listeners an idea of what they previously missed out on. On the opposite end
column4: while “X’ed Out and Tired” is sensible as a closing sigh of relief
column5: as a straight-up acoustic strummer
column6: it doesn’t make much of a case for Tera Melos to unplug just yet. Those both come later on
column7: when the listener is likely to be more exhausted than the people actually playing the music. While it’s exciting to hear a veteran band sharply change course on the fly
column8: Tera Melos doesn’t always have a grasp on the mundane things like pacing or sequencing that make for a smoother LP experience. Still
column9: even if it’s a fourth album delivered with the enthusiasm and conviction of a debut
column10:
Tera Melos sound too damn geeked about where they are now to let X’ed Out be a definitive document.

When the Chicago trio Phuture discovered the Roland TB-303 Bass Line synthesizer sometime around 1984
column2: they knew that it would sound incredible over house beats. Roland had intended for it to be a simple way for a musician to program their own backing parts
column3: but unlike the 808 and 909
column4: the 303 doesn’t make any sort of intuitive sense at all. On top of that
column5: the ones sold in America supposedly came with only the Japanese instructions. Programming even a simple bassline on the 303 was essentially impossible for the average musician. But Phuture figured out how to wrangle a constantly evolving
column6: jarring
column7: harsh electronic ""squelch"" from the machine
column8: and in 1985
column9: recorded “Acid Tracks”
column10: a 12-minute opus of squealing synth noise. After sitting on it for two years
column11: they gave it to Ron Hardy
column12: a DJ at Chicago’s legendary Music Box. As one of the most prominent figures in house’s creation
column13: he ignited a craze in the city for what came to be called “acid house.”

column1: The craze would catch on in England in the late 80s
column2: where acid house begat rave culture
column3: but Soul Jazz’s new two-disc genre survey
column4: Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin’ Zone
column5: keeps its focus squarely on Chicago. “Acid Tracks” isn’t on it
column6: but its 22 songs give a thorough overview of the genre's local legacy-- and we do get one Phuture song
column7: plus a monsoon of squelches
column8: in the form of “Slam”
column9: credited to Phuture Pfantasy Club.

column1: Listening to the compilation
column2: what's immediately clear is how beautifully simple acid house could be. In fact
column3: the more minimal it is
column4: the better. One of its best tracks
column5: Armando’s 1988 single “151”
column6: consists almost entirely of a four-on-the-floor kick drum
column7: a hi-hat
column8: an electronic whirr
column9: and a gnarly
column10: trance-inducing
column11: one-note 303 line. When some electronic handclaps come in at the four-minute mark
column12: it qualifies as an event. And yet there’s nothing lacking in the arrangement. It’s brutally efficient
column13: with a bare minimum of moving parts
column14: and nothing to distract listeners from dancing. In front of the right crowd a DJ could easily stretch it out to at least 10 minutes without upsetting anyone.

column1: Interspersed throughout the compilation are cuts from what the liner notes refer to as the Chicago “experimental house” scene that was happening concurrently. These selections provide a break from the relentless 303 squelch
column2: as well as highlighting some of the more interesting house music coming out of the city during a time when-- to quote “I Believe” by A Black Man
column3: A Black Man and Another Black Man (one of the pseudonyms used by legendary house DJ Farley Jackmaster Funk)-- certain artists were “messing up by trying to make it commercial
column4: ” which would eventually lead to the satiny
column5: spiritless vocal house that dominated clubs during the 90s.

column1: Acid comes packaged with a short graphic novel by Paolo Parisi that offers an alternate acid house history
column2: where the style plays a part in an ongoing battle between extradimensional creatures in which the digital dancehall of early-80s Jamaica also had a role. That’s obviously not how things really went down
column3:
but hearing the radical way that acid house producers were warping and twisting sound back then it would be easy to believe that aliens were involved somehow.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19258/homepage_large.dbbc8907.jpg|The Elektrik Karousel|31316.0|The Focus Group|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghost Box']|2013-05-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:03.609846|"

Almost 10 years have passed since Julian House introduced the fitful rhythms of the Focus Group to the world. It's a music that exclusively trades on finding beauty in the awkward fit
column2: both in the way it sounds and the way it's executed. When listening to a Focus Group album
column3: expect to hear organ drones collide with the clatter of typewriter keys
column4: with indecipherable dialogue extracted from impossibly obscure European art films laced over the top. There is no neat segue between parts. Instead
column5: it sounds like House is sticking pieces of tape together by hand
column6: quickly cycling through fragments of pop culture ephemera in tracks that last two minutes or less (it's usually less). He's probably not working that way
column7: but it's a nice image to have in mind when listening to the Focus Group: House
column8: the mad inventor
column9: lost in a blizzard of unspooled tape that he's gradually feeding into an old Studer
column10: the whole process only making sense to him alone.

column1: That working model served House well initially
column2: but in recent times he's branched out a little. There's been a blurring of the lines between the Focus Group and Broadcast
column3: to the point where it's no longer clear where one group begins and the other ends. The ...Investigate Witch Cults of the Radio Age album bore both their names; a subsequent Broadcast tour (sadly their last due to the subsequent passing of singer Trish Keenan) drew heavily on films made for them by House; and Broadcast's soundtrack to Berberian Sound Studio lent hard on the kind of cut-up work they'd undertaken on Witch Cults. Now
column4: this album bears the credit: ""All titles composed by the Focus Group with help from Broadcast."" Still
column5: Elektrik Karousel feels like the vision of one man
column6: whose bastardization of the word ""carousel"" in the title couldn't be more appropriate. The whole thing passes in such a blur of color that you feel winded just trying to keep up.

column1: Concerns may arise from anyone well-versed in this stuff
column2: especially as the ""hauntology"" sub-genre has had its moment
column3: and other Focus Group albums were delivered with a similar love of parcelling everything up in small packets of multi-colored splendor. But the Ghost Box label has been surprisingly resilient. Last year's Pye Corner Audio album for the label is among their best releases
column4: effortlessly surpassing most of the sub-par John Carpenter clones littering up download folders. Elektrik Karousel works in the opposite direction
column5: strengthening House's position in a field in which he's mostly alone. He's shed many of the horror leanings here
column6: instead bringing the folkier side of the Focus Group into tighter view. The styling of titles like ""Kinky Korner Klub"" and ""The Kool Kranium"" bring Kenneth Anger's Kustom Kar Kommandos to mind
column7: but the mood throughout is more wistful autumnal picnic than it is occultist dinner party at the Dakota.

column1: Those folk elements always existed in the Focus Group's palette
column2: but the prevailing mood on prior albums could mostly be divided up into gleeful tinkering with vintage pop elements and the giallo chills that partly made the Ghost Box label so notable. On Elektrik Karousel there's a stronger sense of melancholy
column3: lending this music a weight it didn’t reach for in the past. It's even there in the most experimental pieces
column4: such as the positively epic (by Focus Group standards) six-minute piece ""The Magic Pendulum""
column5: which builds around a sad horn motif and leaden organ drones. At times it's stunningly pretty-- the one-minute plinky-plonky loop that ""Let's Listen"" works around is one of the few times that House should have worked against his instinct for brevity. But that's the Focus Group
column6: moving on quickly
column7: leaving tiny mysteries trailing behind. Except this time a piece of the puzzle
column8: an explanation for the shades of sorrow
column9:
is provided in the liner notes: ""Thank you Trish for the sounds you sent"".

"|18069.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18069-the-focus-group-the-elektrik-karousel/|7.0|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19180/homepage_large.3a33d905.jpg|Volume 3|5676.0|She & Him|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2013-05-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:04.189341|"

In a recent column at the Week
column2: film critic Monika Bartyzel made a convincing argument that it's time to retire the term ""Manic Pixie Dream Girl."" Critiquing a particularly hollow and noxious stereotypical female character that was cropping up in films like Garden State and Elizabethtown
column3: Nathin Rabin<a href=""http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-bataan-death-march-of-whimsy-case-file-1-eliza
column4: 15577/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> coined the popular term back in 2007. But awash in an endless stream of analysis
column5: over-analysis
column6: supercuts
column7: and admittedly pretty hilarious parody Twitter accounts
column8: Bartyzel now thinks the term has “outlived its usefulness and become a part of the very marginalizing trend that it was designed to rally against.”

column1: Not convinced? Look no further than the common perception of Miss Polka-Dots-and-Cupcakes 2013 herself
column2: Zooey Deschanel. The title star of Fox's sitcom “New Girl” and sundress-clad half of AM radio nostalgists She & Him
column3: Deschanel has also become the English language’s most popular synonym for “Manic Pixie Dream Girl.” Her pretty-vacant role in (500) Days of Summer and the misleadingly “adorkable” marketing campaign behind “New Girl” notwithstanding
column4: there’s more to Deschanel than the stereotype suggests. True
column5: most musicians have to deal with misconceptions and pigeonholing in some form or another
column6: but pop culture has caricatured Deschanel in a way that’s quietly denied her artistic agency. Need proof? Last week
column7: I conducted a very unscientific experiment: I asked five people in casual conversation if they knew that Deschanel wrote all the original songs on She & Him's albums. All five of these admirably honest people gulped
column8: looked down at their shoes and said no
column9: they did not.

column1: A big reason why it’s easy to underestimate Deschanel is that the actor-moonlighting-as-pop-musican is ripe for both parody and Dogstar jokes-- still
column2: I'd bet the keys to my red Plymouth that most people wouldn't have a hard time believing that Jared Leto at least wrote all of the bloated-ego space-operas on the last 30 Seconds to Mars record. But like the unexpectedly complex character arc of her “New Girl” character Jess Day
column3: Deschanel's breezy
column4: inviting
column5: confidently arranged tunes come as a pleasant surprise to those who've dismissed her on flimsy principle (or hypothetical twee allergy) alone. Volume 3-- the latest collection of sun-dappled pop songs she’s recorded with M. Ward under the name She & Him-- provides further proof. Pulling tricks from the songbook of 60s pop and country crooners like Loretta Lynn and Patsy Cline
column6: She & Him bask unabashedly in the glow of nostalgia
column7: but Deschanel also finds a way to assert a unique personality within the pop idiom. “I’m stronger than the picture you took before you left
column8: ” she sings in her amiable
column9: mid-morning yawn of an alto on “Turn to White”
column10: one of Volume 3’s highlights. “In the light
column11: it faded to white.”

column1: Perhaps even moreso than the first two She & Him albums
column2: Volume 3 has an an alluringly casual feel: Deschanel has a certain kind of charisma that allows a song to hang loosely but never fall apart. On a few occasions
column3: things get a little too lax: she mumbles the verses of “Somebody Sweet to Talk To” like a person recovering from dental surgery
column4: but she gets it together in time for a sprightly chorus that ends up being one of the album’s catchiest melodies. M. Ward’s production is at once detailed and featherlight. It sometimes recalls the gilded edges and baroque flourishes on his lush
column5: self-produced 2009 record Hold Time
column6: but the songs themselves aren’t as tight as
column7: say
column8: “Never Had Nobody Like You” (an M. Ward track on which Deschanel provides back-up vocals). Ward gives them enough room to sway leisurely
column9: as though a warm breeze is rustling through.

column1: Volume 3 is the first She & Him album since Deschanel’s divorce from Death Cab for Cutie frontman Ben Gibbard
column2: but those scouring the lyrics for gossip might be a tad disappointed: unlike Ray J
column3: Deschanel is tactfully tight-lipped about her personal business. The best songs here are the ones about heartbreak
column4: but that’s been true on every She & Him album. Deschanel is not a confessional or even very specific lyricist
column5: but she often gets mileage out of zinging
column6: gently self-deprecating turns of phrase like the ones on the excellent opener “I’ve Got Your Number
column7: Son”. “What’s a man without all the attention?/ Well he’s just a man
column8: ” she sings
column9: “Who am I without all your affection?/ I’m a nobody
column10: too.” She has a way with that kind of line that Jenny Lewis has perfected-- cutting in one breath and knowingly self-lacerating in the next.

column1: But that’s precisely why Deschanel's music ultimately transcends the Manic Pixie Dream Girl tag: She spends the following 13 songs asserting that she’s not a nobody when she’s alone. It doesn’t shy away from sorrow
column2: but as far as heartbreak albums go
column3: Volume 3 is surprisingly resilient. When she’s wallowing-- as on the drizzly piano ballad “London”
column4: one of the album’s more forgettable numbers-- Deschanel finds comfort in the fact that at least everybody else around her is wallowing
column5: too. “We all go through it together
column6: but we all go at it alone
column7:
” she sings on “Together”. The sentiment might be depressing if it weren’t tucked inside the most infectious melody on the whole record.

Since arriving during the initial rush of chillwave in 2008
column2: Small Black never had a problem fitting in with whatever’s been happening in indie rock at any moment-- meaning their music threatens to blend in far more than stand out. Grotty
column3: homemade glo-fi singles such as “Despicable Dogs” turned a few ears in their native Brooklyn
column4: but by the time Small Black cleaned up for their 2010 Jagjaguwar debut New Chain
column5: they came off like a regular ol’ synth-pop act with good timing as opposed to an obsessive tinkerer like Toro Y Moi or Neon Indian. The less said about their hip-hop mixtape
column6: the better-- just know that they were hardly the only dudes trying to make cloud-rap beats in 2011. And now with indie getting all grown and sexy
column7: they’ve followed suit on Limits of Desire
column8: a record whose production puts their music in sharper relief
column9: but does so with an R&B slickness that once again puts Small Black right in the center of the zeitgeist rather than above or outside of it.

column1: Lead single and opener “Free at Dawn” at least shows us they made the right call. It’s the most exemplary of how their hi-fi sound-- described by frontman Josh Kolenick as a “million dollar record on a very low budget”-- can prove complementary to the underlying elements of their songwriting. Kolenik’s breathy vocals handle melodies that take long
column2: broad turns
column3: the bass pulses lightly and everything that contributes to the soft
column4: gently ascendant arc-- a sustained guitar riff
column5: light harmonic kisses
column6: lush reverb-- knows not to disturb this groove. Though Kolenik describes what it might feel like to be “reckless as rain
column7: ” “Free at Dawn” is more of a controlled
column8: physical sensation
column9: of a tall
column10: cold one being swept against a sweaty brow.

column1: It’s a nice feeling
column2: one that Small Black can occasionally retrigger throughout Limits of Desire. But Small Black push through 45 minutes of this without generating the necessary heat to keep things interesting. As a vocalist
column3: Kolenik remains more functional than expressive
column4: his range limited in terms of both emotion and melody. In isolation
column5: any of the 10 songs on Limits of Desire are a soothing balm; in sequential order
column6: they’re distinguishable only by increment: “Canoe” is the one with the cooed
column7: falsetto hook rather than the heavily sighed one (“No Stranger”)
column8: “Shook Loves” may or may not be inspired by Mobb Deep
column9: and closer “Outskirts” is six minutes of aloe-infused synth-pop ambience instead of four.

column1: Considering chillwave artists were never been shy about their R&B influences and sought to evoke a sensuality that was foreign to most guitar-based music at the time
column2: Small Black is capable of making a smooth transition to the present. But unlike the nu-makeout music of Vondelpark or Rhye
column3: Limits of Desire lacks crisp definition and spark
column4: instead relying on the same old smeary tactics of reverb
column5: gloss
column6: and languor; thanks to the frictionless production
column7: you can feel the high thread count of the sheets
column8: but never another person.

column1: A generous reading might suggest that’s the entire point. Judging from its title and the garish
column2: meaningful symbolism of its cover art
column3: Limits of Desire is meant to be a conceptual piece about communication breakdowns and failures of the flesh. But as much as Kolenik describes these chasms
column4: he’s more wont to contribute to them. Throughout
column5: he shows a weakness for emo softserve (“Through the thick and lovely smoke/ Full of guts but so shy/ Tell me what you want
column6: she says”)
column7: though more often those sentiments are nudged uncomfortably towards poetry
column8: but just end up not being enough of either (“She was the end of ruins/ A full rush of air”). It’s apt
column9: as musically and lyrically
column10: Limits of Desire plays on the double meaning of “sweet nothings”; you get the feeling that Small Black do want to break free of their past
column11:
but they’re not always convincing at showing how badly they want it.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19225/homepage_large.68daad49.jpg|Replicant Moods|31122.0|Pharaohs|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['100% Silk']|2013-05-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:05.626751|"

Pharaohs plow an unwavering path through the past
column2: taking a route through various strains of dance music that's unapologetically nostalgist in outlook. They're a four-piece band from Los Angeles
column3: originally started by Alejandro Cohen and Samuel Cooper. It's hard to picture their debut full length
column4: Replicant Moods
column5: as the work of four people
column6: mainly because it has more in common with the quiet elation of lone producers like Barcelona's John Talabot. Still
column7: like Talabot
column8: Pharaohs aren't averse to bringing in occasional outside forces. This album's collaboration with the avant-leaning Estonian singer Maria Minerva on ""Miraculous Feet"" even mirrors the pop raptures of Talabot's 2011 match-up with Glasser on ""Families"". Elsewhere
column9: the classicist approach taken to house and Italo influences is a natural evolution from ""Uhh Uhh"" off the band's debut EP
column10: where they resembled a less drug-addled version of the Happy Mondays.

column1: An element of the ultra-relaxed groove from that EP remains here
column2: but mostly everything is tighter and more economical than the music that came before. Often it's close in content to the vintage Roland tweaks of certain songs on the Rapture's Echoes
column3: which in turn formed barely disguised homages to the techno groundwork of pioneers such as Kevin Saunderson
column4: Derrick May
column5: and Juan Atkins. In fact
column6: the entirety of Replicant Moods carries a similar ethos to much of the DFA label
column7: where popular tropes from dance music history reverberate in a contemporary setting. What's impressive is how effortless it all sounds
column8: flicking from dark to light with barely a graceless join in sight. Pharaohs have a real feel for pace
column9: mood
column10: and setting
column11: whether it’s through harder-edged Detroit techno adoration (""Everything"") or in sun-scorched stretches of plain euphoria (""Replicant Moods"").

column1: The tougher stuff doesn't make up the bulk of this album. Instead
column2: Pharaohs are most interested in inhabiting the stretch of clubland that builds toward full-on comedown. ""Beyond Within"" is the only track that reaches for Cafe del Mar-inspired ambience
column3: with the rest making transitory steps into that zone
column4: from the lightness of the Minerva-fronted song to the acid gulps that stretch out across the retro-rusty drum patterns of ""Again"". This music doesn't take you anywhere new and nor does it set out to; instead it demonstrates how certain house and electro moves have a certain timelessness when executed with the kind of skill displayed here. It wouldn't be easy to put a place and time on Replicant Moods if played cold
column5: with no knowledge of from when and where it came. ""F & M Suite"" even feels like a close cousin of T-Coy's ""Carino""
column6: a classic Latin-inspired house tune from back in 1987.

column1: Pharaohs succeed principally because they don't feel the weight of all those influences bearing down upon them. The parts all feel familiar
column2: but the way the tracks here effortlessly transport you out of the everyday is an enviable trick that suggests this isn't a band that feels in awe of the material they're sourcing. It's an interesting route they’ve taken-- ""Uhh Uhh"" suggested something that was edging ass-backward out of a rock format into a more club oriented form
column3: and they've taken that impulse and really sharpened it into something aimed squarely at the dancefloor. There's something to be said for waiting to make an opening statement
column4: for working on your craft. It's paid off for Pharaohs on Replicant Moods. They sound less sloppy
column5: more in control of what they're doing. ""Uhh Uhh"" was a perfectly serviceable
column6:
rough-around-the-edges calling card. But here? Here they just sound sublime.

"|18036.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18036-pharaohs-replicant-moods/|7.5|Nick Neyland

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19190/homepage_large.9db5d6cd.jpg|Kingdom of Conspiracy|2090.0|Immolation|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nuclear Blast']|2013-05-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:06.124836|"

Kingdom of Conspiracy is not a state-of-the-art death metal record. Whether you're judging by speed and technicality or by sheer enveloping atmosphere-- see recent releases by Wormed and Defeated Sanity on one hand
column2: or Portal and Abyssal on the other-- you'll have no trouble finding albums with more impressive on-paper stats. What this ninth Immolation full-length is
column3: though
column4: is something even more satisfying: a state-of-the-art Immolation LP
column5: and a continuation of a hot streak by one of the most rewarding veteran acts in the genre. The Yonkers band
column6: co-led since its 1988 inception by guitarist Robert Vigna and bassist/vocalist Ross Dolan
column7: has never paid much mind to death metal's arms race of extremity; like their contemporaries Suffocation and Incantation
column8: Immolation are currently producing some of the strongest material of their career
column9: an expertly calibrated blend of the byzantine and the straightforwardly brutal
column10: simply by following their own muse.

column1: If there is such a being
column2: he or she communes directly with Vigna-- the band's sole composer-- who wields his riffs like paint
column3: splashed at irregular intervals
column4: or spread out in more methodical arcs and whorls. Since the beginning
column5: Vigna has employed death metal's stock cadences sparingly. The blastbeat isn't an auto-pilot move for him; his riffs clank and lurch
column6: skank and shimmy
column7: high and low registers dialoging incessantly like two opposing hand puppets
column8: one that goes ""chunk"" and the other that goes ""squeal."" Parts appear first in basic form and then take on an eerie neon-like vibrancy thanks to the guitarist's signature whirring harmonies.

column1: This M.O. has remained more or less intact since Dawn of Possession
column2: Immolation's 1991 debut full-length. What has changed is the ferocity of the band's delivery-- which peaked in the early 2000s on extraordinary albums like Close to a World Below and Unholy Cult-- and
column3: more recently
column4: the integrity of their songcraft. With 2010's Majesty and Decay
column5: Immolation were writing the kind of death-metal ""hits"" that distinguish the genre's most elite catalogs-- those of bands like Morbid Angel
column6: Obituary and Cannibal Corpse. Providence
column7: from 2011
column8: was the best kind of stopgap: an EP that upheld Majesty's standard while adding a new element of trancelike
column9: downtempo repetition
column10: further cementing Immolation's indifference to shock and awe for its own sake.

column1: Kingdom of Conspiracy is exactly the record any fan of the two bulls-eyes that preceded would've hoped for. It's less offbeat than Providence or Majesty and Decay; there are few surprises here and even less fat. But as a summation of what Immolation does well
column2: it's close to flawless. The production values are pristine. Mid-period Immolation albums embraced an organic grit
column3: but now the band is all about fierce clarity. Vigna's current method is to compose and arrange entirely on the computer
column4: via Ableton Live; the members then learn the songs and perform them piecemeal in the studio. The end result has a mechanized quality that takes some getting used to
column5: but suits the material well. Kingdom of Conspiracy's core mission is the perfect articulation of Vigna's outlandish ideas.

column1: Even though the album's aesthetic terrain is well-mapped
column2: it's hard not to marvel at Vigna's inventions. ""Echoes of Despair"" is an instant Immolation classic
column3: a perfect illustration of how the band manages to obey the basic tenets of death metal while sounding completely off-the-wall. The intro section staggers forward in top-heavy waltz time
column4: a feel rarely employed in the genre. The song eventually arrives at a blastbeat passage
column5: but first
column6: it makes its way through a series of a brilliantly demented riffs
column7: full of zigzagging chugs and divebombing squeaks. For all its weirdness
column8: the track builds logically to its steamroller of a climax
column9: demonstrating Immolation's trademark feat of simultaneously spinning your head around and inciting old-school fist-pumping.

column1: Other tracks favor atmosphere over density. ""The Great Sleep"" is a mood-driven piece
column2: a demonstration of Vigna's compositional economy. It features a series of tanklike riffs
column3: lumbering and deliberate
column4: offset by majestic leads. The band give each idea its due; they don't move on until each section seems indelible. As well as any item in the Immolation discography
column5: it sums up the way the band juxtaposes frenzied technicality and poetic simplicity in the service of sturdy
column6: memorable writing.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Kingdom of Conspiracy hangs out in the Immolation wheelhouse
column3: while making slight tweaks to the formula. As in their back catalog
column4: the band rails at length here against those who would wield religion as a tool of control
column5: but on songs like ""A Spectacle of Lies""
column6: they widen their scope to include what scans as post-9/11 fearmongering. Lines like ""Inventing the problem/ Naming the enemy/ Creating the conflict"" don't exactly jump off the page
column7: but in the context of the band's firestorm riffage
column8: they capture the right mood of seething outrage. Ross Dolan's uniformly gruff vocal style serves a similar purpose: His delivery isn't the most distinctive or versatile in death metal
column9: but like a top-tier hardcore barker
column10: he summons a rare conviction
column11: focusing Vigna's bizarre creations to a diamond-hard point.

column1: Strangely
column2: there's something heartwarming about Kingdom of Conspiracy. It isn't just the realization that Immolation have retained their staunch intensity for 25 years and counting; it's that you can still hear them pushing to do better
column3: and to do so purely on their own terms
column4: without regard for the kind of arbitrary benchmarks that have threatened to turn death metal from a richly expressive medium into either an athletic contest or inscrutable art project. Immolation are at heart a band that's comfortable in their well-established style; fans know they're not going to throw out a wild curveball like Morbid Angel's industrial-steeped 2011 head-scratcher Illud Divinum Insanus. At the same time
column5: they've managed to find new ways to refine and progress. There's a pride in their steadfast devotion
column6: not to mention a joy. A record as lean
column7: untrendy and straight-up satisfying as Kingdom of Conspiracy could only have arisen out of the passionate care of lifers such as Robert Vigna and Ross Dolan. Their songs might fixate on hate
column8:
but they radiate a master craftsman's love.

"|18002.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18002-immolation-kingdom-of-conspiracy/|8.0|Hank Shteamer

With “re-thrash” pronounced DOA

That French disco-metal producers Justice would lead the charge to make the moribund live album relevant again is at once surprising and completely unsurprising. A recording of a performance by an arena-level dance act is a tough sell

But that's never been Justice's style: Gaspard Augé and Xavier de Rosnay disavow any categorization as dance music performers

column1: As a dance act that have always carried themselves more like an arena rock band than an arena dance act

column3: Marshall stacks

column1: It also helps that like most good performers

column5: then add in theatrically melodramatic strings
column6: piano
column7: and what sounds like a synthesizer tweaked to sound like a big
column8: crunchy distorted electric guitar. Then they dial things back down for some call-and-response with the crowd
column9: before finally easing into something like the version we’re used to. The bass doesn’t even kick in until almost four minutes into it. Towards the end they replicate the loop around which Swizz Beatz built “On to the Next One”

On Access All Arenas
column5: it appears as the first song of their encore
column6: with an extended
column7: stripped-down introduction consisting of Phalen’s part over a four-on-the-floor kick drum and a heavy bass line
column8: before noodling off into prog for a minute

column2: 000 or so people who filled the nearly two millennia-old Roman-built arena on the night of the recording were an enthusiastic group

000 others did.

Like most every record New York collective Zs have released

column5: a horde of singles and
column6: last year
column7: an immersive box set that gathered the complete works of the foundational Zs sextet onto four discs. But Zs operates from a stable core of instability. To wit
column8: they’ve undergone massive lineup changes throughout their lifespan
column9: swapping members among their two drummer/two guitarist/two saxophonist ranks before condensing into a quartet and
column10: most recently
column11: a series of trios. But more important
column12: they’ve always kept their focus fluid
column13: spiraling between roles as a new music ensemble
column14: improvisational welterweights
column15: sheet-music rippers
column16: sing-along weirdos
column17: and post-punk aggressors. As their name unwittingly suggests
column18: Zs has always pushed ideas to their endpoints and began again

column20: ” wrote Trevor Hunter of Zs’ trajectory in the liner notes to last year’s obelisk of variety
column22: “is trying to follow the same course.”

column1: And so
column2: Grain is the first release by the latest Zs lineup-- saxophonist Hillmer
column3: classically trained-and-aimed guitarist Patrick Higgins and incredibly active drummer Greg Fox. Rather than set expectations and parameters for this phase of the band by initially releasing original compositions
column4: the trio opted instead to create a cannibalistic mixtape that feeds on the carcass of the last Zs iteration. Hillmer and Higgins used the last-gasp recordings of the previous trio to create a 21-minute continual rupture of sound
column5: where any one layer or melody or rhythm generally lasts long enough only to reveal something else pushing through it. Fox took the same material and bent it into a strange span of beats
column6: whirrs and drones
column7: populating his side of this quixotic and intriguing LP with both a warped sense of time and a disobedient attention span. Those qualities
column8: of course
column9: trace a through line from the earliest incarnations of Zs to this rather uproarious one.

column1: Zs has forever been a liminal act
column2: living on (and occasionally dying by) any number of thresholds-- to tour or not to tour
column3: to finish a piece or to rip it up every time it’s played
column4: to transgress in the classical world or to befuddle in the indie rock realm. That trait holds for the personnel decision here; rather than make a clean break with the preceding unit
column5: Hillmer built a portal between them by letting the upstart band pilfer the ruins of the past. And sonically
column6: Grain again refuses to land on any one style or direction. Fox is a bombastic drummer
column7: perhaps best known for the way he shifted from steady wallop to sudden bursts in both the black metal act Liturgy and his own astral freak-show Guardian Alien. His focus during “Grain Part Two” certainly hinges on beats
column8: but he trades any expected force for a mercurial finesse. He lights between blissful Four Tet murmurs and cerebral Matmos crunch
column9: between puritanical Ryoji Ikeda cuts and twilit Tim Hecker drones. The rhythm is never still or settled
column10: and the tone is never simple enough to be pretty or punishing; again
column11: Fox-- and
column12: by extension
column13: Zs-- spend these 22 minutes on multiple edges.

column1: Hillmer and Higgins are even more restless
column2: unspooling a barrage of forever-alternating scraps and samples. They hopscotch from Merzbow-sized tumult to funky guitar
column3: from dying-machine industrial music to sweetly mesmerizing rhythmic patter. At one point
column4: they land upon a pulse that’s so grimy and buoyant that you might expect rapper Cities Aviv to jump into it; at other points
column5: they burrow so deep into sonic detritus and damage that you can’t imagine anyone even approaching the mess.

column1: Keep in mind that Grain is only an introduction
column2: a lark that Hillmer conjured for introducing this emergent ensemble. The trio of Hillmer
column3: Higgins and Fox have been touring
column4: building their own manifestation of Zs. Grain makes it clear that they’re unencumbered when it comes to novel approaches but that they remain bound to exactly what Zs has been for so long-- great testers of boundaries and binaries
column5:
an act so reluctant to pick one option versus another that they’ve refused to choose between the old and the new.

Deathspell Omega totally screwed over the nascent French black metal scene once they decided to ditch the raw blasphemy of their first few releases and embrace their well-known hypertechnical riff mangling. It’s now impossible for any band of Gauls with even the wispiest shred of experimental ambition to escape a comparison to everyone’s favorite metaphysical Satanists. column3: or earnest philosophical leanings in the lyrics? DsO reference. Could the word “hypnotic” or “angular” be thrown in there without much effort? Definite DsO reference ahead. It’s with this brush that their slightly younger countrymen in Aosoth will undoubtedly be slathered

column11: and cerebral in turn. The slow

column15: expressive strings lend crucial heft and body to tracks like “One With the Prince With a Thousand Enemies” and “Temple of Knowledge”

column17: Aosoth defy convention without bothering to publicize it. Their style is understated and focused
column18:

Whether they were dismantling the divide between rock n’ roll and acid house

column3: with a snake-charmer horn refrain and a sand-swept
column4: acoustic-guitar groove that alternately surges and dissolves over the course of its nine mesmerizing minutes. Holmes’ wide-screened influence is most perceptible on the album’s long tracks
column5: over which the Scream carefully set the scene before deviously destabilizing it: “River of Pain” is a hushed
column6: Beta Band-style psych folk workout that gradually drifts into the path of an orchestral free jazz tornado; “Relativity” is a raging-raga attack on complacency (“You’re fucking next!/ Condemned to repeat!”) that gets detoured into a moonlit Midnight Cowboy sway. And to the producer’s great credit
column7: even the songs that most flagrantly dip into the blues-- always a danger zone for this band-- retain an absorbing atmosphere and gritty edge
column8: like the empty-bottle-kicking
column9: back-alley strut of “Tenement Kid” and the grey-scaled gospel of “Elimination Blues”
column10: the latter coloured by some lemon-squeezing “uh huhs” from guest Robert Plant.

column1: If these subdued songs channel XTRMNTR's agitated spirit in more oblique ways
column2: other tracks make the connection more explicit: The spectacular
column3: sax-scrambled “Hit Void” is the sequel to ""Shoot Speed Kill Light” we’ve been waiting 13 years for
column4: inheriting the latter’s Autobahn-bound rhythm but stomping on the accelerator and scraping the guard rail until the sparks fly; the hypnotic stomp of ""Sideman""
column5: meanwhile
column6: chisels a proper song out of the jazz funk haze of ""Bloody Money"". However
column7: “Culturecide” would be a more credible civil-disobedient counterpart to “Exterminator” if it didn’t have a title and hysterical chorus cry (courtesy of the Pop Group’s Mark Stewart) that sounded like it was cribbed from an Atari Teenage Riot record. And the upbeat 80s-Stones glitz of “Invisible City” sounds as out of place here as the band’s rollicking cover of Hawkwind’s “Motorhead” did on Vanishing Point
column8: ranking it a distant second in the pantheon of city-themed Gillespie/Holmes collaborations. But More Light’s sprawl is ultimately its greatest virtue
column9: its fusion of dreamy acoustic psychedelia and white-knuckled krautrock propulsion serving as the connective tissue between the blissed-out and bludgeoning extremes of this band’s unwieldy discography. With the Screamadelica nostalgia out of their systems
column10: More Light primes the Scream for their fourth decade in the best possible way
column11: serving as a summary of everything they’ve done before
column12:
yet sounding nothing like it.

Victoria Hesketh has either brilliant or awful timing. Recall her 2009 debut: Little Boots had the fortune
column3: it seemed at the time
column4: to emerge solo alongside about six other new electropop acts
column5: all varying combinations of blonde
column6: British
column7: and boshing
column8: with dossiers full of tie-ins
column9: dollops of irony
column10: and a tendency to deliver suspiciously similar talking points about how their dance music differed from the other dance music conquering the Top 40 in their stead. Of those
column11: Lady Gaga went supernova
column12: La Roux has spent three years writing the follow-up to its debut
column13: the ""is-it-pop-or-is-it-not?"" debate was foisted onto a new group of singers
column14: and all went quiet for Little Boots. Yet her shiny pop debut was ahead of the curve in a way
column15: helmed in part by Greg Kurstin
column16: four years before he became the go-to producer for shiny pop albums. If it’s instinct
column17: it’s the same instinct that steered her ever closer since toward 90s-inspired house
column18: two early singles of which (“Shake” and “Every Night I Say a Prayer”) heralded her second album
column19: Nocturnes-- an album that’s come out just as Disclosure
column20: Rudimental
column21: and seemingly one-third of the British commonwealth have emerged and begun to score uninterrupted No. 1 hits with that very sound.

column1: The major difference
column2: obviously
column3: is that the hype around Little Boots has now completely dissipated-- as have at least some of Little Boots’ industry ties; Nocturnes is out under her own On Repeat label. It’s not a bad thing
column4: exactly; where before Hesketh was all but set up for failure even if she did manage the crossover
column5: she’s now able to settle into a more attainable level of expectations. Hands’ catalog of pop sub-styles is gone
column6: and where that record forced her to sing like about six separate divas
column7: Nocturnes finds her settling on one that aspires to the distance of Saint Etienne's Sarah Cracknell or Sophie Ellis-Bextor. She’s not quite there
column8: and when her approach doesn’t work
column9: it really doesn’t-- as on “Confusion”
column10: which juggles lasers
column11: cowbell
column12: house piano
column13: vocal percussion
column14: and a small packet of stock sounds until its outro
column15: “never lie to me again” is banally repeated
column16: like a petulant lover’s spat. “Every Night” has a cavernous chorus that Hesketh isn’t enough of a belter to fill.

column1: Nocturnes is a big improvement over Hands
column2: though
column3: where even the biggest singles' hooks were made of saccharine
column4: not sugar. Hesketh credits the change to her time spent DJing
column5: but while she’s bound to have been immersed in the U.K. dance scene’s burgeoning 90s revival

column1: Little Boots’ subject matter hasn't changed at all
column2: however. Hesketh is still fond of overly pat metaphor
column3: usually involving her own music; standing in for Hands’ “Tune Into My Heart” and “Stuck on Repeat” are “Crescendo”

column5: and “Broken Record”
column6: sinuous like a fever dream until you realize lines like “thought you were out of mind
column7: instead you’re stuck on repeat” are probably also about Little Boots’ career. (Or
column8: for that matter
column9: “Stuck on Repeat”
column10: which is either horribly lazy or horribly meta and plausibly deniable either way.)

column1: When the metaphors don’t falter

column3: too tired even for a victory lap album. “All for You” is sleepier still. But a good deal of these tracks work just fine: the Dido-at-dusk escape fantasy “Motorway”; “Satellite”

and needs do nothing else. It all adds up to a sort of twisted proof of Hands’ big talking point: maybe you’re a better hitmaker when you’re not so self-conscious about it.

column3: David Lang's music glowed with heat; in 2007
column4: around his 50th birthday
column5: he began the slow
column6: mournful process of freezing it. A stiffening breeze ran through his music
column7: and his works assumed the spare urgency of a life form forced to reorder its priorities to survive. His Pulitzer Prize-winning 2008 masterwork
column8: The Little Match Girl Passion
column9: scored for just four voices and some hand bells
column10: huddled around a handful of close-together pitches like a body trapping heat; the highlight
column11: ""Have Mercy My God
column12: wound slowly around just five notes
column13: all within one octave
column14: sending the same questioning note into the air repeatedly. Something profound had spooked Lang into a consideration of primal questions.

column1: On his new album
column2: Death Speaks
column3: Lang stops dancing around the subject and invites the implied muse behind his late-period transformation to center stage. As its title makes plain
column4: the five love songs on Speaks are in the voice of Death; the words put in Death's mouth
column5: meanwhile
column6: are Schubert's. ""Something that has always attracted me to the songs of Franz Schubert is how present death is
column7: Lang writes in the liner notes. ""It isn't a state of being or a place or a metaphor
column8: but a person
column9: a character in a drama who can tell us in our own language what to expect in the World to Come.""  The second the music starts playing
column10: though
column11: this framework disappears. When Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond
column12: who performs the title role
column13: opens her mouth
column14: you are not thinking about Schubert. You are thinking about death.

column1: Like The Little Match Girl Passion
column2: the instrumental forces are simple: Bryce Dessner of the National on guitar
column3: Nico Muhly on piano
column4: and Owen Pallett on violin and occasional backup vocals. If The Little Match Girl Passion resembled a frozen
column5: minimalist recasting of the English madrigal
column6: Death Speaks sounds like the stem cells of Schubert songs
column7: attempting repeatedly to assemble themselves into form. ""you will return"" is set for a piano and electric guitar
column8: played in a high register
column9: blending together to fool the ear into hearing one harp. At the song's edges
column10: however
column11: the piano throws in compelling ""off"" notes
column12: pricking the surface with the sound of modern
column13: anxious thought. ""I am your pale companion
column14: Worden sings haltingly
column15: longing palpable in her voice
column16: on ""you will return
column17: while the music hesitates its way forward
column18: one tangled figure at a time.

column1: This probing reiteration of a single phrase
column2: one that restates itself in a thousand different ways
column3: is a trademark touch of Lang's. There is a philosophical tenor to this technique
column4: as if the ""correct"" phrasing of this figure is just one more try away
column5: and the changes
column6: when they happen
column7: ripple across the music more than they announce themselves. ""I am walking"" consists of a two-note guitar figure
column8: with small throat-clearing interjections from the piano
column9: while Worden and guest vocalist Pallett's vocal lines cross over each other. The final piece on the album
column10: ""Depart""
column11: a piece for cello and wordless vocals
column12: hangs like smoke
column13: darkening by imperceptible shades. In the pervading unease of Lang's new world
column14: only the smallest tendrils of harmonic motion are allowed to advance the music forward.

column1: This frozen wood is the place from which Lang's music reaches us now
column2: and Worden's voice has maybe been never better used than as its human embodiment. Her rounded
column3: glowing tone remains creamy even as it ascends into its highest register
column4: and she brings an overwhelming sadness to Worden's Death
column5: whose loneliness as she vainly pursues her charges
column6: or even
column7: in ""mist is rising""
column8: begs them to escape-- ""I love you/I love you/I love all of you/Your face/I love your face/Your form/I love your form ... Please don't make me make you follow me""-- is heartbreaking. Her Death is not just human
column9: but humane
column10: burdened by her task and full of compassion for those she visits. She is beautiful
column11: but troubled
column12: and her voice
column13: like these pieces
column14: rings out into a stillness
column15: harmonic and spiritual
column16:
that feels both haunted and becalmed.

Artists who experiment with dance music usually either free the beat from the standard 4/4
column2: warping it into rhythmically interesting shapes that are nearly impossible to dance to
column3: or they leave the beat alone to mess with all the other stuff. Harlem-based producer/drummer Gobby
column4: who’s created beats for the likes of Mykki Blanco and Le1f
column5: is the latter type. From the four-to-the-floor kick drum that opens his debut full-length
column6: Fashion Lady
column7: to the stroboscopically pulsing funk samples that close the album
column8: there’s not much here that a competent DJ would have much trouble blending into a set of uptempo dance music. The album's subtitle is “Techno Ass Album
column9: ” so most of the songs hew to the steady 4/4 structure that powers techno and house music.

column1: Whether or not a DJ would be willing to throw these tracks into a mix-- well
column2: that depends on how adventurous they are. Fashion Lady draws from a wide range of fringey electronic noise freaks
column3: a dense
column4: knotty palette that you'd find in Aphex Twin and Squarepusher's more cerebral material. Elsewhere
column5: there's an absolute mayhem of smeary
column6: lo-fi sounds that sound like they could have been recorded at an aggro DIY art loft show.

column1: Fashion Lady succeeds where the straight techno and noisy sides find an equilibrium. “Cops” matches a steady
column2: uncluttered beat with one synthesizer playing a short sketch of a bass riff and another holding a higher tone
column3: evolving through changes in modulation rather than pitch. On paper that might seem boringly repetitive
column4: but it possesses the same hypnotic power of a classic acid house track
column5: a reminder of
column6: exactly
column7: how sonically strange a lot of classic dance music really was.

column1: Fashion Lady’s center of gravity is located within those moments
column2: which also prove to be the jumping-off point for Gobby's wilder experiments. “Lect Hom” is one of the record's more rhythmically tweaked songs
column3: with a skittering beat that flickers between drum n' bass
column4: Miami electro
column5: and Chicago footwork
column6: topped with a woozy
column7: wobbly bass line and horror movie organ stabs. “VB News” is a murky
column8: overdriven blend of polyrhythmic drumming and dubby synth fantasia. If Blade Runner had a scene involving a cyber-Third-World ayahuasca ceremony
column9: it would be the perfect soundtrack.

column1: Fashion Lady is a fairly bipolar record
column2: and Gobby seems like a fairly bipolar artist-- at least
column3: in creative terms. He constantly tugs back and forth between a dance producer’s desire to bring a crowd together and the noise crowd's opposing infatuation with audience alienation. But the album's most interesting facet is that it never fully succumbs to either impulse. Whether Fashion Lady is a dance record with a noise-minded heart or the other way around
column4: Gobby's propensity to create tension through these competing motivations is compelling
column5:
its central ambiguity providing plenty of fascination.
