Wolf People took to the English countryside to make Fain
column2: because Fain's the kind of record you make in the English countryside. The London foursome's second LP-- third
column3: if you count their sturdy early singles collection Tidings-- harkens back to the days when fife-toting beardos decamped to hillsides to write 18-minute songs about wizards. Indeed
column4: Fain
column5: much like 2010's Steeple
column6: is a progressive rock record of the most British kind: heady
column7: overcast
column8: rooted in English psych-folk
column9: streaked with lightning-flash guitars
column10: thunderous rhythms
column11: and the occasional woodwind. More than anything
column12: music like this is meant to be transportive; surely that's why so much of it came tucked in a triple-gatefold sleeves done up in dragons or dudes in pointy hats. And the shimmering chords of Fain opener ""Empty Vessels"" seem to draw the curtain back on another
column13: promisingly strange little world. But Fain
column14: for all its craggy hillsides and cameos from wizened sages
column15: seems all too content to travel the very same paths of its predecessors without risking the same ridiculousness.

column1: With its amped-up Brit-folk melodies
column2: its pastoral bent
column3: and its occasional flute
column4: Fain
column5: like Steeple before it
column6: owes more than a little something to prog-blues progenitors/expert-level dungeonmasters Jethro Tull. A few softer moments recall less booming Tull contemporaries like Trees; on the heavier end
column7: Fain crashes and bangs like Page and Bonham or Baker and Clapton. Where the fitfully satisfying
column8: decidedly scatterbrained Tidings drew as much from boggy UK psych as it did San Francisco and swinging London
column9: Fain holds onto those few strains of turn-of-the-70s UK rock awfully tight
column10: narrowing its influences in an attempt to expand its scope. Fain does a good job of conjuring atmosphere: the production's crisp
column11: the rhythms punchy
column12: the tension in the air lending everything a certain queasiness. But once you've spent a little time traversing these pathways
column13: you start to feel like you're going in circles.

column1: Most of these songs begin with an explosion
column2: guitar and drums pounding out a carefully calibrated assault. Soon after
column3: frontman Jack Sharp's flickering candle of a voice takes the torch
column4: intoning some far-away wisdom or recalling some long-ago scene. Then the guitars resume their upward climb
column5: clawing their way to a peak of sorts before toppling into the next song. Taken on their own
column6: Fain's constant guitar wig-outs can be electrifying
column7: their blunt force untempered by their jagged complexity. But continually upending Sharp's verses with these fretboard detours leaves Fain feeling disjointed and sapped of its fluidity. Between these corkscrewing guitars
column8: you'll catch glimpses of the world Sharp and company mean to conjure. But Fain thrashes about too much to ever quite come together the way an album like this is supposed to; as distraction-laden as most prog-rock is
column9: Fain seems incapable of holding any one thought for very long without finding it necessary to solo all over it. The instrumental interplay is several clicks past competent
column10: but after a few spins
column11: you find yourself waiting not for particular songs
column12: but individual moments: the way ""Hesperus"" seems to rise a few inches off the ground not quite halfway through
column13: or that trippy little delay-click behind the main riff on ""All Returns"". The rest starts to feel a bit extraneous
column14: interchangeable even
column15: the riffs forced onto these tracks rather than built seamlessly into them.

column1: The spiraling hook of ""When the Fire is Dead in the Grate"" provides Fain with its crowning moment. Over a crashing sea
column2: Sharp recounts a horrific scene: a stormy night
column3: a fire
column4: and footprints in the ash. Yet Sharp-- or whoever he's giving voice to at the moment-- claims to have slept through the whole thing. True
column5: Fain could certainly stand to lose a few of its momentum-sapping guitar blowouts. But what it really needs is more drama
column6: something to elevate it beyond a few half-told tales of yore and a mess of guitars and drums chasing each other around a hillside. Fain clocks in just shy of 45 minutes
column7: with no single track stretching out much past seven minutes
column8: so even all the carefully choreographed guitar whizzbang is kept on a fairly short leash. Sharp's voice is lovely
column9: but he's quite a mannered singer
column10: rarely allowing himself to just go for it. So Fain
column11: for all its geeky underpinnings
column12: never quite seems at ease underneath that wizard cap. The blocky compositions and instrumental rigor certainly make Wolf People a prog band
column13: but progressive? Not particularly. Between its out-of-town origins
column14: its fusty linguistics
column15: and its towering guitar throwbacks
column16: Fain seems to want so desperately to be immersive
column17: world-conjuring
column18: the kind of record you break your weed up on. But by drawing this deeply on both the physical and sonic landscapes of their forebears
column19: and with too many go-nowhere solos blotting out its songs
column20:
Fain winds up feeling stuck in time.

"|18101.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18101-wolf-people-fain/|5.9|Paul Thompson

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19293/homepage_large.199a1849.jpg|Acid Rap|31057.0|Chance the Rapper|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-05-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:13.873571|"

In another world
column2: you can imagine Chance the Rapper lip-syncing “Twist and Shout” at Chicago’s Von Steuben Day parade
column3: surrounded by frauleins doing the money dance. You can visualize a rap game Ferris Bueller: arms outstretched to snare a foul ball
column4: staring stoned at Seurat
column5: ducking fascist educators
column6: and oblivious parents with cinematic ease. You can hear his impression of Abe Froman
column7: sausage king of Chicago
column8: and it’s pitch-perfect.

column1: Barely out of his teens
column2: Chancelor Bennett has already transformed himself from a suspended high school student to the young Chicago rapper universally adored among ""sportos
column3: motorheads
column4: geeks
column5: sluts
column6: bloods
column7: wasteoids
column8: dweebies
column9: and dickheads."" The release of last week’s Acid Rap triggered such intense demand that it crashed both hosting site Audiomack and Windy City rap agora Fake Shore Drive. Cops recently fanned Chance from two separate high school parking lots after mobs formed once kids discovered he was on campus.

column1: But life rarely parallels a John Hughes script. Unlike Bueller
column2: Chance actually got caught skipping school
column3: a 10-day sabbatical that inspired his first mixtape
column4: last year’s #10Day. His neighborhood of West Chatham might not be the worst in a city whose alias is Chiraq
column5: but it’s still South Side and far removed from baronial Highland Park. The drugs are high-velocity
column6: the slang is crisper
column7: and in this scenario
column8: Cameron dies.

column1: The victim was Rodney Kyles Jr.
column2: a close friend who Chance saw get stabbed to death one gruesome night. His memory haunts Acid Rap. On “Juice”
column3: Chance mourns his inability to “be the same since Rod passed.” On “Acid Rain”
column4: he still hears screams and sees “his demons in empty hallways.” The circumstances aren’t necessarily unique. Last year
column5: Chicago murders outnumbered American casualties in Afghanistan. Drill stars
column6: King Louie
column7: Chief Keef
column8: and Lil Durk have given the violence a public face with videos so dark they practically resemble a first-person shooter PS3 game set in Section 8.

column1: Acid Rap isn’t trying to be an alternative; it’s an attempt to encompass everything. There are shout outs
column2: musical or lyrical
column3: to practically every important Chicago tradition short of Thrill Jockey. It invites elements of classic soul
column4: juke
column5: gospel
column6: blues-rock
column7: drill
column8: acid jazz
column9: house
column10: ragtime scat
column11: and R. Kelly
column12: Twista
column13: and a young Kanye to the same open mic poetry night
column14: where the kid on-stage is declaiming about what’s going unreported. Its genius is that he somehow makes this work.

column1: The structure is as expansive and freewheeling as any strange trip. Acid Rap is a less about the attempt to break on through than a way of describing the hallucinatory shades
column2: transitory revelations
column3: and cigarette burns of the journey. You can get off or on the bus at any juncture. There is no ideology or orthodoxy. No arbitrary binaries between conscious or gangster
column4: apostle or agnostic. Freaks and free thinkers are accepted. Chance understands that those who are frightening are often frightened
column5: too. He comes off as a guy who could find something in common with anyone but a high school principal.

column1: Chance mixes nostalgia with a nasal tone as effectively as almost anyone since the Pharcyde. He’s only 20
column2: but “Cocoa Butter Kisses” laments the days of bright-orange Rugrats cassettes and Chuck E. Cheese pizza. It could come off like sentimental back-in-the-day cliché
column3: but there’s a street-smart edge that holds the cheesiness in check. He puts Visine in his eyes so his grandmother won’t know he’s high
column4: acknowledges his addictions
column5: and invites Twista to play the smoked-out
column6: speed-rap
column7: O.G. Jedi.

column1: The guest spots mirror the funhouse characters you’d expect to meet on a memorable acid excursion. Action Bronson offers instant quotables on “NaNa”
column2: sticking out his tongue
column3: slicking back his hair like Rick Pitino
column4: and peeling out in an El Camino with three Japanese lesbians. Ab-Soul plays the shadowy street pharmacist in the liquor store parking lot
column5: opening up the trunk of his Dodge to offer grass
column6: acid
column7: and offside soccer metaphors. Chance’s Save Money crew partner
column8: Vic Mensa and Childish Gambino act as effective co-conspirators.

column1: Some ears won’t settle to Chance’s voice. It occasionally recalls an Animaniac playing the harmonica
column2: a scat singer with a mean soft shoe routine
column3: and/or Lil Wayne and Kendrick Lamar. The latter is his most obvious immediate predecessor and clearly
column4: Chance owes him a stylistic and conceptual debt down to the parental voicemail of “Everything’s Good (Good Ass Outro)”.

column1: But Chance’s vocals are mostly modulated for effect not eccentricity. The cartoon squawk of first single “Juice” bears no resemblance to the mournful Caribbean Kaddish of “Acid Rain”. He leans on his hip-hop inspirations as homage. The intro and outro flip a Baptist hymn from an early Kanye mixtape track. The beat from A Tribe Called Quest’s “Sucka Nigga” is repurposed for “NaNa”. Slum Village’s “Fall in Love” serves as the base for “Everybody’s Something”. 2Pac gets rightful daps on “Juice”. While “Favorite Song” artfully nicks the sample from Mary J. Blige and Biggie’s “Real Love” (Remix).
Even if the voice leaves you cold
column2: you could be sold by the sheer sense of playfulness and love of language. Despite the weighty subtext
column3: it’s often fun and life affirming. Chance stretches syllables to ToonTown lengths. He caroms them off each other like a pool hustler sinking trick shots. He’s a “tobacco-packing acrobat/packin’ bags back and forth with fifths of Jack.” You tend to get swept up in the youthful adrenaline rush like Lamar
column4: mixtape Wayne
column5: early Eminem
column6: or Jay-Z in the ”22 Twos” era. To make sure he has his own spin
column7: Chance stashes his own psychedelics and local slang (“thot
column8: ” “dino
column9: ” “hitters”).

column1: If Lamar’s good kid m.A.A.d city stoked tension through plot cliffhangers
column2: home invasions
column3: and ominous minor chords
column4: Chance’s Acid Rap is a triumph of meditative moments
column5: open-ended quests
column6: and brass flares. The hooks are more jabs than uppercuts. None will probably bang in a club
column7: but most will make sense live
column8: as chanted back by a thousand fans.

column1: “Everybody dies in the summer
column2: wanna say ya goodbyes
column3: tell them while it’s spring

column1: Chance sings this with funereal drone on the second half of “Pusha Man”. It’s the line that keeps sticking in my head when I play the record on loop. It’s a requiem for those already dead and a warning about the imminent carnage coming soon. It’s this fleeting spring afternoon where Acid Rap seems to take place-- the last day off before adulthood-- after you’ve realized your mortality
column2:
but before your fate has been sealed. When you aren’t sure if you’re supposed to say hello or goodbye.

column1:

With a hyper-demanding solo technique
column2: Montreal-based saxophonist Colin Stetson has plowed a unique path through the music landscape in the last five years. His music is heady but always rooted in the body. Stetson uses circular breathing to produce an endless stream of notes in mode of classical minimalism
column3: music that lulls the brain into a sort of reverie. But the unusual production for his solo records
column4: placing microphones close to capture every nuance of sound (the clattering treble of keys
column5: the bassy thump of the pads over the holes
column6: the whoosh of breath
column7: the moan of Stetson’s vocals through the horn)
column8: keeps the hypnotic repetition grounded in an intensely physical now. 2011's New History Warfare Vol. 2: Judges was his breakthrough
column9: an album that appealed to people who had very little time for experimental music that also managed to sound like nothing else. He’s been characteristically busy in the year since
column10: playing solo shows and also touring as a member of Bon Iver
column11: whose leader Justin Vernon is featured prominently on the third part of this solo trilogy.

column1: Though guest vocals on Stetson’s music add a welcome textural wrinkle
column2: it seems like a challenge to figure out exactly how to integrate them. For one
column3: when clear vocals are present
column4: it tends to ground Stetson’s music in genre when it otherwise seems to float somewhere on its own
column5: free of classification. On Judges
column6: that meant the sound of theatrical classical with the calming cerebral articulation of Laurie Anderson
column7: cut with a studied take on blues from Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond. Vernon’s distinctive presence puts this record in a different light
column8: driven home by the fact that opener “And in Truth” starts with a huge spread of his angelic harmonies. For a moment
column9: you feel like you’ve wandered into the next Bon Iver record
column10: and it's slightly disorienting. But the easily identifiable voice is used on four tracks to different ends
column11: affirming Vernon’s ability to adapt his style to the project at hand.

column1: The most striking bit of shapeshifting comes on “Brute”
column2: where Vernon assumes the Cookie Monster bark of a death metal frontman and turns out to be very good at it. Giving Stetson’s skill at conveying menace and the darkly churning low end of his work on the bigger horns
column3: a metal lean to the music makes perfect sense and maybe even seems inevitable. “Brute” feels like the soundtrack to a child’s nightmare
column4: and the fact that it sits so easily next to the subsequent “Among the Sef”
column5: which feels like a triumphant
column6: tightly appreciated fanfare celebrating everything that is good in the world
column7: is a testament to all that Stetson can render from his instrument.

column1: Indeed
column2: To See More Light shows impressive range. In some respects
column3: Stetson seems to have gravitated toward the extremes while leaving the minimalist tapestries in the background. At some points
column4: like on “High Above a Grey Green Sea”
column5: and “Part of Me Apart From You”
column6: his tone is especially gnarled and biting and feels connected spiritually to the dark forces of heavy metal. But “And in Truth” and the multi-tracked Vernon guest vocal on the cover of the spiritual “What Are They Doing in Heaven Today?” are warm and human
column7: more earthy folk than heady art music. The centerpiece that binds it all together is the 15-minute title track
column8: which moans and swoons and moves between sections like a work of romantic classical music. It is perhaps Stetson’s most powerful single track
column9: though it takes some serious focus to absorb in one sitting.

column1: Heard as the closing chapter in Stetson’s trilogy
column2: To See More Light feels essentially like more: it’s more intense
column3: more sprawling
column4: both darker and lighter simultaneously. And in one sense
column5: the record’s marked ambition can make it a harder listen as a whole
column6: as it moves through moods and modes and seems constantly on the verge of burning itself out. But the album’s sequencing and the essential facts of its live
column7: in-the-moment construction keep it flowing like a singular statement
column8:
at times just barely. None of which takes away from Stetson’s hugely impressive achievement: We’re here in 2013 and and he’s spinning out pieces in real-time using common instruments and the result is a sound that could come only from one person on earth.

"|17950.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17950-colin-stetson-new-history-warfare-vol-3/|8.1|Mark Richardson

""Melter's Delight""
column2: the first single from Co La's second album Moody Coup
column3: features a sample from the Upsetters' ""Cloak a Dagger""
column4: a voice introducing the track as ""Music to make you stagger!"" It's a lovely line
column5: and its boastful
column6: confident tone runs counter to Co La's practiced docility. This type of fake exotica-- the desire to displace yourself
column7: but only gently so-- is Co La's M.O.. On Moody Coup he idles more purposefully than on his debut
column8: Daydream Repeater
column9: kneading his many samples into frothy
column10: dubwise vignettes that tickle with recognition.

column1: Co La burdened his debut with a lackadaisical approach to sampling
column2: leaving recognizable snippets (the Supremes!) relatively untreated and then doubling down by looping them ad nauseum. Moody Coup represents a compositional step up
column3: with Co La smoothing many of the seams that showed on Repeater. His samples are better hidden and the tracks
column4: while plenty rhythmic
column5: are no longer quite so stubborn. An infusion of sub-bass turns unassuming moments into a surprise rattle. Vocals from ex-Dirty Projector Angel Deradoorian mean that this album's melodies aren't entirely outsourced. The result is like a baby-shampoo version of Black Dice: lots of rustle and friction but nothing that would hurt your eyes.

column1: This explains why Moody Coup
column2: despite a wide range of sounds (reggae
column3: barbershop
column4: ambient
column5: techno)
column6: spins so easily. Tracks such as ""Remarkable Features"" and ""Head in Hole in Space"" are summer storms: They come together quickly
column7: make a little noise
column8: and move on. This will sound like a backhanded compliment
column9: but Moody Coup is an album that doesn't necessarily reward close listening
column10: because Moody Coup is an album where the details don't necessarily matter that much. ""Baby's Breath"" stirs bongos
column11: childrens' laughter
column12: and what sounds like dripping water
column13: but sussing out the ingredients isn't nearly as gratifying as letting the song's carbonation hiss and fizzle. On ""Make It Slay (Barbershop Solo)"" and ""Un""
column14: Co La approaches the snap-and-crackle noir of Nicolas Jaar but filters out the dance DNA
column15: leaving amiable puddles of sound.

column1: When you're in the sound-art game
column2: the flipside of friendly and gentle is frivolous
column3: an accusation that does get lobbed at Co La. Moody Coup succeeds
column4: though
column5: because of how naturally it comes together
column6: because of how deftly it mimics the rhythms of
column7: say
column8: whiling away a Saturday afternoon. It takes skill to be both abstract and inclusive-- ask Four Tet-- so it's not an accident that Co La's sampledelia lands so softly. Moody Coup is the ""take only pictures
column9:
leave only footprints"" sign at the gates of experimental music: an ode to niceness.

For a time in the early 2000s
column2: British guitar rock experienced a flood of activity that buoyed the nation’s music press into believing that for the first time in ages they didn’t actually need the Gallagher brothers to sell magazines. In this environment
column3: the Coral’s slapdash retread of 60s freakbeat and organ-driven psych rock garnered an enthusiastic reception from critics and festival-goers alike
column4: with sloppy but catchy singles like “Dreaming of You” and “In the Morning” bottling just enough youthful exuberance from the six Liverpudlians to cover up their limited musicianship. But while more interesting bands from the period have fallen by the wayside over the years
column5: the Coral trundle on
column6: releasing dulled retreads of the same record every couple of years that chart reasonably well but show little motivation on the band's part to break out of their narrow
column7: retro frame of reference.

column1: Surprisingly
column2: when Bill Ryder-Jones became the first member to exit the group in 2008
column3: the guitarist made an about turn from their sound
column4: scoring a couple of low budget short films before cutting an accomplished solo debut. Pitched as a musical adaptation of Italian writer Italo Calvino’s 1979 novel If on a Winters Night a Traveler
column5: 2011's If... was predominantly an instrumental effort
column6: incorporating immense string sections courtesy of the Liverpool Philharmonic orchestra and complimented with Jon Brion-like sonic flourishes. On centerpiece ""Enlace""
column7: there was even a sizzling prog rock workout. As it turned out
column8: the man credited as being key to sculpting the Coral’s slack orchestrations actually had ample creativity when left to his own devices.

column1: Stripping away much of what made his previous record a gripping listen
column2: Ryder-Jones takes a quieter approach on follow-up A Bad Wind Blows in My Heart
column3: a set of pensive singer-songwriter ballads and hushed pop songs in the vein of Alex Turner’s Submarine soundtrack
column4: an EP on which Ryder-Jones played guitar. Taking his lead from director Richard Ayoade’s charming depiction of awkward adolescent angst
column5: Turner’s wistful melodies and vibrant tales of a burgeoning teen romance were a dead-on accompaniment to the film’s quirky presentation. But despite recording in his boyhood bedroom and recruiting Submarine producer
column6: Simian Mobile Disco's James Ford
column7: to polish the set
column8: Ryder-Jones' autobiographical anecdotes fail to bottle the same sentiment. His narratives wilt beneath tired imagery and stock similes like “There was something in the air that night
column9: ” (“Hanging Song”) and “It’s not over ‘til I say it’s over” (“Wild Swans”). If you think A Bad Wind Blows in My Heart is a clumsy title
column10: be prepared to sit through two whole tracks of the lyric being repeated over and over again.

column1: What’s most disappointing about the album is how Ryder-Jones has almost completely abandoned taking any sonic risks. His vocal is dulled and rasping throughout
column2: and the songs never blossom like those on If...
column3: seemingly hamstrung by his limited range. It’s not an entire bust though. The acoustic plucks and clean melody of “By Morning I” recall early Belle and Sebastian
column4: while the tender ode to childhood friendship “Anthony & Owen” recalls If...’s more sweeping arrangements
column5: playing to Ryder-Jones’s strengths
column6: which are not insignificant
column7:
if sadly underused here.

Providence
column2: RI’s Howl know how to put the frighteners on listeners before they've even pressed play: The cover for their excellent self-titled
column3: three-song debut depicted a skeleton with her hair blowing in the black wind
column4: with angel wings sprouting beneath a pentagram. 2010's Full of Hell showed a fire-breathing figure cloaked in red and surrounded by creepy
column5: isolated eyeballs. And now Bloodlines offers a verifiable general store of evil-- a heart spurting blood fashioned into flower blossoms
column6: a vacant-eyed wolf snarling up at a naked woman with bleeding eyes
column7: a skeleton wielding a spear against a background of oblivion. And in a catalog of less than two dozen total tunes
column8: Howl have landed memorably frightening handles such as “And the Gnawing…”
column9: “Gods in Broken Men”
column10: “The Scorpion’s Last Sting”
column11: and “Your Hell Begins”. You’re shuddering
column12: right?

column1: Bloodlines is the band’s second LP for Relapse Records
column2: and actually works hard not to repel with fright
column3: despite its image
column4: titles
column5: and lyrics rife with dismemberment
column6: boiled blood
column7: and sin. In fact
column8: its mix of stoner doom
column9: mid-level thrash
column10: and shout-along hooks wants desperately to be loved
column11: for its bulging choruses about “kill[ing] the light” and being torn “limb from limb” to be recited with grim glee. But Bloodlines’ attempt to be liked comes across as the desperate pandering of a band that’s not really certain of what it wants to do anymore. At the start of their career
column12: HOWL was a righteous doom band propelled by hardcore momentum; by the time they recorded Full of Hell
column13: they’d galvanized that mixture into a savage
column14: head-down bluster that suggested High on Fire and was intoxicated with promise. Bloodlines shows traces of that
column15: but the band’s roots are largely crowded out by the need to do a little bit of everything
column16: to connect en masse in only 40 minutes. But the gambit doesn’t work
column17: because
column18: from end to end
column19: HOWL now sounds like a band that’s just trying too hard.

column1: Chris Harris
column2: better known as Zeuss
column3: produced Bloodlines. You might recognize his mononym from albums by God Forbid
column4: Shadows Fall
column5: Hatebreed
column6: and Terror-- that is
column7: slicker
column8: faster stuff than that of HOWL’s past. It’s a harbinger of the trouble on Bloodlines
column9: too
column10: a technically accomplished album where you kind of wish the band would make a mistake. That
column11: at least
column12: would make them feel somewhat as dangerous as their image suggests. Instead
column13: HOWL delivers songs with big
column14: dumb refrains that feel rushed (“Midnight Eyes”)
column15: magpie messes that volley awkwardly between death metal and stoner rock (“With a Blade”)
column16: and flashy solos that propel the players and not the songs themselves (“Attrition”
column17: whose intro reads like a statement of nascent professionalism). Frontman Vince Hausman screams the words to ""Demonic"" in his most malevolent brogue
column18: but this is really just a middling
column19: mid-tempo
column20: metalcore slog. If this is intense as HOWL intended Bloodlines to get
column21: they should have run the cover through a Lisa Frank filter.

column1: There are
column2: of course
column3: moments of genuine excitement during Bloodlines: The amplified blues riff at the start of “With a Blade” is a swiveling delight
column4: and the rhythm section pounding from one end of “Demonic” to the other delivers an enthusiastic bruising. Many of the individual performances are excellent; drummer Timmy St. Amour
column5: for instance
column6: sounds inexhaustible. But the album’s only complete keeper
column7: “Down So Low”
column8: epitomizes the flaw of Bloodlines as a whole. Whirs of noise introduce the tune
column9: which ultimately arrives at a half-time stomp where the drums are restless and the vocals (split here between Hausman and bassist Robert Icaza) are menacing. It manages to give HOWL’s low-slung doom progenitors an invigorating jolt
column10:
and the band hammers hard enough to sound like they’re truly enjoying themselves in the coda-- a rarity on a record that seems too measured and deliberate to allow for much real delight.

Before their show in Seattle last month
column3: London four-piece Savages posted a sign around the venue that laid out a couple of ground rules: no Instagramming
column4: no video
column5: no tweets-- in short
column6: ""SILENCE YOUR PHONES."" This could be seen as a part of a growing trend of bands pointing out how sick they are of looking out into a sea of smartphones rather than human faces (the Yeah Yeah Yeahs posted a similar missive at their recent New York homecoming show)
column7: but it felt more like an extension of Savages’ overall manifesto. And no
column8: “manifesto” is not too dramatic a word; especially in contrast with the Yeah Yeah Yeahs’ sign
column9: which tempered its message with chatty humor (“PUT THAT SHIT AWAY!...MUCH LOVE AND MANY THANKS!”)
column10: Savages’ fiery imperative read like something hammered onto a door. ""OUR GOAL IS TO DISCOVER BETTER WAYS OF LIVING AND EXPERIENCING MUSIC
column11: ” they wrote (caps theirs). “WE BELIEVE THAT THE USE OF PHONES DURING A GIG PREVENTS ALL OF US FROM TOTALLY IMMERSING OURSELVES."" Ironically
column12: their ability to see the value of silence in a world of noise might make Savages the most web-savvy band of the year. People have been tweeting and tumbling about their live shows the way that people used to talk about live shows: something you just have to see for yourself.

column1: If you've paid even the slightest attention to Savages in the year leading up to their debut Silence Yourself
column2: you know that this is how they do things-- in fact
column3: it's very likely you knew something about their philosophy before you heard a note of their music. Whether you find it profoundly refreshing or a little tedious that Savages draw lines in the sand
column4: none of this would be worth mentioning if the music didn’t live up to the force of the message. Silence Yourself proves that Savages are more than just talk. It's one of rock’s most commanding and ferociously poised debuts in recent years
column5: the work of a band whose outsized confidence and sharp clarity of vision doesn’t correlate with the short amount of time it’s been together.

column1: Savages' music feels out of step with current trends-- which I'm sure they'd take as a compliment. With its tumbling
column2: tom-heavy percussion
column3: singer  Jehnny Beth's Siouxsie-summoning battle cries
column4: and the compositional emphasis placed on Ayse Hassan’s bass (in the moments when Beth is silent
column5: the bass feels like Savages’ lead singer)
column6: post-punk is Silence Yourself’s most obvious sonic reference point. And it doesn’t matter that they missed the post-punk revival by about a decade. While the bands that dominated indie rock in the early aughts looked to Joy Division and Gang of Four for reasons that had mostly to do with rhythm
column7: Savages’ music finds kinship with post-punk’s oppositional politics
column8: thematic darkness
column9: and anxiety about the dehumanizing effects of technology-- the spirit is the same
column10: but it’s been adjusted to reflect the times. Savages’ distaste for experiencing life through a screen comes from the same place as
column11: say
column12: Wire’s sardonic take on viewers whose idea of adventure was living vicariously through “the Lone Ranger”; after all
column13: if “Ex Lion Tamer” were written today
column14: it’d probably go
column15: “Stay glued to your iPhone.”

column1: Which is not to say that Savages are writing scathing songs about shitty service providers; their lyrics are boldly stark
column2: elemental
column3: and timeless. (The titles alone hit with a blunt force: “She Will”
column4: “Hit Me”
column5: “No Face”
column6: “Shut Up.”) Beth has said that the band’s writing process is less about addition than subtraction
column7: paring each song down to its most essential shape. All of the best songs on Silence Yourself derive their power from this kind of focused intensity
column8: from the driving
column9: dissonant “City’s Full” to the creeping
column10: percussive lurch of “I Am Here”. The chorus of “Husbands”
column11: a phenomenal single first released last year
column12: sharpens that focus down to a single word. “I woke up and saw the face of a guy/ I don’t know who he is
column13: ” Beth sings in the song’s paranoia-inducing opening moments. A Savages song is about challenging the ideas
column14: words and desires we consider “normal”
column15: and they’ve found that repetition is an effective way to get that point across. “Husbands
column16: husbands
column17: husbands
column18: husbands
column19: husbands
column20: husbands
column21: ” Beth chants in a manic whisper; with each intonation
column22: the meaning erodes from a word that’s ostensibly meant to evoke comfort
column23: protection and familiarity until it feels faceless.

column1: Savages really show promise and range on the slow-burners. The moody dirge ""Waiting for a Sign"" and goth-cabaret closer ""Marshall Dear"" aren't the most immediate songs on the record
column2: but over repeated listens
column3: they bloom. If Hassan and Faye Milton's punishing rhythm section takes the helm on the more frantic numbers
column4: Savages' downtempo moments allow Gemma Thompson and her scuzzy Fender to shine. On the excellent ""Strife
column5: she holds back as often as she strikes
column6: underscoring Beth's most brutal lines with perfectly timed jolts and filling the song's winding corriders with thick plumes of distortion.

column1: The mix allows each band member’s contribution to smolder with equal intensity and lends a palpable physicality to Savages’ sound. Milton handles her toms and bass drum like a boxer going at a punching bag; Hassan’s bass strings pulsate like a throbbing tendons; Thompson’s guitar cuts with a goosebump-inducing tone that recalls a chainsaw
column2: and Beth shrieks like she’s resetting her own bones. Combining in a constant pendulum swing between tension and release
column3: it all provides the perfect atmosphere for the darkly sensual themes that Silence Yourself explores.

column1: As a lyricist
column2: Beth says she’s inspired by the “awkward places” from which “twisted
column3: original desires” spring. “Hit Me”
column4: a sub-two-minute tornado of squalling noise
column5: isn’t about domestic abuse
column6: as some people assume
column7: but is instead about a consensual encounter described by the porn star Belladonna. (Beth: “I hate it when women are turned into victims.”) Savages might make political pronouncements in interviews and on album covers
column8: but their songs come from a lived-in perspective as Beth inhabits her different characters’ states of mind-- and forces the listener to do the same.

column1: ""How old are you
column2: really?"" a voice asks in the opening seconds of the album; it hovers in the air without an answer. It might be a knowing sneer at critics who think Savages are just recycling post-punk’s signature sound
column3: but ostensibly it’s also a salute to an artistic kindred spirit. The line is from Opening Night
column4: a 1977 movie by John Cassavetes-- a filmmaker who also saw a kind of beauty in emotional brutality and was prone to spouting off humanist manifestos. “My films are expressive of a culture that has had the possibility of attaining material fulfillment while at the same time finding itself unable to accomplish the simple business of conducting human lives
column5: ” he said. “What is needed is reassurance in human emotions; a re-evaluation of our emotional capacities.” Substitute “films” for “songs” and those words could almost be lifted off the cover of Silence Yourself. The album cuts through a world of chatter and distraction because it practices what it preaches
column6: transmitting its message directly through the primal
column7:
bone-rattling force of its songs.

"|17977.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17977-savages-silence-yourself/|8.7|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19199/homepage_large.1d233f48.jpg|Songs Cycled|8485.0|Van Dyke Parks|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bella Union']|2013-05-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:18.064477|"

Whole-tone mandolin plinks
column2: the playful hiccup of an accordion
column3: waves of strings
column4: and a middle school band closet's worth of the finest Latin percussion: 10 seconds into Songs Cycled and it's already hard to imagine blaming this music on anyone but Van Dyke Parks.

column1: His first high-profile job was as an arranger from songs from Disney's The Jungle Book
column2: and almost nothing about his essential style has changed since. A Van Dyke Parks song is fussy
column3: dense
column4: and well-mannered but has a flair for mischief. It is simple in rhythm but complex in harmony. It is preferential to funny noises. It is deeply American-- like banjos on the porch American-- and yet like all good American things is preoccupied by what it finds exotic
column5: whether it's Trinidadian Calypso or mid-period French Romanticism. It can be broken down into a million pieces and subjected to intense ethnomusicological analysis. The best of them also happen to be easy and satisfying to whistle.

column1: Songs Cycled collects six 7"" singles he has released over the past few years through his own label
column2: Bananastan. ""Bananastan"" is a very Parksian construction: A fictional foreign country named after something people eat for breakfast. (It's out now on Bella Union in the UK and in July in the US.) Like all his albums
column3: it's cheerful and maddeningly detailed. At times it can feel like musical theater minus the stage
column4: or like a tiny jewelry box
column5: beautiful to behold but too small to actually put anything in. Its songs reflect dryly on corporate greed and joyfully on a woman named Sassafras
column6: whose kisses are so hot she turns swimming holes to steam.

column1: A lot of what's here has appeared before
column2: elsewhere and in different forms. ""The All Golden"" was on his 1968 debut Song Cycle; ""Hold Back Time"" was on his 1995 collaboration with the Beach Boys's Brian Wilson
column3: Orange Crate Art. ""Aquarium"" is actually a 1971 recording of the Esso Trinidad Steel Band
column4: performing Parks's arrangement of a section from Camille Saint-Saëns's The Carnival of the Animals.

column1: And then there’s the traditional music that belongs to nobody. ""Amazing Grace"" appears briefly
column2: as does the indestructible hymn ""Leaning on the Everlasting Arms"". ""The Parting Hand"" is a song traditionally sung in Sacred Harp meetings
column3: a type of unaccompanied choral music known for its clear
column4: bellowing sound. When they appear they appear more as quotes than centerpieces; small towns seen from trains.

column1: It makes sense that Parks retreads older material: He is one of those rare artists who seems to have come out fully formed
column2: with a clear
column3: narrow and diamond-hard vision of what he wanted his music to be. Listening to his discography can be like listening to a manic
column4: brilliant person try and explain the same idea to you over and over again from slightly different perspectives
column5: flapping their hands excitedly
column6: sulking when you confess you still don't quite get it
column7: then waving it all away with yet another joke you won't understand until three hours later.

column1: One of the ironies of Parks's music is that there's so much going on that it can be hard to figure out what to pay attention to. He rarely sticks to a single theme or emotion. (""Busy"" is not an emotion.) He is fluent in simple folksy languages but has a compulsion about speaking in any fewer than five of them at once. Rich
column2: dense moments worthy of human attention fly by one after the other
column3: like a wall where pictures are hung frame-to-frame.

column1: At best Songs Cycled deals in quick-pivot moments: the stark
column2: unified sound of the choir on ""The Parting Hand"" giving way to a misty string section
column3: or Parks's wiry voice snapping out of the confusion of ""Wall Street"" with a line like ""There is just nothing but ash in the air/ Confetti all colored with blood."" What these moments do-- especially in the context of music so dense and restless-- is frame Parks's range. In an instant
column4: he reminds you of the extremes he's capable of: Cynicism and tenderness; clear lyricism and manic density; buttoned-up orchestras and dressed-down steel bands.

column1: I often think I would like his music more if it were simpler and more direct. Clearly he's capable of it. (I've always liked 1972's Discover America best partially beacuse it allows me to imagine Parks as a cruise-ship entertainment director
column2: but more because it just isn't as cluttered as some of his other albums.)

column1: But his stubbornness is part of who he is. ""I guess I am like that rusty nail that sticks out
column2: just waiting to be hammered down by an intolerant bastard
column3: he wrote this year. In 1968
column4: at the hight of blues-derived psychedelic rock
column5: he released <i>Song Cycle
column6: an album essentially rejecting all music made after 1940. Under his suspenders and little straw hats
column7: Van Dyke Parks is often crafting some highly refined iteration of the sentiment fuck y'all.

column1: Ultimately
column2: he's an artist whose shortcomings are all products of his ambition. There are worse places to be. Some artists run out of ideas; Parks seems to constantly have three more than the typical cognitive load of the human brain allows.

column1: His albums don't capture lightning in a bottle
column2: they exist as documents of all the effort he put into them. In the end it's that effort-- that joyful
column3: obssessive effort of the solitary man tinkering in his study from sunup to sundown again-- that makes him sympathetic. ""Lest I get ahead of you
column4: he wrote in 2011. ""My heart will be in the work."" Not ""art
column5: not ""expression
column6: but work: that thing we all have to do but only at our best seem to enjoy doing. ""Work"" is-- and has always been-- Parks's forte. If he misses the forest for the trees it's only because he's having too much fun sculpting the ridges on each beautiful inch of bark.

column1:
[Note: Songs Cycled is out now in the UK via Bella Union and on July 23 in the US via the same label. ]

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lex']|2013-05-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:18.549952|"

There's probably a reason the biographical album doesn't have a strong pop tradition. Lou Reed and John Cale advocated for the genius of Andy Warhol with some success on on 1990's Songs for Drella
column3: and Neutral Milk Hotel's 1998 indie-rock touchstone In the Aeroplane Over the Sea draws on the life story of Anne Frank. But unlike Hollywood biopics
column4: which strike Oscar gold almost annually
column5: bio-albums are few and far between.

column1: If anyone can popularize the bio-album concept
column2: it should be Gruff Rhys and Bryan Hollon. Whether solo or as frontman for long-running Welsh psych-pop anarchists Super Furry Animals
column3: Rhys has always had a knack for communicating lofty ideas with sly wit
column4: warm feeling
column5: and memorably inventive settings. Hollon
column6: an accomplished experimental hip-hop producer/DJ in his own right as Boom Bip
column7: updated 1980s new wave and electro masterfully on his first album with Rhys as Neon Neon
column8: 2008's Stainless Style.

column1: Though that Mercury Music Prize-nominated full-length was inspired by the life of automaker John DeLorean
column2: in a sense Neon Neon's second effort represents their first true bio-album. The silvery
column3: retro-futurist excess of the greed-is-good decade pervaded Stainless Style
column4: and lyrical references to the engineer playboy's life were certainly present
column5: but the record was stuffed with great songs that humanized 80s-retro clichés whether or not you knew there was a story attached. Praxis Makes Perfect's songs never quite hit the highs of its predecessor's best tracks
column6: but it's a more coherent album
column7: and still strangely rewarding in its own way. It's just impossible to separate from its subject.

column1: That subject is Giangiacomo Feltrinelli
column2: a wealthy Italian scion turned left-wing political activist and publisher. He smuggled Boris Pasternak's Doctor Zhivago out of Soviet Russia
column3: published books banned as obscene in Italy-- including Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer-- and played basketball with Fidel Castro in 1960s Cuba. You know that famous image of Che Guevara? Feltrinelli acquired and popularized it. He died
column4: under disputed circumstances
column5: near Milan in 1972
column6: where authorities said he accidentally blew himself up in an act of leftism terrorism against the capitalist structure.

column1: Feltrinelli's story
column2: in other words
column3: is as weird and fascinating in its own way as DeLorean's
column4: full of unlikely contradictions that make it ripe for dramatization. What's all the more intriguing is that Neon Neon choose to tell the story not with the musical styles of Feltrinelli's own lifetime
column5: but with much the same deceptively plasticized synth pop as on Stainless Style. It's as if we're experiencing Feltrinelli's life through the lens of his ultimate failure-- from the perspective of a world where revolutionary idealism had given way to the start of corporate consumer capitalism as we now know it. Imagine if ""Mad Men"" had Debbie Gibson on the soundtrack.

column1: The anachronism is delicious
column2: and when Neon Neon succeed in wedding their high-minded tale to wryly tacky throwback pop
column3: the juxtapositions can be similarly satisfying. ""Dr. Zhivago"" has a chorus so soaring it should get the name Pasternak stuck your head even if you can't pronounce it. ""Mid Century Modern Nightmare"" is another highlight
column4: making rhyming ""bourgeoisie"" with ""tea"" sound not only natural but desirable amid its peppy new-wave clatter. Shuffling first video selection ""Hammer & Sickle"" offers one more unshakable refrain
column5: this time about ""the winner
column6: the loser
column7: and the middle man.""

column1: Sometimes the audacious lengths to which Neon Neon carry their outlandish conceit lifts up songs that might otherwise fall flat. Those unfamiliar with the full details of Feltrinelli's life story might not fully understand how consumerist ode ""Shopping (I Like To)""-- frosty synth-pop that melodically hints at Hall and Oates' ""Maneater""-- fits in. But the fact that Rhys and Hollon have roped in a husky guest vocal from Italian model-singer Sabrina Salerno
column2: who scored a campy 80s Europop hit with ""Boys (Summertime Love)""
column3: is a master stroke of grinning cheekiness. Elsewhere
column4: the actress Asia Argento
column5: daughter of Italian horror director Dario Argento
column6: gives voice to quotes from Feltrinelli himself
column7: ensuring for better or worse that unlike on Stainless Style
column8: here our hero is rarely far from mind.

column1: It's telling
column2: though
column3: that Neon Neon
column4: along with National Theatre Wales
column5: have put together an ""immersive theatrical experience"" based on the album. The record alone makes for the latest solid effort from these two outsize talents
column6: but the stage show ought to be the ideal way to enjoy it. When the songs drag
column7: as they do here toward the end
column8: on tracks like horn-bleating ""Listen to the Rainbow""
column9: they should still be effective as a soundtrack to a visual performance. Rhys
column10: in particular
column11: has a way with high-concept gigs: He billed his off-the-wall 2010 solo tour as a quest to follow in the footsteps of an 18th-century Welsh explorer who searched America for a mythical tribe of Welsh-speaking Native Americans. And after all
column12: if the Marxist notion of ""praxis"" had to do with turning philosophy into action
column13: then a live show based on Praxis should make its cheerful Reagonomics-chic radicalism truly-- sorry
column14: but Rhys does loves his puns-- perfect. The bio-album
column15: sadly
column16:
might still be an idea whose time has not yet come.

column3: Altar of Plagues frontman James Kelly talked about his band’s enormous black metal landscapes as though his Irish trio played free jazz: The group
column4: he said
column5: would lay dormant for extended periods and then work obsessively in an isolated
column6: caffeine-fueled state for two-week bursts
column7: using that sporadic schedule to create music that capitalized more on feeling than technicality. “With us
column8: it’s almost let it write itself. That allows us to engage with it more
column9: too
column10: because it’s so repetitive
column11: ” Kelly said
column12: explaining the oblong and unordinary structures of the four massive songs on Mammal
column13: the band’s second LP. “We just let it grow.” Kelly also called Miles Davis’ Bitches Brew the most inspirational music he’d ever heard
column14: compared Arvo Pärt to Emperor
column15: mentioned his excellent muted dance productions under the name Wife
column16: and called jazz “fire from the soul.”

column1: Kelly’s references and enthusiasms did not adhere at all to any metal-dude stereotypes
column2: and to an extent
column3: that’s long been the fount of intrigue at the center of Altar of Plague’s music. Their post-metal
column4: if one must call it that
column5: took unexpected turns
column6: with moments of ruthless industrial slink or minimal improvisations that turned suddenly to mournful throat signing embedded within more standard forms of aggression. They could roar
column7: too
column8: working themselves into sustained roils that gave any accusations of hipster or dilettante metal a direct and devastating gut punch.

column1: Teethed Glory and Injury
column2: the third LP from Altar of Plagues
column3: is again intended to do exactly that but in a much different way than before. “I just found that the type of black metal we were being associated with was not exciting to me anymore
column4: ” Kelly told Terrorizer in an in-studio interview earlier this year. “What a few years ago was a very exciting and promising template for a genre … has also just been watered down.” Both Mammal and 2009’s White Tomb comprised just four tracks each
column5: with the shortest pushing past the eight-minute mark. But Altar of Plagues pushes the action back toward the center of the song on Teethed Glory
column6: a nine-piece set that favors a more immediate four-to-five minute range. This is a dense and demanding record
column7: where fragments of black metal slam into shards of industrial throb
column8: where sheets of noise work alongside diaphanous electronics. Moments suggest the heyday of Touch and Go Records and
column9: alternately
column10: Nine Inch Nails in Trent Reznor’s commanding prime or Swans at their vitriolic apex. Several electronic impasses are as dense as those of Altar of Plague cohorts the Haxan Cloak
column11: while others could pass as tinted Boards of Canada fragments.

column1: If that matrix of touchstones sounds intriguing
column2: it often is; indeed
column3: with Teethed Glory and Injury
column4: Kelly’s reputation as an avid and eclectic listener feels fully represented by the music his band makes. However
column5: the other alluring aspect of Altar of Plague’s music-- the jazz-like ease with which it was made and
column6: consequently
column7: unfolded-- has almost altogether disappeared. Every moment of Teethed Glory feels like a deliberate plot point
column8: built to fly squarely in the face of any expectations for this brand of aggrandized heaviness. The omission of that free-and-easy mentality isn’t a problem because of the songs’ relative brevity; rather
column9: the pieces within Teethed Glory often feel forced together
column10: coerced into collisions that don’t meld the components so much as stack them side by side.

column1: Altar of Plagues overthinks and overstuffs here
column2: creating a gauntlet that defaces its own delight. “Burnt Year”
column3: for instance
column4: opens with an almost phosphorescent surge of distorted guitar and bass thrum
column5: funneling into a belligerent
column6: howl-along march that suggests the work of Ministry. By song’s end
column7: Altar of Plagues has ripped through an atavistic black metal sprint
column8: dipped into dreamy moments of rest and ultimately arrived at an instrumental surge that suggests the rocky peaks of Pelican. On “A Body Shrouded”
column9: Altar of Plagues' seesaw between post-punk simmer and doom-like pounce adulterates both aspects. Individually
column10: they’re interesting
column11: but taken together
column12: they simply feel claustrophobic. It’s a problem that hounds most of Teethed Glory
column13: a string of compelling parts that does not compel as a whole

column1: The album’s most successful songs are also its most fully synthesized: “Twelve was Ruin”
column2: for instance
column3: pairs Kelly’s blossoming electronic touch to Altar of Plagues' previous sense of sprawl and current sense of attack. It builds through icy keyboards and scythe-shaped guitars
column4: culminating in a coda that’s urgent and intricate
column5: two qualities that often combat one another throughout Teethed Glory. And the record’s first single
column6: “God Alone”
column7: is written so well that its most brutal stretches dovetail perfectly with its more delicate moments. It all cascades into a chorus that sounds as soft as Alcest but as savage as Immortal.

column1: Though Teethed Glory and Injury doesn’t deliver the systemic and singular rupture Kelly and his band might have intended
column2: it should not diminish the excitement for Altar of Plagues’ revolutionary compulsion. If anything
column3: the trio have proven here that they’re driven only by the need to subvert and shock
column4: to weld rather traditional ideas into strange new hybrids. The possibilities that Teethed Glory and Injury present are more interesting than the album itself--and
column5: really
column6: more interesting than the possibilities presented by any Altar of Plagues music to date. Maybe next time
column7:
they’ll write themselves into reality.

Like your grandfather or your youth football coach
column2: Omar S grouses to conceal the fact that he's growing softer and more loving. There's a reason for the enigmatic Detroit producer's tough love: to keep us sharp

column1: On 2011's It Can Be Done But Only I Can Do It

column5: though

column7: berating us with kindness
column8: offering wistful
column9: major-key tracks out of step with Omar's reputation for hissy lo-fi concoctions.

column2: proto-house compositions resembled Kraftwerk as often as
column3: say
column4: Derrick Carter
column5: and parts of Thank You feel like homages to classic house tropes. ""The Shit Baby"" features a deft
column6: familiar piano solo. ""Rewind"" is salty
column7: low-overhead R&B. ""Air of the Day"" unfurls slowly

column1: Instances of Omar's crankiness come off as mere window dressing or
column2: better yet

column4: he replied ""Only a momma's boy cares about artwork!!"" The resulting art-- of Omar nonchalantly kneeling (above)
column5: then standing next to a Corvette-- does not rule out the possibility that he'd simply forgotten he needed album art. If you still need proof of Omar's softening
column6: though

column10:
begrudging concession: feel-good music from a feel-bad guy.

Bigmouth strikes again: the latest target of Bradford Cox's verbal jabs was none other than Morrissey himself
column2: but this particular barrage had a precision of intent that went overlooked by most online gawkers. ""Have you ever read Morrissey's description of the Ramones?
column3: he asked Buzzfeed. ""I will always be on Team Joey
column4: and Team Dee Dee. I come from America
column5: where Bo Diddley was born!"" While Deerhunter's always had a thing for indie rock advocacy
column6: Cox's pointed patriotism was a new kind of stump speech
column7: and in light of <i>Monomania
column8: his typically hilarious candor doubled as media savvy. On Deerhunter’s fifth album
column9: they almost completely jettison the dreamy ambience that tempered even their noisiest work for straight-up raw
column10: bleeding garage rock and populate these songs with junkyards
column11: leather jackets
column12: and motorcycles. The message from Deerhunter: We’re an American band.

column1: So adjust your expectations accordingly
column2: and if this sounds like the protracted playacting usually associated with Cox's work as Atlas Sound
column3: you’re on the right track. The stable democracy of the past few Deerhunter albums has been upended; Josh Fauver left the band
column4: and besides writing most of “Nothing Ever Happened”
column5: his basslines kept Deerhunter rooted in proper rock. Meanwhile
column6: after increasingly proving himself to be a top-notch songwriter in his own right
column7: Lockett Pundt took advantage of a rare year in which Cox released no new music by dropping the excellent Spooky Action At A Distance as Lotus Plaza in 2012. His sole contribution on Monomania is “The Missing”
column8: a fine piece of wistful
column9: ringing indie pop that gets placed between “Leather Jacket II” and “Pensacola”
column10: the album’s raunchiest songs. It could easily be seen as Cox defending his turf
column11: if not for a hazy
column12: meditative stretch during the middle of Monomania that sounds like his take on Lotus Plaza.

column1: But while the songwriting power has become centralized
column2: Monomania as a whole represents Deerhunter’s attempt to get outside themselves. This is particularly true of Cox; whereas on Cryptograms’ “Hazel St.”
column3: he imagined what it might be like to fit in with the normal kids during his childhood in Georgia
column4: years later
column5: this dynamic is fully inverted and he’s found a group of outcasts that’s emboldened in their idiosyncratic embrace of a Dixie upbringing. You can hear the influence of neighbors/collaborators Black Lips in dirtbag storytelling like “Pensacola”
column6: or just in the plain fact that Monomania is the first Deerhunter album that would be welcomed in a dive bar. Their previous physicality was defined by coiled intensity and quick strikes
column7: whereas here they swagger and flex beer muscles. The perverted classic rawk riffs of “Neon Junkyard” and “Leather Jacket II” twist and yowl while “Back to the Middle” and “Dream Captain” are so immediately accessible
column8: they could somehow come off as beneath Deerhunter.

column1: The more prevalent inspiration comes from fellow Athenian and mentor Michael Stipe; you can hear echoes of R.E.M.’s Monster in both the obscene distortion and the decision to follow up their richest
column2: most rococo record with a defiant squall. Cox similarly plays against his reputation given the opportunity
column3: using winks and irony to deviate from the impression that his band’s music is somewhat humorless and sexless. It’s every bit as confrontational as Deerhunter in their dress-wearing
column4: blog-attacking days
column5: only more fun. This can manifest in the glammy stream-of-consciousness from Monomania’s opening duo (“I am the Queen of Bass
column6: ” he announces on “Leather Jacket II”)
column7: or any of the first-person narratives that make good on his purported Hank Williams and Bo Diddley listening. Taking as many liberties with “Werewolves of London” as Kid Rock
column8: “Dream Captain” might come off as puerile southern comfort if it wasn’t such an obvious defilement of it-- bratty boasts like “I’m a boy
column9: man/ And you’re a man
column10: man” are tough to hear as anything other than comedy. Likewise
column11: on “Pensacola”
column12: an unfaithful woman leaves a Greyhound-riding somebody who is clearly not Bradford Cox with “a bald head and trouble.” Is it unfair that Deerhunter can get away with these because they’re Deerhunter
column13: whereas it’s pure shlock from any number of southern rock revivalists? Perhaps
column14: but having a laugh at one's own expense is hardly the most egregious form of an earned indulgence.

column1: But while Monomania as a whole is an unpredictable fulfillment of an unforeseen whim
column2: it’s Deerhunter’s least revelatory and surprising album on a song-by-song basis. There isn’t a clear showstopper along the lines of “Helicopter” or “Nothing Ever Happened”
column3: though the title track makes an admirable effort. They’ve always had a knack for mantras
column4: and after a verse of plaintive gospel shouts (“Come on God
column5: hear my sick prayer/ If you can’t
column6: send me an angel!”)
column7: the nagging phonetics of “mono
column8: monomania” get repeated ad infinitum before dissolving into white noise
column9: motorcycle revving
column10: and a soap opera device that Deerhunter makes frequent use of: after all this time
column11: Cox unexpectedly wakes up.

column1: “I was a dream of myself
column2: ” Cox admits during “Nitebike”
column3: a startling confessional of nothing more than his reverbed vocals and acoustic guitar. Perhaps taking another step back towards the medical maladies that pervaded both his youth and early Deerhunter
column4: he imagines himself on his Big Wheels
column5: “On the cusp of a breakthrough/ When they took me out/ And stuck it in/ It went <i>so deep
column6: man.” Another line gets repeated in greater detail on the Baudelaire-referencing closer “Punk (La Vie Antérieure)”
column7: where Cox muses
column8: “For a year
column9: I was queer/ I had conquered all my fears/ Not alone anymore/ But I found it such a bore.” It feels something like Cox’s “All Apologies”
column10: a litany of wearied
column11: bemused dissatisfaction with everything that he presumed might save him-- getting drunk
column12: being punk
column13: friends
column14: lovers. The plainspoken finality of “Punk” suggests it’s not just a closure on Monomania
column15: but of everything that preceded it.

column1: And that could be disappointing for a lot of people since Monomania is the first Deerhunter record that isn’t a quantifiable leap from what came before; the narrative and artistic arc that ran from Cryptograms to Halcyon Digest was clear and upward
column2: their diametrically opposed centrist indie songwriting and diffuse
column3: noisy ambience eventually converging into a brilliant horizon point. While a knocked-out
column4: “back to basics” approach makes a lot sense as the follow-up to <i>Halcyon Digest

column6: and more importantly
column7: they’ve avoided making their deflating “diminishing returns” record-- their <i>King of Limbs
column8: Centipede Hz
column9: Transference
column10: Sky Blue Sky
column11: etc.-- that casts doubts about whether they’ve gone too far down the same path. They’ve pulled off something admirable in making an illogical left turn feel like the logical next step where one didn’t exist. For the first time since Cryptograms
column12:
Deerhunter’s next move will be harder to predict than Cox’s.

Most rock'n'roll records can be traced back to some specific place and time
column2: but very few provide evidence of their exact origin. ""I guess he doesn't have a gun

column4: as you know
column5: Kurt Cobain... POW!"" The voice belongs to Alex Levine
column6: bassist for New York punk omnivores the So So Glos
column7: kicking off their heart-racingly enjoyable new album Blowout. The snippet was recorded when Levine was seven
column8: at the start of an abrupt and confusing changing of the guard in rock. In the wake of Cobain's suicide
column9: alternative music started looking much different than it had before
column10: as punk got poppier and alt-rock proper got angrier. For twentysomethings making music today
column11: this once maligned schism now feels whole
column12: with likeminded bands like Wavves and the Titus Andronicus subtly paying their dues to the Hollands
column13: Hoppuses
column14: and Armstrongs (Tim and Billie Joe) of their youths. The So So Glos are also a proud result of this divide
column15: where disaffection still lingers but never interferes with having fun.

column1: The So So Glos have zero interest in being sedated. On ""Xanax""
column2: with its festive sha-la-las
column3: sleigh bells
column4: and cowpunk flourishes
column5: frontman Alex Levine warns that ""they just wanna dumb you down like I did."" (Rounding the band out are Alex and Ryan's step-brother Zach Staggers on drums and childhood friend Matt Elkin on guitar.) The So So Glos are clever without being cheeky
column6: sincere without being preachy
column7: self-aware but never too in on their own joke. Still
column8: their most endearing trait is a simple one: They make murderously catchy
column9: endorphin-boosting
column10: shout-along guitar music with vigor and zeal
column11: breaking in their Doc Martens with a mid-song skank on the title track and goofing with Strokes-y cool on ""Speakeasy"". Thanks to their DIY background

column15: but felt that same energy.

column1: Blowout isn't trying to break any molds
column2: but distinguishes itself with thoughtful genre cherry-picking and a more inclusive spin on their contemporaries' established efforts. You can find hat-tips to forebears like the Gun Club and the Replacements (and note the Joe Strummer vocal inflections on the bittersweet ""Island Ridin'"") as well as bands that most pre-pubescent punks would have idolized when the Glos were coming up (""Wrecking Ball"" sounds like Rancid all juiced up on the Beastie Boys). But as far as the current landscape is concerned
column3: the So So Glos have a broader focus. Poking fun at American privilege is pretty standard for a band in their sphere (""Son of an American"")
column4: but the Glos come off less fussy and indignant than their friends Titus Andronicus (they even do a spot-on TA imitation with ""All of the Time""). Parquet Courts feel like spiritual cousins
column5: though SSGs are considerably less stoned and way more caffeinated. Almost every song has some sort of Japandroids-styled oh-oh-oh! chant-along
column6: often more pop-conscious but equally as satisfying.

column1: Full of great hooks
column2: anthemic energy and personality to spare
column3: the Glos are able to etch out their own space thanks to these adventurous songs (the one-two gut-punch of the melancholy-laced ""Lost Weekend"" and ""Xanax"" are both easy highlights). ""I’ll be a buzz bin fly just living to die
column4: Alex Levine sings on the aptly titled ""Everything Revival""
column5: ""and I don't wanna be the guy to sat whatever

Read deliberately
column2: Prisoner of Conscious isn’t that much less provocative a title in 2013 than Nas' Hip Hop Is Dead was in 2006. We're now a little more than three years removed from Waka's infamous ""I'm not into being lyrical"" comments
column3: and about two and a half on from Flockaveli

column5: then
column6: isn't cut out for these times. Songs like 1998's ""Definition"" and 2002's ""Get By"" still deserve all the adulation they inspire
column7: but there's a reason the 37-year-old founding father of conscious-rap is now acknowledging his own antiquity. So when third song “Turnt Up” shows up on Kweli’s fifth solo album
column8: it's probably right to perceive it as an allegorical jailbreak.

column1: And
column2: unfortunately if predictably
column3: “Turnt Up” marks the beginning of Prisoner’s issues. The song knows what it wants to be but doesn’t have the wherewithal to be it. Its piano-lined
column4: uppercutting pop aims for the radio
column5: but
column6: not even factoring in the club-unfriendliness of Kweli’s nose-pinched delivery
column7: I just can’t imagine it fitting in next to “Fuckin’ Problems” or “Bugatti”. The track might be the only flail at relevancy here

column9: the latter as seductive as ever with his suitably come-hither-y hook for “Come Here”-- their appearances scan as misguided attempts at lending the album a vaguely populist hue. For a record that doesn’t have a binding identity in the first place
column10: that’s a regrettably fragmenting problem.

column1: As great as the jutting
column2: soul-sampling production of 2002’s Quality was
column3: Kweli’s saving grace has always been his well-intentioned lyricism
column4: not his taste in beats. But Prisoner is marred by weak analogies (“colder than Minnesota
column5: ” “buzz like Georgia Tech) and Kweli’s bumpy writerliness (“ornithology” and “onomatopoeia” are just two less-than-melodious words used here)
column6: leading this to be his most underwhelming record yet word-for-word. And for every few lines that actually do stand up to some of Kweli’s smarter work (“Black Moses when the mic is on/ That’s why these rappers scatter like roaches when the light is on”)
column7: there’s a half-cocked concept
column8: like this one from “Hamster Wheel”: “How she runnin’ the streets but still standin’ still/ She needa get up off the hamster wheel.”

column1: Listening to Prisoner next to something like the new Chance the Rapper tape reveals the record’s biggest
column2: most pervasive dilemma. Where Acid Rap is a seamless convergence of local  and post-regional sounds
column3:
Prisoner takes on a bunch of things one by one without squeezing the most from any of them. Kweli’s absolutely owned his lane when he’s been committed to it but now he's jumping around from style to style with no destination in sight.

As the Body

column8: they’ve paired with post-metal troupe Braveyoung on the stage and in the studio
column9: grown into a trio and occasionally a quartet
column10: pared back to duo form
column11: and moved from Providence
column12: RI
column13: to their current base of Portland
column14: OR. The time spent in flux seems to have only galvanized the Body’s central focus-- that is
column15: to sound completely terrifying
column16: in an Armageddon-with-a-view
column17: end-of-everything manner.

column1: Master

column1: In the song’s back half

column3: sustained tones
column4: while Buford now rumbles through the rest the kit
column5: favoring body blows to eardrum lashes. But the Body somehow embeds a hook into all of this
column6: meaning that you might want to throw up your fists and shout along with King about collapsing structures and forms. Be prepared to be blindsided by a wave of pain
column7: though
column8: like a quarterback being sacked from the back in one of those NFL Films slow-motion frames. It’s every bit as exhilarating and intimidating as you might hope
column9: and shows the Body joining acts like WOLD
column10: Sutekh Hexen
column11: Locrian
column12: and even Sunn O))) in the masterful art of merging blackened noise and damaged metal.

column1: That’s not even the first three minutes. For “The Blessed Lay Down and Writhe in Agony”
column2: the Body bleeds tension
column3: with soprano vocals spiraling over cross-talking samples. A simple
column4: slow riff and an indirect drum patter gather slowly
column5: supporting King’s falsetto screech. The sound of a pump-action shotgun being slid into firing position serves as the valve’s release
column6: opening a torrent of drone and rumble that funnels into a disastrous coda. King
column7: Buford
column8: the samples and
column9: basically the whole world sound as though they’re being swallowed.

column1: The finale
column2: “Worship”
column3: lacks the immediacy of its companion pieces
column4: but its slow rise through martial drums and a scramble of found voices and manipulated notes suggests the Body’s developing ability to bait its audience with control and nuance. They micromanage the implied chaos until there is no more sonic space
column5: no more spare slivers for sound. When the barrier finally breaks
column6: the Body emerges with all of the atavistic doom force that initially made the band so compelling. Here
column7: the sound is caked in static

but I’m willing to admit I’m not that brave.

Two of the more interesting punk rock records to surface this year come from female-dominated acts drawing heavily from Bauhaus’s taut
column2: aggressive postpunk side and the chilly psychedelia of early Siouxsie and the Banshees: Savages’ Silence Yourself and Wax Idols’ Discipline & Desire. Whether that’s the manifestation of something rattling around pop’s mass subconscious
column3: or just an indicator that right now is a good time in the retro cycle to revive the few years before and after goth’s initial emergence from the first wave of UK punk remains to be seen.

column1: Silence Yourself has been attracting more attention
column2: but Discipline & Desire should also be essential listening for anyone in a gothic mood. It’s the poppier of the two
column3: which makes sense if you’re familiar with Wax Idols’ first LP
column4: No Future
column5: a collection that sounded a bit more like Wire than the typical album emanating from bubblegum-heavy San Francisco garage scene
column6: though it fit right in otherwise.

column1: In the two years since No Future was released
column2: frontwoman Hether Fortune has switched over from playing with a pickup band to recruiting a solid lineup; it's given the project a new sound that’s sleeker
column3: darker
column4: and more distinctive. Where the first album bristled with edgy but outgoing hooks
column5: Discipline & Desire plays it cool to the point of ice
column6: holding the listener at arm’s length and dangling its melodic payoffs tantalizingly just out of reach. The catchiest parts of the album are surrounded by anxious chromatic harmonies and submerged in a cloud of frigid reverb
column7: as if to underline its overall theme that you can’t enjoy pleasure without also enduring pain.

column1: If that sounds like a sado-masochistic approach to making music
column2: it probably is. Fortune has a day job as a dominatrix
column3: and it seems that Wax Idols’ stylistic evolution was the result of taking lessons she learned in the dungeon and finding ways to express them aesthetically. Discipline & Desire-- the title’s a tip-off-- is aloof and commanding
column4: with an expertly honed sense of how far to take the tension it builds before offering relief.

column1: Listeners generally don’t enjoy being messed with in such an aggressive fashion
column2: and it says a lot about where Fortune’s songwriting talents are at this point that she can pull off such a feat. The opening song
column3: “Stare Back”
column4: is not only one of the strongest on the album
column5: but the one that best embodies the forcible arm’s-length thing
column6: with the band riding an anxious two-note groove and Fortune giving her vocals a particularly assertive
column7: clipped edge. The song eventually builds to a bridge that’s as close to a resolution as the band’s willing to give it (there’s still a dissonant guitar line keeping us from getting too comfortable)
column8: but it’s not the release at the bridge that keeps bringing me back to the song
column9: it’s the creepy groove that I can feel crawling up and down my back in a strangely satisfying way.

column1: About halfway through the album
column2: Fortune and company take a break from the power play to deliver three and a half minutes of unalloyed pop compelling enough to stop chatter in a crowded room. “Dethrone” sounds like the Pretenders trying to sound like Siouxsie
column3: and it’s exactly as amazing as you would imagine that scenario to be. It seems like the goth fashion trend of the past few years is also inspiring a new goth music revival. If so
column4:
they should consider using “Dethrone” as its anthem.
