""Do I shout it out?/ Do I let it go?/ Do I even know what I'm waiting for?/ No
column2: I want it now/ Do I need it
column3: though?"" Throughout MCII
column4: Mikal Cronin gets in these ruts. His lyrics are delivered as someone who's never fully sure of his next move and who's completely unclear about his ambitions. He's sure that he's in love
column5: but he keeps letting it slip away. Somehow
column6: he keeps mucking up his day-to-day communication. It never used to be like this. He keeps talking about how time is getting away from him
column7: which might be his way of acknowledging a crisis about getting older
column8: though it's just as likely that he's accidentally spending hours clicking on YouTube videos. He wonders if he's wrong. (He doesn't think so.) He consistently has good intentions
column9: but he's inadvertently prone to choking on the follow-through. He sums up his turmoil pretty well in ""See It My Way"": ""I hear the song-- I wanna sing along with you/ But when I try I’m out of tune/ I turn and walk away."" It's a sweet and snappy sentiment from someone who's ultimately out of sync. This is Cronin's pop poetry for the aloof.

column1: So it's somewhat ironic that MCII is also his most fully realized
column2: beautifully arranged
column3: and well-crafted work to date. Since he's spent the past year shredding for the masses in the Ty Segall Band
column4: it's easy to forget that he recently earned his B.F.A. in Music and learned how to compose for different instruments. He rightly noted that his education came in handy for his Merge debut
column5: which subs out some of the psych freakouts from his first album for string arrangements. K. Dylan Edrich
column6: who recently contributed strings to Thee Oh Sees' most recent two albums
column7: lends her talents to a handful of songs
column8: from the plaintive violin solo on ""Peace of Mind"" to the frantic viola on ""Change"".

column1: One of the most impressive things about MCII is how Cronin balances ""power"" and ""pop"". He makes the ""pop"" part of the equation look effortless-- in 10 songs
column2: he offers 10 solid
column3: catchy melodies. When it comes to ""power
column4: he's much more conservative than he's ever been before-- especially when you consider Slaughterhouse. There are entirely acoustic songs here that pretty well prove that he doesn't need to rely on punk rock sludge. So when the tender stuff is over and he steps on the fuzz pedal
column5: the effects are extremely satisfying.

column1: Album closer ""Piano Mantra""
column2: for example
column3: begins with a particularly fragile-sounding Cronin singing ""I’m tired
column4: I’m sick
column5: I’m broke up."" Edrich's strings are quietly introduced
column6: then an acoustic guitar and some drums
column7: and finally at the end
column8: a feedback screech ushers in a distorted electric guitar. It doesn't even take center stage or threaten to become the main attraction-- it just adds a sturdy
column9: noisy spine to Cronin's formerly delicate ballad. Everything-- strings
column10: fuzz
column11: slide guitar
column12: etc.-- is purposefully and carefully implemented. He uses the more muscular sounds to offset his bubblegum jangle
column13: and while he did ask Ty Segall to lend a hand on the album
column14: he only brought him on board for two guitar solos. Neither are very flashy-- they're well-placed bursts of power that complement the melody.

column1: There's one moment in particular that puts to rest any notion that Cronin is just a glorified garage sideman: ""Don't Let Me Go""
column2: the only track Cronin recorded entirely by himself at home. It's just him
column3: his acoustic guitar
column4: and his voice singing both the melody and harmony. With that skeletal structure
column5: he loses the ""I'm not sure what's next or why I act like this"" tone and gets straight to the point. He pleads for the person he loves to give him another shot. ""You're all I know
column6: he sings in his falsetto. It's the most direct
column7: vulnerable statement he's ever made
column8: and in an album otherwise packed with uncertainty
column9: it's powerful.

column1: Cronin has said that his first favorite album was Nirvana's In Utero-- a record noisily recorded with Steve Albini before the band went to R.E.M./Katrina and the Waves producer Scott Litt to soften a couple of the album's songs. There's a loose analogy at play here-- Cronin recorded MCII with Eric ""King Riff"" Bauer at his Bay Area shred factory
column2: Bauer Mansion. Later
column3: he had the album mixed and mastered at Berkeley's hallowed Fantasy Studios. (Cronin has admitted that he got the idea from Segall
column4: who worked in those same two studios for Twins.) The outcome is a great sounding album that sits nicely between the poles of ""fuzz war"" and ""cooing balladeer."" Cronin has proved with this album that
column5: like Cobain before him
column6:
he's so much more than a longhair with a fuzz pedal. He's an excellent pop craftsman who knows how to turn the power up for maximum effect.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19141/homepage_large.92c396dc.jpg|Everybody Loves Sausages|2736.0|Melvins|['Rock'
column3: releasing a covers album can be like buying a new sportscar-- it’s a gesture intended to distract you from your own impending obsolescence. From the Ramones to Rod Stewart
column4: the act of recording other people’s songs is usually an acknowledgment that you no longer have anything to say. This is not necessarily the case for the two-ton iron chest of blackened sludge known as the Melvins and their new covers record
column5: Everybody Loves Sausages. In recent years
column6: the Melvins have not slowed their pace of releasing original music
column7: or tempered their adventurous (some might say perverse) musical explorations. Unlike most musicians their age
column8: Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover remain eternally open to new experiences
column9: whether it’s teaming up with Big Business for several records or morphing into Melvins Lite with Mr. Bungle’s Trevor Dunn on last year’s Freak Puke. If the Melvins are doing a covers record
column10: it must be because they want (rather than need) to do a covers record.

column1: But why would they want to make Everybody Loves Sausages? Could it be that the Melvins-- underneath all those layers of hair
column2: sweat
column3: and impenetrable volume-- are sentimentalists at heart? Everybody Loves Sausages is essentially a tour through the band’s most beloved songs from their formative years
column4: covering most of the expected bases (Venom
column5: Throbbing Gristle
column6: the 80s Sacramento hardcore band Tales of Terror) and a few surprises (Queen
column7: Roxy Music). The nostalgic drive of Sausages corresponds with this summer’s 30th anniversary tour
column8: which celebrates the legacy of a band that predated
column9: influenced
column10: and finally transcended grunge. In a way
column11: by encompassing the breadth of the group’s punk
column12: pop
column13: noise
column14: and classic rock influences
column15: listening to Everybody Loves Sausages helps to explain how the Melvins got here.

column1: Not that Everybody Loves Sausages is always representative of the Melvins’ iconic punk-metal sound. Because most of the tracks feature guest vocalists
column2: the Melvins are able to try out different
column3: very non-Melvins-like guises. The most radical departure is the cover of Queen’s “You’re My Best Friend” (known here simply as “Best Friend”) with Tweak Bird’s Caleb Benjamin
column4: which emulates Brian May’s bright-plastic guitar sound but otherwise bounces on a low-tech synth-pop pulse like a hopelessly chirpy musical birthday card. For their take on Ram Jam’s “Black Betty” the Melvins credibly remake themselves as a southern-rock boogie band
column5: while the Mark Arm-assisted cover of the Scientists’ “Set It on Fire” manages to out-Mudhoney Mudhoney.

column1: The goofball virtuosity of these tracks is fun if not especially memorable. Where Everybody Loves Sausages hits hardest is when the Melvins assert their personality on the material
column2: rather than vice versa. The epic nine-minute version of Roxy Music’s “In Every Dream Home a Heartache” is an excellent meltdown of arty prog-rock psychodrama
column3: featuring a truly creepy Bryan Ferry impersonation by Jello Biafra. The 11-minute rendition of David Bowie's ""Station to Station"" is another scarifying sprawl
column4: twisting recklessly between dissonant noise and full-bodied guitar blasts. Even better is “Female Trouble
column5: ” where Osborne subs for John Waters’ regular Divine over a sullen caveman stomp that bleeds into prehistoric noir. It’s a reminder that the Melvins aren’t just paying homage to rock history on Everybody Loves Sausages
column6:
they’re now also part of the tradition.

It's often mentioned that singer/songwriter David Wingo has written original music for several David Gordon Green films
column2: as though Wingo's own work as Ola Podrida were absolutely linked to-- and perhaps inscrutable without-- tacit scenes of dreamy rural poetry. But with the release of Ghosts Go Blind
column3: an abruptly extroverted and thoroughly satisfying third album
column4: the Green connection need be mentioned only to dispense with it. While Wingo's songs have an emotional and musical clarity that hint at his filmic background
column5: Ola Podrida has really come into its own. Rather than recording with friends on the fly
column6: Wingo booked into a studio with a resourceful band (guitarist Colin Swietek
column7: bassist Matt Clark
column8: and drummer David Hobizal) that handles lustrous pop Americana and classically proportioned indie rock with expressive professionalism. It keeps Wingo's gifts as a songwriter and lyricist right at the forefront
column9: which are more than ample to maintain interest.

column1: Ghosts Go Blind is simply a great-sounding album. On the surprisingly danceable indie rock numbers like ""Not Ready to Stop"" and ""Staying In""
column2: the understated and crisply shifting rhythm section drives clear
column3: heart-stirring electric guitar melodies
column4: continuously varying the weight and temperature of the song. (Wingo worked with another Texas-based band
column5: Explosions in the Sky
column6: on the Prince Avalanche score
column7: and a bit of their starry conflagration may have rubbed off.) If the up-tempo songs are notably sheer and propulsive
column8: the laidback ones are equally deep and lush: Check out the electric guitar etching soft gold cursive on the ridged acoustic canvas of ""Fumbling for the Light"" and the sumptuously wide
column9: ascending sway of ""Washing Away"". There's no electronic apparatus or laden pedal boards to hide guitars and drums executing scrupulous designs
column10: which gives the album a great clarity.

column1: The side effect of this quirk-free lucidity is that Wingo's songs can sound quite “in the style of
column2: ” with the redeeming factor being that he always nails it. ""Blind to the Blues""
column3: for instance
column4: immediately calls to mind the Clientele with the elegant slump of its silvery guitars and brushed percussion. The title track
column5: with a sweetly drifting vocal melody darkened by resonator guitar
column6: sounds like a flatteringly rusticated Coldplay. The fleet post-punk of ""Speed of Light"" is a dead-ringer for Antics-era Interpol
column7: down to the necrotic nasal quality Wingo lets into his voice. And a strong resemblance to the underrated band Maritime-- the post-Promise Ring project of Davey von Bohlen-- is palpable whenever a matured emo-punk chug steals through the record's changing tones.

column1: Ghosts Go Blind thrives on the vigorous execution of generic gestures
column2: but finds its own personality in Wingo's appealing singing and smart
column3: consistent lyrics. His voice has a plain finish but is strong and on pitch-- he can switch from a steely near-snarl to a high
column4: vulnerable lament with ease. He's very adroit at decorating his melodies without muddying their memorable twists
column5: an infectious example can be found between the verses and choruses of ""Not Ready to Stop"". ""I've been spending all my money like a fool tonight and I'm not quite ready to stop
column6: Wingo sings
column7: then contradicts himself as the arrangement shifts up a gear. This kind of tightly compressed conflict between emotions characterizes the lyrics overall
column8: which portray a distinctly adult perspective on heartbreak-- desperate but self-aware
column9: wary of melodrama-- with nuanced
column10: but broadly resonant images that artfully couch distinctly relatable emotions. The record distinguishes Wingo not only as a noteworthy musical voice
column11: but as a storyteller in his own right
column12:
rather than just a colorist for the stories of others.

The brainchild of Alex Rogers and Sam Shepherd-- better known as Alexander Nut and Floating Points-- Eglo Records occupies a singular niche in the landscape of British electronic music. Perhaps best viewed as a younger
column2: brasher cousin of Gilles Peterson’s Brownswood Recordings
column3: the label emerged in 2009 and has since functioned as a bridge between the increasingly fragmented identity of London's dancefloors and global currents in contemporary soul. After an initial flurry of activity
column4: Rogers and Shepherd have been quieter of late
column5: putting out only two records in 2012. Eglo Records Volume I
column6: though
column7: is their largest project to date
column8: and functions as a consolidation of the successes of those early years.

column1: Of the label’s founders
column2: Shepherd is amply represented here-- Rogers doesn't produce-- and justly so
column3: given his status as Eglo’s most successful export. The compilation opens with ""Radiality""
column4: a gauzy hip-hop instrumental that graced the label’s debut release. But before long we’re presented with the style that Shepherd is better known for: namely warm
column5: jazz-inflected deep house
column6: awash with hand-played synth work and subtly hummable melodies. The effervescent ""Vacuum Boogie"" is a particular highlight
column7: and became something of an anthem on its 2009 release. The producer’s more recent output
column8: meanwhile
column9: reflects a growing distillation of approach-- sometimes to brilliant effect (""Marylin"")
column10: but occasionally at the expense of excitement (particularly in the coffee-table-smooth ""Myrtle Avenue"").

column1: Floating Points also shoulders production duties for Eglo’s other bona fide star
column2: Swedish singer Fatima
column3: on the beatless ""Innervisions""
column4: where his thoughtful chord progressions prove an apt frame for the singer’s broad
column5: smoky vibrato. Elsewhere
column6: though
column7: Fatima is far less refined
column8: and all the better for it: a pair of queasy
column9: Funkineven-produced digital boogie numbers

column11: fall somewhere between Sa-Ra and early Ikonika. Funkineven is an Eglo stalwart too
column12: but his solo inclusions here aren’t quite his best work
column13: leaning towards the acid house retro-revivalism of his 2010/11 output.

column1: The compilation closes with a handful of previously unheard tracks
column2: suggesting Eglo’s future is to be as technicolour as its past. New material from Shepherd comes under the aegis of the 16-piece Floating Points Ensemble
column3: replete with strings
column4: brass and percussion. ""Wires"" is a mellifluous
column5: long-form composition similar to the ensemble’s 2010 Ninja Tune single
column6: though it’s a little unremarkable in its unending niceness. Fatima’s ""Visit You""
column7: meanwhile
column8: is far more intriguing
column9: a lush but ever so slightly off-colour ballad that bodes well for the singer’s forthcoming debut album. Eglo Volume I is dominated by these three charismatic figures-- Floating Points
column10: Fatima
column11: and Funkineven-- and the cross-talk between them. And it’s true that
column12: for the most part
column13: the co-ordinates of the Eglo aesthetic are inscribed within their output. But that’s not to say that the label’s outliers don’t have worthy contributions to make too: particularly fine is Shuanise’s slight but seductive ‘Catch’

column5: but not so much that your ears bleed trying to hear the words. And as a lyricist

column9:
or highway stop of your choosing.

Guided by Voices were back; now

column5: their latest

column7: making as many post-hiatus LPs as they managed during that fabled ""classic era."" Sixteen months back

column10: however

column1: English Little League
column2: like so many GBV albums before it
column3: gathers a couple all-timers and a few respectably jagged pop-rockers together with several total trainwrecks and calls it an LP. First
column4: the good: the exceedingly generous lead single ""Flunky Minnows"" is brimming with so many hooks
column5: it spends its two minutes and change running around in circles
column6: begging you to take them off its hands. Opener ""Xeno Pariah"" is the best first-shot of GBV's second act
column7: a sharp
column8: clear-eyed rocker with a head-lodge hook all its own. Highlights are everywhere
column9: from the sway-and-spill chorus of ""Send to Celeste (And the Cosmic Athletes)""
column10: to the goofball rumble and Zero Mostel gags of ""Crybaby 4-Star Hotel"" and the gnarly heft of bruiser ""Know Me As Heavy"". The playing's shrewd

column1: English Little League marks the first appearance of recordings from Pollard's new home-studio. Which is not to suggest that he's somehow gone slick; even amidst Little League's booming arena-rockers
column2: swift power-pop

column4: and wads of bubblegum
column5: it's on these late-night home-recordings that you can hear the figurative scrape of the tattered Tascam the loudest. Most of the home-brewed stuff takes the form of drunken 3 AM ballads
column6: howls-at-the-moon likely inspired by those nights when the beer's all gone and every liquor store in 20 miles is closed until the morning. In the right mood
column7: these ballads'll knock the wind out of you. But English Little League's got four of them-- ""Sir Garlic Breath
column8: ""Biographer Seahorse
column9: ""Reflections in a Metal Whistle"" and ""A Burning Glass""-- and with every passing weeper
column10: the album sags a tad more.

column1: Still
column2: I'll take a glut of ballads over something like ""Noble Insect""
column3: the dismal co-write from Pollard and Tobin Sprout that leaves neither side off the hook. Over a lunkhead riff

column5: Japan"" semi-tunelessly for a while before sliding into chorus so good-- and so effortless-- you'll wonder why they'd ever think to burn it on a song that dopey. Really
column6: it might be best if GBV stay out of Japan for the time being: the record's other lowlight
column7: the jaunty
column8: underwritten ""Reflections in a Metal Whistle
column9: also shoehorns in a incongruous (albeit less annoying) mention of the country. Tobin Sprout spends Little League with his head in the clouds; whether he's harping on Jesus on the far-too-sweet ""The Sudden Death of Epstein's Ways"" or talking about a girl who chats with refracted light on ""Islands (She Talks in Rainbows)""
column10: his ageless voice and crisp melodies are typically a smart counterpoint to Bob's ragged glories. But these songs he brings to English Little League are pure cotton candy
column11: sticker and more saccharine than they are satisfying.

column1: Guided by Voices weren't even this prolific back when they made their rep for being prolific. So
column2: after unloading so much music in such a short time
column3: finding a moment to step back and consider each album on its own takes some doing. It's clear now that Let's Go Eat the Factory was the weird one
column4: Class Clown Spots a UFO the one with the most range
column5: and The Bears for Lunch the flat-out catchiest. Little League's harder to draw a line around; even with all the ballads
column6: there's not a prevailing mood or a dominant sound. So
column7: while it's perfectly pleasant from moment to moment
column8: the whole never congeals. With 17 songs in just under 46 minutes
column9: a good number of them ballads
column10: English Little League seems to unfold at an unusually relaxed pace; songs that would've been 75 seconds long now get two verses and a repeat airing of the chorus
column11: not always deservedly. Tobin's songs have that gloopy faux-chestra thing going for them
column12: and Pollard howler ""A Burning Glass"" is almost crowded out by echo
column13: but for the most part
column14: the production's spare enough
column15: it doesn't especially feel like production.

column1: Song for song
column2: League's about par with the three LPs that preceded it: The Bears for Lunch is a bit more consistent
column3: but its highs certainly weren't any higher. Still
column4: as with the three LPs it follows
column5: something's holding the very good League back from greatness; in this case
column6: its lax pacing

column8: and whatever the heck ""Noble Insect"" is supposed to be. Great as it is that GBV are still knocking sounds like ""Flunky Minnows"" into the stands
column9: it's a shame they're not popping off 20 such songs a year the way they did way back when. The hits still connect
column10: but the batting average is a little lower these days. In many ways
column11: GBV's revamp is still one of the indie-rock comebacks to beat: they didn't return for a quick cash-grab

column13: willing to risk whatever legend they'd built up in their absence by flooding fans with new material. But
column14: triumphant as the return itself has been
column15:
the records themselves have really only skirted triumph. English Little League is no different.

column3: Akron/Family is either upstart or institution. Unlike mid-decade peers like Animal Collective and Grizzly Bear

column1: Likewise

column3: familiar melody to chew on. There's some more apologizing

The widely-propagated notion that the sound of early-90s New York and New Jersey garage is “back” can seem a little puzzling. In strict terms
column2: the sound of shuffling hi-hats
column3: warm but impacting basslines
column4: sharply percussive organ and piano riffs
column5: and sighing divas has been “back” for European audiences since about 2006
column6: when DJs started dropping old Kerri Chandler tunes with a sudden and unexpected fervor. But it’s undeniable that in the past year this particular brand of house-- organic but glossy
column7: skipping but not too syncopated
column8: feminized but rarely effeminate
column9: flirting with populism while mostly rejecting obviousness-- has turned into something of a revivalist lingua franca
column10: embraced by audiences from a variety of vantage points (post-minimal
column11: post-dubstep
column12: post-bassline) as the good times flavour of the moment.

column1: It’s easy to hear how garage attained this status. On today’s dancefloors
column2: these rounded
column3: sensuous
column4: grooves
column5: asking little but offering plenty
column6: perform best as uncomplicated throwback diversions from the main event
column7: whether emerging out of a more rigorous set of stripped down house and techno like the sun from behind the clouds
column8: or plunging deeper from the more bubbly delights of pop-garage. It’s tempting to posit early garage revivalism as the necessary corollary of the coalitional pastiches that typify so much of dance music’s respectable mainstream
column9: its bumping
column10: pleasure-centered congeniality staking out a past crossroad that ultimately led to nearly every currently popular (post-)house dance style. And there’s something about this music that seems to turn its face to catch whatever light is in the room
column11: throwing up intriguing resemblances and contrasts with whatever company it happens to be keeping.

column1: But this all-purpose charisma is also what makes a compilation like the Needwant label’s Traxx: The House That Garage Built such a mixed proposition. Rounding up 17 examples of contemporary producers trying their hand at the feted sound
column2: Traxx asks us to see garage revivalism by only the light it generates on its own and to evaluate its stylistic tics only in their self-relation. Under these auspices
column3: garage revivalism can seem
column4: if not cloying
column5: then at least less than the sum of its parts. There’s no denying that Needwant have done a decent job of rounding up a representative collection of bona fide anthems. There’s Dusky's ""Flo Jam""
column6: incarcerating Aaliyah’s disembodied vocals from “Rock The Boat” with only an eerie
column7: downbeat bassline and the remorseless swing of the rhythm track for company; or there’s Medlar’s remix of Disclosure’s “Boiling”
column8: its floating synth pads
column9: open hi-hats and bewitching diva vocal capturing perfectly that sense of plush refinement that garage so frequently perfected-- music for dancing in your very best outfit. Best of the anthems is Ejeca’s “Horizon”
column10: which comes closest to meriting the term “shameless
column11: ” its emphatic organ bassline and dense web of diva shrieks and invocations offering up the compilation’s most hedonistic moment.

column1: But too many of these tunes can simply lapse into a mode of pleasant gregariousness
column2: ticking all the right boxes but with only a modicum of flair. This is particularly a problem on the DJ mix version
column3: where the endless success of discombobulated diva moans and bouncy silicon synth implants can begin to blur; frequently
column4: tracks that seem merely functional in that context come to life on their own
column5: such as Harry Wolfman’s excellent garage remix of Ben Pearce’s bluesy “What I Might Do”. But the easily ignorable nature of such charms raises larger questions about the purpose of garage revivalism per se: ultimately
column6: the positive influence this style has on today’s dancefloors is its capacity to be misremembered
column7: to be just yet another influence in the melting pot of today’s house music. By contrast
column8: much of Traxx is too successful at stripping out any hint of an extraneous influence
column9: until what is left is a perfect
column10: but redundant
column11: replica of past glories.

column1: Unsurprisingly then
column2: the hidden treasures of the compilation are its most idiosyncratic
column3: least authentic inclusions. On Real Connoisseur’s “Faux De Baux”
column4: a brooding
column5: metallic bassline and a ruthlessly cut-up diva vocal play tongue hockey with one another
column6: darting in and out with a kind of rhythmic exuberance that most of Traxx is too reverential to attempt. A world away
column7: Breach’s “You Won’t Find Love Again” moves from ominous bass-driven moodiness into an astonishing white-light breakdown of layered synth arpeggio climaxes
column8: before bringing it all back home with a rousing
column9: punchy send-off that takes its cues from 1993 and every year of dancing since. It’s proof
column10: if more is needed
column11: that while there may be value in learning from the past
column12:
most of the time there’s greater benefit in cramming the essentials and making up the rest as you go along.

Alone in the Grave
column2: the latest recording from the young Olympia
column3: Wash.
column4: death metal band Bone Sickness

column7: but falls short of calling it an LP. (Are they considering it a full-length

column2: pretension

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19237/homepage_large.7e9a1c9a.jpg|Fabric 69|31301.0|Sandwell District|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2013-05-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:29.578749|"

Sandwell District scratch a very specific itch for techno fans whose tastes veer towards the darker side of things. During the collective's decade-long run
column2: its releases often siphoned key elements and moods from other genres-- dub techno's hollowed-out sprawl
column3: post-punk's stark seriousness
column4: the grim purposefulness of industrial-- to develop its own identity separate from the minimal overload that swept techno in the 2000s. There are a few flashes of gray-toned color to be found in SD's catalog
column5: but ultimately darkness reigns supreme
column6: as uncredited releases and stark as the DIY packaging that drove home the music's ominousness and severity. The proliferation of similarly-minded labels such as London's Blackest Ever Black imprint
column7: as well as recent flirtations with harsh dance music coming from noise artists like Pete Swanson and Dominick Fernow
column8: have suggested that Sandwell District's influence looms large in 2013.

column1: The rise in stature is somewhat bittersweet
column2: since the label ceased operations at the top of 2012
column3: just under two years after the release of Feed-Forward
column4: a collaborative LP from core collective members Regis
column5: Function
column6: and Silent Servant (the first two of which have also spent the last year keeping SD's name visible by playing gigs under its guise). While the label's official statement concerning the dissolution sounded cryptically robotic (""There is a possibility of future
column7: albeit irregular
column8: print communications with audio accompaniment"")
column9: Silent Servant mastermind Juan Mendez's explanation was more brutally poetic: ""It's what anyone with a passion or half a brain would have done. It will never get old. No one will be able to impose their clean values on it...It was a glorious death
column10: not a mercy killing.""

column1: The cloaked drama of Mendez's statement was a hat-tip to Sandwell District's occasional flair for extra-musical aspects that took on a threatening shape-- the liner notes for the label's second proper release
column2: 2002's remix 12"" of Vandross' ""Hurt Me I'm Waiting""
column3: claim that the original song was stolen from ""a guy who is in jail"" that sent his tune to Regis' previous endeavor
column4: '90s techno hub Downwards. So when SD's Tumblr was updated this February with an image that declared ""Sandwell District Is Dead""
column5: the somewhat unnecessary proclamation suggested that something was afoot.

column1: The big reveal followed a few weeks later: Fabric 69
column2: the first release in two years to bear the Sandwell District name. Compiled by Regis and Function
column3: the latest installment in Fabric's esteemed mix series isn't meant to signal a new beginning for the collective as it is a summation
column4: as Function's Dave Sumner has described its intent as ""encapsulating an era and putting it to rest"". In a press release
column5: Regis knob-twiddler Karl O'Connor is both more oblique and more direct regarding what's ahead for Sandwell District: ""If you want to give the Gods a laugh
column6: talk about future plans.""

column1: Whereas Sandwell District's live sets lean heavily on the type of tunnel-vision techno that gets bodies moving
column2: Fabric 69 is more of a mood piece
column3: a home-listening experience that possesses a clear narrative shape. Patches of clattering ambience give way to endless-sounding
column4: floor-centric passages
column5: with moments of relative placidness acting as sonic bookends. The mix is a collection of things that go ""thump"" in the night that makes few concessions and demands your full attention; its sense of menace is entirely immersive.

column1: That said
column2: Fabric 69's most impressive quality-- especially given the tough stuff involved in its composition-- is how luxuriously listenable it is. Regis and Function went back-and-forth on putting the mix together
column3: with the latter handling the final mixdown after fine-tuning it ""hundreds of times"" while working on his recent Ostgut Ton debut Incubation. The pair's stitch work here is impressive
column4: as they weave 30 tracks from the SD family and elsewhere into a 75-minute mix that sounds seamless to the extent that it's unclear where some cuts end and others begin. Obviously
column5: the Fabric series' reputation makes it a given that there would be an amount of attention spent on putting something together that rises above the quality of your garden-variety RSS-baiting mix
column6: but even so
column7: the sprawl and lavish detail included on Fabric 69 stands out as an achievement.

column1: Some mixes can function as an accessible bridge-gap for those dipping their feet into dance music; I'm not sure Fabric 69 is one of those mixes. The sound that Sandwell District made their name on was singular both in focus and form
column2: so 75 minutes of this stuff could prove a bit taxing-- if not headache-inducing-- for the uninitiated. For first-timers
column3: it's better to approach Fabric 69 as a way of reconciling the past and present. Since its origins lie as a label
column4: Sandwell District is less an artist-heavy project than it is a name
column5: one that stands for something specific; conversely
column6: a few of the non-Sandwell-affiliated artists included in Fabric 69 have received a level of increased exposure that's taken place after the label's shuttering. So despite Sumner's stated aim to close the books on the past
column7: Fabric 69 actually finds itself looking to the present and beyond
column8: strengthening Sandwell District's aesthetic brand simply by pointing out that
column9: if you know where to look
column10:
it's more omnipresent than ever.

Wandering into North Carolina venue the Cat's Cradle circa 2000
column2: I was pleasantly surprised by a mob of shaggy-haired Californians
column3: the ringleader dressed as a 1980s aerobics instructor and dancing like a rubber marionette
column4: banging crash cymbals and chanting something like
column5: ""Can you feel it? Jackson 5! Soul clap
column6: Jackson 5!"" It turned out to be !!! and Nic Offer
column7: who helped light the fuse of the millennial dance-punk craze and have managed to stick around long after it burned out. Many of their peers favored a more cramped and anxious sound
column8: but !!! stood out as freewheeling party monsters that radiated sunny vibes. Thirteen years and five LPs later
column9: the mostly well-turned but low-impact Thr!!!er has all the hallmarks of !!!
column10: minus a crucial one: abandon.

column1: At first
column2: the band suggested that their name could be pronounced as any number of percussive onomatopoeias
column3: but the marketplace quickly settled on ""Chk Chk Chk
column4: a fair approximation of the scratchy funk guitars that are their lifeblood. From their self-titled 2001 debut to 2004's Louden Up Now
column5: !!! stretched their wooly punk-funk into sleeker realms of disco both leftfield and pop
column6: blending the influences of Arthur Russell and the Bee Gees with Talking Heads and Liquid Liquid-inspired rave-ups. The band's stylistic expansion peaked in the influential indie-house single ""Me and Giuliani Down by the School Yard (A True Story)"" before they pivoted away from exfoliating odysseys on 2007's Myth Takes
column7: where meaty rock and soulful deep house tropes came to the forefront of radio-formatted songs with thunderous live drums.

column1: 2010's Strange Weather
column2: Isn't It? was a back-to-basics album that kept the shorter track lengths of Myth Takes but inserted icy grooves where most of the sticky hooks and cathartic dynamics had been. A palate-cleansing minimal dance album was a timely idea
column3: but at four or five minutes apiece
column4: the songs just didn't have time to simmer like the epic ""Giuliani""
column5: often petering out before they could boil over. The same proportional issues cap off the impact of Thr!!!er
column6: with one lean
column7: mannered workout after another fading to silence just when it really starts cooking. ""Even When the Water’s Cold"" is a lively example of the general problem: It has a funk part
column8: a wah-wah part
column9: a dubby interlude
column10: a mild coda. But the dynamic line running through them is flat and unsurprising
column11: never exploding us through the top or plunging us through the bottom of the song.

column1: Though Thr!!!er continues in the same vein as Strange Weather
column2: it's differentiated by a warmer sound palette. !!! melt the ice crystals that rimed their last record with mystic vocal harmonies on ""Fine Fine Fine""
column3: reverbed flute loops on the percolating ""Careful""
column4: and an overall tilting of emphasis from electronic tootles toward tidy
column5: curlicued funk musicianship. The record is taut with the usual wiry
column6: kinked guitars
column7: ropy bass lines
column8: popping handclaps
column9: chanting choruses
column10: and falsetto outbursts
column11: all working efficiently for dancers but evading big moments for listeners. This thinness at the level of content is glaring only on ""Get That Rhythm Right""
column12: where unflattering vocal processing fails to conceal a nebulous vocal melody while flotsam of dubious taste-- goofy sound effects
column13: fleeting filters
column14: a timorous smooth sax interlude-- spins aimlessly on a whirlpool of bass and drums.

column1: As retro-house vamping goes
column2: the svelte and slippery ""Slyd"" fares much better
column3: especially mixed with vocals cuts from Molly Schnick of !!!'s now-dead but arguably superior sister band
column4: Out Hud. ""Californiyeah"" and ""One Girl/One Boy"" have some of the cracking pop panache that elevated Myth Takes
column5: but the tracks that aim for transcendence through recombinative repetition are just too brief and buttoned-down to get there. For all of Thr!!!er’s reliable pleasures
column6: the requisite cover-image riff on the triple-bang logo is the boldest idea here
column7:
which makes for an awfully modest record to hold up against the pop-canon cornerstone for which it was named.

Has Mark Kozelek ever written a truer or more succinct description of his creative process than “Ceiling Gazing”? “Layin’ in my bed ceiling gazing/ Wide awake with jet lag from Australia
column4: ” he sings on the standout from Perils from the Sea
column5: his new collaboration with Album Leaf founder Jimmy Lavalle. As a churchly organ repeats an insistently ascending phrase
column6: Kozelek describes the stack of mail that awaited him after a tour
column7: including “a wedding invitation from a new young relative I never even knew of.” The card sets his mind reeling around his family tree
column8: until it alights on memories of his sister. She’s just suffered through a bad divorce and is raising two daughters
column9: age four and seven; he wants to live a long life just so he can see how they grow up. It’s a quietly poignant song
column10: one that subtly lays out the distance between Kozelek and his loved ones even as it tries to connect them in song. “Can’t stop my mind from racing
column11: ” he concludes. “It’s not good or bad
column12: it’s just how God made me.”

column1: Few songwriters can sketch a scene with Kozelek’s eye for detail or his economy of language
column2: and fewer still can match the insight with which he can draw a character. In recent years
column3: however
column4: the sheer volume of work Kozelek has released through his Caldo Verde Records has tended to dilute the impact of his songs. Not even the most avid fan could keep up with the deluge of bonus discs and live albums
column5: and musically he has narrowed his palette to a single instrument: that nylon-string guitar he introduced on Admiral Fell Promises. It makes more financial than aesthetic sense
column6: as it allows him to keep touring expenses to a bare minimum
column7: but those nylon strings have comes to define his sound both on stage and in the studio
column8: collapsing his songs into one another.

column1: That makes Perils from the Sea unique in Kozelek’s recent catalog. He mostly turns over all the non-vocal responsibilities to Lavalle
column2: so instead of plucks and strums
column3: we hear forlorn beeps and bloops-- somewhat more hushed than on the Album Leaf output
column4: yet distinctively textured and tailored to Kozelek’s signature phrasings. Lavalle favors a subtle pulse and thrum that gently reinforces the concreteness of the details. On “Caroline”
column5: the stuttering beat gooses the tempo a bit and gets Kozelek singing faster than usual. It’s another song that contrasts the securities of home (waking up next to his love and her rat terrier pup
column6: hanging around familiar coffeeshops) with the lure of the road
column7: yet the music lends the emotions a new and more urgent desperation. It may be Kozelek’s finest moment since anything off Ghosts of the Great Highway.

column1: Kozelek writes songs by simply letting his mind wander
column2: then spends years retracing his steps on stage. That his songs move by tangent and discursion can frustrate a listener since it means he tends to eschew choruses
column3: bridges
column4: hooks
column5: and other structural embellishments. Instead
column6: his songs are built almost exclusively from verses
column7: and they often worry over a single
column8: simple melody. When it works
column9: as it does on “Ceiling Gazing”
column10: that approach can locate immense symbolic power in even the most seemingly banal items: a scratched copy of Heart’s Dreamboat Annie that he and his sister played countless times
column11: for example
column12: or the lonely house in Ohio where she lives now.

column1: Lavalle understands this
column2: and he crafts beats to represent the mechanisms of memory. Only occasionally do they sound at cross-purposes. The psychedelic synths on “1936” sound too ominous and otherworldly for what is a pretty thin story centered around a special dime
column3: and on “You Missed My Heart”
column4: the burble of background noise cannot redeem a strained account of a murderer who kills-- and eventually dies-- for love. The sentiment is too clever to ring particularly true
column5: which is on Kozelek’s shoulders
column6: but Lavalle’s beats are too noncommittal to add much gravity or levity. Still
column7: the effort is appreciated
column8: if only because the song shows both men readily moving out of their comfort zones. Perils from the Sea may not be a seamless collaboration
column9:
but neither artist has sounded so purposeful in his reverie in years.

Wiz Khalifa and Curren$y’s collaborative project Live in Concert (not an actual live album) was supposed to come out last summer as a free mixtape but it wound up being delayed. Following a lawsuit against Mac Miller for an unapproved Lord Finesse sample
column3: rappers became more conscious of what they were sampling on mixtapes. Fearing copycat lawsuits
column4: Khalifa and Curren$y held onto the sample-heavy Live in Concert
column5: waiting for the legal dust to settle
column6: and now they've released it as an EP
column7: one that costs money.

column1: These rappers have some history. Back in 2009
column2: Khalifa and Curren$y released a collaborative mixtape
column3: How Fly
column4: just at the point where both were carving out their respective niches. Khalifa found mainstream success with his single ""Black and Yellow"" and Curren$y found critical and underground appreciation by releasing a constant stream of quality music. Both make long records that grow more enticing with repeated listens
column5: after one has tuned in to their respective off-color jokes and personal ticks. Though Khalifa has never been able to match Curren$y’s sheer rapping skill
column6: his nasally voice has a more welcoming tone next to Curren$y's weary snarl.

column1: Imagery is where Curren$y excels (“Motion sensors all over my house/ For investigative-ass hoes/ That’s waiting on me to pass out/ So they can tip-toe all over my home”
column2: from ""Landing"")
column3: and Khalifa will never be able to equal him there. Instead
column4: his verses feel weightless
column5: as he raps  about much money he’s made and many places he has been. Where Curren$y’s attention to detail takes you to those places
column6: Khalifa’s never achieves that kind of tangibility.

column1: The duo share a penchant for jazzy and relaxed funk production (see: Curren$y’s Pilot Talk series) and production is the EP's strength. The excellent flute work from Bobbi Humphrey’s Fancy Dancer is heard all over this EP-- Curren$y and Khalifa can write strong hooks on their own but here they're content to let Humphrey take over. Take “Revenge and Cake”
column2: which lifts its lovely refrain of “Sweeter than sugar/ Sweeter than love” from Fancy Dancer. The samples aren't really mixed or chopped
column3: and since with every track gets an extended intro or outro
column4: it almost feels like the two rappers were in the studio with Humphrey.

column1: Still
column2: Live in Concert is not a mixtape and it isn't free. In a post-Datpiff world
column3: it's reasonable to wonder if anyone will pay for it. But  even free mixtapes require studio space
column4: someone to do mixing
column5: cover art and especially here properly cleared samples
column6: all of which cost money. So while Live in Concert might not justify the money a listener might spend
column7:
you can understand why they would try to recoup.

“Mother of Light” bursts open with the same righteous churn that defines most of Mánégarmr
column2: the excellent debut LP by Belgian upstarts Hessian. Drummer Tim Bryon and bassist Kenneth Vanhoutte throw the full weight of their instruments behind the guitar’s simple
column3: repetitive riff; it’s deliberately blackened hardcore
column4: thickened by a rhythm section that doesn’t want to stand back in the mix. A little less than a minute into the record’s closer
column5: though
column6: a second guitar steps out of sync
column7: baiting the melee with a sustained shriek of feedback
column8: as though the last-resort breaks have been thrown on a runaway train. Indeed
column9: the rest of the track feels like a headlong race down a very steep hill
column10: with that single piercing tone trying to prevent a tumble toward a reckless mess. And it works: By the end of these three minutes
column11: Hessian has slowed to a mid-tempo plod
column12: with spectral background chants and guitars that slowly back off the volume.

column1: That balance between inexorable tumult and controlled chaos largely defines Mánégarmr
column2: a record that zigs and zags in the most surprising ways while always returning to an assured stylistic center. Guitarist and second vocalist Levy Seynaeve also plays bass in prolific Belgian doom benders Amenra

column3: but so is the sense that Hessian is in complete control of all this. The guitar solo at the center of “Plague Monger”
column4: for instance

column6: but Hessian manage not only to make the unlikely sound work within the track but work for the track
column7: too
column8: adding an italicized gusto to the already-intense tune. The centerpiece of Mánégarmr is a three-piece suite that shows the span and strength of their versatility: “Father of Greed” galvanizes its down-tuned doom with grim pugnacity and tweaks it with off-kilter textures and beats. The smoldering exit serves as an apt transition into “Vãmãcarã”
column9: a mix of field recordings
column10: elliptical guitar tones
column11: and occasional chords that suggests spell-casters Cultus Sabbati or the slighter moments of Sunn O)))’s Black One. It swells toward the end
column12: foreshadowing the no-quarter
column13: all-fury approach of the record’s back half. From the anthemic “Swallowing Nails” to the ending “Mother of Light”
column14: Hessian spends the last four songs proving just how hard and heavy they can be for an extended and truly exhausting coda.

column1: None of the constituent parts of Mánégarmr will shock you: At its core
column2: Hessian plays brutal but basic metal
column3: strong but emblematic hardcore and
column4: occasionally
column5: good but familiar drone. The record was mixed
column6: after all
column7: by Tomas Skogsberg in Sweden’s Sunlight Studios
column8: a legendary place that bands simply trying to rupture some hegemony wouldn’t send their music. But these parts stream forward in constantly surprising scrambles
column9: affording Mánégarmr the simultaneous feelings of familiarity and reverence

column11:
from one end to the other.

Pretty & Nice was a band on the brink of being a buzz band. In late 2008
column2: the Boston trio released its second full-length
column3: Get Young
column4: a tightly-crafted burst of energy that fully embodied the reckless abandon of youth
column5: on Sub Pop imprint Hardly Art. By SXSW the following March
column6: they were playing Sub Pop’s party opposite Handsome Furs
column7: in addition to a slew of other gigs. Their brand of infectious dance-punk felt original
column8: with members channeling the raw energy of their debut into impressive new wave elasticity for the second LP. And then

column1: A few years later
column2: and Hardly Art is out of the picture. Pretty & Nice have released EPs and 7-inches on various tiny labels
column3: but no full-length since Get Young. But the band is resurfacing now
column4: as strong as ever. On Golden Rules for Golden People
column5: Pretty & Nice preserve the fizz of youth while finding a way to grow up a little. Rather than slow down
column6: they've incorporated a wider range of sounds. The band’s previous efforts excelled by working within a very specific framework
column7: which fell somewhere between the new wave of Elvis Costello’s first few albums and of Montreal’s least soulful songs. Here
column8: however

column10: orchestral pop
column11: and power-pop. The results are occasionally illogical (funky yet math-y
column12: with eight-bit flourishes) and make for some unusual comparisons (Devo with an ELO-ish vibe). The spazz remains
column13: but it’s accompanied by the kitchen sink.

column1: Take the song “Yonkers”

column3: the track goes through at least five different phases. It segues from a throttle of riffs to a cutesy surf chorus and bridge
column4: from wonky angles into blazing brass
column5: from a heavenly choir of human voices to manufactured bleeps and bloops. It’s disorienting in a joyful way. There are other songs that more fully commit to one or two ideas
column6: such as “New Czar” and “Gold Fools.” The former gives off a feeling that can only be described as “giddy up”; it’s a drum beat that demands one rides on
column7: matched by a throwback pop melody. The latter
column8: one of the album’s more produced tracks
column9: has a dark electronic beat lording over it. Though brief at just a minute and a half

column1: Lewis’ precise diction serves as an anchor amidst the musical chaos
column2: helping the album’s seemingly nonsensical lyrics to stand out. Presenting what seems to be a series of metaphors
column3: he sings about animals
column4: zombies
column5: Malibu
column6: Rockefeller money
column7: unsinkable ships
column8: and shallow beautiful people. He also often repeats the line
column9: “we are all instruments
column10: ” the first words heard on the album. With song titles like “Money Music” and “Gold Fools”
column11: the “golden people” of Golden Rules for Golden People appear to be the ones the band rails against. This is a band comprising people who've worked menial day jobs and who came up through a DIY scene
column12: so it's no real surprise they’re criticizing the upper class. In that sense

column14: really
column15:
Golden Rules for Golden People has plenty to offer for anyone with the energy to keep up with it.

“We could’ve been the American Stones
column3: ” Stooges guitarist Ron Asheton told MOJO magazine back in 1996. “We fucked up
column4: man.” But for all the tales of bloodletting violence and self-destructive substance abuse that defined their initial 1967-1973 run
column5: the Stooges’ biggest fuck-up wouldn’t come until 2007
column6: with the release of their disastrous reunion album The Weirdness. And
column7: ironically
column8: with that
column9: the Stooges finally achieved their elusive American Stones status-- in that
column10: as with the Stones
column11: expressing one’s enthusiasm for the Stooges now requires a qualifying remark along the lines of
column12: “Well
column13: I like their older stuff.”

column1: But where the allergic reaction to The Weirdness and the untimely 2009 passing of Ron Asheton would seemingly discourage surviving Stooges Iggy Pop and Ron’s drummer-brother Scott Asheton from extending their discography
column2: this band has survived bad reviews and the loss of a founding member before. Conveniently enough
column3: their post-reunion narrative can simply mimic that of their first phase: after the group fell apart following the commercial failure of 1970’s Funhouse
column4: Iggy shrewdly reassembled the Stooges for 1973’s Raw Power
column5: by recruiting James Williamson and demoting Ron Asheton to the bassist position. This is the iteration of the Stooges that has been touring steadily since 2010
column6: with Mike Watt replacing Asheton on bass (as he did for the late Dave Alexander in 2007) and honorary fifth Stooge Steve Mackay on sax. And the band's name reassumes its ""Iggy &"" prefix
column7: signaling another change in direction: Where the evil alchemy of the band's first two albums proved impossible to recapture on The Weirdness
column8: Raw Power's more playful
column9: darkly humorous trash-canned rock 'n' rolla provides the Stooges v4.0 with a more easily pliable template to work from.

column1: That's not to say Ready to Die matches the live-wire abandon of its 1973 antecedent-- not even close. And the tame
column2: contained nature of even its most petulant tracks is all the more disappointing given that this band can still absolutely slay onstage
column3: serif;"">. All those years working in Silicon Valley haven't diminished Williamson's fiery fretwork (see: the “Gimme Danger”-styled grind of “Burn”)
column4: but Iggy's delivery is too wry to exude rage
column5: the songs rarely rise above a mid-tempo chug
column6: and Mackay's jovial sax blurts are way more roadhouse than Funhouse. But
column7: unlike The Weirdness
column8: the palpable lack of menace feels intentional
column9: and more true to a band that
column10: in the wake of Asheton’s death and their own advancing ages
column11: has good reason to question its own mortality. Over the shake-appealing shimmy of “Gun” (essentially
column12: a prettied-up “Your Pretty Face Is Going to Hell”)
column13: Iggy sings
column14: “If I had a fucking gun/ I could shoot at everyone
column15: ” a seemingly throwaway
column16: suddenly topical line that recycles one of the more odious lyrics from The Weirdness (“my idea of fun/ is killing everyone”). But where the latter reeked of forced misanthropy
column17: there’s a cheeky nonchalance to his voice here that acknowledges the absurdity of such idle threats coming from a reasonably content 66 year old. Forty years removed from the kamikaze death-trip fantasies of Raw Power
column18: Ready to Die is the sound of Iggy admitting
column19: “I’m too old for this shit.” And he’s come armed with not one
column20: but three acoustic ballads to prove it.

column1: Of course
column2: we’re used to hearing Iggy mellow out at this point-- his last two solo efforts were a record of jazzy chansons and a low-key covers album featuring songs by the Beatles
column3: Serge Gainsbourg
column4: and Cole Porter. But it’s telling that he’s now exposing that sensitive side in the Stooges
column5: as if he’s trying to defuse the band’s formidable mythos from within. The Stooges made Iggy a punk-rock legend
column6: however
column7: that status has exacted a considerable physical toll
column8: one that
column9: to this day
column10: requires him to be the shirtless
column11: stage-diving psycho onstage even as his recent work suggests his interests now lie elsewhere. It’s hard to hear this album as anything but his attempt to punch out
column12: torn as it is between his desire to bow out with dignity and his duty to play the dirty old man for the fans. But where Iggy once made an effort to obscure his pervy provocations in coded language-- “T.V. Eye” had nothing to do with watching television-- Ready to Die yields unfortunate evidence of how he just can’t be arsed anymore
column13: resulting in the lazy-lothario lechery of  “DD's” (“I’m on my knees for those double-Ds”) and “Sex and Money” (“nipples come
column14: and nipples go”).

column1: In light of these numbskull regressions
column2: Ready to Die’s most raucous song
column3: “Job” seems less like a blue-collar working-man complaint (chorus: “I got a job/ but it don’t pay shit/ I got a job/ and I’m sick of it”) than a comment on the slog of being a Stooge. (After all
column4: for all their influence and infamy
column5: the band’s commercial prospects in 2013 are no better than they were in 1969.) So it comes as a great relief when Iggy starts waving the white flag on “Beat That Guy”
column6: a surprisingly radiant
column7: Petty-esque elegy that sounds less like an Iggy Pop song than a James Osterberg one
column8: as he tries to lay his wild-child persona to rest by ruefully admitting
column9: “I’m running out of space/ I’ve run out of time.” The knockout blow is delivered by “The Departed”
column10: a hushed acoustic lullaby that effectively serves as a requiem for both Asheton and the Stooges as an entity: Williamson bookends the track with understated quotes of “I Wanna Be Your Dog
column11: ” while
column12: in between
column13: Iggy repackages old lyrics into fortune-cookie bursts of reflective
column14: Yoda-like wisdom. (“Serious talk’s no fun … this nightlife is just a death trip.”) The song shares its name with Martin Scorsese’s recent Oscar winner
column15: but it’s more reminiscent of that final shot in Goodfellas where Ray Liotta’s reformed gangster retrieves the morning paper from his doorstep: it's the sound of a notorious bad-ass leaving his unsavoury past behind
column16:
resigned to living the rest of his life as a schnook.

column1: It stands to reason many ATDI fans discovered their discography in reverse order
column2: and if you take the headfirst dive into <i>Acrobatic Tenement
column3: you’re shocked at how the same people responsible for “One Armed Scissor” sound every bit as naïve and scrawny as you’d expect of a band who named themselves after a Poison lyric. It’s not exactly their Pablo Honey: many early adapters still will vouch for it as their best and most honest record and they sound like a younger version of themselves more than a completely different version.

column1: They more or less had an idea of what they wanted to sound like. Whether it’s the murky
column2: almost clean guitar tone
column3: the dual-frontman vocal interaction or just a tendency to get as strident as possible on the chorus
column4: much of Acrobatic Tenement was on loan from Fugazi and their ilk. Bixler-Zavala’s vocals are likewise fully formed and while his lyrics tend to be a lot more grounded in tangible goods than they were later on
column5: there’s still a lot of decoder-ring jabberwocky; “Initiation” is rumored to be about ATDI groupies
column6: “Ebroglio” documents a friend’s suicide
column7: but even the hardworking commenters at songmeanings.net think most of these tracks are about breakups
column8: a sure sign that they’re out of ideas.

column1: But the most startling aspect of Acrobatic Tenement is its anemic sound
column2: which allows you to visualize At the Drive-In at the “Bandcamp with local gigs” phase of their career. It’s meant as a souvenir and possible replacement for their “you had to be there” live show; I use that term in the most literal sense
column3: since even if their exhausting touring regimen is still spoken of in hushed tones
column4: it rarely got them out of the Southwest. And Acrobatic Tenement struggles with the same quandary that faces bands whose live performance far outstrips their songwriting and recording skills: considering that the budget was taken from couch cushions (a rumored $600)
column5: why not just
column6: you know
column7: record a live show? I couldn’t imagine Acrobatic Tenement sounding any less slick-- even compared to the brickwalled Relationship of Command
column8: the intended dynamics of “Skips On The Record” and “Schaffino” are rendered theoretical at best
column9: the guitars mostly sound like someone forgot to hit a distortion pedal
column10: and there are several times during the otherwise excellent “Ticklish” where it actually sounds like someone forgot to hit their distortion pedal until midway through a riff.

column1: There are still good songs on Acrobatic Tenement-- “Initiation” and “Star Slight” in particular stand out as strong examples of where post-hardcore was at the time and where At the Drive-In could’ve taken it. But really
column2: the reissue of Acrobatic Tenement is better used as a means of scaling At the Drive-In’s subsequent leaps and bounds-- guitarist/vocalist Jim Ward praised it for its “earnest and pure excitement
column3: ” relative to Relationship’s “craftsmanship.” In other words
column4: both artist and listener alike can appreciate Acrobatic Tenement as the record At the Drive-In made because they really didn’t know any better.

column4: kitschy

column12: nu-metal standard bearer

column1: Make no mistake

Bixler-Zavala’s eventual shift towards prog-metal operatics aren’t as much of a surprise in retrospect listening to the belted chorus of “Sleepwalk Capsules.”

column1: But while Relationship of Command is a juggernaut
column2: it’s not invincible. For one thing
column3: you can sense the fissures forming in ATDI’s songwriting team-- the undeniable chorus of “Invalid Litter Dept.” (you know

column6: because he was available and this was a major label rock album in 2000. Meanwhile
column7: Relationship’s second half anticipates the utilitarian modern rock of Ward’s Sparta; Wallace and ATDI are equally complicit in turning “Quarantined” into a leaden slog and “Cosmonaut” into an undifferentiated flurry of pugilistic guitar.

but no ever said they were romantic.

New albums by Pan American
column4: the project started by Labradford singer/guitarist Mark Nelson at the tail-end of the 1990s
column5: have steadily become scarce. It's been four years since the last one
column6: the ambient leaning White Bird Release. If that record was all long
column7: wintery shadows
column8: this one brings in a touch of warmth from earlier Pan American recordings. The slight shift in tone is mirrored by a change in personnel
column9: with Nelson bringing past collaborator Steven Hess on board as a full-time member of the band. Labradford's Bobby Donne contributes bass on certain songs
column10: helping underpin the harsher sounds by providing a soft bedrock for the players to lean into. <i>Cloud Room
column11: Glass Room was designed to be played live
column12: suggesting a few frayed edges might have cut into the sound. In fact
column13: the opposite is true
column14: with Nelson's fondness for clear-eyed production values still firmly intact.

column1: Those subtle adjustments from the last Pan American record to this one haven't stopped Nelson from tooling around with customary fascinations. An undercurrent of dub sometimes swells up
column2: the influence of Kompakt-style minimal techno can be felt. The way Nelson can beautifully guide a song via the peaks and troughs of his guitar playing must surely come easy to him at this point
column3: although there's never a sense of him lapsing into auto-pilot. As such
column4: anyone looking for a way in to Pan American would be wise to start at this relatively accessible point and work backward. Still
column5: part of the charm of this project is the way it's staged in isolation
column6: with little apparent concern for who is listening or where this music might sit with their peers. That sense of being loosely unanchored from the world gives Cloud Room its alien appeal
column7: making its instrumental drift ripe for personal interpretation.

column1: The ""live band"" approach taken on this album makes it feel a little more human than some of the heavily processed material that's come out under the Pan American name
column2: such as 2000's 360 Business/360 Bypass. It's especially apparent when Hess's percussion is given space to breathe
column3: either as a root to the sound on the tender ""Relays"" or as a guiding force for the extended flashes of guitar squall on ""Virginia Waveform"". If that's disconcerting to longtime listeners
column4: it shouldn't be; there's plenty of material that takes the ""guys in a room"" method and figures out how to make it sound like it couldn't have been made that way. ""Fifth Avenue 1960"" is a highlight
column5: full of electronics treated with cavernous echo that fill out an undercurrent of menace that sporadically surfaces elsewhere.

column1: Like most of the material Nelson has released over the years
column2: the primary takeaway from Cloud Room is a notion of the control he exercises over his work no matter where it takes him. He can work around the white-light loops that flicker through understated pieces like ""Glass Room at the Airport""
column3: or he can amass a towering stack of splintery discordance on ""Laurel South"". But there's always a sense of an assured hand guiding it all
column4: bringing each part together to serve the greater whole. Even his wilder guitar pieces never reach the point where it feels like he's letting go and there's a sense of order being maintained
column5: of advances being carefully spun through a strict framework. It feels good to be back here again
column6: in a place that's become increasingly rare
column7:
but one flushed with a warm feeling of familiarity.

column3: the French electronic music duo Daft Punk teamed up with composer and arranger Joseph Trapanese to score a flashy but hollow reboot of the classic sci-fi movie Tron. As fuel for an action flick
column4: it was an efficient piece of work. A full orchestra and expensive synthetic tones provided the requisite sweep and height; the expected bombast and wonder. But it was hardly recognizable as music by Daft Punk
column5: which was odd because their usual aesthetic would have been such a dynamic fit for the movie's neon world. The dance music auteurs all but vanished behind a deluxe sheen
column6: into the idioms of Hans Zimmer and John Williams. Three years later
column7: the scenario is playing out again with eerie accuracy: Ryan Dombal's review of the Tron: Legacy OST would perfectly fit M83's Oblivion OST with the replacement of a couple proper nouns.

column1: Like Tron: Legacy
column2: Oblivion is a sci-fi extravaganza
column3: directed by Joseph Kosinski
column4: where awesome visual spectacles are staged around a wispy emotional core. Once again
column5: an acclaimed French electronic act pairs with Trapanese and forsakes its artistic identity to satisfy the generic musical conventions of summer blockbusters. Trapanese's orchestration and M83's poppy electronic shoegaze blended well on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15881-hurry-up-were-dreaming/""><i>Hurry Up
column6: We’re Dreaming
column7: the breakthrough album that opened the door for Anthony Gonzalez to make literally rather than figuratively ""cinematic"" music in the mainstream. The tradeoff is that Gonzalez by necessity adapts to Trapanese
column8: the professional here
column9: so thoroughly that it was startling to see M83 in the credits. That churning electronic fingerprint
column10: reportedly deemed ""too indie"" for a Tom Cruise vehicle
column11: is smeared out to an absurd degree. Why hire Gonzalez at all if you don't want raw indie eagerness?

column1: Gonzalez is a masterful stylist
column2: but an average composer at best
column3: which makes the subtraction of his style rather fatal for the Oblivion OST as a standalone experience. The music is more unmemorable than bad
column4: though occasionally Gonzalez's inexperience
column5: which seems to limit what Trapanese can do as well
column6: shows: ""Tech 49"" cheats its way from tense pulse to driving resolution with desultory orchestral passages
column7: while ""Odyssey Rescue"" spatters an erratic path through ambiguously related parts
column8: making us keenly aware of the missing onscreen action that would make sense of it. There are brighter spots: If you took ""Waking Up"" and changed the pounding timpani to synthetic toms
column9: the string section to keyboards and arpeggiators
column10: then you would have a generic but recognizable M83 song on your hands. And Gonzalez's signature arc
column11: where arrangements seem to accelerate through space and then burst into flames upon atmospheric reentry
column12: is evident in ""StarWaves"". But you have to listen pretty hard to hear the ghostly remains of his hand in these backdrops for chase scenes and dream sequences.

column1: Gonzalez does get one pure M83 moment on the title track
column2: which is taut and effervescent with heartfelt vocals from Susanne Sundfør. More like it would have made for a better album that clashed terribly with the cold
column3: inhuman film to which it was attached. It would be foolish to conflate one instance of creative compromise with M83 being compromised in principle. Artists needn't be slaves to their own visions all the time
column4: and there's nothing wrong with working a job for pay. The only real problem with the Oblivion OST is that it was released as M83
column5: which isn't a neutral funnel for Gonzalez's musical craftsmanship. It's a very specific set of promises that go badly unfulfilled. Gonzalez knows this
column6: telling Pitchfork that he would have preferred to release it as ""Anthony Gonzalez and Joe Trapanese."" Universal
column7: more interested in the brand than the man
column8: disagreed. The people who buy action-movie OSTs-- whomever they are-- should be satisfied. But to M83 fans
column9:
this will just be a cautionary tale about an indie auteur turning his back on little machines he can control and getting mauled by a huge one-- Hollywood focus groups-- which he can't.

“You can learn the names of notes and how to make chords that other people use
column2: but that’s pretty limiting
column3: ” wrote David Fair in his mini-manifesto How to Play Guitar. “If you ignore the chords your options are infinite and you can master guitar playing in one day.” Listen to ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts
column4: the sprawling
column5: primitive
column6: raucous debut of Fair’s band Half Japanese
column7: and you probably won’t be surprised that David and his brother Jad never learned to play guitar in any traditional way. But it would be wrong to assume that they couldn’t learn. Read David again: “If you ignore the chords…” Half Japanese made a choice. They weren’t clueless outsiders or deluded novices. Primitiveness was their calling
column8: not their fate.

column1: It was also their path to freedom. As David says
column2: lack of knowledge can mean infinite options
column3: and he and Jad explore a lot of them on <i>½ Gentleman / Not Beasts
column4: often touted as the first (and only) triple-LP debut in rock history. That may or may not be true
column5: but it certainly was the least likely. Before it came out
column6: the Fair brothers had made just a few 7-inches and cassettes
column7: recorded at home (where they lived with their parents) and released on their own label
column8: 50 Skidillion Watts. (One of those early tapes was called ½ Gentlemen / ½ Beasts
column9: but the Fairs changed it to Not Beasts for the box since
column10: according to David
column11: “we’re nice guys.”) British label Armageddon’s offer to put out a box set was so unusual that
column12: when interviewed in the Half Japanese documentary The Band That Would Be King
column13: the Fairs’ parents could only compare it to a then-new box set by Frank Sinatra.

column1: Musically
column2: though
column3: giving Half Japanese six album sides to fill with their spilling ideas made a lot of sense. In no less than 50 songs (now 86 on Fire’s 4LP reissue)
column4: the Fair brothers injected their caveman racket-- usually crafted solely on cardboard-sounding drums and strangled guitar-- into loud punk blasts
column5: shapeless rants
column6: heartfelt confessions
column7: minimal experiments
column8: audio collages
column9: and twisted covers of their heroes the Velvet Underground
column10: Jonathan Richman
column11: and Buddy Holly. Some songs sound like a suburban parallel to the concurrent
column12: atonal no wave movement in New York (David’s chord-avoiding guitar is often a dead ringer for the dissonant shrieks of DNA’s Arto Lindsay). But Half Japanese replaced no wave’s burned-out nihilism with sleeve-worn
column13: open-wound emotion.

column1: Much of that emotion comes from Jad’s adolesecent voice and love-letter lyrics. On bracingly honest cuts like “Shy Around Girls”
column2: “Dream Date”
column3: and “School of Love”
column4: he brings the sentimentality of a lovelorn teenager to the musical equivalent of primal scream therapy. (It’s telling that
column5: according to later member Don Fleming
column6: David claimed that Half Japanese had two kinds of songs: “Monster songs and love songs.”) With these proto-emo bombs
column7: the Fairs predicted a lot of future lo-fi rock
column8: especially the home-taped ballads of Daniel Johnston and the nursery-rhyme swing of Beat Happening.

column1: But don’t mistake Half Japanese’s naked emotion for naïveté-- Jad and David knew exactly what they were doing. That’s especially clear in ½ Gentlemen’s audio experiments
column2: which can be surprisingly formal. The bass cycling through “Du Du Du / Du Du Du” evokes Steve Reich-style minimalism; the repeated notes and found sounds on “T / T / T / T / T” would fit on a Faust LP; the slashing guitar and wordless babble of “Grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr” suggests Derek Bailey backing Yoko Ono; and “Jad Interview”
column3: one of Fire’s bonus tracks
column4: is a word-jazz-like vocal-collage. These aren’t random noodlings that hit on something by chance. There’s clear thought behind each construction
column5: ironic considering how loose the more traditional “songs” are.

column1: Another sign that Half Japanese were more clever than they looked is ½ Gentlemen’s sly sense of humor. You can hear Jad and David winking through the fake-protest chant “No More Beatle Mania” (“once was enough!” Jad screams)
column2: the drooling whine of “I Don’t Want to Have Mono No More”
column3: and the rock-fantasy-camp scenario of “Battle of the Bands”
column4: wherein “backup singers” Mick Jagger and Johnny Rotten are too busy watching David to actually sing. Even funnier are the prankster-ish cover versions
column5: wherein the band rambles through classics as if blindfolded. Jad never alters his singing style throughout “Stooges Medley” (another Fire bonus track)
column6: the musical equivalent of Andy Kaufman doing impressions by merely reciting lines without changing his “Foreign Man” voice. If anyone thought Half Japanese was a hoax
column7: David and Jad were clearly happy to feed that rumor. Yet their brazen refusal to conform to the originals captures the Stooges’ spirit more than any faithful cover could.

column1: All this fearless amateurism can make ½ Gentlemen a brutal listen. As their career went on
column2: Half Japanese gradually turned their monster love songs into more listenable tunes that influenced a generation of indie rockers (most famously
column3: Kurt Cobain brought them along on Nirvana’s In Utero tour and was wearing their t-shirt when he died). But ½ Gentlemen
column4: in its near-giddy willingness to push sound past the limits of amps and tape recorders
column5: is more a precursor to noisy rock experiments like the kiddie nightmares of Happy Flowers
column6: the trash-can blues of Pussy Galore
column7: or the early splatter of Boredoms.

column1: Still
column2: even at its most grating
column3: there’s always a loudly-beating heart inside 1/2 Gentlemen. It’s earnest
column4: eager
column5: and takes a wry view of the world that makes it endearing. And it’s so hard to predict what’s going to happen at any given point that the music never feels dated. Because it was based mostly on their own hermetic ideas
column6: the Fair brothers’ primitivism blasts through the years
column7: too hot for any time period to hold onto. Maybe that’s the best thing about ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts: even today
column8: over three decades later
column9: you can picture Jad and David banging it out in their parents’ house
column10:
thrilled at what they’re discovering.

column7: and
