There's something about being a band unstuck in time that makes the question of aging and consistency almost beside the point. Out There
column2: the debut Heliocentrics album from 2007
column3: still sounds good six years later-- largely because it would've sounded good 40 years prior. Evoking eras without highlighting their most obvious reference points-- all in the process of concocting internationally minded jazz-funk without definitively pointing towards specific geographical sources-- drummer Malcolm Catto assembled a group that only loosely hinted at nostalgic exotica. Instead
column4: they became a live-band culmination of every obsessive hip-hop-era producer's drive to fall deeper into a rabbit hole of the previously unheard. That they were able to translate that experience into collaborative albums with Middle Eastern music scholar Lloyd Miller and Ethio-jazz cornerstone Mulatu Astatke was not only a big honor
column5: but a fitting one.

column1: And yet with all their previous works' engagement with this hazy '70s-via-'90s-via-now sample-source sound
column2: 13 Degrees of Reality finds another angle. The catch is that this their new common thread is a nervous
column3: conspiracy-minded anxiety
column4: the kind that burbles up during points in recent history when the horrible seems feasible. There's not really anything inherently dread-inducing about the Heliocentrics' music itself
column5: which ranges anywhere from delicate beauty to sweaty-palmed intensity. But it can be convincingly heard as a soundtrack to justified paranoia when the first voices on the album are George H.W. Bush's invocation of the “New World Order” segueing into Malcolm X revealing the American dream as an “American nightmare.”

column1: A front-to-back listen hints at barely-controlled chaos simmering for a bit before fading into a wide
column2: dusty horizon. Second track “Ethnicity” reveals a twitchy energy
column3: built off twanging strings
column4: mountainous hard rock breaks
column5: and wandering melodic chimes so distorted by reverb they could be anything from marimbas to thumb pianos. “Mysterious Ways” folds the rhythm section from Can's “Vitamin C” into origami
column6: flips the speed to 45
column7: and jabs at it with analog-electronic stings that have all the interrogatory jabber of Sun Ra's more chaotic pieces. And “Descarga Electronica” hammers out tendon-snapping MPB rhythms drenched in a glaze of bristly guitar feedback. But everything eventually flattens out into an almost meditative reverie once “Wrecking Ball” and its 7-and-change minutes of gauzy
column8: slow-motion acid-funk emerges. By the time the twangy desert soul of “Mr. Owusu
column9: I Presume?” and the rain-drenched
column10: humid glimmer of the kalimba-spattered “Black Sky” seep through the speakers
column11: it feels like snapping out of a jarring but invigorating low orbit into something a bit more free-floating and warm.

column1: Brief interludes call up the defiant croak of William S. Burroughs (“No
column2: we will not listen to you
column3: we have had enough of your common bullshit”) and distant-sounding transmissions from creepy-sounding entities who claim to have access to peoples' dreams and minds. But the album
column4: even as it strings these clips together
column5: isn't some kitschy freak-out montage. It's got the breadth of a comprehensively adventurous band
column6: able to balance a steady motorik churn midway between Kraut and deep soul while letting the pull of improvisational tangents and dub distortion shift the picture. If that style can pull off the tense resistance that the distorted voice clips hint at
column7:
it also works as its own thing-- an unnerving album composed of alluring pieces.

column1: And then there's ""Cloud Aura""

column12: sure
column13:
but musically most of all.

For a while
column2: Maryland singer/songwriter Sam Ray was in a group called Teen Suicide that was intensely loved by a few. Ray grew weary of the melodramatic band name
column3: apparently
column4: and all it implied
column5: so Teen Suicide perished
column6: and the hushed and lovely indie pop outfit Julia Brown was born. Ray introduced his new band to his fans with a defensive flourish: ""If you liked Teen Suicide 'cause of pop songwriting you'll probably like the new band but if you just liked the really over-dramatic drug addict depression catharsis stuff you'll be disappointed and I'll be glad
column7: he wrote on the Teen Suicide Facebook page. He probably didn't need to issue such a ringing pronouncement; Julia Brown
column8: while softer
column9: explore similar darkness with a sweet sadness that does
column10: in fact
column11: feel grown-up.

column1: To Be Close to You is their first official release. It was recorded straight to tape
column2: an act of aesthetic devotion that ensures singular focus on things like incidental sounds: In between songs
column3: you hear doodly guitar moments
column4: muffled coughs
column5: the muttering and teasing of his band mates. Tape hiss isn't a background element here
column6: it's an instrument: on some songs
column7: it's practically the lead singer. ""Recorded at various places over a long period of time
column8: the liner notes indicate
column9: and you can hear
column10: in the busy shuffling of the players and the constantly changing room-space
column11: the tape player being plopped in a series of bedrooms.

column1: For lo-fi or home-taping pop aficionados
column2: this kind of sound world is a reward in itself
column3: and for hardcore fans
column4: To Be Close to You will be instantly inviting. The sound has the blotted
column5: bleedy edges you associate with the tape medium; every sharp edge smoothed out
column6: every sound muffled and half-swallowed. To Be Close to You streams by in a soothing murmur that registers as intimate above all.

column1: The sound is so warm and reassuring that you initially miss the complexity and craft of the music. But on repeated listens
column2: you hear a serious songwriter's mind at work. The glimmering riff on ""Library"" is based on a simple chord progression
column3: but Ray's dense
column4: arpeggiated playing locates a hypnotically cyclical tune in it that is almost as catchy as his unassuming vocal lead. When the song launches into double time
column5: a sawing viola traces the arc of Ray's melody before he sings it. There are surprising corners to stumble on in the arrangements: the brooding ""i will do this for the rest of my life"" ends with some skirling backwards guitars
column6: while ""i was my own favorite tv show the summer my tv broke"" ends in a little pink-blue sunset of viola
column7: cello
column8: glockenspiel
column9: and harmonium. ""Virginia"" is built on a rickety saloon piano in 3/4 time. A few of the songs repeat themselves in acoustic demo form
column10: just in case you like them better that way
column11: and to give you a better sense of how they were built.

column1: It's also a pleasure to eventually discover Sam Ray's dark
column2: sometimes-mordant lyrics
column3: which are also lying just beneath the cottony yawn of the tape. The bleak ""how I spent my summer"" opens with a brief recorded clip of someone muttering ""I was doing heroin in my car and listening to 'Genius of Love'
column4: the word ""heroin"" scrambled slightly. The lyrics depict someone reeling from a loss they cannot process: ""I will move your clothes from one side of the bed to the other/ I will stay in your bed all day/ Whatever it takes/ Taking Valium."" ""i will do this for the rest of my life"" turns on the shrugging refrain
column5: ""I guess you mean more to me than nothing

column1: The sweetly unassuming kind of home-made pop music that Julia Brown make is easily overlooked when it is untethered from its home base; so much of indie-pop's magic resides in its locality

and was looking to expand outward: His vision seems big enough to accomodate whatever canvas he works on next.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19176/homepage_large.4f7dc06b.jpg|The Great Perhaps|594.0|The Boy Least Likely To|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2013-04-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:41.956781|"

UK duo The Boy Least Likely To have emerged as a beacon of stability within the tumultuous confines of the indie pop world by detaching themselves from the hype cycle and embarking on a course of measured release and evolution. In his review of the band's second album
column2: 2009's The Law of the Playground
column3: Marc Hogan spent a considerable amount of time grappling with the album's outmoded feel
column4: ultimately concluding that the record was ""especially out of step in 2009."" Four years later
column5: that statement still rings true: while the reigning hip sound has shifted from Hogan's descriptions of harsh tones and flawless Auto-Tune to a sort of omnivorous polyglot pop
column6: the thoroughly twee vibe and simple songcraft of The Boy Least Likely To remains surprisingly anachronistic. Divorced from the context of the larger pop landscape
column7: the band's new album The Great Perhaps finds Jof Owen and Pete Hobbs progressing at their own pace
column8: exploring new sounds and becoming decreasingly reliant on the juxtaposition of child-like sonics and mature lyrical themes.

column1: The finest moments on The Great Perhaps typically revolve around the band's deployment of a previously unheard influence or instrument. Early single ""Climbing Out of Love"" is constructed around an indelible
column2: bubbly synth hook and a basic
column3: cycling acoustic guitar riff: the result is a touching electro-acoustic pop curio that's reminiscent of the brightest cuts from Bright Eyes' 2005 oddity Digital Ash in a Digital Urn. Another highlight is the gentle ballad ""Michael Collins
column4: which flashes a second or two of Beach House-like drum machine haze before taking a right turn into tasteful string orchestration and harmonies that could've been ripped from a late-period Band of Horses B-side. It's apparent that Hobbs and Owen have been digesting the work of several of their contemporaries
column5: and the deployment of those influences is consistently strong on The Great Perhaps.

column1: The album's other great successes find Owen focusing on specific narratives and fleshing out songs with certain lyrical details
column2: rather than sticking to basic rhymes and big-picture concepts. ""Michael Collins"" uses the imagined experience of an early American astronaut to set up a consideration of our lack of perspective
column3: and the combination of that big lyrical reveal with aforementioned vocal harmony is strikingly touching. Elsewhere
column4: on the slow-paced lament ""The Dreamer Song
column5: Owen's mention of small items like flimsy spring blossoms and gin-lemonade cocktails greatly flesh out an otherwise standard tale of hopeless romanticism.

column1: That said
column2: a few songs over the course of The Great Perhaps' could use a lot more of this sort of detail. The album's weakest songs lean too heavily on the crutch of pairing sonic whimsy with adult rumination on love and loneliness
column3: and the result is a handful of maudlin cuts couched in cliché. In this vein
column4: the album's nadir is the blessedly quick ""Even Jesus Couldn't Mend My Broken Heart""
column5: which marries a sparkly Wiggles-worthy synth melody to the hopeless titular claim. The shock of this combination transcends surprise and quickly zooms into the realm of questionable taste; it feels like a cheap trick
column6: especially given the mature construction of the album's second half.

column1: There's a certain comfort found in following a band whose slow
column2: subtle growth seems entirely separated from the rapidly changing indie pop landscape. The Great Perhaps is another modestly successful step for The Boy Least Likely To
column3: reassurance that the band is still cranking out thoughtful
column4:
gentle work.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19223/homepage_large.bfe3f6a1.jpg|Baba Yaga|31287.0|Futurebirds|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2013-04-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:42.572765|"

In Slavic folklore
column2: Baba Yaga is a female monster who dwells in the forest and feasts on children. This doesn’t necessarily mean she’s evil-- in some stories
column3: she’s a benign or even helpful figure-- but she’s certainly mythical and definitely mysterious. For starry-eyed cosmic country-rock band Futurebirds
column4: Baba Yaga is also a metaphor
column5: for the rigors the Athens-based outfit endured while trying to locate a label to put out its stunning second record
column6: and for the ambiguous darkness that peers inside the lush sprawl of their beautiful
column7: foreboding songs.

column1: Futurebirds have been honing this sound-- a loose-limbed tangle of reverbed guitars
column2: hollered harmonies
column3: and driving yet contemplative Southern rock rhythms-- over the course of two EPs
column4: 2010’s full-length debut Hampton’s Lullaby
column5: and countless gigs in support of kindred spirits like the Drive-By Truckers and Heartless Bastards. For Baba Yaga
column6: they spent seven months sneaking in and out of recording sessions between tours
column7: eventually amassing 30 songs. (Since there are currently five songwriters in the band
column8: material tends to pile up over time.) Eventually the record was pared-down to 13 tracks
column9: but after languishing for months without a label
column10: Futurebirds began to worry whether its new record would ever be heard. The band decided to keep on touring
column11: and share the songs with live audiences
column12: in the hope that someone would notice. (Fat Possum later agreed to put out Baba Yaga.)

column1: Baba Yaga is very much an “on tour” record; the controlled chaos of Futurebirds’ live shows translates on record like never before. You feel the energy
column2: forgive any flubbed notes
column3: and soak in the past-midnight revelry. Many tracks extend past the five-minute mark
column4: with the excess padding coming from guitar solos stacked upon guitar solos
column5: and boisterous sing-alongs allowed to go on for several extra beats. Baba Yaga nails the melancholy of trying to chase and pin down something that’s special and fleeting
column6: because Futurebirds were clearly doing the same when recording these songs. This “something” might be best described as relief; Futurebirds’ twin obsessions on Baba Yaga are dysfunctional relationships and death
column7: with the music acting as a communal salve against the private anguish documented in the lyrics.

column1: Guitarist Thomas Johnson has said “the songs on this album seem to all come from a similar place
column2: which explains the consistent voice on Baba Yaga in spite of the number of different writers. The group’s most prolific composer
column3: Carter King
column4: has the best knack for narrative details
column5: outlining the “coffee beans and Ritalins” that keep the troubled couple at the center of “Virginia Slims” standing upright. In “Serial Bowls”
column6: an infectious Reckoning-era R.E.M. bounce obscures a discomforting portrait of spiritual bankruptcy: “When the nurse saw me drop/ She said mama should’ve used that birth control/ because where my heart was supposed to be/ was like nothing they'd ever seen/ there was nothing/ but a smoking hole.” King tries to side-step the encroaching blackness that surrounds him on “Death Awaits” by going surfing
column7: and finds Zen-like calm in the face of the inevitable: “Get rolled up in the wave
column8: cuz death awaits/ and it’s a mean death
column9: but it’s a clean death.”

column1: King’s songs might shine the brightest
column2: but Futurebirds is unmistakably a band. Each member makes valuable contributions: Johnson’s stormy guitar meltdown “Dig”
column3: Daniel Womack’s beatific campfire ballad “Heavy Weights”
column4: Payton Bradford’s heart-tugging “Keith and Donna” (who might be the only happy couple on Baba Yaga)
column5: and Brannen Miles’ jaunty folk strummer “The Light”. The only Futurebird who doesn’t write
column6: Dennis Love
column7: is the group’s most essential instrumentalist; his striking pedal-steel guitar lines cut through the din on Baba Yaga with the invigorating precision of Ralph Mooney soaring above Waylon Jennings and the Waylors. Take any member out of the equation and the captivating mess of Baba Yaga wouldn’t be splayed in precisely the right places. the rough spots are kind of the whole point.

Snoop Dogg has spent the last decade of his career building a persona based on intrinsic and intentional humor. So when he announced his metamorphosis into the reggae singer Snoop Lion last year while casually referred to himself as the reincarnation of Bob Marley
column5: it was hard not to have a chuckle. The transformation seemed likely to blow over the same way Snoop’s stints as talk show host
column6: sketch comedy actor and porn director did-- another half-remembered bit of listless bond diversification from a rap luminary grown bored of rapping. But Snoop really seemed invested in this Lion thing: his plan to hang out in Jamaica to record a reggae album quickly became a full-fledged Rastafarian spirit journey with guidance from Marley bandmate and roots reggae legend Bunny Wailer and the Rastafari Millennium Council. All of which was ultimately documented in the film Reincarnated and consummated in the album of the same name. Upon release
column7: though
column8: the film immediately infuriated Bunny
column9: who issued a withering polemic castigating Snoop for what he felt was a cavalier and opportunistic misappropriation of Rastafarian culture.

column1: Many of the complaints about the film could be made against the album: Reincarnated is constantly on the hunt for a sense of communion with a world just out of its reach. Snoop’s hardly a natural as a reggae singer
column2: and his performances here are riddled with leaden vocalizing
column3: fortune cookie-grade lyrical mundanities (“Take care of Mother Earth cause-ah she be the planet”) and dreadful fake patois. He wisely buttresses himself with a coalition of singers and actual reggae artists tasked with lending this project the hooks and credibility that he can’t muster. The result is something akin to his short-lived career hosting and directing adult film: you sense Snoop milling around in the background while professionals do the heavy lifting. Singer-songwriter Angela Hunte’s extensive co-writing and backing vocals provide the understated beating heart of the record
column4: and guests like Mavado and Popcaan shine for knowing their way around a reggae fusion record. But the guests can’t always carry the weight: dancehall stalwart Mr. Vegas can’t save “Fruit Juice” from its clunky concept
column5: and the Akon cover “Tired of Running” aims for profundity but lands on karaoke
column6: even with vocals from the man himself to guide the way.

column1: Reincarnated’s strong suit is its production
column2: which was handled in large part by Diplo’s Major Lazer braintrust with help from Vybz Kartel collaborator Dre Skull and producer/songwriter Ariel Rechtshaid. The album’s sonic architects ease off their trademark futuristic dance floor bedlam here
column3: opting instead for what sounds like a lovingly cultivated genre-bending mixtape. Reincarnated flits from the rock-reggae fusion of “Rebel Way” to the old school dancehall of “Here Comes the King” to the lumbering boom bap of “Lighters Up” early on. And then it makes stops at roots reggae for “So Long” and spectral dub on “No Guns Allowed”
column4: which cleverly lays a mellotron line reminiscent of Gorillaz’ “Clint Eastwood” over a loop of Beirut’s “Nantes”. Things get hairy with “Get Away”
column5: which rehashes elements of “Pon de Floor” in spots
column6: and “The Good Good”
column7: a drab acoustic jingle better suited to pad out the back end of a Matisyahu album
column8: but missteps on the production front are mercifully scant.

column1: Snoop Lion’s sage choice of collaborators saves Reincarnated from his limited vision of reggae songwriting and Rasta culture
column2: and the album gets its biggest payoff from its most unlikely contributor. Album closer “Ashtrays & Heartbreaks” parlays Snoop’s partying in memory of lost loved ones into a devastating bridge from Miley Cyrus about pulling it together when your buzz wears off and a chorus both wracked with grief and brimming with determination. “Ashtrays & Heartbreaks” flips Snoop’s pat Hallmark musings and crutch-like over-reliance on more nimble singers into assets to deliver the album’s one true stunner. Reincarnated is spotted with little moments like these
column3: where you begin to see how a batshit late career gear shift might make just a dash of sense executed correctly. Reincarnated doesn't make a case for Snoop as a singer of any stripe. He should honestly stick to rap. And it doesn’t offer much evidence that this Rastafarian conversion isn’t the marketing ploy Bunny Wailer is convinced it is. Too much of it is an ill-advised cultural safari that’s too weird to fly but too monied to fail. But where it succeeds
column4: Reincarnated forces you to forget the principal ridiculousness of the enterprise
column5:
and that is no small feat.

It’s fitting that so much talk about shoegaze plays up security-- the sound is womblike
column2: it blankets you

column5: reverb and distortion can be used to minimize mistakes while bands that stay within the established boundaries are often rewarded by its intense loyalists. Case in point
column6: No Joy; if you like shoegaze
column7: you liked No Joy’s 2010 debut Ghost Blonde
column8: as it was a solid

column10: Brother Kite or A Place to Bury Stangers record can tell you
column11: bands who successfully learned how to synthesize fuzz and pop fizz from Loveless or Psychocandy keel over fast once the training wheels come off. Last year’s Negaverse EP did at least acknowledge a need for a new direction
column12: even if it ventured further into murk. However
column13: the clarity and concision of Wait to Pleasure throws everything into reverse

column1: The easiest way to understand the difference between Wait to Pleasure and its predecessor is to think about the tactile difference between heat and humidity. Whereas the latter was sticky
column2: immersive and overwhelming
column3: Wait to Pleasure offers 11 distinct
column4: tactile sensations that are often diametrically opposed yet placed consecutively; opener “E” slowly boils over after five minutes of glam rock stomp
column5: while the slo-mo pop of “Hare Tarot Lies” calmly lazes in unseasonal warmth. The breakneck pace of “Lizard Kids” leaves the scent of burnt rubber on desert highway after the white hot sensuality of “Blue Neck Riviera”’s dirty electroclash. “Ignored Pets” sizzles
column6: “Pleasure” soothes. It’s a cohesion based on interaction rather than similarity
column7: maintaining a flow that displays No Joy’s subtly expansive range and adds a cumulative
column8: positive effect to already strong individual components.

column1: It’s all the more impressive that they’re able to do so while maintaining the raw elements of Ghost Blonde. While adept at diaphanous cooing
column2: Jasamine White-Gluz and Laura Lloyd’s vocals take on far more of a lead role with piercing
column3: major-key hooks. The guitars are still singed by redlining distortion
column4: but within the context of Wait to Pleasure’s sweeter production
column5: they tend to caramelize rather than corrode. And between “Lizard Kids” and “Ignored Pets”
column6: they’ve established a stylistic template that distinguishes a No Joy song from those of their peers-- combining the pummeling
column7: barely contained pace of a punk rhythm section with shoegaze’s distended high end
column8: rushing through a light net of harmonized vocals that are reverbed to the point of being mere phonetics.

column1: It can be tough to make out the intentionally wordless lyrics from the expressive ones
column2: so the incorporation of synthetic elements tends to bring out their humanity. “Lunar Phobia” follows a continuum of bands whose names served as adjectives for their own sound (Lush
column3: Curve)
column4: beat-driven without crossing over to dance music
column5: and tricked out with a wealth of intriguing effects and layers: bird call vocal samples placed against wafting harmonies
column6: juddering kick drums swapping with backmasked snares
column7: tremolo guitars and raw feedback. “Blue Neck Riviera” goes even further into rhythmic clangor
column8: the blackened
column9: deadpan vocals and clacking drum machines recasting Ladytron as lo-fi nightcrawlers before it revisits the Negaverse album cover
column10: taking off toward the rainbow horizon in its second half.

column1: While improving on the sheer sound of Ghost Blonde on nearly every level
column2: No Joy are still more suggestive than declarative. Allusive titles such as “Night Slug”
column3: “Blue Neck Riviera”
column4: and “Wrack Attack” come off as evidence of an inherent playfulness as well as a wide range of interests
column5: even if No Joy’s lyrics are too deep in the mix to tell if they actually do refer in any way to the techno label
column6: Florida’s Emerald Coast
column7: or ""Saved By the Bell"". A certain kind of impersonality might seem like a cost of doing business in this genre
column8: but within the context of <i>Wait to Pleasure
column9: there’s compensation in hearing No Joy express themselves as a band rather than as people. If you like shoegaze
column10: you’ll probably still like No Joy
column11:
but Wait to Pleasure’s triumph is making it far less of a requirement.

Both of English/German singer Annika Henderson’s releases to date have been named Anika: her 2010 Stones Throw/Invada debut
column3: and now this six-track EP. Note the single “n” in her stage name; she once described the difference as offering “part of me
column4: not all of me
column5: ” stating
column6: “You’re indestructible if you split yourself into little bits.” She’s succeeded in so much as it still seems hard to get an idea of the real Henderson. Sure
column7: she was once a Berlin-based journalist reporting on education reform
column8: and lived in Bristol before that
column9: but the majority of her releases have comprised fantastically dank
column10: intimidating dub covers of pop and folk songs with BEAK> as her backing band
column11: which haven't immediately conveyed a great deal about her.

column1: It’d be unfair to imply that there’s any lack of personality in Anika’s music
column2: though. On the Anika EP
column3: which features one original
column4: there’s a divide between covers to which she brings a certain bloodlust
column5: and those from which she strips it away completely. Her vocal on Ray Davies’ plangent
column6: eerie midnight votive “I Go to Sleep” has a Weimar-like swoop that takes languid
column7: elegant steps around the staccato waltz of the organ and the raw snaps that punctuate each line. The unusual lope in her brusque singing style makes it seem tragic
column8: passionate even. She barks commandingly on a brilliant cover of “In the City”
column9: one of Chromatics’ less impassioned songs
column10: which becomes beefier and funkier in Henderson’s hands. She and her band evoke a Chic shimmy
column11: a Pop Group tremulousness
column12: and add nervy grit to the song that makes it relatable to anyone who doesn’t live in Chromatics’ pastel L.A. fantasy.

column1: On a cover of the Crystals’ “He Hit Me”
column2: Henderson's medicated
column3: dispassionate vocal plays like a coping mechanism to recount the grisly details of an assault to a police officer’s notebook. The band match the surprisingly proto-dubby feel of Spector's original arrangement
column4: but trade the Crystals’ sweet female chorus for a warped
column5: lurching
column6: seasick siren coven
column7: and underpin the whole song with a buzzsaw drone. She maintains the slightest presence on Shocking Blue’s “Love Buzz”
column8: singing in a taunting
column9: distant tone
column10: this time from the perspective of the emotional abuser
column11: dissolving into the chorus as BEAK> push the original’s no-wave minimalism into an almost Eastern palette.

column1: The final two songs on the Anika EP are adapted from the Anika LP
column2: which may make this collection seem like an unnecessary purchase
column3: but they help to solidify Henderson's creative political stance. A redux of her take on Yoko Ono’s “Yang Yang”
column4: a song about the dehumanization of the sexes
column5: is curdled and blurred
column6: though her call to “join the revolution” leaps out from behind the lurching Doppler guitar. A dub version of her own “No-One’s There” isn’t quite as striking as the original
column7: but on the chorus-- “Stop looking over your shoulder/ No-one’s there”-- Geoff Barrow’s production on her voice adds a spatial dimension that warns against her command. Suddenly
column8: she’s cut off mid-line
column9: as if she's been yanked by the throat by an undetected assailant.

column1: Henderson has said that she never wants her music “to shy away from articulating what I believe in
column2: ” yet her original decision to release mostly covers was because she thought releasing an album of her political material “would have been far too heavy for anyone that wasn’t familiar with it.” It’s an intriguing juxtaposition
column3: either indicating a lack of confidence-- and awkwardness is crucial to both her live show and her decision to make music in the first place-- or a stealthier attempt to grease listeners’ ears for an even more jarring collection next time around.

column1: If there’s a political stance to be inferred from the distinctly unsentimental
column2: aloof interpretations she places on songs
column3: it recalls what Ellen Willis once wrote about “aesthete-punk” and “self-conscious formalist” Lou Reed
column4: whose music she <a href=""http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YhvBfNXvoQoC&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=%E2%80%9Can+attempt+to+purify+rock-and-roll
column5: +to+purge+it+of+all+those+associations+with+material+goodies+and+erotic+good+times.%E2%80%9D&source=bl&ots=EQA5HXuKF6&sig=WrwBgaMxg_Ed4ubl98iBLQaX0js&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gZV2UaTYB7DY0QXZhoG4BA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%E2%80%9Can%20attempt%20to%20purify%20rock-and-roll%2C%20to%20purge%20it%20of%20all%20those%20associations%20with%20material%20goodies%20and%20erotic%20good%20times.%E2%80%9D&f=false"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">saw as “an attempt to purify rock-and-roll

column7: with Nick Zinner describing it as “totally fucking outsider
column8: left-of-the-box music.”)

column1: Henderson's few original songs rail against power-tripping cops and capitalism; as far as “authority sucks and everything’s fucked” sentiments go

column5: buried beneath a pile of leaves. The most obvious impression is of some sort of rebirth; no more covers

Henderson has a rare ability to convey a political stance without being overly hamfisted or explicit about it; how she brings that approach to music where she's the creative focal point is going to be seriously interesting to behold.

column1: Vocalist Juan Pablo Rodrigues

column9: his massive
column10: ever-expanding riff drawing up the topography of the cosmos. Keeping the rhythm section lean and the synths fairly sleek and steely might seem to put a lot of pressure on Garcia-Huidobro's guitar. But he
column11: too

column13: and more importantly
column14: when to hold back. This keen sense of drama means every time ""Trees"" brings that riff around again
column15: it's not just a reprise
column16: it's an event. ""99"" plays like a Dali painting
column17: every surface ripples like a pond
column18: every instrument double-helixing around itself.

column1: I've seen a 12-minute version of ""Pulsar"" floating around; mine's 15. Either way

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19175/homepage_large.70bee138.jpg|Young
column3: my name is Yellowman
column4: in the ghetto they call me Mr. Sexy
column5: ” begins “Mad Over Me”
column6: the first track on <i>Young
column7: Gifted and Yellow. If you’ve not met Yellowman before
column8: with this new collection VP Records provides a 40-song introduction. It also presents a case-- “nuff arguments”
column9: as Yellow would say-- for the relevance of 1980s dancehall and the importance of one of Jamaica’s most well-known and well-loved deejays.

column1: Yellow’s accomplishments are significant because he was anything but sexy and successful early on in his life. In fact
column2: his mother tried to throw him away in a dumpster for being a dundus—albino in Jamaican patwa. Winston Foster
column3: the <i>bwoy
column4: was born in 1957 and came of age at Alpha Boys School
column5: a Catholic-run institution for what used to be called “wayward children.” Alpha produced piles of musicians
column6: providing a foundation for the development of ska and reggae-- and
column7: through Yellowman
column8: dancehall.

column1: As Bob Marley famously reminds us
column2: “the stone that the builder refused shall become the head corner stone.” Foster provides snapshots of what it is like to be refused as an albino in Jamaican society in a number of songs featured on YG&Y; in “Bunn the Kutchie” he mentions that “when me did born me mother disown me.” Abandoned by his mother and ostracized as a dundus
column3: Yellowman grew up to become the corner stone of dancehall in Jamaica and the world. He got what Jamaicans would call his bus in the late 1970s with St Thomas-based sound system Aces Disco with whom the deejay perfected songs like “Soldier Take Over”
column4: “Them a Fight I”
column5: and others included on the VP compilation.

column1: In the heyday of the soundsystem
column2: artists not only had the to produce hits in the studio
column3: but also had to work a crowd in the dance
column4: hopping on the mic and riding riddims. The early dancehall era required performers to perform and Yellowman was a master-- danceable tracks like “Body Move” and “Strong Mi Strong” are but two examples. His style is characterized by sharp humor
column5: clever wordplay
column6: and experiments with different voices-- always with a smooth delivery that rocks back and forth
column7: seamlessly shifting from chant into song. It’s the kind of talent and confidence that led to the first major-label signing of a dancehall artist by Columbia
column8: which was looking for the next big thing out of post-Marley Jamaica in 1981.

column1: But YG&Y shows that Yellow wasn’t all about the hype. Sure
column2: there’s self-aggrandizement on display in “Who Can Make the Dance Ram”
column3: but tunes like “Eventide Fire”and “Jah Mek Us Fi a Purpose” provide evidence of Yellowman’s social conscience. However
column4: if there’s one thing that he is known for
column5: it’s for what Jamaicans term “slack”
column6: meaning sexually explicit
column7: lyrics. The hugging and squeezing Yellow chats and sings about in tunes like “Morning Ride” and “Rub and Go Down” may be downright tame in comparison to some contemporary tunes running the dance
column8: but it certainly pushed the limits of 1980s Jamaica.

column1: Yellow’s slackness helped him to turn the tables on those who might wish to ostracize him due to the color of his skin. Researcher and Yellowman-biographer Brent Hagerman suggests that “slackness essentially allowed him to alter the representation of the dundus in society from that of an outcast to a sex symbol.” In doing so
column2: King Yellow challenged and continues to challenge social mores in Jamaica-- confroting stereotypes and forcing his audiences to consider their own assumptions and preconceived notions. It’s no surprise he’s come out strongly against homophobia in the dance: ""I don’t do songs against gay people…If you don’t like a person or you don’t like a thing
column3: you don’t talk about it. You don’t come on stage and say kill them or burn them because everybody have a right to live.""

column1: Jamaican dancehall is often discussed in terms of disconnect from the rocksteady
column2: reggae
column3: and dub era. It’s seen as a dangerous
column4: and degenerative deviation from the golden 1970s. The range of songs represented on YG&Y
column5: however
column6: dispel any notions of Yellowman as a one-dimensional artist or of 1980s dancehall as a morass of slackness. He also demonstrates that dancehall is an integral part of the whole story of Jamaican music’s worldwide success.

column1: Take the song “Zungguzungguguzungguzeng”. After spitting this mouthful
column2: Yellowman asks the listener to “catch it”
column3: but following the thread of the song is actually tough to do. Scholar Wayne Marshall has tracked the memorable melody from 1982 to 2013
column4: from Jamaica to NYC to Puerto Rico to Japan to the UK and back to Jamaica-- the nonsensical lyric plays an important role in rough and tough ragga
column5: conscious hip-hop and party reggaeton. His ability to produce hooks that stick is matched by his ability to play with bits and pieces of tunes throughout his work: “Leaving on a Jet Plane” in “Night Flight”
column6: “Three Blind Mice” in “Who Can Make the Dance Ram”
column7: and “Bring it On Home” in “Yellowman Getting Married”
column8: among many others.

column1: Winning multiple bouts with cancer left Yellow with a disfigured jaw in 1986
column2: but he was and still remains able to control a crowd. He still actively tours
column3: gracing stageshows in Jamaica and around the world
column4: often one of the most well-received acts at reggae festivals. Alongside the two CDs
column5: YG&Y offers a DVD of Yellowman at Reggae Sunsplash in 1988. This footage provides yet further evidence of his significance as a performer: with reams of hits up his sleeves
column6: he’s got stage presence to spare.

column1: YG&Y is not an exhaustive collection spanning this artist’s nearly four-decade long career
column2: but enough to provide a portrait of one of Jamaica’s most important artists. Given his major-label signing and related licensing issues
column3: it’d be impossible to provide a comprehensive picture. Listening to the collection from beginning to end
column4: however
column5: proves that Yellowman is
column6: and will always be
column7:
King of the Dancehall.

column1: There’s nothing quite so streamlined or quite so dramatic on Junip
column2: the band’s follow-up to their 2010 debut
column3: Fields
column4: although there’s also nothing to suggest the band is flailing. Mainly they simply keep on chugging. What worked on Fields works just as well here; what didn’t still doesn’t; and constancy may be the band’s greatest weakness. “Nice” and “easy” have been common descriptors

column11: it comes across as a collaboration among equals.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Winterkorn is especially crucial on Junip

column5: as though stepping intrepidly into some crisis. It’s a tack they use repeatedly

column1: Gonzalez’s voice
column2: which has sounded limited in the past (especially on his solo albums)
column3: takes on a new tranquility in this context. He’ll never be criticized for emoting or overstating
column4: and the fact that nothing flusters him surely gives his songs a certain chill

column6: that coolness is crucial to Junip
column7: whose songs are all about crisis and commitment. The band eschew anything resembling experience or autobiography in order to focus on the hard-won lesson or the encouraging observation. “Step back from the line of fire
column8: ” Gonzalez advises on “Line of Fire”. “It’s your life
column9: it's your call
column10: ” he sings on “Your Life Your Call”
column11: which would come across as coldly dismissive if it didn’t sound so much like Hot Chip. After a while
column12: the album begins to resemble a motivational speech set to music
column13: exhorting its listener while revealing so little about its creators. Ultimately
column14: Junip keep their distance
column15:
offering a comforting hand on your shoulder rather than a full and unreserved embrace.

The Appleseed Cast were tagged as an emo band in their earliest days and that's likely to stick in 2013. It says as much about the elasticity of the genre as it does about how Chris Crisci's mercurial band hasn't allowed anything else to define them since. Over the past decade and a half
column2: they haven't made two consecutive recordings without shuffling their lineup
column3: their sonic focus
column4: and often both: In the late 90s
column5: the Lawrence

column7: band were peers of Mineral and Planes Mistaken For Stars

column9: two-volume series Low Level Owl in 2001

column11: but then again

column13: they moved towards a centrist indie-rock sound before going off the grid into full-on
column14: post-rock moodiness on 2009’s Sagarmatha. By 2011’s Middle States EP

column17: though it’s certainly in contention. At this point

column1: Illumination Ritual can certainly be a potent nostalgia trip: the clean
column2: interlocking guitars

column5: subtle electronic manipulation
column6: and floating ambience.

column1: Crisci kept unusual hours writing much of Illumination Ritual-- as indicated by centerpiece “30 Degrees 3 AM”
column2: the liminal feeling expressed in many of his lyrics are a result of walking the razor-thin line between “up too late” and “up too early.” There’s an unmistakably nocturnal mood to it all and it’s not the kind of wakefulness that’s a result of panic or some other insatiable mania: Crisci’s halting
column3: elliptical lines evoke a moment where you can’t quite decide whether to take your waking state as a sign that you should start that novel or just try one more time to drift back to sleep.

column1: This might not sound all that exciting and for the most part
column2: Appleseed Cast don’t excite so much as they comfort; Illumination Ritual is more a soundtrack for thinking about feelings rather than being in the thrall of emotion. ""Adriatic To Black Sea""
column3: “Great Lake Derelict”
column4: and “Cathedral Ring” provide Illumination Ritual’s most forceful moments out of insistent builds rather than sudden movement-- it’s unclear what Crisci’s getting at besides a certain sense of yearning (lines like ""I feel so akin to rain
column5: “the only girl is shooting for gold
column6: ” “a new cathedral
column7: burn it down” are typical) that’s abetted by the satisfying effect the trio achieves by pushing the tempo and lunging forward musically.

column1: It all makes for a consistent listen

column3: the Appleseed Cast lack the sort of striking dynamics that can serve as a substitute for its lack of immediacy. Nor are they particularly innovative in creating texture; Nathan Wilder is an active and pugilistic drummer who often serves as the “lead” when Crisci steps away from the mic
column4: but too often they resort to the kind of clean
column5: ringing peals of delayed guitar that’s going to sound like something the Edge has already done more memorably.

column1: None of this should be surprising or even disappointing for listeners holding the torch for the Appleseed Cast eight albums and several EPs in. But for the curious listener
column2: the definitive nature of Illumination Ritual can cut both ways
column3: as Appleseed Cast demonstrate their capabilities without having too many definitive strengths come to the fore
column4: consolidating a decade and a half of intriguing
column5:
and occasionally compelling experimentation into a manageable 45 minutes.

Phoenix are a total anachronism-- can you name another post-millennial power-pop band of thirtysomethings that made the jump from cult curio to festival headliners 10 years and four albums into their career? But if their trajectory feels old-fashioned
column3: the French foursome are so perfectly emblematic of our present. Sure

column11: distracted

column9: he ventures once again into rock’s uncool zone
column10: playing around with bar-band blues and raspy blue-eyed soul with long-time pals Phil Cook of Megafaun and Vernon’s pre-Bon Iver band DeYarmond Edison
column11: and Brian Moen of Peter Wolf Crier and Laarks. It’s yet another bold left turn in a career already filled with them
column12: and the least consequential record he’s made yet.

column1: Unlike the Bruce Hornsby piano licks that adorned “Beth/Rest”
column2: or the irony-skirting sax solos of the Vernon-starring Gayngs album Relayted
column3: the rumbly power-trio posturing of Grownass Man doesn’t have a confrontational edge to it. Vernon isn’t out to challenge elitist sensibilities; this is him in “cracked-open beer” mode
column4: goofing off in a low-stakes environment with trusted musical confidants he’s known for years. Vernon first played with Cook and Moen as the Shouting Matches for a one-time-only show seven years ago. (The group has been around long-enough to have an infrequently updated MySpace page.) The Shouting Matches saga might’ve ended there if Vernon hadn’t reconnected with Cook and Moen last year; that these good-natured jam sessions turned into an album speaks to the way Vernon’s fame automatically makes any project he’s involved in a commercial proposition
column5: no matter how casual.

column1: Anyone approaching Grownass Man as a serious artistic statement on par with Bon Iver is bound to be disappointed; to the contrary
column2: the album’s loose
column3: lay-about approach offers an appealing contrast to Vernon’s fussed-over output with his primary band. Grownass Man projects familiarity and comfort; the hominess of the warmed-over classic-rock riffs (check out the brief Back in Black shout-out at the start of opening track “Avery Hill”) a product of Vernon’s Eau Claire roots. Growing up in the Chippewa Valley
column4: Vernon and his bandmates likely encountered dozens of bands that sounded exactly like Grownass Man at places like the Stone’s Throw downtown
column5: and heard stories about the venerable bluesmen and jazz artists who years ago played the legendary Joynt bar on Water Street. If Grownass Man veers dangerously close to full-on Blues Brothers territory on amiable shuffles like “Mother
column6: When?” and “New Theme
column7: ” it’s probably because that was the blues for these guys when they first started playing music.

column1: The most obvious departure point on Grownass Man from Bon Iver is Vernon's voice. Bon Iver fans might wonder where all the falsetto went; except for quick flashes in the heartsick ballad “I Need a Change”
column2: Vernon sticks to his lower register. In the overall arc of Vernon’s career
column3: though
column4: this has been his “regular” voice
column5: going back to his time with DeYarmond Edison. <a href=""http://www.avclub.com/articles/justin-vernon-of-bon-iver
column6: 14201/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">When I interviewed him in 2008
column7: Vernon admitted that he was “insecure” about his natural singing voice. “For the most part
column8: I've been influenced by black singers and singers I couldn't sound like
column9: ” he said. “Whenever I tried to do a dark note or a bent note
column10: I would just sound like Hootie and The Blowfish.” Thankfully
column11: Vernon sounds more like Bobby Charles than Hootie on Grownass Man
column12: applying a meaty growl to the screaming stomp “Heaven Knows” and toning down to a tender whisper on the lilting “I’ll Be True”. While it may not fit with Bon Iver’s present sound
column13: Grownass Man suggests that Vernon’s baritone is a rich weapon in his vocal arsenal that is currently being underutilized.

column1: Perhaps Vernon feels comfortable singing this way on Grownass Man because it is an inherently minor effort that will interest only his most hardcore supporters. Only the Wilco-like “Gallup
column2: NM”-- the latest in a long line of travelogues from indie’s ultimate townie-- sticks out as a song with any potential shelf-life. But
column3: again
column4: looking for enduring music here misses the point. Like any beer-soaked hang with your best bros
column5:
Grownass Man isn’t so much about what’s remembered afterward as it is about having a blast in the moment.

There isn't much room for small gestures in the work of New York-based sound designer Aaron David Ross. On Exo
column2: the album he released last year as one half of electronic duo Gatekeeper
column3: the peaks were something akin to Meatloaf producer Jim Steinman getting behind the mixing desk for the Chemical Brothers. Ross doesn't shy away from listing big beat among his influences-- it's a genre he returns to on Chunky Monkey
column4: the second solo album under his ADR alias
column5: released by Hippos in Tanks. But while Exo was concerned with creating a great glut of noise
column6: Chunky Monkey finds strength in the kind of loopy frivolity practiced by Fatboy Slim or Bentley Rhythm Ace. Despite wearing those influences hard on its sleeve
column7: it's not an entirely backward looking pursuit; this is a record just as inspired by the blinding colors of Rustie's maniacal techno as it is by the Skint Records roster.

column1: The central difference between ADR and Gatekeeper comes from how relaxed Ross sounds here. There's a palpable sense of excitement to each track
column2: a feeling of someone thinking about everything they've ever been influenced by and trying to cram it all into a four-minute dash to the finish line. So we get smoky '80s cocktail jazz butting up against jungle drums and loping reggae basslines
column3: sometimes executed to great success
column4: sometimes sounding like a mess that Ross couldn't quite untangle. Either way
column5: it's clear that he had a wail of a time getting there
column6: even if it's not always as fun to listen to as it was to make. At times it even feels like you're there with him
column7: watching his thought process at work: When ""Social Studies"" leaps from sax solo to acid bleeps there's a great dip in the track
column8: a moment of hesitation that makes it sound like Ross is scratching his head
column9: lost for an idea of where to go next.

column1: However
column2: that lack of purposeful forward momentum is Chunky Monkey’s biggest flaw. With Rustie
column3: you always feel like he's built his domain and mastered it
column4: allowing him to operate with a very precise idea of where to go next and why. Here
column5: Ross goes back and forth between carefully refined material and loose strands of thought that don't lead anywhere particularly inspiring. Sometimes it even happens within the space of a single track-- ""Big Daddy"" meanders into directionless electronic ambience before gaining a greater sense of design through finely clipped jungle drums
column6: cut-up vocal passages
column7: and a series of spaced-out loops set to delicately dance around one another. The warped country-reggae hybrid ""Stray Dog Strut"" is the highlight
column8:
offering a demonstration of Ross's skill for sounding like warring musicians finding unlikely common ground.

The entire purpose of ADR seems to come from deriving harmony from ostensibly jarring parts
column9: another nod back to the kind of how-deep-is-your-record-bag approach that really took hold in the '90s. It owes a decent amount to the Dust Brothers' production on Beck's Odelay

column11: say
column12: the low-key funk of ""The New Pollution"" from that record does. Instead
column13: Chunky Monkey’s charm comes from the childlike glee induced by herky-jerky pop tracks such as the bright ""Whiz Kids"" or the nods to acid jazz and drum and bass that burn through at a furious pace on ""Slush Fund"". It only loosely holds together as an album
column14: never really finding the kind of cohesion to make it pass in a pleasingly blinding flash. Proof
column15: if more were needed
column16:
that taking a mind-bending gallop through music history and leaving a recognizable imprint on it is clearly a tough art to master.

“Winter Prayers”
column2: a standout on Iron & Wine’s sixth album

column11: Numbered Days?

column1: He has
column2: in fact
column3: come very far. In an effort not to play the sad strummer covering the Postal Service for the rest of his life
column4: Beam has spent the last decade engaged in an arms race with himself. With each album he has seriously and self-consciously expanded his range
column5: indulging new musical modes while locating finer grains of emotion. When he’s at his best

column7: and two years later The Shepherd’s Dog (still his finest effort) revealed new full-band ambitions and arrangements as unruly as cowlicks. That pair of releases argued persuasively that Iron & Wine was more than just a guy
column8: a guitar
column9: and a beard.

column1: What was truly remarkable about The Shepherd’s Dog was how quickly
column2: confidently
column3: and gracefully Beam shifted from folk minimalist to roots maximalist. However
column4: 2011’s Kiss Each Other Clean sounded like a step backwards
column5: toggling between the seemingly effortless (the affectionately nostalgic “Tree by the River”) to the turgidly effortful (the strained Dylanisms of “Walking Far form Home”). It plays like the transitional album that should have preceded
column6: not followed Dog. Unfortunately

column8: but he seems as yet unsure how to piece them together.

column1: “Winter Prayers” is one of the quietest moments on the album
column2: but it’s also one of the least fussy songs. Working again with Tin Hat Trio’s Rob Burger

Opener “Caught in the Briars” catches you off guard with its low thrum of horns and reed instruments bolstering one of Beam’s sunniest melodies. Soon the rattletrap percussion comes in
column5: a little stodgy in this context. Then comes piano
column6: adding nothing. The backing vocals insert persistent oohs and aahs

column1: Of course it’s admirable that Beam wants to push himself

But Beam doesn’t do all those styles equally well. His nods to 1970s lite rock on “The Desert Babbler” and the Carpenters-slick “Grass Windows” more than pay off
column5: but “Joy” is sickly sweet
column6: and Iron & Wine-as-jazz-combo is disastrous: “Lovers’ Revolution” is a hot mess of overwrought druggy lyrics and underthought Beat rhythms
column7: and when the song breaks for its instrumental interlude-- too gentle to evoke the havoc of a bad high

column1: The inconsistency frustrates: One minute the arrangements sound crowded with sonic bric-a-brac
column2: the next minute Beam turns on his inner editor
column3: settles into an easy melody
column4: or drops an imaginative turn of phrase. He’s an inventive songwriter with an idiosyncratic lyrical style

column6: as Beam evokes that specific quality of California light on “The Desert Babbler” and “New Mexico’s No Breeze”. His postcard impressionism gives the album its own distinct personality within his catalog

column8:
Ghost on Ghost is best when it’s most straightforward and worst when the experimentalism becomes desperate rather than bold. Too often it sounds as though Beam is less interested in defining a new sound and more concerned with distancing himself from an old one.

Late in 2012 an unexpected release made a splash amidst the deluge of year-end lists coming out at the time. It was a set of three album-length-plus mixtapes of music by pop-R&B singer Cassie
column4: whose self-titled 2006 Bad Boy debut underperformed commercially but inspired a cultish following among R&B obsessives
column5: and who had yet to release its proper follow-up.

column1: Curated by a person or persons calling themselves the Cassie Collective
column2: The Cassie Trilogy collects the various singles and guest appearances that she’d released sporadically over the past few years
column3: sorted under the categories “minimalist R&B
column4: ” “dark electro
column5: ” and “pure pop.” This rubrick not only lent some much-needed organization to what could have been a sprawling mess of a project and helped show off the singer’s range
column6: but also underlined how far she’s consistently been ahead of trends like the wave of atmospheric R&B that followed the Weeknd’s appearance on the scene and the avant garde-leaning artists like Grimes who’ve come to embrace bubblegum synth pop.

column1: The trilogy also served as a reminder that we’re still waiting on that second LP. It’s supposedly still in the works
column2: which is what Cassie and her team have been saying since last decade. But even if it never comes
column3: RockaByeBaby
column4: the mixtape she’s released to hold us over until then
column5: would more than suffice.

column1: It’s clear from the first song
column2: “Paradise”
column3: that the Cassie of 2013 is a whole different creature from the singer we were introduced to in 2006. For one
column4: those different facets that were highlighted on The Cassie Trilogy have been unified into a whole that’s much more than the sum of its parts. There’s no gap between her pop star side and her nocturnal-minimalist-R&B sex kitten side anymore--now they slink up against each other salaciously on tracks like “Addiction” that deliver hooks and bedroom atmospherics in equal measure.

column1: Cassie’s also begun blurring the line between her and the rappers she’s been collaborating with throughout her career. The snippet of dialogue from New Jack City that opens RockaByeBaby and the cover art of her posing with pistol in hand are the most obvious indicators of a more gangstafied image overhaul
column2: but they’re just skin deep.

column1: The more important thing is that the years of work she’s put in since her debut have given Cassie an on-mic presence that’s the equal to any of the rappers she’s recruited for features here. She’s not just a singer anymore; she’s actually got flow. It’s an impressive cast of mixtape heavyweights she’s working with
column2: including Fabolous
column3: French Montana
column4: and Meek Mill
column5: and none of them manage to run away with their respective tracks the way that rapper cameos on other R&B albums tend to. Sometimes she even gets the best of her guests
column6: like “Take Care of Me Baby”
column7: where her nimble
column8: syncopated vocals exploit the best parts of the trap-inflected beat (produced by Mike Will Made It) so thoroughly that by the time Pusha T jumps on it his verse there’s not much left for him to do with the song
column9: and his verse seems almost like a distraction.

column1: Cassie’s willingness to tangle with hard
column2: dark mixtape-rap beats (including one by Young Chop that’s as menacing as anything he’s produced for Chief Keef) gives RockaByeBaby a heft that most female-fronted R&B projects lack. Even the songs that lean more towards straight R&B
column3: like “Numb” and the Jeremih-assisted standout cut “Sound of Love”--which boasts one of the nastiest synth leads in recent memory--have an aggressive edge that suits her newfound swagger.

column1: What’s clear now is that Cassie’s no longer just competing in the R&B game anymore. While RockaByeBaby has aspects that invite comparisons to risk-taking singers like Jeremih and the Weeknd
column2: its really deserves to be held up against the output of melody-intensive rappers like Drake and Future
column3: and it stands up against either. There’s not only not a bad song on the record
column4: but not even any that start becoming skippable after repeat back-to-back listens
column5: a habit that its seamless transitions and remarkable consistency encourages. Cassie fans have spent a long
column6:
long time waiting for the rest of the world to start paying attention to her. After RockaByeBaby I can’t imagine they’ll be able to ignore her for much longer.

column8: the Deadhead twinkle
column9: the sunburnt boogie-- hasn't been replaced by
column10: well
column11: much of anything. Which leaves the perfectly pleasant Rat Farm feeling strangely wanting.

column1: ""Everything's cool
column2: and everything's fine
column3: Kirkwood sings at the top of ""Waiting""
column4: quickly adding ""and everything drives me out of my mind."" That's kind of the trouble with Rat Farm: everything's fine
column5: but that's about the long and short of it. Whether it's the Byrdsy stroll of ""You Don't Know""
column6: a post-grunge chopper ""Leave Your Head Alone""
column7: or a countrypolitan swoon like ""Waiting""
column8: everything here unfolds as you'd expect it to
column9: amicably enough
column10: but with a distinct lack of adventure. The mood's convivial

column12: and the solos—when they happen at all—are clipped. Sure
column13: some things'll never change: Curt still sings like he's holding in a lungful
column14: and there's a certain wobbliness to the arrangements that never lets you forget who you're listening to. But culling the chaos from their sound doesn't exactly flatter what remains

column1: Still
column2: the smile stretched across Rat Farm's face does wonders for the hints of blankness behind its eyes. Curt's mind remains bent
column3: even as his songs have straightened themselves out; Rat Farm's world is populated by a mechanical money

column5: and the titular Kirkwood-owned home for rodents. Dual highlights ""Down"" and ""Time and Money"" allude to adult concerns-- parenthood and cash-flow
column6: respectively-- but even they never seem too far from a shrug and the crack of a beer. At its best

column11:
it seems to be plenty.

The end of “Set to Await Forever” hangs like an unexpected ellipsis: During the first 45 minutes of VHÖL-- the self-titled debut from four West Coast metal veterans so well-regarded that many are calling this a supergroup-- there’s very little space
column2: pause or relief. The album’s blackened hardcore is generally restless and relentless; VHÖL colors the smallest of spaces with extra guitar lines and orotund bass parts
column3: giving the italicized shriek a sense of unordinary saturation. But five minutes into “Set”
column4: the record’s finale
column5: the quartet slows suddenly
column6: tempering their once-irascible sound into an atmospheric haze. The guitar and bass drift toward eternity
column7: while the drums lazily march ahead toward anything
column8: a kid kicking a stone down the street at sunset.

column1: Initially
column2: that slow fade from sustained bustle might have been an apt metaphor for VHÖL itself
column3: a band originally assembled to record only one album. For more than a decade
column4: guitarist John Cobbett and drummer Aesop Dekker played together in Ludicra
column5: an intricate black metal quintet that announced their end in 2011. But Dekker and Cobbett wanted to make one more album together
column6: so they recruited a pair of incredible equals-- Yob vocalist and guitarist Mike Scheidt
column7: who only sings here
column8: and Cobbett’s Hammers of Misfortune multi-instrumental bandmate Sigrid Sheie
column9: VHÖL’s bassist. But when the four entered the studio late last year
column10: they had enough fun and found enough chemistry that
column11: as Dekker admitted earlier this month
column12: they’ve already started writing new material.

column1: That connection feels so obvious on VHÖL
column2: a wonderfully weird intersection of black metal and hardcore impulse and attitude
column3: evocatively laced with bits of prog
column4: thrash and gloriously old-school rock ’n’roll. These songs put immediacy and intrigue shoulder to shoulder
column5: so that genuinely oddball arrangements bolster songs that make you want to join the melee. You’ll likely remember the hangman riff of “Plastic Shaman” and its barked invocation-- “The wage of sin is death
column6: ” snaps Scheidt from his bully pulpit-- the first time you’ll hear it. But this isn’t some simplistic maul; VHÖL reconfigures time and expectation
column7: shifting the tempo and tone so much that the song feels like a rollercoaster inspired by a rodeo. The great “Arising” first rumbles like Motörhead down the straightaway
column8: an approach that likely won’t prepare you for the hyperkinetic
column9: 90-second guitar solo that Cobbett takes during the song’s back half. Against most odds
column10: the parts coalesce
column11: and that’s how it works with VHÖL: Together or separately
column12: these four musicians have been at it long enough to be discontent or uninterested in playing anything too straight
column13: but they’ve also been at it long enough to know that it’s possible to embed strange tendencies within a framework that still sports a visceral magnetism. VHÖL hits on first listen; it captivates on the fifth.

column1: That VHÖL is already at work on new material is good news for these players
column2: because they sound not only reinvigorated in this setting but also somewhat emancipated. Cobbett and Dekker will long be linked with their work in Ludicra
column3: and there are traces of that here
column4: for sure. But VHÖL is a spotlight of their versatility that finds them not only comfortable but also rather exhilarated by such an open-ended platform. By limiting her role to bass alone
column5: Sheie
column6: perhaps known best as a keyboardist
column7: delivers her lines with focus and force. She overruns the rhythm and steps out for sidewinding variations
column8: injecting a position sometimes thought to be a bit big and dumb with a jazz enthusiast’s musicality.

column1: Most of all
column2: though
column3: it’s Scheidt that’s the wonder here. He puts down the guitar and pushes away the typecast set by his work in Yob to treat these songs like very few vocalists could. He’s a chameleon
column4: not only able to move quickly between hardcore berating and classic metal hook-setting but also capable of blending the two. “Insane with Faith”
column5: for instance
column6: is a bug-eyed roar
column7: with the band racing headlong into a circle pit; from the tone of his voice
column8: you expect Scheidt to be in the thick of it
column9: barking while crowdsurfing
column10: doing his best to pull the microphone cord along for the adventure. On the other side of Scheidt’s ostensible range
column11: he delivers long arches of falsetto as the slow exit of “Set to Await Forever” approaches. He’s like a hirsute
column12: heavy-metal soul singer
column13: staring out at a mix of lit lighters and thrown horns. But some of the most intriguing moments on VHÖL come when he’s able to do both. During the chorus of “Insane with Faith”
column14: he crests into a low-level cry
column15: suggesting Iron Maiden reborn in a small rock club. During “The Wall”
column16: his serrated bark comes backed real-time by his more operatic air. That’s the kind of multiplicity upon which VHOL depends
column17:
a quality that makes them less of a supergroup and more of a generative force with an unpredictable will of their own.

Bass music auteurs with wide-ranging interests have become more common in recent years
column2: with up-and-comers routinely crossing over to deep house
column3: tech house
column4: classic techno or spaces in between. It's at the point where every DJ set and label sampler is like a bench stocked deep with utility players. Cosmin TRG (nee Cosmin Nicolae) is one rangy infielder among many
column5: and it might be worth wondering how many of the converts he won over with his early-career dubstep sides or his 2010 breakthrough future garage single “See Other People/Groove Control” stuck around with him when his style-hopping moved further afield.

column1: If they held on through 2011's Simulat
column2: a spare but spaced-out journey into tech house
column3: they might be in for a letdown. With Gordian
column4: Nicolae's gone from evolution to refinement
column5: a paring down that feels like it's wringing every last idea out of the musical concepts he set into motion on his previous album. But what we get here is something more like dilution-- sacrificing its predecessor's stargazing character for the sake of being a sort of ambiguous
column6: fill-in-the-picture take on techno. Granted
column7: that's at least part of what Nicolae intended for Gordian. He's claimed that it's a low-key concept record about mythology
column8: the differentiation between the genuine and the manufactured
column9: perception versus truth
column10: and all that existential good stuff. You'll have to trust him on that-- The titles hint at grand ideas (“New Structures for Loving”; “Desire is Sovereign”; “To Touch Is To Divert”) which evoke more than the attached songs actually do.

column1: As four-on-the-floor pulses go
column2: they're hard to deny
column3: and it's satisfying enough that the man knows how to make a kick drum sound pop your earbuds out. The title track's the best example of how he can build a lot with a little
column4: kicks doubling as a de facto bassline that alternates between letting the beat ride and making it bubble. Giving in to the texture of the drum sounds on the whole is where most of the appeal comes from-- snares and hats distorted into reverberations that pull apart their structure and send flaked-off shards floating up into the air. And if you want a straightforward thump-thump-thump to work its way into your spine
column5: there's some immediate pleasure here
column6: especially when it gets into chord-driven buildups and breakdowns like the bell-shattering “Vertigo” or the heat glow of “Desire Is Sovereign”.

column1: But the emotional appeals
column2: individualistic quirks and unexpected shifts that mark Nicolae's best work is unsettlingly scarce here. In a discography that's regularly brought more to the table than just a good groove
column3: Gordian has an intermittent blankness about it that only occasionally recalls the warm retrofuturism of Simulat
column4: even as it gingerly tries to retrace a lot of that album's steps. It can be attention-getting when a bassline drops out or a new melodic refrain works its way into the track
column5: and there's a fine sense of timing to most of the songs. But it's not often that it registers as anything more than a new patch being cued up
column6: especially in an inexpressive middle stretch that runs through the factory-floor churn of “Semipresent” or the drippy
column7: burbling deadpan minimalism of “Noise Code”. Gordian is never boring
column8:
and none of the songs drag on past the point of entropy. That every listener might bring their own meaning to each song is an provocative approach on Nicolae's part-- but it'd be better if the songs made their own purpose just as clear.

When I saw Ghostface perform with Adrian Younge at SXSW last month
column2: it seemed like the two hadn't figured each other out at all. Younge's band would launch into thrilling versions of classics like ""Buck 50""
column3: then lurch to a halt while Younge demanded we pay our respects. Ghostface stood by
column4: looking bewildered and clearly just wanting to rap. After several false starts
column5: Younge asked Ghostface if he wanted to rap over vinyl; ""I'll do anything you want
column6: Ghostface said
column7: somewhat plaintively. Nonetheless
column8: the team-up between the two soul-steeped musicians seemed sound on paper

column1: They might yet still-- judging from their performance on Fallon recently
column2: they've already hit a new plateau. And Twelve Reasons to Die
column3: their collaborative album
column4: has a crazy-promising conceptual framework; playing off of Ghostface's well-worn persona
column5: it tells the story of Tony Starks
column6: an enforcer for the DeLuca crime family
column7: who is murdered by his former employers after striking out on his own. His remains are melted in vinyl and pressed into a dozen LPs that
column8: when played

column11: most colorful storyteller rap has ever seen. The prospect of him letting his imagination pour itself into the album's four-color-panel universe is enticing. Adrian Younge's band is incredible
column12: rifling through psychedelic soul
column13: Stax
column14: spaghetti western
column15: and more.

column1: And yet Twelve Reasons feels
column2: frustratingly
column3: like a really good idea from extremely talented people that needed more time. Ghostface's lyrics
column4: for one
column5: are uncharacteristically flat and literal
column6: narrating the story's turns in clunky exposition like ""I declare war/ War on the DeLucas"" and ""I want mothers and sons/ I want to murder they daughters/ Revenge
column7: all I see is blood in my eyes/ Like the rise of your worst nightmare
column8: come alive."" There are livewire lines scattered here and there
column9: but Ghost sounded more alive
column10: and packed more Tony Starks mojo
column11: into the low-stakes pre-holiday-rush Wu-Block project and his verse for Cruel Summer's ""New God Flow"" than he does into most of Twelve Reasons. And even for a project specifically intended to lovingly burnish Ghost's mythology
column12: there are so many bald Wu-Tang references -- ""Too many enemies is out there
column13: son
column14: trying to bring the ruckus
column15: he says on (""Enemies All Around Me"")
column16: making ""swarm of killer bees"" references on ""Rise of the Ghostface Killah"" and the very next song-- that it grows distracting.

column1: Still
column2: Ghostface sounds incredible over Adrian Younge's band
column3: which fits him like a custom-designed Starksmobile. ""Revenge Is Sweet"" opens with high voices singing wheezily over a murky
column4: gutted snare tick and piano
column5: channeling the enervated atmosphere of  Sly Stone's There's a Riot Goin' On before Ghost rips into the track. ""Rise of the Black Suits"" and ""Beware of the Stare"" both expertly mimic the texture of RZA loops while warming up the music's edges with cinematic touches: The howling backup singers are the aural equivalent of slow-mo widescreen. On ""The Sure Shot
column6: Pts. 1 & 2""
column7: the drummer tosses off tight
column8: showy fills without pushing against Ghost's voice
column9: while dirty transistor-amp guitars honk nastily in the background. Sometimes live bands can swallow a rapper with over-enthusiasm
column10: but Younge and his crew stay restrained.

column1: Their chemistry is so apparent that it's a shame the final product isn't better. It reminds me of Freeway's The Stimulus Package
column2: another seemingly can't-miss proposition from two phenomenal talents that fell just short. Like a lot of what Ghost has done in the past few years-- Apollo Kids
column3: The Wizard of Poetry in Emerald City
column4: and Wu-Massacre-- Twelve Reasons to Die basically feels like a victim of haste. Ghostface has kept up a fiendish pace even this late into his career
column5: but at this stage
column6: his dogged clip is hurting his output. Now that he and Younge have had some rehearsal time
column7: at least the live show for this record is almost certain to be phenomenal. And there are more than enough positive moments here to make the pairing feel worth that effort. In the end

column9:
a group slowly being whittled away by time and creeping indifference.
