It’s difficult not to pull for Ghost B.C.: During the last few years
column2: the mysterious Swedish metal outfit formerly known as Ghost have cultivated a sterling
column3: alluring persona of subversion and symbolism. Their leader is a papal parody named Papa Emeritus II
column4: who comes cloaked in inverted crosses and a sinister skeletal mask. He's flanked by five Nameless Ghouls dressed in matching black uniforms that suggest Darth Vader using the force to infiltrate and overrun the Catholic Church.

column1: Despite mounds of speculation and the exposure risk the band’s touring schedules involves
column2: the identities of the musicians remain unknown (or
column3: at least unconfirmed)
column4: furthering the allure of their at-large intrigue. Ghost have risen to popularity in relatively antiquated order
column5: too
column6: parlaying the buzz behind a single issued via social media (a move now more democratic than issuing a 7”) into a record deal and a licensing contract for the exciting Opus Eponymous
column7: a debut that upended many 2010 and 2011 year-end lists. The old-fashioned label bidding war that followed led to a contract rumored to be as high as $750
column8: 000 with new Universal Records imprint
column9: Loma Vista. To recap: A major label funds a band that poses as the Anti-Christ and his henchmen and plays old-school heavy metal with hooks as addictive as sin while also covering the Beatles and ABBA: Why wouldn’t you pull for Ghost B.C.?

column1: One compelling reason to forego the Ghost B.C. fanfare is Infestissumam
column2: the band’s mostly laughable second album. The ballyhoo for Ghost’s follow-up has been so strong that it landed them on the 100th cover of Decibel two months before it was issued. A name change
column3: an album cover so controversial some manufacturers allegedly refused to print it
column4: and the fortuitous timing of the actual Pope’s early departure have only ratcheted anticipation. And though these 10 songs seem to be a logical progression from Opus Eponymous
column5: Infestissumam all but abandons the twin senses of danger and discovery upon which Ghost once depended. This is a pop-rock record underwritten with childlike Anti-Christian sentiment; the tension between those underdeveloped directions-- surface-level darkness and near-translucent accessibility-- creates little but an insufferable stiffness.

column1: Sure
column2: Infestissumam delivers a handful of hooks you won’t escape and a few zingers that’ll make you smile
column3: but that’s about it. “Ghuleh/Zombie Queen”
column4: for instance
column5: is the record’s eight-minute centerpiece. Above forlorn piano and Coldplay-earnest guitar
column6: Papa uses his best Ben Gibbard croon to mix Latin and empty Satanic jingoism. The song eventually sidesteps into surf-rock
column7: black metal
column8: and a “Paradise by the Dashboard Light” sing-along; it is one of the most awkward things you will ever hear. At its best
column9: Opus Eponymous capably laced Ghost’s pop ambition with heavy metal’s sense of danger
column10: as with the bracing crunch of “Ritual” or the hangman guitar tone of the simultaneously clever and goofy “Satan Prayer”. At its best
column11: however
column12: Infestissumam is only a reminder of that earlier record’s now-apocryphal promise.

column1: With their label’s largesse secured
column2: Ghost B.C. surprisingly headed to Nashville
column3: Tenn.
column4: to record with Nick Raskulinecz
column5: a regular Foo Fighters producer who’s also worked with the Deftones
column6: Alice in Chains
column7: and Velvet Revolver. If Ghost B.C. were going to be a major-label metal act
column8: they needed to sound like a major-label metal act
column9: right? To that end
column10: Infestissumam is at least a crisp and full production
column11: from the grand theatrical choir that invokes the black mass at the start to the pitch-shifting synthesizer that goads along album closer “Monstrance Clock”. But Raskulinecz brightens the band until the mystery and suspense disappear
column12: turning these evil thoughts into baubles that sound safe enough for big money and rock radio.

column1: The record’s back half
column2: for instance
column3: is a half-marathon of bad stylistic decisions that put Ghost B.C. in settings that they just can’t make convincing. “Body and Blood” is about necrotic cannibalism
column4: but it sounds like something Sloan might have left on the floor of the editing room. Its affable jangle and eventual surge wilt under Raskulinecz’s spotlight. If They Might Be Giants decided to cut a funny little metal record (and why haven’t they?)
column5: “Idolatrine” and its jaunting organ might form the fourth single. And “Depth of Satan’s Eyes” offers neutered quips about flatulence and feces above a vaguely doom metal clip; it’s the sort of flimsy
column6: silly
column7: and safe pap that suggests Ghost B.C. might be a side-project for another band in costume
column8: the motherfucking Doodlebops. Infestissumam is a great critique of how self-serious yet puerile heavy metal can get
column9: but that’s probably not the point of a lucrative record deal.

column1: In the heavy metal community
column2: Ghost B.C.’s defenders often talk about the band as a gateway for young metal fans
column3: a new chance to expand the musty dark legions. In his smart 2011 piece for Invisible Oranges titled “Why Ghost Matters
column4: ” Justin M. Norton argued that metal needs new converts
column5: and that Ghost was the band to do just that. “I could play [Opus Eponymous] for my mother
column6: a Carly Simon devotee
column7: and she’d find something to like. … I see The Undead Pope becoming an effective recruiter
column8: much like Eddie or Anton LaVey. He is metal’s own Uncle Sam.”

column1: But
column3: to what exactly is Ghost B.C. a gateway? Back to old notions of rock’n’roll
column4:
where Jim Morrison is still a poet waxing above organs and major-label polish is a requisite of important music? To an excuse for a lack of substance in the presence of great style and pristine surface? To a worldview in which darkness and anger and frustration serve only to become a punchline and where the Anti-Christ “comes into the daughters of men” and creates silly portmanteaus like “Idolatrine”? Is that even a gateway anyone wants to offer anymore?

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Delicacies']|2013-04-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:57.602999|"

At the end of last summer Deadmau5 wrote a now infamous post on his Tumblr titled ""we all hit play"". His gleeful reveal was that the live performance of EDM was not about talent; he and his contemporaries in the EDM world were simply “button pushers”. So what if his off-the-peg
column3: risk-free “live” shows were a pantomime? The real magic
column4: as he saw it
column5: happened in the studio and that’s what drew his fans to the show. There’s an interesting point in there somewhere about the tension between the creation and presentation of electronic music
column6: which was picked up and eloquently dissected by Elite Gymnastics’ James Brooks on his own Tumblr; noting: “all of the really interesting things about my creative process are happening inside my head
column7: there’s no way for me to show you that the way that a rock musician can.”

column1: While Brooks identified the escapist value in occasionally being “bullshitted” by mainstream music
column2: Deadmau5’s post was ultimately born of a frustration with deception: “But to stand up and say youre doing something special outside of a studio environment
column3: when youre not
column4: just plain fuckin annoys me.” Again
column5: it’s a fair point and one that brings semantics into play: what does “live” electronic music mean today? Is it simply the act of being present and hitting that button? Is it a straight recreation of the album in a public arena? Is it a translation of computer compositions for a live context? Or is it an extension of the music
column6: seeing the tracks as a loose framework within which to experiment and give birth to new versions?

column1: It’s a question that
column2: while perhaps not intentionally
column3: long-serving UK techno duo Simian Mobile Disco provide their own answer to with their new album. Live is a one-take
column4: unedited recording of their gig on the Philadelphia leg of their summer 2012 US tour. SMD are big gear heads-- they perform with a series of analogue synths
column5: 909 drum machine
column6: and effects pedals-- and see their live process as a route to freedom: “On this tour
column7: the setlist was pretty much the same each night
column8: but the way we played the tracks varied. Because of the way we have everything set up
column9: we can easily jam out individual tracks depending on how the we and the crowd are feeling
column10: ” they recently explained.

column1: The result
column2: as with any live album
column3: is not one you can really dip into at random
column4: admittedly a tall order for today’s skip-attuned instincts. But commit to the flux and flow of this 68-minute journey and the reward of riding it is great. Featuring select tracks from across their back catalogue of studio albums-- Attack Decay Sustain Release
column5: Temporary Pleasure
column6: Delicacies and Unpatterns-- Live is a deft exhibition of SMD’s deep understanding of tension and release. They build and stoke steadily throughout the first 15 or so minutes of tough techno rhythms
column7: an immersion that serves to tease impassioned response to the delicate
column8: soaring melody of “Cerulean”. There are audible crowd cheers at the decaying close of their Beastie Boys-evoking number “It’s The Beat” and the bleepy-bloopy beginning of “Skin Cracker” that provide their own joyful reminder of the album’s context.

column1: “Wooden” has some gorgeous cascading keys that evoke the spirit of the UK’s second summer of love and the birth of rave culture a quarter of a century ago. But it’s the segueing of “Seraphim” into “Cruel Intentions” that provides the seductive heart of the record
column2: a sensual reminder of ecstatic possibilities of a half-time beat and a pure house vocal. As with any live set there are points in which you fully inhabit the music and others where your body is so caught up in its motion that your mind wanders. That’s no bad thing. It’s all about context with Live: each moment is a build to and release from the next. However electronic music continues to evolve and grow
column3:
for Simian Mobile Disco the clue’s in their name: the studio might be the starting point but their music is most alive on the road and in the live moment.

"|17877.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17877-simian-mobile-disco-live/|7.5|Ruth Saxelby

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19131/homepage_large.730f473a.jpg|A Quiet Darkness|28894.0|Houses|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Downtown']|2013-04-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:58:58.262265|"

Houses relocated from glo-fi enclave Lefse to Downtown Records for their second album
column2: undergoing major renovations in the process. The duo recorded A Quiet Darkness in their Los Angeles home as well as the Sonic Ranch studio perviously occupied by indie A-listers such as Beach House
column3: Animal Collective
column4: and Yeah Yeah Yeahs. The production upgrade from their debut is significant
column5: but you spot the real difference even before you push play. 2010’s All Night washed up during chillwave’s low tide with an appropriate backstory: Dexter Tortoriello and Megan Messina camped out in Hawaii to get away from the troubles of modernity for three months

column1: In contrast
column2: A Quiet Darkness earned the honor of ""this month's craziest concept album"" in the April 2013 issue of GQ: It’s the story of a couple separated by a nuclear holocaust and attempting to reunite along California’s Highway 10. This will be repeated in every single mention of A Quiet Darkness for good reason: it’s a nice hook that's much more interesting than the album's hour's worth of inert synth-pop ambience.

column1: The problem here is that A Quiet Darkness comprises mostly dirges
column2: and dirges that don’t do a hell of a lot to distinguish themselves from each other. A typical song introduces itself with a four-bar pattern of reverberant piano chords; after the gaps in between are filled in by starlit synth twinkling
column3: that pattern may alter slightly. Tortoriello’s wearied voice draws out a soporific melody which will occasionally be abetted by Messina’s sympathetic harmonies. The songs become increasingly spacious without ever achieving a crescendo and they fall into a rumpled heap after about five minutes of prodding from an unyielding kick drum thud. And then they do it all over again. That A Quiet Darkness doesn’t offer much in the way of immediate pleasure shouldn’t be entirely to its detriment
column4: but this album doesn’t grow on you; it wears on you.

column1: A lot of the blame lies with Tortoriello and Messina’s vocals
column2: which “fit” within the somnambulant tempos and sobering reverb by adding another layer of downy comfort. Tortoriello ranges from a resigned David Gray to a hungover Chris Martin
column3: and he certainly takes pains to let you know this is sad music; note the occasional repeated lyric concerning the white wings of god and birds falling into the hands of decay. He’s an emotive singer
column4: but not an expressive one
column5: and so you never get a sense of desperation
column6: of passion
column7: or any indication that the characters in this story ever burned hotter than a vanilla-scented votive for each other
column8: let alone enough to survive a nuclear winter.

column1: At times
column2: this can actually work to Houses’ advantage
column3: the low-dosage melancholy accumulating to the point where the overall effect becomes incapacitating. They get to this sweet spot by borrowing sugar from their neighbors in the arena-synth game. In the context of A Quiet Darkness’ indulgent tempos and song lengths
column4: the thunderous rolls of booming orchestral percussion and distorted
column5: descending chords towards the end of “Beginnings” are at least welcome for their M83-style grandiosity. By adding piccolo snare rolls and a silvery
column6: slow-moving guitar figure to its drum machine and acoustic pitter-patter
column7: “Peasants” situates itself as a triangulation point between White Ladder and xx; it’s not an isolated incident as Tortoriello appropriates Jamie xx’s riffs the way Jimmy Page appropriated Willie Dixon. Penultimate instrumental “The Bloom” is five minutes of slo-mo
column8: Stars of the Lid-style drone
column9: ostensibly meant as a pregnant pause before the inevitable death of the main characters. Yet the only real revelation is how little it differs from the equally torpid title track
column10: one of the many on A Quiet Darkness that imagines the Antlers’ Hospice consisting only of its ambient interludes.

column1: In the context of a concept album
column2: cohesion should be a good thing-- but it doesn't work in a situation where its creators are trying to form a narrative arc intimating that the characters concerned were married and endured a nuclear disaster. What A Quiet Darkness needs is contrast. That its mournful tones could pass for any old breakup album isn’t evidence of its universality
column3:
but lack of focus.

column2: but then again
column3: the atmospheric black metal duo does not currently claim a particular political affiliation (though their interest in the works of anarcho-primitivist Fredy Perlmea are well-documented). The album title is likely due more to the members’ past endeavors (bassist/vocalist Ray Hawes has done time in black/crust anarchists Iskra and nature-worshippers Fauna) and their obvious reverence for the natural world than their present inclusion in this green circle. Satan is not welcome here-- there is no room for fairy tales in Skagos’ world
column4: and their decision to distance themselves from the trappings of traditional black metal ideology is made apparent in their music.

column1: Anarchic is a sprawling composition
column2: split into four movements and spread across a double LP. The first side is split almost evenly between graceful
column3: shoegazey post-rock and blasts of black metal
column4: and feels warm
column5: organic
column6: and careful. It begins with soft dreamy vocals
column7: solo and in chorus
column8: while lonesome notes occasionally ring out and tension builds until the track explodes into furious blastbeats and raw-throated howls.

column1: The album’s only real misstep comes around 25 minutes in
column2: when a lengthy spoken word piece takes center stage and segues into regrettably mewled half-chant that
column3: as heartfelt as it undoubtedly is
column4: comes across as amateurish and half-baked. Side B picks back up with a single drum
column5: beating a muted tattoo amidst ambient noise before more lackadaisical shoegaze wanders in. The black metal section is a welcome distraction
column6: and shows the band at the top of their game; their atmospheric inclinations are all well and good
column7: but Skagos are most effective when they’re pouring their demons out into razor-edged riffs and snarling condemnations. The tempo soon slows to a true Norwegian crawl
column8: and the vocals drip with muddy viscosity
column9: layered to filthy perfection. Doomy
column10: menacing
column11: and finely in tune with the apocalyptic visions they preach
column12: this section is the album’s best
column13: and the following near-acoustic passage
column14: with its punchy little drum fills and shimmery notes
column15: falls slightly flat in its wake. The rest of the song (there are still seven minutes left at this point) alternates between dark and light
column16: and finishes on the same near-silent acoustic note we met at the journey’s beginning.

column1: Skagos don’t mind being slapped with the “Cascadian black metal” tag-- given that they’re genuinely based in the Northwest
column2: one can see why-- and their black metal moments do show similarities to the cyclical
column3: rough-edged melodic style of Ash Borer
column4: Alda
column5: or even Wolves in the Throne Room
column6: but it’s unfair to paint them with the same wide brush. With Anarchic
column7: they've crafted an impressive
column8: varied
column9: and unique piece of work
column10: one that’s not without its flaws
column11:
but that offers a bounty of rewards along its way.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18826/homepage_large.dd5fd516.jpg|Free the Universe|27663.0|Major Lazer|['Global'
column2: 'Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian'
column4: Diplo’s role as a producer has been steeped in importing
column5: curating
column6: and reconfiguring global dance sounds from favelas to shantytowns to the projects. That approach has been depicted as everything from transcendent
column7: no-borders futurism to an exploitative colonialist ripoff
column8: but most of his fans seem most interested in how much a given track bumps. The critical narrative shifted from Diplo as hipster scavenger to Diplo as arena-ready body-mover on the basis of a pop breakthrough that came through Major Lazer’s “Pon de Floor”. In its original context
column9: it was the centerpiece of an album cross-examined for appropriating dancehall culture and West Indian identity for a dayglo cartoon caricature. Then Beyoncé got ahold of it for “Run the World (Girls)”
column10: Diplo’s name started showing up in the credits of Chris Brown and Snoop Lion albums
column11: the appropriation concerns shifted towards the trap scene
column12: and the authenticity questions gradually quieted down.

column1: There's still something at stake here
column2: however
column3: especially with the delayed
column4: fine-tuned and much-awaited second Major Lazer album finally arriving. At this point
column5: the project name is based more around the elaboration on one producer's vision than a group of familiar collaborators
column6: as Switch and Skerrit Bwoy haven't made the transition from Guns Don't Kill People -- Lazers Do to Free the Universe for the respective reasons of creative differences and religious epiphany. So it's largely Diplo's statement
column7: albeit with a new set of cohorts in Trinidad-born Jillionaire and Black Chiney's Miami-via-Jamaica sound system member Walshy Fire. So Major Lazer's fusion of club music scenes from both Europe and the Caribbean gains a couple new critical sources of firsthand input
column8: and there's more of an opportunity for that sound to be directly informed by artists closer to the source.

column1: The production's by far the strongest link on Free the Universe. Maybe it's not as up-front and audacious as it was on the all-stops overload of Guns Don't Kill People. But it's to-the-point and danceable when it's inclined to aim that way
column2: and most of it's bound to sound commanding through massive stacks of amps. Percussion clatters through on jam-packed snare-clap-kick-hat drum patterns even before the ankle-breaking bass kicks in
column3: while trilling digital chords inevitably steer towards all-caps siren blares. Not all of it's so energetic and frenetic; the foggy
column4: calliope-and-guitar rocksteady underpinnings of ""Get Free"" and the sweet Studio One haze of ""Jessica"" calm the proceedings without killing momentum. A few moments feel like gratuitous
column5: instantly-dated trend-grabs
column6: like when the trance-jungle feints of Flux Pavilion collaboration ""Jah No Partial"" displaces the mood with pro forma arenastep and DROPS THE BASS directly into a puddle of sludge. Yet there's enough here to satisfy the who-cares-crank-that-shit impulse that aptly soundtracks good times with recreational substances.

column1: But there's a different set of problems here -- just look at everybody who shows up with a ""ft."" attached. Fittingly enough
column2: there are a bunch of tracks featuring dancehall icons ranging from Beenie Man to Shaggy to Johnny Osborne. But there are also sincere
column3: zero-slackness ballads featuring indie stars like Ezra Koenig and Amber Coffman. There is also a guest spot from Peaches. And Wyclef. And a teamup that includes Bruno Mars and Tyga. The biggest digression from the dancehall-indebted singer/toaster lineup on Guns Don't Kill People was Santigold
column4: far from a sore thumb considering her definition-ducking versatility as a singer. This time around
column5: she's the closest there is to a direct link from that last album's indie-electro soundclash to this one's omnidirectional crossover bid. And her voice kicks off what turns out to be a sadly disjointed experience: there's an awkward fake patois on what seems like every other track
column6: and the overstuffed lineup dislodges any hopes of a unified musical statement.

column1: All that there's left to do is examine the components and try to figure out what went haywire. ""Wind Up""
column2: ""Watch Out for This""
column3: and ""Mashup the Dance"" deliver the goods when the likes of Elephant Man
column4: Busy Signal or Ward 21 put in their work and keep the energy levels up. But splitting the difference between dancehall and moombahton doesn't always create a distinct new whole that plays up both genres' bounce-ready qualities. The indie names fare OK
column5: even if they sometimes veer towards caricature -- Coffman's dippy Tarzan yells and Koenig's wobbly attempt at Junior Murvin-gone-lover's rock falsetto on the aforementioned ""Get Free"" and ""Jessica"" make them seem a little more arch than they actually mean to be. And a few cuts that stray away from either of those categories turn out laughable: Peaches undercutting an authoritatively cocky Timberlee on the new wavey ""Scare Me"" by dropping a twerp-twerk verse that tries to make a sex-fluids double-entendre based around WikiLeaks
column6: Wyclef's motivational-poster platitudes trying to pass for a hook on (yes) ""Reach for the Stars"" (eesh)
column7: and Tyga chortling out maybe the most shut-the-fuck-up verse of the year on ""Bubble Butt"" (""Damn
column8: bitch
column9: talk much?/I don't want interviews/Ha! I'm tryin' ta get into you/then make you my enemy"").

column1: All those hitches
column2: gaffes and odd little diversions add up. A no-brainer
column3: easy-to-enjoy production slate gets knocked around by its flaws just enough that even the minor
column4: acquired-taste touches seem like just another bad decision. (I don't know whether the filter that briefly makes Shaggy's voice sound like Meatwad on ""Keep Cool"" would sound iconoclastic and funny on a better album
column5: rather than just a baffling flash of annoyance on this one
column6: but there's no point wondering now.) If anybody actually expected this to stink before hearing it
column7: even considering the odd assemblage of cameos here
column8:
they're probably more cynical than I am. But it's a bringdown that what should've been a more faithful yet adventurous transition into a new phase for Major Lazer winds up sounding like so much less than the sum of its parts.

It’s an unfortunate trick of the life of a musician that a single cover version can supercede its original author’s career. One job of the reissue is to hopefully right such wrongs. Such has been the fate of Shuggie Otis
column2: who
column3: at the time of writing
column4: has an All Music Guide entry with the album art of the band who took “Strawberry Letter 23” to #5 on the 1977 pop charts featured before any image of Otis himself. What had become a minor cult around Otis’ short-but-overlooked career surfaced for the first time a quarter-century later. The 2001 Luaka Bop reissue of Otis’ 1974 masterwork Inspiration Information was the first time many heard the original version of “Strawberry”
column5: but that release managed to muddy Otis’ discography
column6: as well. “Strawberry” was originally included on Otis’ previous album
column7: 1971’s <i>Freedom Flight

column9: but new Otis converts could be forgiven for slotting “Strawberry” as a late-album Inspiration track.

column8: Johnny Otis served as the executive producer for his son’s work

column7: there are nods backward to Drifters-style soul (“Walkin’ Down the Country”)
column8: gaudy synth monsters (“Give Me A Chance”)
column9: and even a couple cuts closing the album that nod back to Otis’ blues-rock roots. Yes

column1: If all this isn't convincing enough

column3: sequenced right in the middle of the album
column4: will. At once
column5: it’s a reminder that Otis had few peers as a shredder (at his peak
column6: both Bowie and the Stones offered him sideman gigs)
column7: and the sort of wild
column8: proggy imagination that would make Yes album-art designer Roger Dean blush. It starts with seashore sound effects-- waves crashing

column10: new age prog-funk that might not be everyone’s bag
column11: but which is impossible not to appreciate on its own merits
column12: because it’s performed with such conviction. It only adds to the song's allure that it's been kept private for so long. Such is the wholly unique career trajectory of Shuggie Otis
column13: who is now touring for the first time in 40 years. The Child Prodigy
column14: the Next Big Thing
column15: the Cultishly Admired LA Recluse. Johnny Alexander Veliotes
column16: Jr.
column17: the man who vanished
column18:
but never stopped.

Though the Thermals have often been described as a ""political"" punk rock band over the past decade
column2: their latest album comes from an anti-apolitical standpoint
column3: a less strident and specific version of protest music that reads more like common decency: not so much forged by considered opinions and intense debate as it is a natural byproduct of being sufficiently intelligent
column4: informed
column5: and idealistic. If you posted something on Facebook that admonished gun violence
column6: war
column7: or an impingement on civil rights
column8: Desperate Ground would “like” it without leaving a comment. But it ultimately rings hollow here
column9: as the Thermals still are trying to sound like insurrectionists while leaning so heavy on boilerplate sloganeering you’d think they were the ones running for public office.

column1: After the more introspective tone of 2010’s Personal Life
column2: Desperate Ground superficially evokes the Portland trio’s incendiary earlier work
column3: speaking the same vocabulary as 2006’s high watermark
column4: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9328-the-body-the-blood-the-machine/"" target=""_blank"">The Body
column5: The Blood
column6: The Machine-- so much that at the outset it feels like a return to form more than a retreat. In fact
column7: opener “Born To Kill” could just be The Body’s supernatural sermon “I Might Need You to Kill” told from a different perspective. The Thermals were never much for variety or innovation anyway
column8: and the 10 servings of zippy pop-punk here are of nearly uniform length
column9: tempo
column10: topic
column11: and structure. Even the relative curveballs amidst the missionary strumming of four-chord progressions-- like Hutch Harris straining for a high note in the chorus
column12: just exceeding his range-- seem to pop up in nearly the exact same place.

column1: This classicist template is hard to fuck up
column2: and the Thermals typically have good taste behind the boards: they might well be the only band who will ever be sympathetically produced by members of both Death Cab for Cutie and Fugazi
column3: so the shift from John Congleton’s immaculate naturalism to 90s revivalist John Agnello (Male Bonding
column4: Sonic Youth) should be a cinch. Yet Desperate Ground feels overproduced: The guitars are rendered toothless
column5: in particular
column6: the gutted distortion of “You Will Find Me”
column7: which sounds ripped from a thrice-dubbed cassette.

column1: Harris remains a distinctive and effective singer-- his nasal bray can cut through just about any kind of sonic clutter-- and Desperate Ground never drags
column2: the hooks as facile and forgettable as you might expect from songs with titles such as “You Will Be Free”
column3: “You Will Find Me”
column4: and “Our Love Survives”. Let a latter-day Mark Hoppus or Jim Adkins get a crack at these melodies and you’d have a perfectly enjoyable and gooey low-stakes pop-punk record.

column1: But Desperate Ground is a record that really wants to convey having something to say and Harris has run out of ways to say that something. Not long after “Born To Kill” sets the tone
column2: Desperate Ground feels less like a sequel to The Body than a series of sequels to itself-- on “The Sunset”
column3: Harris sings an executioner’s song
column4: his remorse haunting him like his own shadow. On “Faces Stay With Me”
column5: the same thing happens
column6: only with faces instead of shadows. By the time “I Go Alone” situates itself between Whitesnake and Green Day
column7: they’ve lost even the basic righteousness of sloganeering and you start to hear it as Thermals magnetic poetry with “blood
column8: ” “kill
column9: ” “war
column10: ” “road
column11: ” “sunset
column12: ” and “shadows” all popping up with alarming frequency. You could probably guess 75% of the lyrics from “The Sword By My Side” without even hearing it
column13: and yes
column14: they’re using a weapon as a metaphor for another weapon.

column1: In a way
column2: the stultifying generality of Desperate Ground does lend it a perspective
column3: though it’s the all-too-common affliction of seeing the same wars drag on and the same talking heads making the same points on the news and feeling utterly helpless. Perhaps the pileup of clichés and the numbed production is supposed to give Desperate Ground a meta context
column4: that the endless body count has rendered Harris completely desensitized. But that’s a generous reading for an album that begins and ends with guns-blazin' mission statements with plenty in between
column5:
so it’s more likely Desperate Ground is a failure to respond to the horror rather than an intention to reflect it.

The 33-year-old Hot 97 DJ Peter Rosenberg is thoroughly wedded to the sounds of his youth
column2: specifically the sounds and styles of rap from 1985-1998 (different periods in this stretch of time have been called ""golden age"" of hip-hop). Since attaining a coveted spot on Hot 97’s morning show
column3: as well as his own weekly program
column4: Rosenberg has become both a champion and a patron of the kind of rap he loves while demonizing music which doesn’t fit into the parameters he’s set. (This philosophy caught the most attention in last year’s Summer Jam feud
column5: when Nicki Minaj and other Young Money artists refused to perform after Rosenberg dismissed Minaj's song “Starships” as not being “real hip-hop"").

column1: The new mixtape New York Renaissance is hosted by Rosenberg and sounds exactly how you would expect it to sound. It’s a collection of the New York rappers who are
column2: for the most part
column3: replicating the vibe of the recent past
column4: and it features many of the same faces that showed up for Rosenberg’s SXSW showcase. If you’ve been keeping an eye on the New York underground
column5: you know the names: a couple A$AP’s here
column6: an Action Bronson there
column7: and various members of the Beast Coast collective (Flatbush Zombies
column8: Joey Badass and Pro Era
column9: Dyme a Duzin) to round out the mix. There are appearances from the neo-conscious crowd (Homeboy Sandman
column10: the producer and DC transplant Oddisee) and relative outliers like Smoke DZA and the Kid Daytona
column11: but for the most part
column12: the artists here are those that were tagged as derivative from the moment their music started appearing on Nah Right.

column1: The bright spots emerge when New York Renaissance shows that traditional beats need not play host to conservative thoughts. Action Bronson has shown that from the beginning
column2: and he does so again with his appearance on the Harry Fraud produced “Compliments 2 the Chef"".  Bronson was pegged as a revivalist
column3: in part due to his beat selection and that unavoidable vocal resemblance to Ghostface. But he’s as influenced by absurdist Dipset phraseology as he is anything else
column4: with music composed of larger-than–life scene-making
column5: descriptions of a Epicurean lifestyle and the occasional glimpse of intense vulnerability. His best songs function as both caricature and character sketch
column6: as he continues to add new details to his ever-expanding artistic persona.

column1: The Flatbush Zombies
column2: too
column3: have managed to carve out new territory. Their raw punk energy--probably the most mosh-happy rap concerts I’ve attended-- translates on wax into a constant barely-checked aggression that makes boom-bap sound newly dangerous. The gunshots on their offering here
column4: “Inf Beams
column5: ” are hardly necessary-- Meech’s opening verse is delivered in his signature off-kilter
column6: enunciated flow
column7: and it’s agreeably ominous.

column1: Perhaps the most polarizing figure on the tape
column2: and the one who most embodies both the pros and cons of the Rosenberg approach is Brooklyn's Joey Bada$$. Joey is a talented young rapper
column3: who flows with an uncanny ease and who has yet to make a song that covers new ground. He
column4: along with World’s Fair
column5: Nick Caution
column6: and many of the lesser-known rappers on the tape
column7: make solid comfort food rap but fail to transcend the revivalist label.

column1: Whether that’s a good or a bad thing depends on your perspective-- apart from the occasional contemporary reference (don’t think many Brooklynites were watching Real Madrid twenty years ago) many of these songs could have come from the nineties. Songs like Pro Era’s “New Brooklyn Remix
column2: ” on which producer Dante Ross puts together an Ill Communication soundalike
column3: Homeboy Sandman’s “The Plot Thickens” and Nick Caution’s “Scotty” would have been standouts then
column4: and they can be considered standouts now. They’re far superior to the tired “Like It’s 88” or the Kid Daytona lazing out over the classic beat from “Can I Live""
column5: neither of which would’ve have made your discerning fan’s Memorex back in ‘97.

column1: When underground hip-hop develops an inferiority complex
column2: it tends to lash out
column3: mocking the mainstream while trumpeting its own authenticity. That’s part of the reason that Rosenberg has alienated comparatively forward-thinking people (along with the Young Money camp
column4: who
column5: ironically enough
column6: have grown as stagnant in their approach as Rosenberg has in his). If you can disregard that puerile attitude
column7: music like that found on the New York Renaissance is
column8: at worst
column9: unnecessary. At best
column10: it adds something new to the conversation for people still interested in what exactly it is that rap is saying
column11:
and not just how it says it.

Chicago's Disappears are one of those bands that promise so much
column2: but too often fall short of the high benchmark set by their best material. Sometimes it even feels like they're sabotaging themselves. A 2011 tour with the Psychic Paramount seemed like a great idea in theory
column3: but the reality of trying to compete with the sheer force and invention of their touring buddies left them sounding like wimpy traditionalists. The band's 2012 album
column4: Pre Language
column5: didn't help matters
column6: somehow losing the magnetic force that made the preceding Guider worthy of many repeat plays. Fortunately
column7: changes are afoot. Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley has amicably departed from the lineup
column8: and the band has returned to working in great breadth on ""Kone""
column9: a 10-minute track that builds on the promise of ""Revisiting"" from Guider.

column1: There's something old fashioned about Disappears' approach
column2: perhaps a natural consequence of the fact that singer Brian Case has been around the block more than a few times
column3: first with 90 Day Men and then the Ponys. This is music that comes from a place where there's no shame in trying ideas out in public view
column4: where it's perfectly natural to arrive less-than fully formed. Kone has dropped from out of nowhere
column5: not giving any real idea whether this is a hint of things to come
column6: or a standalone diversion from whatever the band is plotting next. Either way
column7: it's far more compelling than anything from Pre Language
column8: opening up the suggestion that Disappears are fully aware that they function far better when working in repetition than they do when hacking everything down into more compact forms.

column1: This three-track 12-inch simply offers up two versions of ""Kone"" and the additional ""Kontakt"". The version named ""Kone (edit)"" even ends in a locked groove
column2: emphasizing the band's fondness for looking backward and firming up the suspicion that they're finally throwing up their hands and playing to their strengths. The main track is all air-raid siren drones
column3: choppy guitar lines
column4: heavily echoed vocal passages and
column5: toward the close
column6: a steady build of synthesized noise. It's a masterclass in control
column7: never veering into sheer bludgeoning power
column8: always maintaining a steady pace that helps lay out the underlying mood of unease. It goes precisely nowhere and is all the better for it; Disappears' best music sets a mood and pulls you down in it
column9: leaving the listener suspended in a static state.

column1: The same trick works to less effect on ""Kontakt""
column2: especially when an ill-advised Duane Eddy guitar line surfaces
column3: and the blurred version of ""Kone"" at the close of the EP doesn't add much to what came before. But there's an overall sense of bridges being rebuilt here
column4: of a band renewed and galvanized for a bigger project ahead. Another album is promised later in the year
column5: and ""Kone"" should be the natural launch point
column6: a place from which to light the fuse. This is a tougher
column7: more fully realized version of Disappears
column8: operating where their most obvious influences (Spacemen 3
column9: 13th Floor Elevators
column10: Can) have propelled them somewhere instead of bearing down too heavily on their sound. They've regained some attention here. Now
column11:
they just need to capitalize on the forward momentum.

There's a refrain you often hear about bands running on the sort of quick-burning demon energy that the Yeah Yeah Yeahs were channeling in the early part of the last decade: You had to be there. But on rare occasions
column3: a band will make a record so thick with atmosphere that ""being there"" is just a matter of pushing play. Yeah Yeah Yeahs' 2003 debut
column4: Fever to Tell
column5: is one of those achievements: Even if you didn't make it to one of the infamous early New York shows and have the pleasure of getting your glasses sprinkled with the beery spit of a grinning
column6: lipstick-smeared frontwoman in tattered Christian Joy
column7: the record itself did a commendable job of bottling that experience. It was a debut that aced music's classic chemistry lesson: Combine a few unlikely
column8: molten compounds
column9: take a step back
column10: and wait for the bang.

column1: When they put out their second album
column2: it seemed
column3: at least at the time
column4: like the Yeah Yeah Yeahs were growing up too fast. Show Your Bones favored songcraft over shambolic energy
column5: and sounded disappointingly tame on the heels of Fever's maniacal night-sweats. (It was also the beginning of a creative schism in the band; as Zinner told Spin in 2006
column6: ""I didn't want to write and record in a studio... I just wanted to do demos on a four-track in somebody's apartment."" He lost that argument.) But in the long run
column7: Bones has aged remarkably well
column8: and now feels like a pivotal moment in the band's arc
column9: setting the tone for a career of evolution
column10: reinvention
column11: and constant forward motion; 2009’s excellent It's Blitz! was a record of glammy
column12: neo-Blondie avant-pop
column13: staying true to their quirks but successfully expanding their range.

column1: Mosquito
column2: the group's fourth record
column3: is its first step backwards. It feels uncharacteristic
column4: calling to mind a lot of words that have never fit this band before: confused
column5: dreary
column6: uninspired
column7: and-- on one particularly baffling song about aliens-- uncool. Karen may have bleached her hair electric blonde and donned some inspired
column8: tinselly Elvis suits
column9: but for once the band hasn't applied a similarly gleeful spirit of reinvention to its sound. Instead
column10: Mosquito aims for more of a back-to-basics approach. ""We have this shitty little downtown studio [in New York] that belongs to us
column11: Karen said in a recent Pitchfork interview
column12: ""so we wrote songs and recorded demos whenever we felt inspired; it was kind of like Fever to Tell and our first demo."" But the often limp Mosquito lacks their earlier material's spark.

column1: Mosquito is not without highlights
column2: but it requires some patience to unearth them
column3: because when this record is bad
column4: it's loudly
column5: brazenly bad. ""Area 52"" is probably the lowest point in the band's catalog; its lyrics have a Spinal Tap syntax (""Message came from outer space/ Future of the human race"") that makes it play like self-parody. The song also features an uncharacteristically wooden vocal from Karen
column6: who's eventually drowned out by a wash of spacey blips and bleeps. At least she sounds like she's having a little more fun with ""Mosquito""
column7: but even her trademark charisma can't inject a sting into the weak chorus (""They'll suck your blood! They'll suck your blood!"" she tries
column8: over and over). It's surprising how off the mark these songs sound coming from a band who used to be able to do goofy well. The upbeat songs on Fever careened with a wobbly
column9: inebriated energy
column10: but whenever Mosquito aims for ""zany"" or ""light
column11: it teeters around like an exhibitionist ""drunk"" on non-alcoholic beer.

column1: ""Mosquito"" should have been a B-side at best
column2: but the fact that it's the title track-- and the inspiration for the garish
column3: David-Cronenberg-vomiting-on-a-Garbage-Pail-Kids-card cover art-- makes it that much harder to ignore. That a thin
column4: overly literal song like ""Mosquito"" is at the center of the artistic statement they're trying to make only makes this album more of a head-scratcher. Whatever's holding this collection of songs together never quite congeals-- a problem exemplified by the James Murphy-produced ""Buried Alive""
column5: a moody
column6: nocturnal groove interrupted halfway through by a verse from Dr. Octagon (the high-concept
column7: time-traveling alien persona of avant-rap legend Kool Keith) that lands in the song with a heavy thud.

column1: On repeated listens
column2: though
column3: a few diamonds emerge in the rough. Built around Zinner's expectant single-note riff
column4: the gradual crescendo of ""Despair"" plays like a more muted take on Show Your Bones' best single
column5: ""Cheated Hearts""
column6: though its refrain is even more poignant. ""Oh despair
column7: you've always been there
column8: Karen sings with the perfect combination of exhaustion and defiance
column9: ""You were there through my wasted years... there through my wasted life."" The closing track
column10: ""Wedding Song"" (which Karen sang to her husband Barney Clay at their 2011 wedding reception) sounds a bit like a happy-ending sequel to ""Maps""
column11: brooding with a similar emotional intensity (""In flames I sleep soundly/ With angels around me""). But the most promising-- and perhaps only truly new-- avenue the band wanders down on Mosquito is ""Subway""
column12: a subtle
column13: evocative sound collage driven by Karen's falsetto and the percussive churn of a train on the track. It's heavy on conceptual follow-through and finely crafted atmosphere on a record where both are in short supply.

column1: On their best and most smartly sequenced albums
column2: the Yeah Yeah Yeahs create a sense that their bratty swagger and disarming vulnerability were emanating from the same power source. In the wake of Fever's amped-up ""Date With the Night"" or ""Tick""
column3: ""Maps"" feels like an inevitable come-down
column4: but the songs on Mosquito don't feed off each other in the same way. The album's most keyed-up moment comes early
column5: in the solid lead-off single ""Sacrilege""
column6: but when a gospel choir storms the song's closing coda it feels unprompted-- this is a band that used to be able to kindle the same kind of fire from the minimal components of its own chemistry. Still
column7: even if Mosquito suggests otherwise
column8:
the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' much-lauded SXSW showing and recent homecoming performances in New York prove that magic can still happen for them on stage. Maybe now you just have to be there.

For John Dwyer’s “5-10-15-20” interview
column2: the Oh Sees frontman talked about discovering the work of the Mexican psych prog band Los Dug Dug’s. The legend behind their 1972 album Smog
column3: as Dwyer heard it
column4: goes like this: Armando Nava went up to the mountains
column5: took acid
column6: and conceptualized that LP. “He came back and taught it to the band
column7: and it is by far their biggest triumph
column8: ” Dwyer said. Although Thee Oh Sees sound almost nothing like Los Dug Dug’s-- the latter laying on the flute solos a bit too thick-- the opening track on Floating Coffin is called “I Come From the Mountain”. Like most of Dwyer's best songs
column9: it's got muscle and drive. As usual
column10: the story is fractured
column11: abstracted
column12: and therein
column13: too nonspecific to be exclusively about Nava. But the spirit of the myth is there: “I come from the mountain
column14: I return again
column15: ” Dwyer sings. Yes
column16: but is he emerging from the mountain with his masterwork?

column1: Based on their output from the past two years alone
column2: it's hard to fathom what “biggest triumph” would even look like for Thee Oh Sees at this point. Castlemania had Dwyer bleating “I Need Seed” in a strained toad voice; the centerpiece of Carrion Crawler/The Dream was a blistering Krautrock masterwork; “Goodnight Baby” from Putrifiers II was a Nuggets lullaby capped by field recordings of chirping birds. Each of those albums are triumphs
column3: and picking the ""best"" one feels like an arbitrary decision-- they suit different moods
column4: different purposes. In that tradition
column5: Floating Coffin is another resounding success.

column1: And it's sort of a sadistic success. In the tradition of tracks like “The Dream”
column2: “Tunnel Time” is carried by an adrenaline-fueled drive. But this time
column3: the lyrics are about murdering a whole bunch of people
column4: and the central hook is the band singing an evil laugh: “HA HA HA HA HA
column5: HA HA HA HA HAAAA HA!.” Behind every infectious riff
column6: there's a dark undertone. What's behind the strawberries on the album's cover? A murderous gaze. What's behind the earworm hooks and vamp-filled rock'n'roll? Lyrics about splattered blood and dead children. There are a few references to “the maze” as it relates to the narrator's descent into madness. In “Maze Fancier”
column7: he's trapped and sings that there's “nothing inside of me.” Perhaps that dispassionate void manifests later on “Sweet Helicopter” when he takes a dementedly detached view of murder: “I look down and see them looking up.” With his unsettling disconnect between sweet falsetto and portrayal of a glazed-eyed killer
column8: Dwyer definitely earns his spot in the prestigious club of murder balladeers.

column1: Of course
column2: you have to listen pretty carefully to hear Dwyer as demon or serial killer. The lyrics are run through the band's go-to filter of falsetto
column3: voice effects
column4: and extremely loud guitars. The title track is a chaotic burner that sounds like it could fall apart at any moment-- each element is barely held together by the bassline-- so any vocals are pretty well obliterated by volume. But for an album stuffed with great melodies
column5: smooth transitions
column6: shredding guitar solos
column7: and stellar percussion work (the spastic percussion simmering in the background of “Sweet Helicopter” is a particular highlight)
column8: it's hard to mind when the lyrics take a backseat. That said
column9: although Floating Coffin does quite well with its searing powerhouses
column10: the quieter moments add a much-needed sonic diversity. The viola melody that introduces “Minotaur” is gorgeous
column11: and once again
column12: that's for a song that tells a fairly miserable story.

column1: Arguably
column2: the most powerful song on Floating Coffin is “No Spell”. The majority of the track features a gentle melody
column3: buoyed by a soft rhythm section
column4: and some ethereal vocals. There are words on the lyrics sheet for the song
column5: but they appear more as a series of evaporating vowel sounds. And naturally
column6: the quiet is broken by a WOO
column7: a series of hefty power chords
column8: and a guitar solo-- a thrilling stab of power amid the quiet warmth. It's a sweet melody that offers a brief respite from the bloodshed. It also illustrates that there's no pre-established blueprint for an Oh Sees album

column10:
that's an exciting prospect.

Solar Bears dig up cultural artifacts from bygone decades and put them to fresh use as components in a musical style that sounds naggingly familiar without ever quite lapsing into pastiche. Of course
column2: this isn’t a hugely original strategy these days. But Solar Bears’ music draws on a particularly thick soup of contrasting half- and mis-remembered pasts: Boards of Canada’s windswept pastorales alongside the otherworldly film scores of John Carpenter and Vangelis; the glossy sensuousness of Air next to Giorgio Moroder’s synth-disco vistas.

column1: You might infer from this that Solar Bears are a sort of jack-of-all-trades of the nostalgia-trafficking underground
column2: sampling the retro-leaning delights on offer without committing to a single fixed identity. That's valid to an extent. The duo’s 2010 debut
column3: She Was Coloured In
column4: was a sprawling record that had a habit of fluctuating erratically between moods and intensities: from wistful yearning to bucolic contentment
column5: kitschy playfulness and back again in the space of a couple of tracks. But compared to the more approximate DIY tendencies of many of their peers
column6: Solar Bears brought a certain smoothness of execution to the table
column7: and a taste for pop directness that could at points tip over into the mawkish
column8: but could also produce results with huge appeal.

column1: It’s fitting that for their second LP
column2: Supermigration
column3: the Irish duo have stepped out of their bedrooms and into a professional studio
column4: where they can pursue their pop muse with renewed fervor. The greatest indication of this comes with a pair of vocal appearances
column5: both highlights of the album. Sarah P of fellow Planet Mu signees Keep Shelly in Athens contributes to ""Alpha People""
column6: a gorgeously circumspect piece of synth-pop built around tremulous chords. Even more satisfying is the presence of Air collaborator Beth Hirsch on ""Our Future is Underground""
column7: a sprightly number that overflows with spine-tingling joy in the closing minute.

column1: But even where vocals are absent
column2: there’s no doubting that Solar Bears have refined their technique over the past two years. Supermigration is a glistening
column3: richly arranged album
column4: every song lovingly wrought and festooned with lush synth and guitar work. It’s also a far more coherent record than its predecessor. Opener ""Stasis""
column5: featuring a simple piano riff that’s wrenched upwards in pitch as if we’re ascending into some gauzy firmament
column6: is reprised at the midpoint as ""You And Me (Subterranean Cycles)"". Such interludes serve to balance out the album’s weightier moments
column7: and stave off the tendency towards formlessness that blighted She Was Coloured In.

column1: As far as those heavier moments go
column2: the duo’s success is less assured. A string of tracks expand on a disco sound hinted at on She Was Coloured In: ""Komplex"" coasts luxuriously on chunky synth arpeggios; ""A Sky Darkly"" is more imposing; ""Happiness is a Warm Spacestation"" is the most bombastic of the lot
column3: and its relentlessness can feel a little overbearing. Elsewhere guitars supplant synths
column4: as in the angsty ""The Girl That Played With Light""
column5: proving faintly reminiscent of instrumental post-rock.

column1: At times the duo are guilty of excessive portentousness
column2: but there are just as many moments where their grandiose ambitions are convincingly realised
column3: particularly in sunny closer ""Rainbow Collision"". Where Supermigration really grips the heartstrings is on slick pieces of library music revivalism that positively shimmer with kitschy optimism. At their best
column4:
Solar Bears are utterly charming.

It's tempting to feel sorry for Nicolas Fromageau. He founded the electronic shoegaze duo M83 with Anthony Gonzalez in 2001
column2: sticking around long enough to record critically acclaimed second album <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/5006-dead-cities-red-seas-lost-ghosts/""><i>Dead Cities
column3: Red Seas & Lost Ghosts before leaving in 2004. Gonzalez then restructured M83 with new members and a new sound
column4: beginning a steady three-album climb up the international charts that culminated in 2011's Grammy-nominated <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15881-hurry-up-were-dreaming/""><i>Hurry Up
column5: We’re Dreaming. Meanwhile
column6: Fromageau slowly put together the electronic rock band Team Ghost
column7: which finally eked out a pair of EPs in 2010
column8: now followed by debut LP Rituals. It's not exactly a Pete Best story
column9: but if M83 stays on course
column10: Fromageau could merit placement on future ""Musicians Who Left Famous Bands Too Early"" listicles.

column1: But in fact
column2: he's probably right where he needs to be. For all of the similarities between M83 and Team Ghost-- the epic heights and driving rhythms
column3: the screaming synthesizers and hushed vocals-- an essential divergence in perspective stands out starkly when isolated in each project. As M83's music grows ever more affirmative and misty-eyed
column4: Team Ghost is darker and sleazier
column5: countering pastel nostalgia with a kind of stylized cynicism. The tension between Gonzalez's instincts for open-hearted pop songs and Fromageau's for clenched
column6: noisy grooves energized Dead Cities
column7: but it's almost certain that the vocal-heavy ease of access of M83 2.0 led to their breakout from critical-darling status. If Team Ghost seems unlikely to follow suit
column8: at least it sounds like someone doing exactly what he wants to do.

column1: It should be mentioned that Team Ghost is said to play a kind of music called Cold-Gaze
column2: a term coined by NME and embraced by the band
column3: which should not in any way be mistaken for a thing that actually exists. On <i>Rituals
column4: which minimizes the Krautrock influences that permeated the EPs
column5: this imaginary genre amounts to electro-pop and shoegaze infused with the poisoned throb of Suicide
column6: hints of dance music
column7: and a lot of inflammatory alt-rock guitar. The music is consistent in its hulking proportions but eclectic in style-- there is the elastic drone-rock of ""Curtains""
column8: the minimal techno of ""Things are Sometimes Tragic""
column9: the ersatz chamber music of ""All We Left Behind""
column10: and the ambient pop of ""Broken Devices"". As a singer
column11: Fromageau makes the effectively inexpressive Gonzalez sound like Charlotte Church by comparison
column12: and his emaciated murmur gives even the brightest tracks (e.g. ""Montreuil"") an undertow of dissipated energies.

column1: Fromageau uses different strategies to compensate for his limited vocal timbre and range
column2: at least whenever he doesn't just bury it harmlessly in the mix. Sometimes these strategies work well and sometimes they go awry
column3: as on the Auto-Tuned ""Pleasure That Hurts""
column4: which sounds a little too much like an ailing Chad Kroeger singing over serious German electronic music. It's curious why Fromageau doesn't more often use the appealingly lively and unpretentious style of single ""Dead Film Star""
column5: a sticky anthem where Team Ghost fires on all cylinders without overheating-- and
column6: admittedly
column7: sounds most like M83. A few too many other tracks
column8: such as ""Away""
column9: compensate for thin material with sheer bluster
column10: and they can feel unwarrantedly grueling. But there's a conviction here
column11:
and that's nothing to feel sorry for.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19089/homepage_large.6d107168.jpg|Reflection of the Negative|31192.0|Cough|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2013-04-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:08.602247|"

If ever there were an optimal time for Virginia doom acts Cough and Windhand to release their best music to date
column2: this moment seems like the right one. During the last few years
column3: both Richmond bands have fostered a buzz that’s escalated steadily enough to mirror the electric crawls of their music. Ritual Abuse
column4: Cough’s second album and first for relative metal major Relapse
column5: evidenced the group’s ability to punish over the long haul
column6: or to keep 12-minute marches interesting with deliberate lulls and requisite quakes. A year ago
column7: Windhand emerged with a self-titled five-song debut that managed to be simultaneously spooky and psychedelic
column8: with tremors of backwoods horror reverberating within the band’s riff-and-rhythm lockstep. It also introduced Dorthia Cottrell
column9: a singer who slipped a fetching dose of soul into the band’s tidal sway. “Heaven”
column10: she beckoned through repetition at the close of the record’s best song
column11: “is on its way.” You wanted to stick around to see just what that meant for Windhand.

column1: Later this year
column2: Relapse will issue new LPs from both bands
column3: something they’re teasing with the new
column4: three-track split album Reflection of the Negative. The contributions from both bands are
column5: so far
column6: inarguable career highlights
column7: cuts so well imagined and executed that you’ll
column8: once again
column9: want to know what’s next for both. The move is a marketing coup for Relapse
column10: of course
column11: but Reflection of the Negative is also one of the most immersive metal sets to arrive so far this year. If this is only a prelude
column12: the main event will be aptly named.

column1: As Craig Hayes pointed out at Popmatters last year
column2: splits between heavy metal bands are a matter of convenience not only because they allow acts to share costs and fans but also because they serve as de facto display cases for subtle subgenre variations. Heavy metal is a realm of both establishing and erasing rules
column3: meaning that a niche is pure only until someone new can come along and rearrange its ideals. That’s especially true here
column4: with two acts from the same town and typically pinned with the same genre tags-- sludge
column5: doom
column6: stoner
column7: psychedelic-- going in wildly different directions.

column1: As they did in 2010
column2: Cough uses the split LP format to go the distance with one uninterrupted track. These 18 minutes are a showcase of pacing and structure. Cough rides the same theme for the distance
column3: and they don’t suddenly sprint after distended stretches
column4: an easy and pervasive technique in such situations; instead
column5: the quintet methodically adds and removes elements like a creaking organ
column6: spliced movie samples
column7: and shrieking second guitar to maintain intrigue without seeming impatient. Vocalist Parker Chandler initially crawls inside of the amplifier wall
column8: his shrieks made mostly unintelligible by the band’s creeping tumult. Near the halfway mark
column9: though
column10: the drums briefly disappear
column11: leaving only the scrambled guitars and his now settled desperation: “The time has come for sacrifice
column12: ” he repeats. The ingenious setup keeps the track interesting by revealing the layers slowly and in an unexpected order. Nearly a decade into their career
column13: Cough has never sounded so belligerent
column14: frightening or immediate.

column1: On its side
column2: Windhand opt for two numbers
column3: both of which find the band ratcheting its intensity and urgency. The shorter “Amaranth” deals in italicized aggression
column4: turning everything from Cottrell’s arching vocals to the sprawling guitar solo that consumes the song’s back half into a point that must be made now. Though it’s slower than its counterpart
column5: “Shepherd’s Crook” capitalizes on the same feeling. Every piece comes with a little extra energy
column6: whether it’s the irascible noise-guitar introduction or the fortified punch that the drums pack in the otherwise torpid verses. On their debut
column7: Windhand
column8: especially Cottrell
column9: sometimes seemed as if they were hanging around for an audience to arrive
column10: dipping into a groove long enough to give a crowd the chance to show. But with Reflection of the Negative
column11: they’re coming at the audience from all angles. They’re done waiting
column12: and they’re much better for the shift.

column1: Reflection of the Negative also serves as an important notice for the Virginia capital of Richmond. When people talk about metal in the South
column2: they’re quick to trot out the humid burgs of Savannah and New Orleans or
column3: in a much different way
column4: the death metal crucible of Florida. But Richmond has a historic and lively past with loud music
column5: whether talking Honor Role and Breadwinner
column6: Pig Destroyer and Municipal Waste
column7: or even GWAR and Avail. Between Inter Arma’s Sky Burial
column8: a study in metal miscegenation
column9: and Reflection of the Negative
column10:
the city’s already responsible for two of the year’s most compelling metal albums. Release dates for full-lengths from Windhand and Cough haven’t even been announced yet. The time is right. 

"|17894.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17894-cough-windhand-reflection-of-the-negative/|7.9|Grayson Currin

Morrissey Is Not a Human Being
column2: Part Two. The former Smiths frontman
column3: whose health concerns and vociferous animal-rights adovocacy have recently made him to the indie blogosphere what Lil Wayne is to TMZ
column4: could've preempted the ailing rapper's latest album title way back in 1991. Moz had already shown devotees he was
column5: well
column6: human after all
column7: when a planned follow-up to masterful 1988 solo debut Viva Hate fell apart amid professional acrimony and critical rubbishing. Then
column8: after bouncing back brilliantly with 1990's Bona Drag singles compilation
column9: Steven Patrick Morrissey followed through on what he'd been saying all along: That he had no right to take his place with the human race.

column1: Kill Uncle
column2: Morrissey's second solo LP
column3: has a largely deserved reputation as his least distinctive. A minor album by a major artist
column4: it still offers its own curious pleasures
column5: particularly for the converted (who have always constituted much of Moz's audience anyway). And like another wrongly panned outing by a canonical rock figurehead
column6: Bob Dylan's Self Portrait in 1970
column7: Kill Uncle positively revels in its own insubstantiality: Though often critiqued according to an indie tradition grounded in authenticity and personal expression
column8: the album is best appreciated as a campy celebration of the decorative and artificial. The original vinyl includes an etching that reads
column9: punning on Oscar Wilde
column10: ""Nothing to declare except my jeans""; a standalone single coinciding with the reissue is a 7"" vinyl Rickroll.

column1: Morrissey might've had little choice but to wrap himself in arch humor. Where Viva Hate reunited him with the Smiths' producer Stephen Street and found a top-notch replacement for guitarist Johnny Marr in the Durutti Column's Vini Reilly
column2: Kill Uncle's style varies between generically Smiths-y jangle and cabaret-like theatricality. Moz's production team here of Alan Winstanley and Clive Langer had a fairly solid track record (Elvis Costello
column3: Madness; later
column4: Bush's Sixteen Stone)
column5: and they'd actually overseen a few of Bona Drag's lesser cuts. But together with guitarist and Kirsty MacColl collaborator Mark E. Nevin
column6: they failed to give Morrissey a musical setting as singular as his own eccentric presence.

column1: With the heavy lifting left to Morrissey's idiosyncratic lyrics and motley croon
column2: he disappeared into them
column3: tartly disowning such supposed virtues as honesty and passion. The best tracks tend to be the most bitterly funny
column4: such as buoyant alt-pop opener ""Our Frank""
column5: where a wryly ""r""-rolling Moz bemoans earnestness as so much vulgarity (""I'm only human
column6: he sneers!)
column7: only to wind up suggesting his narrator is probably just targeting himself. ""Sing Your Life""
column8: jaunty as the angle of a stylish cap
column9: is a brutal ethering of the troubador-like idea expressed in its title
column10: and contains another surprise ending: Just when it looks like Moz is about to pull back the curtain and reveal ""the truth
column11: it turns out to be only that ""you have a lovely singing voice."" If the Smiths lyric from the The Queen Is Dead's ""Cemetry Gates"" about how ""Keats and Yeats are on your side/ While Wilde is on mine"" was misunderstood in 1986
column12: Moz was beating the world over the head with it in 1991. And the world still wouldn't listen.

column1: The more ostensibly serious songs also mock conventional values
column2: both aesthetically and morally. Much as other tracks here spurn the goal of expressing some timeless artistic truth
column3: ""(I'm) The End of the Family Line""-- an elegantly swaying strummer so ""elegantly swaying"" you can almost hear the air quotes-- finds Morrissey rejecting the biological imperative of passing along his DNA. The family line might be ending
column4: but the song doesn't right away: Just when a muffled speaking voice sounds like it's about to overtake the fading music
column5: Moz comes back for another chorus
column6: spitting his dynastic betrayal in the face of decent-thinking humanity one last time. Similarly
column7: shutter-clicking whirligig ""The Harsh Truth of the Camera Eye"" plays less like a straightforward tale of paparazzi and more like a bleak observation on public image. Both are funnier than their pomp and circumstance might hint. Just think: Moz is mocked for his self-aggrandizement
column8: but it's the breeders who act like we're so special the planet needs our genetic material after we die.

column1: Of course
column2: compared with ""Everyday Is Like Sunday"" or even ""The First of the Gang to Die""
column3: these sardonic jibes are lesser accomplishments
column4: and not everything on Kill Uncle bears revisiting. The racially trolling ""Asian Rut""-- part of a regrettable triptych with Viva Hate's ""Bengali in Platforms"" and ""The National Front Disco
column5: from 1992's far-superior Your Arsenal-- is instrumentally lavish
column6: with accordion and violin
column7: but it carries the album's undercurrent of dehumanization to an unbearable extreme: Morrissey withholds empathy for the victim of a racist attack. Though glorification of thuggish ugliness is a legitimate artistic theme that runs across the work of the writer Jean Genet and director Pier Paolo Pasolini
column8: among many others
column9: the result is frustrating from an artist with an unusually diverse indie-rock fanbase.

column1: Like last year's Viva Hate reissue
column2: the newly remastered Kill Uncle package is only slightly different from its original
column3: and not exactly for the better. ""Asian Rut"" is blessedly lower on the track list
column4: ""Family Line"" assumes its rightful place at the end
column5: and two superfluous B-sides now interrupt the album's midsection: ""Pashernate Love""
column6: a romp too trifling even to succeed as a trifle
column7: and ""East West""
column8: a confounding Herman's Hermits cover that makes sense only as a nod to the album's superficiality (Moz exults
column9: ""Nothing is tacky!""). The redone album artwork likewise emphasizes self-awareness
column10: with photography of Moz posing in a Bona Drag T-shirt
column11: but isn't especially arresting. No extra liner notes. No bonus discs. Nothing that might boost the rating above.

column1: The most noteworthy switch is the replacement of ""There's a Place in Hell for Me and My Friends
column2: originally a piano-based torch song
column3: with a live-in-studio version from 1991's Morrissey at KROQ EP. This take's muscular
column4: rockabilly-infused glam-rock portends the direction Morrissey would take next on Your Arsenal. But perversely removing the most over-the-top
column5: showtunes-y number from Kill Uncle only further undercuts the coherence of its appeal. And what about ""Sing Your Life""
column6: which also appears in a more immediately pleasing but less conceptually appropriate rockabilly version on the KROQ EP?

column1: Now
column2: as ever
column3: provoking and then withholding sensible answers to such obsessive questions remains essential to Morrissey's allure. Kill Uncle came at a time when U.S. audiences
column4: on the eve of Nirvana's breakthrough
column5: might've decided Moz was another alternative-rock icon worthy of widespread embrace
column6: but his decidedly English quirks were almost as out of step in the states as they were in the UK
column7: where his native Manchester had gone (to him
column8: deplorably) Madchester and Britpop was still a couple of years away. Morrissey always knew how to toy with the press; when he came out onstage in London's Finsbury Park draped in the Union Jack
column9: it was a scandal. Before too long
column10: it might've been Cool Britannia
column11: but the irony would've been lost either way: Contrary to Deerhunter's wildly entertaining dismissal of Morrissey in a recent interview
column12: he's no ""Sir Morrissey"" and has harshly criticized other rock musicians who accept royal honors.

column1: For a sense of just how misunderstood Kill Uncle was
column2: consider that Rolling Stone's review at the time compared Morrissey's role with the Smiths to Sylvia Plath and chided the new record for its ""detached feel."" Surely
column3: Plath is over on Keats' and Yeats' side. Meanwhile
column4: over with Moz on Wilde's
column5: detachment isn't necessarily an insult; that doesn't make the record a masterpiece
column6: but it does make it one worth revisiting for Moz's ample cult. In a strange way
column7: the song that best explains Kill Uncle isn't on Kill Uncle at all. It's Bona Drag's ""Disappointed""
column8: where Morrissey sings
column9: and a crowd responds
column10: ""This the last song I'll ever sing (yeah!)/ No: I've changed my mind again (awww...)/ Good night
column11: and thank you."" Morrissey fandom is a lifelong exercise in self-aware disappointment
column12: but if he really is the last of his kind
column13: let's enjoy him while we have him. Though he's been teasing us about his looming mortality for years
column14:
he really is all too human. And he has a lovely singing voice.

In 2010 and 2011
column2: producer Joe Boyd spearheaded a series of live shows in tribute to  Nick Drake
column3: hand-picking performers to cover Drake’s songs. Boyd was not only a central figure in the 1960s folk revival on both sides of the Atlantic
column4: but he produced Drake’s first two albums
column5: Five Leaves Left in 1969 and Bryter Layter in 1970. Few knew Drake quite so well as Boyd
column6: so few are so qualified to re-stage these songs in an affectionate tribute. The mood on Way to Blue: The Songs of Nick Drake
column7: which collects highlights from the concerts
column8: is reverent and dignified
column9: occasionally rethinking arrangements but mostly adhering to the familiar orchestral swells
column10: piano runs
column11: and jazzy guitar licks.

column1: Perhaps that’s the problem. Especially in 2013
column2: 14 years after the VW ad that turned every car buyer into a Pink Moon fan
column3: Way to Blue is too rigid in its approach and too timid in its interpretations to challenge or enlarge our perception of Drake. The tracklist includes several generations of artists
column4: from Vashti Bunyan to Luluc
column5: but with precious few exceptions
column6: they turn Drake’s songs into mumbly folk-pop-- aggressively decorous and strangely passive. In fact
column7: aside from the atrocious backing vocals on Shane Nicholson’s version of “Poor Boy”
column8: the performances are perfectly adequate
column9: but who wants adequate when you can easily pull up the originals
column10: which still sound lovely and intense and devastating.

column1: Despite Green Gartside’s noble yet safe reading of “Fruit Tree”
column2: the only artist who truly gets under the skin of Drake’s music is his contemporary Vashti Bunyan. She manages to overcome the spectacle of the historical venue and deliver a truly meaningful and disarming reinterpretation of “Which Will”
column3: savoring certain syllables and twisting the words into new and strange shapes. By comparison
column4: Lisa Hannigan’s cover of “Black Eyed Dog” sounds self-consciously eccentric
column5: her warbles and coos too practiced
column6: but that’s preferable to Teddy Thompson’s colorless take on “River Man”.

column1: Is it their fault for sounding so passive in their performances
column2: or is it Boyd’s fault for restricting the possibilities and keeping the project so beholden to Drake’s legacy? Most likely the blame rests with everyone
column3: but in truth the very concept of Way to Blue seems flawed: The setting is far too public for Drake’s private ruminations
column4: which reinforces the idea that he lived his pain for public consumption. Boyd and his cohorts aren’t inviting you to sympathize with that pain
column5: but to experience it voyeuristically. Or
column6: to borrow some insight from Boyd’s book White Bicycles
column7: in which he discusses a recent concert by Aretha Franklin: “Waves of self-congratulatory affection passed back and forth between [Franklin and the audience]: she claiming credit for recognizing what they wanted to hear; the audience adoring themselves for being so hip as to want the ‘real thing.’ The music was caught in the middle
column8: lifeless and predictable.”

column1:
(Editor's note: This album was reviewed from an advance copy that contained applause between the songs. The applause was later removed from the final release. The original review had references to the applause that have been deleted.)
