A name like “Rainbow Arabia” comes armed with expectations: a childlike whimsy
column3: a colorful disposition
column4: and some sort of cultural appropriation are among things you’d likely chalk to up a group with the moniker. Their last album
column5: 2010’s Boys and Diamonds
column6: lived up to those first impressions: It was a collection of Orientalism-tinged ditties full of kid-friendly chants and West African melodies. But even when their songwriting was strong
column7: they still felt more like an idea than a band. Their new album FM Sushi
column8: released on their own Time No Place imprint with some help from Cologne techno giant Kompakt
column9: retains that feeling of youthful mischief but reinforces it with tuneful songs and deluxe production that seemed only a distant possibility on Boys.

column1: The Los Angeles husband-wife duo have undergone some changes since then. For one
column2: they’ve brought in a live drummer to beef up their drum machine rhythm tracks. The pool of sounds they borrow from has also greatly expanded. While their reference points are still pretty identifiable
column3: they throw sounds together in a much more interesting way than their old drowning-in-reverb indie pop. It’s noticeable early on
column4: with the spry second track “He Is Sorcerer”
column5: full of New Order grandeur and their most irresistible melody yet. Every phrase uncoils effortlessly from the last
column6: like the stuff summer jams are made of. Tiffany Preston’s vocals sound unnervingly like the Knife’s Karin Dreijier Andersson
column7: but her newfound confidence to play with her voice is almost enough to look past the resemblance.

column1: Though the Prestons are definitely writing tighter pop songs this time around
column2: their inspiration comes from an unlikely source: German synth and soundtrack music from the late 70s. Tangerine Dream and their many contemporaries have been a prominent thread in electronic music for several years now
column3: often with guarded techno types
column4: but the trio handle the influence in unusual ways. The puffy textures serve to make their  pop songs plusher
column5: but the inherently portentous tones provide emotional complexity as well. The title track is turned mournful heart-tugging
column6: and they layer bluesy guitar licks over the the machine moans of “Moments I Had"". Transplanting sounds from all sorts of genres
column7: it would be easy to label them as record-collector pop or internet music dilettantes-- but their music feels too honest and eager for such cynical categorization.

column1: That being said
column2: it does feel like they’re piecing together bits from their favorite artists
column3: intentionally or not. On moments like the arpeggio-drenched “River’s Edge”
column4: or especially instrumental “Thai Iced Tea”
column5: where MIDI sax rides a bumpy groove like a toy miniature “V-2 Schneider”
column6: they’re their own band. But on “Lacking Risk” and “Three Moons”
column7: they blatantly ape the chintziest of 80s pop. They do it well
column8: sure
column9: but so do countless other bands. And considering this is a group that apparently likes to re-interpret entire Tangerine Dream soundtracks in their spare time
column10: it’s obvious that they’re capable of better. FM Sushi
column11: then
column12: is a stepping stone for a group suddenly poised to do great things
column13:
things their debut never even suggested. But looking over the precipice is different than actually crossing it-- so for now we’re stuck with them as they formulate their next move. At least it’s not a bad place to hang around.

column7: Young released a more successful attempt to capitalize on his online popularity
column8: one which brought back the novel
column9: bare-bones beats that he clearly thrives on. The Ol’ Soul EP
column10: a collection of new songs and YouTube favorites
column11: is an arresting rap record
column12: unique in its minimalist sound and bathed in the fingerprints of the South's musical history.

column1: Don’s songs combine Southern rap
column2: soul
column3: and blues into a mix that at times recalls predecessors as disparate as Scarface
column4: Rick Ross
column5: Anthony Hamilton
column6: Floyd Council
column7: and Howlin' Wolf.  The hooks of his best songs are rough dirges and frequently espouse simple
column8: mournful themes like “life goes by so fast” or “this is all I know.” In his verses
column9: he’s equal parts punch line rapper and storyteller
column10: as comfortable rattling off jokes about the color of cocaine as he is taking on the part of the Almighty in the dialectic “Song to God (My Life)”. Apart from these occasional religious digressions
column11: Don’s subject matter consists largely of by-the-book gangsterisms but his wit sets him apart
column12: along with that distinctive voice
column13: a rich
column14: gravelly baritone
column15: untrained and harrowing. On his single  “All I Know”
column16: the humming alone is intriguing enough to merit multiple listens.

column1: By leaving beats almost entirely out of the question
column2: Don demands the listener’s focus. His voice props up some of the weaker songs here-- “Street Life”
column3: a “my girl is the streets” allegory would be a total cliché if it weren’t for its sung introduction. But his rapping can stand on its own
column4: as demonstrated on “Gone Tomorrow”
column5: a detail-heavy tale of an ambitious kid that balloons into a full-blown revenge epic.

column1: Don is a natural dichotomy-breaker. His lyrical facility gives the lie to the stereotype of the monosyllabic Southern rapper even as his Greenville patois makes it obvious where he’s from.  His rhyme patterns are reminiscent of a trap-rapper who’s been robbed of bombastic beats.  And he professes to have a profound faith in God (saying in an interview that the best advice he can give to kids is to “stay prayed up”)
column2: but seemingly can’t resist glorifying the street life that got him sent to prison for eight years.

column1: His uncomplicated approach to songmaking might make Alpoko Don seem like the antidote to music industry excess but his process isn’t quite as influence-free as one might think after seeing him sitting on the porch
column2: creating music out of thin air. Those videos are sponsored by Young Jeezy’s clothing company
column3: 8732 Apparel
column4: and The Ol’ Soul EP was co-produced by Darrell “Digga” Branch
column5: who has worked with Cam’ron
column6: 50 Cent
column7: and Jay-Z. Industry associations might be distasteful to those who have been riding for Don as a kind of rap Horatio Alger yet to be tainted by industry grime
column8: but the music itself is hard to question: even his rework of Patti Labelle’s corporate soft-rock staple “If You Asked Me To” manages to sound gritty (and this is a song that was famously covered by Celine Dion.)

column1: Don is most transfixing when you can see him work-- his are among the videos you’ll want to pull up whenever some idiot starts to question rap’s musicality. And it’s undeniable that the novelty of his approach contributed hugely to the success of his music videos. But if Don were some lousy amateur with a unique approach

column3:
and it’s the latter that will keep The Ol’ Soul EP relevant longer than it takes for any gimmick to get old.

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2013-04-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:12.843209|"

A sense of déjà vu haunts The North Borders
column3: UK producer Simon Green’s fifth studio album as Bonobo. It’s almost 15 years since he first appeared with the shy-footed but prescient “Terrapin”
column4: which later appeared on his debut album Animal Magic and helped him find a name at the forefront of the downtempo electronica scene that bubbled up in the late 90s and early 2000s (a period when ambient pop albums like Air’s Moon Safari and Röyksopp’s Melody A.M. were scoring top 10 positions in the UK charts). Drawing on the noodling notions of jazz and trip hop
column5: downtempo became the clubbing generation’s default after-hours music: the sound of a thousand compilation CDs made for slinging on after the club or soothing heads the morning after the night before.

column1: Bonobo stood above the rest because his compositional touch was so instinctive: deftly coaxing complex emotions from machines while employing acoustic instrumentation sparingly to devastating effect. Throughout the 2000s he built on his reputation for sonic storytelling
column2: culminating in his exquisite 2010 album Black Sands. Yet with The North Borders
column3: Green appears to have hit a stumbling block. The balance is skewed and he all but drowns his knack for emotive instrumentation in the kind of introspective production that marked his formative period.

column1: A number of tracks feature a stock approach to progression and release. They begin as densely layered
column2: moody affairs
column3: caught up in themselves and in the past. It’s only in the final minute or so that the underlying instruments are allowed to sing
column4: and when they do the track finally feels alive in the present moment. On opening track “First Fires”
column5: it’s the strings that finally rise above the cloudy production in the closing minute or so that provide the track with an anchor. There’s some truly lovely arrangement towards the end of “Sapphire”
column6: when a chorus of reed instruments purr sagely to one another. Then again on “Ten Tigers” those heart-serrating strings tease in the background only to momentarily-- fantastically-- bloom as the track fades.

column1: The problem is not so much that these instrumental flourishes are too little
column2: too late
column3: but that the tracks that hold them feel over-worked
column4: the layers so dense as to stifle the ideas. “There's nobody there telling me when to stop
column5: so often I end up adding a bunch more elements to the track after I originally thought it was done
column6: ” Green said recently. “I often have an idea and it starts splintering off into a whole lot of directions; I'm interested in exploring every single one of them.”

column1: Green recorded the album in his new home of New York
column2: following an extensive year and a half touring Black Sands
column3: and you can hear his exhaustion in the album’s confusion. On one hand he appears to reach for dialogue with the chime-led melodies of Caribou and Four Tet on album standout “Cirrus”
column4: a truly joyful
column5: free moment on the album. But on the other hand
column6: it finds him seeking refuge in a realm he knows inside out: lolloping
column7: jazz-inflected soundscapes. While it sounds like he had fun collecting sounds on his travels-- from a truck’s air brakes to train doors closing on the subway-- they are lost in his layering. Even his track with Erykah Badu feels like a missed opportunity: it’s a sweet enough jam but she’s so deep in the mix on “Heaven For The Sinner” that she slips frustratingly out of focus. While for all intents and purposes The North Borders screams “easy listening
column8: ” it’s doesn’t half tie itself up in knots. At its worst-- the limp and dated bumble of “Jets”-- it feels like Bonobo-style music.

column1: That said
column2: his work with new singer Szjerdene has more energy: “Towers” breathes easier
column3: while “Transits” has a narrative depth that largely evades the rest of the album. While it’s exciting that Green will be performing the album live with Szjerdene and a 10-piece orchestra
column4: I can't help feeling he was playing safe by not fully embracing his orchestral exploration in the album’s recording. The North Borders is not a bad album-- for the most
column5:
it’s as inoffensive as those decade-old chill-out compilations-- yet a frustration persists because Bonobo is better than this.

column3: Veronica Mars makes sure you hear and appreciate “Such Great Heights.” Veronica and her totally-wrong-for-her boyfriend Troy are driving around looking for his stolen car when the Postal Service comes on the radio. “I dig this song
column4: ” he tells her. “Yeah
column5: me too
column6: ” she replies. They let it play out for a few more measures of beeps and beats before launching back into their conversation. The song plays again during the closing scene
column7: when the girl detective is listening to a weird
column8: round
column9: portable contraption meant to play compact music discs. The scene is quiet and poignant
column10: not only playing the band’s wistful pop in the foreground but contrasting it with the character’s recent glimpses of the compromised adult world. “Such Great Heights” is a way for Veronica to hang on to childhood for another four minutes and twenty-seven seconds.

column1: Just a few weeks after Veronica Mars did the unthinkable and funded a feature-length movie via Kickstarter-- raising $2 million in eleven hours-- Sub Pop is reissuing the Postal Service’s platinum-selling Give Up in a deluxe
column2: 2xCD set. This pair of pop culture artifacts point to a growing nostalgia for the golden age of prematurely canceled TV shows (see also: the fourth season of Arrested Development) and indie pop as cult soundtrack. The Postal Service's lone album has proved surprisingly influential
column3: casting a long shadow over the 2000s. Not only did it show up in films and on television-- Garden State
column4: Grey’s Anatomy
column5: D.E.B.S.--  but its songs were covered regularly by a wide range of artists
column6: from Ben Folds to metal act Confide to a ska act called Tip the Van. In commercials for Kaiser Permanente
column7: UPS
column8: and (for legal reasons) the actual United States Postal Service
column9: Jimmy Tamborello’s bloops and beeps conveyed the idea of ideas: synapses firing
column10: synergy synergizing
column11: connectivities connecting. For better or for worse
column12: for a little while
column13: the Postal Service made laptops the new guitar.

column1: Not bad for a side project. Tamborello and Ben Gibbard first collaborated on “(This Is) The Dream of Evan and Chan
column2: ” for Dntel’s 2001 album Life Is Full of Possibilities. Apparently
column3: they worked so well together that they kept at it
column4: even corralling Jenny Lewis
column5: Jen Wood
column6: and Chris Walla to play on their songs. In the days before Dropbox and YouSendIt
column7: they had to snail-mail tracks back and forth
column8: so they called themselves the Postal Service. Released in 2003
column9: their debut was a slow grower
column10: but it had a long life and was still producing singles in 2005. What began as a side project… well
column11: stayed a side project
column12: but Give Up looms large in both men’s careers. Tamborello failed to capture that sense of evocative purpose on either of Dntel’s subsequent albums
column13: although he has become a key member of the L.A. blip scene that includes Baths and Flying Lotus. Gibbard has released seven full-lengths with his day-job band Death Cab for Cutie
column14: but many of his best and most beloved tunes are all on Give Up. Which
column15: by the way
column16: is Sub Pop’s second highest selling album of all time
column17: besting the Shins’ Oh Inverted World.

column1: Even in 2013
column2: when those perfectly aligned freckles have faded
column3: it’s not hard to hear why Give Up would be a hit. The album’s highs represent a perfect marriage between Tamborello’s synths
column4: which sound like the first rays of dawn hitting a Mister Bulky
column5: and Gibbard’s gee-whiz lyrics
column6: which possess a mussed-hair whimsy. The best songs here-- not just “The District Sleeps Alone Tonight” and “We Will Become Silhouettes” but also “Recycled Air” and “Nothing Better”-- evoke innocence and imagination in equal measure
column7: a sense of the fantastical that persists as a defense mechanism against the terrible or the simply mundane. No wonder it appealed to Veronica Mars and seemingly every other teenager who heard it: Give Up allowed them to see their worlds differently. “Silhouettes” turned heartbreak into nuclear holocaust without sounding over the top
column8: because who hasn’t felt like the last person on Earth? “Such Great Heights” made freckles more than something to be insecure about; instead
column9: they became the stars that crossed lovers. Thanks to Gibbard’s twee imagery as well as his persistent use of second-person pronouns
column10: Give Up reinforces each listener’s individuality.

column1: By not recording a follow-up
column2: the Postal Service never had to strike that impossible balance again-- they left it up to Owl City
column3: Hellogoodbye
column4: and too many other imitators to carry the synthpop banner. The Postal Service's dubious legacy often obscures the fact that Give Up is only a good album
column5: not a great one. Those quirky lyrics curdle into something unbearable on “Sleeping In”
column6: as Gibbard recounts a dream about JFK’s assassination and the environmental apocalypse. “Clark Gable” is a tortuously meta love song
column7: although that might actually be the point. Sequencing is an issue as well: the album is so frontloaded that the second half drops off a cliff. How many people actually made it to “Natural Anthem”? But the highs are high enough to offset the lows

column5: compact
column6: containable-- which means this reissue doubles as a celebration of the album and as a definitive history of the band itself. The remixes-- by Matthew Dear and John Tejada
column7: among others-- don’t add much to the originals besides length

column9: Nina Simone

column1: The duo covered frequently just as they were frequently covered
column2: so the tracks by the Shins and Iron & Wine at least work as time capsule. The former’s deadpan take on “We Will Become Silhouettes” makes the apocalypse sound jangly and grim again
column3: while the latter’s whispery “Such Great Heights” recalls that moment in the previous decade where folkies were slowing down fast pop songs. On the other hand

column5: there are two new tracks

column7: sadly

column9: the hooks catchy
column10: but these tunes lack any sense of newness or discovery or connection. More crucially
column11: it’s off-putting to hear the Postal Service re-create that 2003 sound in 2013. That’s the burden of any album that so completely defined its time: Give Up remains anchored in its heyday
column12: and like all those canceled TV shows
column13:
it only reminds us how far we’ve moved away from that particular moment.

That English Electric itself was the name of a noted UK train and aerospace manufacturing firm from the 20th Century further underscores that sense of a specifically grounded and gone past

In 2005
column2: Trunk Records founder Jonny Trunk released a book titled The Music Library
column3: which provided an overview of various library music labels dating back as far as the mid 1960s. The book is dominated by the sleeve art produced for the various companies
column4: some humorous
column5: some wildly psychedelic
column6: some dry and instructional. In the section on KPM
column7: a label among the most sampled and influential of the bunch
column8: sit two plain sleeves
column9: one olive green and one burnt orange
column10: both bearing an address
column11: a telephone number
column12: and the words: ""KPM: Music Recorded Library"". They're unremarkable to the untrained eye
column13: even slightly dull in comparison to the blaze of color on offer elsewhere in the book's pages. But
column14: to aficionados of library music
column15: those sleeves are utterly iconic and desirable
column16: housing the kind of records that can easily cause questionably large amounts of money to change hands under the right conditions.

column1: Library music dates back to the 1950s
column2: when the boom in TV shows
column3: films
column4: advertising
column5: and radio produced a near endless need for musical themes (or ""cues
column6: as they're often called). Having a stack of library music on hand was cheaper than commissioning a group of artists to go into a studio and record a new composition
column7: and so the impeccably played work of anonymous session musicians reached audiences of millions. None of the original vinyl releases were commercially available and many of the labels that produced the music remain steeped in mystery. Even the musicians involved are often hard to trace due to the proliferation of pseudonymous recordings
column8: although KPM attracted some of the all-time greats
column9: including Keith Mansfield and Alan Hawkshaw
column10: whose work features prominently on this expanded reissue of a 1999 compilation released by Strut.

column1: The initial fetishization of library music came bundled with a renewed interest in exotica and easy listening that flourished alongside Britpop in the mid 1990s. At Blow Up in London it was common to hear old library music cues being dropped by DJs such as the Karminsky Experience
column2: Stereolab's Tim Gane
column3: and Barry 7 from Add N to (X)
column4: while an adjoining room would blast out hits from Blur and Oasis. Fast-forward a decade
column5: and the Ghost Box label repopularized the music. Danger Mouse
column6: Jay-Z
column7: DOOM
column8: and Madlib have all sampled KPM cues. The styles embraced by the players on Music for Dancefloors are as wide ranging as the artists who have been inspired by them. But what makes this music fascinating is the place in which it falls; never becoming simple exercises in proficiency
column9: but never reaching the same level of inspiration as the artists whom musicians like Mansfield and Hawkshaw are clearly aping.

column1: This is a scratch across the surface of the KPM library
column2: and as such
column3: it's wilfully disjointed. Reggae
column4: samba
column5: jazz
column6: soul
column7: and funk are all tried on for size and quickly discarded
column8: with decidedly mixed results. There's a rare vocal track (Alan Parker and Madeline Bell's ""That's What Friends Are For"")
column9: and the best-known KPM cut
column10: Mansfield's ""Funky Fanfare""
column11: isn't included. Still
column12: compiling this stuff is a minefield
column13: and this is a decent way-in for the uninitiated. John Cameron's gloriously heavy ""Swamp Fever"" is among the best tracks here
column14: and the record it's from
column15: Afro Rock
column16: could easily have yielded far more material for this album had time and space allowed. The sequencing is slick
column17: with oddities like Nascimbene's ""Witchdoctor"" breaking up percussion-heavy
column18: Latin-influenced tracks. Klaus Weiss's ""Morning 1/Morning 2"" even bridges some of the gaps
column19: bringing in a wild array of styles.

column1: With so many crisp and precise beats high in the mix
column2: KPM has understandably provided a rich source of samples over the years. There's certainly a feeling of joy to much of the music here
column3: but little or no sense of abandon. It lends much of the KPM music a unified ambience
column4: locked down in a place it can’t quite get to. Barry Morgan and Ray Cooper's ""Samba Street"" is flooded with uplift
column5: but never arrives at somewhere as unique and unhinged as Ray Barretto or Tito Puente in their respective primes. Hawkshaw's ""Senior Thump"" maps out similar territory to Larry Young
column6: but Hawkshaw remains earthbound
column7: leaving Young to head toward the stars. But that's partly the intent behind this material
column8: to stay palatable
column9: to court as wide an audience as possible for whatever production was going to pick up on this music.

column1: There's an entirely superfluous live performance packaged with Music for Dancefloors
column2: taken from a performance by the KPM All-Stars at London's Jazz Cafe in April 2000. Many of the original musicians were included in the show
column3: finally coming out of the shadows and proving that just about everyone in the business gets a second act at some point in their careers. The performances are as fastidious as you'd expect. Even the closing medley of songs from British sports TV shows is an exercise in pure professionalism: Given the chance to let their hair down and have some fun
column4: these guys simply respond with an astounding display of chops. But it's best to forget the live show
column5: mainly because KPM is something that doesn’t benefit from having its process laid bare. It's far better to leave it drifting in time
column6: rediscovered every decade or so
column7:
this odd period when a strange magic was produced by greying men in cardigans channeling Sly Stone.

Sergei Parajanov's Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors tells the story of Ivan and Marichka
column2: two star-crossed lovers from a tiny village in the Carpathians who find (and refind) each other under the most extraordinary circumstances. It's a vibrant
column3: dizzying film with the quality of a dream: In 1978
column4: the late Roger Ebert called it ""one of the most unusual films I've seen
column5: a barrage of images
column6: music and noises
column7: shot with such an active camera we almost need seatbelts."" The movie struck a chord with Jeremy Barnes and Heather Trost of A Hawk and a Hacksaw
column8: the American duo whose on-record explorations of the folk music of Eastern Europe shares the film's interest in the region's folk traditions
column9: its cross-hatching of the mournful and the celebratory
column10: and its hints of the surreal. You Have Already Gone to the Other World
column11: produced by Deerhoof's John Dieterich and named after the film's most memorable line
column12: is the group's sixth LP
column13: with material both drawn from and inspired by the music in Shadows. It's a kaleidoscopic album
column14: blending sounds from the film itself with centuries-old Ukranian
column15: Hungarian and Romanian tunes and several new compositions that apply a few modern flourishes to the band's tradition-minded melodies.

column1: There's not much separating Barnes and Trost's own pieces with the older material here; this is hardly their first time in the area
column2: after all
column3: and by now
column4: they've studied all the guidebooks and absorbed most of the local customs. Whether it's Barnes plunking out ""Where No Horse Neighs and No Crow Flies"" on the santeur or Trost soaring over the title track on her violin
column5: they've grown into remarkably lyrical players over the years
column6: capable of great nuance and agility. Their passion for the traditional material here is obvious-- there's a palpable joy to the more boisterous stuff
column7: a deep feeling running under the mournful material. And
column8: whether they're using a trill from Ivan's flute as a jumping off point or starting entirely from scratch
column9: their own compositions find ways to move the music of the film into the present without diluting it. A few judiciously applied electronic flourishes aside-- like the IDM-aware drum blowout that closes ""The Sorcerer""-- the rest of this music could've easily come from Myroslav Skoryk's original score from 1964
column10: itself a kind of hybrid of the traditional and the modern with a strong preference for the former.

column1: That Barnes and Trost would draw an album's worth of inspiration from the musical
column2: lyrical Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors seems obvious
column3: but Other World
column4: as a document of that inspiration
column5: sometimes feels caught between a couple worlds. Barnes and Trost have played material from Other World while Shadows flickered in the background
column6: but they're quick to point out that Other World is itself not a soundtrack. It's true that you can't quite sync one to the other
column7: Dorothy/Dark Side-style and since Shadows already has such a rich reservoir of music running under it
column8: they seem to want to position Other World as more addendum than replacement. Their version isn't better
column9: they'd likely tell you-- just a little different. Taken on its own
column10: though
column11: the Other World LP is-- at 57 minutes and change-- a little on the long side
column12: and while each individual piece is plenty gripping
column13: every peak's got its valley
column14: and all that up-and-down starts to wear on you after a while. Other World actually fares worst when you strip it of its context. Coming on the heels of 2011's stellar Cervantine
column15: Other World feels like it might've been stronger had Trost and Barnes held a few more things back.

column1: Shadows is
column2: above all things
column3: a love story
column4: and between the grisly murders and the tender romance of the film
column5: there's a lot of life to depict
column6: and accordingly
column7: a huge range of emotion to convey. By careening between joy and grief at a moment's notice
column8: Barnes and Trost reflect the vast array of feeling at the heart of Shadows
column9: and the music's constant motion speaks to the film's episodic nature. The few songs shared between the film and the LP-- most memorably ""Wedding Theme""-- reflect the tenor of the scenes they're drawn from even without the accompanying images. And their own sharp
column10: sinewy compositions suit the tone of the film-- dizzying
column11: buoyed by life
column12: yet constantly aware of death-- to a T. For all the death hovering over Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors
column13: it's a strangely life-affirming film
column14: a testament to the boundless passion of two souls
column15:
inexorably linked. The rapturous Other World takes that passion and turns it outward.

column1:

The concept of samsara
column2: one of the Buddha's four noble truths
column3: holds that all beings are trapped in a self-perpetuating cycle of birth
column4: death and rebirth. Fueled by internal struggle
column5: we turn along an endless wheel of suffering
column6: passing through untold lives in our never-ending quest for enlightenment. Some meditate upon this truth for years; Kurt Vile
column7: on ""Life's a Beach""
column8: nailed it for us in two mumbled words: ""Life's awhile.""

column1: Vile's music has exuded this unique stoner-Yoda wisdom from the very beginning
column2: even if you weren't searching for it. His sound-- warm
column3: unhurried
column4: and spacious-- doesn't demand close focus
column5: but one of the joys of being pulled into Vile's lonely
column6: contented universe is in discovering that he is muttering sharply self-aware things to himself.  It adds another layer to Vile's appeal; seduced by the soothing
column7: watery-blue glimmer of that sound
column8: which promised to make you feel like the only human in the universe
column9: you slowly realized there's actually one other guy here
column10: and he's kind of a wiseass.

column1: Wakin on a Pretty Daze is Vile's most spacious
column2: becalmed record yet
column3: and it contains some of his best-ever brand of cosmic stand-up. It opens
column4: literally
column5: with a stretch and a yawn: On the (almost) title track ""Wakin on a Pretty Day""
column6: a wah'ed guitar rubs the grit out of its eyes while Vile beholds his furiously ringing phone with clinical detachment: ""Phone ringing off the shelf/ I guess somebody has something they really wanna prove to us today
column7: he notes. Unperturbed
column8: he moves along
column9: concerned with something far more pressing: ""I gotta figure out what kind of wisecrack I'm gonna drop along the way -- today."" The music quickens for a beat or two at this prospect
column10: but settles back down. In Vile's universe
column11: there is time enough for everything.

column1: Accordingly
column2: Wakin on a Pretty Daze moves at its own stately pace and with its own serene logic and time. Songs unfurl for six
column3: or seven
column4: or eight minutes without peaking dynamically or changing; the tangle of finger-picked guitars on ""Was All Talk"" queue up like synth presets that Vile just lets roll. On most songs
column5: four or five chords cycle for minutes on end
column6: echoing upward into the record's warm room tone. ""Pure Pain"" shifts between stomping
column7: hard acoustic chording and two wide-open billowing finger-picked chords that simply hang while Vile muses: ""Every time I look out my window/ All my emotions they are speeding/ Zip through the highways in my head.""  It can be occasionally frustrating to interact with a piece of music so fundamentally unconcerned with interaction
column8: but like anything worth truly loving
column9: Wakin on a Pretty Daze opens up slowly. The music
column10: and the act of loving it
column11: are exercises in patience. Or
column12: as Vile puts it sagely on ""Too Hard"": ""Take your time
column13: so they say
column14: and that's probably the best way to be.""

column1: Vile's releases are small variations on each other
column2: and discerning the differences between them comes down to intangibles
column3: things that are difficult to point to: The fact that he only yelps his little ""Woo!"" twice on ""Shame Chamber""  the first time around
column4: for instance
column5: indicating his bone-deep understanding that two ""woos
column6: for now
column7: are plenty. Or the way the silvery guitar leads snake through the album without ever assuming the foreground
column8: murmuring things that reward attention in the same way Vile's lyrics do. The way the drums nudge gently into the title refrain on ""Girl Called Alex""
column9: and how Vile's ""I wanna-"" is abruptly cut off by a stinging guitar; these details
column10: small by themselves
column11: offer accumulated testimony to Vile's mastery of his world. Wakin on a Pretty Daze breezes past like a Klonopin dream
column12: and radiates an easy confidence that is as rewarding to return to as a melody.

column1: ""Sometimes when I get in my zone
column2: you'd think I was stoned
column3: but I never as they say 'touch that stuff
column4: ' "" Vile sings
column5: with a hint of mockery
column6: on Wakin's closer ""Goldtone."" The song is stunning
column7: a desert island of Kurt Viledom. Ever since Vile signed to Matador
column8: his music has grown warmer and more expansive as he receded further into the privacy of his own mind: On Smoke Ring for My Halo's ""Ghost Town
column9: he crooned gently
column10: ""I think I'm never gonna leave my couch again/ Cuz when I'm out
column11: I'm only in my mind."" ""Goldtone
column12: and all of Wakin on a Pretty Daze
column13: feels like the culmination of Vile's quest to get away from people
column14: noises
column15: civilization and find somewhere to sit and whistle his own tune. If Kurt Vile could paint a storybook Heaven
column16: it would look like ""Goldtone""
column17: and he signs it with his most poetic
column18: self-aware koan ever:  ""I might be adrift but I'm still alert/ Concentrate my hurt into a gold tone."" A guitar pushes a wispy cirrus cloud across the sky
column19: sea-blue chimes glitter
column20:
and Vile mumbles his way into the sunset.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19162/homepage_large.74f3d83c.jpg|No Answer : Lower Floors|4619.0|Wolf Eyes|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['De Stijl']|2013-04-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:17.442476|"

Dig up descriptions of Michigan trio Wolf Eyes from any time during their 16-year existence
column2: and I doubt you'll see much use of the word “precision.” But their music has always had this quality-- even if it’s sometimes been covered in whirring distortion
column3: brittle cacophony
column4: or psychotic howls. Go back as far as “Half Animal
column5: Half Insane”
column6: from 2002’s Dread
column7: and you can hear them picking and placing their sounds meticulously. Even though the results could feel abrasive or abstract
column8: the attack has never been messy or careless. Most of the time
column9: it’s a precise rendering of Wolf Eyes’ horror-movie visions and hard-edged sonic obsessions.

column1: This knack for precision has reached a new level on No Answer: Lower Floors
column2: Wolf Eyes’ first widely-released album since 2009’s Always Wrong. It’s the clearest
column3: most detailed record in their vast catalogue. There’s little in the way of buried elements or blurred dissonance; in fact
column4: much of the album could be accurately described as minimal. The best example is the longest
column5: a 12-minute dirge called “Confession of the Informer”. Sparse and desolate
column6: it contains only a few sounds at any given moment-- and most of them are distant and fade quickly
column7: like the after-images of a light flash disappearing inside your eyelids.

column1: Why is “Confession of the Informer” more gripping than a standard blast of rising noise? The secret lies in Wolf Eyes’ ability to cook up thick tension with the simplest sonic ingredients. It’s a skill they’ve had for a while
column2: but lately they’ve focused it to a point of perfection. It helps that Nate Young and John Olson-- the group’s only consistent members since 2000-- have worked diligently on this aspect of their music outside of Wolf Eyes
column3: in the sparse sketches of their duo Stare Case
column4: the rangy experiments of Young’s Regression
column5: and the reggae-influenced rhythms of Olson’s Hazel and Henry Slaughter. It also helps that new member Jim Baljo adds a further layer of laser-like clarity in his dexterous guitar playing. (Baljo replaced Mike Connelly last fall
column6: though Connelly and the other former Wolf Eye
column7: Aaron Dilloway
column8: both contributed to No Answer: Lower Floors). All these factors have pushed Wolf Eyes to a peak of efficient power
column9: where a single sound can ripple tension through the rest of a song.

column1: The most powerful of those sounds are Young’s simple yet maniacally exacting beats. It’s fitting that No Answer: Lower Floors begins with one
column2: tearing open the stereo space before other sounds can move in. His beats are the spine of the music
column3: the compass around which all the other noises align. So while droning chords spark the slow-swinging “Chattering Lead”
column4: the beat pushes them and Young’s deadened moans forward. It’s also what gives the song visceral impact
column5: more so than the band’s tactile sheen. That sheen might make you woozy
column6: but it’s Young’s beats that punch you in the gut.

column1: What they don’t do
column2: though
column3: is push the music toward crashing climaxes. Young has recently talked about keeping the Wolf Eyes sound “realistic
column4: ” and resisting the temptation to jump from zero to ten at every opportunity. The result of this outlook on No Answer: Lower Floors is momentum that’s primarily implicit. Swells are tenuous and elusive
column5: lurking in shadows without ever jolting into the frame. While Wolf Eyes have often used words and images that suggest the shock of slasher films
column6: it’s this haunting aspect of their music that truly evokes scary movies.

column1: Not that No Answer: Lower Floors is all about negative space. The album’s busy soundscape is much more diverse and rounded than that. In places it offers full-on noise-- take the fire-bomb opening of “Born Liar”
column2: or the siren-like wail of “Warning Sign”
column3: not coincidentally the sole track on the album without vocals. But the fact that Wolf Eyes can do both quiet and loud
column4: fast and slow
column5: or frantic and subdued
column6: is no big deal on its own. What matters is the way they make those polar modes seem united and even indistinguishable. Which is yet another reason why something as subdued as “Confession of the Informer” can feel so vital and active.

column1: This ability to connect opposites explains why
column2: even though they’re often associated with the wave of American Noise that rose last decade
column3: Wolf Eyes have always seemed to occupy their own self-made world. Part of that comes from the way they’re constantly generating releases
column4: both as Wolf Eyes proper and under an endless array of side projects and solo ventures. But it’s also because no one else has swung between extremes so deftly
column5: in a way that makes outer edges meet on a curving continuum rather than sitting on far ends of a spectrum. On No Answer: Lower Floors
column6: this fact
column7: like the music itself
column8:
is clearer than ever before.

"|17968.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17968-wolf-eyes-no-answer-lower-floors/|8.2|Marc Masters

It was 3 p.m. and sunny my first time through Implodes' Recurring Dream
column3: a mistake I only let myself make once. Dream
column4: like the Chicago drone-rockers' debut Black Earth before it
column5: is inexorably nocturnal music
column6: dank and oily
column7: suffused with creeping dread. Ever hear of highway hypnosis? You pull into the garage after a long drive only to realize you can't really recall the last several hours of your life? That feeling's all over Recurring Dream
column8: a mesmerizing record with a distinctly sinister edge. Even as you're drawn in by its narcotic murk
column9: you can't quite shake the feeling that something terrible's happened that you just can't quite recall.

column1: From the layers of scum strewn across its every surface to the minutes-before-sunset cover art
column2: Recurring Dream is well acquainted with the darkness. As on Black Earth
column3: Implodes' gloomy vibe is equal parts post-punk disaffection
column4: shoegaze's motion-blur
column5: and the heft of post-rock. Start mining for reference points
column6: and you'll never stop; the Jesus and Mary Chain's Darklands and Jesu's Conqueror made my notes before I realized I'd never make it out of the Js alive. Despite these disparate landmarks
column7: the uniformly sour mood and near-constant drone that runs through just about every second of Recurring Dream gives it a kind of tunnel vision: whether it's the Mogwai-style blowout in ""Ex Mass"" or the early Beach House-on-dilaudid vibe of ""Sleepyheads""
column8: the persistent crackle seems to cast everything in their world in the same sunless hue.

column1: Spend a little time getting acclimated to the darkness
column2: though
column3: and you'll start to see just how many things are moving around back there. Even after a dozen listens or so
column4: these songs still seem to change shape
column5: their haunting echoes and lurking rhythms fluidly rearranging themselves whenever your back's turned. And when they do break from the near-oppressive opacity
column6: you still up and take notice. ""Prisms and the Nature of Light"" refracts an acoustic kumbaya into something stranger
column7: more surreal. And halfway through several of these songs
column8: guitarist Ken Camden takes a solo that burns through the night like the trail of neon in your rear-view. Their brilliance is quickly swallowed up into Recurring Dream's beyond-black coloring
column9: but these rare flashes of light only seem to deepen the engrossing darkness that surrounds them.

column1: On the whole
column2: though
column3: Recurring Dream's a slinkier-sounding record than its predecessor: the songs are more spacious
column4: less prone to snarling
column5: and they've lowered the volume on Black Earth's stuck-between-stations fizz. It's a tradeoff: the more deliberate Dream doesn't move unless it has to
column6: upping the intensity whenever it does. But
column7: for all the tension Recurring Dream builds up over its 45-minute runtime
column8: there's precious little in the way of relief: Black Earth's periodic blowouts served as dread-diffusers
column9: but the foreboding Recurring Dream closer ""Bottom of a Well"" prefers mystery
column10: sending you back off into the night
column11:
disquieted.

"|17822.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17822-inflated-recurring-dream/|6.8|Paul Thompson

The initial plan for Cyclops Reap was to compile the scraps that didn't quite make the last four White Fence LPs. Apparently
column2: Tim Presley has about 40 unreleased songs lying around
column3: which
column4: considering his backlog and work ethic
column5: makes sense. Since 2010
column6: he's released four solo LPs
column7: one collaborative album with Ty Segall
column8: a live cassette
column9: and a handful of singles. And that doesn't even cover his tenure in other bands. His albums are all nearly overcrowded by sonic ideas and psychedelic twists. Even one of his simpler songs
column10: the acoustic track ""Balance Yr Heart"" off Family Perfume Vol. 1
column11: gives the impression that he spliced together two different-but-similar songs that were floating in his head. In just three years
column12: he's managed to poise himself as a prolific artist in a town that runneth over with prolific artists (Segall
column13: Sonny Smith
column14: Thee Oh Sees mastermind and Castle Face head John Dwyer).

column1: While gathering up old stuff for Cyclops Reap
column2: Presley's prolific instincts kicked in: ""there were more coming. a better crop
column3: he wrote in a press release. He wrote more songs
column4: recorded them to the four-track in his bedroom
column5: and scrapped the compilation altogether. The album ends up being a testament to what Presley has learned in terms of home recording: It's his best-sounding and most easily accessible album to date. It still comes packed with less-than-pristine production and some of the psychedelic tics that marked his previous work
column6: but for the most part
column7: these songs are marked by a surprising amount of clarity. For something with such modest origins
column8: this thing sounds at least as good as Hair
column9: which was made in the studio.

column1: And these songs don't ever feel overstuffed. Everything is faithful to White Fence's well-established aesthetic
column2: but simplified. There's no jumping around or writing three melodies when there only needs to be one. It's a refreshingly streamlined record
column3: and more so than his previous work
column4: there's a slight-but-palpable country influence. Presley picks an acoustic guitar
column5: adds the occasional Southern guitar lick
column6: and sings sweet melodies. In places
column7: this thing could pass for a straightforward singer/songwriter album. (An influence that would make sense
column8: seeing as he started his label just to release Jessica Pratt's album.) ""Beat"" and ""Only Man Alive""
column9: for example
column10: are clear of fuzz and psych freakouts. He just delivers beautiful melodies backed by minimal percussion. This isn't to say that Presley's delivering shockingly intimate lyrics-- as usual
column11: they're stories and phrases doused in abstractions and poeticisms. But sometimes
column12: there's a warmth and familiarity in his words: The instrumentals and vocals in ""Live on Genevieve"" might sound cartoonishly warped and bleary
column13: but the sentiment of ""I wanna live on Genevieve Street with you"" feels resonant.

column1: Of course
column2: it's not all cooing and ginger acoustic guitar strumming. He balances the album's softer moments with ""Pink Gorilla""
column3: the beefiest track of the bunch. It's a song slathered in acid-burnt fuzz where Presley stretches out with an echoing psych guitar solo after hammering out a simple
column4: solid power chord hook. The songs here are lovely
column5: but ultimately
column6: this thing needed some heft-- something that keeps the album's airier material from melding together or
column7: worse
column8: floating by completely
column9: and ""Pink Gorilla"" fits the bill. That's one of Presley's greatest strengths as a composer-- he anchors Reap's quieter songs with substantive sonics.

column1: There's only one old song on Cyclops Reap: ""Make Them Dinner at Our Shoes""
column2: which is from 2009. Like every other track on the album
column3: it's masked under a thin layer of hiss. It's hard to tell exactly what he's singing in places-- his vocals are occasionally eaten by his guitar or another sound-- but one phrase is always clear: ""clear open sky."" Those words are backed by bright major chords on an electric guitar and the soft
column4: steady ambiance of a shaker. Like most of White Fence's lyrics
column5: it's unclear what those words are trying to communicate in a literal sense
column6: but packaged the way they are
column7:
the emotional connection is clear.

Ever since Born Ruffians frontman Luke LaLonde introduced his band's self-titled debut in 2006 with the strangled ululations of a pubescent Black Francis
column3: Born Ruffians have adopted a ""play it live first
column4: ask questions later"" approach that could be endearingly sloppy (2008's Red Yellow & Blue) or exasperatingly sophomoric (2010's Say It).

column1: Earlier this year
column2: LaLonde struck out on his own with Rhythymnals
column3: which he worked on with the Rural Alberta Advantage producer Roger Leavens. Besides establishing him as a different kind of mopey singer-songwriter-- the guy that would name his band's next album after his and his girlfriend's matching birthmarks-- the process gave LaLonde production experience that he in turn brought to Birthmarks along with Leavens
column4: and for the first time Born Ruffians recorded songs together in the studio before seeing how they worked onstage. The result
column5: for better or worse
column6: smooths over the ragged edges that made Born Ruffians such a rivetingly unpredictable band in the first place.

column1: A few months ago
column2: LaLonde gave an interview in which he mentioned that Toronto's BoomBox Studios
column3: where Born Ruffians recorded Birthmarks
column4: doubled as a commercial songwriting outlet. ""I think that means that Roger has to be able to adapt to survive
column5: he needs to be able to do whatever they need him to do. If the ad direction is folky and they say they need a 'Mumford and Sons vibe
column6: ' Roger needs to be able to do that well and execute it in a convincing way
column7: he said. It didn't seem to occur to him that might be why so many bands are suing companies for using barely concealed rip-offs of their songs in commercials. At times
column8: Birthmarks seems to come from this place.

column1: This is as much LaLonde's doing as Leavens'; Red Yellow & Blue's ""Little Garcon"" appeared in an American Express commercial in 2011
column2: after all. Regardless
column3: the harmonies on ""Needle"" are libelously close to those of Fleet Foxes
column4: the chorus to ""6-5000"" wouldn't be out of place on A Hundred Miles Off
column5: and ""With Her Shadow"" borrows Vampire Weekend's appropriated bass lines
column6: even if bassist Mitch DeRosier gives them an extra salty twang. Of course musicians borrow from each other all the time-- and the upshot is that LaLonde and his band mates have developed quite a versatile range-- but these hooks stand out from Born Ruffians' emphatically original material
column7: even if their earlier albums could sound homemade to the point of collapse.

column1: But commercial songwriters know what sounds good
column2: and much of Birthmarks is catchy enough to get stuck in your head
column3: if not necessarily memorable enough to stay there. On ""Too Soaked To Break""
column4: the way LaLonde's reverbed voice ripples over keyboardist Andy Lloyd's arpeggios and woodwinds inspires such complacency that you almost don't notice the same flute melody in the chorus of following track ""Dancing on the Edge of Our Graves"". LaLonde isn't too shabby of a pop songwriter himself: after screeching about needing someone to have sex with on Born Ruffians
column5: he disarmed fans with the studied boy-band swagger of ""I always said I'd be your boyfriend
column6: and that's that"" on Rhythymnals' ""Undone"". He works out these newfound romantic inclinations on ""Permanent Hesitation""
column7: awkwardly gushing
column8: ""I am just a lotus/ And you are just a vine/ I am just a gnome/ And you are so divine."" A song later
column9: LaLonde is back to his old ways with ""nothing but lust"" for someone else's girlfriend
column10: so maybe not that much has changed.

column1: It's still too early to say if the same can be said of Born Ruffians. Birthmarks is their most refined release to date
column2: thanks to Leavens and LaLonde's production sensibilities and the addition of Lloyd
column3: all of which helped fill widening cracks in the band's former drums/guitar/vocals setup. While those factors may have stopped Born Ruffians' total disintegration after things started to fall apart on Say It
column4:
they also snuffed out the strung-out charm of three guys constantly on the verge of losing their cool. And that's a loss the band should remember not to take lightly.

"|17908.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17908-born-ruffians-birthmarks/|6.5|Harley Brown

In a well-publicized late 2011 interview
column3: James Blake drew his line in the sand on the Great Dubstep Debates. The boy who fell for the emotional resonance of bone-disintegrating sub-bass only after years of playing piano privately came out against the American version of guys like Skrillex (whom he couldn’t even be bothered naming). Such performers
column4: Blake contended
column5: appealed strictly to a “testosterone-driven
column6: frat-boy market” that couldn’t be more different from the Feist-and-Joni covers and Bon Iver duets pouring out of the Londoner who’d just turned 23. Blake argued that his music was not only more egalitarian-- appealing to women and men equally-- but was also a purer representation of dubstep as an idea. It was a misrepresentation of American dubstep’s audiences and a presumptuous statement about What Women Want
column7: sure
column8: but at the same time
column9: it was hard to fault Blake for forcefully trying to stake his claim to a patch of land within a genre broad enough to incorporate a rave resurgence and a brooding folkie.

column1: Blake’s real argument for the continued relevance of his dewy
column2: electronic gospel-folk comes via his second LP
column3: Overgrown. At a few points on the record
column4: he seems to be demonstrating to the wub fetishists that he’s also capable of sonic mayhem. Whether they’re meant as representations of conflicted emotions or simply designed to get crowds moving
column5: the codas to “Digital Lion” and “Voyeur” are as bass-first and funky as anything Blake’s done to date. The last minute of “Lion”
column6: which credits Brian Eno as collaborator
column7: prominently showcases Blake’s gospel fixation
column8: his wordless vocals present to acknowledge the powerful groove. For its part
column9: “Voyeur” is possibly his most techno-sounding track to date
column10: though you wouldn’t know it from the opening. Blake begins in jazzy repose
column11: dwelling on a short phrase (“and her mind was on me”) over a light piano loop and minimal bass thump. The introduction of a treated cowbell and a 4/4 thump gradually morphs the song into something resembling a club track
column12: similar to Four Tet’s slow-building 2010 banger “Love Cry” or 2011’s simmering
column13: sample-based “Pyramid.”

column1: Overgrown is a showier album than Blake’s eponymous 2011 debut
column2: incorporating more gospel and R&B elements and a wider variety of textures. In a way
column3: it feels like Blake’s meeting himself midway between his LP and EP personas. The string of EPs he released before putting his blurred face and name on the cover of an LP cast Blake as the latest UK producer prodigy
column4: capable of modern classical pieces and tracks built around Aaliyah and Kelis samples. On his first LP
column5: however
column6: Blake opted for the singer-songwriter move
column7: making heart music instead of head music
column8: alienating certain purists while gaining new fans who have zero interest in his work on the Hemlock label.

column1: On Blake’s own admittedly modest terms
column2: Overgrown is marked by extremes. The album starts in the mode of the 2011 LP on which he rued childhood relationships and pondered his dreams. On the title track
column3: he mewls “I don’t want to be a star/ But a stone on the shore
column4: ” confessing he prefers to blend into his surroundings rather than draw attention to himself. For a guy who puts a crisp
column5: pensive photo of himself on his album cover
column6: it’s a questionable stance
column7: and his delivery is self-serious enough to nearly tip over into self-parody. It pales in comparison to James Blake opener “Unluck”
column8: though it’s saved from schmaltz through Blake’s skill at investing even the cheesiest sentiments with a palpable anxiety.

column1: There’s showy
column2: and then there’s “Take a Fall for Me”
column3: a collaboration with RZA
column4: who Blake gives free rein to smear awkward romantic imagery all over his track. It’s easy to understand why the pair would collaborate: their production styles aren’t dissimilar
column5: both showing a fondness for gloomy
column6: bass-heavy soundscapes rooted in R&B. Why RZA was asked to rap
column7: however
column8: is hard to understand. If you want to hear the phrase “tight as the grip of a squid” on a James Blake album
column9: or an American’s stereotype of a proper British meal (fish & chips
column10: Guinness)
column11: you’re in luck. For the rest of us
column12: “Fall” is Blake’s first out-and-out failure
column13: the sort of song that should have been relegated at the very least to bonus track status
column14: and probably should have been kept private altogether.

column1: Overgrown is not as wall-to-wall great as his debut
column2: but fans of the first LP will still find much to admire. The most promising development is his indulged fondness for various permutations of R&B and gospel styles
column3: best evidenced on the album’s great first single “Retrograde.” Self-described as a song about falling in love
column4: it balances the solemn soul of Bill Withers’ “Grandma’s Hands” with periodic bursts of passion
column5: via Blake shouting “suddenly
column6: I’m hit!” Throughout the album
column7: he successfully splits the difference between the sultry bedroom vibes of R&B’s resurgent Quiet Storm moment and the more mundane life of a British “bedroom” artist fond of keeping to himself. “To the Last”
column8: in particular
column9: tiptoes around a Sade-style smooth-soul composition
column10: aided by the synthesized sounds of waves crashing ashore.

column1: Blake’s deconstructive take on R&B is similar in spirit to that of How to Dress Well’s Tom Krell. In a recent interview with Pitchfork TV
column2: Krell explained his writing process as one of locating bodily sensations that haven’t yet shaped themselves into recognizable emotions. Suddenly you’re hit
column3: in other words
column4: but you don’t yet know if that feeling is joy
column5: anxiety
column6: frustration
column7: or terror-- you’re only aware that something’s there
column8: and you try to freeze it
column9: to examine it more closely
column10: instead of simply slotting it in a category and moving on. This is exactly what Blake does so well (and
column11: for what it’s worth
column12: RZA doesn’t): locating these sensations
column13: and conversing about them. On “I Am Sold”
column14: he even manages to explain the process
column15: by mulling a single phrase over and over
column16: tweaking it
column17: and approaching it from different directions: “speculate what we feel.” Instead of worrying about where he fits in a broader musical landscape
column18: or whether he’s a “star” or not
column19: ” this is Blake’s comfort zone. Whether he’s making bass-heavy bangers
column20: quiet meditations
column23:
Blake is a modern master of emotional speculation.

Over the course of their 1997-2004 run
column2: The Beta Band were a model of aggressive
column3: unabashed peculiarity: from their psych-folk/hip-hop hybrids and sound-collage pranksterim to video shoots in inhospitable climes and bizarro stage outfits involving electric-lit space suits and/or sombreros. Melodic linearity and lyrical candour were never at the top of their to-do list
column4: so it was a pleasant surprise that former frontman Steve Mason’s 2010 solo debut
column5: Boys Outside
column6: evinced such a warm
column7: welcoming folk-rock accessibility and emotional directness. After struggling through the Beta Bands’ flagging commercial fortunes and his own public battles with depression
column8: the album essentially functioned as a form of therapy: You got the sense that Mason was not only picking up the pieces of his once-ascendant career
column9: but of his life.

column1: It’s a process he’s still grappling with on Monkey Minds in the Devil’s Time
column2: which opens with Mason in a familiar setting: lying in bed
column3: engaged in the sort of nocturnal self-analysis that results from spending too many restless hours staring at the ceiling. The first words we hear him sing on the fever-dreamy “Lie Awake” are “At 15 years old
column4: I had to know/ What makes you fail
column5: and what makes you grow”
column6: suggesting that even these astute adolescent inklings couldn’t fully prepare him for the rollercoaster course his adult life would take. But if Monkey Minds begins as another intensely introspective exercise
column7: it gradually blossoms into something else entirely: over 20 sprawling but strategically stitched tracks
column8: its temperament veers from solipsistic to altruistic
column9: charting Mason’s transformation from a man too insecure to leave his room
column10: to one who can no longer ignore the injustices transpiring outside his window.

column1: And that progression is as much musical as it is attitudinal. The first half of the album sees Mason revisiting and improving upon the Boys Outside template
column2: bolstering his gently strummed serenades with more pronounced classic-rock flourishes. The chorus-summoning piano refrain of the beautifully aching “A Lot of Love” offers a distant echo of the Band’s “The Weight
column3: ” while the cheekily churchly “Lonely” and “Oh My Lord” sway in the direction of gospel-gilded FM-radio standards like Stephen Stills’ “Love the One You’re With” and the Stones’ “Loving Cup”. But while these songs count as the most winning and instantly anthemic that Mason has produced since the days when his old band was written into the High Fidelty screenplay
column4: they’re buttressed by various cryptic interludes-- narrative spoken-word snippets (“The Old Problem”)
column5: squeaky melodica solos clashing with motorcylce-engine revs (“Flyover ‘98”)
column6: dubby instrumentals overlaid with Portuguese car-race commentary (“The Last of Heroes”)-- that reconnect him with the Beta Band’s exploratory ethos and deep sense of earthy groove.

column1: And as you venture deeper into Monkey Minds
column2: these transitory tracks start to feel less like nonsensical fragments and more as preludes that signal Mason’s restoked sense of swagger and social conscience. In a nod to early Beta Band experiments like “The House Song”
column3: Mason cedes the mic to MC Mystro on “More Money
column4: More Fire”
column5: a synth-shocked rap-rant about the root causes of the incendiary 2011 London riots and police mistreatment of the underclass; the same shuffling beat is immediately repurposed on the subsequent “Fire!”
column6: which channels the preceding song’s righteous indignation into a playful protest chant
column7: buoyed by titanic blasts of brass imported from Primal Scream’s “Loaded.” And the string-spiked “Fight Them Back” is an even more disarming mix of funk and fury
column8: with Mason casually commandeering a palace coup with “a fist
column9: a boot
column10: and a baseball bat
column11: ” topped by a sample of an especially smug Tony Blair quote that’ll inspire the rabble to start getting in their practice swings.

column1: Monkey Minds’ sharp
column2: late-act turn into politicized proselytizing may seem jarring at first
column3: but then it’s an accurate reflection of how politics can suddenly intrude upon our lives and upend our worldview. It often takes something as calamitous as mass
column4: citywide arson to remind the average person that there’s a world of hurt beyond their self-involved concerns. The gorgeous closing lullaby
column5: “Come to Me”
column6: finds Mason right back where he started-- lying in bed-- but it’s not his anxieties that are keeping him awake: “I used to sit alone and watch your cities rise
column7: ” he sings
column8: “It flashed across my mind the murder in your eye.” He could be addressing his prime minister
column9: or God itself
column10: but in any event
column11:
it’s good to know Mason is now losing sleep for the right reasons. 

"|17852.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17852-steve-mason-monkey-minds-in-the-devils-time/|7.9|Stuart Berman

column2: the duo knocked back cocktails in the mid-afternoon while riffing on embarrassing screen names

column4: and

column1: Indeed

column3: say

column11: for a minute

column1: Sepalcure do very well with nightlife crowds of varying pretension
column2: but their debut album's greatest selling point was how well it translated to the home-listening set. Sharma and Stewart inhaled a few different sub-genres of dance and expelled a romantic sound that approached pop (for bass music

column6: individually

column1: Last year

column3: but Stewart and Sharma have suggested that
column4: since the duo is separated by an ocean (Sharma's New York-based
column5: while the somewhat nomadic Stewart currently lives in Berlin)
column6: there's no guarantee of the project becoming a long-term fixation. New EP Make You
column7: then

column9: suggesting that

column1: In addition to re-asserting their presence
column2: Make You confirms that
column3: at this point

It isn't rare for classically trained musicians to cross into indie
column2: but moving the other way is trickier. Icelandic pianist Ólafur Arnalds
column3: a young composer of shadowy
column4: wistful
column5: slow-paced chamber music
column6: is making it work. He began as a teenaged hardcore drummer with an illicit love of classical and film music. His efforts in that vein earned him a solo deal with Erased Tapes
column7: home to likeminded artists such as Peter Broderick. Touring with Sigur Rós raised his public profile
column8: and in recent years
column9: Ólafur has shown signs of breaking free from indie-classical limbo
column10: securing elite commissions (a score for the great choreographer Wayne McGregor) and signing with Mercury Classics
column11: a new classical label that lacks the prestige of Decca or Deutsche Grammophon but adjoins them via parent company Universal. He achieved all this off the conservatory track
column12: which may account for the composer's ample immediacy and wanting complexity alike.

column1: Ólafur works in blacks and whites. His musical atmospheres might be fairly abridged with the images ""night"" and ""snow;"" his releases swing from casual song-a-day EPs to hermetic
column2: formal LPs and back again. The established foundations are intact on For Now I am Winter: the bitterly romantic strings melting over sparsely chorded rows of simple
column3: chiming piano intervals; the faintly dated electronic production nicked from trip-hop and IDM. The album recalls Valgeir Sigurðsson's Architecture of Loss
column4: except with the dense harmonic storminess blown off. But you can certainly hear major label resources at work. Ólafur handles the laptop and keyboard instruments but contracts out a group of strings
column5: winds
column6: and brass from the Iceland Symphony Orchestra; the porcelain voice of Arnór Dan; and orchestral arrangements by Nico Muhly
column7: who reasonably responds to Ólafur’s material with dramatic yet musically cautious accompaniment.

column1: If you crave morose
column2: impressive beauty
column3: it's here. But for a statement on a new classical label
column4: this sounds a lot like a stirring score in search of its ballet or film. There is startlingly little virtuosity written in the compositions
column5: especially in the piano
column6: where it can be hard to distinguish minimalist profundity from undeveloped themes. The strings and winds are more mobile
column7: but Ólafur still keeps his players working through routine harmonic progressions at a pace so stately it's almost robotic.

column1: The biggest change here is the addition of Arnór Dan's vocals on four songs
column2: which like the music are beautiful and pristine to a numbing degree
column3: at least in this low-contrast context. Making his first appearance over a glacial piano and shimmering pads
column4: he sounds like Antony Hegarty evacuated of wildness and swing-- though he does free up as the arrangement flourishes. He turns in some terrific ornaments halfway through ""Old Skin""
column5: a pretty indie-pop tune that sounds like Lost in the Trees with a sultry-chaste dash of Tom Krell. He's a talented guy
column6: and can seem to be addressing his talent more than the listener. Whereas singers you can really feel make their voices a medium something passes through
column7: Dan's voice here is more of a carefully wrought thing unto itself-- a very fine vase on a very high shelf.

column1: This may all sound grimmer than it is. For Now I am Winter is competent
column2: reasonably varied
column3: and efficiently rousing. Muhly effectuates some pleasing motion in the strings and winds. Opening track ""Sudden Throw"" is compelling
column4: and while its intrigue fades in the driving cinematic wallpaper of ""Brim""
column5: that darkly shining sinuousness rises again in ""Only the Winds"". ""Reclaim"" is a dashing highlight
column6: leaving behind airless dirges and minimalist ice sculptures for a welcome dance tempo. But the lingering impression that there's not a lot to grasp emotionally becomes stark in the thinnest tracks. My takeaway from ""Words of Amber"" is that it sounds really nice to pick a winding path through piano scales in a coldly reflective room
column7: while ""We (Too) Shall Rest"" is a funeral dirge without a subject
column8:
a feeling without a focus.

Carter Tanton is a musician's musician. Even though he released a record
column2: Freeclouds
column3: under his own name in 2011
column4: the Baltimore-based producer and guitarist is still primarily known as a recording engineer for Marissa Nadler and Twin Shadow's George Lewis
column5: Jr.
column6: and as a member of Lower Dens. They're Flowers
column7: Tanton's debut as Luxury Liners
column8: is a product of his time on the road. While in transit
column9: he was forced to abandon his original guitar arrangements for the only instrument on hand: a laptop. Rather than bemoan his restrictive circumstances
column10: Tanton ran with them
column11: making an album that feels like a fresh start.

column1: For They're Flowers
column2: Tanton is concerned mostly with deconstruction and stripping things down. Nowhere is this more evident than on album opener ""Caribbean Sunset""
column3: a John Cale cover. Tanton lifts the lyrics verbatim and tangentially follows the chordal progressions from the original
column4: but overall he completely re-imagines the song so that it swoops and shimmer like light reflected off a glitter ball. And it rings truer for the song's exoticized female protagonist than the original's accordion
column5: stilted violin
column6: and a wood block for good measure.

column1: But deconstruction always brings the risk of collapse
column2: and Tanton reaches a few points in They're Flowers where he should have pulled a different piece out of the Jenga tower. His weak spot continues to be lyric-writing
column3: and ""Memphis Alex""
column4: a tribute to Alex Chilton
column5: is filled with insipid rhymes. The lyrics are usually easy to overlook in the face of his mastery of sound
column6: but it can still be frustrating to parse a line
column7: however abstract
column8: like ""one day my prince will come running home"" (""Valley High"").

column1: Over the course of the album
column2: a recurring theme is Tanton's inability to choose between wistful synth-folk or unapologetic retro bombast
column3: or at least how to reconcile the two. He tries on messy album centerpiece ""Life's a Beach""
column4: which features the War On Drugs' Dave Hartley and his solo project Nightlands. The beginning wades through Hartley's voice and slow wind chimes
column5: speeding suddenly into a thicket of keyboard effects before bringing in the Beach Boys harmonies in the background. Between all that
column6: the interlude's sagging keyboards
column7: and the sheer length
column8: there's just too much going on.

column1: Like any self-editor
column2: sometimes Tanton has trouble knowing when to stop
column3: and this makes They're Flowers feel more like a second draft rather than a finished product. He still seems most comfortable crafting other people's material into a cohesive whole in the studio or on the road. With his own
column4: it's telling that the most fully realized

column6:
and now he just needs to figure out how to use it.

In the seven years since Silent Shout
column5: the Knife's mythology has grown to the point where the Swedish duo seem like something other than a band. ""Band” implies people banging on things widely agreed upon as instruments and making things that most people would recognize as ""music""-- this feels like an inadequately pedestrian way to describe what Karin Dreijer Andersson and Olof Dreijer are. Perhaps even more so in their absence
column6: the Knife have come to seem like a vibe
column7: an ethic
column8: a dark
column9: not-entirely-scientifically-understood phenomena; other bands are to the Knife what matter is to anti-matter. When new artists say they’ve been influenced by the Knife-- and it’s a claim countless have made in the past few years-- they are at this point referencing not just a specific sound but an entire way of being in our information-glutted world: a desire to retain a tightly controlled
column10: precisely evocative sense of mystery and mastery over their image. Even in the wake of such pollutants as international success
column11: ubiquitous acclaim
column12: and frequent imitation
column13: the Knife have found a way to keep their name meaning something remarkably unique and pure.

column1: This has something to do with the fact that Andersson and Dreijer have gone to great lengths to come off like they are something other than human. On stage
column2: they were silhouettes glowing behind a translucent screen. They gave interviews and accepted awards in disguise (moving through a terrifying cycle of bird masks
column3: Dystopian Blue Man Group masks
column4: primate-inspired facepaint
column5: and of course who could forget Andersson's infamous melting flesh mask?). And on the steely
column6: electro-nightmare Silent Shout-- their first great record-- they found new ways to viscerally integrate these ideas into their sound
column7: warping and pitch-shifting Andersson’s vocals until they grew androgynous and post-human. Somewhere in the past seven years
column8: the Knife reached that Lynchian status where everything they do is their own
column9: adjectivally specific kind of creepy. The early press photos for their new album
column10: Shaking the Habitual
column11: made an activity as innocent as swinging on playground swings feel forebodingly sinister.

column1: But buying ""post-human"" mythology wholesale has always sold the Knife a little short. After all
column2: what was their breakthrough hit ""Heartbeats"" if not a heavy-breathing declaration of vulnerability? Even Silent Shout cut through the abstraction and found a pulse-- whether it was the strobe-lit dancefloor rhythms of “We Share Our Mothers’ Health” and “Neverland” or the palpitating storytelling of a song like “Forest Families”. The driving force of their music is the interplay between the uncanny and the familiar
column3: though in all the theatricality it's easy to forget the latter. But the early information that trickled out about Shaking the Habitual served as a reminder. We’re so used to experiencing the Knife at a cool
column4: veiled distance that the most shocking things about their return were the ones that seemed uncharacteristically personable: their faces (on full display in the anarchic video for “Full of Fire”)
column5: their fingernails
column6: their smiles (were they actually smiling in that photo?). For all their sinister
column7: shadowy abstraction
column8: the Knife are at their most disarming and affecting when you’re briefly reminded-- and you often are
column9: over the course of their sprawling
column10: magnificent fourth album Shaking the Habitual-- that Andersson and Dreijer are human after all.

column1: Boundary-busting in content and in form
column2: the 2xCD Shaking the Habitual challenges plenty of perceived notions-- about extreme wealth
column3: the patriarchy
column4: the monarchy
column5: environmental degradation
column6: decreasing attention spans (“It's nice to play with people's time these days
column7: ” Andersson says in explanation of the record's marathon length)
column8: and not the least of which the Knife's own identity as a band. The winding

column1: In plenty of ways

column4: dissonant drone pieces-- and one of them has the feel-good title “Fracking Fluid Injection”. But once you surrender to these facts and descend into Shaking the Habitual

column7: seductively uncoiling
column8: meditative grooves (“Raging Lung”) and ambient stretches

Many of the things that might seem off-putting in theory are what make it hang together so well as a front-to-back listen-- the drone pieces are sequenced such that they act as intermissions
column10: though the kind where the air conditioner's at an uncomfortable full blast and the house lights remain
column11: evocatively
column12: dark. Put it on in a room and it snakes in and out of your consciousness

column14: atmospheric vice grip.

column1: Following Andersson and Dreijer down such a labyrinthine rabbit hole would be difficult if they didn’t hook you from the start

column4: calypso-tinged synths

column6: but Andersson brings a physicality to her delivery that muscles the line right off the page: “I’m telling you stories
column7: ” she seethes
column8: until you can almost see the vein bulging in her neck
column9: “Trust meeeee.”

column2: polymorphously perverse industrial throb “Full of Fire” feeds off the heat kindled by the opening track and rides it for a magnificently maniacal nine minutes
column3: while the creaking
column4: evocative “A Cherry on Top” has got to be one most deliciously creepy Knife songs yet-- of course

column8: melon

column10: manipulated voice so overripe it basically wafts decay. She's clearly having fun inhabiting the role of the fat-with-power monarch here

column4: but would a more effective method of shaking the habitual be

column9: fairer

column11: fueled by an unfashionable but profoundly refreshing faith in music's ability to hypnotize

column13: and to liberate-- to become
column14: in Winterson's words
column15:
""the high note that smashes the glass and spills the liquid.""

column2: two others are titled “Tiananmen Square” and “Berlin
column3: It’s All A Mess”

column7: ” Ministry of Love’s neon-lit reveries of insatiable longing and gothic glamour conjure a romantic ideal of their homebase that translates to an outsider who only has bits and pieces of received pop culture wisdom: one that conflates Hollywood flash

column2: even before releasing a full-length

column4: No Doubt
column5: Bloc Party
column6: Garbage

Black Rebel Motorcycle Club’s career hasn’t exactly been distinguished

column1: On the group’s sixth studio effort
