column3: BRMC make the transition from classic-rock pretenders to full-on classic rock. At this point

column1: If only BRMC’s “rock” songs lived up to their rock attitude. The central weakness of Specter at the Feast is rather inexplicable: Its goodness is inversely proportional to its loudness. Given the record’s somber inspiration
column2: it’s understandable that the best tracks are the ballads. “Lullaby” is all heart-tugging jangle and dreamily descending guitar riffs

column1: The obviousness of Specter is forgivable on these songs; even the record’s de rigueur Spiritualized rip-off
column2: “Sometimes the Light”
column3: carries the weight of real grief. Where the record falters is on the rockers
column4: which are composed of clichés and exhausted riffs only. The record’s saggy middle section is absolutely murder in this regard: The rubbery basslines

(Specter supposedly was a planned double-LP; it really should be an EP.) What hurts Specter ultimately is that this band can’t get out of its own way. The requirements of making another rockin’ BRMC album choke what could’ve been an affecting
column6:
low-key detour. BRMC has experience on its side; if only it also had a little wisdom to share.

column2: “Anxiety’s Door”
column3: flows along a programmed dance rhythm for upwards of seven minutes
column4: swapping in swatches of acoustic and electric guitars between Cox’s plaintive hoots. The song is memorable
column5: in part
column6: because its arrangement is eerily familiar
column7: an echo of the Smiths' “The Headmaster Ritual”
column8: embellished with heaps of psychic jewelry. The title track is looser
column9: weirder
column10: and longer
column11: with Cox competing against blaring saxophones and washes of white noise for sonic real estate. The shrill sounds and long duration (10-minutes) make the song a more demanding listen than “Anxiety's Door”
column12: but it's also a more complete display of the band's weird chemistry. Merchandise's take on pop works with extremes-- tweaking out hardcore kids with fey vocals and ethereal audio gook and then blasting the tamer ears with hi-frequency screeching.

column1: It's only when the tempos start to slow down
column2: like on the ambient ballad ""I'll Be Gone""
column3: that the LP drags a little. There are still plenty of places for Cox to hide in Merchandise's music-- delay swells
column4: blasts of noise
column5: bottomless reservoirs of reverb-- he just never takes the opportunity. However
column6: when the music gears down
column7: he could stand to step a little further into the background.

column1: In interviews
column2: the members of Merchandise-- Cox and guitarist Dave Vassalotti in particular-- have laid out an earnest
column3: if sometimes convoluted
column4: series of principles that guide their music making. When they can
column5: they prefer to play non-traditional venues. They are heavily devoted to their local music community and suspicious of the business practices of larger independent labels. Children of Desire was a well-loved record and
column6: had the band been interested
column7: a more mainstream-minded imprint might have stepped up to release Totale Nite. But so far
column8: they've made good on their ambitions to stay off of the indie-rock cowpath.

column1: Though Merchandise’s music is sonically distant from the band's hardcore pedigree
column2: it places a similar premium on the projection of honesty and unguarded emotions. On Totale Nite
column3: they manage to use small-scale elements-- jangling guitars
column4: cheapo drum machines
column5:
toy keyboards-- to project the urgency of bands with louder screams and bigger amps.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19052/homepage_large.979b3251.jpg|Cold|28709.0|James Ferraro|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippos in Tanks']|2013-04-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:27.604998|"

James Ferraro has become one of the most divisive artists in underground music
column2: although he didn't start out that way. Ferraro has released an extraordinary amount of material since 2004
column3: but you can divide his career into two parts
column4: with 2011's solo album Far Side Virtual as the turning point. As half of noise and drone duo the Skaters and altered tape constructivists Lamborghini Crystal
column5: he enjoyed wide acclaim
column6: but Far Side Virtual saw him equally dismissed as a charlatan and lauded as a visionary.

column1: Talking about FSV in an interview with The Wire
column2: Ferraro called it “an opera for our consumption civilization.” In his work since
column3: it became apparent that Ferraro's interest in the representation of capitalism coincided with a preoccupation with some of its most prestigious and powerful manifestations: namely modern hip-hop. Inhale C-4 $$$$$$$
column4: a mixtape released under the alias Bebetune$ that swiftly followed FSV
column5: and Silica Gel
column6: released in 2012 as Bodyguard
column7: made this clear. By the time Ferraro got to Sushi at the end of 2012
column8: a physical release under his own name
column9: the shapeshift was complete. He had reached a unique and beguiling electronic body music heavily informed by commercial R&B and hip-hop
column10: but somehow contained in his own distroid soundworld.

column1: With new mixtape Cold
column2: that restless creativity remains in forward motion. Ferraro's consistency lies mostly in his ability to confound
column3: a disconnect of simultaneous banality and profundity that has threaded through his output more clearly than any allegiance to a particular sound or genre. For example
column4: one of the most obvious shifts on Cold is his singing. It's on almost every track-- you can't have R&B without it
column5: right? He still doesn't sing very well
column6: but while occasionally painful
column7: the Auto-Tuned balladry is fascinating in its oddness. This style of vocal is almost always reserved for professionals
column8: and hearing Ferraro's amateur but earnest attempts are endearing. Not unlike his pre-FSV solo period when he made an aesthetic out of the hyper-compressed sound of poor bitrate mp3s
column9: it's almost as if he gets a kick out of doing things he knows he shouldn't
column10: upending clearly defined and accepted notions of taste.

column1: The production
column2: on the other hand
column3: is accomplished-- and unusual. One pleasure of the record is the moments where his instinctive
column4: unquantized
column5: sensual funk materializes. Another is in its weird samples: a single coin falling to the floor
column6: what sounds like a sword being drawn from a scabbard
column7: the muffled unintelligibility of distorted voices in the background
column8: digital rain-- all of those appear on “Slave to the Rain”
column9: topped by lyrics like
column10: “Wanna have babies/ And you shower them in cash.” Some might be tempted to compare it to the tongue-in-cheek pop of HD Boyz
column11: but that would be unfair: that Dis Magazine-fueled project was never sincere
column12: and featured experimental artists aping the mainstream. But here this essentially experimental artist clearly manifests mainstream influences.

column1: If the text on the press release for this mixtape (“Cold is the repetition and consumption of hedonism that cannot represent or replace one night of love... Cold outlines the human drama in a nihilistic era."") is taken at face value
column2: Ferraro is still pondering the affect of capitalism. But his interests have been redirected musically
column3: and he touches on the restless groove of two-step
column4: bass swells of dubstep
column5: the tightly sequenced synths of techno
column6: dive-bar lounge blues
column7: and symphonic string arrangements. And while he doesn't really flaunt the vaporwave sound he practically gave birth to with FSV
column8: he does acknowledge it
column9: even going so far as to call a song “Vapor Weight”. But the point with James Ferraro isn't so much that he's constantly switching genres. It's more that he's actually inventing them as he goes along
column10: or changing them so much they become reinvented. Hypnagogic pop
column11: vaporwave
column12: distroid-- he's had a crucial role in them all. Within his sphere
column13: Ferraro is one of the most important artists of his generation though
column14: as Cold demonstrates
column15:
it's hard to get a handle on his career from any single release.

"|17858.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17858-james-ferraro-cold/|7.2|Lisa Blanning

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19130/homepage_large.0e5c84a1.jpg|Victim of Love|29876.0|Charles Bradley|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dunham']|2013-04-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:28.097931|"

With a roster that has boasted singers like Sharon Jones
column2: Lee Fields
column3: Naomi Shelton and the sadly departed Joseph Henry
column4: Brooklyn-based label Daptone Records have forged their retro soul ethos for a decade now with a very calculated method: correcting history’s mistakes by signing aging soul starlets who have fallen through the cracks of time. So how label co-founder Gabriel Roth must have fussed when he came across Charles Bradley
column5: a James Brown impersonator with a harrowing backstory. Enduring homelessness
column6: extreme illness and the murder of his brother (all of which are outlined in the festival circuit documentary Charles Bradley: Soul of America)
column7: Bradley came with a marketable narrative and a dynamic stage presence. Most importantly
column8: his voice gives Daptone’s house musicians a leading man who can channel not just Brown
column9: but Otis Redding
column10: Al Green
column11: and Teddy Pendergrass to boot.

column1: To both Bradley and Daptone’s credit
column2: the singer’s first album
column3: <i>No Time for Dreaming
column4: didn't cash in on his distressing life story
column5: but world-weariness did seep into his songwriting. It was as though harsh life lessons had taught Bradley not to expect a great deal from his apparent ""big break."" The love songs weren’t so much passionate romantic odes as they were desperate declarations of reliance
column6: while the record’s marquee song
column7: “Why Is It So Hard”
column8: offered a cold flipside to the American dream. But what a voice. This wasn’t revivalism for revivalisms sake (a sneer sometimes made at Daptone)
column9: but a collection of songs sung with earnestness and authority that it trumped any such criticism.

column1: Two years on
column2: Victim of Love is a more optimistic record
column3: from the Motown-inspired catchy pop-soul number “You Put the Flame on It” to the gorgeous “Through the Storm”
column4: a quiet elegy to bury his past traumas. But these fuzzy moments are offset by new forays into more coarse instrumentation. “You Put the Fame on It” aside
column5: producer Thomas Brenneck pushes his artist from the 1960s into more 70s R&B than he’s previously been accustomed to. Think Curtis Mayfield’s transition from the swinging doo-wop of the Impressions to his solo
column6: psychedelic blues of the early 70s. “Hurricane” trods much the same path as “Freddy’s Dead”
column7: albeit replacing Mayfield’s drugged out nightmare with an environmental warning
column8: while his handprint is all over the sizzling funk workout “Confusion”. Elsewhere
column9: “Strictly Reserved For You” could easily slide into Al Green’s golden 1972-1975 run
column10: and the chipped guitar lines that recall his great collaborator “Teenie” Hodges are matched with some fuzzy Sly Stone-esque axe.

column1: But Victim of Love is ultimately a less successful record than No Time for Dreaming. For one
column2: Bradley seems less connected with this set. “Love Bug Blues” offers him some blaxplotiation-style cool to ride on-- all nasty guitar lines
column3: fluttering jazz flutes
column4: and forceful horn stabs-- but the lyrics uncomfortably cast him as a horny singleton who has caught glimpse of a potential new conquest. His major flaw
column5: however
column6: has been and continues to be his lack of ability to interact with his band. At times
column7: like on overwrought ballad “Let Love Stand a Chance""
column8: he sounds completely detached from what’s going on around him
column9: as if he cut his vocal a capella in studio far away from his collaborators. This isn’t helped by Brenneck
column10: who turns Bradley’s voice way up in the mix. Considering the singer’s sheer power it’s sometimes an imbalance. For example
column11: the title track is a bare acoustic jam only backed up with some soft background “oohs” and “ahs”
column12: yet Bradley attacks the arrangement with full speed gusto and his potent voice begins to overwhelm.

column1: These blemishes underline that Bradley is still something of a novice to professional recording and requires guidance to funnel his talents onto wax. That’s the job of Brenneck and the Daptone hierarchy
column2: who are probably calling the shots when it comes to his evolving sound. But Bradley has a rare gift of being a singer worth hearing regardless of the material
column3:
and this alone is worth the price of admission.

"|17936.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17936-charles-bradley-victim-of-love/|6.8|Dean Van Nguyen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19058/homepage_large.0e6956de.jpg|I Hear a New World|31165.0|Joe Meek|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['PoppyDisc']|2013-04-05 00:00:00|1960|2016-06-11 16:59:29.937078|"

When the Soviet Union launched a 180 lb. sphere named Sputnik 1 into orbit in October 1957
column2: it sparked dramatic paradigm shifts in technological and scientific research-- not to mention in militaristic
column3: political
column4: and societal paranoia-- in both Eastern and Western blocs. In 1955
column5: button-down American composers like Walter Schumann and Art Ferrante and Lou Teicher were already astral-projecting the sounds of Earth onto space
column6: the former via strange chorale compositions
column7: the latter via John Cage’s prepared piano tones. But post-Sputnik
column8: musical minds achieved their own sort of lift-off: Juan Garcia Esquivel’s exotica miniatures evolved into space age bachelor pad music and the sparkling piano jazz compositions of Chicago-based pianist Herman Blount were credited instead to his Saturn-based alter ego
column9: Sun Ra. And in London
column10: an audio engineer named Joe Meek heard a new world.

column1: By the time Sputnik touched outer space
column2: Meek had already ascended to the top of the charts. According to Barry Cleveland’s book Joe Meek’s Bold Techniques
column3: Meek was the first UK producer to deploy overdubbing
column4: compression
column5: spring reverb
column6: flange
column7: and tape loops to studio recordings. Yet due to his schizophrenic nature
column8: business fall-outs and fights led to Meek recording in his own flat rather than a professional studio
column9: where his eccentric ways began to deepen. Inspired by the day’s headlines
column10: Meek began to conceive of a concept album “to create a picture in music of what could be up there in outer space.” And yet how to evoke the alien and the unknown with only terrestrial instrumentation rendered by humans?

column1: That the sound of a strange sonic world was created from the basic building blocks of a hack skiffle band recorded in his home studio
column2: remains as remarkable a feat as your deadbeat roommate sending a rocket made out of beer cans to the moon. Legend has it that Meek used everything lying about
column3: even the proverbial kitchen sink
column4: recording and rendering the sound of blowing bubbles with a straw
column5: using milk bottles as percussion and a draining sink to capture some of these sounds. There are few 20th century musical genres as odious as skiffle
column6: but Meek set about deconstructing such pap: Traces of things like Hawaiian lap steel
column7: tacky pianos
column8: stiff drumming
column9: maracas
column10: wordless vocal harmonizing
column11: and country guitar licks abound
column12: yet Meek makes the quotidian sound extraterrestrial.

column1: Rather than record all the performers playing together in real time as was de rigueur of the era
column2: Joe Meek isolated instrumentation and treated everything from guitars to voices to a battery of echo
column3: reverb
column4: and other homemade electronic noise-making devices
column5: distorting and distending sound until something strange and new was achieved
column6: his end results much more than the sum of its parts. I Hear a New World remains the paragon for such producer-made music (think dub reggae
column7: Brian Eno
column8: Timbaland
column9: etc.)
column10: nevermind that it was barely heard within that era or in Meek’s lifetime. Originally conceived as a demonstration of stereo sound in the mono era
column11: an EP in an edition of 99 copies circulated in 1960
column12: while a second EP had sleeves printed
column13: but no music. Only in the grunge era (1991) did a fully-formed version of I Hear a New World come to earth.

column1: Twenty plus years after first hearing it
column2: via this vinyl reissue
column3: I Hear a New World still sounds surreal
column4: an alternate universe that infiltrated our own. The opening title track remains a strange hybrid
column5: a pop confection with exotica backdrop
column6: yet with the croon of singer Rod Freeman overlaid with sped-up harmonizing vocals. Yes
column7: the seeds of future pop juggernauts like Alvin and the Chipmunks and Kanye West lie within this world. One can also hear the sort of musical mischief and awe-inspiring noises concocted by the likes of Nurse With Wound’s Steve Stapleton
column8: Stereolab
column9: and St. Etienne
column10: as well as folks who later on covered the title track
column11: like Television Personalities and They Might Be Giants. The gurgling noises that open “Entry Of The Globbots” could easily come from 21st century laptop musicians
column12: even if it does devolve into martial drums and more of those damned chipmunk chortles. Same goes for the crunching noise that turns into a pedal-steel ditty
column13: “Magnetic Field”.

column1: While there was bright moment of pop success in a Meek-produced novelty to come in 1962’s hit “Telstar”
column2: the rest of Meek’s life was tragic
column3: ultimately coming to an end in 1967 when he murdered his landlady with a shotgun and then turned the barrel upon himself. By then he had already cussed out fellow producer Phil Spector
column4: accused a record label of planting microphones in his wallpaper to steal his ideas
column5: and turned down the opportunities to work with a then-unknown David Bowie
column6: the Beatles
column7: and Rod Stewart. And yet the notion of the bedroom producer was born in that flat off Holloway Road
column8: a quirky cosmic yet personal sound that flows through the likes of Sir Paul McCartney (circa McCartney II)
column9: Aphex Twin
column10: Burial
column11: et al.
column12:
all of them releasing a similar sort of music that harkens back to this strange new world.

"|17864.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17864-joe-meek-i-hear-a-new-world/|8.3|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19096/homepage_large.890b98a4.jpg|Caveman|29866.0|Caveman|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2013-04-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:30.553876|"

Since forming in 2010
column2: the New York five-piece Caveman have been slowly garnering attention for their loose
column3: deceptively expansive indie-folk rock. Their music carries both a professional air and world-weary rasp
column4: an impression that’s borne out of the group’s credentials
column5: and overlapping lives
column6: as journeyman veterans of NYC’s massive music scene for the better part a decade. The genesis for Caveman was catalyzed by the almost synchronized dissolutions of its member’s former bands
column7: remembered now only with ghostly MySpace portals: The Subjects (lead singer/multi-instrumentalist Matthew Iwanusa and guitarist Jimmy “Cobra” Carbonetti)
column8: White Clam (keyboardist Sam Hopkins)
column9: The End of the World (drummer Stefan Marolachakis)
column10: and Elefant (bassist Jeff Berrall).

column1: They watched their former musical projects run their course and run out of steam
column2: and slowly drifted toward each other as friends hanging out in Carbonetti’s custom guitar shop in the East Village
column3: eventually realizing they wanted to get on with it as a band. They self-released their debut CoCo Beware in 2011 and toured behind an album of competent indie folk with weird proggy flourishes and surprisingly tight four-part harmonies. It was tentative in some instances and looser in others; more of an early blueprint than anything else. CoCo was then snatched up by Fat Possum
column4: and when the band found themselves ready to put together their self-titled sophomore release
column5: they were armed with the chemistry built from sharing a stage for two straight years.

column1: Holed up in Iwanusa’s grandmother’s New Hampshire barnhouse
column2: they began to work through ideas in long jam sessions
column3: cultivating and tweaking a folksy post-rock template that’s reliant on nuanced interplay between the band members. The result is Caveman
column4: a sophomore album that embraces the spacey expanses and mournful
column5: low-key melodies only hinted at on their debut. Gone is the straightforward thump of songs like “My Time” or the placid alt-country of “Old Friend”
column6: replaced by stranger
column7: more confident experiments like the lurching
column8: ethereal “Over My Head” or the Nebraska-echoing “I See You”.

column1: The group hasn’t rebuilt their aesthetic completely
column2: but they are changing the way they communicate it
column3: and the way they communicate with each other from song to song. Their rich
column4: Brian Wilson harmonies are deployed in unexpected places
column5: and are more haunting and reserved than uplifting. “Where’s the Time”
column6: a bass line gurgling
column7: syncopated slow burn that eventually blossoms into a cacophony of ambient textures and a psyched-up guitar solo
column8: uses those harmonies to underline a chorus that’s oddly selfish and detached: “Where’s the time to waste on someone else’s life.” The fragile
column9: atmospheric folk of opener “Strange to Suffer”
column10: and it’s album closing counterpart “Strange”
column11: has the group harmonizing with almost-falsettos in a way that resembles chanting monks attempting a seance
column12: repeating the song’s only line just twice: “Strange to suffer
column13: why do these people turn away.”

column1: But for all those instances of heady explorations
column2: there’s a lingering feeling that they are still hesitant to really kick down the doors of their songwriting confinements. A track like “Pricey""
column3: with that incredible
column4: stalking guitar riff that could have been teleported here from Pink Floyd’s Meddle
column5: tries to be a dark
column6: prog-inflected opus
column7: but lurches around listlessly with pedestrian vocal parts from the usually stellar Iwanusa. Likewise
column8: the brightly colored neon of more widely used synthesizers doesn’t always gel effectively with band’s usually sterling
column9: rock-based musicianship
column10: propelling some tracks to the stratosphere-- the gliding luxury of “In the City”
column11: for example-- while leaving others with a garish accent mark (“The Big Push”) on an already drab composition.

column1: Regardless
column2: Caveman isn’t short on efforts to move the band’s sound into uncharted territories. It's the first release for the band as an “all in” musical endeavor and it definitely feels that way. In an age where so many group’s are driven by a sole songwriter/creative force
column3: it’s exhilarating to hear an album that’s almost stubbornly democratic
column4:
the confidence that the members of Caveman possess in one another being their most prized asset.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19001/homepage_large.840338d0.jpg|The Terror|1504.0|The Flaming Lips|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bella Union'
column2:
'Warner Bros.']|2013-04-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:31.075931|"

When Wayne Coyne opened The Flaming Lips’ 2004 Coachella set by crowd-surfing in a giant inflatible bubble
column3: it represented more than just another gimmick to add to the band’s ever-increasing arsenal of theatrical parlour tricks. It effectively split the Flaming Lips into two bands. On the one hand
column4: you have the merry pranksters that have remained a constant in music-new feeds for the past decade
column5: whether they’re doing rails with Ke$ha
column6: beefing with Erykah Badu
column7: or taking the concept of a physical album release to literal extremes. And then the other
column8: you have a band that
column9: over the past few years
column10: has entered the most fiercely experimental
column11: stridently anti-pop phase of its long and storied career. It’s just that the former aspect inevitably overshadows the latter-- even on the tours for 2009’s dark
column12: disorienting Embryonic
column13: volcanic salvos like “Worm Mountain” and “See the Leaves” simply got subsumed into the Lips’ usual onstage circus and became the backing soundtrack to more bunny-costume dances.

column1: But with The Terror
column2: the Lips take the bold step of bursting their own bubble. The band’s unrelentlingly bleak new album relates to its predecessor much as Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots did to The Soft Bulletin
column3: retaining its antecedent’s weighty mood but deconstructing the instrumental bombast into more skeletal
column4: mechanical forms. For all its claustrophobic tension
column5: Embryonic still offered much in the way of thunderous rock catharsis; The Terror presents no such salve
column6: drowning its meditative
column7: melancholic melodies in a suffocating
column8: smoggy haze of buzzing synth frequencies
column9: with little rhythmic release. The first song may be called “Look… The Sun is Rising”
column10: but it’s less cheery proclamation than grave warning
column11: its stuttering drum beat and dentist-drill shocks conjuring ominous images of a not-too-distant future where the mere act of going outside will require the use of a gas mask and protective suit.

column1: Tellingly
column2: The Terror has resulted in a complete rethink of the Lips’ stage spectacle
column3: one designed to disorient rather than delight. Last month at South by Southwest
column4: the band previewed the album in its entirety at Austin’s Auditorium Shores with a set-up that deemphasized Coyne’s usual carnival-barker cheerleading in favour of an all-out video-screen sensory assault (and random acts of hair-pulling)
column5: the singer held in place by a custom-made synthesizer molded into a baby doll sprouting massive tentacles that extended to the stage’s backdrop. Naturally
column6: a set of unfamiliar
column7: unremittingly gloomy material didn’t make for ideal Friday-night entertainment for many of the 30
column8: 000 in attendance
column9: but Coyne’s static position onstage is a fitting visual metaphor for his performance on the record.

column1: Where Embryonic played on themes of environmental destruction
column2: The Terror deals in more personal turmoil-- loneliness
column3: depression
column4: anxiety. (Perhaps not coincidentally
column5: the album was preceded by news of Coyne’s separation from his partner of 25 years
column6: Michelle
column7: and of multi-instrumentalist Steven Drozd relapsing temporarily.) Accordingly
column8: Coyne spends the record singing like someone who’s strapped to a hospital bed
column9: often resorting to a cautious sing-speak or fragile falsetto as if too beaten down to muster up the strength for anything more. (Or maybe it’s a vocal-eroding side effect of being the most chatty
column10: gregarious frontman in rock.) Even when unleashing an invective like “You’ve got a lot of nerve/ A lot of nerve to fuck with me
column11: ” his voice remains eerily emotionless
column12: relying on duet partner du jour Sarah Barthel of Phantogram to give the line extra bite.

column1: In light of Coyne’s more muted presence here
column2: the real drama on The Terror stems from the way in which the Lips layer their tones and drones into heady
column3: hypnotic surges. The Terror may be the Flaming Lips' most demanding album to date
column4: but it’s also the most sonically of a piece
column5: immediately thrusting you into its dense miasma and seamlessly dissolving one track into one another; in the transition from the despairing “You Are Alone” into the spectacular percussive procession “Butterfly
column6: How Long It Takes to Die”
column7: you hear the same quiet-to-clamor fluidity that Liars mastered on Drum’s Not Dead. And from the desolate post-apocalyptic atmosphere
column8: some powerfully affecting moments emerge
column9: like “Try to Explain”
column10: a beautifully bruised break-up ballad that romanticizes the past while defeatedly acknowledging that things will never be the same.

column1: But if The Terror presents a distillation and refinement of ideas initially explored on their post-Embryonic interim releases-- like last year’s Heady Fwends collaborations and their infamous hours-long jams-- it still feels underdeveloped in spots. At 13 minutes
column2: centerpiece track “You Lust” is the longest song to appear on a proper Lips record since the 1980s
column3: and a companion piece to Embryonic’s “Powerless”
column4: using a coolly repetitive organ refrain as the foundation for an agitated
column5: free-form synth freakout. But its imposing grandeur is diffused by an intrusive
column6: creepily whispered chorus incantation and a drifting
column7: protracted denouement that lingers for far too long. And in the wake of the absorbing
column8: slow-roiling intensity of the penultimate “Turning Violent”
column9: the closing “Always There... In Our Heart” (a bookend echo of “Look… The Sun Is Rising”) doesn’t quite deliver the blown-out grand finale its repeated 1-2-3-4 build-ups suggest
column10: instead simmering down before reaching full blast. (Seemingly aware of this anti-climax
column11: the band tack on the incongruently cheery Hyundai-ad jingle “Sun Blows Up Today” and an Edward Sharpe-assisted cover of ""All You Need Is Love"" as bonus tracks
column12: a move that feels not unlike appending a gag outtakes reel to a film’s closing credits.) But even if it doesn’t consistently exhilarate to the same extent as the band’s most totemic works
column13: The Terror is nonetheless a significant work in their voluminous canon: By matching their ever-evolving
column14: exploratory musical ethos with less eager-to-please
column15: more confrontational modes of performance
column16:
the album marks the moment when the Flaming Lips become whole again.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19024/homepage_large.ee6c9f7e.jpg|rkives|3575.0|Rilo Kiley|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Little Record Company']|2013-04-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:31.564398|"

There was a time not so long ago when social-media platforms didn’t track their members’ every move and stow the information in a steel lock-box for all of eternity. The proto-blog platform Livejournal
column2: for instance
column3: is a ghost town today. Try to revisit a deleted past life there and you’ll likely be confronted with a crying goat informing you that the account
column4: and all of its entries
column5: have been capital-P purged. Never to be recovered. Resurrecting those pages would mean unearthing legions of fans of the Los Angeles indie-folk band Rilo Kiley
column6: whose final album was released in 2007. Rilo Kiley's frontwoman and former child star Jenny Lewis was
column7: to my memory
column8: a spiritual guide for one subset of the Livejournal community
column9: who'd plaster her lyrics on their entries and profile pages with Belieber-like devotion. I think of Rilo Kiley and Livejournal the way some people think of Tila Tequila and MySpace.

column1: Traces of that intense Rilo Kiley fandom pop up in unexpected places today. Like the arm of Waxahatchee’s Katie Crutchfield
column2: which is inked with the glum charcoal drawing found on the cover of the band’s 2002 album The Execution of All Things. “I’ve listened to that record so many times. [Jenny Lewis] was a perfect influence then
column3: ” Crutchfield said in a recent interview. “Rilo Kiley is obviously an indie rock band
column4: but she sings like a real singer
column5: which is how I always tried to sing
column6: too.” Rilo Kiley stopped making music in 2007
column7: and the memory of their heyday has faded to a dull flicker. But Jenny Lewis can be found in the DNA of many millennial musicians-- women in particular-- making confessional indie-rock today. When Crutchfield sings: “I don’t care if I’m too young to be unhappy
column8: ” you might think of the former child star
column9: who told the world at age 25: “You say I choose sadness/ That it never once has chosen me/ Maybe you’re right.” Exploring old-but-new Rilo Kiley material can feel like connecting vital dots in recent history.

column1: There is no shortage of unheard Rilo Kiley material out there: Sennett and Lewis reportedly wrote 60 songs together in the late 90s
column2: before they even formed a band or a romantic relationship. rkives is a full-sounding collection that reads like a long-lost Rilo Kiley album from the early-2000s
column3: a fact that will satisfy the many fans maddened by their late-career stab at the mainstream
column4: Under the Blacklight. The archive
column5: which is out on bassist Pierre de Reeder’s tiny label
column6: tells a story of the group before Lewis got an expensive haircut
column7: before their music played in scenes of “Gossip Girl” and “Grey’s Anatomy”
column8: before they signed to Warner Bros.
column9: before Ben Gibbard and Zooey Deschanel broke up (or even met). Before we collectively shuttered our Livejournals. The only thing that jolts you back into present-day is rapper Too $hort’s voice on a remix of the strident dance-pop track “Dejalo”
column10: from Under the Blacklight. It's an outlier
column11: and a reminder that newly recorded Rilo Kiley music is exciting in theory but would probably be peculiar and unlistenable in practice.

column1: The majority of the 16 tracks have never been heard before
column2: but their tone will feel familiar. “All the trips that take you there/ All the little white pills that you take will get you there/ All the compliments that you take
column3: they will get you there
column4: ” Lewis reels off (she often narrates her woes in lists) on “It’ll Get You There”
column5: a song that could very well serve as the companion piece to the beloved 2002 depressive anthem “A Better Son/Daughter”. There’s enough screaming and argyle-sweater sadness to date Rilo Kiley as an occasional emo band
column6: but plenty of twang to reinforce the bridge they built to indie-folk land. There are uneasy love letters to Los Angeles that sound like they were composed in Nashville
column7: and housewifely misery of Betty Draper proportions (“No one escapes their liiii-iiiifffee!”
column8: small children chant on “American Wife”.) There is Jenny Lewis
column9: just as you remember her.

column1: And there is Blake Sennett
column2: guitarist and subject of many of Lewis’s doleful lyrics
column3: just as you remember him. Lewis told <a href=""http://books.google.com/books?id=mCQFHMhVuA8C&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=%22I%E2%80%99m+going+to+get+him+with+these+lyrics
column4: +and+he%E2%80%99s+not+going+to+know%22&source=bl&ots=f5TKm5h6D8&sig=2V0NtNEc-xH1P1SPJXYUXQx2_Ys&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2F9cUY2JDIXk4APD3YGABw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22I%E2%80%99m%20going%20to%20get%20him%20with%20these%20lyrics%2C%20and%20he%E2%80%99s%20not%20going%20to%20know%22&f=false"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">SPIN in 2007 that after the pair split six years earlier
column5: she’d thought to herself: ""I’m going to get him with these lyrics
column6: and he’s not going to know. It will be a little secret every night on the road."" Sennett eventually took on a reputation-- unfairly
column7: perhaps-- as a wet blanket of a sideman
column8: preoccupied with his own creative ambitions and bitter about the division of attention among the band’s members. He eventually pulled the plug on the group after their ill-fated final record
column9: explaining later in an interview that he’d ""felt like there was a lot of deception
column10: disloyalty
column11: greed”... things he “didn’t want to submit himself to.” Lewis’ (albeit minor) success as a solo artist likely salted the wound. “She’s meteoric and I’m... mediocre?” Sennett once confessed. He wasn’t wrong.

column1: That whimpering persona translates especially harshly on rkives
column2: which features a handful of tracks he sung. It's almost as though those songs
column3: like the limp relationship post-mortem “Well
column4: You Left”
column5: were added to the collection to show how uniquely appealing Lewis was
column6: to underscore her role as the heart and soul of the project. His voice is deeply
column7: painfully unlikeable. In many ways
column8: the gulf between Lewis and Sennett has become the gulf between Lewis and many of her most adored indie-folk classmates
column9: whose music can sound meek or stale in retrospect. Next to Sennett’s crude whine
column10: Colin Meloy’s overwrought attempts at poeticism
column11: Ben Gibbard’s pallidness or Conor Oberst’s drunken antics
column12: Lewis’ pain sounds downright lovely
column13: her despair dignified.

column1: Lewis’ pain and despair have always been unique forces
column2: packaged in cunning ways. Six years removed from the band’s last proper studio album
column3: rkives is a lens that magnifies the darkness of Rilo Kiley’s catalogue. Like their debut Take Offs and Landings and its follow-up The Execution of All Things
column4: the collection relies on deceptively precious instrumentation and cutesy pop-folk hues to mask-- but ultimately
column5: to highlight-- the sinister core of the lyrics. “The Frug”
column6: a beloved early recording that appeared in a Christina Ricci movie
column7: is perhaps the most darling Rilo Kiley have ever sounded-- but it’s a depressive tale masquerading as a cutesy dance diddy. “I can take my clothes off/ I cannot fall in love/ You’ll never see my eyes
column8: ” she says
column9: once again with the lists. “I cannot do the smurf/ I cannot fall in love/ I’ll never fall in love.” Rilo Kiley songs are often like Edward Gorey stories-- they’re aesthetically dainty enough for children
column10: but someone always dies tragically or has her heart broken at the end of the day. It's an appealing dichotomy that carved out a special niche for the band: Jenny Lewis proved that you can be a female singer-songwriter in the brutal
column11: self-lacerating tradition of Liz Phair or Fiona Apple and an avatar for the arts-and-crafty Urban Outfitters set at the same time.

column1: Sound familiar? Today the burden of that dichotomy sits most squarely on the shoulders of Best Coast's Bethany Cosentino
column2: an artist openly indebted to the music of Rilo Kiley. When Best Coast's music began to circulate in 2009 and 2010
column3: it sounded uncannily familar-- like the lovelorn Los Angeles ballads of a girl whose music I'd learned about through Livejournal. It turned out I'd been listening to Cosentino since our respective high school days
column4: when she'd upload acoustic tracks under the name Bethany Sharayah. I liked it because it sounded like Rilo Kiley. ""When I grow up I know that I will be something special/ And the people will know my face/ And call me by my legal name
column5: she sung on one called ""The War of Copy""
column6: mapping out her own trajectory. Cosentino
column7: I learned
column8: never deleted her Livejournal page
column9: even once she became one of the biggest names in popular indie music
column10: worked with Jon Brion or launched a campaign for Urban Outfitters. There she is
column11: still with a bio that reads
column12: ""It's hard to celebrate with a headache""
column13:
still a member of a Rilo Kiley fan community.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19099/homepage_large.26342b04.jpg|snakes/vultures/sulfate|31202.0|EmptyMansions|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Riot House']|2013-04-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:32.364440|"

EmptyMansions is the result of Sam Fogarino discovering his songwriting muse during downtime at his day gig. Common story
column2: except Fogarino is best known as the drummer of Interpol
column3: a band who in their own words owe their success to the serendipitous combination of four people with complementary strengths and weaknesses. Daniel Kessler wasn’t much of a singer
column4: but had an innate gift for sonorous guitar layering and handling the day-to-day business affairs of a band. Carlos Dengler had little interest in that
column5: though his scything basslines and flamboyant public persona would become equally definitive for Interpol. Meanwhile
column6: Paul Banks made the crucial shift from emotive singer-songwriter to cryptic shouter-seducer by tailoring his voice to the physical limitations of the band’s cramped New York rehearsal space. The final addition of Fogarino really put things in motion; nearly a decade older than the rest of the band
column7: he brought an inimitable instrumental swagger as well as a necessary veteran presence and the enthusiasm of a rock n’ roll lifer who finally found his dream job. He’d been a consummate team player in the years since
column8: so if taking the frontman role in 2013 feels as jarring as
column9: say
column10: Paul Banks making a hip-hop mixtape
column11: unfortunately
column12: the results aren’t much better.

column1: Safe to say the one thing snakes/vultures/sulfate has in common with Everyone on My Dick Like They Supposed to Be is its defining flaw: you can’t doubt the zeal or sincerity of its creator
column2: but this new setting requires an entirely different skill set than the one they’ve established
column3: and there's almost no transferral between the two. The combination leads to
column4: at best
column5: a white-knuckle grasp on competency. While spirited punk incompetency might’ve been preferable in hindsight
column6: any band that features Fogarino on drums is at least guaranteed to sound professional
column7: and would be similarly lucky to have anyone else here involved-- Fogarino enlisted the help of Jesus Lizard’s Duane Denison and Interpol touring member Brandon Curtis
column8: formerly of the Secret Machines
column9: one of the few mainstream bands that could match Interpol’s mighty low end in the early 2000s.

column1: And yet
column2: the trio unlearns everything that distinguished them as instrumentalists on <i>snakes
column3: ending up with something that’s more entertaining when seen as a potential document of alternate history. It’s very easy to envision EmptyMansions as a band that might have been hastily slapped together right after the Jesus Lizard's Shot flopped and before Curtis and Fogarino found their own success. It sounds like radio-ready alt-rock ca. 1996-- so
column4: post-grunge. Which means in practice
column5: it’s nothing but craggy vocals
column6: meaty riffs served medium-well
column7: plodding rhythms
column8: implicit Pixies worship and explicit Neil Young worship; it ends with a cover of “Down by the River” all of things. Besides hooks or any sort of spark
column9: all that’s missing is a one-album record deal with DGC and an ill-fated tour with the Toadies.

column1: That these three guys can’t even come up with any memorable instrumental moments is baffling enough
column2: but the musical basis for EmptyMansions aims low as if that's the only difficulty level Fogarino can handle as a singer right now. He doesn’t make a total faceplant
column3: though the dominant emotion I get from listening to snakes is empathy. You might feel similarly if you’ve ever tried to write songs and quickly realized your inability to perform them. All eight tracks on snakes find Fogarino using a newbie’s cheat codes on the mic: When it’s audible
column4: he affects a Frank Black drawl (“That Man” actually namedrops him) that’s ostensibly meant to add intrigue to otherwise placeholder lines
column5: but more often serves as a way to avoid committing to the demands of melody. Listening to the off-key chorus of “Lyra”
column6: it’s easy to see why he’d go that route. Otherwise
column7: Fogarino cloaks himself with flange effects or simply buries himself in the mix so the song that’s supposedly inspired by Justified (“Up in the Holler”) is interchangeable with the one that takes its cues from Hubert Selby
column8: Jr. (""Sulfate"") or the one that was written by another man nearly four decades ago.

column1: While Fogarino’s tentative performance spares him embarrassment
column2: you wonder why he’s holding back when the mere act of releasing this record is ballsy as hell. At this juncture
column3: making snakes was likely its own reward and it’s hard to imagine Fogarino plotting a Foo Fighters-style exit strategy. But in a strange way
column4: snakes/vultures/sulfate is a record worth hearing because it serves as a reminder of the vast distance between inspiration and artistic realization; writing a good song is extremely hard
column5: capable singers are rare
column6: and compelling frontmen even more so. So EmptyMansions serve as a crossover to a real underground
column7: that is
column8: the 99% represented by bands that are equally competent
column9: anonymous
column10: and ultimately ignored
column11: the sort of music resulting in lonely SoundClouds
column12: sparsely attended bar gigs
column13:
and promo emails that are immediately deleted because the guy who played drums on Turn on the Bright Lights had absolutely nothing to do with it.

Nails are making some of the most thrillingly extreme music right now but the California quartet is difficult to recommend casually. They cram their brief
column2: constantly shifting tracks with a chaotic blend of hardcore
column3: D-Beat
column4: grindcore
column5: powerviolence
column6: and death metal. It's complex music that plows ahead while moving internally in dozens of directions.

column1: But technical descriptions don't capture what they do so well. When Southern Lord picked up and re-released their 2010 debut LP Unsilent Death after its smaller first pressing sold out
column2: they offered a comparison of 90s AmRep bands and early Cro-Mags going faster than either. That sort of works. So does Eyehategod's songbook played by 2013 Converge. This music is more suffocating than it is Suffocation; it also pulls largely from hardcore and comes with plenty of raw emotion attached to it.

column1: Unsilent Death's 10 tracks sped past in 14 minutes; Abandon All Life's 10 tracks just barely break the 17-minute mark. Both releases were produced by Converge's Kurt Ballou. It's assured
column2: sturdy music
column3: and Ballou knows how to make it sound deep and strong. (He does an even better job of it on the huge-sounding new collection.) With this kind of material you also need a vocalist who can stand up to it
column4: and Todd Jones (who used to play in the hardcore band Terror) keeps up with the mutating landscape behind him: he scowls
column5: snarls
column6: howls
column7: screams
column8: spits
column9: and even quietly sighs (in the black metal minor scales and Celtic Frost-like opening of standout ""Wide Open Wound""). At times he feels like a conductor holding together a maelstrom
column10: and when he repeatedly shouts ""I want to see you suffer"" in  the 42-second-long ""Tyrant"" and ""My goal: cause you pain"" in the 55-second-long ""No Surrender""
column11: you believe the sentiments
column12: even though his approach brings a lot of pleasure.

column1: Nails' songs are largely about power and control
column2: suffering and degradation; you get dozens of lines like ""On your knees before me/ I humiliate
column3: I torture/ I celebrate your failures"" in the escalating five-minute doom-to-feedback-implosion closer ""Suum Cuique"". But these songs are also about overcoming those situations. There are sentiments like ""Resolve your vengeance make them pay"" in opener ""In Exodus""
column4: the title track's ""Wield the fucking blade/ Pierce the fucking hate… / Your will is beyond what those cowards posses"" and ""Burn all white flags/ No fucking surrender"" in ""No Surrender"". For all the negatively people talk about Nails espousing
column5: they're ultimately a positive band-- in the sense that they provide a rallying point and a will to power for people open to these kinds of violent pep talks.

column1: But back to the beginning: Abandon All Life is a bracing
column2: cathartic
column3: darkly anthemic collection
column4: but those not used to this sort of thing will probably need to spend some time with so it can slow down some and make more sense. People usually don't think of hardcore punk as ""headphone"" music. Nails should be played loudly
column5: of course
column6: but they should also be listened to carefully on headphones at some point to appreciate how they're layering these elements and creating something so seamless. This is smart
column7: well-plotted music
column8:
which makes its anger all the more effective.

When you think about Canadian indie pop provocateur Mac DeMarco
column2: ""tasteful"" is probably not a characterization that springs to mind. Though this year's 2 proved the guy can do more than just an
column3: ahem
column4: ""creative"" cover of ""Beautiful Day""
column5: he's probably not someone you'd willingly leave your kids with. But he can write a tune
column6: and at least some people in his orbit share that ability. Take Alex Calder
column7: the 23-year-old musician who previously played drums in DeMarco's shaggy Makeout Videotape and has now ventured out on his own with his home-recorded EP
column8: Time. Mac hooked his fellow countryman up with Brooklyn imprint Captured Tracks which
column9: come to think of it
column10: was the least he could do after making Calder kiss a dead deer on camera. But for fans of DeMarco's laid-back
column11: deadbeat jams
column12: Calder is a worthy acolyte
column13: and Time is a delightfully shambling debut that succeeds in spite of obvious trappings.

column1: Calder specializes in a demented take on spangly 1960s flower pop. It's not the freshest approach
column2: but the songs work thanks to creeped-out undertones and his simple yet effective recording technique-- tons of fatty
column3: grumbly low-end that helps frame the spiring
column4: jangling guitars. Calder's music is in fact very similar to DeMarco's
column5: but it also feels reminiscent of Deerhunter's warped pop moves
column6: the eyelid-heavy mysticism of Julian Lynch and the ragged DIY appeal of Ty Segall. Though his style feels recognizable
column7: it's far from mimetic; Time keeps things woolly and weird
column8: often pushing beyond its own limits to produce music that is imperfect but strangely compelling because of it.

column1: Time's amateurism works in its favor. The lo-fidelity sonics are clearly the result of having little to work with (Calder recorded much of the EP in his living room in Montreal). He doesn't have much of a voice
column2: but knows how to mask it in reverb. Drums are junky
column3: ""production"" is nearly non-existent. It amounts to a snapshot of an artist getting to know himself
column4: but one that has more ideas than he's often capable of juggling. Songs typically only have two parts
column5: and at times feel as if they were hastily soddered together
column6: like the hurried work of a high school garage band. It may seem philistinic
column7: but it imparts a necessary urgency
column8: as if these songs just had to come out
column9: no matter the stability of the vessel.

column1: Time is ostensibly a guitar record
column2: as Calder manages to churn out addictive little hooks at nearly every turn. He's almost as good at making odd shapes too
column3: squeezing a surprising amount of texture out of these humble songs
column4: elevating what would otherwise register as unspectacular. Stormy jabs of guitar litter the background of the ambling ""Location""; the paisley-patterned ""Suki and Me"" would be ready for radio if it didn't sound so dosed; the weird ""Lethargic"" finally locates a slippery
column5: sweet funhouse mirror vibe Calder hints at the whole record long.

column1: Time is definitely a slacker's dream-- if bumming cigarettes had a soundtrack
column2: this would be it. But there's also something a little off about it
column3: a pervading sense of unease. ""Light Leave Your Eyes"" contrasts solar-powered guitars with a spooked out chorus
column4: complete with ghosted coos. On ""Location""
column5: Calder sings about ""drinking again without my friends again"" in an eerie sing-song
column6: giving way to the unsettlingly cheerful title track. Calder may not contain multitudes
column7: but with Time he's built a foundation for something more layered and complex than the dirty
column8: pretty things on display here. ""I guess I would call myself a recording artist
column9: even though it always sounds weird when I hear myself saying that
column10: Calder mentioned in a recent video. Get used to it
column11:
buddy.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-04-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:34.220913|"

Outside of a brief period in the early 1990s
column3: Mudhoney has never been fashionable. And this has been entirely by design-- except for the early 90s part
column4: which the band probably would have rather avoided. When Mudhoney was given a plum spot next to Pearl Jam and Soundgarden on the Singles soundtrack-- the Saturday Night Fever of alt-rock-- it dropped a stinkbomb inside Seattle’s coronation as rock’s “it” city: “Overblown” opened with Mark Arm famously snarling
column5: “Everybody loves us/ Everybody loves our town / That's why I'm thinkin' lately/ Time for leavin' is now.” On the new Vanishing Point
column6: Arm is still playing the cranky contrarian
column7: only now he has two extra decades of pent-up pissiness to vent at wannabe ballers. “You’ve always been the critics’ darling
column8: ” Arm bellows at some unfortunate unnamed band-of-the-month on the caustic rant “Chardonnay”. “Get the fuck out of my backstage!”

column1: Arriving at a time when the indie vanguard has about as much to do with punk as Glitter has to do with Apocalypse Now
column2: Vanishing Point is both an anachronism and
column3: if you’re on Mudhoney’s wavelength
column4: a hilarious bulwark against everything that’s annoyingly ephemeral about contemporary underground culture. It sounds like the last stand of Generation X: Vanishing Point is a righteous rallying cry in favor of cynicism
column5: irony
column6: anti-mainstream posturing
column7: and all of those other antiquated concepts that have been deconstructed and discredited in these new
column8: pop-obsessed times. How refreshing that after all the countless trends that once threatened to wipe out bands of their ilk
column9: Mudhoney is still here and not giving a fuck. “I don’t care if you think I’m a prick
column10: ” Arm leers gamely over the transgressive garage-rock thump of “I Don’t Remember You”. “It’s clear to me you’re the same piece of shit.”

column1: Like all born-and-bred bastards
column2: Arm has actually gotten funnier and more charming with age. Perhaps that’s because the 51-year old’s barbs are now as benign as the typical complaints of any out-of-touch middle-aged guy. His “piece of shit” riff on “I Don’t Remember You” is inspired by running into a pushy dude from back in the day who slaps his back too hard at the grocery store. On the smart-ass “What to Do With the Neutral”
column3: he mocks anyone who insists he should have a positive attitude; on “Sing this Song of Joy”
column4: he slips into a full-on taunt: “I sing this song of joy/ For all the girls and boys/ Dancing on your grave.” Mark Arm’s primary influence is no longer Iggy Pop
column5: it’s Larry David.

column1: Vanishing Point is the first Mudhoney record in five years
column2: the longest-ever gap between LPs for the band. Given where Mudhoney is at in its career-- still able to tour around the world
column3: but hardly a big moneymaking proposition-- there’s no guarantee there will be another album. So
column4: it’s nice to hear these guys playing about as well as they ever have on record: The tangle of Steve Turner’s erratic soloing and Dan Peters’ hyperactive drum fills on opener “Slipping Away” are so defiantly Mudhoney-sounding that it single-handedly justifies the price of admission. The difference between Mudhoney in 2013 and the Mudhoney of old is that what once seemed highly flammable is now reassuring. Mudhoney projects tradition and endurance
column5: not danger; the band’s appeal these days is rooted in not spontaneously combusting
column6: so that it can still exist when most of Mudhoney’s contemporaries are extinct.

column1: Not that Mudhoney is resigned to being a museum piece. On “I Like It Small”
column2: Arm is back in “Overblown” mode
column3: going on about the superiority of GG Allin
column4: “intimate settings
column5: ” “dingy basements
column6: ” and (most important of all) “no expectations” over whatever the opposite of those things are. At the start of the song
column7: Arm sounds alone
column8: buried in the kicked-up smoke of screaming guitars and pounding drums. But by the end
column9:
a chorus of people has joined him-- he’s a voice in the wilderness with the backing of a no-longer-marginalized army. What else is new?

"|17833.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17833-mudhoney-vanishing-point/|7.4|Steven Hyden

Rock festivals and arenas don’t book themselves
column3: and British Sea Power have never shied away from asking
column4: “how about us?” The Cumbrian eccentrics aren’t alone in putting themselves out there like that
column5: and they’ve done so reliably since 2005’s Open Season. But the lingering impression left by their brazen debut The Decline of British Sea Power-- the on-stage taxidermy
column6: the military uniforms
column7: the literal shout-outs to Russian literature-- has given everything since an air of audacity even as they spent the subsequent decade moving ever closer to the middle of the road. Machineries of Joy doesn’t take long to dispel any notions about this being anything other than British Sea Power growing more comfortable within their niche; if you like the idea of grandiose
column8: yet compact rock songs filled with arcane literary and historical references
column9: you’ll appreciate its mere existence. If not
column10: Machineries of Joy isn’t going to do much to change your mind.

column1: Machineries of Joy is a more enjoyable experience on the whole than 2011’s Valhalla Dancehall
column2: a record of protracted diversity that only ended up confirming that there's just one kind of song British Sea Power do well. Wisely
column3: the opening title track of Machineries of Joy is six minutes of that one kind of song. “We are magnificent machineries of joy” makes for a fitting thesis
column4: as the band industriously doles out signifiers of natural highs
column5: sighing strings
column6: Kraut-rock propulsion
column7: and ringing guitar chords that evoke the sensation alluded to in the closing bookend
column8: “When a Warm Wind Blows Through the Grass”. The appropriately sylvan “Spring Has Sprung” and “Hail Holy Queen” make similarly disarming and self-evident declarations of British Sea Power’s reigning status as British indie's most literate nature boys.

column1: But most of Yan's lyrics fail to appreciate or reflect the simplicity of his surroundings. Even if British Sea Power is five albums (and one soundtrack) deep
column2: he still maintains the overzealous poetic fervor of a college freshman; when Yan informs the listener “you are a vision of extraordinary contortion/ An athletic form of warm distortion
column3: ” it’s hard to not shrug your shoulders and think

column1: Book smarts and pop ambition aren't incompatible; problem is
column2: British Sea Power continue to be a band that’s well-read but emotionally illiterate. On “What You Need the Most”
column3: Yan sighs “You were my Pyrex baby
column4: ” which would admittedly make a decent construct for a Pusha T song. But hearing nearly six minutes of punning on the physical properties of glass (see: “getting smashed
column5: ” “cracked”) proves more tiresome than its waltz-time lurch. Then there's the would-be pep talk “Radio Goddard”
column6: which is actively frustrating. Note the spelling: It’s not Godard
column7: as in Jean-Luc
column8: someone potentially recognizable to most people who’d come across Machineries of Joy. It’s most likely Robert H. Goddard
column9: the physicist best known for developing the first liquid-fueled rocket after withstanding considerable criticism from the press. So after a couple minutes' research
column10: the call to “tune yourself to radio Goddard” starts to make sense-- but is the point to make you feel smart if you know the reference
column11: or to make British Sea Power look smart if you don't?

column1: On the other hand
column2: playing dumb isn't in their best interest either. Witness ""K Hole""
column3: hootin' and hollerin' garage rock that admirably makes a spectacle of itself
column4: but as someone whose lyrics and demeanor are more Ahab than Tarzan
column5: Yan doesn't take naturally to the role of wild man belter. Even putting aside its awkward melody
column6: ""Loving Animals"" makes its point very clear and still comes off more like anthropology than erotica.

column1: If you've been keeping up with British Sea Power to this point
column2: none of this should be a surprise; inverting the pursuits of the solitary
column3: the naturalist and the academic into subjects for populist music has been their M.O. for over a decade. And yet
column4: Machineries of Joy lacks the kind of crucial equalizers that appeal to all levels of education-- big hooks
column5: convincing physicality
column6: legible emotions. In other words
column7: the exact things that they promised by rhetorically asking Do You Like Rock Music? on their gigantic 2008 album. It was seen as cheeky back then
column8: but as with <i>Valhalla Dancehall
column9:
the detachment of Machineries of Joy flips the question: does British Sea Power like rock music?

The fresh-faced folk pop band Stornoway seem promising: They play with guileless vigor
column2: have a light-stepping chemistry as a unit
column3: harmonize well. Their lead singer Brian Briggs has a lovely
column4: pure high tenor
column5: the kind of voice that effortlessly conveys simple longing. And yet
column6: on their second album
column7: Tales from Terra Firma
column8: they continue to be almost crushingly dull
column9: making well-appointed and cheerfully empty music that successfully communicates next to nothing.

column1: Their Achilles Heel is a simple and unfortunate one
column2: the same on Tales as it was on 2010's Beachcombers Windowsill. Stornoway are clearly in love with Celtic and British folk
column3: and yet they can't write a memorable melody to save their lives. Try to sing along to the verse melody of ""Zorbing""
column4: their most well-known tune
column5: and pay attention to what your face muscles are doing; most likely furrowing with the effort of recall. Each of Tales' painstakingly arranged nine songs sinks underneath the weight of this insurmountable problem
column6: which is a shame.

column1: If you're making folk-pop
column2: an inability to write a catchy melody is a difficult deficiency to overcome. Stornoway try valiantly with their complex arrangements
column3: which quickly grow exhausting. “You Take Me as I Am” is cluttered with horn charts and pointlessly banging piano. “(A Belated) Invite to Eternity” builds to a full Explosions in the Sky crescendo
column4: with glimmering tremolo guitar and a “Tonight
column5: Tonight”-style sweeping string section
column6: but having built zero momentum and generated zero heat until that point
column7: their planned fireworks display fizzles.

column1: “Farewell Appalachia” follows the same pattern
column2: with celesta
column3: finger-picked acoustic and electric guitar all tracing an emptily pretty circle with nothing in the center. The melody of ""The Great Procrastinator"" is almost cleanly written enough to be memorable-- and then the ersatz Dixieland jazz interlude crashes in. Stornoway are deft players
column4: and the transitions are tightly managed
column5: but this is praise on the same order as praising the brushwork in a hotel-room painting.

column1: Briggs’ lyrics are filled with uncomplicated images of the good old British countryside
column2: but his lyrics trample over all these dew-covered fields with wordy
column3: awkward phrasing: ""And in the gathering dew
column4: I was lucid as a floodlight
column5: ” goes a line from “(A Belated) Invitation to Eternity”. “There's a hunger in the air/ A lemon swollen in the trees"" he bleats on “Knock Me on the Head”. On “The Great Procrastinator”
column6: he sings that he is “a scientist with far too many metaphors and far too little data to conclude in time.”  They don’t read particularly well
column7: and they don’t sound much more natural when sung.

column1: Tales From Terra Firma is a peculiar record-- carefree music that feels leaden; tuneful-sounding songs that offer no tunes to hold onto. They seem an odd fit for 4AD
column2: a label mostly home to singular voices. They may be a mercenary signing
column3: an attempt to ride the coattails of Mumford and Sons' success. But Mumford and Sons
column4: as head-smack simple and pandering as they are
column5: have a pretty crucial ingredient in their arsenal: they write anthems. In that regard
column6:
they have Stornoway pretty thoroughly beat.

While Master P dropped Al Capone in January and Mystikal put out the bulldozing “Hit Me” last December
column2: the only alumnus of heyday-era No Limit who’s been consistently releasing worthwhile music is Fiend. The New Orleans rapper was a second-tier figure on P’s label during its absurdly lucrative late-'90s
column3: and back then
column4: he rapped with a throaty yammer that remained the center of attention no matter how hard the Beats by the Pound track beneath him was slamming. But Fiend’s mellowed out over the years
column5: and these days he’s almost exclusively found atop goopy
column6: deeply luxuriating beats
column7: meanwhile fitting squarely into the same league of weed-rap as his buddy Curren$y. And with Lil Ghetto Boy
column8: his first (but probably not last) tape of the year
column9: he’s given us another satisfying slab of the stuff
column10: superceding even 2011’s excellent Tennis Shoes & Tuxedos. The man has his lane.

column1: When he’s not waxing vaguely political on a track like “Blue
column2: White
column3: Red” or imparting a few words on fatherhood during “Violent Violins”
column4: Fiend is laconically exploring Curren$y’s brand of girls-
column5: weed-
column6: and cars-based vaunting. That Oldsmo he just cruised past in? “I’m in a old school that’ll shut down your newest.” Wonder why
column7: in the grand scheme of things
column8: he’s barely a blip on the radar anymore? He’s “too real for TV.” The chick all over him at the club tonight? She’s got ""the type of ass to get yours in trouble.” But while these particular lines all do nicely
column9: Lil Ghetto Boy is a success thanks mostly to non-lyrical factors
column10: and any ground lost due to Fiend’s not-especially-immersing penmanship is more than made up for.

column1: Fiend freestyled over Washed Out’s “Feel It All Around” early last year
column2: but I don’t think he intended it to be the publicity stunt it might’ve looked like; Ernest Greene’s impossibly lush
column3: Gary Low-sampling track just happens to be the kind of thing he’s come to sound gorgeous over. And as is the case with all of his other recent tapes
column4: there’s a ton of that same energy here. Musically
column5: Lil Ghetto Boy is mostly nectary basslines
column6: Nile Rodgers funk guitar
column7: and blaxploitation horn-blasts
column8: a framework that joins so relaxingly with Fiend’s charcoal baritone that parsing through the lyrics becomes an afterthought. It might be a backhanded compliment to say that benefits the tape
column9: but that benefits the tape.

column1: Still
column2: Lil Ghetto Boy totals 22 tracks and tops 70 minutes
column3: and any release this hefty should swerve occasionally in order to keep things interesting. Luckily
column4: a few curves do pop up here. “Lil Sumptin” is the kind of Mouse on tha Track sputter-slap that demands to be set to a video featuring a candy-colored Cadillac with obnoxiously powerful hydraulics. Later
column5: on the back third of the tape
column6: “No Apologies” and “Play if You Want” approach the ominous belfry trap we’re used to hearing Meek Mill tear through
column7: the latter being a beat-of-the-year contender despite its fleeting two-and-a-half-minute run time. Some of these deviations inspire Fiend to bust out that original vein-popping bark of his (not to mention more frequent use of his “WHOMP WHOMP” adlib)
column8: but not one compromises the character of the tape as a whole. A sequential triumph
column9: Lil Ghetto Boy plays like one long
column10: sweeping showcase of what Fiend does best and
column11: when things head toward monotony
column12: some of the other things he’s capable of. He might never again find the commercial success he had early in his career
column13: but with Lil Ghetto Boy
column14:
his second wind (if this phase of his career can be called that) seems to be getting even stronger.

It’s been six years since we last heard from Kinski and I figured they were done. 2007’s Down Below It’s Chaos featured a band that sounded like it was trying to escape its own skin
column2: veering between their drifting space-rock origins and bludgeoning hard rock. When a band sounds that tired of what it made its name doing on its own record
column3: it can be forgiven for hanging it up afterward.

column1: Kinski haven’t quite hung it up
column2: though
column3: and if you were hoping that they just needed a while to clear their heads before making a sequel to the spaced-out drone and loud-soft post-rock of Don’t Climb on and Take the Holy Water
column4: well
column5: the band doesn’t seem interested in giving it to you. Instead
column6: Cosy Moments doubles down on Down Below’s shift to hard rock
column7: sounding at times like it was made in the band’s hometown of Seattle about 22 years ago. I swear they were listening to Mudhoney and Incesticide on repeat when they wrote “Last Day on Earth""
column8: a rampaging
column9: punked-up rocker that flies by in less than two minutes of grunge-y dynamics and walloping drums.

column1: That’s hardly the only blast of crunchy fuzz-- this album only goes directly to the space-rock well once
column2: on the pensive
column3: flute-topped instrumental “We Think She’s a Nurse"". Even then
column4: it does it as a set-up for “Let Me Take You Through My Thought Process""
column5: the minute-and-twenty-one-second grunge-pop song that closes the album. Chris Martin’s lead vocals never approach the raggedness of Kurt Cobain or Mark Arm
column6: nor does he seem especially mad about anything (the lyrics generally rely on the same love of wordplay as the band’s song titles)
column7: and his clipped melodicism combines with the bright fuzztones in a way that oddly brings to mind R.E.M.’s Monster. This too is a sort of outsider’s take on early '90s heavy rock
column8: with just a bit of overt musicianship on display.

column1: There are hints of the old Kinski in places. “Counterpointer” mashes grunge riffs into an odd-metered prog pulp
column2: and the lead guitar on the instrumentals sometimes takes on the spacey character of yore. Overall
column3: though
column4: this is Kinski’s most straightforward rock album
column5: and certainly the Kinski album with the best
column6: most concise vocal songs. If anything
column7: the cranked-up
column8:
low-tempo instrumentals are now where the band fares worst. It’s hard to know what most Kinski fans will think of this. They’re basically a new band now-- even more so than last time-- and they sound refreshed by the change.

Only Wire would attempt to make their fourth album after their tenth. At the beginning of their career
column2: between 1977 and 1979
column3: the great British art punk quartet released three perfect albums
column4: Pink Flag
column5: Chairs Missing and 154
column6: each wildly different from the other. Then they splintered
column7: though a bunch of post-154 songs-in-process came to light later
column8: in the dodgy live recordings that made up the bizarre
column9: messy Document and Eyewitness (1981) and 1996's Turns and Strokes.

column1: Since they first reunited in 1985
column2: Wire has had an exceptionally weird relationship to its own past. During their commercial peak in the latter half of the 80s
column3: they refused to play anything from the pre-breakup era
column4: and for the first few years of their current incarnation
column5: they mostly acted as if they'd jumped straight from Pink Flag to the year 2000. At the beginning of this decade
column6: they started looking back in earnest-- not in a ""hey
column7: kids
column8: we wrote ""12 x U""
column9: remember?"" way
column10: but in a ""cleaning up loose ends"" way. 2011's Strays EP contained four pieces that had been kicking around their live repertoire for a long time but had never been recorded to their satisfaction before; the Black Session album that came out last year actually included a few relatively faithful versions of old songs.

column1: And now they've gone back to the material they'd have recorded for the album that never happened after 154. The 13 titles on Change Becomes Us are new
column2: but the songs themselves aren't; they're all more or less newly rewritten versions of the Document and Eyewitness/Turns and Strokes repertoire. It's not the first time they've reckoned with some of those sketches
column3: either. ""B/W Silence"" and ""Time Lock Fog"" are respectively adapted from ""Lorries"" and ""5/10
column4: which singer/guitarist Colin Newman previously reworked on his 1982 solo album Not To. ""Doubles & Trebles"" is a new version of ""Ally in Exile""
column5: which Wire mutated first into ""Art of Persistence"" on 2000's The Third Day and then into ""I Don't Understand"" on 2002's Read & Burn 01; positioned as the new album's opener
column6: its arrangement and lyric (about a solitary agent in enemy territory) explicitly allude to the way ""Reuters"" introduces Pink Flag.

column1: The Wire of 1980
column2: and the band's members on the solo records that immediately followed the split
column3: were radicals who were trying to pry open the pop-recording form and avoid repeating themselves. The Wire of 2013 have settled on a sweet-and-prickly sound that suits them
column4: and sonically Change Becomes Us is of a piece with Red Barked Tree and Object 47
column5: the other studio albums they've recorded since the 2004 departure of guitarist/texturalist Bruce Gilbert. (These days
column6: his spot is filled by Matt Simms
column7: who's 30 years younger than the rest of the band.)

column1: Considered as a set of songs
column2: though
column3: it's fantastic-- a clear look at the twisty
column4: glittering material that had previously only been a few sparkles of possibility shining through the muck of those difficult live albums. The band who wrote these songs were a couple of years away from becoming hardcore punk icons-- there are hints of that when drummer Robert Grey breaks into a high-speed two-step on ""Adore Your Island"" and ""Stealth of a Stork"". And they were so deeply invested in non-obviousness that their lyrics sometimes read like cryptic crossword clues: the hook of ""Eels Sang Lino""-- recast here as ""Eels Sang""-- is an anagram for ""in Los Angeles.""

column1: But the Wire of 1979 and 1980 were also developing their enduring fascination with unlikely kinds of beauty
column2: and their 21st century incarnation has built some of their most fetching songs from some of the most ragged and jagged ideas to come from their younger selves. (""Re-Invent Your Second Wheel""
column3: sung by bassist Graham Lewis
column4: is a languorous waltz whose DNA has traces of the in-your-face Document and Eyewitness experiment ""Zegk Hoqp"".) History and transformation are
column5: understandably
column6: recurring themes in the new lyrics on Change Becomes Us
column7: and it's a treat to have this missing link in the Wire story repaired
column8:
even if it's as much an anomaly in the present moment as Document and Eyewitness was in its time.
