In 10-second intervals-- the first few bars of a fuzz-drenched guitar riff
column3: the opening thuds of a tribal drum beat
column4: the first line dripping from a stoned vocal-- the Black Angels can sound like the coolest band on the planet. If only there didn’t have to be an endless series of identical 10-second intervals after that; what’s initially thrilling about these Texas psych-rockers gets run through a loop that quickly turns monotonous
column5: then tedious
column6: and finally deadening. Their fourth album
column7: Indigo Meadow
column8: is more of the same.

column1: Just as 2010’s Phosphene Dream was relatively compact and poppy compared with 2008’s Directions to See a Ghost
column2: Indigo Meadow finds the Black Angels once again downplaying their psych side and playing up the rock. Not that the group has exited its original era of inspiration-- the menacing Farfisa organ fills and trebly guitar buzz keep the vibe firmly rooted in the 60s-- but the references have shifted a bit
column3: away from “Sister Ray” and toward the Yardbirds and Nuggets. This suits the Black Angels’ current line-up; now down to a four-piece
column4: they resemble a knuckle-dragging garage-rock band from the LBJ years now more than ever. Instead of prattling over a simple
column5: pulsating groove for several minutes
column6: the Black Angels now apply their muscular clomp to bluesy vamps like “The Day”
column7: which nods towards the Yardbirds’ version of “I’m a Man”
column8: and pseudo-menacing claptrap like the clumsy “Always Maybe”
column9: which has the trippy keyboards and “spooky” vocal affectations of a darkly campy Strawberry Alarm Clock track.

column1: It’s a not a crime for a revivalist outfit like the Black Angels to occasionally lapse into flower-power corniness; if delivered with a little self-awareness
column2: it adds to the appeal of the anachronistic package. What’s not forgivable on Indigo Meadow is the pretension. “Don’t Play with Guns” is one of several mid-tempo slabs of snaky
column3: druggy (or “druggy”) silliness that would go down just fine if the Black Angels didn’t take their own lyrical bullshit (“Now Angie
column4: she was a demon/ She had six arms and Lucifer eyes
column5: ” etc.) so seriously. Unfortunately
column6: the Black Angels seem themselves as bullshit artistes; in the press materials for Indigo Meadow
column7: singer/multi-instrumentalist Alex Maas has the gall to suggest that “Don’t Play with Guns” is a comment on mass shootings like the tragedy in Aurora
column8: CO
column9: even though the song was written days before the massacre. “In ""Don’t Play with Guns"" the antagonist is a female who has the power of persuasion over a man
column10: ” Maas says on the band’s website. “Substitute the female antagonist with a Nation
column11: substitute the manipulated man with yourself. Heed the warning: Don’t play with guns.”

column1: You mean these songs are meaningful warnings so long as you substitute the shallow clichés in the lyrics with real-life substance? What a convenient trick. The sprightly “Broken Soldier” is a more deliberate “message” song about societal violence
column2: concerning a fighting man who posits that it’s “hard to kill when you don’t know what side you’re on.” But applying Maas’ logic to the rest of the record
column3: Indigo Meadow can mean whatever you wish. (The dreary “Evil Things” must be about the federal budget sequester.) Sorry
column4: but that doesn’t pass the smell test. Indigo Meadow isn't a window into the modern world; it's an escape from it. Bullshit is fine if you can sell it
column5:
but the Black Angels have finally laid it on too thick.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18969/homepage_large.538be285.jpg|The Ascent|4645.0|Wiley|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2013-04-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:39.067962|"

I like to think that when Wiley heard Pitbull tell dancers to picture that with a Kodak he felt a bit resentful: despite having nearly written the rule book
column2: none of the rapper’s own ridiculous lyrics and blatant dance-pop crossovers had resonated with non-British listeners nearly as effectively as “Give Me Everything” did. Still
column3: these times should suit the erstwhile “Godfather of Grime”
column4: and at least in the UK they seem to: his latest album The Ascent has already yielded three top 10 hits locally
column5: including a number one in “Heatwave”. If Wiley’s career seems to seesaw between rough-hewn respectability (or obscurity
column6: if you prefer) and goofy populism
column7: his latest sweep into the second category coincides with what must surely be considered goofy populism’s golden age. Sadly
column8: this is not to say that this latest career reinvention is executed with particular grace or skill
column9: and instead The Ascent bows to the received wisdom of cramming as many guest artists
column10: producers and stylistic tics as humanly possible into a 50 minute listen
column11: presumably so as to exhaust listeners into submission.

column1: This conscious attempt to please all audiences is reminiscent of Nicki Minaj at times
column2: especially when you measure the distance from the album’s most aggressive moment (the epileptic shudders of grime crew cut “Skillzone”) to its least (the histrionic
column3: hospital fundraiser advert-ready “Tomorrow”
column4: complete with fake Chris Martin chorus). But Nicki has two clear demographics in mind
column5: and deals squarely to each of them; by contrast
column6: Wiley’s ecumenicalism seems to blur the hard edges around each song until the strict stylistic differences hardly seem to matter. Which is a shame
column7: because track for track several of the contortions come off pretty well
column8: especially the obvious but obviously-fun drum and bass thumper “Reload” (random thesis: drum & bass got hooky again by listening to Madonna’s Confessions on a Dancefloor)
column9: or the bustling
column10: horn-driven funky of “My Heart”.

column1: On the other hand
column2: it’s harder to get excited about Wiley and friends’ attempts at straight rap (what’s the point?) or numerous stabs at the international colors of EDM-pop. In the case of the latter
column3: the problem is not the sound per se; arguably
column4: the arrangements Wiley draws for are more inventive and sympathetic to rapping than are most of the better-known US counterparts
column5: and Wiley is well-suited to the style
column6: readily treading the tightrope between the fabulous and the fatuous. Rather
column7: it’s that if you’re choosing a style which forecloses off so many sensory options (menace
column8: swagger and so on) in favour of a narrow stripe of geared-up melodic anthemism
column9: then you better ensure your anthemism is top-shelf. But the half-heartedly hedonistic R&B choruses on these tunes suggest that on the international market for bolt-on pop exuberance Wiley’s credit doesn’t stretch very far. The exception is the oddly stirring
column10: string-driven “Heatwave”
column11: which flips the script by having Wiley sound hookier than the blankly raunched-up chorus offered by Ms D.

column1: It seems boring and a bit lazy to say that Wiley sounds best when he’s still offering up recognisable grime tunes
column2: but it’s undeniable that on The Ascent the strongest of such efforts capture the rapper in his best light
column3: in part by offering him space to breathe
column4: and in part because the grooves’ stop-start frigidity
column5: their alternations of yawning gaps and sudden collision of beats
column6: mimic the same qualities in Wiley’s flow
column7: that ceaseless monotone command-style filled with unexpected accelerations and decelerations
column8: like a field marshal ordering troops in time with the beat.

column1: Moreover
column2: the always-ambivalent sonic qualities of grime-- its fussiness
column3: even prissiness
column4: evoking so strongly the idea of guys who want to be hard more than they actually are; hard men of the internet comments box era perhaps-- perfectly complement Wiley’s self-obsession. On “Humble Pie” and the particularly great “Broken Thoughts” (shamefully relegated to bonus track status)
column5: Wiley recounts tales of doomed love and precarious achievement with a kind of self-puncturing smallness that seems particular to grime and Wiley as its most emblematic figure. Both tunes feature gorgeously shifting
column6: sighing arrangements from Kid D
column7: their stuttering beats and rippling chimes a world away from crossover
column8:
but far more intimately entwined around the rapper’s curious charms. 

"|17772.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17772-wiley-the-ascent/|6.2|Tim Finney

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19100/homepage_large.169b8f84.jpg|Update|23840.0|Scuba|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hotflush']|2013-04-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:39.822242|"

Over the last decade

column3: with founder Paul Rose producing some of the London-based label's strongest material to date. Rose has made music under several different monikers
column4: but in the past few years
column5: his work as Scuba has arguably proven most vital. Even for someone working in a genre that's as constantly stylistically fickle as bass
column6: Rose has recently proven himself one of dance music's most inventive producers
column7: someone who'd rather take bass places it rarely frequents than simply follow trends. In Scuba's world
column8: nothing is off-limits-- chunky rave chords
column9: huge-sounding trance melodies
column10: house music's persistent thud-- and whatever's in his sonic arsenal is deployed to the point where bass as a genre is nearly and completely abandoned.

column1: An album-oriented artist working within a musical culture where albums have seldom been a point of focus
column2: Rose's first two full-lengths as Scuba
column3: 2008's A Mutual Antipathy and 2010's Triangulation
column4: still featured an abundance of the clattering percussion and gray tones that many have come to associate with UK bass. Last year's Personality
column5: then
column6: was something completely different. Loaded with bold
column7: strident melodies as well as a few stylistic left turns
column8: Personality radiated an aura of positivity that's not easily found in the genre. Less of a maximalist than Glasgow's manically minded Rustie
column9: and not as much of a sensualist as Hotflush-signed duo Sepalcure
column10: Personality regardless cemented Rose as an up-with-people artist
column11: the type of producer who's not afraid to make something crowd-pleasing even if it means sacrificing a level of subtlety in the process.

column1: When taken in chronological order
column2: Scuba's catalog shows clear artistic progression and growth-- which is why it's a little curious that Update
column3: the digital-only compilation that cherrypicks highlights from the project's seven-year existence
column4: abandons chronology entirely in favor of establishing something approaching a narrative (it's probably not a coincidence that the last track here is called ""Lights Out""). The embrace of a non-linear tracklist proves effective
column5: though
column6: in connecting the dots between early material and more recent revelations
column7: proving that even at his sparsest
column8: Rose's keen ear for melody has proven as effective even when his hand tips the scales towards subtlety.

column1: The seismic depth of this stuff isn't rude by any means
column2: but it possesses a disorienting richness regardless
column3: to the point where even the crispest percussive touches seem to reverberate endlessly into blackness. Update's tracks unfold patiently
column4: as even the most chaotic cuts sound micro-managed for maximum effectiveness
column5: so when Rose zooms out to let
column6: say
column7: an expressive synth wash enter the fray
column8: he's in no rush to get back to what he was on previously. He wants you to feel it
column9: to the point where the feeling becomes awesomely overwhelming.

column1: The predilection for creating moments of pure awe is probably why I often find myself reaching for the Chemical Brothers after listening to Scuba. His recent material suggests that Rose shares their-- and
column2: by extension
column3: progressive house's-- psychedelic tendencies
column4: but it's important to remember the Chem Bros' skewed pop instincts are what's continually ensured their commercial relevancy
column5: too
column6: and at his best Rose exhibits similar smarts. Personality cuts ""July"" and ""NE1BUTU"" represent some of his most beatifically straightforward material to date
column7: the former employing synth stabs reminiscent of Van Halen's ""Jump"" and the latter cramming a wealth of sample triggers into its too-tough front half before declarative piano chords and a neck-whipping diva vocal tornadoes through the proceedings.

column1: Then
column2: there's ""Adrenalin"". The 2011 single and deserved centerpiece of Update was
column3: at the time of its release
column4: the first taste of what was to come on Personality
column5: and it arguably still stands as Rose's most excellent work to date. Over the course of eight minutes that feel as if they could go for another hour or more
column6: Rose carefully builds a foundation around an endless repetition of the titular vocal sample-- a 4/4 thud
column7: some shuddering 808 figures
column8: expressive washes of sound-- before
column9: at the tune's near halfway point
column10: a tidal wave of synths crash through to create something that's intangibly anthemic and irrepressibly epic
column11: a glistening trance anthem that even those who still think of trance as a dirty word can embrace. It's the sound of staring into the sun for just the right amount of time-- or
column12: having your mind blown by something with the transportative properties of ""Adrenalin"" while out at a club-- and it represents Rose at his most creatively generous.

column1: Rose's output as Scuba dates back seven years
column2: and as the relatively meek title of the compilation suggests
column3: that's a span of time that doesn't necessarily demand a ""best of"" release. There are many producers
column4: both in bass music and other strains of dance
column5: whose catalogs demand this type of treatment for a variety of reasons
column6: least of which being sheer availability of their catalog to those not willing to do the deep digging. (With Rose
column7: you can get a lot from the readily available full-lengths and EPs
column8: even if seeking out his lesser-known work and singles as SCB proves equally rewarding.) Update
column9: then
column10: gets by on the sheer pleasures it provides
column11:
a collection that transcends necessity on its own merit.

In a landscape where Gucci Mane and Waka Flocka Flame have proven to be

column4: Brick Squad's own Young Thug stands out as an unquantifiable wild card. His style-- which marries the hook-bending sonic sensibility of Future
column5: the pill-addled yawp of Danny Brown
column6: and the playful irreverance of Lil B living together under the guiding aura of Lil Wayne's experimental period-- is hard to define
column7: and he uses this mystique in memorable ways. But
column8: more often than not
column9: he doesn't quite put that enticing package together. David Drake called Thug's 2012 mixtape I Came From Nothing 3 a ""a dense
column10: ambitious attempt to cultivate an entirely new rap style"" while also calling it ""frequently frustrating
column11: shifting from eye-openingly original to inconsequential from track to track."" Much of the same can be said about Thug's newest entry

column1: If it weren't for the moments Thug does puts the puzzle together

column3: and the ones that do get something spinning sometimes don't end up anywhere memorable. The thing is though

column7: in particular

column11: and ""Picacho"". That trio of tracks is essentially a crash course in what constitutes a brilliant
column12: potential-flexing entry from Thug

column14: meandering joints like ""Shooting Star"".

column1: ""2 Cups Stuffed"" is without a doubt 1017 Thug's Wake-The-Fuck-Up moment
column2: a song that builds from an unshakeable
column3: wheeling hook into Thug's chanting
column4: delirious demand for syrup. ""Uno! Dos! Cups stuffed! UNO! DOS! CUPS STUFFED!"" It's repetitive in the way that a hammer's thud might be repetitive. It's great.

column1: Following up the annoying-by-design ""Murder"" is ""Nigeria""
column2: a watery
column3: Gucci-featuring track that sounds like Thug is calling from the corner of the club
column4: maybe even the bathroom stall
column5: maybe underwater. ""Nigeria""
column6: an ode to the potent Nigerian strain of marijuana
column7: gives Thug license to travel around the globe
column8: to Jamaica
column9: to Siberia (""Also cold in Siberia
column10: Thug shivers). It's a good example of the tension Thug creates
column11: batting the trope around in a playful way
column12: while at the same time seeming a little dangerous and unhinged
column13: adrift in the fog of drugs and his nasal fiending is the only thing cutting through the mist. It's something else.

column1: Curious synths provided by producer Jay Neutron lead you into the bizarro universe of ""Picacho""
column2: a pastiche where Young Thug envisions walking up to peers in the club and bellowing ""Pikachu!
column3: maybe even while wearing that red ballcap Ash wears. It takes its title from either the most well-known Pokémon
column4: a cat/rat mixture that doubles as a tesla coil

column1: ""Picacho"" is a good example of just how far Thug will stretch his voice and cadence
column2: sometimes even leaping into a register that Mel Blanc didn't know existed. It's probably the best thing on the mixtape. It's pretty incredible.

column1: One of the strangest things about 1017 Thug is just how flat the more high-visibility collaborations fall; none of the tracks produced by Brick Squad load carriers Lex Luger or 808 Mafia leave a mark

column5:
can radio omnipresence be that far behind? It might take more mixtapes than it should to find out.

column2:
the Creator|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Odd Future']|2013-04-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:40.901265|"

Odd Future ringleader Tyler
column3: the Creator has a rap persona pitched between shock-riddled misanthropy and confessional reflection; he’s preoccupied with his own press and he uses his music as a vent for anger and frustration. His debut album
column4: Bastard
column5: was filled with sharp darts for rap blogs who wouldn’t post his music
column6: while his sophomore album
column7: Goblin
column8: wanted desparately to prove Odd Future was worth all their sudden hype. In the two years since Goblin’s release
column9: Earl Sweatshirt returned from Samoan exile
column10: Frank Ocean opened up about his sexuality in a heartfelt Tumblr note and released the Grammy Award winning Channel Orange
column11: and Tyler unveiled ""Loiter Squad""
column12: an absurdist late night sketch comedy show. As a group
column13: Odd Future embarked on a series of tours that connected them with an expanding base of teenagers and outcasts even as they drew fire from LGBT advocates
column14: women’s groups
column15: and a music press none too amused by the macabre content of their lyrics. A lot has changed
column16: and now Tyler returns with Wolf.

column1: Where Goblin felt like an attempt to shoehorn the whole of Odd Future’s nihilist aesthetic into a single album
column2: Wolf pulls back the curtain and reveal the talented introvert behind the music. The first thing to go is the bratty punk fury of earlier material. The insurgent bravado of “Radicals”
column3: “Sandwitches”
column4: and “French” is scaled back
column5: replaced by songs that flip the conventions of his songwriting inside out. The songs about women are earnest where they used to carry murder ballads’ air of ill intent. Drugs come up
column6: but we also hear about a remorseful dealer surveying the havoc he’s caused and a man having a mercilessly terrible time while high. Wolf is still the balancing act between gruff cynicism and juvenilia that we’ve come to expect from Odd Future (especially on “Pigs”
column7: a bleak radio play about exacting revenge on bullies)
column8: but these songs are more three-dimensional. Tyler’s more likely to aim for melody instead of menace.

column1: Wolf as a whole also sounds gorgeous
column2: and that even goes for the bruisers. The polyrhythmic hi-hats of the madcap posse cut “Trashwang” eventually give pause to a piano bridge
column3: and the blustery lead single “Domo 23” gets a bump from a boisterous horn section. Foreboding numbers like “Rusty” (a lush reimagining of 1990s RZA production) and the nightmarish
column4: tribal “Cowboy” are declawed by rich textures and melodicism. “Answer” sets Tyler’s longing for his late grandmother and absentee father to a bright guitar figure and shimmering organs. “48”’s crack epidemic reminiscence is adorned with elegant pianos
column5: string stabs
column6: tasteful guitar
column7: and spoken word interludes from Nas. Tyler’s pet sounds are dark melodies hammered out on wonky synths and clattering breakbeats but here they come padded with embellishments that give Wolf a cinematic breadth. The album is pretty
column8: but beguilingly so.

column1: There’s something not quite right
column2: though
column3: and it’s not just Tyler’s gritty basso profundo cutting through every melodic flourish. Pacing is one problem. Wolf reprises the winding sprawl of Goblin
column4: hitting its stride on a series of midtempo cuts on the front and back ends but losing steam on a midsection that places too many of its longest and slowest songs back-to-back. “PartyIsntOver/Campfire/Bimmer” marries three unrelated fragments in a manner not unlike Domo Genesis’ Rolling Papers
column5: whose passages of short vignettes gave it an off-the-cuff feel. But the pieces here don’t hang together
column6: and “Bimmer” is too fleeting of a payoff for the uphill trudge it takes to get there. After that
column7: there’s the lengthy “IFHY” (“I fucking hate you
column8: ” natch.)
column9: a bit of Neptunes worship so adroit that its plinking synths and jazzy chord changes give way to a falsettoed coda from Pharrell himself. (The Stereolab-channeling“Campfire” similarly summons that band’s Laetitia Sadier for a guest vocal.) Later on
column10: the sedate acid jazz of “Treehome95” and the closing comedown “Lone” are inexplicably split up by the shrill M.I.A. send-up “Tamale”. Wolf is full of good songs but in the wrong order.

column1: Still
column2: not all of the depressive sluggishness can be blamed on sequencing. Tyler makes very clear that he doesn’t enjoy the trappings of fame. The album is shot through with harsh words for critics
column3: sheepish venue owners
column4: puritanical parents
column5: and groups who’ve picketed Odd Future shows. But if he’s surrounded by detractors
column6: he only has himself to blame. He was bound to be taken for a ne’er do well by a mainstream public who first spotted him in a video eating a roach and hanging himself
column7: to be read for a homophobe after filling his records and tweets with offensive slurs. Tyler should know that we don’t get to control the ways our words are interpreted when they leave our mouths to filter out into the universe
column8: and we certainly don’t get to be coarse or crass without blowback. Over the length of the album
column9: the defensive can become grating
column10: and Wolf’s rebuttals are pointless anyhow. By now
column11: you either like Odd Future and have figured out a mental workaround to reconcile their more troubling tendencies with their obvious talent
column12: in which case this stuff is moot
column13: or you don’t
column14: and this acrimonious self-defense is ill-suited to win you over.

column1: With Wolf
column2: Tyler
column3: the Creator displays a radical growth as a producer
column4: composer and arranger
column5: even if
column6: as a rapper
column7: he’s still up to some of the same antics. Still
column8: the album contains a few of the best songs he’s ever written. “48” is a wonder
column9: “Answer” and “Lone” delve into deeply personal matters with poise
column10: and “Rusty” is one of the most arresting lyrical performances on the record if you can see past the self-serving chest-beating. It’s a big screen rendering of the Neptunes-meet-Stevie-Wonder-in-a-microwave quality of Tyler’s earlier works
column11: the sound of a creative mind coming into the possession of the proper means to carry out its ideas. At its best
column12: Wolf manages to make the inroads toward accessibility that Goblin wouldn’t and pulls it off without sacrificing too much of Tyler’s refreshing capriciousness. When the album isn’t busy telling us that we ought to like it more
column13:
it’s delivering reasons why we actually should.

Drug abuse was as rampant in the Seattle scene as frayed flannel shirts
column2: and few local artists chronicled junkie conflicts quite so persistently as Layne Staley. As frontman for Alice in Chains
column3: he approached the subject with a cagey ambivalence that allowed that band to navigate from glam metal also-rans to grunge grunge mainstays. Drugs were a temptation as well as a burden
column4: and at his best Staley implied that addiction prodded the scene’s severe introversion-- as if that was the pain that everyone was singing about. At his worst
column5: though
column6: he could be ridiculously self-righteous and pompously poetic about his habit. If you don’t believe me
column7: read the lyrics to “Junkhead”.

column1: After Pearl Jam guitarist Mike McCready and journeyman bass player John Baker Saunders met at rehab and formed a band
column2: they brought in Staley primarily because they thought he would benefit from being around some clean musicians. With Screaming Trees drummer Barrett Martin rounding out the band
column3: they played a few shows locally as the Gacy Bunch before decorum prevailed and they rebilled themselves as Mad Season. Even that band name is druggy: a term for the time of year when psilocybin mushrooms are in bloom. In 1995
column4: Mad Season released their one and only album
column5: <i>Above
column6: which notched an honest-to-God radio hit with “River of Deceit”-- something that higher-profile side projects Brad and Temple of the Dog never managed. Efforts to record a follow-up in 1997 went nowhere. Saunders OD’ed in ’99
column7: Staley in ’02.

column1: 18 years after its release
column2: Above is getting the deluxe reissue treatment
column3: complete with unreleased live tracks
column4: a DVD
column5: and some recently completed recordings from the aborted follow-up sessions. It’s a handsome package and easily the definitive statement on this Seattle footnote
column6: but all those extras can’t compensate for what is a bewilderingly self-absorbed album
column7: one so dully self-serious that in retrospect it may have killed grunge dead. So combative and caustic with Alice in Chains
column8: Staley lets his ongoing self-examination curdle into clunky therapyspeak and ponderous nonsense. “My pain is self-chosen
column9: at least I believe it to be
column10: ” he insists on “River of Deceit”
column11: succinctly summing up everything that was wrong with 90s alt-rock.

column1: It’s not entirely Staley’s fault. Mad Season was a new group
column2: and its members were still figuring out what all they could do together. In the reissue liner notes
column3: Barrett Martin maintains they were actually a blues band
column4: which isn’t quite as incredible as it might sound: Saunders
column5: older than his bandmates by a decade
column6: had spent long years in the Chicago and Minneapolis blues scenes
column7: backing Hubert Sumlin and Lamont Cranston. Still
column8: Mad Season wasn’t necessarily interested in blues structure or subject matter
column9: at least not directly. Instead
column10: these songs are long on vaguely bluesy atmosphere. In other words: ominous
column11: minor key
column12: crossroadsy. The average song length runs between six and seven minutes
column13: which makes Above a real slog. They fill that time with some heavy riffage
column14: some noodling straight off a “Yellow Ledbetter” outtake
column15: some marimba chords
column16: and a saxophone solo. It’s not blues grunge so much as lounge grunge.

column1: While Seattle is credited with stamping out the previous decade’s decadent hard rock
column2: heavy metal was always a crucial influence on grunge. The band members’ day-job groups may have sounded like punk that had integrated classic rock at a molecular level
column3: but on Above the nods to metals acts are obvious and unmistakable. Not one but two songs
column4: including opener “Wake Up”
column5: crib the subdued psych-murk of Black Sabbath’s “Planet Caravan”
column6: and McCready does his best Jimmy Page on “Lifeless Dead” and pretty much every other song. Led Zeppelin’s influence isn’t merely in his mile-high riffs
column7: but in the relationship between the lead guitar and the rhythm section. The former struts
column8: the latter stomps
column9: but the effect is all too familiar. Mad Season weren’t interpreting these acts
column10: but merely aping them.

column1: Still
column2: the band’s try-anything ethos is commendable and even occasionally exciting. The glam-punk chorus of “I’m Above” makes good use of Staley’s potent sneer. Then the song breaks for a Spanish guitar solo
column3: and the moment is so random that it becomes bracing
column4: as though every possibility remains open to them. That’s what a side project is for
column5: after all. But not once does Above sound like the work of a real side project-- like four guys relieved to be away from their workaday gigs. Despite the success of “River of Deceit” on alt-rock radio
column6: Above was not especially well received in 1995
column7: and Staley notes this fact on the live disc. He berates critics for writing “retarded reviews
column8: ” countering that the band had a “fucking blast” recording the album. Perhaps they did
column9: but the music they made is anything but a blast. These songs are for the most part joyless and strained.

column1: Live
column2: however
column3: Mad Season sound more in their element. What seemed leaden in the studio comes off loose on the stage
column4: as evidenced by recordings of their show at Seattle's Moore Theater on April 29
column6: and footage from their New Year's Eve show later that year. Onstage
column7: “Lifeless Dead” becomes an especially punchy jam
column8: anchored by the tremendous rhythm section
column9: and local saxophone player Skerik vamps and skronks through John Lennon’s “I Don’t Wanna Be a Soldier” as the crowd moshes in slo-mo. The set lags towards the end and dies with a 14-minute version of “November Hotel”
column10: but these guys actually look like they might be having fun up there. McCready even solos with the guitar behind his head. It’s goofy as shit
column11:
but that’s what makes it a highlight: it’s the one moment in the life of Mad Season when someone managed to crack a smile.

“Sufferer (Love My Conqueror)”
column2: a standout on Hiss Golden Messenger’s fourth album
column3: Haw
column4: is ostensibly a folk rock song
column5: but instead of the expected fiddle playing the solo
column6: there’s an disarmingly baroque string section. On the bridge it swoops and bends dramatically
column7: but as the song winds down
column8: the strings split in two
column9: flowing against each other in strange currents and eddies-- not unlike the North Carolina river that gives the album its title. It’s a powerful moment
column10: one that imbues some real drama into a song that functions as a kind of spiritual interrogation. Is God a liberator or a conqueror? Does man rejoice or despair in His dominion? That ornate string section doesn't skirt the question.

column1: Over the last few years
column2: young folk revivalists have turned to traditional American music as a vehicle for spiritual catharsis: Mumford and Sons tick off rousing anthems like they’re punching a clock
column3: the Lumineers engineer pre-industrial sing-alongs
column4: and Old Crow Medicine Show soldier on as a jam-band comprised of historical re-enactors. At its best
column5: this trend imagines pop music as a potentially communal thing
column6: intended for public experience rather than headphones isolation. In less thoughtful incarnations
column7: the nuances of craft are often jettisoned in favor of fervency. Based out of Durham
column8: North Carolina
column9: Hiss Golden Messenger offers a fine corrective to the recent rash of folk anthems: The songs on Haw pose questions rather than offer easy reassurances
column10: and head Messenger M.C. Taylor is more concerned with spiritual doubt than any kind of comforting certainty.

column1: After nearly a decade with the San Francisco Americana act the Court and Spark
column2: Taylor moved from his native California about as far east as he could
column3: settling in the Tarheel State in the late 2000s. With a degree in folklore from UNC
column4: Taylor has a deep knowledge of Southern folk music
column5: especially that of the Piedmont region of North Carolina. But Hiss Golden Messenger is never beholden to tradition. There are shades of Charlie Poole and Charley Patton in these songs
column6: but also tinges of AM Gold country
column7: jazz
column8: rock
column9: and singer-songwriter pop. So “Sufferer (Love My Conqueror)” includes not only that odd string section
column10: but also gentle bursts of rural psychedelia and backing vocals tinged with both gospel and the Gospel. “Cheerwine Easter”
column11: named for a regional soft drink
column12: is gentle country soul with a sturdy beat and
column13: out of nowhere
column14: a low and lovely sax solo courtesy of Bobby Crow.

column1: Haw is fuller and more adventurous even than 2011’s Poor Moon
column2: with a broader musical palette. It feels more rooted in the Piedmont
column3: thanks to a band that includes Megafaun’s Phil Cook
column4: Black Twig Picker Nathan Bowles
column5: and William Tyler. Notwithstanding the album’s spiritual crisis
column6: the best moments on Haw are also some of the most upbeat and celebratory. “I've Got a Name for the Newborn Child” bounces along on Scott Hirsch’s buoyant bassline; in the promise of a new family
column7: the band channels an excitement that most artists reserve for romance. Likewise
column8: Terry Lonergan’s scissoring high-hat beat lends some joyful pomp to “Sweet as John Hurt”
column9: a tribute to the Mississippi bluesman. But Hiss Golden Messenger remains Taylor’s project
column10: and he exhibits a folksy charisma in this central role. His voice flattens out the hard consonants and savors the softer vowels
column11: suggesting a regional dialect from some dark Tarheel holler. He summons immense gravity for the dark “Devotion” just as easily as he conveys a sense of unburdening on “Busted Note”. Rarely does dark doubt sound quite so inviting. Taylor understands that faith-- in God
column12: in music
column13:
in the flow of the Haw-- is more about the struggle than the resolution.

column4: pogoing
column5: sped-up surf-rock rhythm section
column6: while Jennifer's (better known then by her Dracula-esque stage name
column7: Victor Fandgore) signature move was singing (though more often
column8: screaming) into a rotary telephone rigged up like a mic. Three years after their break-up
column9: Mika Miko's legend is established yet ephemeral; like so many underground heroes
column10: they never made a record that quite captured the caterwauling craziness of their live show. Not that they cared: ""I think we come off better live than we do recorded
column11: Jessica said in a 2009 interview
column12: ""It's better to have that impact as a live band though
column13: isn't it?"" The rest of the band nodded in agreement.

column1: It's kind of ironic
column2: then
column3: that Ride Your Heart succeeds precisely where the final Mika Miko album-- the spirited but thin-sounding We Be Xuxa-- failed: it manages to capture some of the infectious energy of the Clavins' live show. The difference is all in the production: Ride Your Heart is lush but still maintains a certain loose
column4: inviting sloppiness
column5: which suits the more upbeat songs particularly well. Opener ""Looking For a Fight"" lurches forward with a grumbling
column6: belligerent swagger
column7: while Jennifer's whiplashed howl on ""Next Stop"" (""Until next tiiiiiime"") makes the song feel like an adrenaline rush: It sounds like she's shouting the whole thing out of a convertible as it zips around a tight corner. Jennifer's vocals sound comparatively stiff and uninspired on ""Dreaming Without You"" (she doesn't find much emotion in the repeated refrain ""Baby
column8: don't cry/ Baby
column9: don't cry"")
column10: but the stomping percussion and guitar solo (which sounds straight out of a Flamin' Groovies track and cuts through like a beam of California sunshine) shakes the song out of its stupor.

column1: Not every song on Ride Your Heart is so lucky. Bleached's songcraft often feels bland and unimaginative
column2: relying on familiar
column3: pop-worn imagery (""Waiting by the Telephone"") and generic declarations of love. (The inert ""Outta My Mind"" doesn't move far beyond its girl-group-revival-by-numbers hook
column4: ""Get out of my mind
column5: boy/ You know I think about you all of the time."") Though there's an electric current coursing through Ride Your Heart
column6:
it's too often wasted on mundane material-- which is especially disappointing given how zany and lyrically imaginative their previous band was. Hopefully more of that signature flair will creep into future Bleached releases: It's hard to be content with them waiting by the telephone when we've seen them scream into it.

The Besnard Lakes make music as elegant as their album titles are clunky. The Montreal quartet’s fourth record
column3: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/advance/58-until-in-excess-imperceptible-ufo/"" target=""_blank"">Until in Excess
column4: Imperceptible UFO
column5: is no exception. The group’s co-auteurs
column6: Jace Lasek and Olga Goreas
column7: approach the construction of Besnard Lakes’ LPs with the same level of fastidiousness that Brian Wilson and Roger Waters displayed on masterworks of studiocraft like Pet Sounds and Dark Side of the Moon. Lasek and Goreas aren’t mere songwriters who produce pop tunes; they are composers who create musical suites out of sweepingly melodic movements. Until in Excess is the most “composed” Besnard Lakes’ album yet-- the band worked on different sections of the album’s eight songs
column8: and shifted them around like puzzle pieces until achieving the perfect specimens of epic-osity that Lasek and Goreas heard echoing like an interstellar church choir in their heads.

column1: Which is to say
column2: Until in Excess more or less delivers on the “wow” factor one has come to expect from a Besnard Lakes album. As with 2007’s The Besnard Lakes are the Dark Horse and 2010’s The Besnard Lakes are the Roaring Night
column3: Until in Excess doesn’t skimp on the creamy vocal harmonies
column4: booming drum rattles
column5: cinematic strings swooshes
column6: and wicked David Gilmour guitar solos that explode out of the murk with dependably dramatic elan. Well
column7: actually
column8: there aren’t that many guitar solos on Until the Excess: “People of the Sticks” climaxes with some awe-inspiring six-string heroics by Lasek
column9: as does the slow-building “Colour Yr Lights In”
column10: where the squiggly arpeggios lift the anthemic chorus to the precipice of prog-rock nirvana. But aside from the heavy riffing that grinds throughout “At Midnight”
column11: rock music takes a backseat to loftier ambitions on Until in Excess. Lasek and Goreas instead turn the uplifting expressiveness that Besnard Lakes is known for in on itself
column12: fostering a mood of introspective melancholy on a series of slow
column13: orchestral-like pieces.

column1: Most of Until in Excess resembles “Catalina”
column2: a beautiful slow-motion shoegazer symphony that lards on nearly two minutes of introductory new-age synths before easing into the glimmering
column3: mid-tempo meat of the track. Besnard Lakes reliably fill the vastness of their huge-sounding music with immaculate musical ornamentation
column4: and “Catalina” is a fine example of their impeccable Canadian architecture. (Look out for the dreamy surf-guitar accents laid out delicately in the mix that don’t make themselves fully discernible until the third or fourth listen.) “The Specter” is another stunner
column5: opening with a splashy electric keyboard lick that soon gives way for exquisite guitar-driven counter-melodies and spectral mellotron washes. Neither track seems all that concerned with chorus-verse orderliness
column6: which suits a record that favors atmosphere over punchy songs.

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: Until in Excess is another Besnard Lakes’ album album that stubbornly demands to be absorbed all at once
column4: from beginning to end. Other than “People of the Sticks”
column5: the individual songs haven’t been designed to stick out from the whole; the deliberate pace makes the entirety of Until in Excess feel like one long
column6: woozy track. While the winking title doesn’t exactly do the album justice-- it’s not as “excessive” so much as “dense”-- Until in Excess does lack some of the immediacy of Besnard Lakes’ other records. The album closing “Alamogordo” ends with three attention-killing minutes of ambient noise
column7: finally wearing out the welcome for an otherwise captivating collection. For all its beauty
column8: Until in Excess is a little draggy; the balance of ethereal grace and all-out force that distinguished their breakout Dark Horse has tipped a little too far to the ponderous side. Until in Excess rewards patience
column9:
but the roar of old is missed.

The title is sadly accurate. Lil Wayne is a full-blown cottage industry now
column2: a one-man corporation that provides succor and service to careers ranging from Nicki Minaj and Drake’s to Gudda Gudda and Lil Chuckee’s. With this many shareholders come obligations
column3: so despite the increasingly obvious and pressing personal needs of Dwayne Carter the man
column4: Lil Wayne Inc. steamrolls forward
column5: impervious to setbacks. When Carter landed in the ICU for six frightening days this month
column6: after seizures that many assumed were related to his ongoing
column7: years-documented problems with codeine addiction
column8: his handlers smoothed things over with the panicked dissembling of hangers-on propping up an ailing dictator. After his release
column9: Wayne gave a thumbs up to TMZ cameras to allay fears
column10: announcing he was “better than good.” He did look good
column11: but he also
column12: tellingly
column13: shrugged and offered this: “My bum-ass album is coming out... March 26? It's 26?...You’re gonna get that shit or you won’t. If not
column14: it’s whatever.”

column1: This spirit of indifference hangs heavy on I Am Not A Human Being II. In his review of 2011’s Tha Carter IV
column2: Ryan Dombal observed that ""after an epic run
column3: it seems as though Wayne has finally run out of inventive ways to say he's on drugs
column4: or great at sex
column5: or extremely interested in making money
column6: ” and two years later
column7: the prognosis has only grown more grim: No song on IIis meaningfully distinguishable from the next. Everything pumps out in an undifferentiated slurry of interchangeable dick jokes
column8: drug references
column9: and lame puns. Tha Carter IV moved nearly a million copies in a single week
column10: and this staggering success may have sealed Wayne’s artistic fate.

column1: All of the quirks and peculiarities that once made Wayne great have hardened
column2: six or seven years later
column3: into nearly unbearable tics. All of his lyrics have devolved into barely rearranged little puzzles of themselves
column4: with countless versions of his ""She ride/ Take this dick like ___” formulation
column5: none of them funny or creative: On “IANAHB”
column6: a woman takes it like “advice
column7: ” while others ride it like both ""go-karts"" and ""the Kentucky Derby"" on ""Curtains”. His tweaking of gangsta-rap’s language has never been more perfunctory. He sounds terminally bored
column8: and even the better rap songs on here-- the hits
column9: like the Mike Will Made It-produced
column10: Future-and-Drake-featuring “Bitches Love Me” or the rubbery
column11: Bay Area-influenced clap of “Rich As Fuck”-- work around him
column12: not with him.

column1: The only moments where Wayne sounds marginally interested in his own music come when he veers furthest away from rap. On “Romance”
column2: he sings in his croaky
column3: limber way about his profane version of love while Cool & Dre’s synthesizers smear like bionic fireflies: “She kissed my ankle when I twist my ankle/ She even did anal when she don't do anal.” On the big
column4: clomping pop rock of ""Back To You”
column5: his voice is a shpritz of Lil Wayne on the surface of a towering club-pop production
column6: the kind that mashes together the respective sugar highs of Euro club-pop
column7: hair-metal
column8: and synth pop into a glutinous ball (If you’re wondering whose sampled voice that is crooning at the bottom of all that mess
column9: by the way
column10: it’s Jamie Lidell’s.) This might not be the most promising future to ponder for Wayne’s music
column11: but they’re the moments he sounds happiest: as a cog in a much bigger machine than himself
column12:
set free from being the all-consuming center for the first time.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18903/homepage_large.21522578.jpg|The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012|1752.0|Goldie|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['FFRR']|2013-03-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:45.924662|"

There was a point in the late 90s where it looked like Clifford Price
column2: aka Goldie
column3: might be the first dance music artist to become a full-on mainstream megastar. With rock music in its post-Cobain slump and hip-hop’s bling period in full swing
column4: some people were certain that pop music’s next messiah would come out of what everyone was calling the “electronica” community
column5: and Price seemed to fit the bill. After his 1995 debut album Timeless became the most popular drum'n'bass record yet
column6: he was the biggest thing in the coolest kind of dance music
column7: and with his acting roles
column8: high-profile romantic relationship with Björk
column9: and distinctive futuristic gangster-punk image he displayed an obvious talent for doing superstar-ish things. Even Noel Gallagher
column10: who’s never been an outspoken fan of non-guitar-based music
column11: appeared on his second album
column12: a sprawling double album that underlined how well Price fit the established idea of a pop star.

column1: But even though Price looked like a superstar and acted like a superstar
column2: he didn’t sound like one. It’s not that he lacked for pop instincts-- his collaboration with Gallagher was an amply-hooked
column3: razor-sharp fusion of drum'n'bass and punk rock-- his artistic vision was based around hard
column4: uncompromising beats and grandiose aesthetic statements like songs with hour-long running times. He would have been the perfect premillennial video star
column5: if only he wasn’t so intent on making music that would alienate MTV viewers.

column1: Compared to the big
column2: broad
column3: gregarious sounds of big beat artists like Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers who were doing the best job of selling mainstream American on electronic dance music
column4: drum'n'bass seemed downright antisocial. The 160 BPM that the average d&b track clocked in at was far outside the comfort zone for most pop ears
column5: with breaks that were designed to keep a listener from getting too comfortable with a groove. And its makers and fans tended to prefer the shadows to the spotlight
column6: both metaphorically and literally-- the London clubs the scene coalesced around were pioneers of anti-promotion
column7: and their dance floors were often underlit to the point of near-total darkness.

column1: And for all of his apparent pop ambition
column2: Price was one of the biggest proponents of this aspect. The Metalheadz crew he headed up was considered the gold standard for bafflingly complex beats built with a minimum of moving parts and for basslines that dove down to frequencies that could only be reproduced on extremely high-end sound systems-- even then they were more felt than heard. Its skull-with-headphones logo served a role as something like the Jesus Fish for hardcore drum'n'bass freaks. Goldie may have wanted to go big
column3: but only on his own radical terms.

column1: It turned out that rock had at least one more comeback in it
column2: Jay-Z and Missy Elliott had been just waiting for a chance to make hip-hop cooler and weirder than it had ever been
column3: and the “electronica” revolution wouldn’t happen for another decade
column4: by which time it had been rebranded “EDM.” drum'n'bass itself never got a foothold in America outside of car commercials and action movie chase sequences
column5: and as the form mutated into 2-step and dubstep Price slowed his previously hectic release schedule back to a trickle and devoted himself to appearing on a variety of British reality TV shows.

column1: Drum'n'bass is overdue for a real revival
column2: though. In the wake of dubstep getting Skrillex-ified a few producers tried heading back to the genre’s antecedent
column3: but the movement never managed to reach critical mass. The two discs of the new anthology The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012 covering the span of Price’s career make a compelling argument that the world may finally be ready for him.

column1: Disc two
column2: which emphasizes Price’s jazzier
column3: more tuneful side is decent. In his mellower moments he indulges in a taste for 70s soul
column4: but he often verges on smooth jazz
column5: and his choice in vocalists runs toward the workmanlike. The third disc
column6: which collects remixes of his work done by other artists
column7: has more than its fair share of moments
column8: although few feel essential. But it’s the first disc
column9: focussing on his darker
column10: more hard-edged material
column11: where Price’s considerable allure snaps back into focus after years of looking increasingly irrelevant.

column1: Some of drum'n'bass’ appeal has always been its potential to overwhelm the listener
column2: usually through its hyperfast breakbeats and physically aggressive sub bass. The first disc of The Alchemist
column3: though
column4: is stunning in its gracefulness. Price balances the style’s assertive elements with slashes of ambient atmospherics
column5: its headbanging tendencies with dubby mellow vibes
column6: and a particular kind of deeply nocturnal feel that’s frequently referred to as “icy” with a warm human heartbeat. It’s the rare career retrospective that not only sounds good for the time it was recorded during
column7: but sounds good for right now.

column1: Listening to a track like 1992’s “Terminator”
column2: credited to his Rufige Kru
column3: it’s obvious why Price never became the megastar some people hoped he’d be. The song has grace and balance
column4: but repeatedly alternates between a hyperspeed beat based on the Amen break and drawn-out moments of ambient freefall
column5: teasing the listener with rhythmic feints and jabs that won’t let them find their balance. By the time a cluster of ravey synth stabs drops in halfway through it almost seems like a taunt
column6: a reminder of the relative normalcy of an average house track. It’s a mean song
column7: but it’s so well designed that being batted around by it is a pleasure. And after two decades after its release it doesn’t sound any less alien
column8:
or any less perfect.

Vondelpark learned the virtues of patience the hard way. In 2009
column3: when the UK trio's members were still well within their teens
column4: their melodramatically doomy band Lion Club scored what must've felt like a huge break: Converse picked them to be the subjects of a 50-minute documentary on the travails of being in an emerging rock group. It isn't clear exactly what happened next
column5: but tastes change
column6: talent matures
column7: and by August 2010
column8: Vice posted a (no-longer-online) interview cheekily titled
column9: ""Vondelpark Has No MySpace
column10: So You Can Only Learn About Him Here."" A few months later
column11: Vondelpark released the first of two EPs.

column1: I bring up this history to reinforce how impressive Vondelpark's transformation has been. When singer
column2: multi-instrumentalist
column3: and producer Lewis Rainsbury told Pitchfork's Ryan Dombal that Rainsbury
column4: guitarist/bassist Alex Bailey
column5: and keyboardist Matt Law are ""really the first band"" on electronic-oriented Belgian label R&S
column6: he wasn't kidding about the band part. Seabed is the fullest realization yet of the project's immersive smoothness
column7: but what helps Vondelpark's debut album stand out in a deluge of ""Radiohead quietstorm"" is that full-band quality
column8: the organic fluidity of a unit who've been playing together for years.

column1: These days Vondelpark are so unhurried it's almost counterproductive. Seabed arrives at a time when late-night
column2: half-lit
column3: occasionally blue-eyed R&B
column4: often with the disembodied samples and digital silences of UK bass music
column5: has grown so abundant it wouldn't be entirely unreasonable to throw up your hands and go back to old Sade and Burial records instead. But Vondelpark's gradually acquired sense of restraint is so crucial to the album that its slightly overdue release timing feels symbolically appropriate
column6: like the bass that falls behind the beat throughout D'Angelo's surrealistic-soul touchstone Voodoo. When you're eyeing the long haul
column7: there's no rush.

column1: Seabed stretches out in a state of ecstatically aching limbo
column2: gazing at the groove instead of shoes. The record's expansive sense of chronology manifests its in the first seconds of swaying ethereal opener ""Quest""
column3: as Rainsbury
column4: in his mumbly croon
column5: keeps doubling back over his thoughts about growing old and flying to the moon. The title track describes a melancholy romantic holding pattern-- ""I won't say it
column6: if you won't say it ... You will realize""-- as subdued synth-funk cycles toward its own just-out-of-reach epiphany. The largely beatless ""Closer""
column7: where Rainsbury vows he's ""never getting off this rollercoaster
column8: conjures a weightlessness that's more astronaut than amusement-park free-fall.

column1: In true Vondelpark style
column2: Seabed is less a vast improvement on its predecessors than a subtle refinement. ""California Analog Dream""
column3: reworked from 2010's Sauna EP
column4: adds ghostly harmonica and a more pristinely recorded acoustic guitar
column5: bringing the song's San Diego fantasy closer to classic 1980s UK indie-pop. But the dubwise horns and beatific bongos of 2011's nyc stuff and nyc bags EP
column6: itself more polished than the debut
column7: quite rightly led Pitchfork's Hari Ashurst to cite the sadly defunct Air France
column8: who also mixed indie-pop vulnerability with sonic luxuriance. The pacific glow of Aretha Franklin-sampling ""Bananas (On My Biceps)"" has little more than a title in common with Sauna's grittier ""Backflip (In the Sauna)""
column9: but the clean keys and distended drums of ""Outro 4 Ariel"" wouldn't be out of place on nyc stuff's ""Outro for NYC"".

column1: Rainsbury
column2: Bailey
column3: and Law showed long ago that they could draw a crowd with a bold gesture
column4: but Seabed's appeal after multiple listens is in its details. Bailey told London in Stereo his favorite song on the record is ""Blue Again""
column5: a mood piece with melismatic
column6: near-incomprehensible vocals
column7: a crisp drum pattern that comes perilously close to smooth jazz
column8: and a strangely familiar
column9: pinging sound that's like an Apple computer telling you the cursor has gone too far. ""Dracula""
column10: which submerges itself in sub-bass-y self-loathing
column11: is no less appealing. But the most enduring track might also be the record's most overtly romantic: ""Always Forever""
column12: a Drake-inspired dip into Mellow Mellow territory
column13: where lyrical ""tripping"" suggests lovestruck clumsiness as much as psychedelics
column14: and Rainsbury's ""just saying"" that you're having
column15: he's having
column16: a time (the time?) ""of your life
column17:
so ""go on."" Much the same could be hoped for this studied young band.

As a co-founder of Brooklyn’s Dutty Artz collective alongside globe-trotting ethnomusicologist DJ/rupture
column2: Matt Shadetek is no stranger to international cratedigging. The label's grown to be regarded as a great educator in global beats and dance cultures: Hispanic traditions of cumbia and bachata
column3: Jamaican dancehall
column4: Angolan kuduro
column5: and so on. In turn
column6: Dutty Artz has developed a reputation for fostering older
column7: lesser recognized sounds
column8: and fusing them together to build something new and relevant. Often their DJs are informally delegated the task of exploring their own musical roots; Chief Boima is a stan in African dance music
column9: Geko and Uproot Andy are well versed in Latin music. And with The Empire Never Ended
column10: Matt Shadetek
column11: born and raised in New York City
column12: puts aside his wide-cast net to release an album of hip-hop instrumentals.

column1: Though surprising at first
column2: it's not an entirely offbeat turn. Shadetek has been revisiting his love of hip-hop over the last year
column3: releasing “Giddy Up”
column4: a self-described banjee rap track starring Le1f
column5: and “La Vida Loca” with Fabolous and Pusha T collaborator
column6: up-and-comer Troy Ave. The latter makes it onto the album and its piercing
column7: soaring synth wails and big orchestral melodies serve as a primer for the record's larger theme. A product of the early days of New York hip-hop
column8: clubbing at legendary drum-n-bass
column9: jungle
column10: dubstep
column11: and garage party Konkrete Jungle
column12: and a stint living in Berlin
column13: Shadetek hasn’t entirely succumbed to any single trend or genre. He has
column14: however
column15: beefed up his drum machines with snares and hi-hats instead of dem-bow riddims and reggae grooves
column16: and taken a few stylistic notes from Lex Luger to make a hip-hop record with horizons wider than just New York City. He does so with flair.

column1: A large chunk of this album contains trap instrumentals
column2: but Shadetek chooses subtlety in place of someone like Waka's in-your-face approach
column3: turning the collection into a psychedelic journey that’s best for headphone listening. On opener “Visions”
column4: a muddied voice chants as fluttering bleeps accent the trudging drums. “Jaguar” plays out similarly
column5: but with added menace. “Logos” turns rolling snares and syncopated bass kicks into a cinematic scoring for a grim walk through city streets-- then unexpectedly launches into a frenetic dancehall riddim played out via buzzing
column6: pitched-down synths while pushing the snares and bass toward rollicking insanity. Then there’s “Madness”
column7: one of the album’s highlights and a testament to Shadetek’s production know-how. (He also teaches production at NYC’s Dubspot DJ school.) It’s a gorgeously lush orchestration where bloated wubs of bass bolster forlorn synths and a kick-drum. The warped vocal loop becomes a stoner's anthem and a drunken
column8: lovelorn sentiment in one.

column1: As far as the tracks with actual MCs rapping over the instrumentals
column2: ""Psychomatic""
column3: featuring Chan Dizzy and Stratdon
column4: plays out as a dubstep-infected take on R&B. And then there's Riff Raff
column5: whose appearance on ""Bout It Girl"" is wildly confusing but somehow makes the song a standout of the 12 tracks. Its druggy
column6: screwed hook and minimal snaps make the perfect background to Raff's sharp lines
column7: like ""Pop a pill with either hand/ I'm ambidextrous."" Let's not forget that DJ/rupture put out an album with James Franco a few years back. Organized confusion is part of the point here: The album’s title comes from Philip K. Dick’s Valis
column8:
in which the author falls into crisis over the basic nature of reality and meaning. This thing has come full circle.

As Generationals

column3: it's difficult not to yearn for a bit more razzle-dazzle on Heza. True
column4: the album's careful production
column5: inventive percussion
column6: and refreshing marriage of organic and electronic sounds hint at an impressive confidence that's still very much a part of the pair's personality. But they're still a competent
column7: talented
column8:
charming band instead of a truly memorable one.
