column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18989/homepage_large.9f6c56cd.jpg|Delta Machine|1063.0|Depeche Mode|['Rock'
column2: 'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute'
column3:
'Columbia']|2013-03-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:48.371343|"

People who make machines use the term ""delta"" to mean ""change."" Depeche Mode aren't so keen on that any more. Another kind of delta is the home of a strain of blues that's associated with more intense emotion and simpler technology than the synth-pop that made Depeche Mode famous. They got interested in playing with that kind a couple of decades ago
column4: and it served them well
column5: at first.

column1: But the partnership of singer David Gahan and songwriter Martin Gore can't escape the machine they've become
column2: or the holding pattern they've gotten stuck in. (And then there's third member Andy Fletcher
column3: who...Anyway!) The last album they made with more than two songs that have persisted in their live repertoire was Songs of Faith and Devotion in 1993. Since then
column4: they've been on a steady regimen of releasing a studio record every fourth year
column5: followed by a tour where they play a whole lot of songs from the era when Designing Women was on the air.

column1: Delta Machine
column2: like Playing the Angel and Sounds of the Universe before it
column3: was produced by Ben Hillier
column4: includes three songs with lyrics by Gahan
column5: and sounds like it could be a set of outtakes from Songs of Faith and Devotion. The word ""soul"" appears in five of Gore's songs here
column6: not including ""Angel"" or ""Heaven"" (which shouldn't be confused with the earlier ""Halo"" or ""Judas"" or ""Sacred"" or ""Jezebel"" or ""Martyr""). It's old news that Gore's favorite lyrical topic is sin and salvation
column7: and that's historically been a pretty fertile topic for songwriting in general. Unfortunately
column8: there's no line here as sly as ""Strangelove""'s ""I give in to sin/ Because you have to make this life livable
column9: and no sense that Gore's idea of sin extends to anything other than mildly kinky sex.

column1: Then there's the blues stuff
column2: i.e. loops of bluesy guitar licks
column3: as on ""Goodbye"" (which might just as well be called ""Personal Jesus XIV: The Personalizing""). Another one turns up in ""Slow""
column4: repeating endlessly as Gahan sings Gore's lyrics about taking it nice and easy in bed these days. The requisite Gore vocal here
column5: ""The Child Inside""
column6: might have the most embarrassing extended metaphor he's committed to date (tears turn into a river that overflows and drowns the loved one's inner child?). As for Gahan's own songs-- this time
column7: their music is by Kurt Uenala-- they're generally a reasonably convincing imitation of middling Gore. His ""Should Be Higher"" is yet another on the pile of ex-junkie lyrics; his ""Broken"" is a pale Silly Putty copy of ""Behind the Wheel"".

column1: It's not a totally dull record. Gahan and Gore are singing as well and hyperdramatically as they ever have. ""My Little Universe"" is a clever piece of minimalism
column2: constructed around a bare handful of acid-synth riffs-- effectively a companion piece to their 30-year-old ""Leave in Silence"". ""Soft Touch/Raw Nerve"" is catchy enough that its rhyme of ""helping hand"" with ""understand"" is forgivable. ""Angel"" will sound pretty good on their next greatest-hits collection
column3: as long as they don't sequence it too close to ""I Feel You"".

column1: Still
column2: what made Depeche Mode work
column3: when they worked
column4: wasn't just the contrast between Gore's dry detachment and Gahan's dorky innocence (up to
column5: let's say
column6: Music for the Masses) and the late-breaking badassery that replaced it (from Violator onward). It was their constant pushing forward of their sound-- expanding the vocabulary of what electronics could do in pop songs. Their records were packed with cross-talking hooks
column7: ingeniously knotted melodies
column8: noises that blurred the border between pitch and percussion. They made rules for themselves
column9: which made it more fun when they broke them.

column1: But they stopped pushing forward long ago
column2: and now they don't even bother pretending technology has opened up any possibilities for recorded sound in the past 20 years. Now they're just extruding a new album once in a while
column3: reconfiguring the grooves and keywords of the albums from the period when they were a force in pop
column4: without the push toward new noises and uncertain feelings that made that music powerful. There is not a single moment of shock or freshness on Delta Machine
column5:
and it's enormously frustrating to hear what was once a band of futurists so deeply mired in resisting change.

"|17792.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17792-depeche-mode-delta-machine/|5.0|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19000/homepage_large.2ee58f54.jpg|The Julius Eastman Memory Depot|24956.0|Jace Clayton|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New Amsterdam']|2013-03-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:48.892671|"

The composer Julius Eastman lived his life veering between irreconcilable extremes. A pioneering figure in minimalism and an influential member of the 1980s Downtown New York scene
column2: Eastman studied at the Curtis Institute
column3: sang with Meredith Monk on <i>Dolmen Music
column4: sat on symposia with Morton Feldman and John Cage. He also battled alcoholism and crack addiction and lived the last months of his life homeless
column5: rattling between Manhattan's Tompkins Square Park and a shelter in Buffalo. When he passed away
column6: alone
column7: some of his closest friends and associates did not know of his death until months afterward. The potted-history of his life story is of a promising
column8: mercurial talent who thrashed himself apart trying to live too many contradictions.

column1: A black
column2: gay man rattling around loudly in the white
column3: constrained world of classical music
column4: Eastman was a living testament to unbounded American opportunity and woeful American inequality. To describe him in stridently political language is not to hang an unwanted frame around him; Eastman saw himself this way
column5: and discussed his music and life explicitly in those terms. He was
column6: by most accounts
column7: an acrid
column8: seething
column9: and occasionally impossible man
column10: a temperament you can detect in his music as far away as the titles themselves: ""If You're So Smart
column11: Why Aren't You Rich"". ""Evil Nigger"". ""Gay Guerrilla"". The language was so acidic it ate away at the concert-hall universe like stomach lining
column12: a fitting gesture for someone who saw as much rank hypocrisy as opportunity within its walls.

column1: This is a difficult
column2: self-annihilating temperament to pay proper tribute to. On The Julius Eastman Memory Depot
column3: Jace Clayton-- better and more-often known as DJ/rupture-- goes about it exactly the right way. ""Reverence can be a kind of forgetting
column4: he writes in the album's liner notes
column5: and Memory Depot meets Eastman on his own slanted playground
column6: toasting to acid with acid.""Evil Nigger"" and ""Gay Guerrilla""
column7: two solo piano pieces from 1979
column8: form the core of the album
column9: performed here by David Friend and Emily Manzo. Clayton feeds the results of their performances directly into his laptop and scrambles them
column10: spitting out a third stream of input that is often altered beyond recognition. You can never quite tell
column11: listening to the album
column12: where the sounds are originating; the sound is a tempest with no center. The result honors the intentions behind Eastman's trickster spirit to the point that Clayton and Eastman seem very much to be making this music together in real time.

column1: Clayton's take on ""Evil Nigger"" begins with a stammering single note on piano that gets its resonance choked off
column2: until it's just a hammer hitting in dead space. The piece's smallest piece of DNA is a jittery
column3: repetitive nervous trill
column4: and Clayton sends this little figure through a series of frightening transformations: the trill jingles like glass shards in a grocery bag in the second
column5: dissipates into queasy smoke in the third
column6: flits through irradiated air like mutant fireflies in the fourth. In the fourth movement
column7: it's nearly swallowed by a forbidding boom of undertones that well up from the echo of the piano's foot pedals; Clayton pans this roar back and forth in your headphones until it sounds like an air raid. The effect is not so much ""prepared piano"" as ""piano cut free from the time/space continuum.""

column1: The second work Clayton dissects
column2: ""Gay Guerrilla""
column3: has the name of a manifesto
column4: and Eastman once said of its title
column5: ""Without blood there is no cause. I use 'Gay Guerrilla' in hopes that I might be one
column6: if called up to be one."" But the piece
column7: which contains a reinterpretation of the Martin Luther hymn ""A Mighty Fortress Is Our God
column8: feels less like a call to arms than a meditation. Leaning hard into the piano pedals
column9: pianists Friend and Manzo build a calmly hurtling sense of forward motion that is similar to John Adams' ""Hallelujah Junction"". As the sound of the piano starts to leech out bits of its essence in the recording
column10: it becomes
column11: steadily
column12: a music of ghosts. Considering both the state of the NYC gay community during Eastman's life
column13: and how Eastman spent the last few years of his own
column14: the feeling is mournfully appropriate.

column1: Clayton contributes one original piece to Julius Eastman Memory Depot. The ""Callback from the American Society of Eastman Supporters"" posits a different outcome for the memory of Julius Eastman
column2: a world where supporters of Eastman are so legion that they are turned away via robo-call. ""The Julius Eastman Memorial Dinner is an equal-opportunity employer
column3: the narrator (sung by Sufi vocalist Arooj Aftab) chirps brightly
column4: before the piece breaks open into a cool-blue drone and meditation. ""Regardless of age
column5: regardless of race
column6: regardless of color
column7: regardless of creed and disability
column8: sexual orientation
column9: political affiliation"" Aftab sings
column10: searchingly. It is a supremely Julius-Eastman moment
column11: a short sharp bark of wry laughter fading into dead seriousness
column12: and it caps Clayton's searingly immediate communion with Eastman's vital
column13:
contrary spirit.

"|17803.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17803-jace-clayton-the-julius-eastman-memory-depot/|7.8|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18944/homepage_large.711fee94.jpg|Dormarion|27725.0|Telekinesis|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2013-03-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:49.545889|"

To paraphrase Sam ""Ace"" Rothstein
column2: Michael Benjamin Lerner’s voice is like an emotional car wash. No matter what Lerner is singing about
column3: it all comes out sounding clean
column4: winsome
column5: and nice. It’s a good voice for the music he makes as Telekinesis-- the power-pop blueprint has long relied on boyish dudes who can turn their inner misery into sunny songs
column6: and Lerner’s pipes puts him squarely in the tradition of brooding tunesmiths like Matthew Sweet and Fountains of Wayne’s Chris Collingwood. But Lerner’s soft tenor also tends to cleanse his music of any semblance of tension or grit or personality.

column1: Telekinesis’ third album Dormarion is Lerner’s best
column2: most bountifiul to date. At 35 minutes
column3: it’s the longest Telekinesis record by approximately 150 seconds. Sonically
column4: Lerner veers into synth-pop on alluring tracks like the billowy “Ghosts and Creatures” and the near-danceable “Ever True”
column5: and flirts with toned-down hard rock on the magnetic start-stop riff of “Little Hill”. Trading in Chris Walla (who produced the first two Telekinesis LPs) for Spoon’s Jim Eno
column6: Lerner has made Dormarion sound grander and tougher than his old records; he’s looking outside his modest melodic pop-rock for the first time while adding some heft to his always solid melodies. In the studio
column7: Lerner handles almost all of the instruments (though Eno supplies his Bonham-like timekeeping to several tracks)
column8: but Dormarion sounds like it was conceived for his road band. As grabby as the New Order-like “Wires” is on record
column9: the big drums and insinuating bassline ought to get hips swinging when Telekinesis plays it live.

column1: Musically
column2: Lerner has broadened his range of dynamics. But tonally
column3: Dormarion is a little flat. Opening track “Power Lines” has the standard Telekinesis structure: A quiet acoustic verse
column4: an explosive chorus
column5: and Lerner’s sweet vocal confessing bitter truths. “I’m a broken man
column6: ” he sings. “I’m damaged goods.” Several tracks later
column7: the low-key jangler “Lean on Me” is selling fantasies of idealized domestic bliss: “We could cross the country in our beat-up truck/ stopping every minute because the thing don’t run/ but I don’t care because we’re in love.” Lerner’s delivery is the same on both songs-- happy or sad
column8: he sounds blank. He’s like a narrator with no vocal inflections
column9: which makes accessing something resembling an emotional core beyond the surface beauty of the songs very difficult.

column1: If Dormarion is a record of superficial pleasures
column2: at least those pleasures are considerable. As a craftsman
column3: Lerner must be counted among the best young pop songwriters working in contemporary indie rock. At his best
column4: like on “Wires”
column5: he offers a wealth of hooks in the verse
column6: chorus
column7: and bridge. There’s no question he can put a good tune together; what’s less clear is whether he can interpret those tunes as well as he writes them
column8:
and breathe a little flesh-and-blood human messiness into them in the process.

"|17748.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17748-telekinesis-dormarion/|6.9|Steven Hyden

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18992/homepage_large.1dfae9e2.jpg|Nostalchic|30171.0|Lapalux|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brainfeeder']|2013-03-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:50.154492|"

Lapalux stands out as one of the more accessible producers on Flying Lotus’s Brainfeeder label
column2: making music that skews closer to pop than much of the hybridized production the label is known for. The Essex native
column3: born Stuart Howard
column4: showed himself to be a savvy deconstructionist on a pair of 2012 EPs. He took the raw ingredients of offbeat pop songs--melodic backbone
column5: diaphonous vocals
column6: clattering drumlines-- and shuffled them to create IDM tracks that felt inventive and accessible. He's using similar tricks on his debut album Nostalchic
column7: while moving from deconstructed pop to a more relaxed brand of R&B and soul
column8: both genres that complement Howard's consistent interest in texture.

column1: On Lapalux’s first two Brainfeeder projects
column2: When You’re Gone and Some Other Time
column3: you could hear the 25-year old producer cautiously experimenting with new ideas
column4: working within traditional structures even as he experimented with outré sounds. He’s more confident on Nostalchic
column5: walking the line between chaos and stability to create a sound that resembles a jittery
column6: discombobulated version of chillwave. Brainfeeder's Hip-Hop Beats N' Bass blueprint is still present
column7: but it isn't the focus on the album. Instead
column8: on tracks like the back-to-back standouts ""Flower"" and ""Swallowing Smoke""
column9: Howard's working with a hundred little slivers of the same core melody
column10: rearranging them again and again by attaching them to different portions of the beat until
column11: by the end of the song
column12: they fit together smoothly. It's sampling as fine art-- as precise and painstaking as a mosaic.

column1: With all these separate elements floating around
column2: it's possible for things to get a little too messy. ""Kelly Brook"" is muddled and unpleasant
column3: shot through with sounds that don't make sense with each other. It's as if the pieces of several different songs were never properly separated and it’s one of the few moments on the album where Howard doesn’t appear to be in total control.

column1: Vocalists appear throughout Nostalchic
column2: serving as amplified versions of their sampled counterparts from the guest-free tracks. Though Jenna Andrews has a strong showing on the languorous “One Thing” and Kerry Leatham’s distorted voice adds depth to the standout “Without You”
column3: Lapalux is actually his own most reliable performer. On “Walking Words” he's familiar enough with the beat to insert what sounds like his own murmurs and distortion directly into the spaces available and his vocal ends up mimicking the track's motion perfectly.

column1: With a name like Nostalchic
column2: you might assume that Howard is trying to conjure something from the past
column3: to produce the sonic equivalent of immaculate vintage clothing. The sentiments expressed on the album are in keeping with that concept: the lyrics
column4: where they exist
column5: tend to keep things simple with messages like “Do you want to dance?” and “I want to make love.” But
column6: keeping solidly in line with the Brainfeeder tradition
column7: Nostalchic is a forward-looking album
column8:
warm and comfortable but never obvious. 

"|17795.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17795-lapalux-nostalchic/|7.4|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19056/homepage_large.5dd5148a.jpg|The Devil's Dream: Alan Lomax's 1942 Library of Congress Recordings|31164.0|Sid Hemphill|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Global Jukebox']|2013-03-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:50.730452|"

In The Land Where the Blues Began
column2: the folklorist Alan Lomax recalls his epic field-recording voyage through the Mississippi Delta in the early 40s
column3: undertaken at a time when
column4: for Lomax
column5: the stakes felt particularly high. “I knew this was to be my last song-collecting jaunt before the Army got me
column6: maybe the last time I would ever hear the alley blues and the hallelujah spirituals that I believe are the best art our country has produced
column7: ” he wrote
column8: and not without discernible yearning. That urgency would eventually yield the first recordings of Muddy Waters and Honeyboy Edwards
column9: and the first recordings of Son House since his Paramount days
column10: but it’s hard not to feel like Lomax’s desperation-- for ferocity
column11: inventiveness
column12: some kind of rapture-- was probably best assuaged by his discovery of Sid Hemphill
column13: the so-called “boar-hog musician of the hills
column14: ” a fiddler and string band-leader once described to Lomax as “the best musician in the world.”

column1: Lomax found Hemphill in Senatobia
column2: deep in Mississippi’s Hill Country. He’d driven across a crumbling bridge and approached a “sagging
column3: unpainted door on a weathered-gray
column4: warping house.” Before he could knock
column5: Hemphill
column6: then 65
column7: swung it open. “No one had told me that Sid Hemphill was blind
column8: but it was the last thing you’d recall about him
column9: ” Lomax explained. “His face blazed with inner light.”

column1: On August 15
column3: Lomax committed 15 tracks by Hemphill and his backing band (Lucius Smith
column4: Alec “Turpentine” Askew
column5: and Will Head) to acetate disc. Hemphill never recorded commercially
column6: and only Lomax’s field recordings of his work are extant-- meaning that unless you knew a guy (shoddy cassette tapes of Hemphill’s songs
column7: sourced from Lomax’s discs
column8: have been spotted in the damp palms of 78 collectors for decades
column9: passed about like contraband)
column10: The Devil’s Dream is the first time anyone has been properly able to access or disseminate Hemphill’s brain-scrambling yawp. The album’s release this month
column11: over 70 years after its creation-- as a download through the Alan Lomax Archive’s Global Jukebox imprint
column12: or on LP via Mississippi Records-- feels both long overdue and right on time.

column1: Hemphill’s masterwork is “The Carrier Line”
column2: a rambling
column3: six-minute blues ballad about the owner of a local logging railroad and the engineer who ran his train too fast. “You want me to put the whole 21 verses in it?” Hemphill asks Lomax before raising his fiddle and announcing himself. “Sid Hemphill! ""Carrier Song"" was made and played by him
column4: his band!”

column1: There is a wildness to Hemphill’s voice and playing that feels undeniable if not fully singular-- every note is vehement
column2: as if it were stampeded into being
column3: as if it might trample you
column4: too
column5: if you don’t start running. Those propulsive
column6: impatient rhythms make “The Carrier Line” feel literal
column7: like an actual train is hurtling towards Hemphill and his band
column8: only Hemphill is too fearless
column9: too punk rock
column10: to flee or even flinch. Elsewhere
column11: Hemphill’s giddiness at playing and being recorded is evident in his voice
column12: and in the half-intelligible yarns he appears to find deeply hilarious. (“Arkansas Traveler” concerns a kid digging a hole and yellow corn and we-don’t-need-no-supper-in-Arkansas; the punch-line is Hemphill shouting “I know a place!” and it’s always funny
column13: for reasons that remain unclear to me
column14: but don’t much matter.) “Keep My Skillet Good and Greasy” is a raunchy
column15: shambling ode to unflappable libido
column16: and it features a heartbreaking (and unexpected) exchange between two of Hemphill’s backers
column17: one of whom is so out of tune he temporarily stops playing (“You must be scared?” a voice asks. There’s a pause. “You must be scared.”)

column1: Hemphill’s work incorporates attributes of the Mississippi Hill Country’s better-known traditions (the droning guitar blues mastered by McDowell
column2: R.L. Burnside
column3: and Junior Kimbrough
column4: and the fife-and-drum music practiced by Otha Turner
column5: Napolian Strickland
column6: and Hemphill himself)
column7: but part of its pre-eminence concerns its inimitability. The title-track
column8: which features vocals
column9: a bass drum
column10: and quills (a handmade instrument crafted from cane reeds that sounds a little like a panpipe
column11: only flatter and more rudimentary) is a battle cry; Hemphill whoops and wheezes like a feral child lost in a shopping mall. It’s hard to imagine a more fundamentally exhilarating three minutes of music.

column1: There are plenty of reasons to lament Hemphill’s relative obscurity
column2: and his subsequent lack of a professional oeuvre: The exuberance of his performance that day (and it is a performance
column3: rendered heartily and with intention) can sometimes obscure his extraordinary acumen as a songwriter
column4: and there are all the expected fidelity issues (Hemphill and his band are often positioned in awkward proximity to the microphone
column5: and are prone to vaguely acrimonious mid-song chit-chat). The songs themselves contain a preposterous numbers of verses
column6: and aren’t short on impious bits.

column1: But then there’s Hemphill
column2: capable of the sorts of noises only generated in extraordinarily compromised positions
column3: of reflecting our most unruly
column4: un-tempered
column5: subsumed exaltations-- and even then
column6:
they don’t ever sound this ecstatic. Or this free.

"|17862.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17862-sid-hemphill-the-devils-dream-alan-lomaxs-1942-library-of-congress-recordings/|8.3|Amanda Petrusich

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18990/homepage_large.22721248.jpg|Amygdala|1201.0|DJ Koze|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Pampa']|2013-03-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:51.317289|"

Stefan Kozella is a whimsical guy. His music
column2: from his early hip-hop moment through to his minimal techno heyday
column3: has always been suffused with warm psychedelic colour. He brings that touch to his renowned remixes
column4: where he reshapes the tracks of others in ways that would seem totally foreign to most. His first solo album in nine years
column5: Amygdala appears after a quiet period that produced only 2009’s remix retrospective Reincarnations
column6: and the founding of his own Pampa imprint. The German producer’s newest original work retains the quirky spirit of Reincarnations but settles into a kaleidoscopic landscape.

column1: In a quote that’s been haunting Amygdala
column2: Koze has apparently claimed the LP as his Sgt. Pepper’s. Hubris aside
column3: that’s not such an unfair comparison. Both records rethink their respective genres from the ground-up
column4: using elements and instruments that seem unusual on first glance but quietly lay the foundation for subtle reinvention. While it’s not likely to set the world on fire
column5: dig beneath the pastel sheen and Amygdala is uncommonly engrossing for a techno album. Its visionary ambition recalls the fertile sprawl of Villalobos’ 2003 debut Alcachofa; baroque techno blessed with the carefree spirit of lounge music and Quiet Storm
column6: dressed up in tie-dye
column7: the music on Amygdala glows with an easy confidence.

column1: Amygdala feels like a painting made up of delicate brushstrokes compared to techno’s laser-cut precision. Kozalla often chooses softly expressive horns or lolling organ over electronics
column2: as on the plush spring overture of “Royal Asscher Cut”
column3: and numerous vocal features only add to the effect. For an artist who has spoken on record how he hates collaborating
column4: over half of Amygdala’s tracks have a “feature” credit as he brings out a cast of charismatic vocalists from Caribou's Dan Snaith to Matthew Dear. The dips into German balladry via his retouch of the classic Hildegard Knef lament “Ich Schreib’ Dir Ein Buch”
column5: or his own heartworn slow-jam “Das Wort”
column6: contribute to the the hallucinatory haze of styles and voices
column7: like scrambling through a radio dial on mushrooms.

column1: Koze has always had a predilection for looping microscopic vocal fragments as the chief anchor for his songs. But now these ghostly voices coexist with the fleshed-out songwriting; on “Das Wort” they provide a sugary counterpoint to Dirk Von Lowtzow’s gruff German consonants
column2: and on “Ich Schreib’ Dir ein Buch 2013”
column3: a Motown choir’s rendition of “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough” is twisted into a sickly tapestry of moans and screeches. Overstuffed and overfed
column4: each track is an embarrassment of riches with a hook or melodic morsel everywhere you look
column5: but Kozalla never loses the plot in the overflow of ideas.

column1: That’s probably why Amygdala feels so accomplished: songwriting. It’s not something we often think too hard about in dance music. But Koze considers every aspect
column2: from hummable melodies to pristine soundscapes to lyrics. Wisely leaning away from dance music cliches of love and desire
column3: Amygdala’s subjects veer from everyday life to grappling with nostalgia and self-identity. Its most charming moment comes with Matthew Dear’s quirky vocal spot on “My Plans”. In a typically alien cadence
column4: Dear addresses the anxiety of a world where everything seems to be going wrong with the cheeky line: “When I notice the world is falling apart/ I will run a bath/ And why does this make me laugh?” It’s a fine motto for Koze himself
column5: never losing sight of his infectious sense of humour or complete resistance to trends. With <i>Amygdala
column6:
he's created an album that invites obsession. 

"|17793.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17793-dj-koze-amygdala/|8.6|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18991/homepage_large.adc195d5.jpg|NoYork!|29674.0|Blu|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New World Color']|2013-03-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:52.645866|"

After a well-received debut album (2007’s Exile-produced Below the Heavens) and a placement on XXL’s annual star-making “Top 10 Freshmen List” paid off in a major label deal with Warner Bros
column2: Los Angeles rapper Blu plotted a career trajectory that seemed to run counter to that of an artist working to infiltrate hip-hop’s mainstream. He didn’t pine for the A-lister referrals and feature circuit ubiquity that lubricate the most well-oiled artist rollouts. He didn’t hobnob with hitmakers or kowtow to the will of radio. Instead he launched into an exploratory series of experiments: a romance-themed solo EP that introduced him as a quirky but capable producer
column3: a one-track dump of inscrutable rough mixes for an album he lost
column4: a Madlib-produced album Madlib denies involvement with
column5: and a spattering of beat tapes. Much of it arrived defiantly unmastered under pseudonyms on Bandcamp
column6: and none of it sounded like the triumphant follow-up to Below the Heavens
column7: whose legacy now stalked Blu’s every endeavor.

column1: It wasn’t until Blu had successfully conditioned his audience to quit telegraphing his next move that he made his power play: reports from 2011’s traveling hip-hop festival Rock the Bells said that Blu showed up to his set handing out copies of something called NoYork! that may or may not have been the ill-fated Warner album. (Blu denies doing it
column2: but the Warner deal dissolved several weeks later.) However NoYork! slipped out
column3: it was a hard left turn in a career full of them
column4: but one that reinvigorated his artistry instead of adroitly maintaining a low profile as previous releases had. Over the last year or so
column5: Blu has been remastering and reissuing some of the odd curios of the Warner era
column6: and NoYork! has finally gotten a physical deluxe edition release via Blu & his producer buddy Mainframe’s New World Color imprint.

column1: If this is the album Blu intended to give Warner
column2: it’s a maverick move. NoYork! finds Blu tapping a cadre of California instrumental hip-hop luminaries and decamping into the hyperkinetic synth haze and shambolic percussion of the Los Angeles beat scene. NoYork!’s team of Low End Theory mainstays load up the album’s front end with squelching synth workouts like Dibia$e’s “SLNGBNGrs”
column3: which arrives like Pac-Man on power pellets and rides a corroded keyboard groove to a chaotic finish
column4: the dizzying synth undulations of “Soupa”
column5: and the double-time borderline Nintendocore of Daedelus’s jungle-informed “Hours” and Flying Lotus’s “Everything’s OK”. Later
column6: Knxwledge and Sa-Ra affiliate Shafiq Husayn bring us home from the arcade with a series of productions full of airy jazz loops
column7: but as a whole NoYork! is a manic trip into an 8-bit k-hole.

column1: NoYork! manages to duck other releases’ air of intentional self-sabotage thanks to Blu’s renewed lyrical attack. Where releases like 2011’s j e s u s were off-putting because the rhymes tumbled out in fractious fits and starts
column2: oftentimes more chants than verses
column3: NoYork! strikes a balance between the verbose storytelling of Below the Heavens and the studious weirdness of his recent work. “Everybody Nose” details a childhood hip-hop obsession that turned into a rap career
column4: then devolves into a list of beloved 1980s clothing lines and rappers in verse three. Blu bounces wistful rhymes and love raps off sung choruses from Jack Davey and Suzi Analogue early on and then coldly juggles words with friends on the album closing West Coast rap summit “Doin’ Something”. Elsewhere singsong refrains about hating work hold court with nonsensical homages to the cadence and storytelling MF Doom. NoYork!’s rhyme experiments are rangy but self-assured
column5: and Blu finally sounds more invested in making great rap than throwing the mainstream rap audience off his trail.

column1: Billing this physical release of NoYork! as a deluxe edition is a bit misleading
column2: though. It’s actually shorter than what’s been circulating on the net for the last year and a half
column3: losing the Madlib and Samiyam productions (and the feature from psych rap recluse Edan) that padded out the album’s hazy comedown side but gaining a sleek digipak and a poster. The mixes don’t appear to have changed either
column4: and it’s now apparent that the aged tape hiss feel of a few of these songs was an intended effect and not the result of them being unfinished
column5: as was the case with many 2010s Blu releases. This version of NoYork! doesn’t offer any new revelations about the record
column6: but as the physical document of that time a gifted rapper blew off a promising record deal to geek out in the studio with friends and then came out with one of the defining documents of his scene
column7:
it’s still a win.

"|17794.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17794-blu-no-york/|8.1|Craig Jenkins

Last time we heard from Edwyn Collins
column2: on 2010's Losing Sleep
column3: he was surrounded by an auspicious array of accompanying musicians. Johnny Marr
column4: Roddy Frame
column5: and Alex Kapranos and Nick McCarthy from Franz Ferdinand were among the guests who provided the musical assistance Collins needed during his ongoing recovery from the cerebral hemorrhages he suffered in 2005. His condition means he still requires the help of others in fleshing out his songwriting
column6: but Understated plays out like a crucial step toward finding his muse again. The guests here fill important roles
column7: but are lesser known; it's released on Collins' own label
column8: the newly-formed AED Records; and the predominant lyrical theme is one of triumphant return. There's a sense of fight here
column9: of Collins drawing musical strength from his hell-and-back experiences.

column1: Collins has always liked to juxtapose ostensibly jarring styles
column2: famously matching Chic-style guitars to post-punk sharpness in Orange Juice. His best-known song
column3: ""A Girl Like You""
column4: found a place where 60s pop
column5: Motown
column6: and the Velvet Underground could co-exist. He's returned to a familiar set of influences for Understated
column7: working in arrangements that have Paul Riser's name all over them
column8: throwing in jangly guitar lines that hark back to the Orange Juice days
column9: constructing grooves that resemble lost Northern Soul workouts. Collins' voice is a little more world-weary with every passing record
column10: giving ballads like ""It's a Reason"" an extra dose of pathos
column11: in an album already dripping in poignancy and self-reflection.

column1: Still
column2: there are signs that some of the material is a stretch for him to reach
column3: such as certain lines in the countryfied ""Down the Line"". But even there it's impossible not to be moved by his malaise. ""Just understand
column4: I've lost some ground
column5: he croons at one point. So this is a stark record
column6: full of uncomplicated sentiment. It's also one fuelled by a dual feeling of nostalgia
column7: partly abetted by the backward-looking arrangements
column8: and Collins' attempt to address where he is in the world. ""Forsooth"" and ""In the Now"" are likely paired together for a reason; the former might be the most spiritual Collins has ever gotten in song
column9: a direct address about being alive and reborn. The latter is the most strident song here
column10: building a deliberate buffer between his past and present selves.

column1: In a sense
column2: Understated feels like a course-setter for how things are going to be in Collins' career from this point onward. He's certainly shed some of the wit and self-deprecation of yore
column3: although when he does get back there it provides respite
column4: a deviation from the healing he's clearly keen to address in song. ""I’m a singer
column5: of sorts
column6: is the most welcome line here when it comes
column7: all wrapped up in the humble title track
column8: returning to something resembling the old Edwyn we all fell in love with on that first listen to ""Falling and Laughing"". But it's important to recognize that he’s not in that place anymore
column9: not even close to it. Orange Juice's debut You Can’t Hide Your Love Forever is beautiful because of its innocence
column10: whereas Understated is bruised by the many experiences that came afterward. It's no lesser record for it
column11:
just one that feels like a part in the purging process rather than a place where Collins feels fully at ease.

For something so murky and distant
column2: Vincent Caylet's music is remarkably attention-grabbing. Working as Cankun
column3: he mixes loops and echoes into layers of intoxicating fog
column4: but there’s always at least one sound inside his swirl that catches your focus. It could be a chopped-up snare hit
column5: a subliminal bass throb
column6: or a seemingly-random guitar chord that gradually becomes a tune’s heartbeat. Whatever he chooses
column7: these guiding sounds propel his music forward
column8: injecting a definite pulse into what could easily become flatlined mush.

column1: Those versed in muffled
column2: retro-leaning “hypnagogic pop”-- particularly as purveyed by the Not Not Fun label-- might find Culture of Pink rather familiar. But Caylet morphs that style into something less like VHS-dubbed memories-of-memories than an underwater DJ set. That’s partially due to how rarely he settles into a static groove. With music this loop-heavy
column3: it can be tempting to ride waves out toward the horizon. When done well
column4: that choice can pay off-- Sun Araw’s best work is proof. More often it results in lazy filler
column5: a trap Caylet refuses to fall into. Even when a song sticks with one tempo or timbre
column6: he rotates and cross-cuts his churning sounds to keep them in constant motion.

column1: In other ways
column2: though
column3: Culture of Pink has a lot in common with Sun Araw’s gripping grooves. Both acts are partial to tropical atmospheres
column4: using reggae-ish guitar
column5: dub-like bass
column6: and deep-end beats to conjure a steamy
column7: sweaty rainforest feel
column8: albeit filtered through the lens of psychotropic enhancements. Caylet’s best dub mutations are so humid you can practically feel the mist wafting through his sonic jungle. On “Acinom”
column9: languid
column10: overlapping guitars roll across rattling percussion like a stream coasting over rocks
column11: while on “Soul Brothers”
column12: Caylet makes a laid-back swing urgent by flooding it in reverberating tones.

column1: If you’re a fan of reggae and dub
column2: one question pops to mind when listening to Culture of Pink: why opt for a blurry photocopy when you can have the real thing? For me
column3: the answer is easy-- the blur here is just as appealing as the reggae/dub structures
column4: and just as integral. I can’t imagine these tunes without their sonic density; it’s not just in the thick production
column5: but also in the way Caylet places sounds next to each other
column6: the way he transitions from one passage to another
column7: even in the way he plays each instrument and inflects each note. That’s strongest on the album’s longest song
column8: the seven-minute “Why Do You Laugh?” Though its elements are simple-- guitar flickers
column9: bass plunges
column10: a slow
column11: sparse vocal-- Caylet makes them into reflections of themselves and each other
column12: creating a hazy hall of mirrors. As the tune slowly drifts into abstraction
column13:
it becomes a microcosm of his most enticing strength: a knack for creating memorable moments rather than just evoking them.

In September 2011
column2: grindcore band Call of the Void

column5: Col.
column6: along with Denver's Speedwolf. To the University of Colorado students present at the bar to down cheap Old Style and play pool on their Californian parents' dime
column7: they were a noisy interruption
column8: a sideshow sanctioned by the bar yet seemingly uninvited by its patrons. Boulder in general is hostile to anything with distorted guitars at loud volume. If it's not influenced by Phish
column9: Fleetwood Mac
column10: or Skrillex
column11: Boulderites don't want to hear it. Metal bands face such indifference all the time
column12: but Call of the Void didn't get discouraged. They picked up a new vocalist
column13: Steve Vanica
column14: most of the band moved to much more metal-fertile Denver
column15: and they signed to Relapse

column17: their debut for the label
column18: charges through apathy.

column1: Like their peers in Early Graves and the now-deceased Gaza
column2: Call of the Void traffic in a hybrid of hardcore
column3: death metal
column4: and crust. There's a definite Converge vibe
column5: if Converge still had their learned fury but were less knotty in their arrangements. Comparisons to His Hero Is Gone fly in discussing the band
column6: but they're not so much interested in melody as they are with laying waste. “Faith and Filth”
column7: the closing track
column8: sounds like an outtake from Napalm Death's From Enslavement to Obliteration. Low end is pronounced
column9: almost to the point where it would be more appropriate to call them a fast sludge band rather than grindcore. This is especially true on the latter half of “Theory of Mind
column10: ” where around 0:53 the band unleashes a groovy break that resembles Tragedy listening to a lot of Pantera. A call-to-arms rave-up going into a chunky riff shouldn't meld
column11: but Call of the Void's ability to fuse disparate extreme metal influences makes it succeed. The only real “sludgy” part of the album is the introductory dirge of “Faliure”
column12: and from there the album is mostly about speed and venom. They invoke Bower Power in the main riff of “Endless Ritual Abuse
column13: ” but even then that song is too grindy to be sludge.

column1: Call of the Void have that certain strand of rage only Denver bands seem to possess. While they don't sound like their peers in Clinging to the Trees of a Forest Fire
column2: Primitive Man
column3: Speedwolf
column4: or Catheter-- and those bands sound nothing like each other-- all these groups push their amps harder and play nastier seemingly to make up for Colorado's reputation as a laid-back
column5: ski trips and bong rips state. Mellowness only serves to make them more enraged
column6: more willing to say fuck all to limits. Call of the Void are no exception
column7:
and they're proving that Denver is a hotbed of serious vitrol and passion.

The chatter surrounding Nathan Williams' activities has occasionally overshadowed the music itself. It's been five years since Williams' self-titled debut long-player as Wavves
column2: so it's a fine time to step back and re-direct the conversation. Wavves and 2009's triple-v'd follow-up featured monochromatic garage grinders buried under blown-out production-- not exactly the work you'd expect from someone who'd later write a Christmas song for Target with his girlfriend. It's possible that many present-day Wavves fans are unaware that those albums and his sound has changed accordingly. The beery
column3: brawny King of the Beach from 2010 featured improved production and sharp
column4: sticky hooks that were perfectly suited to soundtrack shows on MTV (which they eventually did.)

column1: Following some label drama that almost derailed that album's creation
column2: Williams took the DIY approach by self-releasing 2011's guest-laden Life Sux EP; two years later
column3: he and current musical co-conspirator Stephen Pope have returned with the proper follow-up to Beach
column4: Afraid of Heights. The record is Williams' first for Warner Bros. and Sony-affiliated imprint Mom + Pop
column5: but Williams self-financed the album's recording over the course of a year. It's a big-ticket record made with indie-minded ethos
column6: and the album's tangle of contradictions befits a guy with such a history of contrarianism.

column1: King of the Beach had real-deal rock guy Dennis Herring (Elvis Costello
column2: Modest Mouse) behind the boards; Afraid of Heights features John Hill
column3: a producer with modern pop bonafides from Rihanna to M.I.A. You can hear his touch in the pretty-sounding keyboard-mellotron loop that's interrupted by a low
column4: persistent inner-ear thud in the opening of the typically bratty ""Sail to the Sun""
column5: and Afraid of Heights as a whole is truly a headphones album
column6: a luxuriously produced record tempered with a few moments of noisy studio trickery (notably
column7: the scuzzy rumble of ""Mystic"") for contrast. Five songs feature strings; one features slide guitar.

column1: As for the songwriting
column2: Afraid of Heights finds Williams taking these new elements-- including guest vocalist Jenny Lewis' contributions
column3: only barely heard on the album's melodically winding title track-- and rolling them up tightly in his familiar forward churn. King of the Beach's self-loathing-as-swag anthem ""Idiot""-- one of the most straightforwardly ear-catching songs on that album-- is a jumping-off point. This means that there's less of the formless
column4: small-scale exercises that largely made up Beach's back half; some will miss the eccentricity
column5: but Afraid of Heights' energizing consistency makes for a fair trade.

column1: Williams' lyrics are still dripping with self-loathing. Life Sux's ""I Wanna Meet Dave Grohl"" drew sneers based on the title alone
column2: but the sentiment never seemed explicitly careerist; at some point
column3: you'd have to assume that this guy would rather do anything else rather than continue to address his own personal insufficiencies. Here
column4: ""Dog"" and ""Beat Me Up"" deal with subservience in relationships
column5: while the sprightly ""Lunge Forward"" ends with a wish for the end of humanity. There's talk of graves
column6: death
column7: bruises
column8: and the eventuality of being alone. The negativity is sometimes so pronounced it's almost funny: ""Gimme a Knife"" closes with
column9: ""I loved you
column10: Jesus/ You raped the world/ I feel defeated/ Guess I'll go surf.""

column1: The album's most enjoyably surprising moment arrives when he turns his attention outward. ""Cop"" is a love song
column2: albeit a strange one: it's written from the perspective of the gay lover of protagonist John
column3: who's just killed a policeman. ""Sit back and relax
column4: John
column5: just go home and quickly wash your hair/ Lay back in my arms
column6: Williams sweetly sings
column7: backed by a distant acoustic shuffle reminiscent of Jay Reatard's cover of Chris Knox's ""Turn Down the Shades"". Some strings and stray whistling enter
column8: and the song swells into a big
column9: beatific wash of light before the hook comes in again. It is
column10: without doubt
column11: the most lovely and affecting piece of music Williams has written.

column1: Afraid of Heights is the first Wavves album longer than 40-minutes and sometimes it drags. Williams is an avowed Weezer disciple
column2: and accordingly his more dirge-y creations have always reminded me of the sluggishness found on mid-period Weezer albums like Maladroit. Although he mostly does the the more low-key material right here
column3: ""Everything Is My Fault"" is a real momentum-killer
column4: especially when you realize there's still 10 minutes of album material to get through. Still
column5: Afraid of Heights provides plenty of bummed-out pleasures and Williams' obvious talent is easy to take for granted. At ""Lunge Forward""'s chaotic peak
column6: he cries
column7: ""None of you will ever understand me"" and that may be true
column8:
but his music continues to make perfect sense.

Kompakt opened as a record store in Cologne in 1993 and has been expanding its scope and reach since. If you're the type of person who owns only a handful of electronic albums
column2: smart money says a Kompakt release is among them. And if you're the kind of person who owns dozens of electronic albums
column3: Kompakt likely still commands serious shelf space. 20 Jahre Kompakt / Kollektion 1
column4: which begins a year-long celebration of the label in its 20th year
column5: spreads label standouts over two discs and serves as a reminder that the label's range vastly exceeds its reputation.

column1: And perhaps you do need reminding: Kompakt is hardly the tour-de-force it once was. After owning the better part of last decade with its light melodic touch and tasteful beatsmithing
column2: the label was elbowed out of the spotlight by the harsher sounds coming from Berlin's resurgent club culture and London's fervent bass scene. These shifts threw into relief Kompakt's reputation as purveyors of gentle
column3: polite techno more suited to dinner parties than dance floors.

column1: This reputation is only partly deserved. Kompakt rose to prominence as European club culture wound down from its 90s bacchanal; some of these ravers presumably traded all-night-in-a-field parties for graphic design and advertising jobs. If Kompakt was lifestyle music
column2: it was serving the first generation of techno fans for which the sounds represented something other than a counterculture. The label's sound-- often referred to as ""minimal techno
column3: though frequently no more than one of those terms applied-- left room for sweet
column4: melancholy vocal tracks and helped it find an audience with indie rock fans looking to dig deeper into the sounds that inspired acts such as the Postal Service
column5: the Notwist
column6: and Caribou.

column1: 20 Jahre Kompakt helps both the label and its fans sort through its history. It's not a greatest hits package
column2: but a reflection of the catalog as the Kompakt principals would like to remember it-- some combination of hits and sentimental favorites. It's a smart strategy. The attitude throughout is warm and generous-- this aspect of the label's reputation is deserved-- but the tracks themselves are pliable and lightly funky. 20 Jahre is easy enough listening at low volumes
column3: but crank the dial to reveal gamey basslines and sturdy leads. Suggesting that this music is only for home listening is to listen only through laptop speakers-- a trend that also coincided with Kompakt's heyday. The label's ""schaffel"" (""shuffle"") sound-- predicated on swung triplets (here's an example)-- ensures a playful bounce. (An aside: the label's two Schaffelfieber compilations are ripe for rediscovery.)

column1: The first track
column2: Heiko Voss' ""I Think About You""
column3: plays to expectations
column4: coming off like the Sea and Cake covering Prince. So it's probably not an accident that the second
column5: DJ Koze's remix of Matias Aguayo's ""Minimal""
column6: is a relatively recent smash that mocks the label's buzzword status. ""These clubbers don't dance...'Cause that music got no groove
column7: no balls
column8: croons Aguayo
column9: calling back and forth with a cooing female voice. The classic motorik groove of the Field's ""Over the Ice"" sits alongside the glossy sentimentalism of Superpitcher's ""Happiness"". Dettinger's ""Totentanz"" could almost slide in alongside the pitch-black acid techno coming out of the UK these days. Most of the big names-- Gui Boratto
column10: Wolfgang Voigt
column11: Michael Mayer-- are present
column12: but their tracks here are curveballs. Skipping Jürgen Paape's deeply loved ""So Weit Wie Noch Nie""
column13: for example
column14: in favor of Justus Köhncke's underrated ""2 After 909"" helps breathe life into yet another anniversary compilation.

column1: There was another reason
column2: it must be mentioned
column3: that Kompakt was so successful: its accessibility and willingness to compile itself. Their commitment to the CD format and their excellent distribution made and make their releases easy to acquire. Annual volumes of the Total and Pop Ambient series once served as milestones
column4: though they test patience these days. Kompakt 100
column5: a remix album celebrating the label's 100th release
column6: dropped more than nine years ago. One of the label's best-ever offerings-- co-owner Michael Mayer's seminal Immer-- is itself a mix that sums up the label's sound. There are now three volumes of it.

column1: None of the material on 20 Jahre is difficult to find
column2: and early efforts like Total 2 and Total 3
column3: as well as Immer
column4: stand as better
column5: if less comprehensive
column6: documents of Kompakt's sound. But for anyone new to this friendly
column7: versatile music
column8: 20 Jahre is a smart
column9:
manageable introduction that doesn't give away the farm.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18898/homepage_large.a96a0cf4.jpg|Wooden Ball|30550.0|Blanche Blanche Blanche|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['NNA Tapes']|2013-03-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:59:56.083574|"

Sarah Smith and Zach Phillips
column2: the Vermont-based duo who make up Blanche Blanche Blanche
column3: like to work in miniature. On Wooden Ball
column4: the latest in a rapid-fire series of releases from the pair
column5: only five of the 16 tracks make it over the two-minute mark. Their insistence on recording to four-track tape adds to the small feeling
column6: lending a compressed intimacy to their bursts of all-thumbs pop. A cliche (and a truth) often uttered about four-track recordings is that you ""feel like you're in the room there with them
column7: which is something often ascribed to
column8: say
column9: Lou Barlow's work under his Sentridoh alias. It's not something shared by Blanche Blanche Blanche
column10: who use the muffled textures to make themselves sound anesthetized from the world
column11: lost somewhere in a land of their own creation. Wooden Ball ups that feeling tenfold from last year's Wink With Both Eyes
column12: largely due to the greater complexity of Smith and Phillips' creations.

column1: If Wink was a little too enchanted with the cheap-speed world Ariel Pink created on his earliest releases
column2: Wooden Ball has taken that template and tied a few more knots in it. The outcome has deposited Blanche Blanche Blanche somewhere close to the Ohio punk and New Wave scene that bloomed in the late 1970s
column3: with specific cues taken from Devo's first couple of albums. There's a strong sense of the robo-rock approach of Mark Mothersbaugh's band
column4: a great rush of synthesized movement that's impeccably ordered
column5: yet splinters off at angles you rarely see coming around the bend. Like Devo
column6: it's manic at first
column7: even difficult to process. Smith and Phillips clearly get a kick out of setting up songs that come close to wilting under their own good ideas. ""TED Talks"" is their best example of this to date
column8: drawing vital energy from the deranged motion of the track
column9: which is perfectly balanced by Smith's dispassionate vocal.

column1: There's a confidence here that was only hinted at on Wink. Smith's singing often slows to a spoken-word pace
column2: sometimes strains at the seams
column3: and is regularly furnished with a brash kind of cool. It's like a cross between Ann Magnuson's work in Bongwater and Anna Waronker's supremely disengaged delivery in That Dog. Blanche Blanche Blanche's greatest material resembles an all-out cage match between the instrumentation and the vocals
column4: full of roaming
column5: mechanised basslines (""Time to Remember""
column6: ""Cow""); wild machine noise lost in an upsurge of distortion (""Join the Creative Class""); and berserk 21st century vaudeville (""Looks Don't Run""). There's nothing that resembles relatively straight songs like ""That's Siberia"" and ""Appetite"" from Wink
column7: and this record is better for it. Madness clearly suits them far better than sanity.

column1: One weakness is Smith and Phillips' tendency to flick through styles and present gone-wrong versions of them; ""The One I'll Call"" attempts warped reggae
column2: ""The Kind Dry Stream"" is a demented piano ballad. Those tracks splice up the mood of the record
column3: but they don't need to go there
column4: especially now they've found a footing that's close to being their own. They haven't quite shed all the Ariel Pinkisms either

The wispy
column2: slate gray sky-evoking atmospherics of Heterotic's debut album are an unlikely match for their co-creator

column4: his wife Lara Rix-Martin. That's the romantic pop of Fleetwood Mac and the mysticism of Kate Bush rather than the harsh IDM of Paradinas' defining work as µ-ziq.

column1: At its core

column3: implying not only the pair’s own male-female coupling
column4: but also the term’s technical definition-- that of combining two different genes. The fruits of their labour turn not to be a ghastly hybrid but rather a seamless combination of two unique musical voices. Unlike almost anything Paradinas has put his name to

column1: With six-minute instrumental opener “Bliss”

column3: breezy AM gold melody and wordless harmonies
column4: it channels “Second Hand News” in a summery bluster. But as the rest of Love & Devotion unfurls

column7: tinkling pianos
column8: full-throated mellotron-- that give off a 70s warmth

column1: But those are the instrumentals. Warp-signed folk vocalist Gravenhurst

column4: drastically altering the album’s mood and flow. His lyrical themes turn out to be sad and bitter

column6: bright and chilly like cold air wafting through a cemetery. Possessed of an inherently sad voice
column7: he’s perfect for tracks like the incredible “Slumber”

column10: where he whispers a wrenching ballad about intimacy against a backdrop that feels like a distant heartbeat. It’s like a completely separate project when you put it up against “Bliss”
column11: which comes just two tracks before.

column1: While most of the album has some degree of melancholy floating through it
column2: whether it’s just tinged or just full-blown downer material
column3: Love & Devotion feels split down the middle. Not that variety is necessarily a bad thing. But with the exception of “Blue Lights”-- easily the album’s best
column4: where Gravenhurst’s fluorescent hues channel Britpop larks rather than dour indie-- it feels as if the vocal material belongs to something much more rooted in English pop tradition than the other synthy trifles. It’s not the most cohesive listen

Heterotic stands as a yet another promising venture from one of the most consistently surprising minds in electronic music.

Comedown Machine accomplishes in 38 minutes what nearly a decade and a half of backlash and schadenfreude could not: make the Strokes look like total nerds. This isn’t so much of a revelation as it the culmination of what’s been happening ever since First Impressions of Earth. They got one classic album and another great one exhausting a sound that evoked decades of New York squalor chic through indestructible songs and contradictory images: garages where Orange amps are parked next to Benzes
column2: a trust-funder’s highrise apartment lousy with beer cans and leather jackets
column3: dive bars frequented by models and rock stars. Everything since has taken cues from styles more associated with parents’ basements
column4: musty vinyl shops
column5: and convention centers: dinky synth-pop
column6: surf rock
column7: prog and the weird science of countless 1980s New Wave bands. This flipping of the script can actually be seen as a canny move
column8: recasting the Strokes as lovable underdogs: where they once defined effortless cool
column9: the deeply uncool Comedown Machine smacks of effort.

column1: That goes a long way towards making Comedown Machine more immediately appealing than their last two records; the Strokes sound like they’re genuinely trying here. The functional cover art of Comedown Machine suggests some kind of mixtape the Strokes made for themselves
column2: 11 songs that turn out like 11 different genre experiments viewed through the unmistakable prism of their inhuman rhythmic precision and pinched EQ’ing. There are a couple of Is This It? throwbacks (“All The Time
column3: ” “50/50”) that turn out to be among the least satisfying things here
column4: too flabby to fit into those same jeans from a decade prior. Otherwise
column5: you get elastic funk (“Tap Out”)
column6: dubby dream-pop (“80s Comedown Machine”)
column7: unidentifiable Latin-tinged Casio presets (“One Way Trigger”) and plenty of soft-rock sheen that creates an ouroboros effect of the Strokes sounding like Phoenix when they were trying to sound like the Strokes.

column1: Credit where it’s due: the guys sound like they’re having fun again. At least that’s the gist you get from the numerous
column2: in-studio “throwaway” moments: the flubbed soloing that introduces the otherwise vise-tight “Tap Out” and the labored laughing that closes out “Slow Animals” only take up a few seconds
column3: but they reinforce the idea that this isn’t Julian Casablancas’ de facto solo project despite it sounding closer to Phrazes For The Young than any Strokes LP. But you also sense that the rest of the band getting antsy
column4: issuing challenges to themselves to keep things interesting. Albert Hammond’s solos are charmingly anachronistic
column5: a throwback to when tidy solos were a regular occurrence in three-minute pop songs. But they still can’t shake their tendency to stubbornly hammer at awkward riffs (“Happy Ending”) and clunky chord changes (""Welcome To Japan"").

column1: Still
column2: the limitations of Comedown Machine's protracted diversity all come back to Casablancas
column3: a man with wide range as a listener and extremely narrow range as a musician. In both lyrics and tone
column4: he’s best at playing the laconic cad: So when he barks “you’re going too fast” on “All the Time” as a callback to “Reptilia” and the hotseat urgency of Room On Fire
column5: it sounds forced. On the opposite end
column6: the highlight of Comedown Machine is when he asks “What kind of asshole drives a Lotus?” on “Welcome to Japan”; you half expect him to do the “this guy!” routine as a punchline.

column1: That’s the kind of thing Casablancas does better than anyone. Unfortunately
column2: most of Comedown Machine finds him doing anything but that. “Tap Out” features at least two of Casablancas' most elegant melodies
column3: but his wispy coo turns them into mush. When he takes the opposite tack to channel his inner Tom Waits
column4: he doesn’t fare much better; no one was asking what the Strokes would've sounded like in the Victrola era
column5: but ""Call It Fate Call It Karma"" answers it anyway. If this all smacks of effort
column6: at least they are not taking the easy way out. It’s the 10th anniversary of Room On Fire and in light of what came after
column7: a reissue would surely bring more praise than the initial Is This It? Yes It Is assessment. Or
column8: they could’ve followed the lead of fellow fashion plate/occasional hitmaker Suede and made it a point to sound like their old selves after a long
column9: dry spell.

column1: Still
column2: it’s frustrating for anyone who still puts stock in the idea that the Strokes could and should be one of America’s biggest rock bands. After all
column3: they feel like stars even if the numbers don’t back it up and reigning champs like the Black Keys have about as much charisma and sex appeal as a General Tire. Of course
column4: Black Keys are writing much better songs than the ones on Comedown Machine and if the Strokes seem unfashionable in 2013
column5:
that's the true reason.

It was easy to approach Glasgow trio Chvrches' breakthrough single ""The Mother We Share"" with a degree of skepticism. After all
column3: when you're an up-and-coming European electro-pop band trying to set yourself apart in a sea of soundalikes
column4: titling your second single like a magnetic poetry scramble of one of the Knife's biggest hits doesn't exactly scream originality. But once you hit play
column5: the song itself-- a soaring synth-pop meteorite centered around a sky-high chorus-- had enough transcendent pop power to turn cynics to devotees in three minutes flat. Same went for ""Lies""
column6: the thumping debut single on which singer Lauren Mayberry declared her ability to ""make a true believer of anyone."" Something about Chvrches' pulsing
column7: neon-brite music is like skepticism's kryptonite; their songs are executed wholeheartedly
column8: driven by themes of belief
column9: devotion
column10: and discovery
column11: and imbued with an unabashed sense of wonder. The ornate
column12: sparkling eye make-up that Mayberry sports on stage is the perfect visual metaphor for their sound: It's as though she's trying to make her eyes wider in an attempt to take in as much of the world as she can.

column1: Chvrches came together spontaneously in late 2011
column2: when Iain Cook and Martin Doherty asked Mayberry to sing on some tracks they'd been producing and were pleasantly surprised with the results. As a trio
column3: they're something of a hodgepodge. All three have been in bands but never one that sounds anything like this: Mayberry used to sing in the folky indie pop outfit Blue Sky Archives
column4: Cook played with muted post-rockers Aereogramme
column5: and Doherty was a touring member of the rumbling Glaswegian thunderclouds the Twilight Sad. Despite their varied and somewhat gloomy pedigrees
column6: Chvrches' first EP Recover shows the trio coming together to explore and embrace synth pop's artificial sunlight-- a far cry from the sensibility of the drizzly city that spawned them.

column1: The title track of Recover
column2: though
column3: shines just as bright as Chvrches' first two singles
column4: and it continues to hone a sound that's beginning to sound distinct from their electro-pop contemporaries. Chvrches have garnered plenty of comparisons to Purity Ring
column5: but-- with the exception of the chopped-up Megan James-like vocal hiccups that open ""Mother""-- the Glaswegians' music has little interest in deconstruction. Instead
column6: Chvrches' music is all about the moment when everything comes together-- like when Cook and Doherty's panoramic synth vistas swoop beneath Mayberry's vocal melody on ""Recover"" to round out its anthemic chorus. While their sound often scans ""80s"" (""Now is the Time"" channels some serious OMD vibes)
column7: Chvrches' sense of commanding
column8: wall-shaking dynamism takes cues from dubstep. Occasionally (on the verses of ""Time"" in particular)
column9: Mayberry's delivery feels a little too stiff or meek to compete with the towering sounds around her. When she's on
column10: though
column11: her entrancing voice becomes Recover's centerpiece
column12: giving these songs their human pulse. ""You take what you need
column13: she sings on the title track
column14: ""And I know you don't need me.""

column1: Doherty sings lead on ""ZVVL""
column2: the EP's weakest track
column3: and unlike Mayberry he doesn't quite have the charisma to take center stage. Though they're riding the strength of some very strong singles
column4: the back half of Recover shows that Chvrches are still actively working out parts of their sound-- which
column5: of course
column6: is no great strike against a band that's only been together a little over a year. Still
column7: what does feel almost preternaturally fully formed is Chvrches' melodic sensibility. (The sheer number of Chvrches remixes-- the best being Miaoux Miaoux's candy-coated take on ""Mother""-- floating around right now is a testament to this.) As Chvrches prep their full-length debut for later this year
column8: they're still honing the edge that's going to set them apart. But for the time being
column9:
the hooks are enough to convert plenty of true believers.

In their press shots and videos
column2: Berlin's Brandt Brauer Frick have often played up to the Teutonic stereotype of stiff formality. Their name
column3: of course
column4: sounds like it could’ve been borrowed from a law firm
column5: and
column6: dressed soberly in suits (or at the very least a shirt and tie)
column7: tending to their instruments in a workmanlike manner
column8: you’d be forgiven for thinking this was a trio of white collar workers indulging a hobby on their day off. It’s a mode of presentation not dissimilar to that of Kraftwerk
column9: but in a sense Brandt Brauer Frick are Kraftwerk in reverse
column10: stripping techno of its synthesisers and drum machines and replacing them with acoustic instruments: pianos
column11: strings
column12: brass
column13: and orchestral percussion.

column1: That might seem like a regressive move
column2: and it certainly leaves the trio open to accusations of gimmickry. But so far they’ve done a fine job of dodging the various pitfalls that confront a so-called “crossover” act. Brandt Brauer Frick first emerged in 2009; Daniel Brandt and Jan Brauer both had orchestral training
column3: while Paul Frick had studied classical composition. Thanks to their backgrounds
column4: the Brandt Brauer Frick sound was
column5: and is
column6: instantly recognisable. Mechanical piano figures
column7: played with dampened or treated strings
column8: recall John Cage’s works for prepared piano; detailed live-sounding arrangements reference the finicky bricolage-house of Matthew Herbert; a taste for dense polyrhythms comes from jazz
column9: tempered with a measured pacing borrowed from the finest Detroit techno.

column1: With 2011’s Mr. Machine
column2: though
column3: Brandt Brauer Frick became the Brandt Brauer Frick Ensemble
column4: and the trio’s focus shifted away from the club and towards the concert hall. With a 10-piece orchestral ensemble in tow
column5: the trio re-scored tracks from their 2010 debut You Make Me Real and elsewhere. The arrangements were smart and playful
column6: but could feel a little rote at times. So it's good news that the trio have returned to a studio-assisted setup for their third LP. Muscular sub-bass and booming
column7: power-assisted kickdrums are back
column8: and the arrangements are bolder and more mercurial than ever before.

column1: Miami is a concept album of sorts
column2: bound together by three tracks that reference the city. Opener ""Miami Theme"" is Brandt Brauer Frick at their most epic and their most po-faced
column3: a foggy 10-minute landscape of orchestral texturing dripping with existential dread. ""Miami Drift"" reprises the mood
column4: while the forlorn piano techno of closer ""Miami Titles"" offers little by way of warmth. Elsewhere
column5: ""Ocean Drive (Schamane)"" seems to suggest grey waves crashing under glowering skies
column6: an updating of Sturm und Drang for the techno generation. Fact is
column7: Brandt
column8: Brauer and Frick have spent a total of 24 hours in the city of Miami: They're conjuring a mental state
column9: rather than the azure-skied plastic paradise you might expect. Miami is by some measure Brandt Brauer Frick’s darkest record
column10: giving freer reign to a creeping angst that’s often lurked in the trio’s discography.

column1: It’s appropriate that the album’s dazzling cast of vocalists are coaxed into an almost uniformly spooky style of delivery
column2: like ghosts leering out of the murk. Sa-Ra’s Om’Mas Keith supplies an anaemic whisper to accompany the ominous ""Plastic Like Your Mother""; deep house darling Nina Kraviz’s smoky tones are reduced to a sickly burble in the nightmarish ""Verwahrlosung"" (German for ""neglect""); Gudrun Gut’s contribution to the faintly Jeff Mills-like ""Fantasie Mädchen"" is more sinister yet. All of this is to Brandt Brauer Frick’s credit. Where Mr. Machine occasionally came off twee
column3: Miami is sleek and vicious
column4: pulling no punches. Moments of redemption
column5: when they come
column6: are fleeting and qualified
column7: and all the more satisfying for it-- as in ""Broken Pieces""
column8: where clipped brass chords outline the faintest hint of a pop hook under Jamie Lidell’s strangled soul mewl. Miami shows Brandt Brauer Frick to have reached new heights of imagination and technical accomplishment
column9: but it’s undeniably a challenging listen. Break through its forbidding surface
column10: though
column11:
and the rewards can be considerable.

When Kraftwerk effectively turned themselves into a museum piece
column2: via sporadic full-album shows that began at MoMA in New York in 2012
column3: it felt like Ralf Hütter might be eyeing up a way to call time on the legendary synthpop outfit. Where to go from here? There is one potential last hurrah that could get longstanding fans as excited as they were for the museum shows
column4: albeit one that seems unlikely: a reformation of the ""classic"" Kraftwerk lineup
column5: featuring Hütter
column6: Florian Schneider
column7: Wolfgang Flür
column8: and Karl Bartos. The latter joined the band in the mid 1970s and became much more than a sideman to Hütter and Schneider-- he has songwriting credits on some of the band’s most famous material
column9: including ""The Model""
column10: ""Tour de France""
column11: and ""Computer Love"". A reunion isn't on the cards
column12: but there's little doubt that having Bartos on stage would bring gravitas to the band
column13: even if it had little discernable effect on the music played.

column1: Bartos left Kraftwerk in 1990
column2: amid a swirl of rumors that he was unhappy with the slow creative pace they had settled into. But an initial burst of work
column3: notably with Electronic and his own Elektric Music
column4: quickly faded to silence. Off the Record is only the second album he has made under his own name
column5: primarily based around music he recorded long ago
column6: dredged up from the vaults and given a 21st century gleam. Except
column7: much like Kraftwerk's endless retooling of their work for live performance
column8: much of it is firmly lodged in the past. At some point
column9: approximately around the time of Electric Cafe
column10: Kraftwerk stopped feeling like the future
column11: instead morphing into a quaint look back at how they thought the world would be shaped during their 1970s heyday. Off the Record takes a similar approach. Given a chance to take old material and make it new
column12: Bartos simply leaves it suspended in the period
column13: making few notable advances.

column1: The record is so bathed in retro that there are direct nods back to some of the Kraftwerk material he worked on. ""Rhythmus"" gives the ""Numbers"" beat a tweak
column2: choosing to set it to a fuller musical backing and some achingly familiar robo-vocals. Bartos is one of the few people allowed to get away with such blatant mirroring of the past
column3: but it's hard to escape the thought that he's done it all before
column4: and better
column5: and with a little more elegance and wit. A case in point: naming a song after the Atomium
column6: a structure built for the 1958 World's Fair
column7: just seems so obviously Kraftwerkian that it's redundant. The best Kraftwerk material was smarter than that; it was about great synth paeans to the German equivalent of Route 66 (""Autobahn"")
column8: or looking for beauty in minutiae (""Pocket Calculator"")
column9: or celebrating and warning about the onrush of technology (""Computer World""/""Radioactivity"").

column1: Perhaps it's unfair to judge Bartos next to the peerless heights his former band reached
column2: but Off the Record clearly has aspirations to orbit exactly the same territory. Its nadir comes in ""The Tuning of the World""
column3: a horribly clunky piece of auto-tuned sermonizing in which Bartos outlines his outlook on life. Elsewhere
column4: there are attempts at updating some of the source material
column5: but even that sounds decades behind; ""International Velvet"" resembles Air circa Moon Safari
column6: while ""Hausmusik"" is a strange deviation into the light pop intonations of The The's ""This is the Day"". It's all impeccably executed and precisely arranged
column7: as you'd expect from someone with Bartos's pedigree. But nothing here feels essential in the way that
column8: say
column9: Can's The Lost Tapes did. Instead
column10: there are hints at the reasoning behind Kraftwerk's creative silence. Hütter may have endlessly spun his wheels
column11:
but at least he had the foresight to not tarnish his reputation by rehashing inferior material.

At their best
column2: Kvelertak register as 40-plus years of aggressive-rock history crammed into one filler-free highlight reel. Frontman Erlend Hjelvik screeched exclusively in his native tongue on the Norwegian sextet's self-titled 2010 debut
column3: but the album spoke a universal riff language. Kvelertak's gambit was to smash the barriers subdividing the metal pantheon
column4: so that the nimble six-string grandstanding of Thin Lizzy and cartoonish machismo of AC/DC could mingle with black metal's tortured yowls and headlong blastbeats
column5: and commune with hardcore's bottomless vitriol. Tracks like ""Blodtørst"" honored Kvelertak's righteous name (it means ""chokehold"")
column6: besting Andrew W.K. at his crank-it-up-and-chug party-metal quest
column7: while at the same time mustering enough heft and geeky shred to satisfy any fan of Leviathan-era Mastodon. Extreme metal and rock & roll had cohabitated before-- see: early/mid 90s works by Entombed and Carcass
column8: or the punky hedonism of Venom and their modern-day disciples such as Midnight-- but rarely with such sheer ballsy flair.

column5: and Rush-- but otherwise
