column9: eerily elegant cover art from Baroness's John Baizley and a wholesale avoidance of English. Meir also echoes the tantalizing inconsistency of its predecessor. As on Kvelertak
column10: the choice tracks here are stunners
column11: songs that deserve to be fast-tracked into the heavy-rock pantheon. While there are no outright duds
column12: the less memorable material can't quite measure up
column13: lending the album a certain almost-there feel. Meir isn't the magnum opus Kvelertak clearly have in them
column14: but there's enough brilliance here to indicate that LP three or four very well might be.

column1: Kvelertak's strongest songs have a way of making the hammiest stunts seem completely sensible. Lead single ""Bruane Brenn"" (""Burning Bridges"") charges into the band's wheelhouse: pummeling uptempo rawk with Hjelvik-- a stylistically limited yet enormously charismatic frontman-- shredding throat over top. First
column2: the band hints coyly at pop
column3: with a nifty melodic vocal hook from guitarist Maciek Ofstad and the subtle addition of Vidar Landa's pounding piano in the second verse. Then
column4: at the 2:45 mark
column5: they suddenly ramp down the tempo and burst into a half minute of pure power-ballad grandstanding. The moment is so shrewdly integrated
column6: it doesn't feel like winky pastiche; it's simply what the song demands.

column1: Other Meir standouts show off Kvelertak's mastery of disparate metal varietals. ""Spring Fra Livet"" (""Run From Life"") effortlessly juggles bluesy
column2: shimmy-friendly verses and tremolo-picked cosmic-black-metal interludes
column3: as drummer Kjetil Gjermundrød trades blastbeats for stadium-rock stomp. The effect is one of giddy inclusiveness
column4: as though these marauding Norsemen were clenching their scowling
column5: corpse-painted countrymates in a boozy bear hug. Awesomeness also abounds in ""Trepan"" (the title refers to an arcane medical practice involving skull-drilling) with its breathtaking triple-guitar stop-time interlude
column6: and ""Evig Vandrar"" (""Eternal Wanderer"")
column7: which dispenses with style-hopping in favor of handsomely Zepped-out
column8: stomping-giant raunch rock.

column1: Meir slackens in its second half. ""Tordenbrak"" (""Thunderclap"") features what might be the album's single finest riff-- a florid marvel that sounds something like Boston guitar wizard Tom Scholz embellishing on the Steve Miller Band's ""Jungle Love""-- but the band employs the motif like a crutch
column2: failing to situate it into any kind of compelling narrative arc over a near-nine-minute running time. Other songs seem arbitrarily eclectic. ""Nekrokosmos"" juggles so many sections
column3: it scans as the metal equivalent of a Magnetic Poetry blitz
column4: and when the band kicks into an old-school thrash gallop on ""Månelyst"" (""Moonlight"")
column5: the shift registers as a because-we-can move
column6: rather than one born out of real compositional urgency.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Meir rights itself at the end. The final track-- entitled
column3: yes
column4: ""Kvelertak""-- is a timeless beer-hoister
column5: like a Back in Black outtake souped up with hardcore-style gang vocals
column6: post-Jailbreak fret dancing and a soulful
column7: bittersweet chorus. Clocking in at 3:50
column8: it's basically perfect
column9: a reminder that epic-scale songs and frantic eclecticism are secondary to the band's central mission. Like so many of their beloved forebears
column10:
Kvelertak sound smartest when they're playing it dumb.

Given the reliability of 20-year nostalgia cycles
column2: the reunion of Suede-- or
column3: here in litigation-crazy America
column4: the London Suede-- was inevitable. A new Suede album
column5: however
column6: was not. Mere months after the Britpop progenitors embarked upon a well-received greatest hits revue in 2011
column7: frontman Brett Anderson had returned to his decade-long practice of releasing small-scale solo albums
column8: while a concurrent
column9: exhaustive reissue of Suede’s back catalogue seemingly confirmed the reunion’s retrospective impetus. And there was
column10: of course
column11: the nagging question of whether a new album was even necessary. After all
column12: Suede were their generation’s Saturday night soundtrack to being young
column13: being lost
column14: and undergoing all the necessary preparations (cigarettes
column15: alcohol
column16: drugs of dubious origin) to ensure you leave behind a most exquisite corpse. What could Suede offer to their faithful now that
column17: well into their sober 40s
column18: they no longer represent any of these things?

column1: For Bloodsports
column2: their plan is not to simply recapture their past
column3: but imagine an alternate course for it. Like their 2011 tour campaign
column4: Bloodsports employs the band’s post-1995 line-up-- i.e.
column5: the one without Anderson’s formative songwriting partner-turned-nemesis
column6: Bernard Butler. In the absence of Butler’s authoritative presence
column7: Suede’s albums sometimes veered toward the slight and frivolous
column8: the tension and bravado that fuelled their definitive singles giving way to a certain self-satisfied complacence. But if the relationship between Anderson and Butler’s replacement
column9: Richard Oakes
column10: was decidedly less tumultuous
column11: on Bloodsports
column12: the guitarist’s presence has an undeniably reinvigorating effect on the singer.

column1: Throughout Bloodsports
column2: Suede consistently strikes the balance between decadence and elegance-- a “world wrapped in tinsel
column3: ” swathed in “lipstick traces” and “second-hand furs”-- that marked their signature work. But where Anderson once aligned himself with his fellow misfits
column4: on Bloodsports he’s seeking more meaningful
column5: one-on-one connections. Though it climaxes with a bleacher-baiting gang chorus
column6: the Joshua Tree-toppling salvo “Barriers” is
column7: at its core
column8: an intimate
column9: open-hearted address from someone who wants his relationships to be measured in years rather than nights. And it gets Bloodsports off to a terrifically rousing start; the succeeding “Snowblind” and “It Starts and Ends With You” both come loaded with the sort of do-or-die urgency and knockout choruses to earn retroactive placement on 2010’s Best of Suede compilation.

column1: It’s fitting that Suede are staging their comeback the same month as their patron saint
column2: David Bowie (with whom Anderson famously shared an NME cover back in 1993). But where Bowie spends much of The Next Day sardonically addressing his extended absence and his own mortality
column3: Andrerson hurtles himself into Bloodsports with the stern-faced intent of someone who is grateful to have been granted a second chance and determined not to let it go to waste. And if his outsize passion isn’t enough to push every big-tent ballad over the top (like the middling “Sabotage”) or sell you on the odd underwritten chorus (e.g.
column4: “Come on and hit me/ With your mystery”)
column5: he keeps the frisson flowing well into Bloodsports’ more atmospheric and despairing second act. As the wide-eyed romanticism heard in the album’s opening stretch gives way to a vicious cycle of emotional dependency (“Sometimes I Feel I’ll Float Away”)
column6: betrayal (the eerily desolate “What Are You Not Telling Me?”)
column7: and predatory
column8: restraining-order-worthy behaviour (the ominous “Always”)
column9: the band respond with their weightiest
column10: most calamitous music since side two of 1994’s darkly epic Dog Man Star.

column1: But if Bloodsports stays faithful to Suede’s signature sound
column2: it represents a refreshing evolution in spirit. This is not the place to go to indulge your student-disco nostalgia; rather than try to swagger back onto the scene and try to out-snort men half their age
column3: Suede shrewdly draw our attention to those youthful indiscretions-- ego
column4: insecurity
column5:
obsession-- that we never seem to outgrow.

The Nashville-based William Tyler is obviously an amazing guitar player
column2: but it takes some accumulated hours with his music before you begin to notice and savor his deeper qualities. Making an album of wordless solo guitar compositions that remains interesting for its duration is hard
column3: demanding a range of subtle skills far beyond nimble fingers-- a fine
column4: exacting ear for color
column5: an intuitive sense of momentum
column6: a mind for musical structures. These are fragile musical gifts
column7: difficult to cultivate and even harder to point out
column8: and they become even more fragile when the focus bears down on a single instrument: You are painfully exposed
column9: both as a player and as a musical mind.

column1: Impossible Truth is Tyler's second richly satisfying and absorbing record of solo guitar in three years. His finger-picking offers a lovely
column2: rangy meditation on the power of the good old open-string drone
column3: and if you listen closely
column4: you can hear his searching intelligence animating every note. The cobwebbed cycle of chords that make up the center section of ""Cadillac Desert"" are played like an inner monologue
column5: dimming and surging like a gas lantern. Tyler employs some of the same back-up instruments here as he did on 2010's Behold the Spirit; wisps of pedal steel guitar
column6: stand-up bass
column7: vibes and xylophone
column8: softly glowing horns. But his guitar remains the single waveform bouncing through your headphone-space for nearly all of Impossible Truth's 54-minute running time
column9: and it never once grows tiring.

column1: Once you're fully immersed in Tyler's world
column2: you'll probably stop thinking of his music as ""solo guitar."" He has an uncommon way of making tangles of picked notes ring out like the melody of a searching pop song. Many of the Impossible Truth's pieces trace the contours of a mood that feels similar to the Beatles' ""In My Life"": wistful
column3: valedictory
column4: touched by fatalism. ""We Can't Go Home Again"" opens with two chords that pirouette mournfully from major to minor
column5: before easing with into a series of variations on a pentatonic theme that grow in forcefulness and confidence over three-and-a-half minutes. By the end
column6: it feels a ringing refutation of the title's gloomy proposition. ""A Portrait of Sarah""
column7: a tribute to Tyler's girlfriend
column8: Sarah Souther
column9: opens small-scale
column10: singing a particularly romatic and sweetly ascending tune that eventually kicks into a romping double-time. It's a heart-filling moment
column11: one of the only expressions of boundlessly personal joy on Truth. If there were words to this song
column12: they would cheapen the feeling.

column1: It also helps that Impossible Truth
column2: like Behold the Spirit
column3: is gorgeously recorded. Tyler's lines resonate a sonic space that sounds cavernous and chilly
column4: like he's recording in a drafty
column5: empty church. Although Tyler claims he was trying to escape John Fahey comparisons with this record
column6: through the lived-in confidence of his playing and the sense of folkish ease settling into his compositions
column7: he moves closer to the bracingly simple beauty that Fahey's music embodied. His strummed open chords on ""Country of Illusion"" even hint teasingly at Fahey's version of ""Joy To The World
column8: from the Christmas classic The New Possibility.

column1: But as he moves closer to Fahey's spirit
column2: Tyler sounds more and more like himself. Every melody he plays
column3: like the one that opens ""Last Residents of Westfall""
column4: somehow feels as it if was always there
column5: a rare musical quality that only settles in after years of weeding out the quotations that have crept into your playing. Once you've reached this rarefied air as a player
column6: whatever your musical mind touches will come out transformed
column7: and Impossible Truth is music of almost metaphysical calmness
column8:
in which Tyler's guitar surveys inner vistas and notes their vastness with a kind of Zen detachment.

In the States
column2: the popular perception of soul is that it’s the sound of nostalgia
column3: as defined by Blues Brothers dance-offs
column4: Big Chill soundtracks
column5: California Raisins commercials
column6: Duckie serenades
column7: and the countless dusty hip-hop samples that trigger back-in-the-day remembrances. Even its most visible modern-day adherents-- like Bruno Mars or Justin Timberlake-- reinforce the throwback assocations by using soul music as an opportunity to anachronistically dress up in suits and employ large
column8: identically attired backing bands seated behind large name-plates. But in England
column9: soul has been a constant lifesource for the country’s musical vanguard
column10: whether it was post-punkers mainlining the music’s emotional charge
column11: 1980s New Pop artists adopting its showbiz sheen
column12: or trip-hop producers taking its essence into more dystopian realms.

column1: The genre's dual existence is perfectly personified by Lady
column2: a Transatlantic collaboration between Atlanta native Nicole Wray and Londoner Terri Walker. The former was once a hotly tipped R&B upstart who scored a hit single collab with Missy Elliot in 1998
column3: but spent much of the 2000s as a pipes-for-hire backing singer for the likes of Kid Cudi and the Black Keys; the latter earned a Mercury Prize nomination in 2003 for her neo-soul debut Untitled
column4: but subsequent releases failed to generate the same critical or commercial traction. Playing the role of matchmaker is Truth and Soul
column5: the production team that helped ensure Aloe Blacc never needs another dollar.

column1: <div>Moreso than the singers’ individual pedigrees
column2: it’s the producers’ involvement that provides the most immediate signpost for Lady’s modernized retro-soul aesthetic
column3: which liberally draws on turn-of-the-70s signifiers -- from the unbridled joy of Jackson Five-era Motown to the proto-disco smooth of Philadelphia's MFSB -- but shirks any attempt for faux-AM-radio fuzziness in favour of crisp
column4: clean contours. But Truth and Soul are under no illusion as to who the real stars of the show are
column5: turning in tastefully unobtrusive
column6: appealingly suave arrangements-- chirpy trumpets
column7: silken strings
column8: bouncing-ball piano lines
column9: George Benson guitar accents-- that cooly complement Wray and Walker’s radiant harmonies rather than overpower them. And
column10: in light of their solo career struggles
column11: the singers clearly relish the opportunity to indulge in a little comfort food soul
column12: resulting in an infectiously fun set with broad
column13: cross-generational appeal.

column1: Lady's is a well-trodden field and
column2: at times
column3: their lyrical tropes are overfamiliar to the point of feeling vague
column4: if not downright lazy (e.g.
column5: “keep on running
column6: ” “get ready
column7: ” “baby slow down... you’re moving too fast”). So Wray and Walker distinguish themselves by amping up the charm and cheeriness to the max: The suggestively titled album highlight “Sweet Lady” is not some portrait of some temptress
column8: it’s a paean to their mothers. And rather than try to play up any contrast in their voices or establish any call-and-response tension
column9: Lady presents itself as a purely united front
column10: portraying the kind of BFF bond so strong it can easily withstand one friend sleeping with the other’s boy. (The song documenting that transgression comes with the polite titular request “Please Don’t Do it Again.”)

column1: But Lady’s geniality shouldn’t be confused for naivety. As the simmering late-album ballad “Habit” makes clear
column2: Wray and Walker are fully aware that they’re often “smiling through the pain
column3:
” finding themselves in romantic arrangements that blur the line between feeling loved and feeling trapped; even the innocuously titled “Good Lovin’” suggests a deadbeat boyfriend’s only saving grace is that he's good in the sack. And in that admission we can observe the most authentically retro thing about Lady: how they coyly dress up unsavory subjects in innocent packages as if trying to pull a fast one past Ed Sullivan’s censors.

On paper
column2: Ensemble Pearl isn’t supposed to sound quite so subdued: The new quartet is led by Stephen O’Malley
column3: the stage-right guitarist in thunderous hooded drone giants Sunn O))). Though they’ve explored a range of intricate ideas and dynamic approaches during the last 13 years
column4: they’re perhaps best known for extreme volume
column5: with tidal riffs powered by an arsenal of linebacker-sized amplifiers. In Ensemble Pearl
column6: O’Malley is accompanied by Bill Herzog
column7: the former bassist in Jesse Sykes & the Sweet Hereafter
column8: and the two flashiest members of Japanese metal pillagers Boris-- Atsuo
column9: the bare-chested and gong-banging drummer shouting into the microphone attached to his face
column10: and longtime collaborator Michio Kurihara
column11: a guitarist whose playing seems to thrive partially on sonic showmanship. If you dreamed a team for heavy rock with psychedelic tendencies
column12: this ensemble would be an acceptable fantasy.

column1: But Ensemble Pearl
column2: the quartet’s elegant six-song debut
column3: serves as a spotlight for the plasticity of the musicians that made it
column4: not their power. The brief “Wray”
column5: for instance
column6: recalls little else in the vast catalogues of Ensemble Pearl’s principals. Above a wafting drone that suggests a choir of glass harps
column7: the band adds granulated guitar notes that scrape and pop over guest Eyvind Kang’s mercurial viola tones. For the bulk of the album
column8: however
column9: you’ll likely recognize O’Malley’s steely tone and deliberate progressions from Sunn O)))’s more spare moments. But he avoids the monolithic sound of that group
column10: or their full-length collaboration with Boris
column11: 2006’s Altar. Instead
column12: he etches his riffs here at a relatively low volume. During the smoldering seven-minute “Painting on a Corpse”
column13: he traces each arid note toward its vanishing point. If Sunn O))) began as an Earth tribute band
column14: Ensemble Pearl is an extension of Earth’s latter-day testudinal blues. “Island Epiphany” begins with a similarly subdued lurch
column15: but it rises steadily in both density and decibels. Nine minutes in
column16: the track nears its apogee of intensity
column17: Kurihara webbing sheets of noise and sustain through the rhythm section’s insistent trot and O’Malley’s still-flickering riff. Even then
column18: though
column19: the music feels more like a conversation than a shouting match or
column20: in the case of Sunn O)))

column1: That conversational aspect is crucial for Ensemble Pearl
column2: a record whose layers connect with one another without coercing one another. Though Atsuo has certainly been at times quiet with Boris
column3: his playing here stands as some of the most patient and considered of his career. When the guitars go a bit wild during “Island Epiphany”
column4: he and Herzog stay the course
column5: fostering tension by providing an anchor. He does little more than keep time with his snare and add texture with his cymbals for “Ghost Parade”
column6: and that distance gives even his smallest contributions that much more impact. Ensemble Pearl seems very much about sustaining the balance between being present and passive
column7: or using minor devices to create major effects. To that end
column8: “Giant”-- the late-album
column9: sans-drum drone charged by amplifier hum
column10: and Kang’s viola-- stands as this band’s crowning achievement. These 10 minutes are thick but strangely luminous. The sound is as unified and overwhelming as the audio environments La Monte Young built with the Theatre of Eternal Music
column11: but every element is clear and balanced. You’ll notice moments of twinkling timbre and radiating noise just beneath the hum
column12: telltale signs of the real-time interaction between the players in the room.

column1: That interaction began in 2009
column2: when the band first assembled in Tokyo to start writing material that became part of Gisèle Vienne’s multimedia play
column3: This is How You Will Disappear. Those sessions only began to take shape as an album after the players realized how much they enjoyed working together
column4: so
column5: years later
column6: they returned to the material and finished it stateside with producer and engineer Randall Dunn. Later this year
column7: O’Malley reports
column8: Ensemble Pearl will likely begin work on a new record with additional members. That’s good news not only because this debut itself is compelling but because
column9: at last
column10: it represents a clear synthesis of so many of O’Malley’s activities. In recent years
column11: Sunn O))) has limited its activity to rare live shows
column12: reissues
column13: and rehearsal releases
column14: freeing O’Malley to explore the more experimental realm of his muse. Last year
column15: his duo KTL released its best disc yet
column16: V. His new label
column17: Ideologic Organ
column18: has issued excellent and overlooked work from composer Mats Lindström and improviser Norbert Möslang. He’s improvised with Tim Hecker and Steve Noble
column19: and at May’s Tectonics Festival in Glasgow
column20: he will perform both with American innovator Alvin Lucier and Romanian spectralist Iancu Dumitrescu. That dossier is meant to say that
column22: Ensemble Pearl feels like a probable and timely place for O’Malley’s past with Sunn O))) to collide with his future outside of it-- that is

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19054/homepage_large.eb431d1b.jpg|Calidostópia!|3187.0|Oval|['Rock'
column3: Berlin's Markus Popp became known for trailblazing the iconic Clicks & Cuts style
column4: working with the glitchy audio from skipping CDs. Back then
column5: his band Oval was a trio
column6: but Popp subsequently went solo and pursued an increasingly abstruse aesthetic with a series of albums for Thrill Jockey. Popp has often said that his work from this era was concerned with deconstructing and commenting on ""music"" in the traditional sense of the term
column7: rather than participating directly in that culture. Oval's ""Aero Deck""
column8: from 1994's Systemisch
column9: was sampled on ""Unison"" from Björk's Vespertine
column10: which takes a similarly deconstructionist approach.

column2: after almost a decade of silence from the Oval project
column3: Popp started afresh with the name. He described O
column4: released as Oval
column5: as feeling like a ""debut album"". Sampled sonic minutiae were replaced with real instruments
column6: ""loops"" replaced with ""riffs
column7: and careful studio arrangements supplemented with live improvisation. The results
column8: by Oval's standards
column9: were unprecedentedly warm and inviting. This pioneer of the abstract was
column10: he claimed
column11: finally making ""music.""

column1: Take a closer look at Oval's discography
column2: though
column3: and this narrative starts to feel simplistic. For all his emphasis on procedure over music and his use of self-imposed compositional restraints
column4: Popp has always had something of a populist sensibility. Half of Oval's oft-overlooked 1993 debut LP
column5: Wohnton
column6: featured charmingly unschooled vocals and breakbeat-led percussion
column7: inviting comparisons with contemporaries Seefeel. A decade later
column8: Popp collaborated with singer Eriko Toyoda as So
column9: for an eponymous LP where twilit vocal-guitar ballads lurked under the clouds of digital filigree.

column1: Calidostopia!
column2: recently released as a free download
column3: isn't so much a bolt from the blue as a return to a long-held preoccupation. This record was the result of a 10-day recording session in Salvador De Bahia in Brazil
column4: funded by the Goethe Institute and the Cultural Foundation of the State of Bahia. Popp brought along tracks taken from O
column5: its preceding EP Oh
column6: and offcuts compilation OvalDNA
column7: as well as some unreleased sketches. Seven vocalists from across South America transformed them
column8: in Popp's words
column9: from ""material"" into ""songs."" As such
column10: this record treats vocals in a manner more direct than Popp has attempted since Wohnton
column11: and foregrounds the song-like forms latent in Popp's recent compositions.

column1: Given that many of these tracks have been previously released
column2: the palette of this album will be familiar: gorgeous resonant tones
column3: somewhere between guitar and plucked piano strings
column4: that sputter sharply or lap like waves; splashy drums dancing nimbly around a groove; miniaturised squalls of electronic noise. In fact
column5: as with O
column6: Popp's choice of sounds is almost too uniform
column7: leaving it up to the vocalists to ward off potential monotony. Here they have mixed success. At points the marriage of vocal and backing is entirely adequate but doesn't really amount to more than the sum of its parts. Maité Gadea fails to take command in ""Glossy""
column8: and her contribution feels slightly extraneous as a result; Aiace's melodies on ""Alpen"" and ""Credit Roll"" unfold in a measured
column9: staid manner that seems to stifle the organic nature of their backings.

column1: But a handful of exquisite moments make the whole thing worthwhile. Agustín Albrieu is the most reliable in this regard
column2: his wonderfully clear
column3: open tone lending a starry-eyed quality to opener ""Featurette"" and closer ""Savvy Aeropuerto"". Elsewhere
column4: Hana Kobayashi transforms ""Koral"" into a beautiful hushed lullaby
column5: undeniably the record's highlight. Calidostopia! certainly feels like a hothoused project rather than a painstakingly constructed album-- the vocals are a little lacking in finesse at points
column6: and the wholesale use of pre-existing tracks can lend the thing a feeling of inflexibility. But at its best it's a captivating listen
column7: and an admirable move from a producer who continues to challenge himself after two decades in the game. ""This might be only the beginning
column8:
says Popp of this project. Fingers crossed.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18978/homepage_large.8334f210.jpg|The Invisible Way|2546.0|Low|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-03-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:04.708281|"

It’s easy to forget and hard to believe that Low have been doing this for 20 years now. Alan Sparhawk
column2: Mimi Parker
column3: and John Nichols started the group in 1993
column4: following in the wake of Codeine and Galaxie 500 but eventually coming to represent the slowcore sub-subgenre by dint of sheer longevity. Those two acts have already reissued their entire catalogs
column5: but Low have kept on keeping on. Still
column6: slowcore is an odd sound to buoy such a long career and sturdy catalog
column7: if only because it’s defined by its self-imposed limitation: at its best
column8: that slow tempo can be as intense as a punk song; as boring as wallpaper at its worst. Having hit both extremes at one point or another
column9: the most perfectly named band on the planet have owned up to the restrictions of their aesthetic.

column1: As a result
column2: their catalog is not necessarily diverse
column3: but they’ve managed to find a great deal of variety within this small patch of terrain
column4: thanks primarily to the open-ended nature of the band. Sparhawk and Parker have proved mainstays
column5: with numerous musicians caught in their orbit over time (the latest being multi-instrumentalist Steve Garrington). Furthermore
column6: Low have never shied away from working with producers who bring their own specific styles and aesthetics to their songs. In the late 1990s
column7: Kramer
column8: Steve Fisk
column9: and Steve Albini helped them define and refine their sound; in the next decade
column10: Dave Fridmann and Matt Beckley helmed albums with varying success. All used the band’s glacial dirges as a blank canvas
column11: and Low savored these outside perspectives
column12: as though they knew the band was never quite a self-contained unit.

column1: The latest producer to helm the boards for Low is Jeff Tweedy of Wilco
column2: who recorded the band at the Loft in Chicago. On one hand
column3: he’s such a perfect match that it’s surprising they’ve never worked together before: they’re all indie veterans who have come to represent various aspects of the Midwest-- Tweedy the busyness of Chicago and Low the remote plane of Duluth. On the other hand

column1: For all her positive mental attitudes

column3: a quality that has always been hinted at in her music but that Marnia makes much clearer. Even in the midst of its most festive moments
column4: like the conga-line rhythms of ""Noonan""

But the root of Stern's weakness is also the root of her power: The impression that she could fall apart at any second wouldn't be nearly as dramatic if she wasn't moving so dangerously fast.

column1: Under all the noise on Marnie Stern’s albums there has always been a need for some kind of quiet: For the thoughts to stop cycling

column1: Until now
column2: Stern has lived an artistic double life
column3: treated like a sensitive singer-songwriter for her persona and some posthuman techno-wizard for the way she plays a guitar. On every album since her debut
column4: these two parts of her have come closer together. On Marnia
column5: they’re one. ""Close your eyes
column6: she sings over the grand
column7: noisy waltz of ""Still Moving"". ""Nobody knows when it's gonna be. Nobody knows when it's gonna be. Close your eyes
column8: she repeats
column9: consoling
column10: for the first time in song
column11: someone other than herself.

column1: ""Maturity"" is a hackneyed trope in songwriting
column2: not to mention a word that doesn't quite suit a grown woman who periodically blogs under the name Marnie's fagina. But Marnia isn't the single touch that shatters
column3: it's the long
column4: steady stare that gives way to embrace. Not obsession
column5: as she puts it on ""You Don't Turn Down""
column6: but something deeper
column7: solemn
column8:
and more lasting.

Twenty years ago
column2: James McNew was still the new guy in Yo La Tengo
column3: hand-coloring the covers of 7-inch singles seemed like a totally reasonable thing to do
column4: and tape hiss was more than a badge of pride-- it was a sign of membership to an international society of home-recording introverts who all listened to each other. That was the environment into which the first two solo albums McNew made under the name Dump emerged
column5: timidly and elegantly. They're modest
column6: geeky records
column7: and they foreground McNew's idiosyncracies (like his thin
column8: high-pitched voice
column9: which has pretty much the same failings and lovability as Neil Young's) and tastes in other people's music. But theirs is the kind of modesty that complements McNew's formidable gifts.

column1: He was still immodest enough to name his debut album after its best original song-- although putting the handwritten words ""dump"" and ""superpowerless"" on a front cover was very much in line with the indie pop rhetoric of 1993
column2: when everybody was claiming to be a loser. Superpowerless under-promises
column3: which allows it to over-deliver: it's basically an album as a mixtape-with-handwritten-tracklist
column4: with a good mixtape's sense of flow and contrast. Its main lyrical theme is trying to make connections with other lonely people
column5: which is also the mechanism of its creation.

column1: Some of its songs are nicely chosen covers-- Sun Ra
column2: Wreckless Eric
column3: ""Moon River"" --and others are deeply indebted to a particular artist: ""19 1/2"" is a stab at Melvins-y heaviness
column4: and ""Broken Conscience"" genuflects in the direction of Tall Dwarfs' Slugbuckethairybreathmonster (so did the title of Yo La Tengo's Painful
column5: released the same year). The sweetest response to a favorite record here is ""Ode to Shaggs' Own Thing""
column6: on which McNew reproduces Dot Wiggin's uncertain guitar tone to nip and tuck the Shaggs' awkward instrumental into something a little more graceful. (The new reissue appends an earlier Dump EP and a few compilation tracks.)

column1: If Superpowerless is a sketch of what McNew's solitary space looked like
column2: I Can Hear Music is a portrait of him in a community
column3: especially its second disc
column4: recorded with some of the other performers from the 1994 Fast Forward music festival in the Netherlands. Barbara Manning duets with McNew on the Bonzo Dog Doo Dah Band's ""I Want to Be With You""; Chris Knox
column5: who had supposedly never played trumpet before
column6: blurts a double-tracked solo on the Ronettes/Beach Boys tune ""I Can Hear Music.""

column1: The first disc is another bucket from the same well as Superpowerless: home recordings with their cassette-tape artifacts reproduced as tokens of sincerity; pastiches of favorite bands (""Don't Let On"" is approximately a My Bloody Valentine-style chord progression); instrumental sketches that never quite got promoted to finished songs but have something about them that holds the sequence together; covers that either work nicely with McNew's voice (Ultravox's ""Vienna"") or are sturdy enough to work just fine despite it (Johnny Cash and Bob Dylan's ""Wanted Man""). McNew's strongest original songs are frontloaded this time: ""Slow Down"" and ""Hope
column2: Joe"" still turned up in set lists when Yo La Tengo did their ""spinning wheel"" tour a few years ago and occasionally ended up playing a set of Dump material.

column1: That seems to have been the fate of this project: McNew's songwriting got integrated into Yo La Tengo once it was clear that their 15th bassist was the one who was sticking around. He's been singing the occasional song with Yo La Tengo since 1997
column2: and the last Dump album was 2003's A Grown-Ass Man
column3: with only a handful of compilation tracks released since then. These first two albums are deliberately minor and unambitious
column4: sometimes nearly to the point of abjection. They're also treasures in a way that only small
column5: flawed
column6:
homemade things can be.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18686/homepage_large.132261d3.jpg|Change the Beat: The Celluloid Records Story 1980 – 1987|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Strut']|2013-03-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:09.933135|"

The glory years of the little New York-via-Paris imprint Celluloid Records
column2: represented on this compilation
column3: coincided with a particularly oppressive moment in the “monoculture
column4: ” that great and terrible behemoth we only evaluate now by its absence. In the early 1980s
column5: Lee Abrams
column6: the young prodigy radio consultant
column7: had already spread his vision of “narrow-casting” to American radio
column8: splitting the American listening populace into hundreds of distinct mini-markets and forcibly uncoupling the DNA strands of Black and White music for a generation of listeners in the process. MTV
column9: on the other hand
column10: was a sea of synth-pop
column11: hair metal
column12: and white faces; by the last year surveyed in this compilation
column13: the station had still programmed fewer than 10 rap videos total.

column1: The result was a systemic
column2: pervading sort of cultural racism that had been allowed to gather like rot. It even tainted those who benefited from it
column3: like Hall & Oates
column4: whose records were promoted on the advertiser-friendly and lucrative White pop FM stations that their Black musical heroes were banned from. Such was the world that French hipster Jean Karakos surveyed with a baleful eye when he first visited New York City in 1981: “I saw it with my own eyes in the shops-- there was nothing interesting in these big stores. Just mainstream rock
column5: the same old shit all the time
column6: ” he told The Quietus. ""So
column7: I decided at that point to go and live there in the States.”

column1: Having started in the record business in Paris as an importer
column2: Karakos had spent years loading his car with the best and most interesting records he could find in London’s Rough Trade shops and driving them back to home to sell and distribute. Egged along by his writer friend Bernard Zekri
column3: who was already in New York
column4: he relocated and began exploring on the ground. New York City in 1981
column5: it turns out
column6: was a pretty ideal moment for those who were looking to sniff out interesting culture. Hip-hop was snaking its furtive way down from the Bronx and into downtown clubs like the Ritz and the Roxy
column7: prodded along enthusiastically by ambassadors like Fab 5 Freddy
column8: where it fell in front of the eyes of transfixed interlopers: Rick Rubin
column9: ambling out of his Weinstein dormitory to the “Wheels of Steel” night at Negril; Wendy Day
column10: the stout working-class white woman who would go on to form the Rap Coalition
column11: having her world recalibrated by Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five; and Karakos
column12: along with his friend Bernard Zekri. Karakos
column13: like Rubin and Day
column14: was enraptured by what he saw and decided to get involved.

column1: The story told by Change the Beat is of this moment-- the first collision between Bronx rap with downtown hipsters
column2: the moment when the first art school kids and rappers mingled and checked out each others’ weird records. As with all nascent connections between white and black cultures
column3: the moments it documents are furtive
column4: endearing
column5: electric
column6: and ill-advised. The title of the compilation comes from the only rap track that Fab 5 Freddy ever cut; at Karakos’ behest
column7: Freddy rapped in French over a spare backbeat alongside Zekri’s French-speaking girlfriend (calling herself “Beeside” or “B Side” or just “Beside”) and the resulting song became a club hit. Freddy’s vocal tag also found its way into the backbone of Herbie Hancock’s “Rockit.” It is one of the many great leaping-synapse moments on Change the Beat
column8: one where you can hear a charge in the air of mutual discovery
column9: and the rules for countless future sub-genres being written.

column1: There are dozens of these “Eureka!” moments spread across Change the Beat’s 30 tracks: Karakos
column2: aided and abetted by his likeminded house producer and label partner Bill Laswell
column3: began greedily bottling lightning everywhere around him. The 1983 electro classic “Wildstyle” is here
column4: from Afrika Bambaataa’s outfit Time Zone. There is “Makossa Rock
column5: ” eleven minutes of slow-motion controlled explosion by Laswell’s group Deadline
column6: which counted Manu Dibango on sax and Bernie Worrell
column7: offering his signature squeedling jello-mold keyboard funk
column8: among its members. Oh
column9: and who shows up on guitar “Doriella du Fontaine”
column10: chop-chording along to the shaggy-dog proto-rap by The Last Poets member Lightning Rod? That would be Jimi Hendrix
column11: along with Buddy Miles
column12: on a tour stop. Cataloguing all of the “holy shit” moments documented on Change the Beat
column13: and considering their accumulated weight on the dance
column14: rap
column15: punk and art scenes that followed
column16: is almost exhausting.

column1: But Change the Beat is never exhausting. Disorienting
column2: maybe
column3: as you veer from asphyxiated post-punk wheezes like “Killing Time” to French cold-wave numbers like Nini Raviolette’s “Suis-Je Normale” to Ginger Baker’s “Dust to Dust
column4: ” which is just some twanging guitars and fretless bass. Celluloid released everything
column5: genre or sales potential be damned
column6: and that came to include some stuff that just wasn’t any good
column7: like the minute-long rant that is the free-jazz group Last Exit’s cover of Jimmy Reed’s “Big Boss Man”
column8: or stuff that hasn’t stood the test of time
column9: like French avant-rock bass guitarist Ferdinand Richard’s stumbling garage-psych “Tele
column10: Apres La Meteo.” Through all of it
column11: though
column12: even the small rough patches
column13: runs a certain boundless city energy
column14: the energy of people falling in love with other people’s ideas while the tapes were rolling.

column1: This energy is never more palpable or infectious than “The Escapades of Futura 2000”
column2: which presents listeners with a tableau not far away from what most people imagine when they romanticize early 1980s downtown New York: Futura
column3: the famed American graffiti artist
column4: rapping goofily over a live funk groove; Fab 5 Freddy
column5: cheering along in the background alongside fellow graffiti legend Dondi White. Keith Haring is shouted out in the song’s outro
column6: and on the hook
column7: Futura mounts a heartfelt aesthetic defense of graffiti-- “There’s a lot more to it if you check into it
column8: but the problem is you’re probably looking right through it!”-- that doubles as a neat metaphor for the plight of the developing genre with which graffiti was inextricably tied. If you are given to romanticizing cultural eras
column9: you could pick worse moments to cherish.

column1: Still
column2: a shadow of melancholy hovers over the idealism of Change the Beat
column3: and the Celluloid project by extension. The purity of the enthusiasm and curiosity coursing through the music tells its own story
column4: and it’s a beautiful one-- about the power of music to teach empathy
column5: leap over societal barriers
column6: and broaden experiences. But the truths pressing in outside the studio walls complicate that story: Radio remained effectively segregrated
column7: walling hip-hop off into nightly mix shows or Urban formats
column8: until 1993. The more opportunistic
column9: less scrupulous members of the scene Celluloid documented
column10: meanwhile
column11: found ways to cash in: Malcolm McLaren’s turntables record “Buffalo Gals” became a crossover hit
column12: finding its way into the mainstream pop world that ignored Grandmaster Flash. Against this backdrop
column13: Karakos’ furiously creative
column14: quixotic little label seems less like a revolution and more like an island
column15:
a brief moment of respite from the larger struggles that resume the minute the music stops playing.

"|17495.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17495-change-the-beat-the-celluloid-records-story-1980-1987/|8.0|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18993/homepage_large.365453a4.jpg|The Stand-In|31095.0|Caitlin Rose|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2013-03-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:10.527506|"

In case you didn’t guess from the old-fashioned glamor on the cover of Caitlin Rose’s third album
column2: its first song makes plain that the Nashville singer-songwriter has some quibbles with the modern age. “So long ago my radio heart got broken/ Now the songs I wanna hear
column3: they never play
column4: ” the 25-year old laments on “No One to Call”
column5: which starts with a rock flourish
column6: then sways through a smart Americana tumble of pedal steel and buoyant twangs
column7: like a luxury Richmond Fontaine. Of course
column8: radio stations are fickle by nature
column9: which is what makes them such an enduring lyrical metaphor. The Stand-In is a gorgeous-sounding chronicle of such archetypal props
column10: characters
column11: and sounds
column12: though the conceit does occasionally smother their narrator’s natural
column13: vital wit.

column1: The Stand-In was written in Rose’s living room
column2: where she would get drunk with her two best friends and write songs for characters
column3: underpinned by a streak of personal experience. Warring couples
column4: wallflowers
column5: mismatched just-marrieds
column6: the haunted heartbroken
column7: and fading stars all crop up
column8: united by their mistrust in appearances
column9: awareness of how we can bring out the worst in one another
column10: and a life of lowered expectations. There’s a sneaky
column11: killer couplet at the end of “Pink Champagne”
column12: all softly weeping pedal steel and somberly stepping bass drum
column13: where
column14: some time after a Vegas wedding that they knew was a bad idea even then
column15: the groom wearily observes
column16: “Never will forget the day you turned and said to me/ ‘Darlin’
column17: it was just as lovely as I dreamed that it could be.’”

column1: That slightly passive mode of dejection lingers over parts of The Stand-In
column2: though. Caitlin Rose is witty
column3: brilliant company in interviews and on-stage
column4: and songs like “Shanghai Cigarettes” from 2010’s Own Side Now amply proved that her charming voice can carry all those qualities musically
column5: too. Rose started out playing warehouse punk shows alongside bands like JEFF the Brotherhood
column6: but the often disconnected
column7: character-led nature of The Stand-In means that she’s usually singing at half-mast in a sweet but mopey tone that seems to say
column8: “don’t worry about me
column9: I’ll be okay”; on the Hawaiian cabaret of “Golden Boy”
column10: she pleas for a cad to stick around under the proviso
column11: “I won’t ask you what you’re here for if you’ll stay.”

column1: Although Rose’s voice contains fathoms of power largely untapped here
column2: it is a striking instrument to carry a hypnotic
column3: achey-breaky
column4: pop-catchy chorus
column5: of which she has bucketloads. It's the magnetic power of these choruses that stop The Stand-In from slipping into classy
column6: stiflingly comfortable pastiche. She bares her teeth a little on “Waitin’”
column7: a scathing
column8: sad number where two former halves of a couple realize that neither party ever thought it would work out; on “Only a Clown”
column9: co-written with the Jayhawks’ Gary Louris
column10: she flips a clichéd couplet about putting “a record on” and having the “band play a song” by rolling her eyes at the idea that songs “all about love and believing” have anything at all to do with real life.

column1: The Stand-In opts out of such conundrums by existing in a sort of fantasy world where people call the radio when they have no-one else to speak to-- more over
column2: where people call each other at all. Its use of swooning pedal steel
column3: twangin’ electric guitar
column4: and ringing tube amps give it a period-perfect
column5: shuttered-off feel that's occasionally prone to becoming a tad cheesy
column6: but in an un-self-conscious
column7: honest fashion. Rose's imperviousness to the whims of modern production and concerns is admirable in a way
column8:
though she's undoubtedly got the chops to shed the stylistic crutch if she wanted to.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19034/homepage_large.0a17071f.jpg|Pretend To Be Brave|5338.0|BOAT|['Rock'
column3: Seattle's BOAT have carved out a niche in the crowded contemporary indie rock landscape by delivering consistent
column4: tuneful power-pop with a sense of humor. Band captain D. Crane lands somewhere between an earnest Stephen Malkmus and a focused Robert Pollard on the vocal spectrum
column5: depending on the release; he churns out melodic guitar lines and driving rhythms with the help of his bandmates
column6: and cracks wise about shooting the breeze with his mom over a plate of nachos. While previous albums offered opportunities for wisecracks and appreciative homage-- the heavily referential cover of 2011's Dress Like Your Idols is one such example-- their newest record
column7: Pretend to Be Brave
column8: finds the group maintaining their finely honed sonic equilibrium while exploring intriguing new lyrical motifs.

column1: For a breezy
column2: compact guitar pop record
column3: Pretend to Be Brave is surprisingly concerned with maturity and mortality
column4: and this juxtaposition is the source of some of the album's finest moments. Crane immediately explores the former on the wonderful album opener ""Sharpshooters""
column5: a lovely ode to domesticity and companionship that celebrates the resiliency of an adult relationship. The song is BOAT at its best: playful
column6: concise
column7: and armed with sweet
column8: taut guitar melodies. Elsewhere the album is peppered with statements that often opt for gravity over sardonic wit
column9: from the rain-soaked near-death narrative of ""Inside an Aquarium"" to the nautical adventure gone awry of ""With the Sea at My Back."" Album closer ""Grind Likes Gears"" strikes the record's most poignant
column10: bittersweet note
column11: chugging slowly and flecked with pedal steel: ""As months turn into years/ We grind to halt like gears/ Stripped of all their paint and rusting away."" Crane's endearing yelp ably supports these newly serious lyrical themes: he sings about love
column12: aging
column13: and death with an appropriate degree of emotional investment
column14: and never seems flippant.

column1: BOAT's attempts to pair their more complex thematic material with equally engaging songs achieve varying levels of success. The presence of guest vocalist Shelley Short elevates several tracks to new heights
column2: her sweetness complementing and softening the high end of Crane's vocal work; on standout ""Interstellar Helen Keller
column3: their interplay is simultaneously reminiscent of both Eternal Summers and the New Pornographers' super duo of Neko Case and A.C. Newman. That said
column4: the band's tendency towards brevity occasionally means worthy ideas or melodies are cut short and prematurely discarded. The aforementioned ""Sore Toes and Elbows"" soars to a powerful climax but lacks the lengthy build-up it deserves
column5: and a handful of songs on the album's back half hint at interesting rhythms and melodies without allowing them room to breathe. Crane and his bandmates have tapped into a reservoir of solid ideas that are ripe for expansion
column6:
and Pretend to be Brave indicates they could justify using the extra space and time.

"|17839.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17839-boat-pretend-to-be-brave/|6.8|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18934/homepage_large.d80b538a.jpg|The 20/20 Experience|4920.0|Justin Timberlake|['Pop/R&B']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['RCA']|2013-03-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:11.707578|"

Consider 'N Sync's 2001 hit ""Pop""
column2: a defensive track co-written by Justin Timberlake that takes aim at boy-band haters. ""All that matters is that you recognize that it's just about respect
column3: he sings. The song was on 'N Sync's final album
column4: Celebrity
column5: which sold nearly two million copies in the U.S. in its first week-- and by that point the group had gone platinum about 30 times over. Even back then
column6: this desire for meaningful admiration was nagging at Timberlake. ""Pop"" is slyly referenced on ""Strawberry Bubblegum""
column7: a love-as-sugar-rush space-soul trifle from the singer's third LP
column8: The 20/20 Experience. ""I'm gonna love you 'til I make it pop
column9: he goes
column10: emphasizing the last word with the exact same sense of joy as he did 12 years ago. But now there's no irked aftertaste. Justin Timberlake is respected
column11: and he's using that cred to make an eight-minute love song with the word ""bubblegum"" in its title that astutely references Barry White
column12: Drake-style ambient R&B
column13: and Sly Stone. He's walking the walk and chewing gum at the same time.

column1: The same can be said for the rest of The 20/20 Experience
column2: which has Timberlake seamlessly conflating the last 40 years of pop
column3: soul
column4: and R&B into a series of warping seven-minute songs that shamelessly extol the joys of music and marriage. More ambitious and judicious than his first album
column5: Justified
column6: and more consistent than 2006's FutureSex/LoveSounds
column7: the record mixes up not only genres and traditional song structures
column8: but entire critical value systems. The poptimists who rode Timberlake's wave to post-guilty-pleasure virtuousness may decry its lack of three-and-a-half minute hits; old-schoolers may dismiss its simplistic themes. But by combining the direct warmth of a picture-perfect wedding with music that is complex and expansive
column9: he's harkening back to an era when the biggest-selling album could begin with a six-minute
column10: multi-part
column11: groove-based epic called ""Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'"" and another extended
column12: expertly arranged
column13: gloriously campy touchstone called ""Thriller"".

column1: Within his own discography
column2: Timberlake's current path can be traced back to one song
column3: the Timbaland-produced ""Cry Me a River"". More than any other
column4: that track-- which sounds as odd and gothic and heady today as it did in 2002-- made way for his current role as first-class pop vanguard. FutureSex
column5: spearheaded sonically by Timbaland once again
column6: developed the syncopated formula further
column7: lengthening beats
column8: adding scene-setting interludes
column9: and generally approaching pop with the sort of rule-crushing abandon that is often desired but rarely achieved. But then Timberlake went into movieland
column10: and Timbaland
column11: along with many of his peers
column12: went into Euro-schlock-land
column13: and ""SexyBack"" became an ever-foggier memory
column14: made more poignant because it marked a time and a collaboration that seemed completely over. Which is yet another reason why The 20/20 Experience is such a welcome comeback. It's not only about the return of a human being who can hold an entire stadium rapt for hours
column15: but a producer who had seriously lost his way.

column1: 20/20 has Timbaland
column2: along with protege Jerome ""J-Roc"" Harmon
column3: returning to the sounds that flipped so many ears at the beginning of this century: the Bhaṅgṛā rhythms that drive ""Don't Hold the Wall""
column4: the squealing vocal samples of ""Spaceship Coupe""

The experimental folk music of Julian Lynch
column2: spread out over a handful of cassette releases
column3: singles
column4: and now four proper albums
column5: is unfailingly polite. In an installment of Pitchfork's ""5-10-15-20"" series
column6: Lynch even hinted that it had to be that way because he didn't want to annoy his neighbors. It's work that tiptoes gingerly into the world
column7: and there's something endearing about that
column8: indicating a lack of confidence
column9: perhaps
column10: or an intuitive reflex to stick a few barriers between himself and the world that he can't dislodge.

column1: Parallels have been drawn between Lynch's work and post-rock in the past
column2: and it's hard to escape those again on Lines. ""Carios kelley i"" initially spins into the wistful orbit of the Sea and Cake before taking a detour into the jazz fusion world Tortoise explored on TNT. The difference between those groups and Lynch is that
column3: some four albums into his career
column4: it's still hard to figure out who he is and what he's trying to communicate. Lyrics are mostly rendered indecipherable
column5: good ideas are picked up but never returned to. It's music that easy to marvel at
column6: to admire the technical skill and use of sound. But it's much harder to fully fall in love with.

column1: Lynch's music is always meticulously arranged
column2: and the pristine structure of Lines makes it feel like little has changed in his painstakingly precise world since 2011's Terra. Lynch has a considerable talent in this arena; he knows exactly when to bring in a parp of flatulent horn
column3: or to release the tension when a great pile of instrumental parts begin to teeter on top of one another.

column1: He can play it simple
column2: too. ""Lines"" is one of the prettiest songs he's written to date
column3: and is expertly built up from a simple piece of strummed repetition that allows the rest of the instrumentation to amiably wander into the track as it progresses. It's the second longest song here
column4: which feels key. Often Lynch is a little too quick to call time on his genre digressions. The Can-influenced ""Horse Chestnut"" feels like it could have arrived at a different spot altogether if he loosened the tight control on it. But that isn't
column5: and never has been
column6: Lynch's place
column7: and wishing him to get there is
column8: by now
column9: a mostly futile pursuit.

column1: That ""place"" where Lynch resides still mostly remains in the folk tradition
column2: in affably worked songs spun around simple guitar structures
column3: like this album's ""Gloves"". There's never any dirt under his fingernails
column4: never any sense that he has the confidence to reach a place of great lyrical depth. And that's fine
column5: mostly. Occasionally there are unwelcome turns
column6: the stodgy rock of ""Onions"" being a particularly egregious offender
column7: but mostly this is Lynch doing what he does in his usual tasteful but somewhat unremarkable way. If Lines adds something to the world
column8: it's akin to the feeling you get from a small act of kindness from a stranger. Not something you forget in a hurry
column9: but not something that necessarily adds much significance to your life. Lynch seems comfortable here
column10: scattering out another set of question marks
column11:
his unassuming approach etched in just a little harder with every passing release.

Despite releasing a generous amount of music over the past couple years
column2: Deniro Farrar hasn’t made it easy for us to pin him down. The North Carolina rapper prefaced 2010’s Feel This with an announcement fitting for a release that made its way through chipmunk-soul
column3: stadium-EDM
column4: and a “Laffy Taffy” remake: “I’m Deniro on some tracks
column5: Deniro Farrar on other tracks.” He hasn’t outright claimed DID as an influence on his songwriting since then
column6: but his personality has remained elusive. The production of last February’s DESTINY. altered mixtape was sometimes busy enough to shroud him in the mix
column7: while October’s Kill or Be Killed was a full-length team-up with Oakland’s fast-rapping Shady Blaze and consequently didn’t always keep him in the foreground longer than a minute or two. It’s only this time around
column8: with The Patriarch
column9: his second solo tape
column10: that the resolution on Deniro has been high enough for us to really gauge him.

column1: The 25-year-old’s voice falls somewhere between Bun B’s and that of former G-Unit great Young Buck
column2: but his verses have a lot more in common with the ones Freddie Gibbs has been pumping out. Deniro’s a gangsta rapper
column3: more or less
column4: except he’s as prone to inverting typical gangsta-rap formulae in order to highlight his desperation and struggle as he is to rampant misogyny and violence. The epigram here is a nod to Shyne’s rant “Dear America”-- “I’m only what America made me/ Young
column5: black
column6: and fuckin’ crazy”-- and Deniro’s often at his best when extricating his dilemma strand by strand. This can be found in both understated revelations (“I ain’t got shit to my name but this AK”) and more pronounced intimations of his elder-statesmanship
column7: like this one from “Thug Till I Die”: “Makin’ millions sellin’ grams
column8: that shit ain’t realistic/ It’s either death or prison
column9: that other shit television.” Deniro’s had a bumpy personal life-- his younger brother
column10: in fact
column11: is currently facing a murder charge-- and there’s palpable pain and hard-earned sagacity here
column12: at least when he’s not saying something like his “chopper make ‘em dance like a ballet recital.”

column1: Deniro’s native Charlotte doesn’t boast much in the way of a traditional sound
column2: and so
column3: unlike many Southern rappers
column4: he has no moral obligation to add to some specific regional legacy. It’s a freedom that works in his favor. Besides Nova Scotia’s Ryan Hemsworth and Chicago duo Flosstradamas
column5: The Patriarch’s producers are all very minor names
column6: staples only in the tight-knit community of so-called blog-rap. But they’re also guys who have worked with Deniro before
column7: and they’re starting to figure out the best approaches to backing him. From the skyward ambience of “Feel the Rain” to the gyrating “Back/Forth/Back” to “My Life”’s <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gl83mI69nX4"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Kick
column8: Push”-like kick-clap
column9: these are all great-to-excellent beats. But just as crucially
column10: not even the busiest productions (“Look at the Sky”
column11: the remix of Hemsworth’s “Based World”) stand out so much as to obstruct our look at the guy they’re supporting. Which is good
column12: because the guy they’re supporting is worth hearing as clearly as possible.

column1: The Patriarch might not present anything totally uncommon during its 50 minutes
column2: but there are a couple personal breakthroughs here for Deniro. “Thug Till I Die” might be his first deliberate earworm
column3: and while it recruits light Auto-Tune in an effort to make the most out of the chorus
column4: it puts Deniro in a nuanced sensitive-thug mode instead of just making him sound soft. On the other hand
column5: “Big Tookie” is the most replayable song with a titular reference to gangland since “B.M.F.”
column6: its tumbling
column7: Hemsworth-provided keyboards providing a supremely effective contrast to some of Deniro’s hardest bars yet. Until The Patriarch
column8: I had no major reservations about labeling Deniro a “blog-rapper
column9: ” the title he’s so often been handed thus far. These two songs-- and plenty of others here
column10: really-- render that designation questionable. Whatever the next step is for Deniro in 2013
column11:
he seems more than ready for it.

Purling Hiss started off as the solo side-project of Mike Polizze
column3: then the guitarist of Philadelphia free-form heavy rock outfit
column4: Birds of Maya. His first release
column5: a self-titled CD-R that was later pressed to LP
column6: didn’t stray far from that band’s sound. The songs
column7: which were recorded to a cassette four-track
column8: were simple and spontaneous-- thick with blistering solos
column9: bluesy churn
column10: and lo-fi gristle. But deep down in the murk
column11: Polizze stashed a handful of great hooks. On Public Service Announcement
column12: his third LP under the name
column13: but his oldest set of recordings
column14: the guitarist spliced his fuzz-addled leads into three chord pop songs that recalled 90s classic rock apologists like Dinosaur Jr. and Meat Puppets.

column1: Since then
column2: Polizze has expanded the project into a power trio
column3: recruiting drummer Mike Sneeringer and bassist Kiel Everett
column4: and hit the road opening for Kurt Vile
column5: Woods
column6: Wilco
column7: and Dinosaur Jr. <i>Water on Mars
column8: which is out on Drag City
column9: is the first record that this lineup has done together and also the first of the band’s LPs to be assembled in a professional studio. As a result

column1: Purling Hiss is one of a community of Philadelphia-area bands that have been combing dino rock tropes through weirder
column2: outsider sensibilities. Most of the band’s peers-- Kurt Vile
column3: the War on Drugs
column4: and Blues Control-- fold spacey effects and new age tones into chord changes that venerate Bruce Springsteen and Tom Petty. Ambience isn’t Purling Hiss’ thing
column5: though. They rock at high volume and in earnest. Album opener
column6: “Lolita”
column7: could have snuck onto the b-side of Nirvana’s Bleach
column8: riding a screeching riff that ping-pongs between octaves into a sleazy
column9: chugging verse. Indie rock guitar hero status is too easily bestowed these days
column10: but Polizze deserves some recognition. He’s not a show off
column11: but his playing betrays a few years spent patiently studying guitar heroes both cool (Kawabata Makoto) and uncool (Grand Funk Railroad).

column1: On Water on Mars
column2: Polizze makes an effort to show off both sides of his songwriting-- the heavy
column3: gnarly stuff
column4: but also the slacker-pop hooks that made Public Service Announcement stand out. As a lyricist
column5: Polizze steers clear of deep reflection and introspection. He’s a more of a generalist
column6: blurring everyman rock thoughts (“Everybody wants to have a good time”) with a little bit of urban dirtbag dream logic (“Found a god in a parking lot
column7: saw a life in a grain of sand”). His softest turns here
column8: “She Calms Me Down” and “The Harrowing Wind”
column9: are as moody and skewed as any of his bedroom tapes.

column1: On the record’s title track
column2: Purling Hiss’ two personalities blend together. The song
column3: which carries on for more than seven minutes
column4: inverts the usual verse-to-jam trajectory. Polizze’s vocals only arrive after five minutes of fuzz-wah histrionics and rather than building to a dense crescendo
column5: Sneeringer keeps the band in line with a steady marching rhythm. It’s heady and blown out
column6: but somehow easygoing at the same time. The ability to slide between these two poles is what makes Purling Hiss’ unique. They have the riffs
column7:
but none of the anxiety.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18801/homepage_large.51691fc0.jpg|Sky Burial|30991.0|Inter Arma|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2013-03-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:14.126544|"

On the second full-length from Richmond
column2: VA's heavy psychedelic alchemists Inter Arma
column3: danger and apocalypse always loom nearby
column4: casting long shadows over everything within sight. In these eight songs
column5: the destroyer becomes the vaunted creator. Humankind sends the earth into a vortex of despair and decay. End-times gloom represents a lone currency of hope. The music is made to match
column6: too
column7: with salvos of rapid-fire black metal and plumes of foreboding instrumental drift lightning the lantern toward darkness.

column1: Listening to Sky Burial
column2: however
column3: is one of the most exhilarating experiences you might hope to have with a record
column4: largely because its creators sound so obviously intoxicated and energized by the possibilities of music itself. As these five multi-instrumentalists and experimenters work through creaking doom and obliterative marches
column5: smoldering introductions and scowling grooves
column6: the sense that they’re loving every moment of this is pervasive. They foreground their enthusiasm and counter the darkness with contagious élan. Appropriate for an album so obsessed by the beginnings that endings can bring
column7: Sky Burial’s misanthropic heart is inspired enough to make one
column8: well
column9: happy.

column1: At nearly 70 minutes
column2: Sky Burial is a massive stylistic crucible where unlikely influences and aspirations bleed and blur into one another. Inter Arma represents a convergence of disparate traditions-- Led Zeppelin and Lightning Bolt
column3: Pink Floyd and Pentangle
column4: Immortal and Enslaved
column5: Sleep and the Staple Singers. Though all these strains share the same space
column6: Inter Arma never sounds claustrophobic
column7: meaning they give each component its due before showing how it can cooperate with the next approach. Acoustic interludes in the midst of loud rock records
column8: for instance
column9: certainly aren’t novel ideas
column10: but when Inter Arma push away from the amps and drop the howls
column11: the acoustic instrumentals don’t function as mere sideshows. Lined with sighing steel guitar and sustained piano notes
column12: the four-minute “The Long Road Home (Iron Gate)” shows similar development to the 10-minute epics that bookend it. Inter Arma opens its successor
column13: “The Long Road”
column14: with more than seven minutes of rising rock ’n’ roll action
column15: reaching the It Still Moves-sized limits of My Morning Jacket before catapulting
column16: without hesitation
column17: into a malevolent Scandinavian-influenced blast. At one point
column18: “Westward” flips from a patchwork of noise and grindcore into the sort of open-wheel blues metal you’d expect from millennial Allman descendants.

column1: One could counter
column2: of course
column3: that being stoked on making music isn’t enough to make said music good. The teenager enlisting friends to join a basement rock band is certainly zealous
column4: but that doesn’t mean their tunes are worthy of your time. But Inter Arma isn’t just ardent. Rather
column5: these songs are both well designed and well executed. The ingenious “’sblood” rides the same riff and rhythm for most of its six minutes
column6: while Mike Paparo shouts four repetitive lines about the limits of the earth. He breaks the lines into pairs
column7: though
column8: a device that the band uses to create a tripwire of tension as the audience awaits the conclusion. Opener “The Survival Fires” might be the band’s best dexterity showcase to date. Drummer and instrumental cleanup man T.J. Childers works through demanding patterns; he rolls into stuttering beats and lumbers into distended grooves. The guitars match the action
column9: countering the central theme with grinding dissonance and sudden breakaways. In metal
column10: this sort of spirit without the skills to match can be a missed opportunity
column11: while the skills without the spirit can be worse still. Musically
column12: Inter Arma is good enough to manage all of these sounds; emotionally
column13: they are excited enough to make them work in one righteous exhortation.

column1: Sky Burial will likely land as one of the year’s great breakthroughs for a heavy act
column2: standing
column3: at least in my mind
column4: as the same sort of pay-attention proclamation as the Body’s All the Waters of the Earth Turn to Blood in 2010 or Pallbearer’s Sorrow and Extinction in 2012. That’s good news for Relapse Records
column5: the venerable metal syndicate that picked up Inter Arma after their fine full-length debut
column6: Sundown. But listening to Sky Burial
column7: you get the sense that an escalation of notoriety won’t change Inter Arma so much. They are
column8: after all
column9: already making music that doesn’t make sense on paper. Segue the Southern rock instrumental into Second Wave black metal screech? Sure. Volley from tightly wound prog into swaggering stoner land? OK.

column1: The root of Inter Arma’s creative success seems to be their delight in stubbornness
column2: their willingness to indulge what they’d like to indulge
column3: with no need to negotiate genre expectations. In this post-everything moment
column4: where multiple sounds often arrive at once
column5: it’s common for young musicians to exist as magpies
column6: collecting stylistic scraps only to display them as their own piece. It is
column7: however
column8: much rarer for those results to seem so wholly synthesized
column9: even as the individual parts don’t buckle under the weight of their accoutrements. Sky Burial does just that
column10:
brandishing erudition just enough to arrive at a crossroads of inspiration and innovation.

"|17607.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17607-inter-arma-sky-burial/|8.2|Grayson Currin

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18716/homepage_large.36422597.jpg|Muchacho|3475.0|Phosphorescent|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2013-03-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:14.701802|"

When Phosphorescent's Matthew Houck came off the road in support of his last album
column2: 2010's Here's to Taking it Easy
column3: he was mentally and physically exhausted
column4: uncertain he wanted to make another Phosphorescent record. So he dispatched himself to Tulum
column5: a small community in Mexico
column6: where
column7: he said
column8: ""I just checked out of my life for a while."" As he took long solitary walks in the woods and swam
column9: the pieces of what would become Muchacho began taking shape in his mind.

column1: As with everything Houck does as Phosphorescent
column2: from 2007's urban-rustic classic Pride to his 2009 Willie Nelson tribute record
column3: this little story has an endearingly second-hand ring to it
column4: as if Houck was obediently following the dictates of some dog-eared country-drifter playbook tucked in his back pocket. But this credulousness is also key to his music
column5: which glows with simple reverence and purity. On Muchacho
column6: Houck gathers together everything he's attempted-- beery
column7: rollicking country-rock
column8: haunted tribal hymnals
column9: regret-soaked bar room heartbreak-- and fashions it into something close to a defining statement.

column1: The first layer of Muchacho to savor is the simple gloriousness of its sound. Houck records his music largely alone
column2: bringing in key players for individual parts but crafting the end results meticulously
column3: in isolation. With the assistance of engineer John Agnello (Kurt Vile
column4: Male Bonding)
column5: he has produced a bright
column6: rich
column7: warmly three-dimensional record
column8: one that fuses the headed-for-the-big-city bar-rock signifiers of Here's to Taking it Easy with the night-sky awe of his earliest work. In fact
column9: the album feels like a daylight version of Pride
column10: a point hammered home by the contrast between that album's ""Be Dark Night"" and this one's two book-ending hymnals.

column1: Accordingly
column2: listening to Muchacho often feels like being warmed by afternoon sun as it floods your window. Every sound is lovingly recorded and given a cradle of space: The rounded pop of the drum track on ""Terror in the Canyons (The Wounded Master)""
column3: paired with tumbles of upright piano and softly pattering bongos; the dryly whispering bowed harmonics that open ""A Charm/A Blade""; the mournful little mariachi trumpet solo winding through the country waltz of ""Down to Go"". The first thing we hear on the record
column4: introducing the opening ""Sun"" hymnal
column5: is a dreamlike
column6: welcoming major-key synth flutter. Those synths reappear on ""Song For Zula""
column7: mingling with crystalline threads of pedal steel guitar
column8: lifting country's signature instrument further heavenward.

column1: At the center of all these majestic noises sits Houck himself. His voice is an unreliable instrument-- reedy
column2: hiccuping
column3: prone to cutting out entirely mid-note-- but he plies it heartbreakingly
column4: never more than on Muchacho. On ""Sun
column5: Arise!"" and ""A New Anhedonia""
column6: he stacks himself into massed
column7: keening layers
column8: like a church full of choirboys. It’s a technique that he’s used before
column9: but he has never sounded as overwhelming as he does here. The persistent catch in his voice
column10: meanwhile gives him an unstable
column11: baby chick fragility
column12: magnifying the pathos of a line like
column13: ""See honey I am not some broken thing/ I do not lay here in the dark waiting for thee"" from ""Song For Zula"".

column1: One of Muchacho's main thematic concerns is redemption
column2: and it’s one Houck explores with his customary ringing
column3: allegorical language. Sometimes his writing grows so high-flown that it eludes sense: ""I was the wounded master
column4: and I was the slave… I was the holy lion
column5: and I was the cage/ I was the bleeding actor
column6: and I was the stage
column7: he sings on ""Terror in the Canyons (The Wounded Master)"". More straightforward is this
column8: from ""Muchacho’s Tune"": ""See I was slow to understand/ This river’s bigger than I am/ It’s running faster than I can
column9: though lord I tried."" It’s a simple sentiment
column10: pitched somewhere south of Zen koan and just north of heartland-rock cliche
column11: and it maps out the coordinates of Houck’s world: It’s a place where well-worn sounds are the most beloved
column12: where ideas and poses are settled into like old chairs. On Muchacho
column13:
Houck invests this world with new beauty and profundity.

Like so many scrappy
column2: pub-rocking British blokes before them
column3: Palma Violets face an awkward proposition when presenting its debut record 180 on this side of the pond. Because they've received ecstatic acclaim from the most excitable parts of the English music press
column4: they will inevitably be described as “hyped” or (worse) “over-hyped.” And this will impact how 180 is perceived in this country
column5: because of the aforementioned long line of scrappy (and hyped!) pub-rocking British blokes that have tried and failed to make an impression in the States. But Palma Violets aren’t actually being shoved down any American throats-- the group’s energetic classic-rock re-workings are the polar opposite of what’s considered fashionable in our national music press. Over here
column6: Palma Violets are in the untenable position of seeming vastly oversold while really being a huge underdog.

column1: 180 is an appropriately modest yet likeable effort for an underdog act-- bigger on heart than brains
column2: the record’s lack of sophistication speaks to the bands members’ age and limited experience (they’ve been together for less than a year and a half) as well as their dearth of cynicism or guile. Palma Violets play proudly sloppy rock‘n’roll that unapologetically draws from the most obvious sources imaginable for a young band from London: the Clash
column3: the Velvets
column4: the Doors
column5: a little Springsteen
column6: Oasis’ Definitely Maybe
column7: Clinic’s Internal Wrangler
column8: the first couple of Libertines singles. Given that the band members all hover on the north and south sides of 20
column9: it’s fair to assume that they’ve only been listening to those bands for a few years. Rock music probably entered their lives with the Arctic Monkeys
column10: and they’re still thrilled by it. 180 is an act of evangelism from giddy enthusiasts who don’t know how well-worn these sounds are because they’re new to them.

column1: The single that started the mini-wave of Palma-mania in the band’s home country is “Best of Friends”
column2: which is placed at the start of 180 like an invitation. Truth be told
column3: it is a great song
column4: with a tightly strummed guitar riff pitched somewhere between punk and Merseybeat and a bear-hug of a chorus hollered with beery gusto by guitarist Sam Fryer and bassist Chilli Jenson. The excitable chemistry between Fryer and Jesson is what ignites Palma Violets’ lauded concerts. On “Best of Friends
column5: ” they consciously grasp for the legendary shouty harmonizers of Brit-rock’s past
column6: and while they’re no Strummer and Jones
column7: they squarely nail the pint-hoisting romanticism of fresh-faced pals forming a gang and striking out against the world. Lyrically
column8: “Best of Friends” is like a prequel to Faces’ “Ooh La La
column9: ” where the sting of a busted-up romance (even if it’s brushed off when the guys sing
