column6: judging by his licks

column8: the Velvet Underground’s ""Sister Ray""
column9: “and Faces’ “Stay with Me”. Mayhew supplies trance-y drone to “Step Up for the Cool Cats” and a menacing psychedelic patina to “Chicken Dippers”
column10: almost single-handedly preventing 180 from relying too heavily on the more predictable
column11: monochromatic guitar-rock bravado of songs like “Johnny Bagga’ Donuts”
column12: the album’s loudest and dumbest track (in a good way).

column1: No
column2: Palma Violets don’t deserve the amount of ink they’ve received overseas. The songwriting is a little undercooked: “We Found Love” is rife with lyrical groaners (“gonna find myself a ladyfriend and stick by her until the end”) and ends with a direct lift of the riff from “Sweet Jane"". Palma Violets aren’t there yet; if they aren’t tossed on the young rock dude scrap heap too quickly

column4:
and not have anything clever to say in response. Sometimes a good racket speaks louder than words.

Aly Spaltro’s stage name and backstory may at first seem awfully whimsical; the name Lady Lamb the Beekeeper came to her in a dream

column3: Maine. So far
column4: so Fox Searchlight. But forget fey; that basement gave her license to get loud

column8: biblical epics call to mind Jeff Buckley
column9: Okkervil River
column10: Jack White
column11: Helium
column12: and the Dirty Three.

column1: The lyrics of Ripely Pine are hungry for love and experience and bone-picked honesty. She explains the title as a kind of openhearted longing
column2: though it's gorier than that: “Let’s crawl all over one another like crows on a carcass

column4: fetid thing

column6: 19. “Love is selfish/ Love goes tick-tock-tick/ Love knows Jesus/ Apples and oranges
column7: ” she sighs of its many coexisting contradictions.

column1: “You with the nape that holds my gaze/ You with the tongue that speaks my name

column5: not in spite of it. Some of them have been worked on for five years

column7: and with only three songs under four minutes and almost everything playing out like the closing number of a headline festival set
column8: it’s much too long. While her gentler solo songs are pretty enough
column9: they can also be samey
column10: making the hour length even less necessary. But what Ripely Pine has that much comparable rousing-but-empty country-tinged trad rock doesn’t have is raw
column11: credulous fire.

column1: The best songs here are all nearly seven minutes long
column2: but their erratic structures make compelling stages to watch dueling tirades of emotion swarm around one another. Spaltro wields ferocity and timidity equally well
column3: to the extent that it’s hard to tell which is her more frightening mode. The incensed “Bird Balloons”
column4: an unresolved tale of betrayal
column5: regret
column6: and acceptance
column7: has an excellent
column8: spat pay-off: “My hair grew long so I fucking cut it/ And when you looked away I stuck those trimmings in your locket
column9: ha ha ha ha.” “You Are the Apple” eases into a bluesy lope and twang
column10: and then a swashbuckling burst of timpani and strings
column11: Spaltro screaming
column12: “I still need your teeth around my organs.” What should be the payoff to the Alabama Shakes-loose “Crane Your Neck” is Spaltro howling “I’m as blue as blood before the blood goes red
column13: ” in a cadence borrowed from the hilt of “Fake Plastic Trees”; its “twist yo’ hips” shimmy-to-fade epilogue is unnecessary and a bit rote.

column1: The “blue blood” line crops up a few times on Ripely Pine
column2: notably on “Aubergine”
column3: where Spaltro comitragically sings about how someone makes her “into an egg without yolk
column4: ” making it clear that she means the lifeless shade of blood
column5: not the regal kind. Conversely
column6: Ripely Pine is one of the most nourishing
column7: deeply alive records of this young year. On closer “Taxidermist
column8: Taxidermist”
column9:
she reconciles with herself: “‘How do you do?’ I say/ ‘I’ve heard such lovely things about who you are and where you’ve been/ But be in me again.’” These songs are about Spaltro five years ago; hopefully reassembling the parts doesn’t mean locking up these messy song banquets for a neater record next time around. Thalia Zedek’s voice has aged exceptionally well
column2: perhaps in part because it always sounded rather organically aged to begin with. The most immediately striking thing about Via
column3: the latest album from the former Uzi
column4: Live Skull and Come singer/songwriter
column5: is how little her voice has changed over three decades of performance. For evidence
column6: check out clips from Come’s classic 1992 debut album Eleven: Eleven
column7: soon to be reissued by Matador. By that point Zedek’s voice had already matured to a well-cured rasp
column8: and 20 years later it still sounds as potent and seemingly durable as ever; the aural equivalent of someone whose hair turns silver in his or her 20s and then essentially looks the same throughout adulthood.

column1: What has changed over the years has been the nature and arrangements of Zedek’s bands. Uzi and Live Skull made spiky No Wave
column2: whereas Come specialized in a distinctive form of emotive scorched-earth blues/punk. Since the dissolution of Come in 2001
column3: Zedek has fronted bands that tend to slip in between various genres
column4: buffering her voice and electric guitar with a variety of acoustic instruments in a manner that recalls the Bad Seeds or Dirty Three. While she has never quite found an instrumental foil to fully fill the crucial role former Codeine guitarist Chris Brokaw played in Come
column5: her longtime collaboration with viola player David Curry and pianist Mel Lederman has proven a good match for her knotty songcraft. On <i>Via
column6: their playing sounds loose
column7: familiar and jammy
column8: with the musicians able to pivot from lively near-country rock to passages of noisy turbulence in the flash of an eye.

column1: In a recent Boston Globe piece
column2: Zedek expresses bemused chagrin at her reputation as a brooding artiste. “It’s already started with the reviews
column3: ” she says. “It’s the same ‘angst
column4: agony
column5: and anguish’ bit. I think
column6: ‘What are you listening to?’” She's not entirely wrong; “agony and anguish” are too harsh a description for the songs on Via. But neither is the album all major keys and sunny beaches. (Even in her earliest work it is hard to find a Zedek song that sounds young and frivolous.) As ever
column7: Zedek specializes in thorny songs that unflinchingly address adult topics and full-grown problems
column8: with the malleable backing of her guitar and band providing either momentary refuge or sympathetic cries of exasperation.

column1: You don't have to dig too far into the likes of “Walk Away
column2: ” “Get Away”
column3: or “Go Home” to pick up on a theme of dislocation; Via’s songs frequently seem to dole out advice to characters caught between one home and another
column4: stuck in a pattern of bad situations or repeated mistakes. “Did you ever come to find that what you thought that you had lost was right where you left it last?” she sings on “Walk Away”. As with so much of Zedek’s best work
column5: these songs have the nurturing feel of someone talking others through decisions where there is no clear right or wrong choice
column6: in a manner free of platitudes or pat answers.

column1: This sense of nurturing goes a step further on the forceful “In This World”
column2: a crisply-strummed acoustic pep talk to a struggling friend that could double as a universal call of the nursemaid or long-term caregiver. “Won’t you help me and heal your body? Won’t you give me some kind of sign?” she asks before eventually declaring
column3: almost as an afterthought
column4: “Because there’s nobody that stands completely alone in this world.” It’s that slender reed of hope or recovery that continually shines through even Via’s darkest moments. The album closes with two lengthy tracks
column5: “Lucky One” and “Want You to Know”
column6: which each last more than six minutes and generally let the full group’s restless
column7: roiling music do the heavy lifting. The sequencing seems rather odd
column8: as either one could just easily be the big cathartic grand finale and putting them right next to one another tends to blunt the impact of both. Nevertheless
column9: the camaraderie evident in the band’s tumultuous playing serves as a balm against any of Zedek’s dreaded “angst
column10: agony
column11: and anguish
column12: ” as though intended to leave the listener with the impression that things in this life might yet work out
column13:
despite any evidence to the contrary.

Musical secrets are still out there
column2: even if they’re no longer hiding in plain sight. The Mutant Sounds blog
column3: so long a bastion of barely-heard esoterica
column4: recently ran into trouble
column5: ultimately deciding to take down the vast collection of free downloads they had lovingly curated since 2007. Mutant Sounds has announced it will continue in some format
column6: although the download archive apparently won't be returning in full
column7: pushing its myriad obscurities a little further back into the shadows. That stuff is still out there
column8: of course-- anything released to the internet never goes away for very long-- but the ghost-like presence of shuttered ""sharity"" blogs
column9: all emptied of their wares
column10: already resemble thoroughly picked-over corpses discarded at the roadside.

column1: Mutant Sounds mostly traded in obscure
column2: out-of-print
column3: long-forgotten releases; music that was either impossible to find
column4: inordinately expensive
column5: or both of those things. A re-interpretation of ""issues pertaining to copyright online"" is cited by the blog owners as a reason for removing the files. Perhaps it's wise that they're protecting themselves in this way
column6: even if copyright issues feel like the furthest thing from the minds of artists releasing limited edition cassette-tapes three decades ago. Either way
column7: the biggest loss
column8: other than the free ticket to wallow in some of music's darkest
column9: most mysterious corners
column10: is the fact that a handful of musicians whose work circulated on those blogs ended up getting officially reissued on proper labels. This was a place far removed from rampant piracy. Often
column11: it felt like an invaluable service was being carried out.

column1: The folks at the Digitalis label first came across the work of U.K. duo Leven Signs via a ""chance encounter"" with a cassette of their solitary album
column2: Hemp Is Here
column3: originally released in 1985. A search of the Mutant Sounds archive brings up a 2007 post for the album
column4: which is likely to have been most people's entry point to the record. In many ways it typifies the spirit of the blog
column5: taking great lurches in style
column6: having scant regard for the world outside
column7: sounding like it was recorded on a piece of old kitchen roll. Sometimes it bears a tiny resemblance to the wider post-punk narrative being spun at that time
column8: especially when clattering
column9: gamelan-influenced percussion collides into the kitchen sink sound of bands like Rip Rig + Panic. But its most overt tie to post-punk is in its desire to tear up music history in order to not sound like anyone else at all.

column1: Leven Signs is the work of Peter Karkut and Maggie Turner; the latter provides vocals that occasionally sound like a less-stern Nico
column2: all buried so deep in the mix that it feels like she's performing somewhere else
column3: in a distant room
column4: with a different band altogether. What Karkut is doing is anyone's guess. There are perceptible organ tones
column5: noises that resemble slide whistles
column6: percussion that sounds like a recording of one of those wind-up toy drumming bears. It's clear that a lot of work and thought went into Hemp Is Here
column7: especially in the tracks where abstract tape loops are laced around one another
column8: recalling the future voyages into playfulness of the Focus Group. There's also a strong sense of junk shop experimentalism later shared by groups like Pram
column9: where everything is thrown up in the air and loosely arranged after it lands.

column1: At times Hemp Is Here shares a sense of discovery with Scott Walker's later works
column2: albeit one executed on a fraction of the budget. Occasionally a male vocal emerges on certain tracks
column3: presumably belonging to Karkut
column4: bearing a deep
column5: throaty abrasion that closely mirrors Walker. Similarly
column6: it's not hard to imagine Karkut mic-ing up a piece of meat and thwacking away at it
column7: just to see where it will take him. That place where Leven Signs ended up is still hard to define
column8: even some 28 years later. But the beauty of this record
column9: and much of the Mutant Sounds family of which it feels a part
column10: is in the feeling of listening to something that fell between the cracks
column11: that perpetually escapes easy definition. Digitalis tracked down Karkut in order to release Hemp is Here
column12: although few details on how this recording came into being are forthcoming. It's a more powerful work that way
column13:
carrying around a few hundred imagined histories on its back.

Clinic have never been ones to heed conventional wisdom
column4: the logistics of singing through surgical masks being but the first of many aesthetic hurdles they've erected between themselves and pop accessibility. After all
column5: here is a band that
column6: in an attempt to overcome the seven-album itch-- and possibly give themselves something new to talk about with interviewers after 15 years in the game-- turned to acclaimed sound-collagist Daniel Lopatin (a.k.a. Oneohtrix Point Never) to mix their 2012 release Free Reign
column7: only to shelve all but two of his submissions. You could sense that second-guessing on the final product: While Free Reign saw the band stretching out more than usual
column8: with its psychedelic drones and funkier grooves
column9: the album was still quintessentially
column10: claustrophobically Clinic
column11: caught between competing desires to expand the band's sound without dramatically altering it.

column1: But Free Reign's shortcomings aren't anything some corrective surgery can't fix. And so
column2: just months after the album's release
column3: we have Free Reign II
column4: which is not so much a remix album or a sequel companion piece as a complete do-over-- the U.K. indie equivalent of Bobby Ewing suddenly turning up in your morning shower. Free Reign II reinstates Lopatin's original mixes (plus new ones for ""Miss You"" and ""You""
column5: the two songs of his that made the previous cut) and resequences the album in reverse order. But while this may read like some egregious ploy to make fans buy the same record twice-- song titles are merely appended with a ""II""-- they should be thankful Clinic are going through with the plan. In this revised form
column6: Free Reign is elevated from an intriguing if flawed work into the band's most consistently illuminating and sonically adventurous album since 2002's Walking With Thee.

column1: In Lopatin's hands
column2: Free Reign's subliminal textural details take the starring role
column3: smashing through the original's glass-ceiling containment to reveal a vaster sense of space and far greater dramatic tension. The album's low-key
column4: wandering closer
column5: ""The Sun and Moon"" is reborn as Free Reign II's deliriously disorienting opener
column6: its Manzarekian organ pumps amplified into glass-shattering tremors and free-jazz sax squeaks heigthening the carnivalistic clamor. On the original Free Reign
column7: the blissed-out reverie ""Misty"" gradually eased you into the record
column8: establishing a slack
column9: laissez faire tone; here
column10: ""Sun and the Moon II"" violently thrusts you in
column11: foreshadowing the more turbulent funhouse experience to come. Even the found-sound recordings of children at play that permeate ""You"" assume a more sinister
column12: predatory tenor on ""You II""
column13: their increasingly mutated voices fusing into the sheets of guitar noise that eventually consume the song. In this revamped context
column14: the ascendant organ drone that rises above the song's fiery outro feels less like a simple Suicide tribute and more like a spacecraft escape from an exploding planet.

column1: Lopatin can't rehabilitate every track-- ""Cosmic Radiation"" is still a scatterbrained psych-jazz scribble of a song. But his gnarlier mix and flipped-script sequencing do wonders for what was Free Reign's most rudimentary turn
column2: ""See Saw"". Where the original overemphasized its temper-tantrum bashed beat and remedial
column3: morse-code melodica riff to the point of annoyance-- its position as second-track nearly derailing Free Reign's momentum from the get-go-- the song is utterly transformed into Free Reign II's explosive side-two climax. It's the moment where all the strategic soundscaping Lopatin has exercised over the course of the record comes to a head: The drums stomp with crater-inducing force
column4: the guitars turn several degrees thicker and nastier
column5: Blackburn's impetuous vocal is reverbed into a more antagonistic scowl
column6: and whole thing swirls and snarls like a fairground attraction spun out of control. And in its wake
column7: ""Misty II"" finds its true calling as the album's comedown closer
column8: sending us adrift on a billowy bed of analog-synth starbursts. (It's followed by a tacked-on bonus track
column9: ""Done and Dusted II"" that hearkens back to the motorik bounce of early singles like ""The Second Line""
column10: but doesn't quite fit with the album's droning
column11: cerebral vibe; nor does it give Lopatin much opportunity to go crazy on the console.)

column1: One can only imagine that Clinic's reticience to initially release this vastly superior version of Free Reign can be chalked up to misgivings about showcasing Lopatin's textural trickery at the expense of the group's performances. But Free Reign II is precisely the sort of risky
column2: rejuvenating album Clinic needed at this point in their career
column3: one that audaciously upends the perception that this band just releases the same album over and over. Sadly
column4: it's been brought to market as a secondary
column5: supplemental release whose belated appearance may have bypassed the window of opportunity to recapture some of the considerable buzz the band enjoyed back at the turn of the millennium and re-stoke the interest of fans who may have tuned out since. At the very least
column6: it puts lie to that old shampoo-ad slogan: sometimes
column7:
you do a get a second chance to make a seventh impression.  

"|17762.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17762-clinic-free-reign-ii/|8.0|Stuart Berman

On their 2010 sophomore release Part II: The New December
column2: Los Angeles fractured pop collective Fol Chen wrote one truly great song. Lead single ""In Ruins""
column3: a spindly
column4: exotic earworm of a track was an undeniable standout that should've played to a bigger audience. Despite encouraging remix EP (and soundtracking one of the more satisfyingly strange onscreen love scenes in recent memory)
column5: ""In Ruins"" still cast a long
column6: curious shadow over the rest of the wandering New December. But with The False Alarms
column7: Fol Chen's third LP
column8: it seems as if the song's modest legacy can be extended a little further. The False Alarms follows ""In Ruins""'s lead and homes in on the band's gift for obtuse but viscerally catchy songs
column9: just like the one that could've launched a thousand car commercials.

column1: ""The False Alarms"" opens the record with a distinct air of confidence
column2: with Sinosa Loa's vocals fluttering at the forefront and producers Samuel Bing and Julian Wass dicing up equilibrium-disrupting pulses
column3: clattering drums
column4: and capering bell tones. There's a new lightness in these songs
column5: no matter how familiar they might seem. The False Alarms boasts everything from clipped acoustic guitars to digitized harpsichord sounds to dance-kit mined beats. But this time around
column6: everything is implemented so cleanly and economically
column7: what was previously a bit slow and staid now feels reinvigorated. The songs are given the necessary room to breathe
column8:
as everything is placed deliberately and little is wasted along the way. 

The False Alarms is just flat-out catchier. There's an impressive amount of single-worthy material
column9: to the point where the creepy-comely ""200 Words""
column10: the one they actually went with
column11: would probably be the fourth or fifth choice for most. The early back-to-back combo of ""I.O.U."" and ""A Tourist Town"" is a particularly exciting one-two. ""I.O.U."" initially sounds too precious with its shy vocals and dewy twinkles
column12: but it eventually becomes addictively slinky
column13: thanks to its simplicity. Better is ""A Tourist Town""-- a legitimate banger and an easy companion piece to ""In Ruins""-- complete with Middle Eastern inflections and an ""I got drunk again"" chorus that begs to be featured in a loft party sequence on the next season of Girls. Other notable tracks don't garner quite as much attention
column14: but all come equipped with welcome reference points. Both ""200 Words"" and the robo-spooked ""Boys in the Woods"" both owe a debt to Ladytron
column15: while ""Doubles"" sounds like Laurel Halo trying to translate ""Hollaback Girl"".

column1: Still
column2: old habits die hard. The other half of The False Alarms
column3: while not a complete wash
column4: finds the band sounding lost. Detours into coldwave and seance-y Scandi-pop still feel like an attempt to steer things in a new direction
column5: but the songs fall prey to the same kind of directionless
column6: inertia-deprived trappings that helped sink Fol Chen's previous records. With so much engaging material sprouting up elsewhere
column7: it feels less like an act of self-sabotage. So The False Alarms just simply isn't the record it could've been
column8:
but it's hard to complain too much when you get to walk away with a handful of fine songs.

There are
column2: roughly
column3: two kinds of musicians in this world: the ones who make grand gestures that suggest the universe’s infinite depth
column4: complexity and wonder
column5: and the ones who execute their ideas with such perfect simplicity that they make you believe-- often for 3 minutes at a time-- that the world might actually be flat after all. L.A.-via-Boston DIY grunge-popper Colleen Green stands resolutely in the second group. Her scrappy brand of minimalism follows in the tradition of Beat Happening
column6: the Ramones
column7: and Blink-182 (she’s cited the band’s 1993—1999 run as a crucial influence; in other words
column8: nothing after the fart-and-boner-joke auteurs’ short-lived “mature phase”) and is based in a faith that most things worth saying can be expressed with just a deadpan drum machine
column9: an uncomplicated couplet
column10: and three torpedoed power chords. Green’s persona is a logical extension of her music
column11: too. When an interviewer asked her last year to elaborate on the lyrics to her song “Green One” (what did green signify
column12: he wanted to know—nature? her family name? weed?) her response to this question was as laconic
column13: goofy
column14: and no-frills as one of her best songs: “I dunno
column15: it’s like
column16: green is just what I AM
column17: you know?” To ask Colleen Green <i>what does it all mean
column18: man? is sort of like asking Joey Ramone to elaborate on the pedagogical philosophy of the teaching methods at Rock & Roll High School.

column1: The songs on Green’s Hardly Art debut Sock it to Me are brazenly simple
column2: but they have a shrugging
column3: take-me-as-I-am charm that makes them feel like celebrations of their own limitations. All of her songs begin with a nearly identical beat made by a drum machine that sounds like a model discontinued about 20 years ago. When asked why she uses a drum machine
column4: she’s said it’s because she doesn’t know how to play the drums; I doubt she will ever learn. Her music is anti-striving: why push past your limits

column7: it must be said

column1: Sock it to Me mines the melodic sensibility and lyrical themes of 60s girl groups-- good boyfriends (“When He Tells Me”)
column2: bad boyfriends (“Darkest Eyes”) and mean girls at school (“Every Boy Wants a Normal Girl”). But while the first wave of girl group music was a profession of collectivity and shared wisdom
column3: Green’s music is proudly solo
column4: the product of one singular
column5: isolated person. Not that it bothers her. About a minute-and-a-half into the album
column6: on the infectious
column7: wound “Only One”
column8: she engages in a multi-tracked call-and-response chant with herself. “Oh yeah/ Uh-huh/ Oh god/ I really love my boyfriend
column9: ” she sings
column10: and then plays her own backing singer: “She really loves her boyfriend.” In Green’s solitary bedroom-pop universe
column11: loneliness isn’t a source of sadness so much as aesthetic choice and
column12: occasionally

column1: Sock it to Me comes on the heels of a couple solid cassette releases-- Green One

Harmony Korine's Spring Breakers was a media phenomenon before anybody had seen so much as a promotional still. For starters
column2: Korine

column6: Faith

column8: dangerous Candy. An early teaser features the leads belting out Britney Spears' ""…Baby One More Time"" and that's not the only (nor the most memorable) Spears homage in the movie. And then
column9: to top it all off

column11: a former Warped Tour band member turned posterboy for dubstep's more malignant cliches.

column1: It's clear from the opening credits of Spring Breakers-- the most cartoonishly turn't-up Spring Break scene you could possibly imagine

column3: old and new

column8: instrumental originals to the soundtrack-- Martinez handles the curious
column9: searching electronic interludes ""Pretend It's a Video Game""
column10: ""Your Friends Ain't Gonna Leave With You""
column11: and ""Never Gonna Get This Pussy""
column12: while Skrillex handles the relatively more aggressive textures of ""Ride Home"" and ""Park Smoke""-- but the fiber of Spring Breakers is the sonic influence that they have on one other.

column1: Skrillex
column2: in particular
column3: benefits from Martinez' presence. Though Moore has recently attempted more laid-back approaches to composition
column4: songs like ""The Reason"" didn't sound as idiosyncratically him
column5: and don't prove as captivating or recognizable as his contributions here. The new music
column6: stitched between previously released tracks (like Skrillex's ""With You
column7: Friends (Long Drive)"" and Gucci Mane's Ferrari Boyz cut ""Young Niggaz"")
column8: achieves an important headspace for both the dramatic arc of the film as well as the soundtrack as a piece of music. Between the blurry revelry and the careening rush of consequence borne of violent impulse

column6: contemplative whisper. Here

column8: Skrillex's ""Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites"" gains a pensive new tone

column10: as well as the Martinez/Skrillex sequel ""Son of Scary Monsters"". On Ferrari Boyz

column1: There's a turning point of the film

column5:
Spring Breakers is the rare soundtrack that covers both extremes and makes it work as a whole.

It's tempting to claim that the Helado Negro of 2009's Awe Owe is unrecognizable in the Helado Negro of Invisible Life. The former was a softly warped
column2: pastoral record with Spanish lyrics and prominent Latin guitar; the latter is a more urbane electronic pop record with lyrics in English and Spanish. But in every style Roberto Carlos Lange develops
column3: a sultry
column4: dreamy temperament remains apparent
column5: from the shimmying cadences and simmered arrangements to his just-woken-up voice. Invisible Life is the clearest and most dynamic Helado Negro record to date.

column1: His transition from acoustic to electronic took place on 2011's Canta Lechuza
column2: which was lively but sometimes drifted through embryonic learning passages. Helado Negro generally deals in smart sounds rather than memorable songs (outside of maybe ""El Oeste"") but that changes with Invisible Life. Lange has committed to his MPC game and tightened it up
column3: knotting his signature atmospheres into immersive
column4: highly musical beats scrawled with unstable sub-rhythms. The glass-brick chords and deeply pumping bass of ""Dance Ghost"" are solidly constructed but hairline-cracked by jittery
column5: stereo-panned clicks

column8: considered payoffs

column3: exhuming mysterious but vibrant sound-worlds from the ocean floor of his imagination. He's never before ventured anything as formally distinctive and effectively delightful as ""U Heard""

column2: for instance

column7: Canta Lechuza seemed like Lange dabbling in electronic music

column9:
it sounds more like him finding his voice.

column7: dressed like a Viking and [a] ‘mad scientist
column8: ’” by the time Plank began to make his name as a producer
column9: he had already studied under Karlheinz Stockhausen and recorded Marlene Dietrich. To trace his production credits from 1969 onward is to follow the lineage of krautrock itself. Plank was behind the earliest Kraftwerk
column10: Cluster
column11: Ash Ra Tempel
column12: and Guru Guru albums along with innumerable others. (Can
column13: Amon Düül
column14: and Faust were among the few genre proponents not bearing his fingerprints.)

column1: Eno himself encountered Plank when he ventured to the German countryside to collaborate with Moebius and Roedelius of Cluster
column2: and his is the first voice you hear on the box set
column3: on the woozy pop Eno & Cluster collaboration “Broken Head”. Plank’s studio was in a converted farmhouse in Neunkirchen
column4: 30km east of Cologne. “His mixing desk had been modified so that with one finger he could simultaneously deploy echo and panning effects
column5: ” Sheppard wrote. “For Plank
column6: mixing was a matter of quixotic performance as it was technical application.” While his cues might have been taken from the likes of Lee “Scratch” Perry and King Tubby
column7: Plank’s productions eschewed easy earmarks. And while his influence on the likes of Martin Hannett is evident
column8: the box shows that there was no singular “Plank sound.”

column1: For one disc at least
column2: Man captures some of Plank’s essence. Spiky no-wave electro noise from Japan rendered with half of Can that anticipates Silent Shout? Check Phew’s “Signal.” Joy Division-style punk? That would be D.A.F.’s rumbling “Alles Ist Gut”. A dark
column3: cavernous b-side on a debut single from an act that would become one of the 80s most revered pop acts? See Eurythmics’ “La Sinistre”. Beatific oceanic ambience? Cue up closer “Leb Wohl!” In a three-song span
column4: the set shows how Plank moved from the producer’s chair onto a more active
column5: collaborative presence in the studio: from the jittery and jangly noise courtesy of Plank’s collaboration with Moebius to a proto-industrial spoken word piece with Red Krayola’s Mayo Thompson
column6: and onto an alien yet ebullient proto-techno track from Moebius-Plank-Neumeier (of Guru Guru). Yes
column7: the producer could be more than just a finger pressing record
column8: a participant in the very sound he was rendering to tape.

column1: But by the second disc
column2: the man
column3: his sense of capturing space
column4: and his great oeuvre fall woefully out of focus. His groundbreaking work harnessing the unfettered electronics of early Kluster and Kraftwerk is wholly missing (with the latter’s disavowal of their first four albums leading up to Autobahn acutely felt). Same goes with his New Romanticism work alongside Ultravox and John Foxx. His stranger 80s work
column5: producing the likes of A Flock of Seagulls
column6: Les Rita Mitsouko
column7: and Whodini
column8: is also noticeably absent. Instead
column9: one has to suffer through a stodgy and useless cover of “Eleanor Rigby” and the man’s own drunken bellowing of “Silent Night” at the disc’s end. And why Bluepoint Underground’s namechecking of the man in the late 90s warrants inclusion here is beyond me. The last disc comprises a live set
column10: featuring Plank fully transitioned to performer down in Mexico in 1986
column11: unleashing squalls of industrial noise alongside Dieter Moebius and Arno Steffen
column12: less than a year before he succumbed to cancer in 1987.

column1: Worse still is the entire disc of underwhelming remixes. Automat’s “Broken Head” remix is serviceable
column2: but Justus Köhncke’s flatulent remix of Michael Rother’s “Feuerland” only detracts from the original’s eloquence. Günther Lause reducing Phew to the sound of jingling jewelry while music plays two rooms over need not take up 10 minutes. Same goes for a sleep-inducing remix from Crato that’s also past the double-digit mark. Eye from Boredoms does a cartoonish
column3: whiplash remix that goes to the other extreme
column4: giving the impression that none of the remixers involved really understand Plank.

column1: After four discs
column2: one comes no nearer to understanding who that man was. Refined and impish
column3: noisy and tranquil
column4: grotesque and resplendent
column5: Plank’s handiwork feels at once ineffable and instantaneous. When the jackhammering of Neu!’s “Hallogallo” ruptures the proceedings midway through disc two
column6: the effect remains startling. One remains hard-pressed to identify specifically what Plank contributed and what sprang from Rother-Dinger
column7: but the close partnership is evident. And it sounds nuts four decades later. ""Craziness is something holy
column8: Plank said in an interview with Electronic Musician magazine shortly before his death
column9:
and yet the set conveys only the merest glimpse of the man’s insanity.

"|17582.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17582-whos-that-man-a-tribute-to-conny-plank/|5.9|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19007/homepage_large.76f53dc7.jpg|Sound City: Real to Reel OST|8214.0|Dave Grohl|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Roswell']|2013-03-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:25.411332|"

About halfway during the time that elapsed between Kurt Cobain’s suicide and the release of the first Foo Fighters album
column2: Dave Grohl made his first public
column3: post-Nirvana showing in the most unlikely of places: On ""Saturday Night Live""
column4: manning Tom Petty’s drum kit for a couple of weed-scented folk-rock jams from Petty's Wild Flowers release. But if the surprise cameo provided little indication of Grohl’s imminent future as the guitar-slinging
column5: camera-ready leader of one of the last arena-rock bands left standing
column6: it was the harbinger of another role he would grow to relish over the next two decades: that of a dutiful gatekeeper of classic-rock tradition. Grohl’s essentially the middle-man who helps the geezers look cool to the kids: He’s got an open-door policy for Rock and Roll Hall of Famers to join him onstage anytime; he’s got enough charm and charisma to coax the most reclusive living member of Led Zeppelin out of semi-retirement; and he’s always on hand to help Grammy Awards producers mitigate the encroaching influence of EDM. This sort of cross-generational appeal has made Grohl not just the nicest man in rock
column7: but its Employee of the Month for nearly 20 years running.

column1: And no doubt
column2: he’s probably the only person who could have made Sound City happen. Grohl’s directorial debut pays tribute to the legendary-- and recently shuttered-- L.A. studio that produced Fleetwood Mac’s 1975 self-titled effort
column3: Tom Petty’s Damn the Torpedoes and what seems like every other album in perpetual classic-rock radio rotation
column4: not to mention alt-rock touchstones like Rage Against the Machine’s debut
column5: Weezer’s Pinkerton
column6: and
column7: of course
column8: Nirvana’s Nevermind. But if the impetus for the film is a certain they-don’t-make-’em-like-they-used-to nostalgia
column9: its accompanying soundtrack release-- also documented onscreen-- is a noble attempt to put the lie to that sentiment. Having purchased the facility’s hallowed Neve 8028 board and installed it at his own 606 Studios
column10: the Foo Fighters frontman used his documentary as an occasion to gather various famed Sound City alumni together to create new music using an old-school tool.

column1: However
column2: “being friends with Dave Grohl” is not the most coherent unifying principle for a stand-alone album
column3: given that his friends here include everyone from Stevie Nicks to Corey Taylor of Slipknot. And a mutual admiration for a bygone recording studio doesn’t provide much of a conceptual conceit to build a record around. Grohl
column4: naturally
column5: sounds the most invested in the cause: His epic showdown with Trent Reznor and Josh Homme on “Mantra” climaxes with a rallying cry (“And all of this will never be the same”) that essentially reads as an indictment against the technological and economic shifts that drove the studio out of business. But other artists
column6: like the Black Rebel Motorcycle dudes on “Heaven and All”
column7: simply show up as if they were cutting their own album. With its hit-and-miss deviations in tone and quality
column8: Real to Reel feels less like a tribute to a studio that created some of the greatest albums of all time
column9: and more like an approximation of a typical Active Rock Radio playlist.

column1: The album works best when embracing the sheer absurdity of its ad-hoc supergroup combinations. Back in 1981
column2: Rick Springfield and Lee Ving (of L.A. hardcore heretics Fear) represented the polar opposites of the rock-frontman ideal. Here
column3: we find them on back-to-back tracks leading various Foo Fighters with equal amounts of bravado and self-deprecation. Springfield’s “The Man That Never Was” makes for a cheeky comment on his own faded celebrity
column4: while Ving’s berserker turn on “Your Wife Is Calling” feeds on the neuroses of the domesticated aging punk. But the 62-year-old Ving is neither the oldest nor most impetuous guest on hand here: After making its surprise debut at last December’s Hurricane Sandy tribute concert
column5: Paul McCartney’s “Cut Me Some Slack”-- which sees the former Beatle backed by the surviving members of Nirvana-- still excites with its “Helter Skelter”-scaled bombast
column6: hoarse-throat howls
column7: and fierce double-timed outro. It’s the best representation of Grohl’s intent for his Sound City mission
column8: to recapture some of the raw spontaneity that’s been lost in an era where so many recordings are clicked and cut with clinical precision.

column1: It’s too bad that many of the other collaborations here feel as generic and laborious as a ProTools tutorial. Grohl
column2: Masters of Reality’s Chris Goss
column3: and half of Rage Against the Machine team up for “Time Slowing Down”
column4: which comes off like a rejected Stone Temple Pilots audition for The Crow soundtrack; “From Can to Can’t”
column5: meanwhile
column6: squanders the power-pop chops of Cheap Trick’s Rick Nielsen and desert-burrowing bottom end of Kyuss bassist Scott Reeder on a plodding post-grunge power ballad belted with clenched-neck earnestness by Corey Taylor.  But it’s the date with Stevie Nicks that feels like Real to Reel’s biggest missed opportunity: “You Can’t Fix This” is a forced attempt to update the witchy-woman archetype of “Rhiannon”
column7: but its heavy-handed lyrics about dancing with devils forsake mysticism for melodrama. And yet
column8: even Real to Reel’s failures are a testament to the greatness of Sound City Studios-- in that they prove it takes more than the right equipment
column9: the right people
column10:
and good intentions to recreate the magic of what once was.

"|17810.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17810-dave-grohl-sound-city-ost/|5.3|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19008/homepage_large.7478229c.jpg|Adrian Younge Presents the Delfonics|31129.0|The Delfonics|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Wax Poetics']|2013-03-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:26.106562|"

It's almost 20 years since Rick Rubin successfully repositioned Johnny Cash from a fading star in a terminally uncool genre into the walking embodiment of cool with American Recordings. In the interim
column2: the late-career Rubin-style makeover has become just as much of a cliche as the album of standards from the American songbook. A release about a new collaboration between the Delfonics' William Hart
column3: and Adrian Younge
column4: a producer several decades his junior
column5: said that the resulting album was going to be ""what the kids call 'hip-hop'""-- which sounds a lot like an unappealing welcome to the rap game Rubin-Cash formula.

column1: Fortunately
column2: it turns out that Younge's approach towards working with an older artist is less like Rubin's and more like Quentin Tarantino's: Instead of aiming for gravitas and youth culture appeal
column3: he's placed Hart in his own stylized and slightly warped vision of the past that's both a tribute to the Delfonics' heyday
column4: a radical deconstruction of it
column5: and something altogether original.

column1: Younge and Hart's album doesn't actuallly sound much like a Delfonics record. In the group's late 1960s and early 70s prime
column2: they were at the vanguard of the Philly sound that replaced the hard-edged funk that girded the popular black music of the time with a slick breeziness that could occasionally border on easy listening. Delfonics records were gorgeously produced
column3: with Hart and his rotating cast of support singers floating layers of vocal harmonies over lush beds of strings and horns.

column1: Younge-- who produced the album
column2: co-wrote all of its 13 songs with Hart
column3: and played a couple of dozen instruments on it-- exchanges all that for a sonic aesthetic that has more in common with the more eccentric strain of soul and R&B records that are so beloved by hardcore crate diggers and producers like J Dilla and Madlib. Instead of the luxe orchestration that was a trademark of peak-period Delfonics
column4: Younge has given Hart idiosyncratic arrangements full of harpsichord
column5: glockenspiel
column6: and the electric sitar
column7: which impart an element of campy psychedelia
column8: but thankfully avoid crossing fully over into kitsch. With a mix that leans heavily on analog grit and high midrange tones
column9: it sounds like the test pressing of a long-lost psych soul record rescued from a storage unit
column10: and achieves a similar kind of retro accuracy that Younge gave to his soundtrack for the 2009 faux-vintage blaxploitation flick Black Dynamite.

column1: For much of the album Hart sings solo
column2: another departure from the Delfonics sound that we're used to. Purists might be consider the move tantamount to sacrilege
column3: but it suits the material. Hart treats Younge's arrangements like an obstacle course
column4: slipping nimbly through them with an agility that belies his age. His falsetto is still as crystal clear as it ever was
column5: even if he has to bend the occasional high note in order to find the right pitch.

column1: There are a number of potential issues with calling this record Adrian Younge Presents the Delfonics: Crediting what's essentially a William Hart solo album to the group could be considered questionable
column2: and Younge taking top billing on the record's title and artist credit is either audacious or presumptuous. And anyone expecting a revival of the Delfonics sound we all know and love very well may walk away disappointed.

column1: Taken on its own terms
column2: though
column3: the record works. And if Adrian Younge's approach to the project becomes the new formula for older artists
column4: then all the better. A musician demanding the respect they're due is understandable
column5:
but one taking their reputation and using it to crack open new artistic territory is much more interesting.

"|17811.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17811-the-delfonics-adrian-younge-presents-the-delfonics/|7.5|Miles Raymer

column1:

As recent breakups go
column2: G-Side’s didn’t register with the same magnitude as that of the Mars Volta or Das Racist
column3: but the tributes their split did garner were well earned. Though the Huntsville
column4: Ala.
column5: rap duo's musical boldness pulled together various corners of the internet-- The ONE... COHESIVE’s “How Far” sampled Beach House’s “10 Mile Stereo”
column6: while iSLAND’s “Gettin It” sliced up Tame Impala’s winding “Why Won’t You Make Up Your Mind?”-- ST 2 Lettaz and Yung Clova always had their feet cemented in the spongy
column7: candy-coated stylings of early 8Ball & MJG and other Southern luminaries. It was an aesthetic that
column8: if not exclusively theirs
column9: no one else did better
column10: and it provided the foundation of five satisfying (if commercially ineffectual) albums in barely four years
column11: from 2007’s Sumthin 2 Hate to 2011’s iSLAND.

column1: While Clova
column2: as the head of Athens
column3: Ala.-based collective Lambo Music
column4: has continued to release new material since he and ST officially parted ways
column5: the latter has worked faster. Less than a week after the breakup came his debut EP
column6: R.E.B.E.L.
column7: which proved to be the most sonically daring release ST’d been involved in yet. Sampling the Beastie Boys
column8: Bone Thugs
column9: Empire of the Sun
column10: and Skrillex
column11: much of it was as kinetic as any of the party-rap by his Huntsville pal Jackie Chain (albeit in a much different way). Not only did it suggest ST would be just fine without his former partner
column12: its best moments justified G-Side’s dissolution in that it exposed a singular vision that might never have been achieved by the pair as
column13: well
column14: a pair.

column1: Originally planned to be G-Side’s sixth LP
column2: The G... The Growth & Development wound up as ST’s full-length solo debut. It marks the first release of the 27-year-old’s career that doesn’t have much in the way of continuity. Three tracks approximate pure East Coast classicism-- “Trillmatic”’s first half
column3: for example
column4: could hardly be more reminiscent of that Nas album’s “Memory Lane (Sittin’ in Da Park)”-- and two more aim for the club nearly as overtly as G-Side’s “College Chicks” did in 2009. Of course
column5: those make for two very distant poles
column6: but given that ST has written both with unabashed hubris and of everyday struggles whose details wouldn’t sound out of place on some meditative Rhymesayers single
column7: we know the guy has range. And everything on The G falls within that range.

column1: Besides those from the well-intentioned but occasionally goofy “Not a Luv Song”
column2: these verses don’t show any sides of ST we haven’t seen before. Fortunately
column3: he has no problems finding inventive ways to tread his usual topics. Here’s a note on his dope-dealing history from “Green Light District”: “Hit that bitch with P’s and O’s/ She flip them letters like Vanna White.” On “Flashlight”
column4: ST steps back for a survey of the Big Picture
column5: growing as pensive as ever in the process: “What good is having a voice if you only talk about yourself?/ What good is having a choice if you only choose to hurt somebody else?” Later on that same track
column6: he looks at his surroundings and concludes
column7: “This ain’t livin’
column8: that’s why I’m livid.” Nothing worldview-shaking or stunningly pithy
column9: maybe
column10: but as per always
column11: ST consistently gets the job done here.

column1: A few obstacles prevent The G from reaching a serious peak or sustaining any real hot streak: some elements that were surely appended to give the album a more expansive feel-- GMane’s interstitial musings
column2: the longish in- and outros
column3: the instrumental “Lighthouse”-- account for too much of the album’s 42-minute duration. (Those GMane interludes don’t serve the same narrative purpose as
column4: say
column5: Kendrick’s mom’s do on <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17253-good-kid-maad-city/?utm_campaign=search&utm_medium=site&utm_source=search-ac"">good kid
column6: m.A.A.d city.) It’s also frustrating that ST insists on working with relative unknowns instead of collaborating with a heavyweight who might help draw him somewhere near the limelight of rap in a grand sense; Grilly and Bentley might sound a little like Big K.R.I.T. and a more restrained Gunplay
column7: respectively
column8: but they lack the intangibles those guys would bring if they were actually here. Barring the EP/pre-album teaser Prelude... To The G
column9: The Growth & Development might be the feeblest release of ST’s career so far. It’s never bad
column10: but it could have been more streamlined
column11: and we should be hearing a little more ambition from a guy who
column12: as he tells us on “Flashlight”
column13:
is hoping to be a star at some point.

Horrors frontman Faris Badwan was the famous face behind Cat's Eyes' 2011 debut
column3: but Rachel Zeffira's story has since proved more intriguing. A half-Irish
column4: half-Italian classically trained opera singer with roots in rural Canada
column5: Zeffira is perhaps the only living person who's both worked with visual vanguard Chris Cunningham and performed for Pope John Paul II. Shortly after Cat's Eyes was released
column6: Zeffira went off on her own and put together a pair of solo tunes
column7: including a cover of My Bloody Valentine's ""To Here Knows When""
column8: that led to the eventual creation of her solo debut
column9: The Deserters.

column1: Zeffira handles writing
column2: singing
column3: and production duties here
column4: and also assembled and conducted the orchestra
column5: whose parts were recorded at Abbey Road
column6: narrowly avoiding bankruptcy in the process. She plays nine different instruments. Of course
column7: one only needed a listen to Cat's Eyes to glean Zeffira's considerable talents-- the broken-radio orchestral pop on which she took the lead easily make up the album's high points. However
column8: much of The Deserters consists of mournful melodies. When the tempo occasionally picks up and percussion enters the equation  the effect is akin to throwing your iTunes on shuffle and transitioning from Air to
column9: say
column10: Pantera.

column1: There's an unmistakable presence that looms over The Deserters
column2: same as it did with Cat's Eyes
column3: and it's that of late Broadcast singer Trish Keenan. At this point
column4: it's impossible to talk about Zeffira's voice-- a fragile
column5: even-tempered thing that's worlds away from what you'd expect with operatic experience-- without mentioning Keenan in the same breath. Broadcast's sound has proved more influential in modern indie with every passing year
column6: but while a few Keenan-alikes have popped up here and there Zeffira's timbre is exceptionally similar. It hovers over almost everything else
column7: an anti-gravitational presence amidst an already weightless environment.

column1: Her voice suits the album's main theme: the act of leaving. Sometimes
column2: Zeffira's the one taking a hike
column3: as she does atop the piping synths of ""Letters From Tokyo (Sayonara)""; elsewhere
column4: she's left standing at the ""Front Door"" waiting for someone who may never return
column5: or detailing someone like the vanishing girl at the nucleus of ""Break the Spell"". Her lilting
column6: detached voice stays in the same mood throughout
column7: emphasizing the uncertainty contained within these 10 songs.

column1: Ultimately
column2: though
column3: Zeffira's voice isn't notable so much for who it sounds like as it is for how she uses it-- which brings us to that My Bloody Valentine cover. Obviously
column4: it's a good time to unleash a take on any tune from Loveless; regardless of when this was recorded
column5: the opportunity wasn't wasted. The original's swirling guitars and ambient confusion are swapped out for
column6: at first
column7: just Zeffira's voice and her piano-- then
column8: a distant buzzing
column9: picked strings
column10: and swelling woodwinds and brass that build in their intensity to the point where the prettiness is suffocating come the end. Play it loud enough
column11: and it almost works just like its source material.

column1: It's a bold
column2: smart take on a song that's oft been pilfered. Unfortunately
column3: the cover also highlights The Deserters' biggest flaw. This is a record that operates in two modes: light
column4: floaty-yet-expansive orchestral pop
column5: tempered with a few doses of samey motorik noir. Blame the learning curve-- after all
column6:
this is someone who's only been making pop music for two or three years thus far. A little more stylistic and structural variety could lead to something special. 

"|17428.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17428-rachel-zeffira-the-deserters/|6.3|Larry Fitzmaurice

Carmen Villain's first single
column2: ""Lifeissin""
column3: was a placid ballad with something dark and evasive at its core: Over a faint glimmer of guitar
column4: Villain murmured sour nothings about closing the blinds
column5: going to hell
column6: living in fear. Even the song's run-together spelling suggested something slurred from the corner of the mouth. Like R.E.M.'s ""Perfect Circle""
column7: the song danced in the middle distance
column8: defying you to twist the lens and sharpen its edges.

column1: Carmen Villain
column2: aka Carmen Hillestad
column3: is a similarly blurry prospect: The fact that she was once a model
column4: appearing on the cover of magazines like Vogue and Marie Claire
column5: seemed to be the only available scrap of biographical information. One of few exceptions
column6: an interview she posted to her own Facebook page
column7: was conducted entirely in Swedish. Google Translate helped to extract a few intriguing morsels: She chose the stage name Villain to help distance herself from her modeling career. Her debut album Sleeper is the first music she's ever shared with the world
column8: after writing in private for years. And much of the album
column9: she said
column10: ""is about indifference
column11: being in a kind of emptiness.""

column1: This foggy unease and blankness communicates itself everywhere on Sleeper
column2: a frustratingly imperfect record that nonetheless holds onto the essential mystery that sparked my curiosity. It is gloomier than ""Lifeissin""
column3: which surfaces through the murk here as a lone moment of clarity. Hillestad surrounds her bored
column4: flat-as-earth vocals with a smeared wall of half-tuned guitars
column5: evoking the seedy prowl of Royal Trux and early Sonic Youth. There are strong hints of bad drugs
column6: and the unpleasant sensations that accompany them.

column1: The songs with strong
column2: legible vocal melodies carry themselves the best
column3: transforming all of this disaffection and spiritual emptiness into something worth making your own. Hillestad has a knack for curdled
column4: nursery-rhyme melodies
column5: like the late-album highlight ""Dreamo""
column6: which walks up and down the same four half-steps like someone humming to themselves. ""They caught me staring out the window
column7: she sings
column8: a lifelong dysphoric on guard against another well-meaning intervention from the outside world. She hits this note repeatedly in her lyrics
column9: which seem to regard regard human interactions through a thick pane of bulletproof glass. ""People keep telling me
column10: real life can be real nice
column11: she sings on ""Two Towns"".

column1: This noncommittal shrug occasionally prevents Sleeper from hitting harder. Without pushing further into her exploration of despair or sharpening her songwriting
column2: Hillestad sometimes lets her music just sit there. Stretches of the album simply drift past
column3: like the cut-and-paste interlude ""Slowaway"" or the six-minute drone piece ""Obedience""
column4: during which there isn't much left to focus on save for the album's rich
column5: reverb-heavy production. ""What is love
column6: but a second hand emotion?"" Hillestad sings on the haunting ""Dreamo""
column7: quoting a beloved Tina Turner line. In my attempts to gather some surrounding context
column8: I ended up corresponding briefly with Hillestad
column9: who told me the quote was a tribute to the lifting power of a memorable song. ""That Turner lyric is a sort of reference to the type of cultural noise
column10: for example heard through the radio
column11: that could momentarily drag me out of the detachment I could quite often find myself in
column12: she wrote. It's a neat object lesson in where she should go next: Music expressing detachment is easy
column13:
but music that addresses it requires some heavier lifting.

"|17773.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17773-carmen-villain-sleeper/|6.6|Jayson Greene

Insofar as anything about Devendra Banhart was ever considered ""underrated
column3: the man rarely got enough credit for his sense of humor. He was often called ""playful"" or ""mischievous
column4: or some other lightly stepping compliment that aligned more comfortably with the image of him as the kind and gentle Cosmically Transcendent Avatar of Freak-Folk. But check his track record: ""This Beard Is For Siobhan""
column5: ""Chinese Children""
column6: ""The Beatles""
column7: Megapuss
column8: and
column9: <i>oy vey
column10: ""Shabop Shalom""-- dude's got jokes. If you still don't get the picture
column11: witness the title of his latest album Mala. It's a term of endearment that loosely translates to ""sweetie pie"" in the native tongue of his fiancée
column12: Serbian artist Ana Kraš. But as a guy who frequently sings in Spanish
column13: Banhart must be very aware of how most people will initially read it-- especially in light of the artistic freefall he's been in for the past six or so years. If he's baiting us with a pun
column14: it's a great relief to find out he's earned the right to fuck around
column15: as Mala is Banhart's best record in nearly a decade-- largely because it's his loosest and funniest.

column1: While not exactly a trend within itself
column2: it's interesting to see how Banhart's latest follows a similar route to recent solo albums from Christopher Owens and Jim James
column3: longhairs who had similarly been burdened with messianic praise and rock savior archetypes. Like those men
column4: Banhart has eased back on multiple levels after increasingly ambitious records
column5: digging up pre-Beatles concepts of pop and rock while writing from non-punk states such as loving with levity and aging with grace. Mala's no less diverse than Cripple Crow or Smokey Rolls Down Thunder Canyon
column6: but it's exponentially less heavy-handed in its genre-hopping. As the lovely instrumental ""The Ballad of Keenan Milton"" attests
column7: he hasn't completely foresworn solo acoustic performance
column8: but otherwise
column9: these songs are short and spare
column10: little more than reverbed electric guitar accompanied by light drumming and rudimentary synth tones. It retroactively posits him as something of a missing link between Ariel Pink and Owens
column11: which is an accomplishment within itself.

column1: Most importantly
column2: these are by far Banhart's most plainspoken and legible songs. Considering they're in the form of soft-shoe jazz or playful R&B
column3: there isn't urgency per se
column4: so much as immediacy resulting from how Mala often feels like snippets taken from Banhart's daily life. ""Daniel"" namechecks bars and street names as well as ""waiting in line to see Suede play
column5: while the record's cloaking
column6: murky production gives the impression that he stills lives on a more mysterious plane than most of us. It also gives Banhart the freedom to get a little goofy even when Mala sounds dead sober. The muffled disco strut of ""Für Hildegard Von Bingen"" reimagines the 12th-century mystic as ""a VJ on location"" and leaves it as just a passing fancy Banhart felt worthy of capture rather than some high-minded metaphor. Likewise
column7: ""A Gain"" is more of an interlude than a song
column8: about a minute of free-form violin and Banhart muttering lines about being a disappointment to his mother
column9: hair gel
column10: and the W Hotel. As he rushes to jam in every last word in the line ""love is gonna be a long lost biological father
column11: he's laughing at his own emo capacity as well as the nakedly ""confessional"" format.

column1: For the most part
column2: Mala makes good on its titular inspiration by way of including plenty of silly songs about love. Which is different than ""silly love songs"" in a crucial way-- Banhart's light touch with the more embarrassing aspects of relationships cuts against the occasional whimsy
column3: and his self-deprecation feels earned
column4: humanizing him as someone who can be a jerk in mundane ways: a guy who dated starlets but probably got yelled at for leaving the toilet seat up. Banhart takes on a deeper register that's equally suave and fatuous on ""Never Seen Such Good Things""
column5: a song that borders on rhinestone cowboy pop. He laments a lost love with momentary nobility before the gawky phonetics and crude sentiment of ""if we ever make sweet love again/ I'm sure it would be quite disgusting"" make it a multilayered joke at the expense of our faulty memories regarding exes. This is even more pronounced on ""Your Fine Petting Duck""
column6: a duet where Banhart and Kras play ex-lovers on opposite ends of a proposed reconciliation; Kras wants him back
column7: Banhart is quick to remind her of the numerous ways in which he was a total ass: ""If he ever is untrue/ Just remember I was too... and so much more so."" For whatever reason
column8: it switches midway to a lo-fi electro-pop thump while Banhart and Kras sing in German
column9: because... why not? Even if it's fiction and decidedly anti-romantic in content
column10: the feel is that of an inside joke between two people who really like each other; in practice
column11: it's an ironic Valentine that's a powerfully effective demonstration of the conspiratorial giddiness of new love.

column1: So it's best to think of Mala as a new beginning for Banhart than a triumphant return to form-- for one thing
column2: this is not the sort of record that will bring back the diehards who felt he fell off the moment he traded in his four-track
column3: to say nothing of cleaning up his image and reneging on the promise of ""Long Haired Child"". And he still isn't the most fastidious editor of his own work; on the whole
column4: it's for the best that his mojo and humor are given equal billing on Mala
column5: though he should've kept the Zappa pastiche ""Hatchet Wound"" to himself. But one overly bawdy locker room joke is a small price to pay as Banhart sounds refreshed and relieved here
column6: someone happily on the outside looking in rather than trying to situate himself as a countercultural star
column7:
and finally taking the opportunity to show that he doesn't take himself as seriously as a lot of people take him.

Jay Farrar has always stood up for the Little Guy in America. Most of his songs are about regular folks facing down some challenge
column2: whether it’s a powerful corporation
column3: a corrupt politician
column4: or simply hard times. With Uncle Tupelo in the early 1990s
column5: he wrote paeans to anonymous laborers and pitiable drunks
column6: although the ensuring alt-country movement borrowed the romanticism and ignored the radicalized politics of <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/8344-no-depression-still-feel-gone-and-march-16-20-1992/"">March 16-20
column8: he discovered Woody Guthrie and recorded a few albums of languid agit-folk-rock that were heavy on vague outrage and light on sense. Okemah and the Melody of Riot
column9: named after Guthrie’s birthplace
column10: had all the passion of a thesis paper
column11: as though Farrar admired his idol’s righteous anger but had no idea how to duplicate it. Even on One Fast Move or I’m Gone
column12: his 2009 book report on Kerouac
column13: Farrar lost himself in unquestioning idol worship of the Beat Poet.

column1: If those albums depict the American everyman laboring and traveling
column2: Son Volt’s latest
column3: Honky Tonk
column4: shows the Little Guy at leisure. As the title suggests
column5: the milieu is the roadhouse full of people nursing beers and broken hearts while wearing ruts in the dance floor. Instead of Okies or Beats
column6: Farrar’s inspiration is Bakersfield
column7: the California crossroads that figured so prominently in the country of music of the late 1960s. Acts like Buck Owens and Merle Haggard emphasized electric guitar and drums
column8: steely riffs and solid rhythms
column9: and that harder sound distinguished them from the more traditional strains of country emanating from Nashville. For Son Volt
column10: that means a constant two-step rhythm
column11: a fiddle that swirls in and out of focus
column12: pedal steel that sheds a tear in everybody’s beer
column13: and an electric guitar that bounces around some of the faster tunes like “Bakersfield”.

column1: It may be the best Son Volt has sounded in a decade and the most engaged Farrar has sounded in longer
column2: but that’s not really saying much. As a singer
column3: his voice drifts into a muddied
column4: low monotone that favors an unhurried midtempo and tends to flatten the melody; as a songwriter
column5: he tends to favor obtuse wordplay that obscures rather than illuminates his subject matter. On Honky Tonk
column6: he makes the most of those limitations
column7: more or less. His voice sounds positively animated on “Seawall” and “Barricades""
column8: and he lovingly draws out the long vowels of “blues” on “Angel of the Blues”
column9: as though reluctant to actually part with the word.

column1: To adapt to the roadhouse setting
column2: Farrar’s songwriting has grown more straightforward as well
column3: even if he favors the same theme on almost every tune: “Don’t let the barricades of life keep the wild spirit still.” But some of his attempts to evoke actually do evoke; some of these songs sound like they have thousands of highway miles between them and are coated with dust. “Down the Highway” may be his best roadtrip anthem since “Windfall” on Son Volt’s ’95 debut
column4: Trace. “There’s a world of wisdom inside a fiddle tune
column5: ” he sings. “Throw this love down the highway/ See where it takes you.” The scale is less ambitious
column6: but writing about the travails of the heart is just as righteous as building a machine to kill fascists.

column1: The problem with Honky Tonk is that it’s more suited to the road than the roadhouse. The pacing is so languid
column2: the dynamics so muted that I doubt this iteration of Son Volt would last very long in a real honkytonk. They’d clear the dancefloor and possibly get drowned out by chatter. While the Bakersfield sound is not strictly dance music
column3: it is by its very nature social music
column4: meant to be experienced and enjoyed communally. Yet
column5: Farrar’s songs sound introverted instead of extroverted
column6: suited more to his own idiosyncrasies as singer and bandleader than to the needs of his perceived audience. In other words
column7: you can’t scoot a boot to this album. Farrar continues to sing about regular folk
column8:
but still hasn’t found a way to sing to them.

Last year's Consignment: Favor for a Favor

Sometimes he tried to wear a lothario's robes instead of playing to his hard-nosed blue-collar strengths. But Boldy's presence was reason enough not to skip ahead. He spends most of his time detailing the intricacies of selling cocaine and raps with a numbed monotone
column4: and he's the kind of rapper who boasts of his product's popularity while looking over his shoulder

column1: Boldy's new EP
column2: Grand Quarters
column3: gathers songs from the last few years and adds new material. Half the tracks are produced by Chuck Inglish of the Cool Kids

column6: and his beats are some of his hardest yet

column1: ""Gettin' Flicked"" finds a second home here after first appearing on the 2010 Cool Kids mixtape Tacklebox
column2: and surrounded by other tracks similar in aesthetic
column3: it's even more effective. Woozy synths approximate police car sirens
column4: and Boldy crafts a tight narrative in which
column5: after being released from jail
column6: he goes straight back to the only life he knows. It's packed with details that give it a lived-in feel
column7: like the fact his Air Jordan XII sneakers don't have any laces or that it was his aunts Lynnette and Marsha who accepted his collect call when he was arrested. The broken-subwoofer thump of ""For the Birds""-- the only one of the three Inglish-produced tracks not to have been released in some form before-- frees Boldy to dig into the corners of the track as he expands on slang for a brick of cocaine into a track's worth of fowl-inspired drug talk. Because they leave so much room for him to maneuver
column8: these tracks serve as an excellent introduction for those unfamiliar with Boldy. The wide-open spaces highlight how flexible of a rapper he is
column9: how much energy he can inject into a tightly-coiled style. His raps aren't quite melodic
column10: but they possess a musicality that keeps them engaging.

column1: The new tracks further highlight that flexibility. ""Come Here"" is bombastic and celebratory
column2: radio-friendly without sacrificing Boldy's idiosyncrasies-- the song even finds him trying on Auto-Tune for size
column3: and thankfully it's more Future than Rebirth-era Lil Wayne. ""I Can Pull It Off"" is probably the most melodic production Boldy has ever rapped over
column4: a shimmering tapestry of adrenaline-soaked synths with a sticky hook to match.

column1: Because it repurposes older material
column2: Grand Quarters feels like a stopgap release more than anything else
column3: a lead-in to Boldy's forthcoming Alchemist-produced album
column4: scheduled for later this year. The outlines of two diverging courses for Boldy's career are plotted here. But given Alchemist's noir-ish take on classic New York boom-bap and ""Power Glove""
column5: their collaboration from last year's Russian Roulette

column7:
harder-hitting sound of the first half. But Boldy's surprising range here suggests that he'll be ready for whatever comes.

Bandshell's part of the ever-growing generation of young artists who
column2: thanks to the digital age

column6: though

column9: in accordance

column1: The internet can be a desolate place
column2: and Bandshell more or less lives on the internet
column3: so his music follows suit. His debut EP
column4: last year's Hessle-released Dust March
column5: less resembled proper techno than it did a skeletal
column6: perverted take on the genre. The beats were sparse and unstable

column11: brittle textures

column13: though

column1: ""Broken"" is a word that's popped up a few times in attempts to describe Bandshell's sound; appropriately
column2: ""Winton""

column4: sounds like busted parts held together with masking tape. (Caustic View is the third release from Lib Tech
column5: following strong output from Laurel Halo and Surgeon/Regis pair-up BMB
column6: and it further suggests that the imprint is one to watch for off-center beat fare in the future.) The tune's thick bass introduces something more floor-ready than anything on Dust March

column1: ""Winton"" is aggressive and splayed
column2: and it's the only track on the EP that operates as such-- Caustic View's four pieces travel on their own paths. ""Nice Mullet"" is all hissing steam and dirty tones
column3: with piping machinery as a rhythmic backbone; ""Landfill"" switches out the fog for a healthy dose of paranoia
column4: as noise blasts puncture the atmospheric humidity before a sludgy synth melody turns the whole thing into a bombed-out anti-anthem. Most intriguingly is ""Winton""'s A-side sharer
column5: ""Perc""
column6: the EP's longest and most meditative cut. The composition is relatively simple-- a few interlocking synths that sound as if played from six rooms away
column7: a sneakily melodic low end
column8: the warm thud of the backbeat
column9: and the faintest whiff of tape hiss-- but the results are affecting and contemplative
column10: reminiscent of the prettier moments on dance deconstructionist Actress' beguiling 2012 album R.I.P.

column1: Bandshell has stated that he used to ""write a lot of music"" but is more judiciously creative as of late. So despite the possible assumption that Caustic View suggests artistic growth from his material out there thus far
column2: the fact that two of these tunes have appeared on previous mixes potentially disproves a sense of chronology-- ""Landfill"" especially
column3: as it appeared on Bandshell's own Sonic Router mix around the time of Dust March's release. (In a full-circle of sorts
column4: ""Perc"" showed up on Ben UFO's recent
column5: relatively rough'n'tumble Fabriclive mix.) Instead of piecing together Bandshell's past and future
column6: then
column7:
it's more fun to wonder where the promising talent will go with his sound next.

Before there was Ziggy

column12: when David Bowie was just another struggling London songwriter desperate for a break
column13: he shot a promotional film to showcase his particularly dramatic brand of performance. Along with a handful of songs-- including an early version of ""Space Oddity"" in which a tinfoil-helmeted Bowie is seduced by a couple of space sirens-- the reel included an original mime piece called ""The Mask"". It shows Bowie
column14: looking like the least intimidating pirate of all-time in tight white tights
column15: a frilly top
column16: and a pageboy wig
column17: stealing an invisible mask and proceeding to charm his family
column18: co-workers

column20: films

column24: though."" The mime ends with the white-faced ""star"" giving his biggest performance yet-- and then he can't get the mask off. It strangles him. ""The papers made a big thing out of it
column27: they didn't mention anything about a mask."" Even before David Bowie gained a smidge of notoriety
column28: he was well aware of its pitfalls-- and his own susceptibility to the lure of disguise.

column1: To put it mildly

This malleability astounds because it runs so counter to the way most of us think and behave. It's non-conformist
column11: uncomfortable
column12: and irrational
column13: without any of the detrimental consequences that are supposed to come along with such rule-breaking. Granted

column15: but even those disappointments led to the despondency that fueled his oblique Berlin trilogy. While many artists claim to despise the status quo
column16: only a few have discarded previous successes with the abandon of Bowie

column1: The following couple of decades weren't quite as fulfilling

column10: and it seemed like David Bowie was settling into a respectable late-career renaissance. And then
column11: on June 25
column13: he collapsed backstage after a show in Germany

column15: though
column16: I won't be writing a song about this one

column18: following the angioplasty. ""I can't wait to be fully recovered and get back to work again.""

column1: Nearly a decade of silence followed. Rumors of retirement or serious illness came up once in a while
