column3: a friend of Bowie's was quoted as saying
column4: ""If you were in hospital after a heart scare
column5: would you be wishing you'd spent more time flogging yourself on tour? Or would you be wishing you could spend more time with your five-year-old?"" The explanation seems reasonable; Bowie was going to avoid rock'n'roll fogey-dom by avoiding rock'n'roll altogether while making up for his early fatherly failures. But then he figured out another way to move ahead.

column1: On several levels
column2: David Bowie's 24th studio album is a cunning act of sleight of hand. On The Next Day
column3: he hasn't only come to terms with his past-- he's making his old material work for his new material. For Bowie
column4: the always-savvy son of a public relations man
column5: it's good for business and good for art. The ""Heroes""-erasing cover is an admission
column6: a boast
column7: and a provocation (""how dare he!"") all at once. And by keeping the album's recording sessions a tight-lipped secret
column8: the back-from-the-dead exclamation of its announcement was that much more pronounced. Also
column9: by abstaining from any new interviews and only releasing a few drab black-and-white promo photos
column10: he's all but forcing the press to go back through his archives to fill the inevitable cover stories from all across the globe. So
column11: there's long-haired Hunky Dory Bowie on the cover of France's Telerama
column12: a lightning-eyed Aladdin Sane fronting the UK's Q
column13: a ""Heroes"" outtake peering out from Japan's Rockin'On. He turned the ""David Bowie is dying!"" worry into a thousand fawning would-be obituaries that instead build excitement for his new album-- all while he's likely sitting at his computer
column14: sipping tea and enjoying the coup.

column1: The music found within is also something of a bait-and switch; on the surface
column2: many tracks are uptempo rockers that recall various moments of Bowie's near-50-year career-- hopeful fodder for a tour that looks unlikely to take off-- but delve into the lyric sheet and you'll find death
column3: war
column4: graves
column5: murder
column6: and ghosts at almost every turn. Admittedly
column7: this is not new subject matter for the singer-- his 1967 debut album ended with the theatrical ""Please Mr. Gravedigger""
column8: an essentially a cappella tale of a child killer and a man re-digging holes for bodies after a bomb tore up their original resting places. And there's the glam apocalypse story of 1974's Diamond Dogs. But while those yarns could be fanciful and campy-- the musings of a young man glamorizing or sensationalizing the ultimate end-- The Next Day's deathly bent is more blunt.

column1: Inspired by English medieval history books
column2: the title track tells of a man being dragged and maimed by an angry mob. ""Here I am
column3: not quite dying/ My body left to rot in a hollow tree
column4: sings Bowie
column5: in a husky voice. The simmering ""Love Is Lost"" observes a troubled
column6: perhaps suicidal 22-year-old girl whose ""fear is as old as the world."" It builds to a clenched-fist climax with Bowie ruefully pleading ""oh
column7: what have you done?"" ""Valentine's Day""
column8: meanwhile
column9: is a Ziggy-style romp... about a tiny-faced school shooter; ""How Does the Grass Grow?"" offers a quasi-sentimental graveyard tale in which Bowie quips
column10: ""Remember the dead/ They were so great/ Some of them""; ""You Feel So Lonely You Could Die"" wishes comeuppance upon a heartless Cold War assassin. You get the point. It may very well be his bleakest set of lyrics to date
column11: words that don't glorify death as much as they detail its cruel inevitability throughout history. So while ""The Next Day"" could be seen as an optimistic phrase on paper
column12: on the title track its describing nothing less than eternal brutal violence: ""And the next day
column13: and the next
column14: and another day.""

column1: Musically
column2: The Next Day isn't as radical or dreary
column3: as it bounces around from style to style
column4: casually suggesting past greatness while rarely matching it. The production is clean and crisp
column5: almost to a fault
column6: leaving little room for the off-kilter spontaneity that highlights Bowie's best work; it's no coincidence that two of the album's best moments
column7: on the skulking ""Dirty Boys"" and the taut ""Boss of Me""
column8: feature glorious sax solos from longtime collaborator Steve Elson. Too often
column9: though
column10: the instrumentation sounds museum-ready. This is a shame
column11: especially considering Visconti's pedigree-- this is the same guy who revolutionized the way rock drums sound on Low by pitching them down using a device that
column12: he boasted to Bowie at the time
column13: ""fucks with the fabric of time."" The same effect teasingly shows up ever-so-briefly on The Next Day
column14: at the start of ""Love Is Lost""
column15: and the Scott Walker-style closer ""Heat"" nails a disconcerting ambience
column16: but otherwise
column17: the album's sonics could've certainly been fucked with a bit more.

column1: In 1974
column2: Rolling Stone sat a 27-year-old Bowie down with a 60-year-old William Burroughs to discuss accelerating technologies
column3: the uselessness of love
column4: and the quality of porn films from country to country: ""The best ones were the German ones
column5: Bowie concludes. (In one of the few Next Day press photos
column6: the 66-year-old Bowie sits beneath a photo of himself and the famed author from that '74 interview.) They also touch on the trappings of public perception. ""They want to see their picture of you
column7: says Burroughs
column8: ""and if they don't see their picture of you they're very upset."" David Bowie has made a career of walking that line between the picture people want to see and the one he wants to give them. In this way
column9: The Next Day finds him as astute as ever
column10: casting a ghoulish shadow over sounds and images we know and love. In fact
column11: there was at least one exclusive magazine cover photo to go along with the new record; according to an editor's letter
column12: the image that appeared on the front of last week's NME arrived in his inbox with the message
column13: ""This is just for you. No-one else has seen this. David would like to be on the cover."" The photo
column14: shot just last month
column15:
shows two eyes-- one pupil bigger than the other-- behind a stark white mask.

"|17855.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17855-david-bowie-the-next-day/|7.6|Ryan Dombal

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18822/homepage_large.4ae444b8.jpg|Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre)|195.0|Apparat|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute']|2013-03-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:33.276164|"

There is a level of expectation with a piece of work like Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre) that threatens to color the experience of listening to it. It's a reminder that what we bring to a piece of music shapes how we listen. In the crudest of terms
column2: it's an album adapted from a score for a piece of theatre based on novel responding to a historical event. More specifically
column3: it is the work of Berlin-based producer Apparat
column4: commissioned by German theatre director Sebastian Hartmann for his 2012 production of Tolstoy’s War and Peace. While these cold facts could perhaps appear impenetrable on paper
column5: Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre) is a delightful challenge to both fixity and expectations.

column1: There are many layers of response at work here and
column2: similarly
column3: as many reflections and echoes between the various responses. It was the result of intense collaboration between Hartmann and his cast
column4: Apparat’s Sascha Ring and the musicians he involved
column5: and with the ever-shifting nature of the production itself during the making and staging of it with the score performed live by an orchestra each night. That inherent sense of flux permeates every note on the album; it surprises at every turn. The delicate music box chimes of “K&F Thema” seem to come from nowhere
column6: like sparks of vibrant light shooting up from the stark
column7: watery landscape of the preceding “Blank Page”. Swelling strings proceed to engulf the chimes until they themselves are cut short
column8: succumbing to distant drums sending out a warning. “K&F Thema (Pizzicato)” is
column9: as the title indicates
column10: a plucked variation on the main theme
column11: conveying a level of affected yet affecting sophistication. The desire to join the dots in the bigger narrative is strong: is this the aristocracy’s last dance before the war fractures their insular way of life?

column1: Swimming beneath Ring’s orchestral arrangements is a primordial soup of sonics: the falling of rain outside a window
column2: the awkward tumble of unknown objects
column3: a shrill whirl of drills. The hustle and bustle of these sounds ground the grandiose orchestration in the real world
column4: give it an abstract sense of the mud and blood-splattered physicality of war. Ring’s skill here recalls the work of cult techno producer Torsten Pröfrock
column5: a man he has previously paid tribute to for instilling in him “the idea of sounds having a patina [...] That sounds really needs something like that-- a little dirt is always important in your music.” There are also lines to be drawn with the work of cellist Julia Kent who incorporates found sound into her recordings. On an even wider level
column6: it speaks to the many conversations going on in contemporary composition today: briefly
column7: about whether to embrace electronic means
column8: as Anna Meredith has done
column9: or uphold tradition in composing solely for orchestra.

column1: Ring has
column2: of course
column3: come to the orchestra from the other side of the fence. It was his last album The Devil’s Walk that first found him breaking with his techno production past to more fully incorporate instrumentation and his own singing voice. While there's a touch of mid-90s
column4: prog-rock musical theatre to the two vocal tracks on Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre)-- “Light On” and “A Violent Sky”-- it's not unwelcome. Ring’s orchestral and electronic score communicates the narrative’s swing from complacent luxury to riveting despair
column5:
showing what happens when worlds collide.

"|17624.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17624-apparat-krieg-und-frieden-music-for-theatre/|7.5|Ruth Saxelby

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19009/homepage_large.146331fa.jpg|Between Places|30062.0|Young Dreams|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modular']|2013-03-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:33.827853|"

A few months ago
column2: when Young Dreams covered a song by former tourmates Tame Impala
column3: they renamed it “Feels Like We Only Go Bachwards”. The pun spoke volumes. Young Dreams are baroque
column4: a little anachronistic and
column5: occasionally
column6: wincingly earnest-- but at least their self-presentation shows that they’re fully aware of all these things. Everything about them has an air of almost orchestral grandeur. A Norwegian pop collective whose membership sometimes is as high as 12
column7: their press material describes them not as a band but a “sovereign nation.” Their recent single
column8: the floating
column9: psych-pop anthem “Fog of War”
column10: was a standard tale of alienation and teenage dreams
column11: except for the fact that instead of pining for the girl next door
column12: the narrator was “waiting for my own Athena.” Dream big or go home.

column1: Young Dreams are from Bergen-- a city where
column2: by their own admission “it rains 400 days a year”-- but sonically
column3: Between Places imagines a place where the sun shines bright. Their densely flourished yet weightless pocket symphonies owe an obvious debt to the Beach Boys
column4: but certain elements of their sound also nod to more contemporary artists: the buoyant vocal harmonies on “Footprints” recall Grizzly Bear circa Veckatimest
column5: while “First Days of Something” centers around a breezy riff that wouldn’t sound out of place in a Vampire Weekend song. Still
column6: Between Places has a thematic unity that makes it something more pointed than a collection of influences. Whether about escaping the oppression of adolescence or your dreary local weather patterns
column7: Young Dreams’ music exalts the transformative power of imagination. “I think it's a reaction to the weather we have: freezing cold
column8: no light
column9: ” the de facto frontman Matias Tellez said of their sun-dappled sound. “I think it's just that
column10: when things are miserable
column11: you start dreaming of things that aren't as miserable.""

column1: Between Places is certainly an impressive sounding album. Its best songs
column2: like “Footprints” and the eponymous “Young Dreams” achieve a difficult balance of feeling grand and baroque but never overcrowded; woodwinds
column3: synthesizers and choral background singers add a fullness to the atmosphere but duck out of frame right at the moment when they’d be too much. The hooks are unabashedly epic
column4: and the atmosphere is immersive but light. The album’s high point
column5: “Fog of War”
column6: sounds like a Killers song coming apart in the outer reaches of the stratosphere.

column1: But Young Dreams have to work some things out down on earth before they can effectively soar that high. Tellez’ lyrics often either too bland (“We’re restless
column2: that’s why we keep on moving…We’ll live forever”) or
column3: when he zooms in and attempts a bit more specifics
column4: clumsy (“I couldn’t stop talking/ I now need a charger for my mobile phone”). This wouldn’t be such a problem if the songs weren’t structured and mixed as though the lead vocals were the most important things going on-- they haven’t yet mastered the trick that a band like Grizzly Bear do so well: presenting lead vocals as though they’re just another instrument in the song
column5: and using lyrics more for texture than explicit meaning. The band’s songwriting chops are evident on Between Places
column6: and it’s refreshing for a debut to err on the side of being too ambitious
column7: when so many new indie bands nowadays suffer from the opposite problem. But the content of these songs doesn’t quite earn their epic execution. “Not empty
column8: because of our young dreams
column9: ” Tellez professes on the closing track
column10: but it’s the dreams themselves that feel hollow and faceless
column11:
the kind whose specifics you strain to remember the next day.

"|17812.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17812-young-dreams-between-places/|5.7|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18971/homepage_large.6147e95f.jpg|LISm|193.0|Ellen Allien|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bpitch Control']|2013-03-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:34.289771|"

Berliner Ellen Allien clearly doesn't view boundaries in quite the same way as many of her techno peers. Using terms like ""fearless"" to describe musicians who cycle through contrasting styles in their career often comes across as lazy shorthand for competency-- the music rarely eclipses its obvious influences. Allien has occasionally veered close to that space
column2: although mostly there's a strong feeling of immersion in the genres she splintered off into in works like Sool and Dust. LIsm
column3: a single track that clocks in at 45-minutes
column4: is her most fractured work to date
column5: a piece that veers from abstraction into song-oriented forms and through the clubby territory that made her name. It's adapted from a work she produced for a dance performance at Paris' Pompidou Centre in 2011
column6: with Allien subsequently retooling the music she composed to give LIsm a peculiar life and feel of its own.

column1: This is more likely to be a one-off project than a firm detachment from the scene that spawned Allien
column2: but it's certainly something far closer to avant rock circles than it is to anything approaching dance music. As an overall work it bears few peers
column3: although there are passages that produce a sense of familiarity. The opening guitar strum is reminiscent of the slow creep lead-in from ""Nice One"" by improvisational Portland troupe Jackie-O Motherfucker
column4: while the clear-eyed pop that closes out the track is just a production budget short of Dr. Luke's domain. In between those bookends come impulses that need a road map to make sense of
column5: although the beauty of LIsm comes from dipping in and getting lost. The sequencing is skillfully cut together
column6: as you'd expect from someone with Allien's DJ pedigree
column7: although it never ends up as a mere technical feat to marvel at. She's clearly more interested in digging out an emotional core to this work.

column1: It's a wayward journey
column2: which appears to be the intention of the piece
column3: although at times it produces the kind of mixed results you get from opening a novel at a random page and trying to make sense of it. Sometimes that can produce a whole other world
column4: a place where the reader is forced to color in the background in interesting ways; at other times it's impossible to get your bearings. LIsm is both those things
column5: a place where the minimal techno of Sool brushes up against primal screams reminiscent of the stringy howl of Liars' Angus Andrew
column6: only to take a thrilling left turn into gamelan-influenced percussion. At those points
column7: LIsm forges ahead with purpose
column8: resembling a DJ set that's part education
column9: part historical melting pot. When it doesn't work it feels a little clunky. Sparse jazz moves collide with glacial Vangelis synths
column10: 0PN drones segue awkwardly into classical piano
column11: drum machines pointlessly sputter into life then fade away.

column1: That sense of just trying stuff on to see whether it works has some merit
column2: but it does cause LIsm to lose purpose at crucial junctures. There's a sag in the center of the piece
column3: a feeling of Allien not keeping her eye on the bigger picture as a soupy array of styles slosh about aimlessly. It's no surprise that her exit door out of there is via the kind of thoughtful techno that harks back to her Berlinette days. But in this context it doesn't feel like a retread
column4: instead coming across as a crucial part in the LIsm narrative
column5: a way of figuring out how darker fare can form part of a slow build toward celestial clubland. The barbed metallic drones that guide Allien to that place are the highlight of the track
column6: a beautiful mesh of criss-crossing figures
column7: all set at purposefully difficult angles to one another. That's LIsm's place
column8: looking for commonality where none exists
column9:
succeeding because it shapes conversations through the klutzy way its parts are assembled.

"|17774.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17774-ellen-allien-lism/|6.4|Nick Neyland

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18922/homepage_large.b9f1a23a.jpg|Toy Love|31053.0|Toy Love|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Flying Nun'
column2:
'Captured Tracks']|2013-03-11 00:00:00|1980|2016-06-11 17:00:35.049446|"

Though they existed for less than two years
column3: Toy Love are immeasurably important to the history of New Zealand music. They helped inspire the creation of Flying Nun-- perhaps the most important independent label in the country’s history-- and last year their influence was recognized via induction into the New Zealand Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. It’s odd
column4: then
column5: that for decades after their 1980 demise
column6: their music was represented primarily by a record they didn’t even like. That’s because the production on their sole
column7: self-titled album (issued on major label WEA) buffed the edges off their melodic but raucous post-punk.

column1: Flying Nun rectified that a bit in 2005 by reissuing a newly-mixed version of Toy Love
column2: adding singles and demos in a 2xCD package called Cuts. But for anyone curious about the band’s reputation as a vital
column3: high-wire garage act
column4: now is truly the time to dive in. A few months ago
column5: Goner issued Live at the Gluepot
column6: a ripping double LP of recordings from the band’s final shows. And now Captured Tracks
column7: as part of its new reissue program with Flying Nun
column8: has compiled two discs’ worth of singles and demos under the name Toy Love (a slightly confusing move
column9: since the original self-titled album is not included).

column1: Of the two
column2: Live at the Gluepot is more immediately impressive
column3: just in terms of sheer speed and momentum. Amazingly
column4: Toy Love played nearly 500 shows in their brief existence
column5: and here that experience is loudly obvious. Each of the record’s 25 short
column6: sharp songs flies by so quickly you might find have trouble remembering any single one. But that’s likely the point--- Toy Love doesn’t sound interested in finding perfectly-crafted melodies
column7: but in cranking out tightly-wound tunes with as much snarling energy and coursing blood as possible. That head-down approach is reflected in the between-song banter of singer Chris Knox. His wry intros-- “this next one we found on a back of a chewing gum wrapper in 1939”-- suggest the music should be taken just seriously enough to enjoy the hell out of it.

column1: Toy Love did bury some memorable gems inside their quick-shot post-punk
column2: and that’s clearer on Captured Tracks’ compilation. Punchy tunes like the winding “Squeeze”
column3: the rising stomp “Sheep”
column4: and the swaying “Swimming Pool” (in which Knox oddly parodies Bob Dylan’s nasal croon) all rival the best of contemporaries like the Buzzcocks and the Undertones. I’m most partial to “Amputee Song”
column5: an anthem for the limbless that predicts both the organ-driven garage of the Clean and the weird monster tales of Tall Dwarfs
column6: the equally-vital act that Knox and guitarist Alec Bathgate went on to form. It also highlights Toy Love’s unique combination of bold enthusiasm and dark humor-- it’s hard to imagine anyone besides Knox making a nihilistic chorus like “We don’t exist!” sound so exultant.

column1: Enthused humor has been a Knox/Bathgate trademark since the days of their first group the Enemy
column2: from which Toy Love was spawned. And Knox has valiantly maintained that attitude since suffering a stroke in 2009. Many artists rallied around him after that tragic event
column3: creating a tribute compilation and rekindling interest in his great body of work. Hopefully this pair of Toy Love releases will do the same
column4:
but you don’t have to know who Chris Knox is to appreciate Toy Love and Live at the Gluepot. All you really need is a pair of working ears.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18867/homepage_large.4a208954.jpg|New Moon|29754.0|The Men|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-03-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:35.730523|"

It's the first law of indie-rock: Every grungy
column3: guitar-powered act-- from Dinosaur Jr. to Titus Andronicus-- eventually goes a little Crazy Horse
column4: gradually easing their squalling sludgefeasts into a classic-rock comfort zone. I just didn't expect it to happen so soon for the Men. Over the course of two quick-succession albums
column5: 2011's Leave Home and last year's Open Your Heart
column6: the Brooklyn bruisers' primordial post-hardcore roar had exploded into a constellation of possibilities
column7: exploring everything from krautrock to country to shoegazed psychedelia. But the Men that hit the road in early 2012 to promote Open Your Heart were already a different band than the one documented on that record. Their once-unwieldy noise was being harnessed into a more economical drive and harmonicas were being blown. A band that less than two years ago sounded like descendents of Big Black had already found their way to Big Pink.

column1: This is the Men that greet us on New Moon-- recorded
column2: natch
column3: in a cabin in the Catskills. And what gracious hosts they've become
column4: welcoming us in with the gentle
column5: piano-tapped lullaby ""Open the Door"". Even when you take the band's rapid-fire maturation into account
column6: the song still startles with its angelic harmonies
column7: peaceful images of ""trees swaying
column8: and general air of bonhomie. But if the opener seemingly announces a break from the band's formative inspirations
column9: New Moon as a whole reinforces their spiritual connection to them. In hindsight
column10: 1980s indie rock wasn't so much an antidote to the preceding generation's dinosaur rock as a tough-love corrective measure to revitalize it
column11: from the Minutmen’s CCR/BOC boosterism to Hüsker Dü's sand-blasted take on the Byrds. What the Men ultimately share with their SST forbears isn't a sound but a work ethic
column12: with a record-release output that can barely keep pace with their artistic progression
column13: fuelled by a blatant disregard for the punks they're bound to piss off along the way.

column1: But as New Moon proves
column2: there's a big difference between respecting tradition and being boring
column3: between quieting down and going soft
column4: between being earnest and being sappy.  The album's more rustic first side may exhibit their newly professed fondness for Tom Petty
column5: but the spirit is still a lot closer to Johnny Thunders' Heartbreakers. Acoustic guitars are front and center
column6: but they slash and scrape rather than soothe; the early double shot of ""Half Angel Half Light"" and ""Without a Face"" suggests Full Moon Fever had Jeff Lynne been ousted from the producer's chair and replaced by Spot. What initially impresses about the record is not just that the Men have reconciled their growing affinity for delicate
column7: confessional songcraft with their usual raw frayed-nerve energy
column8: but how easy they make it look.

column1: That's not to say there weren’t some growing pains along the way: Shortly after the release of Open Your Heart
column2: the band excommunicated bassist Chris Hansell
column3: the guy responsible for <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4VKsjmFD-bk"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the most unforgivably caustic

column8: upstanding

The general trajectory of Pete Swanson's solo recordings is one of increased corrosion
column3: where each new record he puts out bears a sound that atrophies a little more than the last. If you take in a few plot points-- say
column4: 2011's Man with Potential
column5: followed by 2012's Pro Style
column6: and then this new EP for Mexican Summer/Software-- it feels like you're simultaneously witnessing a refinement of his vision and the gradual destruction of his core aesthetic. In a 2011 interview for the Out Door
column7: Swanson discussed how he was often bugged about krautrock and electronic influences on his former band
column8: Yellow Swans
column9: and how the duo's early experiments were born out of ""not being satisfied with what generally existed"" in those styles. That sense of dissatisfaction has continued on the beat-heavy output under his own name
column10: taking a scorched earth policy toward EDM that gleefully pulls out all the ugly innards of the genre.

column1: Punk Authority
column2: the latest in a string of wittily titled releases from Swanson
column3: pulls everything into a bigger
column4: fuller
column5: more expansive framework. The title conveys confidence
column6: even if it is some private
column7: unexplained joke
column8: and it's a feeling matched in the music. Here
column9: everything is pushed up into the red. Even less cluttered moments
column10: such as the clock-ticking beats that form an intro to the title track
column11: are in the throes of deterioration
column12: lost in an attempt to bend everything toward breaking point. At times there's only a tiny semblance of order peaking through the debris
column13: but it's always there
column14: just about keeping everything together. Still
column15: it's hard not to think of this as some kind of end game that Swanson has been careering toward
column16: especially when that title track is shunted into a pure whiteout phase that makes it hard to focus on anything other than the unholy shitstorm spewing out of your speakers.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Punk Authority is only concerned with the present
column3: not the future or the past. This is Swanson finding a new type of delirium and wallowing in it
column4: letting it expand and contract over four tracks that begin in unadulterated mania and never look back. It's obtrusive
column5: even obnoxious at times. The first lick of noise from ""C.O.P."" feels like a bratty kid spitting in your eye and lifting your wallet from your pocket while you're still comprehending what happened. The bleepy motif strung throughout that track is the closest anything here gets to having a solid link to dance music
column6: ultimately coming off like a version of LFO's ""Freak"" stretched out on a torture rack. There's something cleansing about returning for repeat plays
column7: a sense of Swanson purging some unidentified horrors from his life. The silence that settles in at the end of the EP resembles the pause in time needed when comprehending a piece of really bad news.

column1: The track that precedes that silence
column2: the 13-minute ""Life Ends at 30""
column3: is Swanson's wildest statement yet
column4: a berserk piece of man vs. machine noise that's as bruising as it is euphoric. It's a dense work
column5: plagued by a million tangential thoughts all piled up on top of one another
column6: creating a sense of claustrophobia that never lets up. The term ""nosebleed techno"" has already been coined to define a sub-genre of hardcore
column7: which is too bad; it would be the perfect ugly descriptor to hang around the neck of most of the material here. ""Life Ends at 30"" is a great example of Swanson’s ability to gain a form of lunatic momentum that positions him right on the brink of chaos. He doesn’t appear interested in total formlessness
column8: instead reaching a place that gets as close as he can to all-out loss of control then just about pulling back. Getting there is a thrilling white-knuckle ride
column9:
like peering over the ledge for 30 minutes but never jumping off.

Brendan Canty played drums in Fugazi; Rich Morel's a singer-songwriter with a side-hustle remixing Nelly Furtado songs for the club. The two met when they both joined Bob Mould's touring band (Morel and the ex-Hüsker host a monthly DJ night in D.C.). The stylistic gap between a post-punk legend like Canty and a song-and-dance man like Morel might seem a bridge too far
column2: but Canty and Morel's pedigrees
column3: impressive as they are
column4: don't really loom all that large on Deathfix
column5: their new band's self-titled debut. Canty and Morel bonded over a love of shaggy 1970s rock
column6: and there's plenty of Big Star and Deep Purple's influence to be found on Deathfix
column7: cut with swampy grunge
column8: post-rock
column9: and a touch of funk. So many new bands from established artists hinge on the tension between the two styles
column10: but there's not much tension of any kind to be found on the surprisingly loose-limbed Deathfix. Unmoored from expectation
column11: uninterested in rehashing past glories
column12: Canty and Morel make for the basement
column13: looking to make a racket all their own.

column1: Opener ""Better Than Bad"" practically swings an arm out the window and asks if you need a lift. The glam-spangled
column2: sweet-as-Raspberries power-popper seems to be at least 90% hook
column3: its ribbony lead guitars driving the song's melody off into the night. ""Low Lying Dreams"" introduces the first of several unseemly characters
column4: as Morel's Mark Lanegan-worthy leer gives way to a sweeping eastern-tinged crescendo. Faraquet's Devin Ocampo and Medications' Mark Cisneros joined Canty and Morel in the studio
column5: fleshing out their demos with bits of their own
column6: and the results are remarkably fluid
column7: never showboaty
column8: perpetually locked-in.

column1: Most of Deathfix's lyrics concern themselves with the down-and-out. Characters sidestep sobriety
column2: idolize wantonly
column3: die in depressing fashions. Take ""Hospital""
column4: which flits between the mania of a fever-dream (""the patients are turning red"") to a young girl
column5: a do-not-resuscitate order
column6: and a patient's bed with a regrettably high turnover. Morel and Canty won't paint you a portrait
column7: exactly
column8: but there's enough detail in these thumbnail sketches to suggest a very real (and very troubled) cast of characters hanging in the shadows of these songs. Until ""Dali's House""
column9: that is.

column1: ""Dali's House"" is a goof; that's the only explanation. Riding a stock funk groove with a distinct jam band lean to it
column2: ""Dali's"" finds our speak-singing narrator wishing he himself could house a loose gathering of cool kids from the annals of history: Jane Birkin
column3: Muhammed Ali
column4: Mr. Dali himself. If some guy wryly intoning a who's who over a locked groove sounds a little familiar
column5: that's because it's supposed to: ""I wish I was James Murphy's house
column6: Morel notes
column7: ""because you can steal ideas
column8: and Daft Punk's always playing there."" It's kind of a rimshot in search of a punchline
column9: but there's just a hint of acid in the delivery that makes it awfully hard to conclusively figure for a burn or a tongue-in-cheek tribute. Considering how quickly the song devolves into silliness-- ""I wish I was the guy from House's house""-- we'll go with the latter. But while the first DJ to fake-out an LCD-expectant crowd with ""Dali's House"" is a hero in waiting
column10: essentially it's just one of those jokes that gets less funny every time you hear it.

column1: Deathfix quickly recovers with ""Playboy""
column2: which charts a surprisingly nimble path between tricky jazz rock chords and starry-eyed
column3: lighter-flicking balladry. But the snarl of its guitars can't keep the slow-burning ""Mind Control"" from getting a bit bogged down in its own murk. There's no shortage of dynamism in Deathfix's arrangements
column4: a lot of little parts sliding past the periphery. But the strange paths some of these songs travel to get to their eventual crescendos occasionally gets them stuck in one place
column5: or one mood
column6: for too long. Penultimate track ""Mind Control"" gradually builds to a window-shaking post-rock climax
column7: but it takes eight minutes and a false ending to get there. Deathfix gets its expansive
column8: laid-back feel from the relaxed conditions under which it came together
column9: but that's also the source of its occasional directionlessness and the fuck-around vibe of ""Dali"". The approach gives Deathfix a certain slightness that may rankle fans of either of its principals' more serious work. It's hard to imagine that bothering Morel and Canty much
column10:
though; they're clearly having way too much fun.

Remember how the internet was supposed to make albums extinct? Around the turn of the century
column2: serious-minded pop scholars were telling us that listeners would stop caring about compendiums of songs with pre-designed tracklists and conceptual underpinnings. The online world was supposed to free us from the tyranny of 50-minute bulks of music. We would now only be concerned with gloriously succinct
column3: stand-alone tunes. But that hasn't happened. There's still an expectation that makers of songs need to group them together into LPs and EPs at some point
column4: even if those songs wind up suffering in the process.

column1: One band that doesn't benefit from the album format is Glaswegian indie pop trio Golden Grrrls. The band's full-length debut comes after a series of 7-inch and cassette-only releases that presented Golden Grrrls' modest
column2: pared-down charms in appropriately modest
column3: pared-down packages. As guitarist Ruari MacLean acknowledged in a 2012 interview
column4: Golden Grrrls derive their sound from ""classic American indie stuff"" and ""also a lot of Flying Nun/Kiwi pop stuff."" That much is obvious from a cursory listen to Golden Grrrls
column5: which is built on MacLean's buzzed-up riffs and flat
column6: deadpan monotone playing off the surprisingly intricate (but always novice-level simple) instrumentation and backing vocals supplied by guitarist Rachel Aggs and drummer Eilidh Rodgers.

column1: When heard in two or three-song bunches
column2: Golden Grrrls sounds great; opening track ""New Pop"" is 110 seconds of chest-bursting guitars and charming boy-girl vocals giggling and making eyes at each other. The next song ""Past Tense"" offers more of the same: a chirpy melody
column3: slipshod rhythms
column4: low-key (and off-key) harmonies. By the third track ""Paul Simon"" (the legendary singer-songwriter is surely referenced for his jangly
column5: pre-Bridge Over Troubled Water Simon & Garfunkel hits
column6: not his more adult-oriented solo material) the formula has already been strongly reiterated and not at all elaborated upon.

column1: If Golden Grrrls had ended there
column2: it would've been another pleasurably slight and bite-sized entry in the band's discography. But even though the next eight songs only last about 20 minutes
column3: the rest of Golden Grrrls feels much longer. There are some good songs here: ""Think of the Ways"" is a delicate beauty
column4: and ""We've Got…"" brings the record to a reliably breezy conclusion. But Golden Grrrls was born to make 7-inches; this band needs to say its peace and leave
column5: not linger while the buzz wears off. The bursts of bright energy and amateurish enthusiasm on Golden Grrrls shine on wondrously for several minutes
column6: but after a while the limitations of stunted musicianship and repetitive songwriting take over. What Golden Grrrls screams out for is a haunting ballad or an experimental
column7: noisy detour or two-- anything to add variety to what is otherwise a stiflingly samey album. In lieu of that
column8:
an unsparing editor would've sufficed.

column3: unexplained ""blood on the back seat

column3: she sings

column6: deft strokes thanks to her knack for knowing exactly which physical details will carry emotional resonance. There's something almost unbearably poignant about the wedding reception she describes where ""make-up sets on [the bride's] face like tar"" and ""the champagne flutes poorly engineered

column2: tradition

column5: ""You got married when you were 15

column8: while she presents a peer's wedding as more of a ""tragic epilogue"" than a celebration on ""Dixie Cups and Jars"" (which feels like a slightly more harrowing take on Built to Spill's ""Twin Falls""). ""You’ll remain

but generous.

column2: English singer-songwriter Kate Nash is still figuring out what she likes musically and
column3: most of all

column10: and got a all-female band she’s dubbed “girl gang”. Nash co-wrote her first album with Adele’s partner-in-crime Paul Epworth

column1: As was the case on Nash’s first two records

column5: Spektor-esque piano riffs of her debut and the acoustic strumming that defined both previous albums. She’s apparently taken up the bass

column7: after the Tarantino film)
column8: and tried to make it sound rockabilly. She continues to mine throwback sounds

column1: Nash was one of those artists who broke on Myspace

column3: the type of girls who read Camille Paglia and identify with riot grrrl but reblog photos of Kurt Cobain and dip-dyed hairdos. Everything about Girl Talk screams “take me seriously

column7: some young
column8: mainstream female singer needs to stand up for this stuff. Katy Perry decries the word “feminist” while Lady Gaga defends it to death

A few years ago
column2: a micro-scene started brewing in the UK
column3: centered on a loose collection of friendly
column4: lo-fi-leaning rock bands. This cohort was best represented on the 2010 compilation PVI0006/IBB004
column5: jointly released by artist-run labels Paradise Vendors and Italian Beach Babes. As that generic title implies
column6: the scene was more about inter-band camaraderie than a specific sound-- more about sharing split releases and trading links than hiring publicists or branding themselves. So it's no shock that no movement ever came from it; in fact
column7: a few of the bands don't even exist anymore. But others-- Male Bonding
column8: Cold Pumas
column9: Fair Ohs-- have gone on to make more substantial work on their own.

column1: At the head of that surviving class sits Mazes
column2: thanks to the leap they've taken with their second album
column3: Ores & Minerals. Its predecessor
column4: 2011's A Thousand Heys
column5: was a solid take on 90s American indie
column6: but a bit too beholden to its influences. Ores & Minerals fixes that and adds a lot more. Singer/guitarist Jack Cooper claims he wanted to make a record ""that wasn't influenced by anything but influenced by everything
column7: and his trio has achieved that seemingly paradoxical goal. You can still hear traces of other bands here
column8: but Mazes' sound now is more an idiosyncratic hybrid than an enthusiastic photocopy.

column1: That's perhaps due to how the trio wrote their songs this time. Many began as loops rather than melodies
column2: resulting in immediate hooks that gradually extend into something longer-lasting. The effect is clear from the very first track
column3: ""Bodies""
column4: which morphs from a simple indie pop tune into a hypnotic twin-guitar jam. It evokes similar journeys by Television and the Feelies
column5: not in exact sound but in feel-- that is
column6: in the way its seven minutes of blissful music would still be effective at twice the length.

column1: The template set by ""Bodies"" is furthered by the krautrocky title track and the mesmerizing ""Skulking""
column2: which ramps into a crescendo of Velvet Underground-like fuzz. In between those expansive pieces lies a wealth of sonic variety. There's the slow sway of ""Dan Higgs Particle""
column3: the proggy
column4: Malkmus-esque lope of ""Sucker Punched""
column5: and even an eerie piano piece called ""Leominster"". Mazes fuse those styles by sheer force of personality-- each tune bears their own thoughtful approach first and influences second.

column1: It also helps that Cooper keeps the words to a minimum. Many of his lyrics on A Thousand Heys comprised long sentences spooled out in a breathless
column2: sometimes rambling rush. But here he sticks mostly to short phrases with lots of pauses in between. The tactic gives the album a haiku-ish feel
column3: with Cooper exploring his subjects--- relationships
column4: divorces
column5: aging-- in terms that are openly universal rather than limitingly specific.

column1: There is one moment on Ores & Minerals that could be about something particular. Halfway through the title track
column2: Cooper sings about ""looking in
column3: looking out on a scene that's distorted/ Liking things
column4: friend it
column5: report it/ You're contorted."" Perhaps that's his take on what happened with the scene Mazes came from (something he expands upon in this interview)
column6: suggesting any attempt to summarize only distorted what it was really about. But it feels more like Cooper's moved on
column7:
and on Ores & Minerals he's more interested in contorting his own sound than worrying about anyone else's.

column1: Welcome Oblivion at least starts strong: The blistering glow of opener ""The Wake-Up"" balances a deep throb with melodic chirps and Maandig's expertly crisscrossed vocals. She spends the back half of the 100-second song working through a series of reversed and reordered syllables

column2: with her pleasant voice politely holding the place for something greater. In the verses of the title track
column3: for example

column5: her voiced barbed and warped

column7: though

column11:
the project Trent Reznor attempted to use to stay current but ultimately used to restart Nine Inch Nails.

column7: the actual listening experience of In Dark Denim is inexcusably flawed for Antwon's most high-profile release to date.  For one thing
column8: the mixing is atrociously muffled and off-balance
column9: and rarely in a way that enhances the experience.  Something like the volatile
column10: Afrocentric ""Burn Away"" benefits from the clatter
column11: but otherwise ""1MillSnippet"" and ""Boomerang"" sound like poor YouTube rips and gain nothing from the bouncing reverb and complete lack of bass. Meanwhile
column12: Antwon's flow on ""Still Guarded"" is barely on speaking terms with its beat
column13: an unfortunately fitting closer for a mixtape that simply sounds rushed as opposed to urgent.

column1: Curiously enough
column2: the tracks that delve into Antwon's darker past are the most underdeveloped. ""Burn Away""
column3: ""1MillSnippet""
column4: and ""Rare 2000s"" contain intriguing details-- talking shit to his parole officer
column5: friends dying of meth addictions
column6: nights at the local park-- but either cut off short or rely on outside sources to drive their point home. All things told
column7: Antwon has the inverse problem of most rappers-- his persona is fully formed and he has a gift for choruses

column10:
that doesn't mean it’s a success on its own terms.

As much as listeners strive to seek out and reward bands that are truly original
column3: there's a sense that complaining about derivative music is an ultimately futile affair
column4: on par with doing the same about traffic
column5: exorbitant athlete salaries
column6: or primetime sitcoms: it's something of a victimless crime that's impossible to realistically eliminate
column7: so you might as well learn to deal. On that note
column8: Suuns' Images Du Futur is indeed a derivative record
column9: but in a paradoxically unique way that doesn't allow the typical mitigating circumstances to be considered. The Montreal band doesn't recall a specific era of music
column10: nor do they remind one of the kind of band so ingrained in the culture that they're basically public domain. This is something far more weird: on their debut Zeroes QC
column11: Suuns occasionally sounded like Clinic
column12: a band that is still functioning and wholly idiosyncratic
column13: in between extended bouts of electronic
column14: psych-prog freakouts. But here they sound like that band and that band only to the point where it's a protracted game of chicken with the audience-- or Suuns have actually never heard Clinic before in their lives. Otherwise
column15: how could they not notice?

column1: The most overt similarities make it almost impossible to hear anything else-- ""Minor Work"" pretty much rips off Clinic's single most identifiable riff (""The Second Line"") verbatim
column2: and I'm just gonna give people taking Copyright Law this semester a freebie and suggest you place ""Sunspot"" and Walking With Thee's ""Come Into Our Room"" back-to-back. But otherwise
column3: Suuns are just guilty of having the kind of exceptionally good taste that just so happens to be shared by countless other bands. It's clear from the propulsive
column4: linear
column5: and chilly songs of Images Du Futur what makes them tick-- the mechanical pulse of kraut-rock
column6: post-punk's fractured syntax
column7: and unorthodox instrumental techniques
column8: studio trickery owing equally to Radiohead and dub
column9: and overall
column10: the morose
column11: drowsy demeanor of the Velvet Underground. At times
column12: it can be genuinely exciting to hear all of these elements coalesce
column13: especially when given the rhythmic drive that accurately previews their visceral live shows-- opener ""Powers of Ten"" draws out tension between a frantic buzzsaw riff and a heavy drum plod
column14: Ben Shemie's guitars imitate Doppler effects and power drills on ""2020""
column15: and sunlit harmonies peek through the overcast pallor of ""Minor Work"".

column1: And yet
column2: Suuns can never mount the best possible defense to accusations of theft: to add something new to it and prove they're refracting their influences through their own ideals and experience rather than just filtering. As a result
column3: nearly every song on Images Du Futur feels like a bin of used CDs or an mp3 folder rather than a living thing
column4: something to peruse rather than engage. Whether it's the rather not-magnificent ""Holocene City"" or the dreary ""Edie's Dream""
column5: Suuns sound cold when they mean to sound cool
column6: channeling music obsessed with motion but more or less running in place themselves.

column1: Likewise
column2: Shemie doesn't do much to let you in; beyond his half-mutter
column3: half-hiss vocals evoking pitch-perfect Ade Blackburn karaoke
column4: whenever he repeats sentence fragments as a way of sounding urgent
column5: it just sounds like tossing of flavorless word salad
column6: overly plainspoken and cryptic at the same time. You wonder about the message being conveyed by bullishly-titled closer ""Music Won't Save You"" and it just feels like an unintentionally apropos eulogy for a record that disappoints by geeking out over its record collection and effects pedals without offering some kind of emotional center. Pretty much any way you slice it
column7:
Images Du Futur is just too clinical.

German death metal quartet Defeated Sanity have not strayed from their formula on their fourth album
column2: Passages Into Deformity. They're still a hybrid of early Cryptopsy's blinding technicality and Suffocation's NYHC-esque breakdowns-- ""slam parts
column3: to those in the know. There are plenty of bands that attempt this fusion
column4: but few do it with such care and precision. Defeated Sanity have always been stronger than their ""brutal death metal"" peers in part because they do not use either of those elements as a crutch: too much technicality can only hide a lack of songwriting and ideas for so long; slams serve as fun reprieves
column5: but should never be the center of one's sound. Defeated Sanity strike a balance between both
column6: making their product more potent.

column1: On Deformity
column2: they use a much crisper production than on their last album
column3: 2010's Chapters of Repugnance
column4: taking out some of the low end and cleaning up the guitar sound. For their tech side
column5: this is a boon. Christian Kühn's guitar work gets to shine as a result. The slams do suffer a little from the greater absence of bass
column6: but they still pack plenty of heft. Deformity features the same lineup as Repugnance
column7: save for new vocalist Konstantin Lühring
column8: who replaces A.J. Magana. He doesn't sound that much different from his predecessor
column9: just a tinge lower. Band members as interchangable parts has plagued metal for some time
column10: but think of the upside to Lühring's seamless transition. Cryptopsy's biggest strength was their distintive vocalist Lord Worm
column11: and since his two departures from the band
column12: they've never regained their footing. Defeated Sanity don't have to worry about that.

column1: Throughout the record
column2: there are interludes that
column3: while fitting with the macabre feel of the music
column4: are not the sounds you'd normally find on a death metal record. The oddest of them is on ""Verblendung""
column5: capping off with a layer static burying a drum pattern somewhere between Converge at their most experimental and IDM. ""Lusting for Transcendence"" ends with a guitar drone over the sound of someone eating flesh
column6: which is fairly death metal in and of itself. It's also be interesting to see if the piano that caps ""Verses Of Deformity"" could be woven more tightly with the music. The interludes signal a desire
column7: perhaps on the band's part
column8: to want to bring new elements and directions to their sound. One instance of a desire to musically expand does not come from an interlude
column9: in fact
column10: it doesn't come until the album's almost over. The end of ""Martyrium"" (where Magana makes a guest vocal appearance) has drummer Lille Gruber cutting loose and going off on a bit of a freeform jam. For most of the album
column11: he's connected with the guitar
column12: but in this instance
column13: he's on his own tangent
column14: not caring what Kühn does. A whole album of that would be a disaster
column15: but that taste at the end serves as a fitting closer.

column1: Deformity sees the Defeated Sanity at an interesting point in their career. While sticking to their sound
column2: they've making moves that indicate they're ready for bigger things. In some ways
column3: the stage is set: in all of the mainstream music press' more recent fascination with extreme metal
column4:
Wormed-- a Spanish band who are Defeated Sanity's few worthy contemporaries-- being featured on NPR may be the strangest. Perhaps the public is ready for this sort of stuff.

'Loma Vista']|2013-03-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:46.956647|"

Rhye's short history is marked by serendipity and mystery. A couple of years ago
column4: after being tapped by Hannibal's Copenhagen-based electronic group Quadron
column5: producer/vocalist Mike Milosh flew to Denmark to work with the group and they hit it off. Eventually
column6: Quadron producer Robin Hannibal moved to L.A. in pursuit of a woman
column7: and Milosh coincidentally relocated there as well
column8: and started his own serious relationship (which has since evolved into a marriage) before they reconnected musically.

column1: From what Milosh has said
column2: Rhye's primary goal is to pay tribute to this type of world-tilting romantic experience
column3: but so far the pair have delivered their interpretations of this very personal phenomenon from behind a veil of secrecy. They released their first single
column4: ""Open""
column5: anonymously
column6: and promoted it in a deliberately opaque fashion
column7: like a YouTube video of Milosh serenading his wife with a solo piano rendition of the song
column8: shot in a way where you can barely make him out in silhouette. Even after revealing their identities
column9: the pair refuse to say where the group's name comes from or what it means
column10: and their full names don't appear anywhere in the liner notes to their debut album
column11: Woman.

column1: Even without a face to attach it to
column2: Rhye's music itself feels deeply intimate. Much of this comes from Hannibal and Milosh's deft arrangements-- each of Woman's 10 songs makes its point with a bare minimum of moving parts. Beats
column3: basslines
column4: and Milosh's voice are at the center of nearly all of them; although a majority of the tracks boast arrangements for horns and strings
column5: most of these are so subtle that you might not even realize they're there until you read the liner notes afterward. The lean production leaves little space between the listener and the songs
column6: and they feel almost touchably close.

column1: And then of course there's Milosh's voice itself
column2: a gorgeous and graceful countertenor that many listeners have mistaken for a woman's
column3: especially in the days before the group unmasked themselves. He's a subtle performer
column4: but also canny. The restraint that the pair shows in their arrangements also carries over to his singing
column5: which rarely rises above the volume of a conversation. It's gentle
column6: soothing
column7: and easy to get lost in.

column1: That voice has drawn a number of comparisons to Sade
column2: and the music behind it only underlines those similarities. Woman offers few sounds or ways of deploying them that wouldn't be familiar to an R&B fan in the 90s
column3: especially if they were into the British wing of the genre that at the time was focused on making gently bumping
column4: slightly jazzy bedroom music.

column1: And although Milosh is an outspoken critic of what he considers a trend of crass sexualization in pop music
column2: the album still embraces the physical aspects of the romantic experience it intends to glorify. Its sensual aspects may share the same sense of self-control (it's sexy without being overtly sexual
column3: erotic but not lascivious). As well-mannered as its carnal side may be
column4: Woman is bound to become fodder for a tasteful boudoir soundtrack
column5: something to be slotted next to the xx
column6: another band Rhye's been frequently compared to.

column1: The satin-sheets sensuality and Milosh's vocals are impressive enough that they could save an otherwise unremarkable album
column2: but the pair are also gifted songwriters who seem even stronger as a pair than as they did separately. Woman has only one bad song on it
column3: though it should be noted that it's seriously bad: ""One of Those Summer Days"" is boring and hook-free
column4: and it not only dives face-first into the kind of sickly cloying sentimentality that they studiously avoid on the rest of the songs
column5: but does so to the accompaniment of a drippy smooth-jazz alto sax solo.

column1: But a good number of the remaining songs come breathtakingly close to their own kind of perfection
column2: at least close enough that it's hard to imagine how anyone could improve them. ""Open"" may be so derivative of Sade that you may as well call it an homage
column3: but considering that the closest point of comparison would be Sade's ""By Your Side""-- one of the few truly perfect songs in pop history-- that's hardly a complaint. And I'd be surprised if Justin Timberlake and the members of Phoenix aren't holding their new singles up to the lithe
column4: clean-lined modern disco sound of ""The Fall"" and frowning at the results.

column1: Music about happy
column2: successful relationships is always a tougher sell than music about romance gone bad
column3: for the same reason that tragedies are more compelling than stories where everything works out fine for everyone. Bad fortune is naturally fascinating and contentment isn't
column4: and unless you're in a happy
column5: successful relationship you don't want to hear about someone else's. But Woman somehow gets to break those rules
column6:
in large part because the music itself is so easy to fall in love with.

Shlohmo (real name is Henry Laufer) is the flagship artist of Friends of Friends
column3: a label whose artists are making it more and more difficult to distinguish between genres. The producers in FoF's stable draw on every musical ingredient available to them; they source samples and influences from any decade

column5: or style that they're interested in. What's most impressive about what Shlohmo and his peers are doing

column1: Two sections of the Shlohmo's new EP
column2: Laid Out
column3: have an uncanny catchiness. The first is from the single ""Don't Say No""
column4: featuring Tom Krell of How to Dress Well singing in his most desperate falsetto. The other sticky section is the loop from the best track on the EP
column5: ""Out of Hand"". There's an obvious difference between the two: one features a singer emoting as best he can
column6: with provocative
column7: romantic lyrics. The other has just the ghost of a vocal

column1: ""Later"" the six-minute centerpiece of the album is similar to ""Out of Hand"" with its looped
column2: anguished vocal sample. Only here
column3: the voice is blurred beyond the point of recognition. The track doesn't have the same kind of grab as its predecessors (perhaps because the repeating loop is less recognizable as a human voice)
column4: but it's equally intense
column5: with waxing and waning drum machines that surround and heighten that go-for-broke sample.

column1: Laufer's last project
column2: the Vacation EP
column3: played around with these kinds of melodies and samples
column4: but that record largely avoided pop leanings. It was withdrawn
column5: soft
column6: pretty
column7: akin to Nicolas Jaar's debut Space is Only Noise or to Teebs' Ardour. And while it was solid
column8: Vacation was made for people who were already comfortable listening to electronic music. The first three tracks on Laid Out have far more ambition: they're meant to pull in pop and R&B listeners who might not otherwise be drawn towards electronic music.

column1: The last two songs on the EP
column2: ""Put It"" and ""Without""
column3: hold more back and function almost as sketches of the songs that come before them. Each has an instrumental through-line that one can imagine being replaced by a stronger sample. They're smart and well-constructed but they can seem out of place
column4: and dwarfed by what came before. Still
column5:
those first three: Shlohmo's already one of the better producers of his young generation and Laid Out should add substantially to his growing reputation.

Josh Ritter is a big picture kind of songwriter. Eschewing the confessional approach along with overtly personal lyrics
column2: his last two albums were less about himself and more about all of America all at once
column3: as though Ritter were reconstructing John Banvard's panoramic trip down the Mississippi. The Historical Conquests of Josh Ritter and So Runs the World Away boast ambitious feats of songwriting and composition
column4: yet his craft often undercut rather than underscored his headiest insights. The music sounded too composed: too predetermined
column5: too polite to adequately depict the chaos and sheer weirdness of history. It makes sense that his best work to date isn't an album or a song

column7: Bright's Passage
column8: which blended history and fantasy
column9: grand tragedy and life pre- and post-WWI into imaginative literary fiction.

column1: For his seventh full-length
column2: Ritter has abandoned the broad canvas of history. The Beast in Its Tracks is his most ostensibly personal album to date
column3: smaller in scope yet deeper in detail than anything he's done yet. Technically
column4: it's a break-up album
column5: inspired by his divorce from singer-songwriter Dawn Landes. But that label implies messy emotions
column6: lives upended
column7: dishes thrown. Ritter's songs are less about recrimination than recovery. In a letter to fans
column8: he explains that his first songs as an ex-husband were too bitter to record

column15: too.""

column1: That distance has its advantages and disadvantages. On the plus side
column2: it allows Ritter a big-picture perspective: the past as a landscape he has traversed and can see more clearly from this peak. Beast is contemplative and forgiving
column3: a means of burying one relationship to commit to another
column4: and Ritter nicely evokes the excitement and resignation of such a transition. On the other hand
column5: distance is distance
column6: and much of the album is too cool
column7: too levelheaded
column8: too past tense. The spry pace and playful melody of ""Nightmares"" distract from the horrors described in the lyrics
column9: as such nightmares are safely over. The best moments are the rawest and least guarded
column10: when the pain and regret sound inescapably present tense: when he laughs off his insomnia on ""Evil Eye""
column11: when he notices similarities between his new lover and his old wife on ""A Certain Light""
column12: when he finally allows himself to enjoy a bit of happiness on ""Joy to You Baby"".

column1: The Beast in Its Tracks forgoes the expansive arrangements of Ritter's previous albums in favor of scaled-back arrangements that emphasize a few instruments interacting directly with each other. The songs build patiently
column2: allowing repeating musical themes to mirror persistent lyrical themes. ""Hopeful""
column3: the album's highlight
column4: opens with a spare acoustic strum
column5: then builds from the ground up: a simple drumbeat
column6: a simple electric guitar pendulum
column7: a one-note piano theme. The effect
column8: however
column9: is surprisingly sophisticated. On that song as well as on ""Bonfire""
column10: Ritter rushes his delivery
column11: packing the measures with as many words as he can. There's a new
column12: anxious energy to his vocals
column13: which gives the sense that he's trying to get his thoughts out before they grow cold or before he loses his nerve. It's an effective and illuminating technique
column14:
revealing just how much divorce and recovery have changed Ritter: He seems to understand that all those mixed emotions can't be so easily fit to music.

In the handful of years they've been making music together as Javelin
column3: pop collagists (and real life cousins) George Langford and Tom Van Buskirk have never been afraid to push their luck. With their irreverently fun

column7: Tiger Beat
column8: and Wire magazines. But instead of remaining content with merely kicking out more jamz

column1: Much of Hi Beams is means to translate as outsized fun

column3: dumb grins

""Nnormal"" (a baffling choice for a first single) fancies itself as some sort of warped brand of robot rock but comes off like a companion piece to ""Nothing Ever Happens On Mars"". Worse is ""Judgement Night""
column5: which interrupts a cheesed-out interpolation of Peter Gabriel gone ratchet with giant squalls of jock-metal guitar (to its credit

column7: but rather either unappealingly cheeky (""Friending""
column8: ""Drummachines"") or blandly earnest (""Light Out""

column1: The takeaways here are slight
column2: but still evident thanks to their years spent sample-mining. Langford and Van Buskirk have good ears

column4: crisp hand claps

column6: the Mark Mothersbaugh-checking snippet ""Garth Hudson""

column9: a suite from a Wes Anderson movie that hit the editing-room-floor

it results in little more than a fitful stomach ache. But the real disappointment lies in the sense that Javelin decided now was the time to quit horsing around and become a ""real band."" What they lost sight of in turn was the fact that they already had a pretty damn good one to begin with.

London-based Midwesterner and electronic music artist Karen Gwyer deals in abridged thoughts
column2: often setting ideas in motion with barely any sense of form brought in to shape them. The intrinsic openness of her work differs rather strongly from Gwyer's recording process for the new album
column3: which was undertaken in a great creative outpouring in the months leading up to the birth of her first child. Such rigorous circumstances haven't led to a work of great conceptual heft. Instead
column4: Needs Continuum feels more like a gathering of sketches

column1: The bulk of Needs Continuum is shorn of traditional vocals
column2: with hums and sighs occasionally buried in the mix. ""Pikku Kokki"" includes the album's only recognizable vocal
column3: delivered in a series of whispered lines. Elsewhere
column4: Gwyer uses her voice as an extra layer of instrumentation
column5: simply letting spectral coos drift across tracks such as ""Night Nails"" and ""Plan B"". It’s a trick that works reasonably well
column6: but it adds to a sense of hesitance and
column7: at times
column8: a lack of confidence about the project
column9: especially coming off the back of that debut EP released in an edition of 13 copies. It makes Gwyer’s work feel like a secret that she’s reluctant to share
column10: constructed in a place so private that she’s wary of letting anyone in. Perhaps such reticence is understandable considering the circumstances in which the record was made
column11: especially as she has talked of wanting to make something that ""measured up to the significance of the start of a new life"". Occasionally she does approach such peaks. The coupling of the beautifully vacillating ""Waukon"" with the sobering ""Jajja Uses Ancestral Spirit"" is where the album reaches its apex.

column1: This isn't a cohesive work by any means: There's a demo-y feeling to some of the pieces
column2: coupled with a sense that this is an album with a decent amount of inspiration but just lacking in execution. Perhaps that's to be expected-- after all
column3: Gwyer was working under extreme circumstances. It doesn't feel like it would take a great shift to give her work the kind of gravitas that Julianna Barwick's music often possesses
column4: and the two certainly share a fondness for diaphanous vocal pining. There's plenty of potential in the electronics here
column5: too
column6: particularly when they form into the kind of supple globules that Daniel Lopatin constructed under his Oneohtrix Point Never guise around the time of Returnal. Gwyer's not there yet
column7:
but Needs Continuum contains some satisfyingly oblique turns.

Trevor Powers doesn't come off as older and wiser than his 23 years: just look at any picture of him
column2: with his slight build and cherubic mop of curls
column3: or take one listen to his nasal
column4: keening voice. Likewise
column5: his heartfelt 2011 debut The Year of Hibernation dealt more in truth and honesty than profundity or authority
column6: skirting cliché while affecting people in meaningful ways. These qualities are about the only things that haven't changed for Youth Lagoon on Wondrous Bughouse. This record broadens Powers' musical and lyrical scope into something universal in a literal and figurative sense
column7: evoking the cosmos
column8: heaven
column9: and hell. But Powers sounds curious and awestruck rather than naïve
column10: someone who explores this lush and frightening soundworld instead of explaining it.

column1: The cosmetic changes are obvious. If you've been paying attention to sonics over the past couple of years
column2: you'll recognize the saturated
column3: bottom-heavy production as that of Ben H. Allen. After hearing Allen give a subwoofer shape-up to previously brittle bands like Deerhunter
column4: Animal Collective
column5: and Washed Out
column6: the pairing seems almost inevitable. But while the production is an upgrade
column7: the real growth is thematic. Hibernation obsessed over escape and became defined by its limitations
column8: whether it was its meager recording budget or just the sense that Powers felt trapped by his surroundings in Boise. But Bughouse looks inward and discovers the endless possibilities of imagination and introspection.

column1: Youth Lagoon is still very much an internally-focused project and
column2: with its abundance of effect pedals and stereo panning tricks
column3: Wondrous Bughouse will likely be branded as a headphones album. Don't believe it. As with Hibernation
column4: this is a record that's meant to be cranked as loud as possible; for one
column5: volume decompresses these thick songs
column6: amplifying the crucial addition of live drums on ""Raspberry Cane"" and ""Mute"". More importantly
column7: Wondrous Bughouse needs room to breathe from a songwriting standpoint. With Powers' lyrics and Allen's production striving to create a celestial whole
column8: Bughouse is meant to conjure infinite space.

column1: This much is conveyed by the sonar blips that take up the three-minute opener ""Through Mind and Back"" before fading into the spellbinding ""Mute"". Nearly every song on Hibernation began quietly
column2: so it's jarring to hear Youth Lagoon take a more widescreen turn-- echoing drums
column3: gleaming peals of delayed guitar
column4: all washed by ocean spray reverb. This lasts for one minute before a detuned loop of bells recasts ""Mute"" as a juggernaut
column5: a steady
column6: booming drum beat framing a strident vocal performance from Powers
column7: a guitar solo that recalls Doug Martsch's expressive
column8: longing leads
column9: a minor-key piano loop that appears ready to take the song to a completely different plateau before cruelly cutting out.

column1: These songs are all bigger and bolder without being unnecessarily complicated. While Powers' melodies are simple and immediately memorable like nursery rhymes
column2: everything surrounding him is in flux. The songs on Wondrous Bughouse are continually subjected to flange and phase effects
column3: and it's not the gentle
column4: headswimming ""whoosh"" that typified recent records such as Lonerism or mbv. The cranked oscillation gives these songs a proper sense of danger and hyper-alertness. The combination of the processing and Powers' devious lyrics (""'I won't die easily'/ That's what they say when I erupt into laughter"") gives the calliope-like melody of ""Attic Doctor"" a fitting
column5: monstrous overtone. The synth progression that emerges during the anthropomorphic grotesquerie ""Pelican Man"" would be a perfect evocation of Elephant 6's Beatles obsession
column6: but the pulsing modulations turn into something closer to slasher-flick fare.

column1: It's often scary stuff
column2: more reminiscent of Syd Barrett's bad-trip fairy tales. Though Powers isn't dealing with death in a manner that conveys gravitas or experience
column3: Wondrous Bughouse is very much about mortality
column4: albeit filtered through surrealism
column5: parable
column6: and metaphor. Rather than a simple longing for the past
column7: Powers feels obsessed with human frailty and decay. Similarly
column8: the songs of Bughouse aren't subject to tangents so much as following a dream logic working where any thought
column9: regardless of how awesome or fearsome it is
column10: doesn't end until it reaches a conclusion it sees fit.

column1: Powers' choice to write most of these fanciful flights in waltz time gives everything a properly anachronistic feel. The hopscotch melody on ""Dropla"" makes it sound like a playground chant and the lyrics see its narrator dealing with death in a selfish
column2: forgivably childlike way
column3: hanging on to faint hope (""you'll never die
column4: you'll never die"") and lashing out when the prayers go unanswered (""you weren't there when I needed""). Between the threatening taunts of ""Attic Doctor""
column5: we hear vast stretches of music for the Peanuts gang to ice skate to: ""Third Dystopia"" refracts a sea shanty through multiple funhouse mirrors; the submerged second half of ""The Bath"" places Powers somewhere between a baptism and a drowning. On ""Raspberry Cane""
column6: Powers sees himself as irredeemable (""I'm polluted by my blood/ So help me cut it out and rinse it down the drain"") and while closer ""Daisyphobia"" views humanity as ""mortals on the run"" from an all-seeing God
column7: Wondrous Bughouse slinks towards an disturbing and unresolved conclusion
column8: a slow fade of distant synth whinnies and stumbling
column9: inexact beats.

column1: Though unnerving
column2: it is familiar
column3: albeit in a style of indie rock that was prominent when Powers was
column4: by his own admission
column5: listening to Bad Boy records Allen might've played a part in. Think of the Flaming Lips
column6: Mercury Rev
column7: Grandaddy
column8: Sparklehorse
column9: Modest Mouse
column10: Built To Spill
column11: all bands who in some way combined a projected naivety with grand designs: adolescent vocals picking at metaphysical mysteries
column12: an insatiable curiosity with the capabilities of the studio. But Youth Lagoon is also a spiritual progeny in terms of geography. All these bands emerged far from media centers-- Oklahoma City
column13: upstate New York
column14: Modesto
column15: central Virginia
column16: Issaquah
column17: Wash.
column18: and of course
column19: Powers' own Boise. Listeners often try to discern something special about creating art in places like these
column20: whether the scarcity of live shows and bands makes music more important or a lack of urban stimuli allows for deeper meditation on the big picture. Though the songs themselves are wonderful
column21: that's the powerful source Powers taps into here: if you feel like the dark center of the universe or simply need a little space
