Gold Panda arrived on the scene in fine style with 2009's ""Quitter's Raga"". As a statement of intent it sat comfortably with many of the preoccupations of the time
column2: mixing hazy nostalgia with the dancefloor-referencing electronic pop of Mount Kimbie. Even ignoring its timeliness
column3: the project's debut is a gem
column4: a stuttering
column5: maximalist joy-overload
column6: infectious in its naivety. A handful of further tracks followed
column7: cementing an aesthetic that was placeless
column8: both in its stylistic touchstones and its persistent use of non-Western samples
column9: but also intimate in its homespun feel
column10: its imperfections and its repeated references to loved ones and missed places. While far from ground-breaking-- the twin forks of his family tree stretch back at least as far as Four Tet and J Dilla-- his dusty aesthetic was singular and tremendously easy to love.

column1: An album
column2: Lucky Shiner
column3: followed on Ghostly International in 2010. It was a solid if not stunning debut
column4: falling short only next to the the considerable promise of Gold Panda's earliest output. Comparisons to the twinkly sample-scapes of Four Tet and the Field's gauzy techno became perhaps a little too pertinent
column5: and in streamlining his sound Gold Panda seemed
column6: slightly
column7: to dull its charms. In the wake of the album the producer's momentum appeared to falter. His 2011 DJ Kicks mix rummaged through an array of contemporary electronica but failed to come up with a statement of particular coherence. The original Gold Panda productions accompanying the mix
column8: meanwhile
column9: were among his most polished work to date
column10: exploring glistening melodic techno in the Border Community vein. Looking back over the past four years
column11: there's no doubt that he has refined his process. His shepherding of samples has become more assured
column12: and their edges are often smoother these days
column13: all the better to slot into a coherent whole. But with that refinement has come a mounting sense that the mild anarchy of those early recordings was a large part of their appeal.

column1: The Trust EP is a case in point. Across its four tracks
column2: he explores familiar themes
column3: but with diminishing returns. The intro
column4: a foggy
column5: submerged drone
column6: is the most confrontational thing here
column7: though at barely a minute long
column8: it functions as little more than a palette-cleanser. The title track
column9: meanwhile
column10: sees him at his most relaxed
column11: its melodies nestled snugly in a slow-mo house framework. ""Burnt Out Car In a Forest"" draws on much the same sonic toolbox-- particularly the bell-like tones
column12: themselves dangerously reminiscent of Four Tet-- though in a more energetic setting. Flurries of claps and hi-hats give the impression of density
column13: but where previously he might have inundated the track with melodic content
column14: here his repitched sample-melodies do the bare minimum.

column1: The downtempo ""Casyam_59#02""
column2: finally
column3: is the outlier. It's more melodically forthright than its companions
column4: but there's still a disappointingly maudlin quality to the way it unfolds. The fact is that for music like Gold Panda's to function-- music that trades in a kind of heartfelt
column5: familial warmth-- you need to believe it utterly
column6: be swept up by its strength of feeling. It's all too easy
column7: otherwise
column8: to read it as a succession of empty platitudes
column9:
a sort of limp unending niceness that gestures at profundity without ever quite getting a grip on the heartstrings.

In 2010
column2: Raphaelle Standell-Preston and Alexander Cowan spent a couple of months wandering around Central America
column3: and when they came back they made an EP that sounded like an uncommonly lyrical ""How I Spent My Summer Vacation"" essay: eight songs of humid
column4: sun-kissed
column5: heart-on-its-cut-off-sleeve electro-pop. Of course
column6: Blue Hawaii was not the only band on the beach in 2010
column7: but Blooming Summer managed to sound like something unique. Standell-Preston's voice moved through these songs like a jellyfish
column8: tumbling with such grace that its sudden sting came as a surprise. ""I think about you thrusting into her
column9: she sang on the best song ""Blue Gowns""
column10: her voice full of anguished jealousy and self-reproach
column11: ""And I ask myself
column12: how stupid can you get?"" Blooming Summer captured the joys and fears of a new relationship (Standell-Preston and Cowan are a couple) with careful precision
column13: but it also felt unassumingly excellent. Blooming Summer had a quiet release on then-very-niche label Arbutus; you can still download it on their Bandcamp for $1. Standell-Preston became better known for fronting the more guitar-driven band Braids
column14: while Blue Hawaii seemed destined to be a side project little known to people outside the couple's friends in the Montreal DIY scene. Then
column15: of course
column16: that scene blew up.

column1: Sudden
column2: international attention is sometimes enough to make a tight-knit regional scene implode
column3: but in the past few months a few other artists have risen to the occasion and started to fill out the spotlight that Grimes has shone on her home scene Montreal. Doldrums
column4: the scrappy
column5: sample-heavy project from junkyard dreamer Airick Woodhead
column6: stepped up with Lesser Evil
column7: a full-length debut full of soaring
column8: dystopian party anthems
column9: while brooding duo Majical Cloudz recently made the leap from Arbutus to indie-giant Matador on the heels of a strong
column10: idea-packed EP. But there's a downside to this kind of opportunity; people move on.  ""As friends grow past the Montreal scene and leave
column11: there's a kind of falling apart there
column12: ” Cowan said in a recent FADER interview. When you listen to Blue Hawaii's first proper full-length
column13: Untogether
column14: this comment feels not like a diss to anybody in particular so much as a creative statement of purpose; it contextualizes the themes of disconnect
column15: alienation and independence that coarse through Untogether. As Standell-Preston put it
column16: ""I think [making the record] was an attempt to find the glue as everything was drifting apart.""

column1: She was actually talking about her partnership with Cowan as much as her hometown. (Well
column2: creatively speaking
column3: not romantically-- they're still together.) In the three years since the cohesive Blooming Summer
column4: they’ve ventured down slightly separate paths: Standell-Preston's taken a more new-agey route (experimenting with avant-garde make-up in performance; making small-talk about chakras in interviews) while Cowan spent some time absorbing EDM culture in Europe. But
column5: true to its title
column6: Untogether is less interested in blending all its competing enthusiasms together and more intent on emphasizing the space that separates them-- in that way at least
column7: it's kind of the anti-Visions. Standell-Preston's vocals are routinely snipped
column8: chopped and pasted back together like ransom notes
column9: while Cowan steers the tracks with underlying trancelike rhythms. Untogether sometimes feels like a reaction against Blooming Summer's easy
column10: inviting pop pleasures-- which is not necessarily a bad thing. At its most evocative
column11: Untogether creates the eerie feeling of being the only person in a cavernous
column12: strobe-lit club. Take the awesome two-part highlight ""In Two""-- where the atmosphere's so diffuse and desolate that even a sudden intrusion of handclaps doesn't  feel like a moment of collectivity or unity. Instead
column13: it only emphasizes the feeling of isolation: the claps sound distant
column14: drifted in
column15: and possibly made by ghosts.

column1: ""The other day
column2: I had a beautiful thought
column3: Standell-Preston sings on the closing track
column4: ""The Other Day""
column5: and then lets loose the most elegant-sounding DGAF in recent memory
column6: ""What if I didn’t care at all?"" It's a freeing moment-- unclasping the pressures of the scene
column7: the stress of communicating with another person
column8: and all the other anxieties that have pulsed beneath the 10 songs that came before it. It's also a much-needed moment of repose. The problem with Untogether is that that Blue Hawaii occasionally get carried away with emphasizing and embracing disjointedness. Cowan's fingers are a little trigger happy
column9: and so the subdued
column10: gradually unfurling beauty of ""The Other Day"" hints at what might have happened had they given some of these songs a little more breathing room. Like the haunting single ""Try To Be""
column11:
""Day"" feels like a moment of both restraint and unity-- Cowan's rippling arpeggios compliment (rather than interrupt) Standell-Preston's crystalline vocals. Blue Hawaii still bloom most vividly when they're working together.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18869/homepage_large.bf4713af.jpg|Hymnal|5012.0|Benoît Pioulard|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2013-03-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:00:52.934154|"

There's something very rundown about the music Thomas Meluch makes under his Benoît Pioulard alias. Not just in its emotional content-- although there are plenty of allusions to shattered dreams and ruined love-- but also in the way it's executed. He's never really moved beyond a preference for dust-caked tape recordings
column2: often causing him to come across as a doomed romantic slowly disappearing into his own reflection. It's an illusion
column3: of course
column4: but one that Meluch has become truly accomplished in executing. Hymnal sees him walking along a familiar faultline
column5: but like his prior albums
column6: particularly the exemplary Lasted
column7: there are a few new crevices to explore. In particular
column8: this record was inspired by Meluch taking up residency in the southeast of England
column9: and his resultant exploration of the religious iconography he discovered both there and on mainland Europe. It lends Hymnal a ceremonial air
column10: culminating in an imposing instrumental drone piece that blackens the center of the album.

column1: In 2011 Meluch put out a release for Desire Path titled Plays Thelma
column2: mostly based around beatless drone pieces. It opened up a strain of thought this record occasionally capitalizes on
column3: particularly when he dips into work such as the barely existent ""Censer"". But that's only half the story
column4: as Meluch can't resist returning to the kind of fine-spun emoting he's better known for
column5: splitting Hymnal somewhere between campfire warmth and ice-cold shivers. It's a combination that may sound jarring
column6: but ends up working quite seamlessly with his firm hand moving all the parts into place. Meluch can even get away with tying a Simon & Garfunkel glow to Robert Kirby-inspired strings on ""Litiya""
column7: and then segueing the whole composition into an actual recording of church bells on the following ""Knell"". The latter is his most literal nod toward the religious emblems that inspired him. Elsewhere it's deployed with greater subtlety
column8: such as the ecclesiastical air that floods into the echoing passages of ""Florid"".

column1: The air of disquiet that seeps in forms loose ties between Hymnal and other recent artists who've explored the inherent creepiness in the rolling hills of the English countryside. This album doesn't share many aesthetic ties with Julian House's work in the Focus Group
column2: but it does share a sense of things not quite being right
column3: of an ostensibly idyllic place suddenly revealing danger. Pitchfork's Larry Fitzmaurice discussed the resemblance of Meluch's work to ""aged film footage"" in his review of Lasted; here it's often reminiscent of an old Public Information Film
column4: depicting the entire world as a place loaded with potentially lethal mishaps at every turn. It's there in the eerie piano runs of ""Homily"" and it's there in the wonky tape intros that beckon in ""Excave"" and ""Margin"". Meluch heightens the tension by stacking these tracks up against sunnier fare like ""Hawkeye"" and the Elliott Smith homage of ""Reliquary""
column5: lulling you into a false sense of security before pockmarking you in goosebumps.

column1: Hymnal is most definitely the type of album that has a centerpiece around which the rest of the album flows
column2: and when it comes-- titled ""Gospel""
column3: strategically placed as the sixth out of 12 tracks-- it looms over everything that comes before and after. It's an instrumental work
column4: and one that most deeply evokes the record's stated inspirations. ""Gospel"" again triggers strong visual cues
column5: with drones stretching out like mist hugging the ground
column6: decaying fingers prodding at keys to provide the track's brittle organ grind
column7: a field recording of birds soaring into the sky to provide a form of release at its end. Certainly it's tempting to conclude that a whole album of this stuff would elevate Hymnal beyond Meluch's other works
column8: although its rare power is at least partially derived from its standalone nature. Instead
column9: it takes its place amid a spattering of welcome deviations that exist here
column10:
all lodged in a subtly different type of ruin.

column4: the hoarse rasps are out of place; Horna's former vocalists favored a higher

column7: though
column8: his vocals become an obvious asset: harsh

column10: and imbued with manic intensity. His masterful performance on ""Aamutähden Pyhimys"" alone makes it clear that
column11: allegiances to Corvus or Nazgul notwithstanding

column1: Horna's twin trademarks are a reverence for black metal's Second Wave and deft utilization of melody within their pitch-black compositions. Shades of early Mayhem

column9: offers a good example: It's constructed around an icy chord progression
column10: graced by an especially unhinged vocal performance from Spellgoth
column11: and rides out on one of those hypnotic mid-paced dirge Horna do so well. The production is as raw and ragged as one would hope-- buried by time and dust
column12: without the wet cardboard drumming or lo-fi crackles.

column1: All in all
column2: Horna have once more delivered what they do best
column3: a Horna record
column4: and a solid one at that. They aren't rewriting the book
column5: but Spellgoth's vocals are reason enough to give it a listen
column6:
and the very fact that black metal like this is still being written and released in 2013 is heartening.

While it's tempting to connect Sally Shapiro's reticent persona to her fragile
column3: vanishing music-- supposedly she’s too shy to perform on stage or let producer Johan Agebjörn join her in the studio-- it's a red herring; some of music's most extroverted voices belong to reclusive singers
column4: and her albums from Disco Romance on down are just as easily explained as the product of a ghost-girl persona as that of a Giorgio Moroder fan getting really into Tigermilk one night.

column1: Somewhere Else isn't quite a departure from Sally Shapiro's last two albums
column2: but in among the sequencers and identikit drums are instruments from a more muted palette: flute
column3: saxophone
column4: and beats that skitter rather than shimmer. The evolution was probably inevitable. The influence of Belle and Sebastian has long been palpable on Shapiro's work
column5: and plying feathery vocals over disco is a gimmick that can't work forever; she and Agebjörn have often cited Italo divas Katy Gray and Valerie Dore as inspirations
column6: but theirs is a genre is full of one-hit wonders. Gray
column7: for instance
column8: only had the one song. By Shapiro's second album
column9: 2009's My Guilty Pleasure

column1: There's enough here that sounds of a piece with her last two records. The effervescent ""All My Life"" and ""If it Doesn't Rain"" soar like lost Disco Romance tracks
column2: and the title of ""This City's Local Italo Disco DJ Has a Crush on Me"" certainly fits. Those songs were done solo-- much of Somewhere Else is farmed out to outside producers
column3: another new development. They're either artists reprising their roles from Agebjörn's solo-ish album Casablanca Nights (which had enough Sally Shapiro tracks that it was basically Disco Romance 2.5)

column5: like the Drive soundtrack-boosted Electric Youth.

column1: As on Casablanca Nights
column2: the returns vary. Lead track ""I Dream with an Angel Tonight"" seems like Shapiro's normal fare-- boy meets girl
column3: girl comes to love boy
column4: boy was never meant for girl
column5: who realizes this on the dancefloor-- until the track concludes in the musical equivalent of a sigh. At least the quiet-breakup track ""Sundown"" brings a foregrounded sax solo out of nowhere
column6: which eventually comes to mimic Shapiro's voice
column7: a neat trick. ""What Can I Do""
column8: meanwhile
column9: is your common or garden twee pop song. If you heard it in isolation
column10: you'd never guess its singer once put out an album called Disco Romance.

column1: Le Prix collaboration ""Architectured Love"" is fittingly titled
column2: chilly and gorgeous as an ice palace. The New Wave-y ""Don't Be Afraid"" first appeared on French producer Anoraak's solo debut Wherever the Sun Sets

column6:
and only goes to show that the disco romance formula is both harder to pull off and more singular than you'd think.

As I've listened to the debut EP from Cyclopean
column3: I've pondered the many meanings of the word they chose for their name
column4: trying to figure out which one best fits the music. There's not one that really works. Where a Cyclops has just one eye
column5: and therefore no stereoscopic vision
column6: this music makes expansive use of the stereo field and the depth afforded by modern recording; where the cyclopean masonry of Mycenae is characterized by large
column7: unwieldy stones organized in non-regular patterns
column8: this is disciplined
column9: orderly music with a steady pulse. Really
column10: there's nothing big
column11: unwieldy
column12: lumbering
column13: slow
column14: fiery-tempered
column15: or depthless about it. Perhaps they were referring to a cyclopean image
column16: which is what the brain makes from the two inputs it receives from the eyes-- these four players do
column17: after all
column18: meld quite seamlessly into a unit.

column1: The four in question
column2: Irmin Schmidt
column3: Jaki Liebezeit
column4: Jono Podmore
column5: and Burnt Friedman
column6: have history together. Only Friedman and Podmore have never collaborated before
column7: and Schmidt and Liebezeit are of course two of the founding members of Can
column8: one of the greatest art-rock bands ever. If there's a single
column9: crucial thing they've brought with them from that band into this one

column11: none of the musicians here ever hogs the spotlight. Schmidt's keyboard washes in particular are a bit like air
column12: something you hardly notice but that you wouldn't be able to breathe without; they're essentially the sonic glue of the record

column1: There was a time when instrumental music like this might have been called experimental
column2: but these musicians are a bit past the experimenting
column3: and have moved into a phase of sonic mastery. They use prepared piano for the main melody of ""Fingers""
column4: but they do it without calling attention to it
column5: and the rubber band guitar that pops up here and there is played a little like a Persian tar
column6: providing little figures that swirl in the corners of the rhythm track like dust bunnies stirred by the breeze.

column1: These details and subtleties of sound are the main things that draw me back to Cyclopean-- these are songs that are far more about learning than feeling. They're played with skill and precision
column2:
and the sound is close to Bark Psychosis' Hex without the emotional anchor of the human voice-- it's that last part that keeps Cyclopean from being a record for more than just fans of the band members and their aesthetic vision. The overall effect of EP is like watching time-lapse video of weather systems or solar flares-- your awe at the complexity of it and the immense energy embodied in the events is tempered by the remoteness of what you're seeing.

Pitchfork's Brian Howe provided a useful overview of Hans-Joachim Roedelius in his review of Qluster's Lauschen
column5: noting how prolific the krautrock elder statesman has been in his career. The paint has barely dried on Lauschen
column6: but another full-length album from Roedelius has already surfaced
column7: this time in the form of a collaboration with bookish singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole. Initially it feels like an absurd pairing
column8: with little common ground to be found between Cole's snappy
column9: literate guitar rock and his new partner's fondness for expansive electronic introspection. The duo have spent most of their careers orbiting completely different spheres. But in 2001 Cole released a solo album named Plastic Wood
column10: a record of delicately spun ambient tracks that owed a debt to Roedelius's output in Cluster. The pair subsequently corresponded
column11: met in person
column12: and plotted Selected Studies Vol. 1 by exchanging files online. If you're an artist contemplating work within a discrete electronic framework
column13: as Cole has been inclined
column14:
it helps to have one of the all-time greats on board as a collaborator.

This is an album firmly embedded in Roedelius's world. There are no vocals
column15: nothing that resembles a guitar sound
column16: no devotion to pop or rock structure. It's not clear who did what
column17: although it's tempting to cast Cole as a student learning from a master of the genre. To do so wouldn't be entirely fair. Plastic Wood demonstrated Cole's understanding of this type of work
column18: even if it did meander into aimless drift at times. That's a key difference between Cluster and many of the acts that use them as a starting point-- they never coasted
column19: always looked for new sounds
column20: constantly stretched at boundaries. There's a sense of adventure to Roedelius that he hasn't lost at the age of 78. Like Lauschen
column21: this isn’t an essential document in his career
column22: but it is a further example of him working in tandem with someone to help reshape his putty-like template. There's a sense of another mission accomplished by the time they reach the otherworldly music box feel of the closing ""Lullerby""
column23:
a sense that Roedelius has planted flags in some small new areas that were awaiting his discovery.

There are two types of mood that Selected Studies dips into
column24: both carrying just enough thematic ties to make the album gel as a whole. The first type is full of sparse
column26: rendered with minimal instrumentation to maximize the feel of broody deliberation. These tracks take the form of the seasick ""Wandelbar""
column27: the trickling piano runs of the Eno-like ""Still Life With Kannyu""
column28: and the barely-there ""Orschel"". It's the kind of overcast place you'd expect to find Roedelius
column29: and also a place that will be familiar to anyone who has heard Cole's prior ambient work. The other type of mood has a little more meat on the bone
column30: lending a sense of misery filling out and bubbling over. ""HIQS"" is all unsettling machine noise
column31: resembling a creaky engine room dangerously sputtering to the end of its existence. ""Pastoral"" takes a less severe route
column32: letting waves of serene sound simply overlap and fade away. Best of all is ""Fehmarn F/O
column33: which is driven by piercing synth lines that sound like their maker is barely in control of the machinery
column34:
adding a welcome dose of bedlam that touches on the kind of anarchy Add N to (X) liked to set in motion.

It's hard to escape the feeling that this is a very self-referential album for Roedelius to make
column35: especially as one of its tracks (""Selbstportrait-Reich"") partially takes its name from a series of solo albums he has put out over the years. Naturally
column36: it's one of the best pieces on here
column37: layering Moog twists over a minimalist backing that never really goes anywhere and never really needs to. It's particularly impressive that Cole can work so effectively in such an area
column38: especially when his best work (""Perfect Skin""
column41: essentially) is so in thrall to coupling classic
column42: sweeping pop moves with pithy wordplay. It leaves Selected Studies in an odd place
column43: one that doesn't feel like any kind of stretch for one of its participants
column44: but is quite the opposite for the other. Still
column45: that sense of tension doesn't transpire in the recordings
column46: which ultimately fall a little too far inside Roedelius's comfort zone to be truly remarkable. But he again shows a mastery over that space
column47:
where even the smaller steps in his journey end up pointing in the right direction despite not always taking the most logical turns.

The title of the latest collaboration between brothers Wolfgang and Reinhard Voigt translates as ""The Magical World of Others"". It fits in a sense: Die zauberhafte Welt der Anderen is less the straightforward collection of minimal techno that you might expect from the pair's individual catalogs than an hour-long immersion into a universe that the Voigts have been building for ages
column2: but only occasionally allow outsiders inside.

column1: It's a world with its own unique dynamic. The tracks don't present themselves up front
column2: but rather unspool without hurry
column3: changing shape dramatically in the process. ""Intro König"" opens with droning
column4: electronically generated textures
column5: then layers on lush
column6: spookily dissonant strings before suddenly transforming into a strangely psychedelic house track piled with backwards guitar loops
column7: a barking dog
column8: and weird
column9: unidentifiable amusical sounds flickering across the spectrum. The ambiguous Eastern drone that makes up the two-minute-long ""Akira"" reappears at the end of the album in the form of the 26-minute ""Akira Mantra"".

column1: Throughout the LP there are repeated vague hints that the Voigt brothers' world has some sort of storyline running through it
column2: like we're hearing the score to a film that only exists in their shared imagination. Near its end
column3: the Euroclubby ""Hotel Noki"" breaks down into twinkling piano and a recording of someone pulling up on a motorcycle
column4: then pulling away again. If there's not a narrative element to the song
column5: the Voigts are very cleverly messing with our heads by strongly implying that there is.

column1: A narrative would help explain some of the odder choices that the pair makes throughout the album. Even after spending half the record making it clear that they intended to stretch outside of their usual aesthetic territoriy
column2: with tracks that reference industrial music
column3: hard rock
column4: and even a little bit of blues
column5: the mid-album detour into electronic smooth jazz on ""Sozial"" (complete with flute solo) is a jarring surprise. The dissonant drone that enters part-way through the song to add a hint of menace to the schmaltz makes it a weirdly discomfiting listen.

column1: That discomfort
column2: and wondering why the Voigts would want to unsettle their listeners with such a sinister track
column3: are intriguing. ""Sozial"" would be perfect as the soundtrack to a particularly sleazy scene in a David Lynch movie
column4: but otherwise I can't think of a good reason to spend several minutes listening to malefic electro smooth jazz. There are a few other missteps: A couple of tracks offer the tasteful
column5: Germanic approach to house music that's generally associated with the lobbies of boutique hotels. And ""Akira Mantra"" is 26 minutes of just one loop that never seems to evolve in any way
column6: which isn't meditative but maddening.

column1: It's not all bad
column2: though. ""Der Keil NRW"" has the glossy black sheen of an 80s John Carpenter soundtrack. The plump synthesizers and Teutonically rigid rhythm of ""Triplychon Nummer 7"" are pleasantly reminiscent of vintage European EBM. And ""Intro König"" is just fascinatingly weird. Die zauberhafte Welt der Anderen works best if you go ahead and make up the movie that you want it to be the soundtrack to. It's unlikely to be a magical one
column3:
but it's certainly got transportive potential.

Louisiana rapper Kevin Gates is a star on par with Lil Boosie around his stomping grounds in Baton Rouge and New Orleans
column2: but he hasn’t had much luck in popping nationally. Gates got a taste of nationwide notoriety after inking a deal with Lil Wayne’s YMCMB imprint a year ago but spent most of his tenure there on ice with YMCMB’s well-populated roster of benchwarmers. It’s a shame they couldn’t find a use for him. Gates’ mixtapes peruse an emotive
column3: melodic style that often gets him incorrectly lumped into the same milieu as introspective lady-killers like Drake and Future. His similarities to those artists starts and ends with the fact that he’s a capable rapper and singer. He’s more technically gifted at both than Future
column4: whose acerbic croak is often cloaked in a mist of Auto-Tune
column5: and he’s more weathered and streetwise than Drake
column6: whose background in soap opera acting undercuts his talk of hardship of its relatability. Gates has been at it at least as long as either of them
column7: and his new mixtape The Luca Brasi Story imbues trap’s claustrophobic bleakness with an emotional nakedness
column8: capable lyricism
column9: and melodic certitude many of its recent breakout stars have lacked.

column1: Gates openly plays off the complexity of his character in naming the mixtape after The Godfather’s Luca Brasi
column2: a brutal but unerringly loyal contract killer whose first scene in the film adaptation shows him mulling over how best to present a gift to the don’s daughter at her wedding. Gates shares that devotion to matters of the heart and matters of the street
column3: and The Luca Brasi Story oscillates wildly between the two poles. Street anthems like “Paper Chasers” and “Weight” hold court with tender tales of love under duress like “Arms of a Stranger” and “Twilight” (yes
column4: that Twilight). That might sound like a strange brew
column5: but Luca Brasi’s portraits of lonesome lotharios and traphouse paper chasers all teeter over the same the brink of collapse
column6: and the intensity and break in Gates’ voice make it the perfect vehicle for these stories of desperation. He’s got his method down pat
column7: so The Luca Brasi Story really lives or dies on the kinds of songs he chooses to apply it to.

column1: The Luca Brasi Story soars on upbeat productions like Swiff D’s “Paper Chasers” and Nard & B’s “Hero”
column2: which apply Kevin Gates’ sing-song cadence to 808s and frenetic synth runs. Gates is also at home on the moodier stuff: the twinkling keys and trance vibes of “Hold Ya Head” and “Twilight”
column3: and the ethereal
column4: pulsating bass of “Neon Lights” and the spectral keys of “Arms of a Stranger” all provide the perfect space for him to examine his shortcomings and insecurities. The only real problems arrive when Gates gets more conventional trap sounds to work with. “Weight” and “Flex” both overlay ominous hood gothic beats with vocal performances that are a touch derivative. “Weight” proposes a clever nutrition metaphor
column5: but Gates plainly approximates Young Jeezy’s asthmatic wheeze on the song’s guttural
column6: multitracked chorus. “Flex” finds Gates co-opting Gucci Mane’s smooth but subversively verbose flow when guest Terrance Hines isn’t hammering away at the song’s grating chorus. 22 tracks is a few too many opportunities to flounder
column7: and while The Luca Brasi Story’s misses are mercifully scant
column8: there’s maybe just a little too much of it to go around.

column1: Kevin Gates is a gifted
column2: pliable songwriter figuring out how to reconcile the cold embrace of street life with a longing for companionship. On The Luca Brasi Story
column3: he mostly settles for ping pong
column4: cordoning off its more contemplative fare from its tough talk and shifting radically in tone from one song to the next. It isn’t really until the mixtape’s closer “IHOP (True Story)” that we get a glimpse of what Gates can do without barriers. “IHOP” is a winding story-song rapped a capella with what sounds like Gates tapping out a rudimentary beat on his chest. It recounts a story of a man at wits end from relationship troubles who stumbles into a set-up and survives to coldly execute a revenge attack. It’s a chilling bit of dopeboy determinism that digs deeper than the self-aggrandizing boasts of invincibility that anyone who lived it would have every right to express
column5: instead examining the outward stimuli that coerce us into losing control. You immediately get the sense that there’s more to Gates than he’s even letting on
column6: that The Luca Brasi Story’s deft exercises in adjoining pop sensibilities to trap are just Gates working out the kinks
column7:
and that something special is just over the horizon.

column8: she will give one of music's coolest-ever Simone de Beauvoir shout outs (""And I'll be rockin' The Second Sex famously"")
column9: she will mumble spoken-word dialogue that sounds like an agoraphobic practicing casual conversation in a mirror (""Hey/ Oh
column10: hey friend/ How were your... holidays?""). But the miracle of the Hello EP is that these songs are never weighed down by her eccentricity; thanks to her keen ability to craft a featherlight pop hook
column11: Thompson-Hannant makes even the clumsiest
column12: most anxious feelings take flight. She's called her sound ""bedroom paranoia
column13: a tongue-in-cheek double entendre that accounts for both her DIY aesthetic (the EP was self-recorded) as well as her lyrical preoccupation with the anxieties of crushing
column14: dating
column15: and intimacy. Though comparisons to some of her Montreal peers are inevitable
column16: a lot of her emotionally candid
column17: frayed-nerve lyrics (like ""Don't Leave It To Me""'s kinetic chant
column18: ""Fear
column19: fear
column20: fear/ Sex
column22: sex"") wouldn't sound out of place in an Autre Ne Veut song.

column1: Thompson-Hannant has done time in a handful of bands
column2: but outside of Montreal she's probably best known as one of two vocalists from the art pop band Shapes and Sizes. Their three albums had exciting moments but were often overcrowded with ideas; without fail
column3: Thompson-Hannant's vocals were the most memorable part of a Shapes and Sizes song. Her transition from co-vocalist to solo artist feels like a wise career move. Thompson-Hannant's voice is soulful
column4: distinct and expressive enough to be the single focal point of a song
column5: but she also has a knack for exploring (and occasionally finding offbeat humor in) isolation and loneliness. ""Sure I got friends
column6: I've probably got more friends than you
column7: she sings on ""Single Status""
column8: a tossed-off boast that turns quickly to a self-deprecating punchline
column9: ""I just don't ever see 'em/ They're probably busy doing/ Whatever it is that they do.""

column1: Brief as it is
column2: Hello does show a bit of range
column3: moving from 80s-leaning bubblegum mysticism (her name isn't the only thing about the project that evokes the angsty British duo Shakespears Sister) to looser
column4: DIY-funk-tinged numbers. The excellent ""Don't Leave It to Me"" is an electric
column5: sub-three-minute pop song that perfectly captures the simultaneous joy and the terror of new love
column6: while the next song
column7: ""Contentedness""
column8: is something else entirely: a guitar-driven
column9: palm-muted meditation on the challenges of finding happiness (""Contentedness
column10: you can come on in/ But I wouldn't take your shoes off"") that ambles its way towards the six-minute mark. But just as she finds liberation in imperfection on ""Mozart's Sister""
column11: Thompson-Hannant (never one to brood for too long) comes to a similarly empowering conclusion here: ""I'm prone to flight
column12: and I like it that way.""

column1: Because of its brevity and rough edges
column2: Hello feels more like an introductory handshake than a fully-realized debut
column3: but it nonetheless hints at a promising future. It will be interesting to see if Mozart's Sister can strike a balance between grit and gloss: this EP's handmade
column4: isolated feel is a big part of its charm
column5: but it also hints that she's capable of something more ambitious. Grimes is a decent comparison only because she's successfully found that particular balance
column6: but in the end
column7: she and Mozart's Sister are reappropriating pop in an attempt to do two different things. Grimes finds power in ambiguity-- the pop element of her music is about tapping into something universal but hard to pin down. The more lyric-driven Mozart's Sister finds power in the act of sharply articulating (and unabashedly celebrating) very specific feelings. For her
column8: pop is the fairy godmother of everyday life
column9: transforming imperfection into freedom
column10: anxiety into ecstasy
column11:
and awkward moments into alternative-universe #1 hits.

""Shiver""
column2: the first song on Australian electro rock trio PVT's third album
column3: begins with warm analog synth arpeggios and the vocals of frontman Richard Pike layered and detuned into a syrupy psychedelic sound that's barely human. As the song progresses
column4: it accumulates parts that either support a melodic
column5: even twee
column6: pop side
column7: or undercut it with a current of aggressive sonic weirdness. It's a fascinatingly unpredictable and completely enjoyable song. It also sounds remarkably like a collision between the Postal Service and the Knife
column8: which could be a coincidence if the rest of the album wasn't littered with seemingly deliberate references to a diverse cast of musicians who've straddled the border between electronic dance music and pop.

column1: PVT was formerly a more cerebral
column2: less pop-oriented group that collaborated with Scott Herren in both Prefuse 73 and Savath y Savalas
column3: and recorded with Tortoise's John McEntire. Their last record
column4: 2010's Church With No Magic
column5: whipsawed between dense
column6: abrasive prog and ambient minimalism. While some of their past recordings have incorporated Pike's vocals
column7: this is the first album where he sings on every track. His transition into the traditional frontman role is only one aspect of an extensive band overhaul that's made them substantially more accessible.

column1: Like a lot of albums by artists who've ditched the constraints of ""serious"" music in order to indulge their taste for pop
column2: Homosapien comes off as someone finally giving themselves permission to explore their basest pleasure points. This might explain the amount of homage going on
column3: as well as the breadth of the influences they explore. Given the opportunity to make any kind of electronics-enhanced pop music they want
column4: PVT seems to have tried to make all of them. Ironically
column5: the most enjoyable songs on the album are the most challenging ones with the fewest references to familiar work. ""Vertigo"" builds from a skittering quasi-footwork beat into a lush
column6: slowly shifting tangle of synth pads and polyrhythmic drumming. ""Homosapien"" has a weirdly lumbering beat and a lot of noise
column7: with Pike's vocals processed in various ways past the point of intelligibility.

column1: Homosapien's constant fluctuations between styles means it's a mercurial and somewhat uneven listen. After the warm introduction of ""Shiver""
column2: the album suddenly turns icy and delivers two consecutive songs whose combination of cold-blooded roboticism and organic kinkiness shares a lot of similarities with Gary Numan and Marc Almond's early work. ""Casual Success"" has a postpunk edginess that's less derivative of the subgenre's innovators like Gang of Four than relatively recent revivalists like the Rapture and LCD Soundsystem. The heavy INXS vibes emitted by ""Love & Defeat"" give a sense of how pop the group's willing to go. Their occasional reliance on pastiche earns itself a sort of pass
column3: however: Compared to their past work
column4: it's almost as if Homosapien is some new band's debut album
column5:
and first albums have a tendency to be derivative.

column3: the lead singer and songwriter of the Portland-based indie-pop group Parenthetical Girls

column14: more embarrassing transactions. In the video for ""The Pornographer""

column19: while someone off-camera performs oral sex on him. Watching his face

column8: just guide these hollow hips of mine inside those equine thighs

column10: and on ""For All the Final Girls""
column11: he purrs ""Could be cousin touched us too much?"" Beneath these lines
column12: you can almost hear Pennington's eyebrows arching hopefully: ""Oh
column13: have I shocked you? No? Hmm. Ok
column14: how about now?""

column1: Thankfully

column4: detailed arrangements. In the background of ""Weaknesses""
column5: a wandering keyboard line with a faint samba flavor offers counterpoint to Pennington's vocals. On ""For All the Final Girls""
column6: a fidgety groove coalesces from unlikely elements-- the dinner-club plucking of violins
column7: scrubbing cellos
column8: and trilling piano. Pennington's melody for ""Evelyn McHale"" is so graceful and balanced that the words become mere roller-coaster cars to deliver its precision-tooled joy. Pennington and Bischoff have simpatico sensibilities
column9: and could probably one day collaborate one day on a killer modern musical. Pennington might not have the depth to sell the part he's auditioning for just yet

baby.

Moving to Montreal from Toronto a few years ago drew Doldrums (aka Airick Woodhead) into one of the most exciting art pop scenes of the past few years
column2: home to Grimes
column3: tourmates Purity Ring
column4: D'Eon
column5: and others. His debut album Lesser Evil is in large part the product of those cities' DIY/noise scenes
column6: where Woodhead came up throwing warehouse parties. His addictive single ""Egypt""
column7: however
column8: nods toward earlier such scenes in Brooklyn (Black Dice
column9: Gang Gang Dance) and Baltimore (Dan Deacon): It's cacophonous and polyrhythmic
column10: continuously falling apart and putting itself back together. Just when it appears ready to implode from hyperactivity
column11: the song erupts into an unearthly refrain
column12: no doubt designed to link a mass of partiers into a temporary
column13: euphoric community.

column1: Yet the name ""Egypt"" signals that Evil is primarily rooted in Woodhead's active imagination. The Doldrums project started as pure science fiction
column2: with Woodhead picturing drugged patients in an experimental clinic who started sharing ""dream maps
column3: which lead to ""this extremely fucked up
column4: dystopic place in which everyone's wildest
column5: darkest fantasies are being realized."" We're introduced to this scenario on ""Anomaly""
column6: as he asks: ""Are you living out your fantasy/ Or caught in someone else’s dreams?"" The track's gothic atmospheres and pulsating electronic rhythms link it to Crystal Castles
column7: another Toronto duo similarly prone to creating soundworlds with no fixed address. ""Holographic Sandcastles"" takes this approach to its endpoint: Woodhead finds himself face-to-face with a fellow traveler ""10 miles underground
column8: an ocean over our heads now"" amidst an echo-laden soundscape.

column1: Evil is equally borne of Woodhead's skill at channeling the infinite possibilities of digital production and the countless distractions of online life. That ""fucked up
column2: dystopic"" site of wild
column3: dark fantasies? Some of us call it ""the internet."" The most talked-about pre-release story surrounding Evil has been that Woodhead compiled it on a laptop borrowed from his pal Claire Boucher
column4: then featured that laptop's busted monitor on the album cover. It's the perfect metaphor for Woodhead's brand of jittery maximalism; it's easy to imagine him climbing inside
column5: pushing it to its absolute limit
column6: then posing next to the rubble when he was done. Out of this scorched earth M.O. arises Evil's most massive song
column7: ""She Is the Wave"". It's less than three minutes long
column8: but every second is packed airtight with laser stabs
column9: spiraling synth squeals
column10: and dark sub-bass. (And yes
column11: there is an internal organ-rearranging ""drop"" a few seconds in.) Bass is one of the album's most recommendable sonic traits: for all of Woodhead's tweaked-out
column12: non-linear layering
column13: he pays a lot of attention to low end.

column1: Among the sensory overload
column2: there's a strong sense of naïve romanticism unique to a kid in his early 20s. Much will likely be made of Woodhead's androgynous vocal style
column3: but primarily
column4: it just sounds young
column5: the kind of wide-eyed enthusiasm perfect for a guy who named his musical project after a fantasy world. These songs sound complex
column6: but lyrically they're mostly about simple things that we fixate on when we're young: love
column7: identity
column8: escape. On the title track
column9: the album's highlight
column10: Woodhead grabs a fellow traveler and splits from a world of his own creation-- because it's boring
column11: like the Doldrums in in The Phantom Tollbooth that gave his project its name. They don't know what they want to do
column12: or where they want to go
column13: they just want to get there quickly. As the squealing synth melody driving the song turns into a howl during its last third
column14: Woodhead starts chanting a refrain that kids have relied upon for centuries
column15: and which is axiomatic for Evil as a whole: ""If I don't see it
column16:
it's not there.""

French electronic musician Kavinsky knows something about what makes a great action movie soundtrack: His song ""Nightcall"" is as synonymous with Nicolas Winding Refn's Drive as scorpion jackets and hot pink brush fonts. While it was written and released before Drive was filmed
column2: the song's perfect placement in the film
column3: and the recognition that it brought Kavinsky's way
column4: seem to have inspired him to replicate it. His new album Outrun isn't attached to a picture
column5: but it's meant to tell the story of a lovelorn young man in the mid-1980s who
column6: through some magical auto accident
column7: becomes some sort of zombie man/car hybrid... who makes electronic music.

column1: The details of Kavinsky's intended narrative are blurry
column2: and possibly nonsensical
column3: but he succeeds in making an album that suggests that it's the soundtrack to something
column4: and at least making it clear that it has to do with cars and the 1980s. Its title was taken from the 1986 Sega driving game of the same name (which puts the player in control of a Ferrari Testarossa). There's also a depressingly uninspired rap by Havoc from Mobb Deep that uses the word ""car"" dozens of times
column5: as well as the presence of ""Nightcall""
column6: which seems to have been included here because
column7: why not?

column1: But Kavinsky doesn't need words
column2: or even his close association with Drive
column3: to project an automobile air: Outrun is littered with musical allusions to speed. ""Testarossa Overdrive""
column4: with its arpeggios
column5: slow-motion chord changes
column6: and a lead synth pitched somewhere between a wailing guitar solo and a wailing sax solo
column7: provokes synesthetic flashbacks to bygone games of F-Zero. A childhood's worth of low-budget VHS action movies has trained my brain to interpret the ominous piano and digitally emulated strings on ""Rampage"" as cues for a shadowy stalker type driving the city streets at night in search of prey.

column1: Because most of Outrun's musical references are to non-musical media
column2: it's kind of unclear what its purpose is. It's technically an electronic music album
column4: but while Kavinsky came out of the same French dance music scene as Daft Punk and Justice
column5: the album doesn't really work as dance music-- the beats are never the center of the production
column6: and they're too rigid anyhow. A lot of the songs come off like synth-emulated rock
column7: but the lack of vocals on any of them aside from ""First Blood""-- which has a high-pitched contribution from the British singer Tyson that would have sounded good over the end credits to any of the American Ninja movies-- gives them the feel of uncompleted demos by an age-old hair metal band.

column1:
Where Outrun unambiguously excels is in inducing a severe case of nostalgia in media consumers of a certain age. There's something in Kavinsky's evocation of 1986 that affects a primal part of my psyche. It took me a while to figure out that it has its finger right on the exact time where video games and movies taught me to lose myself in screens for days at a time.

column3: reissues (especially of widely available material) are tricky fodder. Glibly re-assessing the work of Charley Patton-- one of the most exhilarating and unknowable figures in the American canon
column4: an ur-influence on the whole of popular music-- feels ridiculous in 2013. Patton's work is inarguable
column5: established. The best reissues should proffer some kind of revelation: either by gathering unreleased or under-heralded material
column6: or by the imposition of a compelling rubric (in the spirit of Harry Smith)
column7: or by making something sound extraordinary.

column1: Since 1986
column2: Document Records has been engaged in a vigorous hustle to reissue every pre-war blues song ever commercially recorded
column3: while periodically doling out other forms of rural American music (gospel
column4: old-time
column5: country) recorded between 1900 and 1943. Many of Document's old LP pressings are expensive if not backbreaking to procure
column6: but for anyone who discovered the country-blues that way
column7: they represent a kind of sacred gateway-- those stark white covers
column8: that black block type
column9: a grainy photograph
column10: some mystifying voice eeking out from the grooves. Still
column11: Document's engineers are notorious for their overuse of noise reduction filters
column12: which impose a shrill flatness on performances sourced from decaying 78rpm records
column13: and in the 78 re-mastering community-- a terrifying micro-universe presided over by Yazoo Records' Richard Nevins-- Document remains a source of moderate derision.

column1: Which is why Jack White's decision to reissue selections from the Document vault (beginning with Patton
column2: Blind Willie McTell
column3: and the Mississippi Sheiks) on his Third Man label can feel like the apotheosis of a very specific kind of fetishization. The blues
column4: maybe more than any other American genre
column5: is subject to endless mythologizing-- it is famously apocryphal
column6: shrouded in crossroads-at-midnight mystery. Those romantic notions are
column7: as In Search of the Blues author Marybeth Hamilton points out
column8: ""enormously seductive."" It feels good to position the blues as a singularly raw
column9: marginalized expression
column10: to champion its so-called strangeness; the magnetism of those narratives can blind a listener to everything else. For White
column11: those Document LPs led him directly to a well of source material that later fed an entire body of work (if not an identity)
column12: and these reissues feel like an expression of earnest gratitude to the label. What they don't always feel like is an appropriate paean to the music.

column1: Charley Patton's Complete Recorded Works in Chronological Order
column2: Vol. 1 collects all the sides from Patton's 1929 sessions for the Grafton
column3: Wisc.-based Paramount Records. A Delta-born guitarist and singer
column4: and widely considered the finest practitioner of pre-war
column5: acoustic country-blues
column6: Patton possesses a throaty
column7: lawless voice
column8: which he employs to staggering ends. Blues music can be spiritually crushing
column9: but it can also be caddish
column10: if not obscene: On ""Pony Blues""
column11: listen to Patton's raunchy
column12: snarled delivery of a line like ""Baby
column13: saddle my pony
column14: saddle up my black mare/ I'm gonna find a rider
column15: baby
column16: in the world somewhere."" Bluesmen knew torment
column17: but they also knew the solace of sin.

column1: The songs included here-- some of Patton's best-- are above reproach
column2: and unsurprisingly
column3: this material is not currently under-represented in record shops. If you're after an artifact
column4: Revenant's comprehensive Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues: The Worlds of Charley Patton
column5: was a more deserving indulgence
column6: containing seven CDs housed in reproductions of Paramount sleeves (there's also a gold-embossed box
column7: pages of notes and annotations
column8: and a short paperback book by John Fahey)
column9: though that is now out of print and terrifyingly expensive. If you're more compelled by fidelity (itself a dicey quantifier as it relates to gouged 78s)
column10: Yazoo's Charlie Patton: Founder of the Delta Blues 1929-34 is peerless
column11: sourced from the cleanest discs and artfully re-mastered by Richard Nevins. If you're immovably devoted to long-playing vinyl
column12: there are the gray-market European releases
column13: including five (note- and source-less) LPs by the Italian label Monk
column14: and the scads of reissues cooked up and released by various imprints since Patton was first deified by collectors in the 1940s. If you're less concerned with the material world
column15: most of these songs are now instantaneously accessible via Spotify and iTunes. In 2013
column16: there are many roads to 1929-- which makes the basic utility of White's mission dubious.

column1: And at the risk of assuming the persnickety
column2: exacting voice of a 78 collector-- that high
column3: lonesome sound!-- the package itself is underwhelming. Patton's name is spelled both Charley and Charlie
column4: depending on where you look (for whatever it's worth
column5: it appears on the original Paramount 78s as ""Charley
column6: although many believe Patton himself preferred ""Charlie"")
column7: and the accompanying essay
column8: by the British critic Mick Middles
column9: is not without grammatical blunders (Middles also quantifies Patton's influence by noting that he's been name-checked in song titles by Bob Dylan and the ""British indie band Gomez
column10: which seems like a deeply preposterous way to compute his legacy). There's also a mistake in the track-listing on my copy: ""Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues"" is the second song on Side B
column11: not Side A
column12: where it's been swapped with ""Shake It and Break It (But Don't Let It Fall Mama)"". (I will now attempt-- and fail-- to resist pointing out that the “But” should also be out of the parenthesis in the title of that track). In White's curated universe-- where the idiosyncratic and the analog are prized
column13: aesthetics are multi-dimensional
column14: and the presentation of art is as essential as the art itself-- it seems like a more exacting approach should have been applied. Or: if you’re gonna be precious about your shit
column15: be precious about your shit.

column1: The other two records in the bundle fare better. Blind Willie McTell
column2: a Piedmont-style fingerpicker from Georgia
column3: came up as a street performer before he was recruited to record for Victor in 1927
column4: and he enjoyed a relatively prolific career before his death in 1959. The tremble in his voice is echoed
column5: often
column6: in White's own vocals-- it's a stunning little wobble
column7: an undulating admission of total vulnerability. White
column8: like McTell
column9: knows how effective it can be; it's nearly impossible to dislike McTell
column10: even when he's opining the various women he's already bedded today (""One for in the morning
column11: one for late at night/ I got one for noontime
column12: to treat your old daddy right
column13: he warbles in ""Three Women Blues""). Although McTell's work has been reissued before
column14: his records aren't as rare as Patton's
column15: and were rendered in better studios (ergo: they sound better)
column16: so the question of what gets obscured or highlighted in the re-mastering is less pressing. And while Middles could stand to stop using Bob Dylan as justification for liking blues music (he invokes Dylan's 1983 track
column17: ""Blind Willie McTell""
column18: in his opening line)
column19: the reissue feels more benign than egregious. Same goes for the Mississippi Sheiks
column20: a guitar-and-fiddle family band from Bolton
column21: Mississippi whose ""Sitting on Top of the World""
column23: has since been covered by Bob Wills
column29: and Jack White (on the Cold Mountain soundtrack). For a Sheiks fan anxious to hear these songs on vinyl-- and who can't find the Monk records
column30: or the Matchbox Records releases from the mid-1980s-- whatever new re-mastering current Document owner Gary Atkinson performed yielded worthwhile results: the singer Walter Vinson

column1: In the spirit of the Folkways archive
column2: White has pledged to keep these records in print (on vinyl) ""as long as Third Man Records exists."" His intentions seem pure
column3: and any gesture that makes these songs more available to listeners should be appreciated
column4: if not applauded (although in this particular case
column5: White may have flubbed an opportunity to champion a more obscure artist
column6: like Big Bill Broonzy or Johnnie Temple). But it's still imperative to remember that blues music-- its nuances and devastations
column7: its cadences and riddles-- should be heard and appreciated beyond whatever personal or cultural subtexts we might choose to apply to it; that the sound is the thing. There are good reasons to reissue extant material
column8:
but it's hard to recognize any here.

column3: while periodically doling out other forms of rural American music (gospel
column4: old-time
column5: country) recorded between 1900 and 1943. Many of Document's old LP pressings are expensive if not backbreaking to procure
column6: but for anyone who discovered the country-blues that way
column7: they represent a kind of sacred gateway-- those stark white covers
column8: that black block type
column9: a grainy photograph
column10: some mystifying voice eeking out from the grooves. Still
column11: Document's engineers are notorious for their overuse of noise reduction filters
column12: which impose a shrill flatness on performances sourced from decaying 78rpm records
column13: and in the 78 re-mastering community-- a terrifying micro-universe presided over by Yazoo Records' Richard Nevins-- Document remains a source of moderate derision.

column1: Which is why Jack White's decision to reissue selections from the Document vault (beginning with Patton
column2: Blind Willie McTell
column3: and the Mississippi Sheiks) on his Third Man label can feel like the apotheosis of a very specific kind of fetishization. The blues
column4: maybe more than any other American genre
column5: is subject to endless mythologizing-- it is famously apocryphal
column6: shrouded in crossroads-at-midnight mystery. Those romantic notions are
column7: as In Search of the Blues author Marybeth Hamilton points out
column8: ""enormously seductive."" It feels good to position the blues as a singularly raw
column9: marginalized expression
column10: to champion its so-called strangeness; the magnetism of those narratives can blind a listener to everything else. For White
column11: those Document LPs led him directly to a well of source material that later fed an entire body of work (if not an identity)
column12: and these reissues feel like an expression of earnest gratitude to the label. What they don't always feel like is an appropriate paean to the music.

column1: Charley Patton's Complete Recorded Works in Chronological Order
column2: Vol. 1 collects all the sides from Patton's 1929 sessions for the Grafton
column3: Wisc.-based Paramount Records. A Delta-born guitarist and singer
column4: and widely considered the finest practitioner of pre-war
column5: acoustic country-blues
column6: Patton possesses a throaty
column7: lawless voice
column8: which he employs to staggering ends. Blues music can be spiritually crushing
column9: but it can also be caddish
column10: if not obscene: On ""Pony Blues""
column11: listen to Patton's raunchy
column12: snarled delivery of a line like ""Baby
column13: saddle my pony
column14: saddle up my black mare/ I'm gonna find a rider
column15: baby
column16: in the world somewhere."" Bluesmen knew torment
column17: but they also knew the solace of sin.

column1: The songs included here-- some of Patton's best-- are above reproach
column2: and unsurprisingly
column3: this material is not currently under-represented in record shops. If you're after an artifact
column4: Revenant's comprehensive Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues: The Worlds of Charley Patton
column5: was a more deserving indulgence
column6: containing seven CDs housed in reproductions of Paramount sleeves (there's also a gold-embossed box
column7: pages of notes and annotations
column8: and a short paperback book by John Fahey)
column9: though that is now out of print and terrifyingly expensive. If you're more compelled by fidelity (itself a dicey quantifier as it relates to gouged 78s)
column10: Yazoo's Charlie Patton: Founder of the Delta Blues 1929-34 is peerless
column11: sourced from the cleanest discs and artfully re-mastered by Richard Nevins. If you're immovably devoted to long-playing vinyl
column12: there are the gray-market European releases
column13: including five (note- and source-less) LPs by the Italian label Monk
column14: and the scads of reissues cooked up and released by various imprints since Patton was first deified by collectors in the 1940s. If you're less concerned with the material world
column15: most of these songs are now instantaneously accessible via Spotify and iTunes. In 2013
column16: there are many roads to 1929-- which makes the basic utility of White's mission dubious.

column1: And at the risk of assuming the persnickety
column2: exacting voice of a 78 collector-- that high
column3: lonesome sound!-- the package itself is underwhelming. Patton's name is spelled both Charley and Charlie
column4: depending on where you look (for whatever it's worth
column5: it appears on the original Paramount 78s as ""Charley
column6: although many believe Patton himself preferred ""Charlie"")
column7: and the accompanying essay
column8: by the British critic Mick Middles
column9: is not without grammatical blunders (Middles also quantifies Patton's influence by noting that he's been name-checked in song titles by Bob Dylan and the ""British indie band Gomez
column10: which seems like a deeply preposterous way to compute his legacy). There's also a mistake in the track-listing on my copy: ""Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues"" is the second song on Side B
column11: not Side A
column12: where it's been swapped with ""Shake It and Break It (But Don't Let It Fall Mama)"". (I will now attempt-- and fail-- to resist pointing out that the “But” should also be out of the parenthesis in the title of that track). In White's curated universe-- where the idiosyncratic and the analog are prized
column13: aesthetics are multi-dimensional
column14: and the presentation of art is as essential as the art itself-- it seems like a more exacting approach should have been applied. Or: if you’re gonna be precious about your shit
column15: be precious about your shit.

column1: The other two records in the bundle fare better. Blind Willie McTell
column2: a Piedmont-style fingerpicker from Georgia
column3: came up as a street performer before he was recruited to record for Victor in 1927
column4: and he enjoyed a relatively prolific career before his death in 1959. The tremble in his voice is echoed
column5: often
column6: in White's own vocals-- it's a stunning little wobble
column7: an undulating admission of total vulnerability. White
column8: like McTell
column9: knows how effective it can be; it's nearly impossible to dislike McTell
column10: even when he's opining the various women he's already bedded today (""One for in the morning
column11: one for late at night/ I got one for noontime
column12: to treat your old daddy right
column13: he warbles in ""Three Women Blues""). Although McTell's work has been reissued before
column14: his records aren't as rare as Patton's
column15: and were rendered in better studios (ergo: they sound better)
column16: so the question of what gets obscured or highlighted in the re-mastering is less pressing. And while Middles could stand to stop using Bob Dylan as justification for liking blues music (he invokes Dylan's 1983 track
column17: ""Blind Willie McTell""
column18: in his opening line)
column19: the reissue feels more benign than egregious. Same goes for the Mississippi Sheiks
column20: a guitar-and-fiddle family band from Bolton
column21: Mississippi whose ""Sitting on Top of the World""
column23: has since been covered by Bob Wills
column29: and Jack White (on the Cold Mountain soundtrack). For a Sheiks fan anxious to hear these songs on vinyl-- and who can't find the Monk records
column30: or the Matchbox Records releases from the mid-1980s-- whatever new re-mastering current Document owner Gary Atkinson performed yielded worthwhile results: the singer Walter Vinson

column1: In the spirit of the Folkways archive
column2: White has pledged to keep these records in print (on vinyl) ""as long as Third Man Records exists."" His intentions seem pure
column3: and any gesture that makes these songs more available to listeners should be appreciated
column4: if not applauded (although in this particular case
column5: White may have flubbed an opportunity to champion a more obscure artist
column6: like Big Bill Broonzy or Johnnie Temple). But it's still imperative to remember that blues music-- its nuances and devastations
column7: its cadences and riddles-- should be heard and appreciated beyond whatever personal or cultural subtexts we might choose to apply to it; that the sound is the thing. There are good reasons to reissue extant material
column8:
but it's hard to recognize any here.

column3: reissues (especially of widely available material) are tricky fodder. Glibly re-assessing the work of Charley Patton-- one of the most exhilarating and unknowable figures in the American canon
column4: an ur-influence on the whole of popular music-- feels ridiculous in 2013. Patton's work is inarguable
column5: established. The best reissues should proffer some kind of revelation: either by gathering unreleased or under-heralded material
column6: or by the imposition of a compelling rubric (in the spirit of Harry Smith)
column7: or by making something sound extraordinary.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18835/homepage_large.f84e1ee6.jpg|An A.merican D.ream|4526.0|VietNam|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2013-02-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:03.894837|"

You probably thought you’d never hear VietNam again. The surrealist trad-rockers were last active back in the mid-2000s
column2: when they generated a decent amount of buzz based on one EP (2004’s The Concrete’s Always Grayer on the Other Side of the Street) and a self-titled full-length released in 2007 featuring guest vocals from Jenny Lewis and production by Beachwood Sparks’ Dave Scher and (weirdly) Mickey Madden of Maroon 5. After that
column3: VietNam just sort of faded away. Given how VietNam didn’t exactly set the world on fire commercially
column4: it seemed safe to assume that these guys shaved off their beards and took office jobs somewhere.

column1: But
column2: alas
column3: head ’Nammer Michael Gerner kept the faith
column4: and after several years of focusing his creative energy on film soundtracks and his solo project DA
column5: he has assembled a new version of VietNam and recorded the band’s first album in six years
column6: An A.merican D.ream. The passage of time did nothing to dilute Gerner’s ambition: Just as VietNam was a sprawling mess of stoner poetry and extemporaneous jams
column7: An A.merican D.ream is a record thoroughly enamored with the thrilling possibilities and tired clichés of classic rock. For Gerner
column8: each song is an opportunity to make a mind-blowing
column9: motherfucking statement-- he pushes
column10: stretches
column11: elongates
column12: and expounds every lyric and musical element
column13: adding a couple of minutes of ambient noise to the bloat for good measure. Gerner’s best musical asset is unquestionably his conviction
column14: as he speaks and performs utter bullshit with the fervor of a true believer. With his penchant for wordplay and the druggy
column15: let-it-all-hang-out formlessness of Neil Young’s early 70s albums
column16: he has the attitude and tastes of a great singer-songwriter. What he doesn’t have are the songs.

column1: Vietnam are not exactly understated or ideologically sophisticated. Gerner last checked out during the final throes of the Bush administration
column2: and now that he’s back he’s not about to let the intervening years go without a chin-stroke-y remark or several. The one-minute piano dirge “1.20.09” memorializes Obama’s first inauguration by cursing out corporations picking through the “bones of human rights.” On the spacey “Blasphemy Blues”
column3: Gerner plays a “dirty little devil” with a pitchfork and a “tail in my pocket” (we’re talking here about a literal devil
column4: because of course) spying evil people lurking amid “mansions inside mansions inside mansions.” The campy would-be epic “W.orld W.ar W.orries” aspires to be “Desolation Row” and winds up somewhere closer to “Eve of Destruction”-- Gerner blares pseudo-profound gibberish (“I kill my wife/ I kill my brother/ For this trick/ Why do I bother”) for more than three minutes before anything resembling a song materializes
column5: and then prattles on for several more minutes about post-modern confusion. “We’re all goin’ crazy from these visions in our heads
column6: ” he sings. Totally
column7: dude. Totally.

column1: As silly as the songs on an A.merican D.ream are
column2: it is Gerner’s wincingly theatrical vocals that really take the album into the realm of unintentional comedy. The ""self-serious hippie"" archetype is easy to make fun of
column3: though Gerner’s passionate commitment to the material makes Vietnam oddly compelling. The amount of hyperbolic earnestness on display is bracing and
column4: frankly
column5: kind of refreshing given how aloofness is the default posture for so many indie bros these days. An American Dream was made by a guy drunk on delusions of grandeur-- even if Gerner whiffs more often than not
column6:
at least he’s swinging for the fences.
