column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18851/homepage_large.dd87ae70.jpg|Heliosphere|31008.0|Benjamin Damage|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['50 Weapons']|2013-02-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:04.430547|"

Benjamin Damage lives for today. Or at least he lives for the same yesterday as lots of his contemporaries. When Damage came up several years ago
column2: his work-- solo and with frequent collaborators Venom and Doc Daneeka-- traced the move of UK producers to the sounds of early house music. Damage and Daneeka contemporized them by adding aspects of UK Funky and bass music
column3: though last year's They!Live didn't live up to the promise of early single ""Creeper"". On Heliosphere
column4: Damage's first solo album
column5: he moves into the harsher
column6: straightline realm of rave techno
column7: a resurgent style invigorated by a flood of European producers returning to the industrial climes of UK thrashers like Surgeon and Female.

column1: Damage's techno productions are a lot like his house tracks: good but a little generic. The album doesn't feel retro or modern
column2: just careful and deliberate. Damage isn't an extremist; the 10 tracks on Heliosphere don't hurdle forward
column3: storm noisily
column4: or threaten. The malicious UK variety of techno that Damage borrows from was nihilistic
column5: and had as much in common with noise or hardcore as funk and disco. (It even looked like hardcore
column6: sometimes.) Damage's version is more orderly. Even when Heliosphere whips itself into a frenzy
column7: like during the breakneck revving of ""Delirium Tremens""
column8: it does so safely
column9: never coercing.

column1: Despite a couple of intriguing
column2: spaced-out interludes that have much in common with Boards of Canada's inky psychedelia
column3: the album carries on predictably
column4: checking off boxes: punishing banger (""Extrusion"")
column5: acid workout (""Spirals"")
column6: piano-led stomper (""0I0x""). It's a techno buffet
column7: a place where detail is sacrificed for variety. And that's the problem: there's little here that Damage could call his own
column8: no characteristic drum treatments
column9: few memorable snaps of melody. The sequences are short and compact; the whole album sounds like it was laid out with a protractor and graph paper. The album's best
column10: most assured moments are those slower tracks. ""End Days"" is silky and assured
column11: a twirling ribbon of synthesizers set atop tittering hi-hats. Moody table-setter ""Laika"" is menacing and foggy.

column1: This kind of concrete
column2: warehouse dance music demands grayness
column3: but the tension on Heliosphere is like the tension during the opening scene of an action film: we know the principals can't die yet
column4: so there's nothing at stake. And like an action flick
column5: the cared-for
column6: excellently produced content-- here
column7: ashy noise for partying
column8: there
column9: people being shot and buildings blowing up-- masks the project's ultimate conservatism. Which is a shame
column10:
because Damage definitely has the ear for this music. It's his voice he needs to locate.

"|17652.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17652-benjamin-damage-heliosphere/|6.0|Andrew Gaerig

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18844/homepage_large.d58283cd.jpg|Anxiety|29170.0|Autre Ne Veut|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer'
column2:
'Software']|2013-02-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:05.195514|"

Autre Ne Veut's self-titled debut was the epitome of fringe back in 2010: someone with an unwieldy handle and a staunch commitment to anonymity making warped approximations of 1980s and 90s R&B on a label that primarily trafficked in lo-fi curiosities. By the time Arthur Ashin revealed himself in 2012
column3: all of those characteristics had become basic tools of indie rock buzzmaking. Though prevailing trends have positioned Autre Ne Veut closer to the center of discussion
column4: he remains quite outré on new album Anxiety. The cover no longer bears a replication of Edvard Munch's The Scream
column5: but he kept Anxiety as the album title; you can't say he didn't warn you about him losing his cool time and time again on his marvelous and moving second LP.

column1: While by far his most accessible work to date
column2: Ashin's busy hands keep Anxiety off-kilter throughout. The touches of dissonance help convey the message of each song: brash sax honks evoke the morbid discomfort of ""Counting""; the yearning ""Don't Ever Look Back"" hitches on sharp feedback before giving into harmonized hair-metal guitars; as ""Play by Play"" restlessly prepares for its massive chorus
column3: Ashin's voice is layered and deformed with sudden fits of pitch-shifting. While Ashin's past as a jingle writer manifests in focusing every song with a melody that sticks
column4: they're not the kind of tunes I imagine being belted out by the kids chorus at PS 22. His melodic sense feels more intuitive
column5: looping and darting perilously. They can initially come off as harsh before the warmth courses through; repeat the experience four or five times and you might want to go hug someone.

column1: That much is played out in Anxiety's bookends
column2: songs that are structured to deliver tremendous codas with extremely different effects. Opener ""Play by Play"" has a ""Purple Rain""-like gospel build
column3: as oddly juxtaposed harmonies rising and crashing with every round; it's conceivable that Anxiety could buckle under the weight of its impact after only five minutes. The comparatively sedate closer ""World War"" fizzles into electronic static mid-way through
column4: easing out into a resigned duet that thematically connects with ""Play by Play"" to give Anxiety a sense of cycle. The message of ""Play by Play"" was ""don't ever leave me alone
column5: on ""World War
column6: he pleads
column7: ""no way you'll ever be my baby.""

column1: In between
column2: that polarity of desire and disappointment is fully explored by Ashin's erratic and ecstatic voice. Describing its tone doesn't quite convey its appeal
column3: nor does it demonstrate how much of an acquired taste it is. His glass-shattering falsetto runs and chesty bleats transform Anxiety from a great pop record into something powerfully therapeutic
column4: more about casting off inhibitions than actually hitting those high notes.

column1: It's the sort of performance typically ascribed to the hyper-emotive subgenres of rock
column2: so it's no surprise it works splendidly on unhinged songs like ""Ego Free Sex Free"" and ""I Wanna Dance With Somebody"". The latter doesn't quote Whitney Houston like his recent solo rendition of ""World War"" did; he simply captures the unchecked desires conveyed in the title. The enduring surprise of Anxiety is that Ashin's nervy approach works just as well on the ballads
column3: his voice lending an edge to songs that might otherwise slip into filler territory. His performance is toned down only somewhat on ""A Lie""
column4: ""Gonna Die""
column5: and ""World War""
column6: the titles of which give you an idea of the phenomenal stakes Ashin can create vocally. There's sadness in these songs
column7: certainly-- but while they sound like slow dances
column8: they feel like the entire universe caving in on Ashin.

column1: It could certainly be a turn-off
column2: or at least criticized as ""oversinging."" But the demonstrative nature of Autre Ne Veut is pretty much the point
column3: and as with collaborator and peer How to Dress Well
column4: it has as much in common with Broadway as it does with R&B; you imagine he's drawn to this style of music because it's a means to a kind of spiritual transcendence that most rock music isn't particularly interested in. So it's understandable that ""Ego Free Sex Free"" becomes something of a mantra for Anxiety. On its face
column5: it's a curious slogan-- typically
column6: we prefer pop stars to indulge in ego and certainly avail themselves of carnality. But judging from Ashin's explanation regarding the song's inspiration
column7: you can see what he means by it
column8: how the neediness of the self can stand in the way of true and meaningful connection. Yes
column9: it's completely corny and I'm pretty sure it's the reasoning behind every nudist colony. And yet
column10: it fits within the context of Anxiety
column11:
an album where Ashin fearlessly reveals himself as a person and an artist and dares you to open up in the same way.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18864/homepage_large.fbaac71d.jpg|Through the Window|3478.0|Prurient|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2013-02-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:05.754428|"

The path from black metal to techno via noise is so well-travelled these days that you could
column2: if you were feeling melodramatic
column3: call it an exodus. It's a trip the now L.A.-based Dominick Fernow has been prolifically and prophetically plugging away at for well over a decade
column4: carving out a reputation for ferociously uncompromising sonics with an inquisitive air. Having taken a pleasurable detour toward grinding synth pop on his 2011 releases Bermuda Drain and Time's Arrow
column5: with Through the Window
column6: Fernow convincingly throws himself to the growling hounds of techno.

column1: Through The Window is an overtly theatrical body of work even by the standards of the worlds it straddles: the high camp of metal
column2: the existential roar of noise
column3: and techno's ritualism. Its three tracks even function like the three acts of the archetypal quest tale
column4: spanning the journey
column5: the obstacle
column6: and the reward. ""Through the Window"" sets the scene for Prurient's techno rebirth before ""Terracotta Spine"" issues a blood-curdling screech of noisy resistance
column7: which we're gratefully delivered from by the still-ominous yet tonally triumphant ""You Show Great Spirit"": our reward for endurance though
column8: of course
column9: there's joy to be found in the enduring itself. That final act builds seductively in waves
column10: a delicious drowning that leaves the sharp tang of aluminum on the lips. While each track could be enjoyed on its own merits
column11: the three tracks need one another
column12: requiring the other's context and contrast.

column1: Fernow's command of texture is in full
column2: swaggering flow throughout. Underneath the pummeling rhythms of ""Through the Window"" lies a sea of writhing life-- adrenaline-laden breathing
column3: static clicks
column4: the prickling of erect hairs-- while
column5: later
column6: in the final moments of ""You Show Great Spirit""
column7: we're left with the chip-chip-chink of metal against metal
column8: fragments dropping to a stone floor. These are loose ends
column9: sure
column10: but all the more intriguing for it. There's a similar approach to melody too. It comes and goes
column11: weaving in and out with a gently shifting intricacy yet refuses to submit to convention.

column1: Unlike the aforementioned Time's Arrow and Bermuda Drain
column2: which featured foregrounded vocals (somewhat controversially to noise purists)
column3: Fernow's voice drops to a barely discernible
column4: deathly whisper on Through the Window. ""Big things grow much bigger/ And need bigger things inside them
column5: he intones archly
column6: which could be read as a clue to his own evolution
column7: and that of the wider noise scene. When sonics themselves have lost their power to shock and excite-- or when we are too comfortable with the old ways of feeling uncomfortable-- we look elsewhere to revive the sensation. Little wonder contemporary techno's diametric binding of ritualistic rhythms and elastic form appealed.

column1: ""Noise used to be a place that was devoid of expectations
column2: Fernow told Tiny Mix Tapes in 2011. ""But there are people who have been working 24 hours a day to make it into a genre of music like any other with a set of rules and regulations
column3: which to me is the antithesis of noise ideology. So I have no problems with not being categorized as such
column4: because that word has come to mean the opposite of what it should."" Some 15 years on from his first Prurient album
column5: it is thrilling to still hear the vigor in his searching; in his questioning of restrictions and extending of freedoms. This gripping chapter in his exploration might not quite be his definitive statement
column6:
but then definitive has never been of interest to Fernow.

"|17665.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17665-prurient-through-the-window/|7.4|Ruth Saxelby

Work felt like work
column2: so Optica-- the fourth LP from Sweden's Shout Out Louds-- takes things a little easier. Recorded over a year and a half and produced by the band (with an assist from Radio Dept. affiliate Johannes Berglund)
column3: Optica is warm
column4: expansive
column5: and swimming in strings. Judiciously paced
column6: too: Clocking in just under an hour
column7: there's not a hasty second to be found among these dozen tracks. The Shout Out Louds took their sweet time with Optica
column8: and it shows: the production's richer
column9: more inviting
column10: their movements more deliberate. But the romantic desperation that carried this band's pre-Work output is hard to come by on Optica
column11: an okay enough widescreen synth-pop record with some major urgency issues.

column1: Matching the electroid strut of the Flaming Lips' ""Fight Test"" to any major key Cure single
column2: the rousing
column3: skywritten melody under opener ""Sugar"" is easy to get lost in. Current single ""Illusions"" follows
column4: a glimmering New Order tribute destined to pad out dance night playlists in the months to come. Things start to slip around ""Blue Ice""
column5: a swoony New Romantic puddle dripping with lousy puns (""Blue Ice"" becomes ""blue eyes"" that ""came out of the blue
column6: which
column7: well
column8: yikes) and a limp
column9: hushed-for-a-reason melody. Mercifully
column10: Arcade Fire-y corker ""14th of July"" sweeps in to the blood going a bit
column11: but it's only when Adam Olenius starts singing that you'll start seeing red. ""Take me to the room where you grew up
column12: he requests
column13: before adding ""I bet it's got a great view/ I bet no one loves you.""

column1: It's a strange moment
column2: maybe Optica's strangest. And while it's not a great line on its own
column3: the sheer abruptness of it all offers a brief but badly needed respite from the synth-dappled serenity that surrounds it. Optica's a pleasant enough record on the whole
column4: but it suffers from a kind of excessive competence: at this point in the game
column5: the Shout Out Louds are seemingly incapable of penning a genuinely lousy tune
column6: but as with Work
column7: they're having some trouble settling on a truly inspiring one. What Pitchfork's Marc Hogan wrote about Work-- ""all innocuous midtempo thrum and vague yearning""-- seems every bit as applicable here; These songs tend to float along on sturdy but unspectacular melodies
column8:
agreeable enough not to send you across the room looking for the pause button but rarely so gripping you'll remember one song by the time the next one gets going.

The band's year-and-change in the studio wasn't for naught
column9: and the mostly self-produced Optica proves the Shout Out Louds' worth behind the boards. Every surface on Optica shimmers
column10: and every close listen turns up more spangles to dislodge from your earlobes. But Optica's detail-oriented sonics can't quite make up for some of its big picture deficiencies
column11: imprecise emotions and melodies that feel rounded off at the edges to discourage friction. The Shout Out Louds deserve their propers for bringing a little more color back into their sound in the wake of Work's Dockers-clad drudgery. But
column12: much like its predecessor
column13:
Optica's pervasive mildness doesn't give you much to latch onto.

Formerly a knob-turner in the melodic noise rock band Parts & Labor
column2: Dan Friel went solo with 2008's Ghost Town on Important Records and now moves over to Thrill Jockey for Total Folklore. He uses cheap keyboards
column3: chained pedals
column4: field recordings
column5: and knick-knacks to brew his blown-out
column6: euphoric tunes
column7: and records them on an ancient PC. The precarious setup translates into punchy instrumentals instilled with the raw energy of punk. This is noise pop that doesn't stint on either side of the bargain
column8: striking a perfect balance between cataclysmic and catchy.

column1: Friel does not remotely fuck around in getting Total Folklore started: ""Ulysses"" is a beautiful bastard of a noise pop jam that lasts for almost 13 exhilarating minutes. From the filthy bass and shattering drums to his suspenseful squeals and wriggly neon accents
column2: every part is vicious and volatile. Friel corrals all this unruliness with a heaving boom-clap beat that he keeps milling down to an earthquake-low rumble before rebuilding it differently
column3: with audible allusions to prog
column4: hair metal
column5: trancy electro
column6: and even 90s slacker rock.

column1: Meting out earworms and explosive drops until the end
column2: Friel earns every minute of ""Ulysses"". It fills a good third of the album
column3: and you might imagine it would leave you worn out for the remainder. But ""Ulysses"" is so energizing that the shorter tracks seem to whiz by
column4: with plenty of highlights among the desultory interstitials. There’s ""Valedictorian""
column5: a sweetly screaming anthem in the style of M83; ""Scavengers""
column6: with its nasty groove and drunkenly weaving pitch
column7: and especially ""Thumper""
column8: where a touching melody ripples rapidly.

column1: Still
column2: no one could be expected to sustain the maniacal force of ""Ulysses"" for longer than Friel already does
column3: and the following tracks can't help but pale a little in its shadow. They settle into slightly more prosaic electro pop proportions and cadences
column4: becoming more reliant on distortion than structural instability. Long rows of evenly pulsing notes paired with streaming harmonies make for a low-stakes default mode. But when an album's mild downsides are all relative to its overwhelming strengths
column5:
it's hard to complain.

The mythology behind Destruction Unit is that they were born from the deserts of Arizona. But that hasn't always been the case: They began in the early 2000s when frontman (and former Reatard) Ryan Rousseau joined forces with two Memphis residents and members of the Lost Sounds: Alicja Trout and Jay Reatard. Since then
column2: the band's lineup has completely changed. On Void
column3: it's Rousseau on guitar and vocals
column4: his brother Rusty on bass
column5: N. Nappa on guitar
column6: J. Aurelius on guitar
column7: and J. Keefer on drums. (Count 'em: three guitars.) They're affiliated with Arizona's Ascetic House collective
column8: and if the sound they offer on Void is any indication
column9: they've planted some deep
column10: firm roots in the desert.

column1: Here's an album where the guitar sound merits descriptors like ""expansive
column2: swirling
column3: echoing
column4: and maybe most notably
column5: ""chaotic."" Their krautrock grooves are given menace with Rousseau's screams and the overpowering low-end of Rusty's bass. Each song is laced with sonic tinges that invoke an uneasy
column6: dark haze of psychedelics (see titles ""Druglore""
column7: ""Smoke Dreams""). In their delivery
column8: there's an undercurrent of hostility and snarling anger (see titles ""Evil Man""
column9: ""Exterminate""
column10: Void). Nearly every song offers the aural equivalent of walking into a bar full of stereotypical biker toughs-- everything's muscular
column11: intimidating
column12: mean. Now might be a good time for a reminder: This band's name is ""Destruction Unit.""

column1: Void's strengths are in the band's song structuring. On ""Evil Man""
column2: the formula of ""simmering lead-in"" to ""drum crash"" to ""simmering verse"" to ""wall of sound
column3: all backed by a melody marked by catchiness
column4: is foolproof. In general
column5: they've got ""the drop"" pretty well figured out. For a track that's eight minutes long
column6: ""Smoke Dreams"" is consistently riveting. Their well-established sprawling kraut echo hangs above their more muscular leanings
column7: continuously morphing over Flores' drum attack. And when a track features vocals
column8: Rousseau's darkwave-tinted voice is perfectly suited to this sort of material. The strongest song by a mile
column9: though
column10: is ""Exterminate""-- three minutes of punk rock bite washed in synths and the band's signature kraut sonics.

column1: But in its six tracks
column2: the title Void proves to be an unfortunate one-- there's an unmistakable emptiness to the album. There are interesting guitar flourishes in the almost eight minutes of ""Druglore""
column3: but mostly
column4: it just sits there simmering while not really going anywhere. Even a song like ""Blame""
column5: which benefits from bellowing vocals and crashing percussion at the midpoint
column6: is made less interesting by its too-long simmer and overly repetitive elements.

column1: With the complementary sounds they implement-- the ones that brings to mind the desert-- it's understandable that there's some desolation here. But that doesn't mean the album itself has to sag. Structurally speaking
column2: Void is fairly similar to a recent LP from the other end of the United States: Deep Thuds by the Philadelphia band Spacin'. Both feature lengthier atmospheric songs punctuated by tracks with firmer melodies. Here
column3: the spaciness is just too spacey and the hooks aren't quite there. Even when you disregard ""hooks"" or ""catchiness"" and stack this album next to the recent work of Moon Duo/Wooden Shjips mastermind Ripley Johnson
column4: Void feels thin by comparison. There are strong songs and moments
column5:
absolutely-- just not enough.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18831/homepage_large.17526200.jpg|AMOK|28660.0|Atoms for Peace|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2013-02-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:09.526109|"

The Eraser was Thom Yorke's attempt to liberate himself from the burden of being frontman for the most over-analyzed rock band in the world and explore more insular and austere forms of electronic production. Atoms for Peace is likewise his attempt to liberate himself from the burden of being Thom Yorke
column2: shirking the added psychoanalytical interpretations that solo releases inevitably attract by receding into an all-star cast (complete with a name-- cribbed from a Dwight Eisenhower speech and subsequent program by way of an Eraser track-- that sounds like some one-off 1980s charity-single supergroup). From the similarly greyscale Stanley Donwood cover art on down
column3: AMOK is essentially Yorke's follow-up to The Eraser
column4: backed by the band that performed the album's songs during a handful of live dates over 2009-10: producer/multi-instrumentalist Nigel Godrich
column5: Red Hot Chili Peppers bassist Flea
column6: David Byrne percussionist Mauro Refosco
column7: and drummer Joey Waronker (a.k.a. the 21st-century Jim Keltner).

column1: Actually
column2: ""performed"" is a gross understatement—in the hands of Atoms for Peace
column3: The Eraser's songs were utterly transformed from skeletal synth sketches into full-blooded
column4: festival-rocking workouts that gave Yorke occasion to test out the dance moves he would later flash in the ""Lotus Flower"" video. So there's good reason to believe that vibrant energy would spill over to AMOK. The new record is certainly a more colourful
column5: layered work than The Eraser
column6: and suggests all those late-night
column7: Fela Kuti-soundtracked benders Yorke's talked about in interviews were as much educational as they were recreational. But if the opening ""Before Your Very Eyes"" faithfully assumes the jittery cadence of 70s Afrobeat
column8: it doesn't seem all that interested in acquiring the same force
column9: preferring to skitter rather than swagger. And it sets the tentative tone for an album that's intricately assembled and rhythmically complex
column10: but oddly inert. ""I made my bed
column11: I'm lying in it
column12: Yorke sings early on
column13: a fitting advertisement for the unpredictable artistic course he's charted throughout his career. But over the entirety of AMOK
column14: you get the overwhelming sense that
column15: this time
column16: his sheets are tucked in too tight.

column1: Surprisingly
column2: what this thing really needs is more Flea. While some Radiohead fans may view the union of Yorke's fragile
column3: world-weary croon with Flea's cock-in-a-sock showboating as pure sacrilege
column4: Mr. Slappeh De Bass commendably spends much of AMOK reminding us what a tastefully melodic player he can be when he keeps his right thumb in check. The album's most invigorating moments come when he takes the lead
column5: like on the hypno-funk throb of ""Stuck Together Pieces"" and the mid-song ramp-up on ""Dropped""
column6: whose accelerated
column7: slippery groove indicates that Kevin Shields isn't the only 90s alt-rock icon currently getting mileage from his old drum'n'bass records.

column1: But Flea can't carry the rhythm section alone. AMOK was reportedly built through a process of Yorke and Godrich handing over their laptop demos to the rest of the band for their embellishment. But Waronker and Refosco seem more intent on studiously replicating every last click and cut than giving the songs extra width. Instead
column2: AMOK subtly applies its intensity through textural density—like with the fuzzy synth oscillations on ""Before Your Very Eyes"" that threaten to vaporize Yorke's vocal
column3: or the eerie post-apocalyptic drones that permeate the title track's dubstep strut. But in each case
column4: they set you up for a climax that never comes
column5: with the songs pulling back or fading out just as they seem ready to erupt into something more fierce. For all the rhythmic chicanery at play
column6: AMOK feels strangely static and contained
column7: giving a perpetual sense of jogging in place.

column1: This wouldn't be such an issue if Yorke assumed a more commanding presence
column2: but his diffident vocals here-- which favor the hushed
column3: high-register end of his range-- suggest a desire to
column4: if not disappear completely
column5: at least dissolve into the clattering backdrops. For all the electronic abstraction heard on The Eraser and Radiohead's King of Limbs
column6: Yorke's performances were for the most part assertive and forthright
column7: making the songs more impactful than their brittle structures initially suggested. On AMOK
column8: Yorke's lyrics tend to drift in and out of decipherability
column9: his impressionistic protest songs hinging on appropriations of well-worn phrases (""the will is strong
column10: but the flesh is weak"") or withering mantras (""care less
column11: I couldn't care less""). And the more intimate the songs get
column12: the more distant he becomes: the synth-swaddled soul ballad ""Ingenue"" counts as AMOK's most humane
column13: romantic turn
column14: yet also its most inscrutable.

column1: And that's ultimately the most frustrating thing about AMOK: the fact that you can hear the great potential in every song
column2: and so easily imagine how the hand-clapped hook of ""Judge
column3: Jury
column4: and Executioner
column5: the percussive breakdown of ""Unless
column6: and the creeping exasperation of ""Reverse Running"" would absolutely pop with a more vigorous attack. No doubt
column7: like The Eraser
column8: these songs will go down a like a storm in a live setting. But
column9: given the caliber of players Yorke has on hand this time around
column10:
it's disappointing that we still have to make that assumption.

Mount Moriah is a real college town band-- though not in the pejorative sense. The band formed from a record counter friendship between singer Heather McEntire and guitarist Jenks Miller at the since-shuttered Schoolkids Records
column2: on the University of North Carolina campus. On the band's rootsy
column3: countrified second album (and Merge debut) Miracle Temple
column4: McEntire sings of a life in a town ruled by student seasons
column5: where you stay after everyone goes
column6: leaving summer wide open. Album opener ""Younger Days"" ends on a question: ""August is over so when are you coming back?"" McEntire sings it with resigned hope: when they're gone
column7: they're gone.

column1: The album is nostalgic for people and times that can't be had again
column2: no matter what magic you attempt. ""You know I really tried
column3: girl/ To lift your small town summer malaise
column4: she sings
column5: in ode to a wild girl who just couldn't hang. ""How I tried for years to return there
column6: goes ""Union Street Bridge""
column7: recalling misspent youth. Most of the songs are in the past tense and measure the chasm between the innocent spoils of then and the sadness of now by what's been lost in the interim: fearlessness
column8: blind love
column9: the ability to make someone weak in the knees. ""Go on
column10: disappear
column11: she sings on ""I Built a Town""
column12: casting out this awful ghost of the perfect past. Miracle Temple orients itself from the knowledge that there is no being restored.

column1: McEntire grew up on Southern Baptist hymns and Springsteen; the influence of both are evident here. The plaintive appeals in her lyrics and the soulful burr in her voice are church skills since refined for secular use. There is some Darkness on the Edge of Town within Miracle Temple; dreams too big for a small town
column2: highways beckoning getaway from all that conspires to keep you there. In lieu of Jersey
column3: high school sweethearts
column4: and Carter-era gloom
column5: it's the Outer Banks
column6: straight girls' drunken flirting
column7: and cruel summers.

column1: But McEntire could be singing about anything with lyrics deep or dumb
column2: and it would hardly matter-- there is that voice of hers. The comparison to young Dolly Parton is not undue; the quiver as she gets to the song's emotional center
column3: the way she reigns herself in right before you expect her to belt it. Like Parton
column4: she reserves her big voice for when she needs to bring out the drama. McEntire often gets pegged as post-punk
column5: due to her proximity to the DIY scene she came up in
column6: but on ""White Sands""
column7: she stretches ""kids"" to nearly four syllables (something like ""key-yuh-hid-s"" with a little hiccup in the middle)-- conclusive proof that girl is country.

column1: Alas
column2: the rest of the band is not. They are very much Southern
column3: but that is not that same thing. They lay in and drift a bit between punctuating
column4: shuffling rhythms-- their loose hooks mimicking a drawl. Jenks Miller
column5: a guitarist with enough confidence to occasionally venture solo as Horseback
column6: keeps his accompaniment spare; his long single note runs to accent McEntire's melody lines fill in the excited silence.

column1: The album's stand out track is ""I Built a Town""
column2: which is the sort of Muscle Shoals throwback many attempt and few land. The strings swell
column3: the organ whirrs
column4: and you imagine a bouffanted McEntire
column5: a la Dusty in Memphis
column6: wiping her tears away as the back-up girls coo. She gave it all
column7: and now
column8: now there's nothing. It's easy to imagine that doing an entire record that straight would just be a showy genre exercise for them
column9: but that can't keep a girl from wishing for more. The rest of the band obviously knows that McEntire is the showpiece-- songs like ""Those Girls"" show that they do
column10:
setting up her big moments with subtlety and understatement-- reminding us that the real power is in restraint.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18958/homepage_large.79716ddf.jpg|New Jet City|29043.0|Curren$y|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2013-02-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:10.764895|"

Here was Curren$y
column2: with about as much conviction as he's ever managed
column3: on 2011's ""Car Talk"": ""Critics say that he flow only 'bout weed/ They don't know about me."" The NOLA native had reason to be defensive

column1: That willingness to shake things up is usually pretty subtle-- not the case with New Jet City. Structurally

column1: This starts
column2: inevitably
column3: with the guy's rapping. Nobody's mistaking Curren$y's for much of a technician
column4: and nothing here will change that; as ever

column7: sticky voice of his no problem in all the beats that come his way

column1: Knowing that there is a minor shortage of Curren$y's linguistic gifts here

Every last visitor trusts in his strengths to make things come together just right: Lloyd waxes euphoric for his hook on ""Purple Haze""
column9: while Juicy choppily says things like ""I shine like a UV ray/ And I get head like a new toupee"" for ""Three 60"". Some of the collaborations work because of chemistry

column1: New Jet City has already racked up more DatPiff downloads than Curren$y's last tape
column2: the blaxploitation-based Priest Andretti. But even though there are moments here suggesting that Curren$y is switching up his style to appeal to a broader range of listeners (don't be surprised if the Wiz- and Ross-featuring ""Choosin'""
column3: for instance
column4: turns out to be his biggest song of the year)
column5: I'd like to think that he took a go at all these sounds in order to prove just how adaptable he is. For a guy who releases not particularly ambitious music as often as he does (three releases a year
column6: minimum)
column7:
the idea that he can still be hungry to do things a little different is a pleasing one.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18841/homepage_large.a321b38a.jpg|The Underground Resistance|1274.0|Darkthrone|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Peaceville']|2013-02-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:11.470967|"

When you think of Darkthrone
column2: you think of fun
column3: right? If you scoffed
column4: guffawed
column5: or simply disagreed
column6: don't worry-- you're safely in the majority. The Norwegian band are best known
column7: of course
column8: for what their 1999 album labeled ""ravishing grimness""-- savage
column9: belligerent
column10: and unfiltered black metal
column11: epitomized by a blitz of icy hot classics that started with 1992's A Blaze in the Northern Sky and end
column12: depending upon your stance on Second Wave orthodoxy and eclecticism
column13: sometime just before or after the turn of the millennium. They're the dudes that epitomized ghoulish corpsespaint covers
column14: brandished the credo ""True Norwegian Black Metal
column15: and fended off Aryan allegations as Varg Vikernes headed to jail. So
column16: no
column17: maybe fun isn't the first adjective Darkthrone conjures.

column1: But it's hard to imagine two middle-aged men having more fun than Fenriz and Nocturno Culto-- the band's lone multi-instrumentalists
column2: songwriters
column3: and singers for two decades now-- do on The Underground Resistance
column4: their inescapably enthusiastic 16th studio album. Darkthrone long ago gave up on black metal
column5: turning instead to an open-ended and unmitigated interest in recombining the metal they loved as kids: thrash and crust punk
column6: high-flying British metal and blustery hardcore. Those influences were always tucked within Darkthrone's most famous albums
column7: but lately they've given over to them entirely. The simple joy of these influences is the thread that ties together The Underground Resistance
column8: an album about unfit enemies and deserved death that nevertheless delights in its own music-making élan. Darkthrone's already been involved in a movement that revolutionized heavy metal both sonically and stylistically; The Underground Resistance
column9: then
column10: is simply the latest and most propulsive homage to the bands that sparked that revolution for them.

column1: In the early days of Darkthrone
column2: Fenriz didn't give many interviews
column3: or at least he didn't say much in them. These days
column4: though
column5: he writes liner notes in which he conveys his influences and intentions. And his Metal Band of the Week blog advocates for young acts he likes and older acts he thinks went overlooked. He's made up for that early media quiet by seemingly giving interviews to most anyone who has asked. In doing so
column6: he's often surprised journalists with his forthrightness and humor. ""Isn't it normal to want to communicate your life's work?” he asked That’s How Kids Die
column7: questioning those surprised by his newfound verbosity. For a guy who once posed in corpsepaint
column8: he sure uses a lot of emoticons and knows a lot about Pink Panther.

column1: But Fenriz rightly insists that there's not a lot of humor in Darkthrone's new music. (With a song sporting a name like ""Leave No Cross Unturned""
column2: though
column3: there is certainly some.) Still
column4: The Underground Resistance flaunts the sort of vigor you'd expect from old friends out to have a good time: ""Dead Early"" is a menacing five-minute race that suggests Motörhead loaded on piss and vinegar
column5: while the relentless chug of ""Lesser Men"" pogoes from circle-pit invocations to head-down
column6: horns-up headbanging. ""Valkyrie"" begins with a classic doom feint
column7: craggy acoustic guitars introducing a riff that unfurls over cascading drums. They return to that slow burn for the coda
column8: but the middle is all blustery thrash
column9: with Fenriz chasing himself in circles behind the drums while his falsetto peaks above the din. The album's real clincher
column10: ""Come Warfare
column11: the Entire Doom""
column12: is a series of swivels and sprints
column13: once again teasing doom before harnessing the band’s death metal past in an eight-minute anthem. The aforementioned ""Leave No Cross Unturned""
column14: the disc's 14-minute finale and the longest song ever in the Darkthrone catalog
column15: confirms the band’s gumption to simply go for anything. They hint at Saxon and Maiden with operatic vocals and an incredibly sharp hook and then at punk with the blissfully simple but successful outro. What’s more
column16: Fenriz and Nocturnal Culto even circle back toward their weighty black metal reputation with the blanket of serrated guitars near the song’s start. A few minutes later
column17: Fenriz howls from some deep abyss. In turn
column18: they leave no relevant idea unturned.

column1: Fenriz and Nocturno Culto own one of the great unimpeachable brands in all of heavy metal
column2: and they've protected it not by limiting it but by letting it expand and fluctuate as need be. Rather than retread what's made them famous
column3: Darkthrone have continually confirmed their status by refusing to kowtow to old expectations. They don't play live
column4: and they don't depend on this band for their income; therefore
column5: they don’t need this band to sound like it did it 1993 so they can cash in on the past rather than risk their image on the present. Amid tides of ceaseless band reunions and reissues that more often than not repeat what we already knew
column6: Darkthrone in 2013 find themselves in an extremely enviable position because they have done exactly what they've wanted. Legends encumbered by being legends
column7:
they stick true to the title of The Underground Resistance-- they are two veterans having fun by continuing to play like they're carefree teenage rebels. 

"|17642.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17642-darkthrone-the-underground-resistance/|7.4|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18902/homepage_large.88e2c6e3.jpg|Velvet Changes|29336.0|Dog Bite|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Carpark']|2013-02-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:12.050344|"

Amid the flurry of chatter inspired by the sudden release of the first My Bloody Valentine album in 22 years earlier this month was half-serious speculation about how m b v would affect the legion of indie bands still drafting in Loveless' jet stream all these decades later. Now that Kevin Shields was ""back"" orchestrating perfect storms of ugliness and beauty
column2: would it put dozens
column3: if not hundreds
column4: of ineffectual faux­-gazer outfits out of business? The answer is: not exactly. But it does put records like Dog Bite's new Velvet Changes in a fresh
column5: not-so-flattering perspective.

column1: Dog Bite is an Atlanta-based group fronted by Phil Jones
column2: an artist and musician whose most notable gig to date is playing keyboards in Washed Out's touring band. On his own in Dog Bite (which includes members of Mood Rings
column3: Balkans
column4: and Red Sea)
column5: Jones applies a chillwave sensibility to the late 80s/early 90s reverbed-out dream-pop template. The songs on Velvet Changes unfold more or less as expected: The tempos are languid
column6: the guitars are chiming and luminous
column7: the bass lines are melodic though not particularly forceful
column8: and the drumming is tepid. Dog Bite fetishizes iconic sounds without investing them with any of the transcendent emotion-- be it fury
column9: sorrow
column10: exhilaration
column11: or a mix of all three-- normally associated with those sounds. What Velvet Changes offers instead of genuine feeling is superficial prettiness that reads as callow once you venture an inch deep into the murk.

column1: The album-opening ""Forever
column2: Until"" putters forward on a moderately brisk rhythm guitar strum
column3: which contrasts with Jones' expressionless
column4: soporific vocal. The delivery of ""Forever
column5: Until"" makes it impossible to discern what exactly Jones is warbling about
column6: though by the next track
column7: the vaguely danceable ""Supersoaker
column8: this seems like a blessing. ""Hot dream/ Warm touch/ Cool bed/ You're tough
column9: Jones sings with a boyish sigh-- a nonsensical line that's especially vacuous given the drowsy musical surroundings. At least ""Native America"" has an engaging
column10: syncopated rhythm that briefly wipes the sleep out of Dog Bite's eyes. But like the rest of Velvet Changes
column11: ""Native America"" doesn't build over five minutes so much as repeat itself to the point of tedium. A lack of musical sophistication or a dearth of good songwriting-- no matter the culprit for Velvet Changes' problems
column12: Dog Bite has little to say and a severely limited vocabulary with which to say it.

column1: Aside from the rare musical flourish
column2: like the progged-out synth that squiggles its way into the back half of ""Prettiest Pills""
column3: Velvet Changes is one long
column4: predictable drone. The classic records that inspired Dog Bite specialize in creating an air of mystery that draws you deeper into the music and your own heart. All Velvet Changes creates is a disquieting malaise that deflects any attempt to penetrate its billowy
column5: monochromatic
column6:
meaningless contours.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18827/homepage_large.d0a96856.jpg|Jamie Lidell|2475.0|Jamie Lidell|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2013-02-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:12.593155|"

Jamie Lidell in traditionalist blue-eyed soul mode can be good; Jim is still a fine record to sink into on a weekend afternoon. But he shines when he really pushes things
column2: playing up the unpredictable smooth-yet-sharp timbre of his voice and pitting it against a deviation of R&B that's not quite beholden to a specific style. When Jamie Lidell's lead single ""What a Shame"" debuted last fall
column3: it was an encouraging bellwether
column4: a bristling fusion of current dance and R&B trends that lurched and pulsed like crossover dubstep used to a few years before the EDM craze enlisted it in the loudness wars. ""What a Shame"" did what great alt pop should do: sound radio-friendly while not entirely sounding like much else on the radio.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: most of Jamie Lidell sounds like everything else on the radio-- more specifically
column3: those transmissions hanging 25 light years out in space that are still beaming signals from 1988. And while there are worse sins than aiming for a faithful recreation of every Reagan baby's favorite rollerskate jams and almost succeeding
column4: there's also a failure to distinguish itself from the precedents it pays tribute to-- a simulation that's almost instantly forgettable
column5: especially in the wake of adventurous oddity Compass. Everything that makes Lidell unique is buried under a fog of spot-the-reference touchstones
column6: a predictable pop funk pastiche that points towards the obvious forerunners-- the Minneapolis sound of Prince and Jam/Lewis; In Square Circle Stevie; red codpiece-era Cameo-- but doesn't do much to expand on the form.

column1: Not that this keeps him from cranking out a couple decent songs. ""So Cold"" has this spaced-out The Love Below outtake feel to it that builds from a wounded
column2: disoriented intro into a frost-covered sheen of hazy boogie funk
column3: and its terse yet anxious keyboard solo is the liveliest moment on the record. The New Jack Swing mutation of ""In Your Mind"" is deconstructive without being smarmy about it; slightly off-kilter synths and burbly digital bass run interference
column4: but energize the backbeat instead of derailing it. Sadly
column5: there's little else that sticks in the compositions
column6: which seem to play it safe compared to the borderline iconoclastic 80s funk homages like Multiply's ""When I Come Back Around"" or ""I Wanna Be Your Telephone"" from Compass. Most of this could remind veteran R&B fans that they'd be better off listening to actual solo Roger Troutman (""Do Yourself a Faver"") or Running Scared soundtrack Michael McDonald (""Big Love"") than blurry Xeroxes. And considering how similar tributes to the same era from mainstream R&B and pop figures ranging from Ne-Yo to Timberlake to the-Dream have been a standard ploy for years
column7: it only stands out that much more just how risky this stuff isn't. Who's up for a po-faced version of Chromeo?

column1: But that's only half of the problem. The other
column2: inseparable half is Lidell's voice-- less taking an adventurous approach to the sincere self-awareness of his limitations than a workmanlike take on sub-Jamiroquai all-surface singing. Half the time
column3: he's flat and affectless
column4: like he's skimming the lyric sheet waiting for something interesting to sing. And three-quarters of that time
column5: he's also inarticulate
column6: pulling the mix over his voice like a muffler and enunciating like he's burned the roof of his mouth. The titular hook to ""Big Love"" becomes more indistinct as it goes on
column7: ending up something like ""bee luh."" And while overdubs and multitracks draw some attention-getting melodic qualities from his voice
column8: they also muddle it into distorted mush-- though it's not as ill-advised as the downpitched adenoidal Dixieland goof ""why_ya_why""
column9: which is the cruelest parody of Cee-Lo ever recorded whether it means to be or not. If there were deep personal insights trapped inside that garbled diction
column10: it might be worth it
column11: but given all the flat cliches (a typical example from ""Blaming Something"": ""There's always a price to pay/ For all that runnin' away"")
column12: it's not worth straining your ears.

column1: The shame of it is that somewhere in here there's an album that could've done more to revive the mostly moribund idea of 80s pop tropes in contemporary music. As a producer and musician with an ear for what sounds good as pure timbre
column2: Lidell has previously shown a gift for pulling all the updated sonic potential from decades-old ideas. That retrofitting occasionally gets over the novelty of dealing with the past here and there on this record
column3: and sparsely draws on his history of IDM tinkering to give it some subtly strange qualities. But it's not enough to keep Jamie Lidell from disappointing anonymity. Most of the time I tried to remember a song 15 minutes after hearing it
column4: I got the Whispers or Alexander O'Neal stuck inside my head instead. That's a nice thing for a mediocre album to do
column5:
but a letdown from someone who isn't a mediocre artist.

"|17628.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17628-jamie-lidell-jamie-lidell/|5.6|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18829/homepage_large.a76d58cb.jpg|The Marriage of True Minds|980.0|Matmos|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-02-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:13.158106|"

Matmos has made a career-long game of devising increasingly outre frameworks for its records. Half the fun of any new Matmos album
column2: in fact
column3: is in discovering its motivational concept: examination of the sounds of an operating table
column4: for example
column5: or the folk music of the Civil War. And yet the conceit for The Marriage of True Minds
column6: their ninth full-length
column7: just might top them all; if its hypothesis were true
column8: you would hardly need this review to tell you what to expect of it
column9: because you would already know.

column1: Briefly: The members of Matmos
column2: Drew Daniel and Martin Schmidt
column3: conducted parapsychological experiments on a series of test subjects that sound oddly similar to those from the opening scene of Ghostbusters: They attempted to telepathically communicate their intentions for this record to their subjects
column4: who then reported any images or sounds they thought they received. Their input is woven inventively throughout True Minds; On ""In Search of a Lost Faculty""
column5: you can hear these participants struggling to describe visions of triangles (a startling number of them report having received images of triangles
column6: actually) while Daniel and Schmidt surround them with ringing chimes. The concept seems designed for ethereal
column7: mystical music
column8: but Matmos doesn't really do ethereal or mystical: The Marriage of True Minds hits harder and feels more joyfully physical than anything Matmos has done in years.

column1: Daniel and Schmidt sometimes give off the impression that they are eggheads
column2: forensic scientists of sound
column3: but Matmos' music
column4: at its best
column5: has always been fun
column6: and The Marriage of True Minds is no exception. With some judicious excisions of its scary and disturbing parts
column7: most of it would make an excellent soundtrack for a kindergarten classroom. ""Very Large Green Triangles"" starts out with some heavy
column8: irregular stomping
column9: transitions into some four-on-the-floor pummeling
column10: and then lurches to an abrupt halt as if signaled by a cartoon traffic cop's hand. ""Mental Radio""
column11: with its sploshing puddle sounds and clattering layers of percussion
column12: sounds like a conga line sent across across a wet
column13: dirty subway platform. ""Ross Transcript"" opens with the sound of a radio flitting between stations
column14: landing briefly on a syrupy bit of Muzak before plowing forward
column15: cycling through a menagerie of funny sounds
column16: including baaing sheep and babbling
column17: indignant chatter seemingly recorded on the planet Tatooine.

column1: There are still occasional bursts of discomfort-- Daniel and Schmidt have cast-iron stomach for cringe-inducing sounds
column2: and it wouldn't be a Matmos album if you didn't occasionally wince. The dry
column3: squeaky violin that briefly saws away on ""You"" hits the ear like a dentist scraper touching an exposed nerve ending. ""Ross Transcript""
column4: in addition to the funny noises described above
column5: also samples a bit of what sounds a lot like choking and spluttering. Their music has always had an antic
column6: morbid cast to it
column7: like a Grimm's fairy tale with all the ghoulish aspects slightly accentuated
column8: and The Marriage of True Minds is maybe the most confident they've ever been at balancing the two sides of this equation.

column1: There are many songs on this album
column2: for instance
column3: that you could actually dance to
column4: rather than just think about doing so. The stomping
column5: crunching
column6: tactile feast of itching guitars
column7: hand claps
column8: and zooming interstellar synths that is ""Tunnel""
column9: for instance
column10: is an NYC no-wave disco done as a splatter painting. ""E.S.P."" starts out with a parodic
column11: goofy recitation of the lyrics to the Buzzcocks' song ""E.S.P."" in growling
column12: black-metal style. Then
column13: after thrashing through some doomy down-tuned metal guitars
column14: it lifts off into a fizzy
column15: joyful coda
column16: a hootenanny swarmed by genetically engineered fireflies. I didn't make the connection to the Buzzcocks song until the fourth or fifth listen
column17: as I was too absorbed in the music itself. The best compliment you can pay Matmos' music
column18: then and now
column19: remains that in the moment
column20:
it didn't matter to me in the slightest.

"|17630.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17630-matmos-the-marriage-of-true-minds/|7.5|Jayson Greene

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18674/homepage_large.ccf8a276.jpg|Flume|30917.0|Flume|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Transgressive'
column2: 'Mom & Pop'
column3:
'Future Classic']|2013-02-22 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:01:13.775107|"

In an interview with Dazed Digital last year
column4: Australian beatmaker Flume said
column5: ""Music essentially boils down to two main elements
column6: rhythm and melody. I feel tones and textures often get overlooked
column7: so I like to take my time finding the right sounds."" The approach is working for the unassuming 21-year-old musician
column8: otherwise known as Harley Streten: In November
column9: his self-titled debut album and its single ""Sleepless"" beat One Direction for the number one position on Australia's charts. Streten celebrated by posting screenshots of the ensuing Twitter outrage.

column1: He doesn't come off as a firestarter
column2: though
column3: or even all that different from other young electronic producers. He listens to J Dilla and Flying Lotus
column4: started tinkering with production when he was barely a teenager
column5: and still makes music in his parents' basement. While his approach to warped sound owes much to Dilla
column6: Flume's aesthetic can be compared to SBTRKT's integration of R&B's bedside intimacy with distant beats and silky voiced female singers.

column1: Streten explores his sonic palette with varying degrees of success on Flume. It's a little long on instrumental filler (""Space Cadet""
column2: ""Warm Thoughts""
column3: ""Ezra"")
column4: highlighting the fact that at this point in his career
column5: samples and singers are Streten's most effective asset. Those features mask the fact that most of his songs are structured around samey
column6: distracting background swoops that introduce climactic moments.

column1: On ""Sleepless""
column2: singer/model Jezzabell Doran is Streten's Jessie Ware
column3: though he gives George Maple more of the spotlight on ""Bring You Down"". Her featherlight refrain ""Hush now
column4: you're standing on a landmine"" is the centerpiece around which snares skitter and arpeggios twinkle
column5: her voice soaring as Streten drops a judicious beat into the bridge. On ""Insane""
column6: Streten distorts Australian singer Moon Holiday's lovely but affectless voice into a melodic foil to his throbbing builds and drops. Sometimes
column7: neither the vocals nor backing can save the show: ""On Top"" features uninspired rapping from New York MC T.Shirt (""The night's forever young/ It's us that gets old"") that falls flat over offbeat thuds and simulated siren wails.

column1: Now and then
column2: Streten strikes an unusually potent streak: On ""Left Alone""
column3: a chorus persists throughout as if dogging guest Chet Faker's slurred pleas for solitude. Preceding track ""Holdin' On"" juxtaposes an old-soul male vocal sample and gospel echoes (""Mama
column4: I love you!"" ""Yes I do!"")  with muffled keyboard stabs and serious swing for an effect that recalls Jamie xx's Gil Scott-Heron remixes. Sinuous opener ""Sintra"" chops up vocals like James Blake's ""CMYK""
column5: a foil for the calming
column6: sweet ""Star Eyes""
column7: which closes the album with a dream sequence made up of screwed bits of speech. On ""What You Need""
column8: Streten makes a claim-- ""Been waiting to love you/ ... I've got what you need""-- shiver so that it sounds like she's slowly dissolving into tears. With that kind of control over his songs and performers
column9:
Flume could easily evolve into a sought-after producer.

"|17484.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17484-flume-flume/|7.4|Harley Brown

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18773/homepage_large.e032cfb2.jpg|Saal|29808.0|Serengeti|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Graveface']|2013-02-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:14.387659|"

Serengeti has often tended towards extreme sadness in his music-- on his last record C.A.R.
column2: David Cohn ended one song by desperately screaming
column3: ""We're not immortal"" over and over again-- but it's possible that his new album Saal is his most despairing yet. Sometimes that despair is dressed up in the stories of other people or in a brittle sarcasm. Sometimes it's just lain bare over the track
column4: raw as hell and occasionally downright uncomfortable.

column1: Saal was recorded early last year in Bonn
column2: Germany and you can feel how the distance freed the Chicago native up to experiment with form as he moves from faux-bright folk songs into downbeat monologue. He's always straddled the boundary between rapping and spoken word poetry
column3: but here he's part spoken word poet
column4: part folk singer. He sings more often than he raps
column5: and delivers loose
column6: sloping verses when he's not singing. The shift isn't unpleasant-- 'Geti has a decent voice and he doesn't oversing or strain himself.

column1: The production is unusually ornate
column2: entirely supplied by Tobias ""Sicker Man"" Vethake
column3: an experimental musician with a background in classical cello. In his own work
column4: Vethake combines the structure of pop and the instrumention of classical music to create short
column5: formalized studies in sound. (His cover of ""Party Rock Anthem"" is worth a listen.) On <i>Saal
column6: he uses violins
column7: cellos
column8: bells
column9: and all other manner of classical instruments to construct unwieldy soundscapes for 'Geti to travel through. The beats are consistently surprising-- coherent and steady one moment
column10: and filled with static the next-- and they complement Geti's off-kilter musings nicely.

column1: The opener ""Karate
column2: finds the two musicians working in perfect tandem. It's an expertly constructed folk song that layers spoken verses and a sung hook atop a mournful cello. The story focuses on two characters
column3: Charles and an unnamed older woman
column4: who are stuck with each other. Finely wrought details set the scene in the first verse: ""Coin collections
column5: camcorders
column6: and silverware/ Strangulations
column7: police card on the au pair."" There's clearly been some kind of catastrophe in Charles' life
column8: but the immediate tragedy soon gives way to something worse. The woman he's stuck with has lost her own son and she takes it out on Charles: the first line of the hook is ""and her strength overwhelmed his karate."" It's dark yet effective
column9: using the image of a boy helplessly trying to use karate to drive home the idea of innocence lost in a hurry.

column1: Some of the songs here are even more subtle. ""Accommodating""
column2: on which Serengeti channels the Mark Oliver Everett of <i>Electro-Shock Blues
column3: starts off sounding like a cute little song about wanting to do something for someone who always does things for you. But as Geti rattles off some of the ways that he would like to accommodate the person in question
column4: you notice a pattern. He wants to
column5: amongst other things
column6: help the anonymous ""lose some weight and learn to eat right
column7: ""make cologne
column8: and ""extract your own pheromones."" He's interested in making the person more sexually attractive
column9: which
column10: of course
column11: would just be way of accommodating himself again.

column1: These clever little songs
column2: on which dark thoughts are given costumes and animated by wit
column3: are the most enjoyable parts of Saal. Later in the record
column4: 'Geti gets blunter
column5: and the results can be unnerving. ""Divorce is the new wedding
column6: stop is the new start
column7: he claims on ""Glassell Park"". Following that train of thought
column8: ""Wedding"" is a painfully sad dirge which finds him attending an ex's wedding
column9: still trying to get her to sleep with him. The bonus track ""Queen Wasn't Content"" is clearest of all: ""Every now and then I can't stop crying/ If there's a God then he must not know me/ Hasn't even taken a glance this way."" There's nothing bad about these songs
column10: but their unsparing melancholy leaves craft behind
column11: the writing forsaking artistry in the name of clear expression.

column1: All this darkness will serve as relief for listeners of a certain mindset. Saal isn't meant for a casual listen and is probably best played without any company around-- it's serious
column2: overstated
column3:
and unavoidably heavy. But the album makes for an understanding companion if you're all alone and having a really terrible night.

"|17579.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17579-serengeti-saal/|6.3|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18803/homepage_large.f655b523.jpg|Rough Carpenters|30992.0|Black Twig Pickers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-02-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:15.035347|"

There's a paradox that sets the Black Twig Pickers apart from their peers. The acoustic quartet plays songs particular to the region they call home
column2: the mountainous stretch that extends from North Carolina upward into West Virginia and Kentucky. They've learned their tunes by seeking out old-timers and their extant kin
column3: by reading the histories and joining in song circles and all-night jams. Musicians regularly gather in their droves to do exactly that with many of these songs
column4: but the Pickers are a thoroughly modern old-time band.

column1: The Pickers' draw to these antediluvian songs seems simply to be the music itself
column2: rather than its aesthetic. They've repudiated fellow acoustic travelers who dress in period costumes
column3: and they don't pretend to be genre purists
column4: confessing in recent interviews to interests in Lil B and Terry Riley
column5: Junior Kimbrough and the Fall. They backed Jack Rose on the monumental Luck in the Valley
column6: while the group's young banjo player
column7: Nathan Bowles
column8: and their research-driven leader Mike Gangloff
column9: play in Pelt
column10: the brilliant Appalachia acoustic drone ensemble. They are also one of the rare string bands to work with a record label that's associated with indie rock; their relationship with Chicago's forever-interesting Thrill Jockey affords them access to new sets of listeners
column11: but it also confirms their proclivity for breaking from their scene's often-cloistered ranks. Students and teachers
column12: gatherers and conveyors
column13: Black Twig Pickers know that the survival-- and especially vitality-- of this American folk form depends upon pushing it past its regional strongholds.

column1: Rough Carpenters is the latest in an impressive string of Black Twig Pickers full-lengths; it's the swiftest
column2: too
column3: as its 45 minutes feel much shorter thanks to the enthusiasm of the gamboling quartet. Excepting a two-song experiment from late last year
column4: it is also the first to integrate fiddler and dancer Sally Anne Morgan. Appropriately
column5: the band met Morgan at a late-night house party of pickers and listeners in Virginia
column6: later reconnecting with her at a political rally in the mountains of Kentucky. Her contribution is key here
column7: as the Pickers spend almost half of Carpenters working through one instrumental configuration that hinges upon her addition-- fiddles in complementary tunings
column8: accompanied by the quick flick of Bowles' rhythm-inclined banjo and guitarist Isak Howell's heavy and brisk strums. During ""Where the Whippoorwills are Whispering Goodnight""
column9: for instance
column10: she and Gangloff sing to one another with a fetchingly bittersweet tone
column11: telling the tale of this Charlie Poole favorite without saying a word. During ""Charleston Girls""
column12: they play with the intoxicated euphoria of two red-faced lovers cycling round and round on the dance floor
column13: all excitable and lusty.

column1: Morgan's second fiddle has added more flexibility to an already-versatile outfit
column2: a characteristic that Rough Carpenters makes remarkably clear: As Gangloff bows the theme of ""Little Rose""
column3: Bowles bangs across the fiddle's neck with chopsticks
column4: eliciting the rhythmic melodies of a hammered dulcimer on a budget. Howell adds harmonica on ""Banks of the Arkansas""
column5: lending a bit of depth to a thin song from the wings by countering the lithe melody of the twin fiddles and the steady banjo-guitar trot. It's the sort of smart textural addition you'll barely notice but that you'd certainly miss if it had never been there. The fiddles even take a turn for themselves on ""Old Christmas Morning""
column6: their strings and bows emitting white-hot streaks of radiant abrasion when Gangloff and Morgan pull against the melody.

column1: This time out
column2: the Pickers-- a group whose vocals have generally functioned better live than on tape-- even connect by voice. Consecutive cuts ""Roll on John"" and ""Jack of Diamonds"" feature some of the band's best singing to date: Howell keens high and lonesome during the latter
column3: while Morgan chases his words on the former with casual charm
column4: as if she's the mockingbird teasing the poor man's lament. Howell does get swallowed a bit by the title cut
column5: but the song finds its sparks in the banjo harmonies of Bowles and Gangloff. They put the tinny stereotype to rest at once
column6: weaving a web that sounds somehow lush-- maybe not the first word that comes to mind when one considers the five-string punchline. The Black Twig Pickers
column7: after all
column8: continue to confound expectations for such ancestral acts
column9: even as they expand their erudition within and embrace of the canon itself. Rough Carpenters sounds vibrant and enveloping
column10:
an old-time feat for these mercurial times.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18895/homepage_large.17fef760.jpg|For Professional Use Only|29765.0|AraabMuzik|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-02-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:15.573593|"

Forget the title of AraabMuzik's new mixtape and look at the cover for a second. That's the producer/DJ/MPC wizard rocking the Sahara Tent at Coachella last year: It was not only one of the wildest shows I had the pleasure of witnessing in 2012
column2: it was the culmination of one of the strangest career arcs in recent memory. If you initially viewed Abraham Orellana's 2011 breakthrough Electronic Dream as a hip-hop producer making an instrumental record
column3: it did what it was meant to-- it got Araab a lot more work. But as word spread about the extent of his talents
column4: Electronic Dream became a preview of his must-see live sets
column5: which translated to festival stages whether they primarily trafficked in EDM
column6: hip-hop
column7: or indie rock. Despite not being the ""official"" follow-up to Electronic Dream (there was also last year's collection of stray beats
column8: Instrumental University)
column9: For Professional Use Only feels like it's trying to reflect Araab's current status: It's bigger
column10: bolder
column11: and more ambitious than its predecessor. But the impact works in reverse-- it's meant as a souvenir for Araab's live sets while having the unexpected effect of showing his range as a producer rather than a performer.

column1: Of course
column2: the obvious question is how For Professional Use Only can truly recreate the live experience without the visuals. There is undoubtedly a wow factor to seeing Araab perform
column3: as he breaks down the last line of rockist defense against ""this music works better live
column4: i.e.
column5: ""he's just pushing buttons."" Which
column6: hell yes he's pushing buttons. But the guy is about moving bodies for an hour at a time
column7: not just dropping jaws in one-minute stretches. Even without his ""you are listening to AraabMuzik"" tag
column8: he does have audio tricks that let you know it's him. He hasn't altered his approach in any significant way here; it's still punishing beats that repeat every four bars and jagged
column9: spazz-out synth lines that are loud as fuck
column10: most things that people find either attractive or repulsive about the EDM kings that have welcomed Araab and vice versa. It's also cut with short passages of twinkly MDMA rap that evoke the moment your drug of choice kicks in and you get to enjoy the high rather than the increasing buzz. There's plenty of moments where Araab revisits such ideas from Electronic Dream (""Never Have To Worry""
column11: ""Turn Tha Tide"")
column12: and it can still be powerful in proper doses.

column1: On the whole
column2: though
column3: Professional Use feels more based in hip-hop than Electronic Dream
column4: in tune with Araab's physical movements when he's not going hundred-hand slap on the MPC; it's typically him in an exaggerated
column5: full-body headknock. It's interesting how much of it recalls late-90s Ruff Ryders considering that crew's willingness to act as a counterbalance to hip-hop's obsession with ecstasy and shiny suits; you hear the rudimentary tones of early Swizz Beatz in ""Street Knock""
column6: while ""G Riding"" comes close to quoting the chunky old-school drumbreak of ""I'm A Hustla"". Elsewhere
column7: he tweaks existing templates for modern ears
column8: as ""D.R.U.G.S"" and ""So Good"" respectively apply the stylistic tics of Dr. Dre and Dilla into something cloudier. Occasionally
column9: he gets a little too overt in his beat-cribbing: ""Heaven"" could pass for any number of faux-Timbaland beats from 1999; ""Getting 2 The Point"" is standard issue Lex Luger/Young Chop and ""SUCCUBI"" is so blatant about its TNGHT envy that it has to be tongue-in-cheek.

column1: Still
column2: Araab's willingness to stretch keeps For Professional Use Only engaging throughout
column3: which is no easy task; it's 67 minutes long
column4: about 15 minutes longer than a typical festival set and probably 15 minutes more AraabMuzik than anyone needs in one sitting. I wouldn't say there are too many dead spots here-- it's just that you might not have the stamina to keep up. Araab's beats have enough melodic heft and substance that you can listen for 40 or so minutes without thinking
column5: ""Man
column6: it'd sure be nice if someone was rapping over this."" By the same token
column7: his production doesn't have the same capacity for storytelling-- whenever a track goes past three minutes
column8: there's a good chance it's overstaying its welcome.

column1: As with Electronic Dream
column2: Professional Use Only is ridiculously loud and will drive you insane on headphones. I can't think of too many acts besides Sleigh Bells who make such explicit use of brickwalled mastering as a clear aesthetic choice
column3: and it's worth noting that you could listen to both of their albums in the time it takes to finish For Professional Use Only. Beyond the physical weariness
column4: it also limits Araab when he tries to make beats that require room to breathe
column5: such as the mid-00s Kanye fluff of ""Beauty"". You don't need any background in trance music to appreciate these songs more deeply
column6: nor do you need to be an audiophile beyond maintaining that
column7: ""if it's too loud
column8: you're too old."" If you hear For Professional Use Only and imagine it pumping out of gigantic bass bins
column9:
you ""get"" it.

Musical density can falsely suggest volume: Listening to a two-sided
column2: 40-minute
column3: wall-to-wall extreme noise record
column4: for instance

column7: each guided by its own system of verses
column8: a chorus
column9: and a bridge. For the latter

column12: and then repeating the process. But that 40-minute noise record might stuff as much sound as it can into that equivalent space

column1: Excepting their 2003 debut
column2: Vexovoid-- the fourth and most recent album from Australian heavy metal abusers Portal-- is the band's shortest full-length to date and their first to fall just to seven songs. At 35 minutes
column3: it is barely longer than your average primetime sitcom or less than a quarter of the music rock'n'roll votary Ty Segall released last year alone. But parsing Vexovoid
column4: Portal's first as a quintet and first since 2009's addled and diverse Swarth
column5: should take you the better part of this calendar year. Initially forceful and ultimately complex
column6: Vexovoid redirects the image of death metal through a dervish funhouse
column7: where the expected shapes have been mutated and multiplied into orders so strange they seem surreal. Rhythms stay the course where you expect them to shift before finally switching without warning. Sharp-barbed riffs emerge from and climb above dins that once seemed irreparably unordered. Songs that
column8: for the first minute
column9: appeared to have but one aim and direction find a half-dozen new missions and vectors in a five-minute span. Hearing it all go by-- the forms flux
column10: the pieces connect
column11: the momentum volley-- provides an exhilarating
column12: bewildering sort of audio whiplash. Vexovoid is a gauntlet that
column13: to run again and again
column14: is every bit as exhilarating as it is exhausting.

column1: Portal has long tapped into sounds beyond death metal basics to warp their core
column2: with traces of doom metal and stoner rock
column3: black metal and noise rock trapped within their already-claustrophobic music. But Vexovoid eliminates the seams better than ever before
column4: with alien sounds woven perfectly into the native space. ""Orbmorphia"" splices the kind of technically daunting sprints that canonized Meshuggah into rote death metal blitzes. ""Plasm"" hammers away with similarly primal simplicity
column5: but Portal perverts it via sly embellishments-- molten waves of repetition rather than riffs that slice and flee
column6: or the slow quake of the bass rather than an ordinary game of four-string keep-up. When the drums disappear after three minutes
column7: they give way to a corrosive drone. The transition is surprising but deserved and brilliant
column8: a conclusion foreshadowed by the now-obvious maneuvers of the tune's first half. Likewise
column9: the guitars of closer ""Oblotten"" radiate grimly with the lock-step tremolo of black metal
column10: while drums boom in the distance
column11: as though industrial samples have been slingshot randomly into the frame. Hidden behind each of those percussive quakes
column12: there's a sad little riff shared between the bass and a guitar. When the cacophony finally chokes out
column13: though
column14: only that riff remains
column15: creeping quietly into nothing.

column1: Go back and trace its progression: It's the kind of detail that you might miss the first dozen times you hear Vexovoid
column2: especially if you've persevered its meticulous and merciless 35 minutes in one sitting. Such intricacy is precisely what makes Vexovoid-- a trove of interconnected themes and variations
column3: distractions and redirections
column4: barbed by the one of the heaviest bands in the genre-- so rewarding. If these 35 minutes feel like twice that
column5: it's because Portal thought through every step
column6: packed all of its ideas as tightly as possible
column7:
and left it for you to decode.
