There's an image that keeps appearing in my head while listening to Maxmillion Dunbar's second album
column2: House of Woo. It's of Andrew Field-Pickering
column3: aka Maxmillion Dunbar
column4: a balding
column5: broad-shouldered
column6: slightly round man who looks like someone capable of giving life-affirming hugs. By his own account
column7: Field-Pickering spent a lot of time making Woo while lying in a recliner
column8: looping its tracks for hours on end
column9: while his girlfriend lay in a second recliner next to him. That I don't know what his girlfriend looks like doesn't matter. What's important is the image of this man
column10: in a recliner for hours on end
column11: content with the sound of his own crisp
column12: blissful music.

column1: Like a lot of young instrumental electronic producers in 2013
column2: Field-Pickering's style sounds cherrypicked from a series of fashionable pasts
column3: never unfamiliar but not easily pigeonholed either. His love for house is obvious
column4: as is his love for the oblong swing of early 90s R&B. (He's also one half of Beautiful Swimmers
column5: who have released a handful of oddball house tracks here and there
column6: including a contribution to the Permanent Vacation label's wonderfully named If This is House I Want My Money Back Zwei.) But even at their most pounding
column7: the rhythms of Woo feel secondary to its ambience
column8: which is silvery and synthetic
column9: but plays at being organic
column10: like the weird waxy feel of a fake plant.

column1: Field-Pickering's way with sound is Woo's most enchanting feature: the pinched-balloon squeals of ""Ice Room Graffiti""
column2: the cascade of synthesized bells on ""Coins for the Canopy""
column3: the meditative refrain of ""Kangaroo""'s pale trumpets; sounds that lull the brain into some uncanny dead space where nothing quite seems real or imagined. It's tempting to write that Woo is an ambient album
column4: but ambient music tends to interact with an existing environment instead of creating a new one entirely. Woo is like a pocket jungle for and by people who never leave the city.

column1: In that sense
column2: Field-Pickering's closest points of reference are guys like Wally Badarou and Jon Hassell
column3: composers who got their start in the late 1970s making textured
column4: polyethnic art music that blended live and synthesized instruments
column5: guided more by the color of sound than structure. (Hassell once called it ""coffee-colored classical."") Field-Pickering
column6: though
column7: isn't nearly as accommodating as Hassell
column8: either in sound or vibe. Despite the hours of recliner replayability
column9: nothing on Woo is particularly plush or friendly-- instead
column10: it pushes happily into the unfamiliar
column11: hacking away at the brush
column12: disappearing into CGI shadows.

column1: Woo is more or less an extension of-- and improvement on-- the ideas explored on Field-Pickering's debut
column2:
2010's Cool Water. His curse is that he's making music in a field of alt-electronic bedroom producers both totally divorced from pop music and yet overcrowded with some of the most rote and uncreative musical minds imaginable. His gift is that he isn't one of them.

Neil Hagerty has been doing a bang-up job of ensuring Royal Trux remain the one 1990s indie-rock institution that never reforms. He's reportedly turned down multiple reunion tour offers
column2: opted out of participating in Drag City's recent Trux reissue campaign
column3: and declared his utter disinterest in the prospect whenever the question pops up in interviews. His recent choice of homes-- New Mexico and
column4: currently
column5: Colorado-- keep him well insulated from music-industry machinations; Rather than stage
column6: say
column7: a Royal Trux comeback at an ATP festival
column8: Hagerty would sooner play sparsely attended weekly residencies in Denver dives. All the while
column9: he's been pushing his post-Trux outfit the Howling Hex further and further away from his previous band's bell-bottomed boogie
column10: favouring a scrappy
column11: norteño-spiced tack that
column12: since the release of 2007's XI
column13: has done away with drums altogether.

column1: Given his strident don't-look-back ethos
column2: it was something of a shock when
column3: last December
column4: Hagerty announced he would be performing Royal Trux's 1990 mind-fucking masterwork Twin Infinitives in its entirety at a New York City show
column5: albeit with an unknown female vocalist filling the high-heeled cowboy boots of Hagerty's former foil and flame
column6: Jennifer Herrema (currently of Black Bananas). This news was soon followed by the announcement of a new Howling Hex album that
column7: for the first time in six years

column10: if not outright retrace his Trux tracks

column1: But listening to The Best of the Howling Hex
column2: you're reminded not so much of Royal Trux's music as their second-most viewed YouTube video. In the infamous bootlegged clip
column3: the band -- fresh off from signing an ill-fated deal with Virgin Records in 1995-- are being subjected to one of the least glamorous aspects of major-label patronage: having to record a soul-destroying succession of station IDs for generically named local music video shows. But a funny thing happens on the way to Alternavision: while Herrema's disdain for the process intensifies with each cigarette puff
column4: Hagerty gets really into it
column5: and becomes increasingly obsessed with getting each take just right
column6: giving his partner instructions with the fussy impatience of a movie director running over-budget. You get the same sense listening to The Best of the Howling Hex: the album is maddeningly repetitive to the point of seeming like some cruel joke
column7: but there's something admirable and charming about Hagerty's determination to make it work.

column1: The most hilarious thing about The Best of the Howling Hex isn't the faux greatest hits title-- the album features all new material
column2: natch-- but the fact that Hagerty recruited a new drummer only to have him play the exact same beats throughout the entire record
column3: as if he were a human Casio preset. The album cover may list eight tracks
column4: but there are really only two songs here: The slow ones play out like some bizarro reggae/polka/acid rock fusion scraped from Ween's old four-track; the fast ones keep double-time pace with cowpunk dust-ups of yore
column5: like the Meat Puppets' ""Lost"" or the Minutemen's ""Corona."" Atop both are Hagerty's circular
column6: repetitive melodies and his furious fretwork
column7: which can dazzle in any context. But rather than provide points of distinction
column8: his brain-scrambling
column9: six-string swirls are consistently mixed so low as to be overshadowed by the chintzy
column10: clipped
column11: one-note rhythm guitar accents. ""Variations on a theme"" is an understatement for what transpires here; choruses mostly follow the same patterns as the verses
column12: time changes are practically non-existent.

column1: But the album's title starts to make a little more sense if you view The Best of the Howling Hex as an ongoing process through which Hagerty is trying to refine and perfect a particular song form. As wearing as it is to hear the same arrangements over and over again
column2: the songs do get better and more engaging as the album chugs along: In this unwavering setting
column3: the subtle
column4: soothing synth line that buttresses the congenial melody of ""The General Prologue"" hits with all the splendour of a meteor shower
column5: and heralds the album's most ebullient guitar hook; by the time we reach ""Green Limousine""
column6: the Hex's default oompa-oompa gait has acquired a more frantic energy and
column7: in the process
column8: goads Hagerty into his most urgent and spirited vocal performance. And if the closing ""Trashcan Bahamas"" starts out like yet another trip to the bionic hee-haw
column9: it suddenly detours into an ascendant
column10:
arpeggiated grand finale that sees Hagerty achieve his own version of ""Beck's Bolero"". But that sense of triumph is as much as ours as it is his-- a parting reward for those of us who manage to stay sane while the songs remain the same.

Declaring a man to be a ""god-like genius"" several months shy of his 5oth birthday implies he has no more worlds left to conquer. It's been like this for Johnny Marr since before his 25th birthday
column3: when he co-wrote a couple dozen perfect pop songs with Morrissey and then departed for a series of celebrity rocker odd jobs in other people's bands (including Modest Mouse
column4: the Pretenders
column5: Talking Heads
column6: and Pet Shop Boys). To say Marr ran up the score on his legacy with the Smiths
column7: and has been treading water ever since
column8: would be reductive. But Marr has been playing with house money for as long as many of today's indie-poppers chasing ""Hand in Glove"" and ""There Is a Light That Never Goes Out"" have been alive. Johnny Marr is an institution now-- and institutions are supposed to stay in the same place
column9: right where we left them
column10: until they topple over.

column1: Marr (hopefully) has a long way to go before that happens. So
column2: now that his extended tenure as a gun for hire appears to have been put on hold
column3: he's set about making his first proper solo record
column4: The Messenger. (Marr's 2003 album with the Healers
column5: <i>Boomslang

column7: that's because it is. The Messenger is precisely the big
column8: bright
column9: jangly guitar rock LP that Smiths fans would have killed for in 1994. The record's immediately appealing ""Smiths plus 20 pounds of muscle"" sound would have fit in perfectly alongside Oasis' Definitely Maybe and the Verve's A Storm in Heaven on a typical Anglophile's CD rack 20 years ago. In 2013
column10: though
column11: The Messenger exists in its own
column12: hermetically sealed context.

column1: As Marr recently told Pitchfork
column2: The Messenger was consciously crafted to appeal to his old fans. ""I wanted it to sound effortless
column3: not like I was trying to reinvent the wheel
column4: he said. ""I'm not interested in trying to have people who might like other kinds of music follow me. I don't want to please them."" Based on this criteria
column5: The Messenger is a success. The guitar tones on this record are fantastic-- which is to say
column6: they instantly bring to mind the dense
column7: intricate
column8: and yet lightly airy riffs that Marr strummed over Morrissey's asexual witticisms in the mid-1980s. ""European Me"" is manna for Marr obsessives
column9: opening with a stuttering six-string barrage that quickly blossoms into a wondrous expanse of chiming Rickenbackers. The title track is another instant grabber
column10: marrying disco rhythms with Marr's spidery guitar over a bed of mood-setting synths. Lead-off track ""The Right Thing Right"" is pretty awesomely Smiths-like
column11: too
column12: with Johnny throwing in some frisky Keith Richards licks in for good measure.

column1: The Messenger begs to be received on its own modest terms and its pleasures-- Marr's guitar playing
column2: the no-frills production
column3: those big and cavernous choruses-- wear off after prolonged exposure. Marr is still a top-flight musician
column4: but he's not really a true solo artist. As a vocalist
column5: he's a warm if unexceptional presence; he tends to get lost inside his own immaculately constructed guitar cathedrals
column6: particularly when he has nothing to say in his lyrics. For ""I Want the Heartbeat""
column7: Marr effectively grinds a metallic bass line against his own over-amped guitar
column8: but the song's narrative about a man falling in love with a machine is a dopey metaphor for our culture's obsession with technology. In the latter half of The Messenger
column9: even Marr's playing starts to lose some of its vigor; ""Say Demesne"" is draggy
column10: late-period U2 balladry for aging Gen-Xers.

column1: The best parts of The Messenger have a sideman's sensibility; Marr is great at doodling in the margins but falters when it comes to filling up the center with substance. The result is a record that grabs your attention initially
column2: but is unlikely to hold it in the long view. Not that it matters-- Marr was a legend before this record
column3: and he'll still be one after it. The Messenger won't be included in the body of work that made Marr great
column4:
but it's a solid approximation of his strengths.

column7: few such an easy rapport with him as McCarthy. Many
column8: including Cheyenne Marie Mize and Angel Olsen
column9: counter Oldham’s studied detachment with a warm engagement
column10: which worked well on Among the Gold and Wolfroy Goes to Town
column11: respectively. But McCarthy can sound just as out there as Oldham himself; he voice is dry and husky
column12: with a subtle expressiveness very much like his. Rather than churning the kind of sexual energy that has driven so many duos from Parton/Wagoner to the Civil Wars
column13: theirs is more of a Platonic tension.

column1: In other words
column2: McCarthy and Oldham haven’t re-gendered the Everlys’ songs for co-ed vocalists. Rather than two lovers having it out in songs
column3: they sound like two friends drinking over shared memories and commiserating over separately broken hearts. Oldham is her “best unbeaten brother
column4: ” to quote his own song. With no driving interpretive concept here
column5: the focus is largely on the Everlys’ adventurous taste in songs. Most of the tunes on What the Brothers Sang hail from the 60s
column6: well after their heyday; hits are passed over in favor of deep catalogue cuts.  “Milk Train”
column7: by Tony Romeo (most famous for writing the Partridge Family’s “Hey I Think I Love You”)
column8: is told from the point of view of a train switchman; “Poems
column9: Prayers & Promises”
column10: by John Denver
column11: could be a hippie anthem
column12: which is about the furthest thing from the Everlys’ clean-cut image of the 50s. Still
column13: all of the songs on What the Brothers Sang sound like they might have sprung from the same pen
column14: bottling up all the complexities of broken hearts and presenting them with languid
column15: sophisticated country-rock arrangements.

column1: While it occasionally saps these songs of some of their tension
column2: that sense of camaraderie enlivens the album and energizes the performers. Oldham hasn’t sounded quite so animated as he does on the cover of the Everlys’ cover of the Spencer Davis Group’s cover of Jackie Edwards’ “Somebody Help Me”
column3: although even his invested
column4: in-character vocals can’t quite sell the period piece “Milk Train”. Every bit his equal
column5: McCarthy thrives in this austere setting. Without the distractions of the Faun Fables’ Americana drama
column6: she displays a remarkable range
column7: belting like the Heart sisters one minute
column8: sounding indistinguishable from Oldham the next. Still
column9: What the Brothers Sang is best when it’s simplest and most direct. “Devoted to You” and “So Sad” are all the more powerful for being so spare in their arrangements
column10: as though illustrating the power of a small country bar band. On the other hand
column11: “Omaha” has an exurban sprawl that sounds out of place among these more private meditations
column12: and the rustic psychedelica of “My Little Yellow Bird” distracts from rather than reinforces the wistful melody and the lyrics’ immense longing.

column1: Ultimately
column2: What the Brothers Sang is a tribute to what the brothers sang
column3: not necessarily how they sang it. The album’s true subjects are the many songwriters behind the Everlys-- an incredibly wide and eclectic sampling. McCarthy and Oldham wear the weight of that history lightly-- perhaps too lightly. This is a spirited album
column4: yet somehow slight. It’s a modest monument to their heroes
column5: although perhaps that is the whole point: Perhaps What the Brothers Sang is specifically intended to leave you wanting more substantial
column6:
in order to inspire listeners to dig deeper into the Everlys’ catalog and beyond.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18955/homepage_large.a2fe9495.jpg|Wrath of Caine|6310.0|Pusha T|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['GOOD']|2013-02-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:20.081001|"

As one half of the Clipse
column2: Pusha-T felt the havoc that finicky rap labels can wreak on a career; the group’s decade-long tenure is fraught with shelved albums
column3: excruciating stints in label purgatory
column4: and critically acclaimed commercial flops. When his brother Malice found religion on a sabbatical from rap
column5: Pusha’s alignment with Kanye West’s G.O.O.D. Music imprint redoubled his rap industry stock
column6: earning him name recognition
column7: chart successes
column8: and award nominations that eluded him in the Clipse. His initial solo releases were shaky
column9: though. His 2011 debut mixtape Fear of God was brittle and half-baked
column10: and while the album-length EP Fear of God II: Let Us Pray fared better
column11: it did so by cannibalizing the best songs from the mixtape and padding out its tracklist with appearances from famous guests. Nearly two years on
column12: Pusha has bested the Fear of God series with Wrath of Caine
column13: a stopgap mixtape of originals meant to tide us over until the release of his forthcoming solo album My Name Is My Name
column14: whose title quotes Marlo Stanfield of HBO’s beloved cop drama The Wire.

column1: It makes sense that Pusha-T would fixate on Marlo
column2: a ruthless drug dealer who kills his way into a higher tax bracket only to find himself at a loss for what to do with his newfound money and dominion. Pusha’s partnership with Kanye West brings stability
column3: and more importantly
column4: direct involvement in a hit parade steered by one of the best producers in the industry. For an underdog whose kingdom was built on a dealer’s twin thrusts of entrepreneurialism and danger
column5: whose displays of wealth were couched in the hard luck stories of how it was acquired
column6: to suddenly lose that underpinning of struggle is jarring. It makes for a lot of brazen talk of money. Wrath of Caine is Pusha-T coming to terms with his place in the rich asshole bracket he and Kanye detailed with “Runaway.” “Peasants ain’t sittin’ with the kings
column7: Goliath ain’t worried ‘bout your sling
column8: and Cassius ain’t bothered by your swings”
column9: he raps on “Doesn’t Matter”.

column1: Wrath of Caine’s caustic witticisms work in contrast to the gossamer production. Chief Keef associate Young Chop imbues the larger-than-life kingpin posturing of “Blocka” with pillowy low end and spectral synths
column2: with very little in between. Harry Fraud’s work on “Road Runner” and Boogz and Tapez’ “Only You Can Tell It” both warp vocal samples into massive
column3: stately productions that sound like trap music rebuttals to the seraphic grandeur of Clams Casino. Jake One serves up sedate reggae for “Take My Life”
column4: while SK and Arthur McArthur recreate the mood of reggae with swaying
column5: oceanic synths on “Trust You”. Pusha seems pretty taken with Jamaican culture lately: “Blocka” features vocals from newly minted dancehall star Popcaan and a video shot in Kingston
column6: and Wrath of Caine is peppered with spirited patois toasts from a gangster’s spoiled moll. (It’s also worth noting that “Pain”
column7: My Name Is My Name’s lead single
column8: samples the Nyabinghi drums of Rastafarian religious rituals.) It’s a fitting connection for Pusha
column9: as his own history
column10: insofar as rappers’ autobiographical tales are to be believed
column11: is a kind of winding Shottas-esque story of drugs
column12: shady business associates
column13: and unbelievably good luck.

column1: Pusha-T has navigated this improbable second act of his career with caution. His visibility is as great today as it has ever been
column2: but he moves with an astute awareness of his peculiar place as both a seasoned rap veteran and a relatively untested commercial commodity. That means playing by the rap majors’ rules
column3: keeping his buzz warm by giving away fully realized songs for free online and ceding lyrical real estate to feature artists du jour like Rick Ross and his Maybach Music Group henchmen. Wrath of Caine’s guests neither add to nor subtract from the proceedings
column4: and where he can
column5: Pusha wisely relegates them to hook duty. After Fear of God’s withering batch of middling freestyles and rangy originals and Fear of God II’s pervasive sense that the artist with top billing was a guest on his own album
column6: Wrath of Caine is really the first hint of what Pusha-T is capable of as a solo artist. He’s not really relatable anymore
column7: and hard times are distant memories rather than palpable realities
column8: but he’s still got sharp wit and snarling lyrical intensity to fall back on
column9:
and Wrath of Caine thrives off of that gritty elan.

"|17758.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17758-pusha-t-wrath-of-caine/|7.2|Craig Jenkins

column2:

In the context of Led Zeppelin’s discography
column3: III is the “soft” record. Before then
column4: Zeppelin was known as a bunch of knuckle-dragging lemon-squeezers who distorted the blues with consciousness-shifting levels of pure volume. But on <i>III
column5: they embraced acoustic instrumentation and more thoughtful songwriting. This bugged old fans
column6: but it made the band more palatable for everybody else. Portland noise-poppers Eat Skull exist in a stranger
column7: less shlong-y dimension than the mighty Zep
column8: but its latest record III similarly departs from the cacophony that precedes it. The disembodied
column9: screechy detritus floating amidst the sneakily catchy songs on the first two Eat Skull records has been pushed down low into a foreboding hum on III-- or removed altogether. It hardly seems accurate to describe III as noise-pop at all-- it’s just a straight-up pop record
column10: and a very good one at that.

column1: The first Eat Skull record in nearly four years
column2: III almost sounds like the product of an entirely different band. Eat Skull’s full-length 2008 debut Sick to Death was among the least accessible records in a spate of tinnitus-inducing indie-pop releases from the period; any hummable moments on that record quickly had buckets of acid poured on them. Eat Skull dialed back considerably on the wincing-inducing treble on 2009’s Wild and Inside
column3: veering instead toward loopy garage-rock and surprisingly sweet songcraft. But the relatively clarity of Wild is nothing compared with the fidelity upgrades made on III. With its brisk acoustic strum and angelic piano tinkling
column4: “Amnesty Box” is a curveball in Eat Skull’s catalog: it’s a song made for slow dancing
column5: and between normal people even (as opposed to Beatles-loving psychopaths). “Catch Em Before They Vanish” is another breath-taking beauty
column6: with luminous guitars rubbing gently up against each other like prime-era Built to Spill.

column1: Singer-guitarist Rob Enbom recently joked that Eat Skull listened to a lot of Phil Collins while making III-- comparing anything on this record to a No Jacket Required deep cut would be overstating things
column2: but not that much. Listening to the album-opening guitar workout “Space Academy
column3: ” it’s not difficult to spot the departure points from Eat Skull’s previous records: Enbom’s vocals are audible and affecting
column4: the song builds over the course of nearly five minutes to a killer climax
column5: and the gently rolling beat acts as the primary hook. If Eat Skull truly was studying the book of Phil
column6: it learned valuable lessons about how to build a pop song.

column1: The easy-listening aspects of III are sure to disappoint those who love Eat Skull for its in-the-red side. Thankfully
column2: the group hasn’t lost all of its weirdness. The bleary
column3: free-form synth number “How Do I Know When to Say Goodnight?” sounds like elements of three different
column4: equally strange songs bleeding in and out of each other. The fantastic “Dead Horse” intercuts the album’s bounciest melody-- which includes a recurring reference to Tommy James’ “Crimson and Clover”-- with stomach-churning imagery about “watching dead horses decompose.” Even creepier is the malevolent “Stupid Moon
column5: ” which lays a bluesy guitar lick over a low tide of dark
column6: rolling feedback before easing into the deranged sound collage “Twin Sikk Moons”. But what was once alienating and difficult in Eat Skull’s music now reads as interesting quirks attached to pleasing packages. With <i>III
column7: Eat Skull is willing to be loved-- and be loveable
column8:
too.

"|17662.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17662-eat-skull-iii/|7.4|Steven Hyden

""I want to create an island universe with another person-- either the listener or a lover-- so that we can share the same feelings and things
column2: Feeding People singer Jessie Jones said
column3: referring to the title of the California five-piece's second album. When choosing her desert island discs
column4: she wasn't exactly picky: Island Universe feeds off meandering Strange Days interludes
column5: Sabbath sludge
column6: and the loud
column7: fast riffs of Black Lips and Davila 666
column8: the band's one-time label Burger Records label mates. These disparate strands are tied together by Jones' distinctive voice
column9: but only just.

column1: Guitarist Louis Filliger writes most of the songs
column2: though their many personalities could be attributed to the way Jones performs. ""I feel like I channel other people's emotions and different unseen entities
column3: she told the OC Weekly. ""I hear inside voices
column4: she yowls on ""Inside Voices""
column5: which shifts more traditionally between tight fills and loose comedowns. ""Everybody's sick and tired of being bored."" Thankfully
column6: Feeding People don't match spiritual ennui with musical torpor; the band's volume and reckless rhythms take care of that.

column1: That's likely down to Island Universe's two distinctive producers: Hanni El Khatib is known for his electroshocking blues
column2: while Jonny Bell of Crystal Antlers specializes in more lighthearted psychedelic pop. Both styles are present in the transitions between ""Other Side""-- which accesses its friends in the ether through a neat two minutes of interlocking guitar-- the tranquil ""Island Universe"" (allegedly inspired by the classic romanticism of ""My Girl"")
column3: and the momentum-powering ""Big Mother""
column4: where Jones really unhinges her jaw
column5: as if channeling Screaming Females' Marissa Paternoster.

column1: The first half is then sealed with ""Uranium Sea"" and ""Insane""
column2: which respectively deal in pummeling riffs
column3: and invocations of the Golden State (""Cali is calling me!""). The band seems to be having the most fun here: Jones takes her time enunciating each vowel and Filliger indulges in noisy tangents with gospel-like fervor. ""The Cat Song (Secrets of Luna)""
column4: however
column5: throws a wet blanket on the beginning of the second half
column6: which struggles with an identity crisis.

column1: Backed by violins and flutes
column2: Jones' warbling on ""Cat Song"" comes off too serious
column3: especially after the hair-raising tracks that precede it. The prosaically titled album closer ""Closer"" aims for an epic build but the attempt sounds contrived rather than anthemic. Getting weird in their own way sometimes suits Feeding People best. Though it doesn't fit the album's flow
column4: ""Desert Song"" is still entertaining
column5: like an exotic dancer turning up at the wrong party
column6: although even then
column7: Jones' spoken-word tangent about desert sand
column8: cactus roses
column9: and nothingness barely works. ""Red Queen"" is a demented dirge that aspires to Page and Bonham levels of burned-out one-upmanship between Filliger and drummer Mike Reinhart.

column1: Feeding People's energy is abundant and undeniable
column2: but all over the place on Island Universe. Despite abandoning any sense of sequencing on the second half
column3: they're clearly aware of the power of a good album arc
column4: but they couldn't quite pull it together and their psychedelic compulsions can seem out of place. As it is
column5: Jones' idea about some shared emotional and spiritual paradise is lovely
column6:
but her band's directions don't make it easy to get there.

"|17759.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17759-feeding-people-island-universe/|5.9|Harley Brown

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18889/homepage_large.f921262d.jpg|Exai|168.0|Autechre|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2013-02-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:22.065991|"

Autechre neither make casual music
column2: nor do they make music casually: The English duo of Rob Brown and Sean Booth have released 11 albums under the name in the last 20 years
column3: along with a chain of EPs that have generally been as integral to their evolution as the long-players. All of those albums easily pass the one-hour hurdle; 2008's excellent Quaristice comprised 20 relatively brief tracks cut from hours of extended jamming
column4: but it still clocked in just shy of 74 minutes. In 2010
column5: the two enthusiasts offered a webcast of an exhilarating 12-hour DJ set
column6: pogoing from hip-hop and indie rock to industrial and electronica. (One short and emblematic sequence incorporated Eno and Byrne
column7: RZA
column8: Coil
column9: and Boards of Canada.) A certain charm of Autechre has always been that they love music and they love making music; even at their most clinical
column10: this zeal has remained an inherent premise.

column1: In the last decade
column2: the Manchester duo rewrote their own rules
column3: leaning on the risks of their early works until
column4: by their eighth LP Untilted
column5: it was clear that their intention was no longer simply making bodies move
column6: though that was sometimes a by-product. If Autechre's earliest records were typically classified as intelligent dance music
column7: their later efforts might best be dubbed intelligence-enabled dance music-- with eclectic touchstones absorbed and dissolved
column8: they did whatever they wanted. ""I think there's always this competitive freshness that we're trying to achieve
column9: Brown told an interviewer around the time of Quaristice's release. ""That's all there is in terms of statement or communication.""

column1: But for all their influence
column2: energy and innovation
column3: Autechre have never been very good editors. Their EPs are the length of most bands' albums
column4: while their albums run about as long as short feature films. If you hear an interesting sound or idea from Autechre
column5: you're bound to hear it again and again before a track's end. Despite their creative restlessness
column6: Brown and Booth have never been very good at moving on their music itself. These qualities dovetail to the detriment of Exai
column7: the band's eleventh record-- and
column8: by a margin of about 40 minutes
column9: its longest. Though it's often interesting
column10: Exai is insufferably exhausting
column11: a record imprisoned by the obsessions of those who made it.

column1: Five years ago
column2: in an interview with Pitchfork
column3: Brown said that the possibilities of technology had made music production intimidatingly infinite. A key to productivity
column4: he implied
column5: was setting limits and aims. ""You've got to be realistic
column6: he said. ""You can sit in front of a computer and have a blank slate and be completely overwhelmed by the possibilities and not get anywhere."" Whereas 2010's wonderfully muted and warm Oversteps found a path and followed it
column7: Exai is a behemoth devoid of focus
column8: an album on which the tough decisions about direction and
column9: later
column10: elimination have not been made. There are bass-heavy beaters that suggest the pair's earlier works
column11: and amorphous drone numbers that don't; there are glitchy sprints that chirp
column12: and menacing slogs that haunt. Just one of its 17 tracks doesn't break the four-minute mark
column13: and many slingshot between various sounds and schemes
column14: meaning that the transitions within the album and the songs themselves are weak
column15: if not nonexistent. Pieces shift into bridges that lead nowhere (""T ess xi"")
column16: suddenly mix their metaphors and mechanics (the end of ""recks on"") and wallow in aesthetic indecision (tone-setting opener ""FLeure"").

column1: There's nothing actually wrong with the sounds on Exai: Though they don't turn many new tricks
column2: Autechre have once again proven to be top-notch sonic magpies and brilliant technicians. ""Irlite (get 0)"" makes a synthesizer sound like a church organ overrun by the ghosts in the graveyard
column3: while ""T ess xi"" employs fluorescent soul keyboards as its basic building block. ""deco Loc"" turns someone's voice inside out
column4: creating beautiful textures and themes from a sound salvaged and forcibly repurposed. The drums splashed over the surface of ""Runrepik"" suggest sun-warped crunk singles. Its chaser
column6: is an industrial crucible where the ruptures of power electronics and the force of dubstep are heated until they ricochet off one another. Brown and Booth are familiar with each other's habits
column7: and wary of them
column8: too. ""T ess xi"" showcases a sort of rhythmic volleyball between the pair
column9: where several seemingly simple beats tease one another
column10: shifting so as to avoid anything so obvious as a groove. Likewise
column11: ""vekoS"" ends when its subaquatic beat surrenders slowly to a tide of overwhelming static. On an album of erratic shifts and very few segues
column12: it's a moment of impossible tension.

column1: Arguing that an album offers too much music seems passé at best
column2: entirely irrelevant at worst. Aren't records just old-fashioned methods of assembling information
column3: arbitrary holding tanks for material that could be released in online formats that don't adhere to time limitations or sequencing expectations? Possibly
column4: and perhaps Autechre is once again ahead of a curve that we barely recognize. But that doesn't solve Exai's fundamental problem: Some of its songs deserve to be cut into halves
column5: while others should have been chopped wholesale. With those snips
column6: Exai would be a really good Autechre album that summarizes the various successes of their career in an hour or so. As is
column7:
it's as much a frustrating obstacle course as it is a grueling marathon.

"|17691.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17691-autechre-exai/|5.9|Grayson Currin

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18825/homepage_large.8578de1f.jpg|Like Rats|2331.0|Mark Kozelek|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Caldo Verde']|2013-02-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:22.803454|"

""So I spent all yesterday hanging out by myself
column2: says Mark Kozelek between songs on his new live album. ""Went out last night... by myself. Spent today... by myself. It's alright. I spend a lot of time by myself."" This might be one of the more revealing moments on any Kozelek/Sun Kil Moon/Red House Painters release: a complete and pointed dismissal of any romanticism that might still cling to the touring life. Rather than carouse around Melbourne or even see the sights
column3: he admits
column4: ""I don't even know the name of the hotel I'm at. I just walked around the park
column5: went to the 7-11
column6: ate some nuts or something. I don't fucking know. I was bored out of my fucking mind.""

column1: That disappointment-- the unbridgeable rift between how you dream your life will go and how it actually turns out-- is the subject of Kozelek's most recent studio album
column2: last year's harrowing
column3: weirdly humorous Among the Leaves. Song after song bemoans the fate of a cult musician in his 40s
column4: a songwriter's songwriter who has put 20 years into a career that has leveled out
column5: who has won glowing reviews but has very little to show for it except his name on a marquee. 7-11s in Melbourne look just like 7-11s everywhere else; a bag of nuts can be the highlight of your day. Expressing his extreme weariness with the touring life
column6: Kozelek sounds better than he has in years-- more engaged
column7: more personable
column8: more observant
column9: and more willing to describe the world around him
column10: even if it tends to end at the stage lights.

column1: Live at Phoenix Public House Melbourne may be his most substantial live album in ages. It draws heavily from Among the Leaves
column2: and makes a worthy addendum to the studio recording because it places these songs in what sounds like their natural setting: a small club sparsely filled with adoring fans clapping politely even after Kozelek laments the lop-sided male: female ratio. There's a sobering gravity here
column3: a weird black humor accentuated by the relatively short run time: 12 tracks instead of Among the Leaves' 17
column4: coming in at a reasonable 60 minutes instead of 80.

column1: Kozelek's guitar playing is precise and lovely
column2: especially during the solo on ""Heron Blue""
column3: and his voice retains its hangdog eloquence
column4: effortlessly evoking his workaday loneliness on ""Broken Wing"" and the brutally candid ""Track Number 8"". Perhaps the standout on Phoenix
column5: however
column6: is the stage banter. Several of his previous live albums
column7: including last year's On Tour
column8: have excised his between-song ramblings
column9: but they sound crucial to this set
column10: a revealing counterpart to the songs. He exercises a sly humor that's at once gracious (commiserating with the staff who will lose their jobs when the Phoenix Public House closes) and biting (dedicating ""The Moderately Talented Young Woman"" to an audience member who describes herself as a musician and waitress).

column1: There's a great
column2: weird
column3: tense moment when Kozelek considers the irony of a fan who loves his music so much that he downloads it illegally. ""I'm trying to understand. So you live in Melbourne
column4: Australia
column5: and you bought my music off a Russian web site. Why? Why'd you do that?"" Kozelek sounds both touched and offended. That's the central conflict on Among the Leaves
column6: but it's even more pronounced on Live at Phoenix Public House: Kozelek is grateful for his fans' dedication over the years
column7: but on some level he resents them for leading him into such a lonely life.

column1: So maybe Like Rats is a peace offering. His previous covers albums have been fan favorites
column2: presenting his melancholy takes on songs by AC/DC
column3: John Denver
column4: Low
column5: and Stephen Sondheim
column6: but this new collection may be his most varied and adventurous. The tracklist portrays a man with broad listening habits
column7: who not only translates these songs into his own particular style but erases the distinctions between genres. ""Time is Love""
column8: a silly concept song by Josh Turner
column9: has the same rhythmic thrust as Ted Nugent's ""Free-for-All""
column10: and the Descendents' ""Silly Girl"" proves just as melodic as the snappy ""Right Back Where We Started From""
column11: the 1976 hit by UK singer Maxine Nightingale.

column1: Just as he brings these songs into his realm
column2: they expand his realm
column3: forcing him to rethink how he uses his voice and guitar. He opens Genesis' ""Carpet Crawlers"" in lush a cappella
column4: layering his vocals in a way that expresses a profound
column5: possibly narcotized wonder at the little creatures around him
column6: and the one-two punch of Bad Brains' ""I"" and Godflesh's ""Like Rats"" redirects his signature low-key sound to express something like outrage and anger-- a wholly new mode for Kozelek. On the other hand
column7: Bruno Mars' ""Young Girls"" wryly comments on all the tales of obsessive female fans on Among the Leaves
column8: and Kozelek turns the hook into a wistfully descending melody.

column1: Any record that emphasizes variety will have a few tracks that fall just outside the artist's reach; not everything works quite so well
column2: although that has more to do with song choice than execution. Despite his attempts to alter the melody
column3: Kozelek's version of Danzig's ""13"" recalls Johnny Cash's similarly acoustic yet superior version
column4: and he awkwardly truncates the Dayglo Abortions' ""I Killed Mommy""
column5: as if he can't bring himself to sing some of the more extreme lyrics. While it does sound like the ultraviolent companion to Kozelek's understated serial killer rumination ""Glenn Tipton"" (which he revives on Live at Phoenix Public House)
column6: it ultimately sounds pointless and self-indulgent
column7: intended perhaps to entertain himself more than his audience. But after so many bland hotels and anonymous convenience stores
column8:
who can blame him for making his own fun?

"|17626.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17626-mark-kozelek-live-at-phoenix-public-house-melbournelike-rats/|6.7|Stephen Deusner

1|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18824/homepage_large.292a7cf6.jpg|Live at Phoenix Public House Melbourne|2331.0|Mark Kozelek|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Caldo Verde']|2013-02-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 17:01:22.803454|"

""So I spent all yesterday hanging out by myself
column2: says Mark Kozelek between songs on his new live album. ""Went out last night... by myself. Spent today... by myself. It's alright. I spend a lot of time by myself."" This might be one of the more revealing moments on any Kozelek/Sun Kil Moon/Red House Painters release: a complete and pointed dismissal of any romanticism that might still cling to the touring life. Rather than carouse around Melbourne or even see the sights
column3: he admits
column4: ""I don't even know the name of the hotel I'm at. I just walked around the park
column5: went to the 7-11
column6: ate some nuts or something. I don't fucking know. I was bored out of my fucking mind.""

column1: That disappointment-- the unbridgeable rift between how you dream your life will go and how it actually turns out-- is the subject of Kozelek's most recent studio album
column2: last year's harrowing
column3: weirdly humorous Among the Leaves. Song after song bemoans the fate of a cult musician in his 40s
column4: a songwriter's songwriter who has put 20 years into a career that has leveled out
column5: who has won glowing reviews but has very little to show for it except his name on a marquee. 7-11s in Melbourne look just like 7-11s everywhere else; a bag of nuts can be the highlight of your day. Expressing his extreme weariness with the touring life
column6: Kozelek sounds better than he has in years-- more engaged
column7: more personable
column8: more observant
column9: and more willing to describe the world around him
column10: even if it tends to end at the stage lights.

column1: Live at Phoenix Public House Melbourne may be his most substantial live album in ages. It draws heavily from Among the Leaves
column2: and makes a worthy addendum to the studio recording because it places these songs in what sounds like their natural setting: a small club sparsely filled with adoring fans clapping politely even after Kozelek laments the lop-sided male: female ratio. There's a sobering gravity here
column3: a weird black humor accentuated by the relatively short run time: 12 tracks instead of Among the Leaves' 17
column4: coming in at a reasonable 60 minutes instead of 80.

column1: Kozelek's guitar playing is precise and lovely
column2: especially during the solo on ""Heron Blue""
column3: and his voice retains its hangdog eloquence
column4: effortlessly evoking his workaday loneliness on ""Broken Wing"" and the brutally candid ""Track Number 8"". Perhaps the standout on Phoenix
column5: however
column6: is the stage banter. Several of his previous live albums
column7: including last year's On Tour
column8: have excised his between-song ramblings
column9: but they sound crucial to this set
column10: a revealing counterpart to the songs. He exercises a sly humor that's at once gracious (commiserating with the staff who will lose their jobs when the Phoenix Public House closes) and biting (dedicating ""The Moderately Talented Young Woman"" to an audience member who describes herself as a musician and waitress).

column1: There's a great
column2: weird
column3: tense moment when Kozelek considers the irony of a fan who loves his music so much that he downloads it illegally. ""I'm trying to understand. So you live in Melbourne
column4: Australia
column5: and you bought my music off a Russian web site. Why? Why'd you do that?"" Kozelek sounds both touched and offended. That's the central conflict on Among the Leaves
column6: but it's even more pronounced on Live at Phoenix Public House: Kozelek is grateful for his fans' dedication over the years
column7: but on some level he resents them for leading him into such a lonely life.

column1: So maybe Like Rats is a peace offering. His previous covers albums have been fan favorites
column2: presenting his melancholy takes on songs by AC/DC
column3: John Denver
column4: Low
column5: and Stephen Sondheim
column6: but this new collection may be his most varied and adventurous. The tracklist portrays a man with broad listening habits
column7: who not only translates these songs into his own particular style but erases the distinctions between genres. ""Time is Love""
column8: a silly concept song by Josh Turner
column9: has the same rhythmic thrust as Ted Nugent's ""Free-for-All""
column10: and the Descendents' ""Silly Girl"" proves just as melodic as the snappy ""Right Back Where We Started From""
column11: the 1976 hit by UK singer Maxine Nightingale.

column1: Just as he brings these songs into his realm
column2: they expand his realm
column3: forcing him to rethink how he uses his voice and guitar. He opens Genesis' ""Carpet Crawlers"" in lush a cappella
column4: layering his vocals in a way that expresses a profound
column5: possibly narcotized wonder at the little creatures around him
column6: and the one-two punch of Bad Brains' ""I"" and Godflesh's ""Like Rats"" redirects his signature low-key sound to express something like outrage and anger-- a wholly new mode for Kozelek. On the other hand
column7: Bruno Mars' ""Young Girls"" wryly comments on all the tales of obsessive female fans on Among the Leaves
column8: and Kozelek turns the hook into a wistfully descending melody.

column1: Any record that emphasizes variety will have a few tracks that fall just outside the artist's reach; not everything works quite so well
column2: although that has more to do with song choice than execution. Despite his attempts to alter the melody
column3: Kozelek's version of Danzig's ""13"" recalls Johnny Cash's similarly acoustic yet superior version
column4: and he awkwardly truncates the Dayglo Abortions' ""I Killed Mommy""
column5: as if he can't bring himself to sing some of the more extreme lyrics. While it does sound like the ultraviolent companion to Kozelek's understated serial killer rumination ""Glenn Tipton"" (which he revives on Live at Phoenix Public House)
column6: it ultimately sounds pointless and self-indulgent
column7: intended perhaps to entertain himself more than his audience. But after so many bland hotels and anonymous convenience stores
column8:
who can blame him for making his own fun?

no world is Andrew and Daniel Aged's second release as inc. (formerly Teen Inc.)
column2: and it refines and improves on 2011's 3 EP. On that brief release
column3: the two L.A. producers were still trying to extract their strengths as songwriters and producers from their fixation on 1980s R&B. Two years later
column4: they've found a much more appealing comfort zone. The Ageds are producers and session players first-- they've produced and played with a handful of big names in R&B
column5: soul
column6: and pop music as well as lo-fi artist Nite Jewel-- and this approach manifests itself clearly on no world
column7: which feels like the work of studio hermits successfully dialing in on a sound. The atmospheres
column8: textures
column9: and melodies here feel drawn from a parallel universe where smooth Quiet Storm standards like ""All This Love"" or ""Secret Lovers"" were made in the ProTools era of infinite layering.

column1: Whether by plan
column2: luck
column3: or a combination of both
column4: no world finds itself in good company. Over the past 12 months
column5: sultry
column6: slow jam R&B has made an incredible comeback: Miguel's ""Adorn"" borrowed from ""Sexual Healing"" and Gregory Abbott's ""Shake You Down""
column7: and the sound found its cachet heightened with Frank Ocean's ""Thinkin' Bout You""
column8: Usher's ""Climax
column9: Jessie Ware's Devotion
column10: and the Voodoo reissue. inc. doesn't aim to duplicate the vocal abilities or striking personalities of their most skilled contemporaries
column11: instead opting for distinct scene-setting. Opening cuts ""The Place"" and ""Black Wings"" are enveloping soundscapes cloaked in velvet
column12: cut with a self-conscious air of mystery. When Andrew sings
column13: ""I feel like you've been here before
column14: it's the perfect piece of bedroom soul scene-setting: It's all about you
column15: not him
column16: wait... doesn't he know you from somewhere?

column1: Though the album is obsessed with the sound of the early 1980s
column2: the Ageds incorporate nods toward R&B's internet-fueled 21st century mutations; ""The Place"" and ""5 Days"" pull the flat
column3: skittering drum patter from Atlanta's trap-rap production playbook. The last few years' indie/R&B crossover resonates throughout the album
column4: as well
column5: with good reason. Legendary British independent 4AD is releasing no world
column6: and the grey
column7: slowly billowing guitars on ""black wings"" and the cavernous atmospherics of ""Angel"" feel like the Aged brothers' nod toward label godheads the Cocteau Twins and This Mortal Coil. Andrew's muted vocals throughout the record
column8: mixed to blend in with the production
column9: have more in common with Toro y Moi's willowy retro soul than anything currently climbing the R&B charts.

column1: Being perfectly of its time obviously doesn't mean that no world competes on the same level as their most successful contemporaries: the xx
column2: Rhye's <a href=""http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/17/arts/music/rhye-offers-a-warm-croon-wrapped-in-an-enigma.html?pagewanted=all"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">viral-era
column3: gender-twisting Sade fixation
column4: even How to Dress Well's full-on smooth-soul deconstruction. There's the sense that the duo with the purposefully generic corporate moniker
column5: the timid fixation on lower case letters
column6: and the penchant for composing songs out of genres are comfortable with their whispery anonymity
column7: which is fortunate: inc. is both faithful to its source material and clever enough to twist it into new shapes
column8: but at least for the time being
column9:
no world is unlikely to bring the Ageds out of the shadows.
